HEADLINE: The G.O.P.'s Legislative Blackmail

 BODY:
Republican Congressional leaders plan to extort political concessions as the price of meeting two budget deadlines next week. They are playing an ugly game of political coercion that will force President Clinton to accept dubious programs that he would otherwise veto or else risk endangering the Government's credit rating.
One deadline is looming on Wednesday, when the Government is expected to reach its legal limit on borrowing. There will be no instant default because current law gives the Administration a limited ability to tap trust funds to pay off bondholders. But eventually the Government will default unless Congress raises the debt ceiling. Default would be treacherous because it could unsettle capital markets and drive up interest rates on future debt, socking the taxpayers. 
 The Republicans plan to use the threat of default as a crowbar to force Mr. Clinton to accept legislation he opposes. The House and Senate passed bills yesterday that would give him what he needs, a bill to lift the debt ceiling. But they include unrelated amendments that, for example, curtail appeals by death row prisoners. They would also strip the Administration of its ability to exploit money in trust funds to avoid default in the future. Thus next month, when the new debt ceiling is reached, the President would be in an untenable position: either sign a new debt-ceiling bill sent up by Congress -- no matter how many odious amendments it might contain -- or else default.
By shackling the Administration's tools for managing debt, the bills would alter the balance of legislative power in budget negotiations. If Congress is committed to making this change, or altering other laws, it should do so through ordinary legislative means that preserve the right of the Senate to filibuster and the President to veto.
The second deadline occurs Monday, when the Administration's temporary authority to spend money on discretionary programs runs out and permanent budget bills remain tied up in committee. Government offices will have to close unless the White House and Congress pass another stopgap measure.
Here again Republican leaders are trying to force the White House into accepting irresponsible measures as the price for keeping the Government functioning. The House and Senate have passed stopgap bills to which they attached restrictions on the right of nonprofit groups that accept Federal money to engage in political advocacy, even using their private funds. These restrictions are not about balancing the budget and do not belong in bills extending the Government's budget authority. The restrictions should be forced to clear the ordinary legislative hurdles, including filibuster and veto.
Unfortunately, the Democrats' hands are not clean. They resorted to similar tactics when they controlled Congress and a Republican controlled the White House. But political blackmail is unprincipled no matter which party employs it.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Teaming Up to Sell Rembrandts
Sometimes the lines blur between the role of an auction house, traditionally a public forum, and that of a dealer, whose business is transacted in private. While auction houses have always sold works by "private treaty" (a sale in which the house finds a buyer for an artwork without putting it on the block), the lines become murkier still when a dealer and an auction house form a working relationship. 
 The latest example of such a strange pairing involves Sotheby's and Artemis, the London dealer. They have teamed up to sell an extraordinary collection of 122 Rembrandt etchings assembled by Joost R. Ritman, an Amsterdam-based manufacturer of disposable utensils for airlines. Adrian Eeles of Artemis helped Mr. Ritman form the original collection, which is why his gallery is associated with the auction.
Peter Kortenhorst, Mr. Ritman's financial adviser, said the reason he was selling his Rembrandt collection, along with a host of other objects, is that he is raising capital in an effort to reacquire his company, De Ster, which was taken over by a bank two years ago.
The etchings will be on view from tomorrow through Thursday (by appointment only) in a small annex at 411 East 76th Street in Manhattan where Sotheby's stores and exhibits art. The collection is being sold as a whole, rather than as individual etchings, by private treaty sale.
Aretmis isn't the only dealer involved with Mr. Ritman or with Sotheby's. While Sotheby's is including his jewelry, Dutch silver, 17th- and 18th-century glass and Oriental carpets in various auctions, Robert Noortman, another London dealer, is working with Sotheby's on the private treaty sale of about 20 Old Master paintings.
This isn't the first time Sotheby's has linked up with a dealer to sell important property. The best-known partnership was formed five years ago when Sotheby's joined forces with William Acquavella, the Manhattan dealer, to form Acquavella Modern Art, a subsidiary of Sotheby's Holding Company. It paid $143 million for the contents of the Pierre Matisse Gallery in Manhattan, which included about 2,300 works by such artists as Miro, Dubuffet, Giacommeti and Chagall, and has been selling the works privately since.
"I think there will be a lot more partnerships like this in the future," said Diana D. Brooks, Sotheby's chief executive officer. "We have more access to sellers."
 
 
 
Breaking Through $100 Million
 Both Sotheby's and Christie's broke the $100 million barrier for the first time since May 1990 as the week of the important Impressionist and modern art auctions ended on Wednesday night.
That evening, the Sotheby's sale scored the highest total, taking in $113.6 million, still below its estimate of $126 million to $174 million. Of the 88 works offered, 65 found buyers.
On Tuesday, the Christie's auction made less. But more of the works offered sold than at Sotheby's. The Christie's sale totaled $107.7 million. Of the 62 works offered, 55 found buyers.
Both evenings underscored the strength of the market, with more $5 million-plus works offered than in any of the last five years. Both sales had moments when it seemed as though no price was too high. At Sotheby's, van Gogh's "Thicket" (1890) sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for nearly $27 million, more than twice its $10 million high estimate.
 
 
 
Auctioneers Are Auditioning
 It hasn't been the same at Sotheby's since John Marion retired. The star auctioneer, who was also the chairman of Sotheby's in New York, left the company nearly a year ago. Filling the void hasn't been easy.
Simon de Pury, Sotheby's chairman in Europe, is now the auction house's top auctioneer. David Nash, director of Impressionist and modern art worldwide, is trying to enter the arena. Another familiar face, Diana D. Brooks, the company's chief executive, has been quietly practicing taking bids in small day sales. "My colleagues felt it was important for a top Sotheby's official here to be an auctioneer," she said. "And I am surprised to say that I love it. It's terrific to be in there with clients." She will conduct one session of the contemporary art day sales next week.
Does this mean she will begin taking the important evening sales soon? "Not for a long time, if ever," she said.
 
 
 
The Tate Wins an $80 Million GrantStrikes It Richer
 All it took was an abandoned power station and a dream for the Tate Gallery of Modern Art in London to win $80 million in lottery money from the Millennium Commission. The grant, which was announced last week, means a big leap forward for the Tate. The money is half of what is needed to transform the 100,000-square-foot Bankside Power Station on the South Bank of the Thames into London's first museum of modern art. It will be the first national gallery to be built in Britain since the 19th century.
"Just as the Pompidou Center has successfully attracted visitors to Paris, the regeneration of Bankside will create a new public facility south of the Thames and revitalize the surrounding area," said Virginia Bottomley, the chairman of the Millennium Commission.
By the rules of the lottery, the Tate has to match the $80 million, which it plans to do by raising funds from private sources. "We're hopeful we will be able to announce final commitments from some donors over the next three months," said Nicholas Serota, the Tate's director.
Mr. Serota said he had known that the Tate was a leading contender before the lottery grant, but that he had been nervous before the announcement because of recent public opposition to spending lottery proceeds on projects perceived as elitist. "That we are creating something entirely new helped," he said. "So did the fact that this project will help to regenerate a whole area of London." The new museum is expected to create 650 jobs in the borough of Southwark, generating about $75 million in economic activity each year. Tate's existing Millbank building is to become the Tate Gallery of British Art, showing works from the Renaissance to the present.

HEADLINE: Alaska Legislators' Oil Vow Gets Different Play at Home

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Nov. 10

 BODY:
In trying to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling, Congress is banking on a promise from Alaska political leaders that all money earned from oil leasing will be split evenly between the state of Alaska and the Federal Government.
But members of Alaska's powerful Congressional delegation, all Republicans, have been saying one thing in Washington and quite another back home. The lawmakers have told their constituents that the promise of a 50-50 split is a ploy to win approval in Congress. Once the refuge is opened, they said, Alaskans will sue to get 90 percent of the royalties. 
 A successful suit would undermine Congress's main justification for allowing oil and gas drilling in the refuge, which President Clinton has vowed to protect. Oil development in the refuge was added as a rider to the Congressional budget resolution on the ground that the billions earned from leasing would significantly help to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
As the differing interpretations have come to light in the last week, Alaska's political leaders have scrambled to explain themselves.
"I misspoke about my position," Representative Don Young said in a letter to Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia. If there is no 50-50 split, Mr. Gingrich has said, there will be no development deal in the refuge, a 19 million-acre home for caribou, grizzly bears and innumerable other species.
Mr. Young was referring to a statement he made in an Alaska radio broadcast last week in which he said: "My decision has been all along that, all right, we'll take the 50-50 and then we'll go after the rest of it at a later time. If necessary, we'll do it through the court system."
Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska made similar remarks several months ago. Talking to reporters in Alaska, Mr. Stevens said that oil drilling should move ahead on the promise of the 50-50 split but that "once the state actually receives less than 90 percent -- then we can sue."
The lawmakers now say they do not plan a lawsuit, and they promise to share the oil revenues evenly with the rest of the United States. But it may not matter what their new position is. The 1959 Alaska Statehood Act, which
brought the 49th state into the union, clearly says that Alaskans will receive 90 percent of royalties from any lease of Federal land.
The only way to insure the 50-50 split is to amend the state compact through a vote of the people of Alaska or the State Legislature. Given Alaskan dependence on oil windfalls, it is far from certain that such a radical departure from the way the state now shares oil money would be approved. This year, each man, woman and child in Alaska received a dividend check of $990 from the state's oil revenue. The state does not have sales or income taxes.
"I would say it's very much up in the air," said Fritz Pettyjohn, an Anchorage lawyer and former legislator active in the conservative wing of the state's Republican Party. "A lot of people just aren't ready to give up that much of what they feel is rightfully theirs."
Mr. Young, while telling Speaker Gingrich that Alaska will agree to give up its 90-10 share rather than lose the chance for any new royalties, has expressed doubt at home about the outcome. "I do, frankly, think there will be people who will go to court over it and eventually win this issue and this argument," he said in the radio interview.
Mr. Young, chairman of the House Resources Committee, refused to talk to a reporter on Thursday about his remarks last week. His chief of staff, Dan Kish, said, "He put his foot in his mouth and misspoke." Mr. Kish said Mr. Young stood by the promise of a 50-50 split.
Gov. Tony Knowles of Alaska, a Democrat, said he thought he could persuade the Legislature to change the statehood compact when it met in January. But without the change, the effort by Congress to open the Arctic refuge would be dead, Mr. Knowles said.
In Congress, some lawmakers say the comments by members of the Alaskan delegation show that the Republican leadership was misled. Congress was expecting to receive half of about $2.6 billion from the initial seven-year oil leases. That money was to be used to balance the the Federal budget.
But if the 90-10 split is enforced, then only about $260 million would go to the Federal Government and the rest would go to Alaska. Those numbers also reflect an estimate of oil prices that are much higher than many economists predict.
Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who opposes drilling in the refuge, said, "What this shows is that the Alaska delegation made a promise to Congress that they can't keep, and is completely unenforceable."
Representative Scott L. Klug, Republican of Wisconsin, is leading a group of House Republicans who have asked Mr. Gingrich to strip the Arctic oil drilling rider from the budget reconciliation bill, a blueprint for Federal spending over the next seven years.
"Very serious doubts have been raised about the total funding that would be made available to the Treasury from the proposed leases," Mr. Klug wrote in a letter to Mr. Gingrich last week; the letter was co-signed by Representative Bruce F. Vento, Democrat of Minnesota.
The Arctic refuge has shaped up as one of the major environmental battles of this Congress. President Clinton has said he will veto the budget bill if it has the provision to allow drilling in the refuge. His supporters view it as an appeal to the majority of Americans, who, according to recent polls, are uneasy about Congressional efforts to roll back environmental protection.
Environmentalists say drilling would cause irreparable harm to the refuge, where huge caribou herds provide food for the native Gwich'in people. Supporters say the drilling, which would take place on the bleak northern plains, can be done with minimal damage to the environment.
In Alaska, oil drilling has broad support, and many people would rather take their chances on the election in 1996 of a more development-minded Republican President than give up their 90 percent share of oil riches.
"Quite frankly, there's a big argument going on within the Republican caucus right now," State Senator Mike Miller, a Republican from the town of North Pole, told The Fairbanks Daily News-Miner on Thursday. "I'm leaning toward requiring a vote of the people."
This year, Alaskans were paid $536 million from the Permanent Fund, which was set up in 1982 as a way to share Alaska's oil wealth with its citizens. The fund is now worth $18 billion, and it grew by an average of $6.7 million a day over the last year.
What feeds the Permanent Fund is oil from Prudhoe Bay, the largest oil field in North America. But that oil will be depleted in about 20 years, according to geologic estimates. In the meantime, with oil prices much lower than Alaska's economists had expected, the state is facing a big deficit.
There is wide dispute over how much oil may lie under the tundra of the Arctic refuge.
"What this is really all about is the high-pitched whine of the Alaska greed machine," said Allen Smith, the Alaska head of the Wilderness Society, an environmental group. "We have no state sales tax. No income tax. We get 85 percent of our revenue from oil, and all of sudden we're facing a $500 million deficit."
Accepting only 50 percent may be hard for most Alaskans to swallow, but making such a promise now looks like the only way to insure Congressional passage, said Mitch Rose, a spokesman for Senator Stevens.
"If the price of getting the Arctic refuge through Congress is accepting 50 percent of something, rather than 90 percent of nothing, then we're going to stick with 50-50," Mr. Rose said.

HEADLINE: Rights Groups Say Shell Oil Shares Blame

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Human rights advocates and environmental organizations in the United States and Britain angrily criticized the Shell oil group yesterday after the hanging of the Nigerian writer Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other activists, saying the company had damaged the executed men's reputation with Nigeria's military rulers and could have done more to secure their reprieve.
A group led by Mr. Saro-Wiwa, the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni Peoples, had protested environmental damage by Shell and other oil companies in the Ogoni region in the Niger Delta, as well as human rights abuses there by the Nigerian military against the Ogoni and other ethnic groups. 
 Shell suspended operations in the Ogoni region in 1993 after civil unrest, but still produces about half of Nigeria's crude oil output of two million barrels a day.
"Shell is the bulwark of Nigeria's economy, producing almost half its oil," said William Shulz, president of Amnesty International. "It did not do all it could have done. It had influence which it did not exert."
Gavin Grant of the Ogoni Community Association, a London-based organization that supported Mr. Saro-Wiwa's campaign, said, "Shell demonized Ken Saro-Wiwa in the eyes of the Nigerian military." Human Rights Watch called on Shell and other oil companies to close down their operations in Nigeria.
Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the company's formal name, issued a statement from its London headquarters expressing "deep regret" that the executions had taken place. It said that it no immediate plans to scale back its operations in Nigeria.
Behind the anger with Shell lies a perception that the company was halfhearted in its efforts to secure pardons for the men after they were condemned to death at a trial widely seen as flawed on charges they had incited demonstrators to murder four pro-Government chiefs.
On Oct. 31, after the defendants were found guilty, Shell acknowledged it was being pressed to use its influence'with the Nigerian Government to secure clemency for them, but said it would not do so, saying, "It is not for a commercial organization like Shell to interfere in the legal processes of a sovereign state such as Nigeria."
The company also accused Mr. Saro-Wiwa of supporting violence, saying that although his organization asserted its campaign against the oil drillers was nonviolent, "this is not our experience."
The company's grudging attitude brought protests from Mr. Saro-Wiwa's supporters in the West. On Nov. 2, Shell issued another statement in which it dropped the accusation that Mr. Saro-Wiwa abetted violence and called it "understandable" that the families of those condemned to death should issue "emotional and moving appeals on their behalf."
But the company expressed no regret at the death sentences and again refused to intervene on the condemned men's behalf.
Only after the death sentences were confirmed by Nigeria's ruling military council on Wednesday did Shell issue a third short statement, saying Cor Herkstroter, chairman of the committee of managing directors of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, had written to the Nigerian military ruler, Gen. Sani Abacha, "requesting clemency on humanitarian grounds."
But it warned that openly pressing the Nigerian authorities to commute the sentences might prove counterproductive, saying "many of those who know Africa best, like Nelson Mandela, have advocated quiet diplomacy as the way forward."
In this case, however, quiet diplomacy did not work.

HEADLINE: NIGERIA EXECUTES CRITIC OF REGIME; NATIONS PROTEST

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Nigeria's military Government today executed Ken Saro-Wiwa, one of the country's leading environmentalists and authors, provoking international protests and calls for punitive measures against Nigeria.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa, 54, a prominent critic of the Government who was arrested last year on charges of murder that he had steadfastly denied, was hanged with eight co-defendants at the prison in the eastern city of Port Harcourt at 11:30 A.M., the official Nigerian press agency said. 
 The executions, which followed an outpouring of appeals for clemency, drew a swift international response.
The United States, Britain and other countries withdrew their ambassadors, the Commonwealth countries were considering whether to expel or suspend Nigeria and the World Bank announced it would not support a $100 million loan to Nigeria for a huge project to develop liquefied natural gas.
The White House called on the United Nations to condemn the executions and consider an embargo on sales of military equipment to Nigeria. But it stopped short of calling for the action that would sting most -- sanctions on the oil exports that provide virtually all of Nigeria's foreign income.
South Africa's President, Nelson Mandela, called the executions a "heinous act." In Washington, the White House issued a statement that deplored the Nigerian Government's "flouting of even the most basic international norms and universal standards of human rights."
Nigeria went ahead with the executions despite the multitude of calls for leniency, which reflected an increasingly cloistered siege mentality among the country's military rulers, diplomats said.
For the last several years Mr. Saro-Wiwa, a popular author, playwright and television producer, has been one of the Government's most articulate and determined critics. He had built a campaign against environmental damage by oil companies and for a fairer share of Nigeria's immense oil wealth for the regions where it is produced.
Mr. Saro-Wiwa's organization, the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People, grew to become the largest political organization in the 350-square-mile homeland of the Ogoni. This ethnic group, to which he belonged, includes 500,000 people who live in the oil-rich but desperately poor swamplands of Delta State.
When the movement's members began to demonstrate for an end to oil spillages by Royal Dutch/Shell and for a share of the revenues from the oil pumped from their land, international human rights groups say, Nigerian troops began mounting a kind of scorched-earth campaign against the Ogoni, burning villages and committing murders and rapes.
Shell, Nigeria's largest oil producing company, has acknowledged frequent spills but has said the Ogoni movement exaggerated their impact.
After four pro-military traditional leaders were killed last year, Mr. Saro-Wiwa and several associates were quickly arrested for the crimes. But his defenders say he was framed and did not receive a fair trial.
Deeply unpopular, the current Nigerian leaders have little to show for over two years of near-absolute power in what was once one of Africa's most prosperous countries and is now one of its most miserable.
The head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha, issued a clemency order last month lifting death sentences in a reported coup plot involving a former head of state, Olusegun Obasanjo, and dozens of other former officials, army officers and journalists. Diplomats and Nigerian analysts said the order had created profound tensions among senior officers who interpreted the lifting of the sentences as a dangerous sign of weakness.
"These guys know that they have their backs against the wall," a Western diplomat said of Nigeria's leaders. "There are people in the ranks who are against them, there are people in their own circles who are having doubts, and with the population against them and now the world against them too, they must feel that to show any softness is to commit suicide."
The executions drew outraged reactions at a meeting of Commonwealth heads of government in Auckland, New Zealand, a regular event that brings together Britain with its former colonies.
Hours after the announcement of the executions, Prime Minister John Major of Britain and President Mandela each called for the expulsion of Nigeria from the 52-member organization.
"I would recommend every move to indicate to the Nigerian Government that we totally condemn what they have done," Mr. Mandela told reporters in Auckland.
In recent days, both Mr. Mandela and Mr. Major had been advocating a quiet diplomacy toward Nigeria, and until the executions were disclosed, neither Britain nor South Africa had supported growing calls for Nigeria's expulsion from the Commonwealth.
Defending his country against the wave of criticisms, the Nigerian Foreign Minister, Tom Ikimi, who was attending the Commonwealth meeting, said Mr. Saro-Wiwa was guilty of "the brutal murder of four Nigerians from his area."
"Which state does not have problems?" Mr. Ikimi added.
Germany, Austria and South Africa said they too were recalling their ambassadors, and a flood of other condemnations were announced from African countries and from the European Union.
With an eye to the country's human rights situation, the International Finance Corporation, an arm of the World Bank, announced today that it was rejecting the $100 million loan to Nigeria that was seen as crucial to a $3 billion project to - liquefy natural gas. For decades the gas has been burned off rather than captured and processed at Nigeria's coastal oil fields.
The flaring of this gas, which generates smog and raises the temperature of the surrounding areas, was one of Mr. Saro-Wiwa's longstanding complaints against international oil companies operating in Nigeria.
Since his arrest, Mr. Saro-Wiwa had been held in a military camp in Port Harcourt, where he had been denied ordinary visitation rights and allowed infrequent access to legal council.
"I was found guilty even before I was tried," he told the court at his sentencing. "In the course of this trial, I have been brutalized."
On Thursday, Mr. Saro-Wiwa's wife, Hauwa, was turned away from the detention center where he was held as she tried to bring her husband food. The authorities took the food to Mr. Saro-Wiwa, but Nigerian press reports said that when the prison authorities refused to say where it had come from, he refused to eat it.
Earlier this year, Mr. Saro-Wiwa's lawyers abandoned his defense, saying they were being mistreated by the country's military authorities and routinely denied access to Government documents pertaining to the case. The lawyers, themselves prominent human rights figures in Nigeria, said it was plain that the country's military justice system had ordained Mr. Saro-Wiwa's conviction from the start.
For his part, Mr. Saro-Wiwa -- one of his country's best-known poets, a onetime government minister and formerly a highly popular newspaper columnist -- has always maintained his innocence.
"The crime of the Ogoni people is that they had the temerity to ask for their rights from both the Government of Nigeria and from Shell," Mr. Saro-Wiwa wrote in his opening defense statement.
"What the criminal partners of this alliance are trying to tell the world by this arraignment is that the black man, even the best of them, is no better than a criminal," he said. "For if a man of my upbringing, education, cultivation and demonstrated achievement in various areas of life cannot conduct an argument for rights peacefully and in a civilized manner, then no one else can do so."
In response to the executions, President Clinton recalled Ambassador Walter Carrington from Lagos and planned to lodge a protest with the Nigerian Ambassador. He took a series of steps that largely extended current American restrictions on Nigeria, but stopped short of measures with large practical effects, like economic sanctions or an oil embargo.
The President also directed the American representative to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, to start consultations on "appropriate U.N. measures to condemn these actions."
American officials said Ms. Albright would seek support for a condemnatory resolution by the Security Council, a strong action in that body.
If the United States is able to win passage of such a resolution, officials might then consider pushing for an international arms embargo. "It would not be an easy thing to do," an official said.
There was no talk of economic sanctions or an oil embargo. Officials said that it was traditionally quite difficult to rally any international support for oil embargoes and that unilateral oil embargoes were not effective. Nearly half of Nigerian oil exports go to the United States, an American official said, although that amounts to less than 10 percent of overall American oil imports.
In other steps, the White House announced that Mr. Clinton had banned the sale and repair of military goods and services for Nigeria, a largely symbolic action since the United States has already stopped most if not all weapons sales to the African nation.
He extended the current United States ban on visas -- which already prohibits the entry of senior Nigerian military officers, senior Government officials and their families -- to include all military officers and civilians who "actively formulate, implement or benefit from the policies that impede Nigeria's transition to democracy."
Mr. Clinton ruled that Nigerian officials visiting the United Nations or international financial institutions would be under cold-war-style travel restrictions and must stay within 25 miles of those institutions. And he said the United States would continue to oppose International Monetary Fund loans and debt relief for Nigeria.
The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said in a written statement that the United States "strongly condemns" the execution of the nine men. "These executions demonstrate to the world the Abacha regime's flouting of even the most basic international norms and universal standards of human rights."

HEADLINE: Energy Chief Expresses Chagrin Over Monitoring Reporters

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary said today that she was "chagrined and embarrassed" that her department had hired a company that ranked reporters who cover it, but the White House said that, despite the furor over the practice, Mrs. O'Leary could keep her job.
Mrs. O'Leary said the contract with the consulting firm, Carma International, had been requested without her knowledge last year, by the then-head of the department's press office. That person, Michael Gauldin, was Bill Clinton's press secretary when Mr. Clinton was Governor of Arkansas. 
 The White House said the practice was "unacceptable and will not be tolerated." Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, ordered Mrs. O'Leary to cut the budget for her office by $46,500, to cover the cost of the contract. It ran from December 1994 until the department canceled it in August.
The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said the contract was "just another reason to turn out the lights at the Energy Department." House Republicans, who also want the department broken up, said more than 70 of them had signed a letter urging Mrs. O'Leary's resignation.
Mrs. O'Leary said, "I think people were gunning for the whole department, and having lost that piece, they're gunning for me."
Mr. Gauldin, who now holds a similar job at the Interior Department, could not be reached today for comment on the episode. There was no answer at his home or office today, a Federal holiday. He did not reply to an E-mail message.
Mrs. O'Leary said the contract, which also involved rankings of members of Congress, governors and others, was part of an effort to improve the department's credibility among all the people it dealt with. She said her department had never asked for the ranking of reporters or others that the consulting concern provided, only an analysis of coverage. She said she had seen only two of the concern's monthly reports and had not read either far enough to find the rankings.
She said that the Carma contract had been canceled because the reports had not been useful and that no action had been taken based on the reports.
The White House statement said, "Upon receiving Carma's initial reports, the department should have directed Carma not to rate reporters and news organization and in failing to do so, exercised poor judgment."
Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, where the department is planning to store nuclear waste, complained last month that Mrs. O'Leary was traveling more than the Secretary of State and with a larger entourage. Republican members of Congress had also complained about the Secretary's travels.
Mrs. O'Leary, who was in New Orleans today on a previously scheduled trip to discuss aid to the oil and gas industries, said in a telephone conference call with reporters that an advisory panel comprising academics, public officials and a journalist had recommended that the department should determine how it is perceived.
A survey requested by Mrs. O'Leary's predecessor found that among 450 people who dealt with the department, its headquarters was trusted less than almost all other institutions and industries, even the civilian nuclear industry.
The Energy Department was created almost 20 years ago from the remnants of the Atomic Energy Commission, which routinely lied about its nuclear activities in the name of national security. With its cold-war mission gone, it turned to cleaning up atomic weapons plants and disposing of surplus nuclear materials. Repairing public trust was crucial, Douglas Elmets, its press secretary in the last years of the Reagan Administration, said today.
"Far more than her predecessors," he said of Mrs. O'Leary, "she came to the realization that if you don't have the public on your side, or the media on your side, for that matter, you're going to have a very difficult time getting the cleanup going." Mrs. O'Leary said today that her department's credibility had now taken a step backward.
Carma counted people quoted in stories about the Energy Department and judged their comments as positive and negative and how much so. The largest group of those saying positive things were Energy Department officials.
It also listed and rated members of Congress, state regulators, governors and other who said things that it judged unfavorable.
Carma reported on "positive messages," like "the risks of public exposure from stored plutonium is extremely low" and "the D.O.E. handles too many important areas to justify elimination."
It listed "negative messages" like "little progress is being made to clean up plutonium storrage sites" and "D.O.E.'s budget should be cut substantially."

HEADLINE: Terms of Muslim-Croat Alliance Are Set at Dayton Talks

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A wide-ranging agreement to invigorate a tenuous Muslim-Croat alliance in Bosnia was announced today by senior Administration officials and portrayed as an important step toward an overall Bosnian peace settlement. But the effectiveness of the accord and the strategy behind it remain uncertain.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, on a one-day visit to the peace talks here, said the accord would bring the Muslim-Croat federation established last year "to life" and described it as "an essential building block of peace in Bosnia-Herzegovina as a whole." Up to now, the federation has done little more than stop the fighting that raged in 1993 between Muslims and Croats. 
 The agreement, signed after 10 days of negotiations here that have scarcely begun to address the most contentious issues of an overall Bosnian peace, amounts to the first serious attempt to divide authority between the central Government of Bosnia and the federation, establish the rudiments of economic life, and integrate divided Muslim and Croatian communities.
But it hardly touches on one of the most difficult questions: the degree of integration between Croat forces and the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Army. During a recent offensive in western Bosnia, fighting twice broke out between Croatian and Bosnian units, bringing the federation to the verge of collapse.
Moreover, it remains unclear whether the American strategy of strengthening the military and economic power of the Muslim-Croat federation as a counterbalance to the Serbs will ultimately prove compatible with the stated American aim of maintaining Bosnia as a single state. The stronger and more integrated the federation becomes, the more the Serbs of Bosnia may feel their future lies elsewhere.
"If the federation can succeed as a multi-ethnic democracy, then so can Bosnia-Herzegovina as a whole," Mr. Christopher said. But if this is to happen, then the relationship between the Muslim-Croat federation and the Serb republic within Bosnia foreseen in any peace plan will have to be one of cooperation rather than hostility.
It is far from clear how such cooperation will be worked out in that the basic aim of the Serbs' current leaders remains that of ruling themselves with a view to eventual confederation with Serbia or secession.
As the agreement was signed today by the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, and the Croatian President, Franjo Tudjman, Croatia moved troops and heavy artillery close to Eastern Slavonia, the one remaining Serb-held part of Croatia.
The troop movement may amount to no more than saber rattling. But it nevertheless underscored the fragility of the negotiations here. President Tudjman has vowed to retake Eastern Slavonia by the end of this month through negotiation or military might.
The agreement signed today gives the federation government extensive powers, including control over defense, justice, customs collection, taxation, agriculture, health and internal affairs.
The central Bosnian Government, whose form and function remain to be defined in any overall peace accord, would retain control over foreign policy, foreign trade, air traffic control, immigration and citizenship, and monetary policy.
Over the last 20 months, since the formation of the federation, Croats and Muslims have argued over how authority should be divided. The Muslim-led Government has been reluctant to cede any real authority to the federation, while Bosnian Croats have seen the federation as a means to weaken the Government and strengthen their ties with Croatia.
In practice, Croatian-controlled areas, amounting to about 20 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina, have been governed by the self-styled authorities of Herzeg-Bosna and have pushed ahead with integration with Croatia.
The agreement seeks to undo this process by dissolving the institutions of Herzeg-Bosna. At the same time, four federation ministries -- commerce, traffic and communications, energy and industry, and education, science and culture -- are to be established in Mostar.
Every fourth session of the federation's government, which is to meet weekly, will be held in Mostar. The remainder will be held in Sarajevo.
In one of its most important stipulations, the accord says a new customs system is to be set up by Dec. 10 and internal customs checkpoints between Croatian and Bosnian Government-controlled areas removed.
Because Croatia and Herzeg-Bosna control geographic access to landlocked Bosnia, Croats have been able to take an enormous cut on all goods going into Bosnia. This practice has infuriated the Bosnian Government. Beginning with the 1996 budget year, the agreement says an agreed proportion of customs revenue will accrue to the central budget of the Bosnian republic. An annex to the agreement establishes steps to bring about the reunification of Mostar, the magnificent city on the Neretva River whose Old Bridge, a marvel of Ottoman architecture, was destroyed by Croatian shelling during the 1993 war. The city has remained divided along the front lines of that conflict.
On the central issue of military integration, the agreement calls only for greater integration between senior Croat and Muslim commanders. It adds that "international assistance" will be sought in the creation of a "joint planning staff."
In practice, "international assistance" almost certainly means American help. This in turn raises the difficult issue of how American military aid to the federation will prove compatible with a large American presence in the NATO force that would be sent to police any overall settlement.

HEADLINE: Bias Against Straphangers? Suburbanites Beg to Differ

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Their trains may have padded seats, luggage racks and toilets, but many commuters on the Metro-North and Long Island railroads don't think they're getting a far better deal than their subterranean cousins.
For one thing, commuters in the nearer suburbs say current fares of $6 or so per ride -- or roughly $3 with a monthly pass -- mean they already pay two to four times as much as subway riders for trips that are shorter than many subway rides. 
 "This is not a question of discrimination," said Bruce Goldman, a Manhattan salesman who commutes on the Long Island Rail Road from Island Park, just six miles east of the Queens border. "They can take the subway from the Bronx to Brooklyn for $1.25. It costs $142 a month on the train, and that's going to increase."
Although suburbanites have been portrayed in a recent transit lawsuit as the undeserving winners in the latest round of fare increases, many commuters say they are not getting any bargain. They say it may be too simplistic to conclude that the fare increases are discriminatory because they are proportionately higher in New York City, where transit riders are predominantly black and Hispanic, than in the predominantly white suburbs.
That argument, raised by civil rights and transit advocates in a lawsuit against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, led a Federal judge last week to block a 25-cent subway-fare increase. A Federal appeals court overturned the ruling on Thursday, but the issue is unlikely to be settled until a trial later this year.
Commuters point out that their world has its own economic diversity: one in five commuters, for example, has a family income under $50,000. And commuters like Jonathan Factor say that people who protest the new fare structure -- a 20 percent increase on the subways and an average 9 percent increase for commuters -- forget that many riders are "taking a double hit." More than 60 percent of L.I.R.R. commuters and a third of Metro-North commuters also take the subway to work.
"I suffer the increase on the Long Island Rail Road, but I also pay the increase on the subway," said Mr. Factor, a lawyer from East Meadow who takes a train to Pennsylvania Station and a subway to his lower Manhattan office. "I feel doubly discriminated against."
Metro-North commuters who ride long distances from communities like Poughkeepsie and Somers said that while they got more distance for their money, they could not afford to pay much more for transportation.
"The fare discriminates against all hard-working people, no matter whether they're in the city or around the city," said Robert Peter, a recently retired engineer who had been paying $10.25 each way to make the 50-mile commute from Somers, N.Y., or $185 with a monthly pass.
Dan Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North, said officials had decided that they could not raise fares for remote stations like Poughkeepsie, where the monthly fare will be $257 starting Dec. 1. Many people settled so far from New York because they could not afford houses closer to the city. Raising their fares, he said, would drive them into car pools, cutting the transit system's income.
Many commuters also do not fit the Cheeveresque stereotype of a prosperous white stockbroker in a trench coat. Metro-North said that although the median household income for its commuters was $93,750, 21 percent have household incomes under $50,000. On the L.I.R.R., where the average household income of the riders is $84,000, 25 percent of riders have family incomes under $50,000.
Cassandra Trotman is a Panamanian immigrant who commutes from the Bronx's Woodlawn station to White Plains to earn $6 an hour caring for the frail as a home health aide. She pays $2 each way for her commute and does not feel she should pay more to protect the subway and bus fare, which she also pays.
"Commuters are not all wealthy people," she said. "I'm a mother of three kids. Sometimes I have to borrow the money from a friend to pay the fare."
The fastest growing segment of commuters, railroad officials said, is working-class people -- store clerks, baby sitters, cleaning workers and students -- who commute from the New York to more affluent suburbs. To encourage this group's ridership, Metro-North fares from the Bronx are kept artificially low.
The economic woes of commuters draw little sympathy from Gene Russianoff, the lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, which joined in bringing the civil rights suit against the proposed transit fares. Two-thirds of subway riders have family incomes of under $50,000, he said.
"Railroad commuters have a quicker, safer ride than people coming in on a stop-and-go subway trip," he said. "More people sit on the railroad than on a subway or bus."
Still, he cautioned, he was not promoting fare increases for commuters, only more generous subsidies for subway riders.
And among commuters, there is considerable sympathy for subway riders.
"It's clear the rise in the fare places an undue burden on those least able to afford it," said Irene Ditti, an L.I.R.R. commuter who lives in Rego Park.
Yet many commuters bristled at the implication that they should subsidize the subway system.
"If one management owns hotels in New York and Los Angeles, that doesn't mean they should charge more in New York to carry the hotel elsewhere," said Benjamin Schaffer, a Manhattan architect who lives in White Plains.
There are also businessmen like Richard Wehrmann, 41, who said the subject of fare increases didn't "warrant my time" because a one-way fare increase of 50 cents for the White Plains-to-Manhattan trip was not enough to pinch financially.
"I don't count my change," he said.

HEADLINE: State to Let Owners Clear Park Lands

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Over the objections of some environmentalists, the Pataki administration has decided to allow owners of private woodlands within the vast Adirondack Park to clear-cut tens of thousands of acres where trees were damaged in a freak windstorm last summer.
The decision represents a substantial shift in the state's land-use policy for private holdings within the park, where the largest previous permit for clear-cutting involved 55 acres. 
 Much of the private land in the park is actively logged, but not by clear-cutting -- a process, environmentalists argue, that by stripping the land of every tree eliminates wildlife habitat and can cause erosion and runoff, which can harm streams and lakes.
Representatives of the logging industry called the plan a reasoned response to an extraordinary natural disaster. The potent windstorm at dawn on July 15 steamrolled a Rhode Island-sized stretch of the 6 million acre park system, killing four campers and a motorist and damaging or toppling an estimated 125,000 acres of trees. Of that, more than 30,000 acres are privately owned.
While the Adirondack Mountain Club also endorsed the plan, other environmentalists said the decision reflected a pro-business tilt at the Adirondack Park Agency, a state agency which regulates private land use, now that Gov. George E. Pataki has replaced its chairman and several board members.
To qualify under a blanket permit that is to take effect early next week, any landowner in a swath crossing four Adirondack counties need only claim that one of every three trees in a woodland was damaged in the storm. But no inspections will be required to verify such claims.
Gregory A. Hill, an assistant director of the Adirondack Park Agency, said the permit balanced the need to preserve the park's integrity with the need to respond to the storm. "We changed it in several respects to respond to environmental concerns," he said of the new policy.
Representatives of several environmental groups, including the Adirondack Council and the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, said they did not object to limited clear-cutting, but they were alarmed at the lack of government oversight, particularly in areas with sensitive wetlands.
They said they would mount legal challenges to the permit, the final language of which was released yesterday by the Adirondack Park Agency.
"We think that the A.P.A. is turning its back on its historic role as protector of the Adirondack Park," said Sarah Meyland, executive director of Citizens Campaign for the Environment. "This new permit, we believe, is serving the needs of the forest products industry and not the needs and interests of the public."
Other environmentalists, noted however, that their fears were tempered by the recognition that the market for timber is weak and therefore the economy may well restrain the timber industry even if, as some see it, the Pataki administration won't.
Neil Woodworth, a lawyer for the Adirondack Mountain Club, said, "Frankly, the major companies are not going to want to take down any trees they don't have to."
The storm also created a dispute among state environmental and fire officials and environmentalists over what to do about millions of fallen trees within the "forever wild" areas of public forest preserves. A decision on that front is expected by the end of the year.
The damage to private lands was seen as needing quicker action, so privately owned timber would not go to waste.
After the storm, timber companies like the International Paper Company, which operates tree farms on 300,000 acres within the park boundary, asked the state to issue special guidelines that would -- on a one-time basis -- allow extensive clear-cutting where the storm damaged private forests. Industry officials said that if timber wasn't salvaged quickly it would rot or discolor.
But some environmentalists said the permit, which expires on June 30 next year, will allow landowners to clear-cut entire forests under what amounts to an honor system. John F. Sheehan, a spokesman for the Adirondack Council, a private group, said the permit is far too generous in allowing two live trees to be cut for every dead or damaged one.
Mr. Woodworth of the Adirondack Mountain Club said that while he generally supported the permit, he was disturbed by the provisions covering clear-cutting in wetlands, particularly the absence of a requirement that Park Agency forestry experts visit cutting sites.
"We wanted the agency to go out on each and every clear-cut in wetland areas," Mr. Woodworth said. "In the field, an A.P.A. forester and a company's forester can very nicely determine what's necessary," he said. "But if they're just talking about it on the phone, he won't know how wet it is, what's in there."
Robert Stegemann, a spokesman for International Paper, said the A.P.A. responded well to the blowdown, inviting environmental groups and the industry to help it draft the permit. "It's good to see government trying to address a unique situation in a responsible way," he said.

HEADLINE: Debt Ceiling Impasse Dampens Bond Prices

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the Republican-controlled Congress and the Clinton Administration still at loggerheads over raising the Federal debt ceiling to allow the Government to meet interest payments, Treasury securities fell yesterday, continuing their slide of Thursday.
Traders and dealers seem convinced that politicians could not possibly be so naive as to allow a default that would undermine the Government's credibility. Yet the unsureness of the situtation is weighing heavily on bond prices. 
 "We're moving through a period where the Government's credibility is being beaten up every day," said Hugh A. Johnson, chief investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation.
The 30-year bond fell 23/32 , to a price of 1077/32 , sending its yield up to 6.33 percent, from 6.28 percent on Thursday. That was still at the low end of this year's range; in January the yield was as high as 7.92 percent.
The Treasury said yesterday that an auction of $29.6 billion of three- and six-month bills scheduled for sale on Monday could be postponed because of the conflict.
Bill Gamba, senior vice president in charge of the Government trading desk at Cowen & Company, said: "I think that the Street is convinced that we will see some sort of an accord on the debt ceiling this weekend. Some market participants are still even looking for an interest rate cut at the Fed's Open Market Committee meeting on Wednesday. But I think the cards are stacked more toward a December ease."
Discussing the possibility of a Government default, Mr. Gamba said, "I believe that the repercussions would far exceed anyone's estimation." But, he added: "I don't believe the Government would allow that to take place. It's really hard to say how the market would react, because it's never happened."
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, called the impasse between Congress and the Administration macho theatrics that were being played to the hilt. Still, he saw a potential for both a "loss of credibility and a significant decline in prices."
Mr. Delaney said that the "procrastination and posturing is negative for both the markets and national image in the long run."
He added that if "the Treasury pulls out all stops to insure timely payment on principal and interest," there will be a short-term, temporary effect of uninvested cash looking for a home.
In addition to the uncertainty caused by the impasse in Washington, traders were inclined toward caution before next week's scheduled economic reports and the Federal Open Market Committee meeting. These are among the reports due:
*On Tuesday, October retail sales;
*On Wednesday, the October Consumer Price Index, October industrial production and capacity utilization, and September business inventories;
*On Thursday, the November Philadelphia Fed survey and initial weekly unemployment claims;
*On Friday, October housing starts.
One positive economic straw in the wind yesterday was a survey by the University of Michigan, which reported its preliminary sentiment index for November rose to 90.7 from 90.2 in October. Economists say the higher number suggests that the wrangling in Washington has not had an adverse influence on consumers' attitudes.

HEADLINE: Dow Sets Another Record But Overall Market Is Off

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Even though the Dow Jones industrial average set a high for the third consecutive session, stock prices were under pressure yesterday as investors worried that the Federal Government might default on its debt because of political conflicts over the budget.
The 30-stock Dow average gained 6.14 points, to 4,870.37, buoyed by a round of computer-guided buy orders and the strength of its large-capitalization cyclical issues. For the week, the Dow had a gain of 44.80 points. But in yesterday's trading the broader averages turned lower, and there were more declines than advances on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 "People fear the implications of a Government default," said Edwin C. Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A., explaining what he called "a cloud over the market."
With Congress and the Clinton Administration in an impasse over raising the $4.9 trillion debt ceiling, bond prices fell yesterday. The bellwether 30-year Treasury bond slumped 23/32 and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.33 percent, from 6.28 percent on Thursday.
Falling bond prices led to weakness in the overall stock market. Among the other indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index eased 0.54 point, to 592.72, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.72 points, to 1,063.87. Declining issues on the Big Board outnumbered advances by 1,246 to 975. Volume was light, with 298.7 million shares changing hands, down from 380.8 million shares on Thursday.
The Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet next week and there has been talk of a possible reduction in the Federal funds rate, which is charged on overnight bank loans. But many analysts do not expect any action on rates at this meeting.
The stocks of brokerage firms, which are sensitive to changes in interest rates, suffered some big losses yesterday. Morgan Stanley dropped 1 7/8, to 87 3/4, and Merrill Lynch declined 1 5/8, to 58 7/8.
Among the big movers in the market, American Greetings, which announced that it would take a charge for a corporate revamping in its third quarter, declined 3 7/8, to 27. Canandaigua Wine, which reported lower-than-expected earnings for its fourth quarter, plunged 1813/16 , to 311/16 . And Marvel Entertainment, which said that third-quarter profits dropped, fell 2, to 11 7/8.
Drug companies that sell heavily in overseas markets also fell. Johnson & Johnson closed at 79 3/4, down 1 1/4; Abbott Laboratories ended at 39 1/4, down 3/8, and Pfizer closed at 58 1/2, down 1 1/8.
On the other hand, stocks involved with the Internet continued their upward push. Spyglass increased 8 1/2, to 92; Netcom On-Line advanced 3/4, to 79, and Sun Microsystems rose 4 3/4, to 89 7/8.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Stocks and the Peso End Day Largely Unchanged

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Stocks ended largely unchanged today, buoyed by a surprising show of peso stability against the dollar but held back by fears that turmoil will again rock Mexico's fragile markets.
The stock market's index of leading shares ended down 0.99 of a point at 2,310.10. Gainers outpaced decliners by a slender 32-to-28 margin. 
 "The market ended quiet," one trader said. "There are an equal number of optimists and pessimists out there."
The peso steadied today after a two-day slide in volatile trading. The peso settled today at 13.25 United States cents, unchanged from Thursday.
"The peso is too devalued right now," a dealer said. "It is at levels which are excessively low and there has to be a correction."
Mexico's currency plunged Thursday to an all-time low of 12 United States cents, generating panic in the market, before Banco de Mexico, the central bank, stepped in to sell around $200 million and buy pesos in a bid to support the Mexican currency.
Banco de Mexico said today that it did not intervene in the market again to help the embattled currency, although some analysts said they did not believe the central bank.
Some foreign investors searched the market for cheap shares after the peso's recent fall, but others took profits from gains on Thursday, fearing the peso was headed lower.
Analysts said high interest rates and inflation following the peso's woes will weigh on stocks in the coming days.
"I think investors are coming to the conclusion that 1996 is going to be another lackluster year," said Vinod Sehgal, director of Latin American analysis at Oppenheimer & Company.
Analysts said investors would closely watch the 1996 budget, which is to be introduced on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher in Thin Trading, As Fears of a U.S. Impasse Ease

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose in thin trading yesterday as currency traders in Europe and the United States grew slightly more confident that an agreement on the United States budget could soon be reached.
The dollar was also helped by a steadying of the Mexican peso, which slid the two previous days in volatile trading. 
 Many banks were closed yesterday in observance of Veterans Day, contributing to the thin trading.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 100.90 Japanese yen from 100.40 yen on Thursday. The dollar also climbed to 1.4176 German marks from 1.4104 marks and to 1.1390 Swiss francs from 1.1361 Swiss francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5665 from $1.5794.
The dollar started its rise during the overlap between United States and European trading. Robert Ryan, who follows foreign exchange at the Bank of New York, said the timing indicated that both European and American traders were taking the opportunity to reverse earlier positions to cut their risk over the weekend.
The reaction follows a sharp fall in the dollar on Thursday as anxieties over an impasse on the United States budget finally affected world currency markets.
"Yesterday, we were all upset about a budget impasse and today they said, 'It's the weekend, we better square our positions,' " Mr. Ryan said.
President Clinton said yesterday that he wanted to work with the Republican-controlled Congress on the budget but not "under the threat of a Government default or shutdown."
Ron Leven, a global currency strategist for J. P. Morgan & Company, said traders noticed quickly that the dollar did not fall after Mr. Clinton's announcement, which came a little after 1 P.M.
"People said, 'Uh, oh, if the dollar didn't fall on this, I better get out,' " Mr. Leven said.
In other currency trading, the Mexican peso settled at 7.55 pesos to the dollar -- unchanged from Thursday, when it hit a record low for the second consecutive day against the dollar. That took pressure off the dollar, which is affected because of the close economic ties between the United States and Mexico.
The mark weakened yesterday, as some traders grew concerned that growth forecasts for Europe might be overstated.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Hunsicker Leaves Mets for Houston Job

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

 BODY:
Gerry Hunsicker, the Mets' assistant vice president of baseball operations since 1991, was named the general manager of the Houston Astros yesterday.
The Astros also announced that they would continue to reside in Texas in 1996 rather than be sold and moved to northern Virginia. 
 "The Mayor and some of the key business leaders in the city were here to make a joint announcement with Drayton McLane to announce that the plans to move the franchise to Washington have been tabled and the Houston Astros will play in Houston in 1996," Hunsicker said by telephone from Houston.
Hunsicker, who began his baseball administrative career with the Astros in 1978, signed a three-year contract. At least one-third of his tenure will now be spent in Texas, something that only two weeks ago was not guaranteed. McLane, the Astros' owner, seemed more than willing to sell the team and see it moved because of protracted losses -- $60 million in three years, McLane contends -- and poor attendance.
"Drayton has asked the community for its support and 1996 will be the year of reckoning for the city, or the opportunity for the city to come out and show that support to ultimately determine whether this is a viable city to house a major league franchise," Hunsicker said.
"At some point during the '96 season, Drayton will evaluate and make a determination to see whether it is viable here or reopen discussions about the possibilities of moving."
Hunsicker, 44, replaces Bob Watson, who resigned from the Astros on Oct. 23 to become the general manager of the Yankees. The risk of not being able to stay in Houston, Hunsicker said, is something that comes in today's economic climate.
Still, Hunsicker said he signed on with the team because "these opportunities don't come along very often."
"There's never a perfect opportunity today with the economic problems in the game," he said. "Every job has its drawbacks. The reason this opportunity seemed right because it was coming back to an organization that I was familiar with."
Hunsicker acknowledged that leaving the Mets now that many of the players he helped nurture through the minors are making contributions makes the decision somewhat bittersweet.
"I grew up with a lot of these kids and they're finally getting to the point where they're maturing and ready to make a contribution at a major league level, that's certainly one of the rewards for people in scouting and development," he said. "The fact that I'm not there, however, will not dampen my pride and enthusiasm for what has happened in those areas."

HEADLINE: Canada Without Quebec Won't Fall Apart

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Edgar M. Bronfman's Nov. 5 letter on Quebec: Mr. Bronfman describes himself as a former Canadian, and I suspect he harbors a nostalgic view of Montreal as far more important to the Canadian polity and economy than it once was. The sad fact is that Quebec and Canada have had less and less to do with one another over the last few decades. 
 A Canada without Quebec would not fall apart. Quebec has been at the heart of Canadian decentralization efforts for several decades, as federal governments attempted to accommodate the forces driving increased powers to Quebec. Quebec's separation would end this process and give Canada a unity of purpose it has never before enjoyed.
Canadians are aware that Quebec is a nation evolving into a country. There is nothing the Government of Canada can do to "buy" Quebec's loyalty, as it has attempted to do since the 1960's, and the citizens of Canada will not allow any further efforts to decentralize the country. As the referendum revealed, only in Montreal and the regions nearest Ottawa do most of its citizens feel any atavistic attachment to Canada.
What does all this mean to Canada outside Quebec? Precious little. For the past 25 years, economic power has shifted from Montreal to Toronto and, increasingly, Vancouver and Calgary. English and French have, as languages do, settled into their own territories, with Quebec increasingly unilingual. To most Quebecers and Canadians, Quebec is already a separate country in all but name.
Mr. Bronfman's view that Atlantic Canada cannot survive without Quebec is inexplicable. For at least the past 15 years Quebec has been considered, officially, a have-not province and receives far greater federal money than it pays in taxes.
As a British Columbian, I find Mr. Bronfman's assertion that without Quebec we would leave Canada and drift into the United States to be baffling. Western Canada has always wanted a greater, not lesser, role in Canadian confederation. We want in, not out.
In a Canada without Quebec, western Canada would have a much greater say in the governing of the country, and the political balance of power would come to resemble the westward economic flows already taking place.
 
JAMES SAVAGE
Dallas, Nov. 5, 1995

LENGTH: 364 words

HEADLINE: How to Answer a Hanging in Nigeria

 BODY:
Scorning pleas for clemency from governments, human rights groups, environmentalists and private citizens across the world, Nigeria's military dictatorship executed Ken Saro-Wiwa yesterday. A military court had convicted him in the murder of four pro-government leaders of the Ogoni people. But Mr. Saro-Wiwa, an anti-government Ogoni leader, was nowhere near the murder scene and was denied a fair chance to defend himself.
For two years, Gen. Sani Abacha's military Government has been systematically eliminating its critics by execution, long prison terms, intimidation and exile. The suppression of dissent has given a corrupt clique of generals a free hand to loot Africa's most populous country and drive it toward a new civil war. 
 Humane principle and raw self-interest compel the rest of the world to respond forcefully. America's Ambassador to the United Nations, Madeleine Albright, made a good start yesterday, urging the Security Council to condemn Nigeria's action. Unfortunately, the Council is unlikely to act. Nigeria is a current member, and China usually vetoes resolutions condemning violations of human rights.
But other effective action is possible. Heads of government from throughout the formerly British Commonwealth are meeting in New Zealand this weekend and weighing graduated sanctions against the Abacha regime. These begin with a suspension of all but humanitarian aid, an end to military cooperation and denial of visas to top officials of the military Government -- moving on, if needed, to a freeze of leaders' overseas financial assets and an oil embargo. Nelson Mandela also wants Nigeria expelled from the Commonwealth.
Commonwealth leaders should apply the initial sanctions at once, and other nations and institutions should join in. Washington, which has led the way on low-level sanctions, should consider tougher measures, including an oil embargo. The United States is one of Nigeria's main oil customers.
Nigeria's self-inflicted tragedy threatens to spread misery throughout West Africa, compromising its neighbors' economic and political prospects. The world must respond with tough and targeted economic sanctions.

HEADLINE: As Crisis Looms, Essential Services Are Assessed

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
If the Government closes down Tuesday morning, as looks increasingly likely, people may find it hard to complain to their congressmen about a delayed Veterans Administration check or the Statue of Liberty turning them away.
That is because 9 of the 15 telephone operators in the House of Representatives will be told to stay home, the first time in the history of Government shutdowns that Congress itself has had to share the consequences of the Government's failure to complete a Federal budget. 
 In the past, Congress exempted itself from many of the laws it wrote for everybody else. But, with the ascendancy this year of Republicans determined to make Congress more accountable, lawmakers subjected themselves to the same treatment.
This time they are joining the legions of other Federal workers being evaluated as to who is essential to Government and who is not, an exercise going on all over town today, where senior officials were deliberating over such questions as:
How would things be arranged to get Air Force One fueled for the President's trip to the Asian Pacific Economic Conference in Japan?
Could the negotiators at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio, be paid on time if they continued their peace talks with Balkan leaders?
What would officials say to the 23,000 people holding tickets to the eagerly awaited Vermeer exhibition that opens Sunday -- but may close Tuesday -- at the National Gallery of Art?
Would Labor Department lawyers decide that Consumer Price Index figures, on which securities markets depend, could be published on Wednesday?
Whose scientific experiments could be set aside for an indeterminate period without being ruined?
As Congress pushed through temporary measures extending financing for Government agencies and Government borrowing, both of which President Clinton has pledged to veto, senior administrators throughout the Government braced themselves for what now seems an almost inevitable shutdown.
"It seems very unlikely we could get a turnaround," Alice M. Rivlin, the Budget Director, said in an interview this afternoon. A shutdown of any length, she added, would "be very difficult for a great many people."
Most Federal workers were off today, which the Government was celebrating as Veterans Day. Following a regular, though probably hectic, workday on Monday, some 800,000 Federal workers, or 40 percent of the nonmilitary Government payroll, would be sent home after reporting for duty Tuesday morning if no agreement was reached or imminent.
Those remaining on the job would be those considered essential to public health and safety or part of a cadre needed to complete an orderly shutdown, such as locking offices or concluding last-minute business. About half those to be furloughed are in the Washington, D.C., area, with the rest scattered throughout the United States and in embassies and other facilities abroad.
Most things, of course, are already decided since the Government had made contingency plans earlier in the year for a shutdown on Oct. 1, the first day of the 1996 fiscal year.
Air-traffic controllers would scan radar screens, meat would be inspected, as would passengers arriving from abroad, Amtrak trains would run and the mail would go through. Social Security checks would be distributed as usual and the contractors and states that process Medicare and Medicaid payments would continue to make these payments.
Food stamps would also be available, because the Agriculture Department's financing bill is one of two that have been enacted so far; the other covers military construction.
The Federal Reserve, which obtains its money from its investment portfolio, would continue to move trillions of dollars around the financial world electronically and weather forecasts would be as reliable as ever. Veterans and military hospitals would be almost entirely unaffected.
As for the military, the 1.6 million men and women around the world would remain on duty, though the Pentagon said 279,000 of its 850,000 civilian personnel would be furloughed, mainly those involved in planning, low-priority maintenance or some kinds of training.
And it will be business as usual at the Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters and overseas stations, which, if necessary, could draw on secret contingency funds in a crisis.
"Nobody in the field asks me whether the Continuing Resolution means I can't come to work," a senior official said, referring to the stopgap spending measure.
One of the most visible effects of a Government shutdown would be a severe State Department cutback, perhaps 90 percent, in issuing passports and visas. Passports would be issued only in emergencies, which generally require a ticket to prove an imminent departure as well as extra payment.
"Very quickly you'd see huge lines," predicted Richard Greene, the Department's chief financial officer. Passport offices are expected to be crowded on Monday.
Americans abroad would find curtailed ability to get help if they should get sick, lose documents, be arrested, run out of money or otherwise need embassy aid. In many countries, however, the law requires that local employees be paid. In all, 1,600 of 8,000 State Department employees in the United States would be furloughed, while only 1,800 of 18,000 abroad would be idled.
National parks would also be closed, though visitors will have free, unattended access to some, at least for awhile, as the Interior Department estimates it will take three days to clear campgrounds and concessions.
One of the more complicated and potentially costly situations is that of the thousands of holders of Treasury bills, notes and bonds that come due next week. Today, reflecting the general turmoil over Government finance, the Treasury issued a notice that investors who have given standing instructions for automatic reinvestment of proceeds from maturing issues may lose one or more days of interest.
This would occur if replacement securities cannot be issued as scheduled because the ceiling limiting Government debt had not been raised. For those planning to purchase new 10-year notes, in fact, the Treasury warned that investors would have to pay the Treasury accrued interest from Nov. 15 until the date the bonds are actually issued so they could get a full semi-annual interest payment May 15, 1996.
Although 46 percent of Treasury Department employees would be idled, the Internal Revenue Service would continue processing tax returns and the Mint and Bureau of Engraving and Printing would keep churning out produce coins, currency and stamps.
It was not clear, however, that the Federal Communications Commission could complete its auction, slated for Monday, of licenses to operate "wireless cable" systems.
As for the President, officials said he could go to Japan because the Constitution obliges him to carry out foreign policy, Air Force One being necessary for security and secure communications. The White House entourage, however, was thought likely to be smaller than usual if confined to "essential" personnel.
One White House aide made a dentist appointment for Tuesday afternoon.
At least one Government official, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, seemed resigned to more than the fleeting shutdowns that have prevailed for the past 15 years.
She has been called for jury duty on Monday and has not sought to be excused even though she has been asked to be available for five days.

GRAPHIC: Photo: White House tours are among the nonessential services that could be halted by a Government shutdown. (David Scull/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "A GUIDE: How a Shutdown Would Affect Some Government Services"
 VETERANS -- No veterans' benefit checks would be mailed. But medical staff would remain on duty at veterans' hospitals and clinics.
 DEFENSE -- All active-duty military would report to work, along with roughly 570,000 of the Defense Department's 850,000 civilian employees.
 PASSPORTS -- Passports would not be issued except in emergencies, for which a purchased ticket is required.
 TOURISM -- National park visitor centers and monuments would be closed. All Smithsonian museums in Washington and New York would close, as would the National Zoo, in Washington.
 JUSTICE -- Federal prisons would operate as normal, and Federal courts would remain open but most civil cases would be postponed.
 RETIREES -- Social Security checks would be issued, but applications could not be processed.
 MAIL -- The Postal Service, which is self-supporting, would continue mail deliveries as usual.
 WELFARE -- Cashing welfare checks would continue, along with food stamps, but no applications would be processed.
 TRANSPORTATION -- Air traffic controllers, the Coast Guard, railway inspectors and other essential safety personel would remain on the job. Amtrak trains would continue running. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk
