HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Taking Stock in Third World;
A World Bank Unit Tries to Jump-Start Capitalism

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Nearly two years after it opened for business, the Lusaka Stock Exchange is not exactly humming.
Thanks to a series of setbacks -- including the murder of the organizer's brother, the delayed privatization of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines and other state-owned businesses and the continuing malaise of the local economy -- the exchange's four employees don't have a great deal to do. On a typical day, 20,000 shares change hands, the equivalent of about 2 seconds of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Yet no one is having second thoughts at the International Finance Corporation, the World Bank agency that served as midwife for the exchange, in the capital of Zambia, in southern Africa.
Sooner or later, foreign investors will discover Zambia, and the sputtering Lusaka market will be one reason they do, say officials of the Washington-based agency. A stock market, they say, even an anemic one, signals an openness to outside investment and raises even a poor country's flag a little higher on the international horizon.
"The stock exchange is the national airline of the 1990's," said Francois Wohrer, an investment officer at the I.F.C.
Indeed, more and more countries like Zambia are turning to exchanges to attract some of the billions of foreign dollars now pouring into the world's emerging markets. And when they do, they usually turn to the International Finance Corporation for help.
Founded nearly 40 years ago, the agency is the World Bank's financing arm for the private sector, with a mandate to stimulate capital markets and promote productive companies in developing countries. Toward that end, it offers technical advice that ranges from setting up stock exchanges and banking systems to writing new commercial laws. And it makes direct investments in companies starved for capital.
In its early years, the agency largely got nowhere. Most economies in the developing world were tightly controlled, and foreign investors could see plenty of risk but little opportunity.
"In the beginning, it was preaching in the desert," said Rudolf H. van der Bijl, a manager in capital markets at the agency.
But all that changed in recent years as the movement to free markets swept through Latin America, Asia and Africa and as the Communist world collapsed. Suddenly, the I.F.C. found itself in demand during a period of growth, with the capitalization of emerging markets increasing more than tenfold in the last decade.
Now, with so many markets bubbling and so many Western investors eager to jump in, the agency is something of a victim of its own success. Some critics in the private sector say it has outlived its usefulness, only getting in the way of smart money that is finding its own opportunities all over the world.
But private money, the agency's defenders note, likes to go where the action is, leaving it to the I.F.C. to get the action started in the first place. The agency is still busy, they say, setting up or repairing stock markets in places as far apart as Romania and West Africa, where it is putting together the first regional exchange in the world.
The Lusaka market, a part of the country's transition from a stagnant, highly centralized economy to a capitalist one, has had all the problems of a typical start-up operation.
The goal was to build a real exchange out of what had been an informal stock trading system, in which shareholders connected through local newspaper ads.
A team of the agency's market specialists arrived in Lusaka in March 1993, 10 months before the market was scheduled to open under the terms of a grant from the World Bank.
The man to meet was Ben Ngenda, a local lawyer who was trying singlehandedly to write the country's new securities laws. "The poor guy, the first time we met him, he was totally lost," said Mr. Wohrer, the investment officer, recalling Mr. Ngenda sitting in his office amid piles of regulations from other countries.
Ultimately, Zambia settled on a leanly run exchange, with four regulators to oversee the four employees, who run things on a single personal computer. I.F.C. officials laud Mr. Ngenda for his role in shaping the exchange, saying that nearly every successful stock market owes its existence to the enthusiasm of one local individual.
But while the exchange opened on schedule, in February 1994, little else has gone right.
Even before opening day, Mr. Ngenda fell out of favor with the Government, which apparently lost the will to privatize as fast as he wanted, and he was not picked to run the country's new securities commission, as the I.F.C. had hoped. Shortly after the opening, under circumstances that remain unclear, Mr. Ngenda's brother, an accountant, was shot and killed while investigating fraud in a local company and Mr. Ngenda's office was ransacked. Mr. Ngenda, who now has bodyguards, has little to do with the exchange anymore.
Meanwhile, the privatization that would have resulted in more companies being listed on the exchange still has not occurred. Indeed, only one company -- Chelanga Cement -- has been privatized and listed so far, although trading of seven other stocks occurs on an unofficial basis.
"You have all this local politics, of which we can only know a tiny bit," said Theresa Barger, who was division chief of the I.F.C. for Africa from 1992 until earlier this year.
For better or worse, the exchange is now pretty much on its own, consulting the agency's officials when needed.
Starting stock markets is only part of the agency's work. Often it will revamp a market that is inefficient, corrupt or simply not functioning. In Venezuela, it helped create an electronic stock exchange, the Bolsa Electronica, that now operates in tandem with a manual exchange.
"When you have the most active emerging market in the world operating on a manual basis, you have a recipe for disaster," said Peter Tropper, a senior investment officer at the agency.
This was also the case in Kenya, where the Nairobi Stock Exchange, which was established in 1954, had slowly withered because of antiquated trading practices and heavy taxes. The agency brought in computers and a better system for clearing trades. It also persuaded the Government to cut taxes. Last year, the market capitalization doubled, to more than $3 billion.
But the success of the agency has led to questions about its relevance. With private-sector specialists in emerging markets seeking opportunities in even some of the most exotic locales, the agency's role is in flux.
In particular, critics say the I.F.C. has a growing reputation for making bad investments in companies. Even when its decisions are sound, it is criticized, because its investments can crowd out private money.
Richard W. Richardson, a former official of the agency who is now a senior adviser to the Overseas Development Council, a private group, said the agency's goal should be its own extinction. But as a practical matter, that is not likely to happen, he added. "People don't like to work themselves out of jobs," he said.
Not everyone in the private sector is sure the agency has been eclipsed.
"The name I.F.C. investing in an opportunity can bring in other investors because they feel the I.F.C. has done its homework," said Marianne Hay, who manages emerging market money for Morgan Stanley, including the firm's $240 million Africa Fund.
The agency has tried to respond to criticism by pushing out into the periphery of emerging markets, to places in Africa and the former Soviet Union. In the year ending June 30, it lent or invested $2.9 billion in 213 projects in 67 countries, a 21 percent increase in financing over the previous year. The agency is underwritten by the 162 countries that belong to the World Bank; it also borrows money on the open market.
Still, many at the agency realize that times have changed.
"The I.F.C. needs to be ahead of the curve -- we go where angels fear to tread," said Ms. Barger, the former division chief for Africa. "As it turns out, angels and devils tread everywhere now."
The agency does have some of the former Communist world to itself, perhaps because it is such hard going there.
In Romania, for example, the first post-Communist Government was enthusiastic about a stock market, calling on the I.F.C. in 1990 to start the process. A team of experts arrived in November 1991, but two months later the Communist Party was voted back into power. Though work on the exchange continued, a subtle harassment campaign was begun against the consultants, said Mary Ellen Iskenderian, who oversaw the project for the agency.
"The first housing was at this old Government resort that was an hour-and-a-half drive out of Bucharest," she said. "It was perceived as a kind of harassment, that they don't want us."
The market officially opened last July, but trading has been put off several times, in part because of a stalled privatization program. Trading is now scheduled to begin Dec. 1.
In fact, privatization, along with controlling inflation and unemployment, is among the key requirements for a stock exchange. The goal is to reach a critical mass of about 20 listed companies.
In West Africa, the agency is trying to get around the shortcomings of individual countries by linking up the seven members of an economic and monetary union.
This regional market would replace the Abidjan Stock Exchange in the Ivory Coast, which has suffered for years, in part because of the requirement, until recently, that prices could not go down.
The new market, which will also include Benin, Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger, Senegal and Togo, is expected to have about 60 listed companies when it opens a year from now.
The ultimate test of the agency's work, of course, is what becomes of a market when it is on its own. The prognosis for the Lusaka exchange would appear to be good, despite its light trading so far. In fact, a second company, Shoprite-Checkers, a supermarket operator, is scheduled to be listed in a few weeks.
Ms. Hay of Morgan Stanley is already paying attention. "It's one that we're watching," she said, "and it's one that will be in the Africa Fund at some point."

HEADLINE: Cuba Libre, and Benetton, Too

BYLINE: By Andrew Meier; Andrew Meier writes often about the former Soviet bloc.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Thanks to a Cubana Air flight from a West Indian isle, I recently joined the growing number of Americans who have crossed a final frontier of the cold war. Cuba is one of the hottest destinations in this hemisphere. The tourists may go for sun and sand, but they also bring change. And if enough Americans went, they could bring down their Government's embargo.
Quite a few yanquis are already there. Cuba may be Communism's last haven, a Galapagos of the cold war, but more and more American executives are scouting the terrain. On Oct. 6, the day Mr. Clinton relaxed travel restrictions, Time Warner escorted an entourage of corporate executives to dine with the aging dictator in Havana. (Mr. Castro's table included the heads of G.M., Lockheed, the Gap, Sears, Kmart, Hyatt and two dozen other giants.) 
 Most Americans still have to go via Mexico or the Bahamas or Latin America. As you'd expect, they are an odd collection. There was the author of best-selling thrillers, who confessed, when caught by surprise in a pizzeria near the old Havana Hilton, that he had come in search of material. There was the Southern Baptist, on leave from his floor-tiling business in Georgia, who had come to save the souls, as he put it, of "the voodoo shell-flickers."
Most surprising were the yanqui prospectors eager to make the most of Mr. Castro's fading memory of Marxism. "Hundreds of American businessmen have been here," said a correspondent who has lived in Cuba for years. "They know the place is coming up for sale."
Cuba drifts somewhere between Communism and capitalism. In an air-conditioned hotel room in Havana you watch Bosnians on CNN waiting for bread, while a block away, in the ruins of a colonial villa, men carry home buckets of water five flights up marble stairs. You pay everywhere in dollars and get change in the tourists-only currency (convertible to the dollar at one-to-one). At a hotel bar you have two Coca-Colas, one from Mexico, one from Canada. (Like the Campbell's and Gerber's in the dollars-only stores, they are the forbidden fruit of Nafta.) The Oklahoma oil-and-gas man next to you orders a Jack Daniels and a pack of Marlboros.
In Havana, in short, you find yourself wondering, "What embargo?"
It's a nation open for business. AT&T, Sprint and M.C.I. have provided long-distance links. Benetton has billboards next to faded portraits of Che Guevara. Adidas and Mizuno sponsor Cuban athletes. The Italians have come to sell cars, the Canadians to dig for minerals, the Israelis to plant citrus groves, the Spanish to run resorts.
In its strange intermezzo, Cuba has the same desperate characters I saw in Moscow a few years ago. The pubescent prostitutes in search of exit visas are outnumbered only by the hard-currency scavengers who sense opportunity. But the end may not loom so near for the old guerrilla. Fear pervades Mr. Castro's island, and there is no sign of any Cubano Lech Walesa mobilizing in the cigar factories. Mr. Castro's move in September to allow businesses wholly owned by foreigners will only fortify Cubans with dollars, who are the backbone of his rule.
Americans who want to bring democracy and free enterprise to Cuba needn't be stopped by the embargo. They can go, now, and trade with the enemy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 909 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

BOND OF IRON: Master and Slave at Buffalo Forge
By Charles B. Dew. Norton, $14.
 The author provides a detailed portrait of economic and social life at a Virginia ironworks before and after the Civil War. He shows that the industrial skills of the black slave laborers afforded them an autonomy that was unheard of in agriculture. He "complicates and enriches our understanding of the human as well as the larger social and economic meaning of American slavery," Drew Gilpin Faust said here last year.
 
COME ALONG WITH ME: Part of a Novel, Sixteen Stories, and Three Lectures
By Shirley Jackson. Edited by Stanley Edgar Hyman. Penguin, $10.95.
 Long before anyone had heard of Stephen King, a New England writer was turning out stories about the macabre and the surreal, and how frequently they could be found in small towns. This anthology includes Shirley Jackson's best-known story, "The Lottery," as well as her last, unfinished novel and some intriguing insights into her fiction. In 1968 our reviewer, Guy Davenport, said: "Only things haunted by our own touch are worth having; our hell is to live with things haunted by another's hands. Shirley Jackson knew better than any writer since Hawthorne the value of haunted things."
 

MEA CUBA
By Guillermo Cabrera Infante.
Translated by Kenneth Hall with the author.
Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $15.
 This collection of essays often celebrates Cuban intellectuals while cursing the regime that has crushed many of them, particularly homosexuals. Written by a Cuban expatriate and novelist, these pieces create "a moving chronicle of love and despair for the country he lost to Castro," Alma Guillermoprieto said in these pages last year. The origins of that loss are explored in CONTESTING CASTRO: The United States and the Triumph of the Cuban Revolution, by Thomas G. Paterson (Oxford University, $14.95). The author argues that by backing the dictator Fulgencio Batista and by ignoring the causes of Cuban discontent, the United States helped create the Communist nation at its doorstep. He "succeeds admirably . . . in telling a story that is crucial to understanding the frigid standoff" between the two countries, Thomas Carothers wrote here in 1994.
 
EATING PAVLOVA
By D. M. Thomas. Carroll & Graf, $10.95.
 What if Freud had written a memoir? In this fiction the dying psychoanalyst tells his daughter Anna of adventures, amorous and otherwise, that may or may not be imagined. Last year our reviewer, James R. Kincaid, said, "Stoic wit sustains . . . this extraordinary novel."
 
VOYAGE TO THE GREAT ATTRACTOR: Exploring
Intergalactic Space
By Alan Dressler. Vintage, $13.
 A young astronomer relates the bumpy journey -- both scientific and personal -- that led him and six colleagues to conclude that a vast region of space is being pulled toward some huge yet undiscovered mass called "the great attractor." The book "reads like a novel, with strong characters, conflicts and suspense," Dennis Overbye wrote in the Book Review last year. Cutting-edge science is also the subject of THE QUARK AND THE JAGUAR: Adventures in the Simple and the Complex, by Murray Gell-Mann (W. H. Freeman, $15.95). In it a Nobel Prize-winning physicist explains that it is the tendency of complex systems to emerge from simple ones. "His intellectual power shows through," David Lindley said here last year.
 
TAFT
By Ann Patchett. Ivy, $5.99.
 Fate and circumstance create an unlikely alliance between the narrator, a black bar manager and former bluesman, and two working-class white teen-agers who have recently lost their father. Last year our reviewer, Diana Postlethwaite, said, "Ann Patchett is unique: a generous, fearless and startlingly wise young writer."
 
SEX AND SUITS
By Anne Hollander. Kodansha Globe, $13.
 Everyone knows that tailored clothing is enduring -- but erotic? The author, an art historian, argues that the basic man's suit is both an expression of the modernist esthetic and the wearer's virility. "Her book is a masterly endorsement of fashion's bid to be included among the modern arts," Bill Blass wrote here in 1994.
 
WEST OF YESTERDAY, EAST OF SUMMER: New and
Selected Poems (1973-1993)
By Paul Monette. St. Martin's, $9.95.
 These works bear witness to the poet's life, from early places and events to the advent of AIDS, which eventually claimed two of his lovers and finally himself. The newest are "moving in their anger and their mourning," one critic wrote in 1994. Also reissued is LAST WATCH OF THE NIGHT: Essays Too Personal and Otherwise (Harvest/ Harcourt Brace, $12), which include Monette's reflections on topics from gay politics to his own mortality. "His outrage and passionate convictions drive this book," Claudia Ricci wrote in these pages last year.
 
HUNTERS & GATHERERS
By Geoff Nicholson. Tusk/Overlook, $10.95.
 Steve Geddes is writing a book about collectors. This fictional account of his research shows how even disparate things can be linked. The novel is "clever, entertaining and intriguing," Eric Kraft said in the Book Review earlier this year.
 
BAD HAIRCUT: Stories of the Seventies
By Tom Perrotta. Berkley, $6.99.
 Set in New Jersey, where the author grew up, these 10 tales recount the coming of age of the narrator, Buddy. Mr. Perrotta "carefully details the texture of his childhood world," Jennifer Howard wrote in these pages in 1994. LAUREL GRAEBER

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1595 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: By Douglas Durst;
A Savvy Developer Who Marches to His Own Beat

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
BACK in the summer of 1987, the Durst Organization began building 114 West 47th Street. It was a time when developers were putting up huge office towers all over the West Side, certain that the appetite for high-priced space would never be slaked.
Not Seymour B. Durst. He did not build until United States Trust signed on for more than half the building. And if U.S. Trust were to back out, he said at the time, "we won't proceed further than the excavation." U.S. Trust didn't, the building went up on schedule and, unlike other towers of the time, it remained fiscally sound. 
 Now fast-forward to the fall of 1995. Most developers will not consider building without a tenant in tow. But not Seymour's son, Douglas. He wants to build an office tower on the east side of Broadway, between 42d and 43d Streets -- on spec. In fact, he just took $215 million in first mortgages on three of his other buildings to do so.
"My father understood that the market was overbuilt in 1987, and I understand that space is scarce in 1995," Douglas Durst said.
Spoken in true Durst contrarian fashion! Ever since Joseph Durst, Seymour's father, started the company in 1915, the Dursts have marched to their own drum sounds.
They bailed out of residential properties in the 1940's, as soon as rent control was installed. They embraced the Grand Central area, building office towers on Third Avenue when most developers thought the market stopped at Fifth Avenue, and on Sixth Avenue when those same rivals doubted that corporations would place their headquarters that far west.. And while other real estate families built downtown, or outside city limits, the Dursts stubbornly stuck to midtown in the 40's.
"My father would not build anything he could not walk to," Douglas Durst recalled.
Five years ago, the Dursts sued to stop four buildings from going up on Times Square, saying that adding that much space would destroy the market. They lost the suit -- but the economy did what the courts did not, and the towers have yet to be built.
Now, Douglas Durst thinks the time to build is here. He may be right. According to RELocate, which tracks rental space, only about 18 percent of the 215 million square feet of office space in midtown is less than 15 years old. Only five of the newer buildings have large blocks of contiguous space.
"I don't think Douglas is dreaming," said Stephen B. Siegel, the Edward S. Gordon Company's president. "On a limited basis, this market can absorb new construction."
Nor are many new buildings in the offing. Brokers say that HRO International is very close to getting a tenant -- and thus, financing -- for a new tower at Madison Avenue and 47th Street. The only other possible project -- the tower that Rockefeller Center Development Corporation wants to build at 49th Street and Seventh Avenue -- has been indefinitely sidelined. The tower must use the air rights from some of Rockefeller Center's bankrupt buildings, and the bankruptcy court now controls those rights.
"Even if the air rights were settled tomorrow, it could take three years before we started building," said Jonathan D. Green, the Development Corporation's president.
The Dursts, in contrast, are raring to go. When Seymour Durst died, at age 81, last May, he left a legacy of nearly 5 million square feet of office space, in eight buildings that, brokers say, are invariably well maintained, modernized and realistically priced -- and thus, almost fully rented. They are also all within an easy walk of each other.
The 50-year-old Douglas, now the company's president (the Durst mantle of leadership normally passes by seniority, but Douglas's older brother, Robert, is uninterested), is holding to his father's ideas of constant capital improvement and geographic tightness. But otherwise, he will not march lock-step to the beat his father heard.
"There may not be substantial differences, but there will be subtle changes in methods and approaches," he said.
The changes thus far have not at all been subtle. Douglas Durst is looking for equity partners for the Times Square tower; his father was a development loner. Seymour Durst would only build as-of-right; his son is quite willing to negotiate zoning rules.
And while the father stuck to his real estate knitting, the son believes in diversification, particularly when it dovetails with his personal interests. Douglas Durst is an avid supporter of the arts; this year the Durst Organization co-produced "Hamlet" on Broadway. Douglas Durst and his wife, Susanne, are avid equestrians and environmentalists who have long used horse manure to enrich the soil on their 300-acre organic farm in Northeast, N.Y. (Miscellaneous fact: Eli Zabar sells Durst tomatoes at his Vinegar Factory.) Now the Durst Organization is talking to an Italian company about a joint venture in composting.
Mr. Durst makes no apologies for stamping such a personal imprimatur on the company. "I am making the decisions now," he said. "So far, I've been pretty successful."
INDEED he has. Douglas Durst joined his father's firm in 1968, armed with a bachelor's degree in economics. For his first decade, he spent a lot of time handling personal residential projects, learning the management side of the business, and familiarizing himself with the company's buildings and leases. By the 1980's he was ready to immerse himself in deal-making.
Today, his 39-year-old cousin, Jonathan (known as Jody), handles operations, while his cousin Joshua, 37, handles residential properties and development sites.
Deal-making remains Douglas's bailiwick, but he does not rule by fiat. About three years ago he led negotiations with the Internal Revenue Service, which has since moved into 1133 Avenue of the Americas, which spans 43d to 44th Streets. The deal was complex, involving carving a side entrance to the building and sealing off an entire floor to satisfy zoning density rules.
Others at the negotiating table remember him as clearly in charge of the deal but ready to take advice from his cousins, from the tenants, even from brokers.
"Douglas is a leader, but he leads through team effort," said Carol Nelson, Gordon's executive vice president. Joseph Siegel, an I.R.S. executive, concurred. "Douglas's style was to work through other people," he said. "He's clearly on top, but he knows how to delegate."
What he does not know how to do, Mr. Siegel said, is make small talk. "Douglas is more curt than other developers," he said.
Indeed, in an industry rife with tales of tantrums and scenes, there are few stories circulating about any of the Dursts.
"Interesting anecdotes come about from problem deals," said Ira Schuman, an executive vice president at Julien J. Studley. "With the Dursts, there's no screaming or histrionics; it's just boring and reliable."
And it seems that Douglas Durst, while not humorless, is known as particularly taciturn. "He doesn't like fluff and he doesn't say a lot, and what he does say, he has thought through," said Tara I. Stacom, a Cushman & Wakefield senior director. Added Mary Ann Tighe, a Gordon executive managing director who worked on the I.R.S. deal: "Seymour's sense of humor was elfin and twinkly, Doug's is ironic and deadpan."
Nor do tenants necessarily miss the social niceties. "We cut our deal with the Dursts in six weeks," said Robert J. Egan, a partner at the law firm Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler, which in 1994 moved to 1133 Avenue of the Americas. "Somewhere else, it might have taken six months."
One reason for the speed, several brokers note, is that Mr. Durst never lets his ego get involved in deals. They say he readily seeks advice, he is flexible on rents, and gives in to demands for such things as extra electricity, even if he feels they aren't warranted.
"He's more concerned with building a relationship than with getting the last 50 cents on a deal," said Josh N. Kuriloff, a Cushman & Wakefield senior director.
 BUT Mr. Durst does have a massive dose of economic pragmatism. For example, he is quite willing to rent space in prime office buildings to less than stellar retailers. One example: He rented the store at 201 East 42d Street to Conway's, a discounter.
"He goes for the best tenant available at the best rent he can get," said Benjamin Fox, a partner of New Spectrum.
("They were supposed to deliver a more upscale store, but the lease language wasn't as enforceable as we thought," said Mr. Durst.)
Mr. Durst says he is in "discussions" with Conway about the store's image. He is also, although he won't discuss it, probably in discussions about where his company goes from here.
Mr. Durst says that, despite his bullishness on the economy, he would not build a speculative office tower that did not hook up to the site the Dursts own to the east of the one on which he wants to build. Once he puts a tower on that site -- probably six years from now -- that's the end of the Durst commercial assemblages.
But, with no creditors or shareholders to satisfy, Mr. Durst can take his time deciding strategy. The chances of the company leaving family control are nil. Either Jody or Joshua will probably take over in a few decades. Yet another cousin, Kristopher, 23, is joining the company this year.
So far, none of Douglas's three children -- one son, 25, and two daughters, 18 and 27 -- have joined the business, but he does not rule it out. "When she was 8, my youngest daughter said she wanted to be president of this company some day," he said. "I wouldn't be surprised if she does it."

HEADLINE: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:

THE CONFIDENCE GAME
How Unelected Central Bankers
Are Governing the Changed
Global Economy.
By Steven Solomon.
Simon & Schuster, $30.
 While the title "The Confidence Game" might suggest another harangue against the power of central bankers, Steven Solomon argues that their independence is necessary. Hundreds of billions of dollars began flowing faster and faster through international financial markets in the 1980's, threatening to swamp any country's economic policies with little warning. In that environment, writes Mr. Solomon, a freelance financial journalist, "the democratic self-interest was increasingly best served by delegating monetary responsibility to an independent, nonpartisan cadre of internationally minded technocrats dedicated to continuity and financial order rather than relying on the right thing being done by foreign governments prone to political expedience, bouts of paralysis and incompetence." Despite the book's international theme, the focus is more on the Federal Reserve than the Bank of Japan or Germany's Bundesbank. Mr. Solomon is also more descriptive than analytical. Much of the book consists of a year-by-year -- and even month-by-month -- description of international monetary policy through the 80's and early 90's. But anyone who needs to know about recent international economic history -- particularly American college students in economics -- will find this book a solid review of the background to today's news. KEITH BRADSHER

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

ARTISTS AT WORK
Sixteen years ago several artists seeking inexpensive work space found some vacant buildings on Canal Street in the Industrial Park area of Stamford. Since then the artists' numbers have grown along with their status and they are called the Loft Artist Association. 
 Each year they have held an Open Studio Tour and the 1995 edition on Saturday and Sunday is supported by grants from the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, the Richard and Hinda Rosenthal Foundation and Heyman Properties. More than 35 painters, sculptors, photographers, performance artists, puppeteers and other creative tenants will be on hand from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. both days, exhibiting their work and their workplaces.
This year's event is dedicated to Reuben Nakian, the Stamford-based sculptor who died in 1986. A collection of his original plaster figures and cast bronzes, first moved into the complex 15 years ago, has been installed in its own new gallery.
Admission is free and visitors will be offered refreshments as they wander through the studios. To reach the site, at 737 Canal Street, take Exit 8 northbound from Interstate 95 onto Canal Street, or Exit 7 southbound and left onto Canal Street. For more information call 961-0658.
 
HOLLYWOOD TURKEYS
Tom Holehan and the Stratford Library have collected some of Hollywood's tackiest movies, dubbed them "The Turkey Film Festival," and scheduled them on Monday through Friday of this week. All screenings are at noon, uncut, free of charge, and audiences are welcome to bring bag lunches. Mr. Holehan, a director, arts critic and member of the library staff, will offer commentary on each film.
The first, "Butterfield 8," released in 1960 won an Oscar for Elizabeth Taylor. Some believe the award was mainly for Ms. Taylor's spunk during filming, when she experienced the first of many hospitalizations.
Tuesday's film, "Can't Stop the Music" (1980), puts Tammy Grimes, Valerie Perrine, June Havoc and Bruce Jenner in musical numbers reminiscent of parents' weekend at summer camp. In "Johnny Guitar" (1954) Joan Crawford and Mercedes McCambridge battle each other and the Old West in cowgirl outfits.
"Mandingo," produced in 1975, miscast James Mason as a bigoted Southern plantation owner. The final opus, "Bride of the Monster" (1956), starred Bela Lugosi and was directed by Ed Wood. The library is at 2203 Main Street and the phone number is 385-4162.
 
HANDMADE GIFTS
The line forms outside hours before the annual Christmas sale of the New Canaan Sewing Group opens. The group, which was founded in 1931, now numbers more than 100 women who contribute their handiwork and have made their organization a treasured source of gifts for Christmas, birthdays, graduations and other events.
Doors will open on Thursday at 10 A.M. at Waveny House in Waveny Park, 677 South Avenue, and close at 2 P.M. Not a lot of time to go through the plethora of needlework, decoupage, lace, table linens, pillows, doll clothes and furniture, miniatures of historic New Canaan buildings, handknitted sweaters and mittens.
Over the years the volunteers have contributed nearly $775,000 in profits to area charities and social agencies. Last year some 22 organizations shared $40,000 raised through the sale. (More information: 966-1171).
 
BEIJING TROUPE
The Central Ballet of China, appearing at Jorgensen Auditorium in Storrs on Tuesday at 8 P.M., combines folk idioms with the traditions of classical Russian ballet. Its dancers have been coached over the 34-year history of the company by such distinguished dancers and choreographers as Rudolf Nureyev and Beryl Grey.
The troupe, which is based in Beijing, deals artistically with repressive attitudes at home, as in the piece called "New Year's Sacrifice," wherein a forcibly married young Chinese bride is unveiled -- bound and gagged.
Other portions of the program are described as more balletic, contemporary, funny, and in "Pas de Quatre" show the power and style of the male members of the troupe.
Tickets at $10 to $14, with discounts for students and older people, may be reserved by calling 486-4226.
 
ALONG THE WATER
Connecticut's riverfront and shoreline areas are the focus of the third annual conference on preserving historic landscapes, organized by the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation. Titled "Where Land and Water Meet," the conference will take place on Wednesday from 8:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. at Water's Edge Inn in Westbrook.
Waterfronts, managed by various municipalities, are difficult to control regionally. Some areas --including Norwich, New London, Derby, Norwalk and Collinsville -- have embarked on redeveloping their waterfronts as centers of retailing and recreation. Many rural communities are faced with sewage systems designed for summer cottages that have in recent years become year-round homes surrounded by additional development of larger homes.
Guilford, Westbrook, Portland and Westport are experiencing severe pressure for development by commercial interests, and cities like New Haven, Hartford and Middletown would like to reopen public access to their waterways, which are currently cut off by highways and railroads.
Among the speakers in the morning session are Elizabeth Mills Brown, architectural historian from the Waterfront Center of Washington, D.C.; James Gibbons, planner, and Peter Patton, Wesleyan University professor.
Three workshops offered during the afternoon include a two-and-a-half-hour cruise on the Connecticut River, narrated by Bruce Yenawine of the Connecticut River Museum in Essex; a session on preservation and planning, and one on economic development by Charles Brilvitch, municipal historian from Bridgeport.
Advance registration is $50, $55 on the day, including lunch. The cruise costs an additional $20, and the conference plus a one-year membership in the trust is $70. Call 562-6312 to register or obtain more information.
 
IN A DEVIL'S DEN
A walk through the Devil's Den Nature Preserve in Weston will now be easier with the publication of a 48-page self-guide booklet available from a box at the map shelter in the parking lot. It costs $3, but may be borrowed free of charge if it is returned in good condition.
The Saugatuck region of the 1,720-acre preserve is featured, with 19 stations along the trail. The booklet is designed to accommodate visitors who complete a hike of the trail or who come back to finish their trek on another day. The booklet covers the ecosystem of the preserve, its biodiversity, watershed protection, trees, plants and animals, and human activity.
The booklet was written by Lillian Willis and illustrated by Dick Maccabe, edited and researched by Stephen Patton and Lise Hanners. The Nature Conservancy preserve may be reached via Route 57 off Exit 42 of the Merritt Parkway, east on Godfrey Road to Pent Road, which ends at the preserve's parking area.
For more information call 226-4991. ELEANOR CHARLES

LENGTH: 845 words

HEADLINE: CITY LIFE;
In Trenton, a Ditch That Was a Canal Fights for a Comeback

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
For most of its meandering route across central New Jersey, the Delaware and Raritan Canal is quiet and scenic, an extended waterfront park with a broad pathway where mules once pulled canal boats. Here in Trenton, it recalls this city's industrial prime of nearly a century ago, when barges carried coal and lumber through a thriving business district.
But for generations, the canal's Trenton section has been anything but thriving: a muddy, garbage-strewn ditch through a neighborhood of dilapidated houses and abandoned warehouses, of vacant lots roamed by drug dealers and vagrants who barely notice the nearby Battle Monument commemorating George Washington's first victory in the Revolutionary War. 
 Now, city officials are trying to restore the canal and its neighborhood to a semblance of their former selves through a $60 million Canal Banks project, which would rehabilitate houses and public spaces. Although the project has only begun, there are signs of progress: tractors churning, houses going up, pedestrian paths being blazed.
"For many years, the canal has almost been a negative, not a positive," said Mayor Douglas H. Palmer. "But the water gives any city a great opportunity to develop, and when you couple that with highway access, you have an area that has a lot of potential."
In fact, it was highway access that hastened the neighborhood's decline in the 1950's. With the construction of Routes 1 and 29, much of the traffic through the Battle Monument area, known as Five Points, was diverted from the inner city. By the early 90's, the area had become a drug hangout surrounded by bars and liquor stores. Today, unemployment in the neighborhood is 22 percent -- twice the city's average -- and a third of the 6,500 residents are below the poverty level.
In 1991, the city proposed a wide-ranging redevelopment project for the 265-acre Canal Banks Neighborhood Target Area. Alan Mallach, the city's director of housing and development, says the project has symbolic significance: Five Points is the geographical heart of the city, and the monument commemorates the battle that put Trenton on the map. And Trenton is, after all, the state capital.
Mr. Mallach says that although serious work has been going on for only a year or so, and not always smoothly, the progress is encouraging.
Take North 25 Park, an unsightly concrete jungle gym and unofficial drug center that was demolished last year and resodded this summer. (It takes its name from a nearby center for the elderly.) The city plans to add benches and playground equipment next year. It will do the same for the triangular Battle Monument Park, with new benches and other improvements expected by next summer.
Along the canal, a three-mile pedestrian and bicycle path is being cleared. Parallel to the canal will be a linear park along a former railroad right-of-way. Until this summer, that right-of-way was a drainage ditch, overflowing with debris and the nastiest of rodents. Now, part of the ditch has been paved over, flanked by newly planted trees and new curbs.
Another high priority is the rehabilitation of vacant but structurally sound buildings to create new housing, particularly for home buyers. About 150 homes have been built; the goal is 600 by 1999. At the same time, the city plans to redevelop several abandoned buildings, including an 11-acre Magic Marker factory on Calhoun Street, to attract businesses. A small shopping center has been planned along North Broad Street.
To pay for the project, the city has tapped a variety of sources: a state contribution of $3 million, from money that became available when the Richard J. Hughes Justice Center was refinanced; $1.5 million from the Capital City Redevelopment Corporation, a state agency, and assorted other millions from Federal, state and private grants. A total of $15 million has been spent on or committed to the project, but at least $40 million to $50 million is still needed, Mr. Mallach said.
Bill Valocchi, project coordinator for the Canal Banks redevelopment, said the early financing and work had provided a sort of foundation for the effort. But he added: "There are a lot of unknowns. If we couldn't continue the process, it could easily go back to the way it was."
Residents have largely supported the venture, although there have been some reservations about turning what has long been a business district into one that is mostly residential. Jeffrey W. Utley, owner of Willie's Restaurant on North Broad Street, is pleased with the project even though he must move his business up the road to clear the way for new housing.
"It's hard for me to get uprooted, but in the long run, it's going to pay off, not only for me, but the community and the city and the other people who have been dying for some changes," he said. "I hope it's contagious. If you live next door to someone who's always sloppy, and you clean up your own place, they're going to start catching on. And those who don't catch on are going to leave, because they'll stick out like a bad needle."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Delaware and Raritan Canal and the Battle Monument once formed the heart of Trenton. Now the city is restoring the area; this worker is straightening a curb. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Mrs. Whitman's First Lady

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
CHRISTABEL VARTANIAN says she has one of the best jobs in the Whitman administration: She is in charge of graciousness. For Ms. Vartanian, the job seems as tailor-made as the pink fitted jacket she wore one recent morning on a tour of the official mansion, Drumthwacket.
The job, head of protocol, pays $55,385 and is a new one -- for a very good reason. While Mrs. Whitman entered office equipped with a First Gentleman -- John Whitman, an investment banker -- he was not willing to take over traditional First Lady jobs: planning dinners, rescuing guests stranded awkwardly at official cocktail parties, presiding over household staff meetings, charming visiting legislators and business leaders. 
 So this Governor, the first woman to serve as New Jersey's head of state, needed her own First Lady -- someone unquestioningly loyal and discreet, with an ambassador's sense of propriety. Fittingly, she turned to her old friend, supporter and neighbor, Ms. Vartanian.
True to form, Ms. Vartanian rose to the challenge, and with characteristic graciousness. "I'm fortunate she asked me," she said.
But what does this new department actually do? For starters, Ms. Vartanian and her two assistants deal in details. They dig up new addresses for the holiday cards, approve the gilt state seal on the dinner invitations, coordinate the napkin colors with the tablecloths, procure fresh orange juice for the Saudi Ambassador while making sure the skirts of all women within his sight cover their knees. Through all of this, she eschews the limelight, letting credit fall on the Governor or the staff.
She is more than a social secretary, though. With the Governor's scheduler, she plots out Mrs. Whitman's days. Her charge is those social events that are really business, as opposed to the Governor's few social events that are actually for fun. Typical of a year's hundreds of occasions are a high tea for the Ambassador of Mongolia, a cocktail party for the Coalition for Lower Taxes, a luncheon for the Heavy Construction Coalition.
This particular morning, the occasion is a children's tour of the six formal downstairs rooms of Drumthwacket, the Governor's official mansion in Princeton. The upstairs rooms, like those in the White House, are private, for family living. The children are from Far Hills Country Day School, which the two Vartanian children -- Nishan, now 19 and at Rollins College, and Annabel, now 17 and at Blair Academy -- attended, along with the Whitman children.
Ms. Vartanian looks impeccable in her pink jacket with black trim over a black dress and black pumps -- an outfit reminiscent of those Jacqueline Kennedy wore as First Lady. There is, in fact, a vague resemblance, in the swinging dark hair and oval face with blusher-flushed cheeks.
"The Governor was really excited to hear you were coming," she tells a foyer filled with children, "and she was so sorry she couldn't be here."
If the Governor, in fact, had more pressing engagements than greeting a schoolchildren's tour, Ms. Vartanian gives no hint. She seems to be of a rapidly evaporating school of women who learned to soothe, to defer, to charm, to tip things into the most favorable light. And to be savvy while doing it. Of the gate-enclosed, antique-filled mansion surrounded by rolling lawns and gardens, attended by servants, she says, "Really, this is the people's house."
Only two statements approached anything like criticism: "The transition was not the smoothest thing," said said of the hand-off from the previous administration, and: "We don't want to criticize Giuliani's staff. I do believe he has someone in protocol." She was referring to the diplomatic uproar that ensued when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani forced Yasir Arafat to leave a concert during United Nations festivities in Manhattan.
Ms. Vartanian grew up in Clewiston, in South Florida, daughter of one of the town's most important men. Her father, Loyd Kelly, owned the Caterpillar tractor franchise in the country's biggest sugar-growing area.
SHE was valedictorian of Clewiston High School, and majored in theater and English at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla. She prefers to keep her age private, explaining, "I'm from the South." At Rollins, she met her husband, Paul, who now sells antique jewelry wholesale from an office in Manhattan. They moved to Long Island and then Bedminster. Through Governor Whitman's parents -- "such gracious people, so welcoming" -- she met John and Christie Whitman. That was around 1974. When Ms. Whitman ran for Governor, the Vartanians offered "moral support" and helped organize fund-raising events.
Accepting the new Governor's request to help out, Ms. Vartanian found herself immediately facing a weeklong series of parties for the World Cup soccer championships. She needed to identify, find addresses for, invite and prepare for 3,000 guests
"I had no lists," she said. Lists, and lists of lists, are her basic tools.
She and Rachel Donington, an assistant, began by drawing up alphabetical categories: Assembly members, senators, cabinet members, celebrities and members of the clergy, the press and sports figures. They asked friends and acquaintances. They looked up Italian and German corporate divisions in the state -- for the countries playing -- and invited the chief operating officers. They came up with 22 computer-printed pages of names and addresses of prominent people to invite to the parties.
Ms. Vartanian shopped until she found the perfect fabric for tablecloths -- a soccer-ball print -- and had soccer-ball invitations printed. She located New Jersey singers and musicians.
Her philosophy of party-giving is to "get the big picture." Menus, caterers, decorations and entertainment -- all revolve around that.
If the World Cup parties were "lighthearted," sporty, the Vietnam Veterans Memorial fund-raising event was "patriotic." There, she arranged for life-sized bronze statues of a wounded soldier, his buddy and a nurse to be placed in the center of the big tent on the lawn. The state troopers' bagpipe and drum corps played.
"It was wonderful they had that opportunity," said Ms. Vartanian, apparently referring to both the musicians and the guests.
"It was fabulous," said Ms. Donington, who is 26, and postponed law school for this "only happens once" job. "They loved it."
Ms. Vartanian: "We try to make people comfortable."
Ms. Donington: "People are so enthusiastic. It's so rewarding."
Referring to the Governor, Ms. Vartanian said: "Of course our parties are only as good as she is." In setting the tone of events, she added, "we want to reflect how the Governor would like things to be; we think of that first."
Ms Donington: "We make the style. Style is just as important as strong policies."
The heart of the style and the protocol is Drumthwacket, 150 years old, with its busts and portraits of George Washington and its thick curtains and archways, three chiming grandfather clocks and brilliantly shined oval desk for signing bills into law. The mansion is grand and lovely, like a period museum, and so formal that both the footsteps and voices of the staff members, volunteers and docents seem muffled, hushed. Even the iced tea is striking, made by a Drumthwacket recipe that includes fresh mint grown in the garden.
Drumthwacket, Ms. Donington said, "is perfect." And she went on: "It's karma. Good things happen at a place where good people are doing the good things."
Those things, by necessity, include feeding and amusing some 10,000 guests a year. Inexorably, the parties continue -- tea for 100 from the Federation of Jewish Women, a reception for the 80 members of the Garden Club of New Jersey, dinner for the Mexican Economic Trade Summit, a group of 20.
In addition Ms. Vartanian and Ms. Donington are planning Mr. Whitman's project for governor's spouses. This year the theme is "children and violence," and Mr. Whitman and Ms. Vartanian are trying to get a "Just say no to violence" campaign going. They're starting with a poster contest for juvenile offenders.
MEANWHILE, there are everyday crises. Making sure, for instance, that extra place settings are removed from banquet tables, something the White House staff neglected, Ms. Vartanian once noted when she was there. Or if, as she has done, Governor Whitman makes a last-minute appearance somewhere. It happened recently when Pope John Paul II arrived at Newark International Airport. To make sure the Governor had a chair, somebody hastily handed one over the fence to somebody else, who put it on the tarmac minutes before the Governor walked over. "Too last-minute for me," Ms. Vartanian said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Christabel Vartanian, the Governor's protocol director, at Drumthwacket, where politics and socializing intersect. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
After Assassination, Israel Is a Fragile Market

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
AS a shaken Israel recovers from the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli financial markets are girding for two big tests in coming weeks.
Ever important will be the participation of American and other foreign investors, who had been moving into Israel in recent months, but who may now remain on the sidelines for the short term. 
 Perhaps they have good reason. The Israeli markets are likely to be fragile and volatile, with poor earnings from even a single company -- like the disappointing report last week from the high-technology manufacturer Elbit -- capable of sending the entire market down. The Mishtanim index of 100 stocks on the Tel Aviv stock exchange fell 1.8 percent in extremely light trading last week.
Well before the Rabin assassination, the stock market had been depressed, hurting even well-regarded companies like ECI Telecommunications Ltd., Bezeq, Tadiran and Teva Pharmaceutical.
The first big test for the Israeli markets since the assassination will come as early as this week, with a nearly $130 million stock sale in the United States for Koor Industries, a Tel Aviv-based conglomerate that is a mirror of the Israeli economy.
A second test will come later this month when Israel seeks to sell $250 million of government bonds.
But in the long run, Israeli and American financial analysts say the biggest test will be the ability of the Government of Shimon Peres, Mr. Rabin's successor, to continue the peace process and to calm the political waters at home. A signal of his success or lack thereof could come in elections as early as February. If a Peres Government manages to provide stability for the Israeli political system, it would build confidence among American, European and other foreign investors, the market watchers said.
For all the foreign investors now getting cold feet, "there are many, many more who have not invested at all and are actively considering it," said Lior Bregman, an Israeli market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company. "Israel, you must remember, is a country that performs better in crisis than under normal circumstances."
Israel has the largest nonoil economy in the region, and a growing number of financial analysts say it has been unfairly lumped with emerging markets like Mexico, now suffering from a currency crisis.
Having absorbed a flood of immigrants from the former Soviet Union, Israel continues a remarkable transformation from a war economy to a powerful peacetime economy whose principal export markets are Western Europe, North America and Asia. Its gross domestic product will probably rise this year by more than 6.5 percent.
Foreign investors have finally started to move into Israel, including such marquee names as Nestle, Cable and Wireless, Intel, Motorola and even Roy Disney, the nephew of Walt Disney, whose Shamrock Holdings is already a big investor in Koor.
The market reception of Koor's planned sale of nearly seven million American depositary receipts this week will be closely watched. The sale has already been delayed a week, in part because of the Rabin assassination but also because of concern over market demand. Koor, with nearly $3 billion in 1994 revenue, is Israel's largest industrial group. It has interests in Tadiran, a maker of telecommunications equipment; Makhteshim Chemical Works, a pesticide maker; Nesher Israel Cement Enterprises, a construction company, and Sonol Israel, one of the country's largest chain of gas stations. "You buy Koor and you are buying Israel," Mr. Bregman said.
As is often the case in the Middle East, the outlook for business in Israel is complex. True, the Likud party has moved a bit from the right toward the center over the years, and the socialist-leaning Labor party, the party of Mr. Rabin and Mr. Peres, has moved somewhat toward the center as well. Both support similar economic policies, like privatization and the deregulation of financial markets and of foreign investments.
But the remaining differences are significant. If Likud, led by Benjamin Netanyahu, wins the election, it may return to its past policy of devoting hundreds of millions of dollars to Israeli settlements in the occupied territories. Besides provoking the Arabs, such an action would drain money from the Labor party's program of building roads, modernizing telephone service and other public spending that is critical to business.
Whatever the bumps along the way, the peace process may be inevitable. "Peace is on automatic pilot," said David Rosenberg, research director for Pacific Mediterranean Capital Markets Group, a research firm in Herzliya, a Tel Aviv suburb. "Short of disavowing the Oslo agreement, Netanyahu has to go through with it."
But even peace has its implications for business. Should Syria reach an agreement with Israel on the disputed Golan Heights, defense spending would rise temporarily, mainly to pay for redeploying military bases, curbing civilian spending.
No matter which party takes control of the country, it will have to deal with some clouds hanging over the economy and the financial markets. Inflation, tame until recently, threatens to flare, though not to the ruinous 400 percent levels of the 1980's. Now exceeding 7.5 percent annually, inflation could reach double digits next year.
Interest rates, recently stable, appear to have nowhere to go but up. Israelis are already paying a real interest rate of nearly 8 percent, compared with 3 percent or so in the United States. And the burgeoning trade deficit is likely to double to more than $10 billion this year.
"You somehow have to find a way to finance this growing trade deficit," said Victor Halpert, who follows Israeli securities for Salomon Brothers in London. "But Israelis themselves, disappointed with the performance of the stock market last year, are not participating in stocks. Therefore, Israel needs more foreign investment and must borrow more money through the sale of bonds."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MADISON SQUARE;
Baruch Plans Hung Up as S.R.O. Holdouts Hang On

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
When Jim Davis looks at the Hotel Gramercy, a shabby warren of tiny rooms in a faded brick building at 24th Street and Lexington Avenue, he sees a bit of New York history -- a single-room occupancy hotel devoid of crack and crime, a haven for genteel people who happen to be down-at-the-heels. (Murray Kempton, the writer, planned to spend a night in the hotel and ended up staying for three years in the late 1970's, said Mr. Davis, an unemployed construction worker and handbag designer.)
But when officials from the state's Dormitory Authority look at the sagging seven-story hotel, which is said to be more than a century old, they see a potential roadblock in the final phase of a proposed multi-million dollar project that will consolidate Baruch College, which is now housed in six leased buildings from 18th to 26th Streets. (The first phase, a $159 million library and technology center, opened at 151 East 25th Street, in September 1994.) 
 The Dormitory Authority would like to demolish the Gramercy and the Amsterdam Hotel, once a crime-ridden S.R.O., as well as most of the other buildings in an area bounded by 24th and 25th Streets and Lexington and Third Avenues to make room for a $270 million, 416,800-square-foot hulk that will house classrooms, academic offices, physical education facilities and an auditorium. Demolition is scheduled to begin next spring.
The problem is that 19 scrappy residents of the Gramercy and the Amsterdam will not budge. They are appealing a State Supreme Court decision granting the Dormitory Authority a condemnation order; a hearing is set for December. "This is a David and Goliath story," Mr. Davis said.
Donald Eng, a lawyer with David Rozenholc & Associates, a Manhattan firm representing nine of the tenants, added: "Baruch can expand without taking S.R.O. units. You're going to have more homeless people on the street."
In 1991, John Egan, the former executive director of the Dormitory Authority, promised Community Board 6 that displaced S.R.O. tenants would be relocated within the neighborhood in equal or better housing and that 155 units of S.R.O. housing would be built in the neighborhood to replace the demolished units.
The Dormitory Authority doesn't dispute this. But now, it says Mr. Egan was not authorized by the State Legislature to build replacement housing. "It was not a legal promise," said Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the Dormitory Authority, adding that the agency is not obligated to relocate the remaining tenants but has hired a relocation company and a social worker to help them find housing. Residents of the S.R.O.'s say they have been interviewed by the relocation company, Relocation Management Associates, but have not been shown any new housing.
The former owner of the Gramercy and Amsterdam, LB Oil Company, stopped renting rooms when residents died or moved away. Some were harassed into leaving, said Mr. Davis, citing heating and electrical problems that went unattended. John E. Tuchler, who managed the buildings for LB Oil, denied any campaign of harassment and added that all tenants were offered $7,500 to leave.
But the remaining tenants deny they were offered a financial incentive. "Why would they offer money to an old bird like me?" said Lawrence Clayton, 89, a 22-year resident of the Gramercy. "I'm not worried, though. I'll just marry some rich old lady about 120 years old and I'll be set." MONTE WILLIAMS

GRAPHIC: Photos: "This place has character," said Lawrence Clayton, 89, who has lived in the Gramercy for 22 years. "The Gramercy is charming and quaint, just like me. In my last few years, I just want to enjoy my leisure and talk to myself."; "I've always wanted to live in New York," said Jim Davis, 51, who grew up in Trenton, N.J. "The Gramercy allowed me to live in New York. The Gramercy is magic. A lot of Runyonesque characters used to live here."; "Who does the Dormitory Authority think it is?" said Gosse Eppinga, 67, a retired waiter and bartender, who has lived at the Gramercy for 12 years. "It can't just push people around. There are no other places for us to go. You don't uproot old trees." (Photographs by Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Future View: Reorganized Industry, Change in Sales

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
BRACE for a complete reorganization of the investment management business in the United States, Goldman, Sachs & Company says. A host of pension funds, mutual funds and institutions now manage $6 trillion, but rising costs and global competition will reduce the field to a handful of dominant companies and many small specialty firms, Goldman predicts in a recent report, "The Coming Evolution of the Investment Management Industry: Opportunities and Strategies."
In the mutual fund industry, Goldman expects several big changes in how funds are distributed to investors. For now, there are simply too many funds vying for too few assets, meaning that brokers, financial advisers and others who distribute funds have considerable leverage over fund companies and can demand high fees for their services for the foreseeable future. 
 But there will continue to be a movement away from products sold by full-service brokers, who impose sales charges of perhaps 5 percent of the amount invested, according to Goldman. For investors who want advice, financial planners will be the distributor of choice, Goldman predicted. Their fees are relatively low, at 1 percent to 1.5 percent of assets under management. Also, the financial interests of planners and investors can be aligned, whereas brokers may have incentives to sell specific funds.
In the "do it yourself" camp, investors will probably shift away from dealing with fund companies directly and toward electronic systems. Discount brokers like Charles Schwab and Fidelity Brokerage already allow investors to make fund purchases from many companies through them and then send out consolidated statements of fund holdings, reducing the paperwork. (Along the way, no-load fund companies may rely more heavily on electronic distributors to whom they pay a toll.)
But electronic distribution and financial advisers will help investors understand the taxes on and risks of their holdings. With more knowledge about taxes, investors may flee from funds with both taxable and tax-deferred money in search of the best treatment for each. Companies will probably respond with more products for those interested in minimizing taxes.
Investors now have trouble determining risk, partly because many managers have broad authority and because disclosure of holdings must be made only twice a year. With better information about risk from advisers and electronic services, investors may demand changes.
 
Through a Glass Ceiling
 Women keep showing up as managers of the leading money market funds. Among the seven taxable money fund categories, women ran the top-performing funds in five categories as of Sept. 22, said IBC's Money Market Insight, an industry newsletter. That quirk prompted an IBC survey, which found that 43.3 percent of the 987 money funds are run by women. (Funds with more than one manager were excluded from the survey.) By comparison, women run just 11.5 percent of stock funds and 13.8 percent of taxable bond funds. They show up more often at municipal bond funds, at 22 percent.
A money fund is generally considered a stepping stone to a stock or bond fund, said Tracy Burk, the editor of IBC's Money Fund Report in Ashland, Mass. There are fewer securities to analyze in money funds than in stock and bond funds. The concentration of women reflects their recent entry in the money management business, Ms. Burk said, and suggests that many will move to the stock and bond side in coming years.
As to questions about bias, the women who manage money funds did not express complaints. "Performance is so critical that sponsors don't care who is running the money, as long as they are doing a good job," Ms. Burk said.
 
What's Insured And What's Not
 Too many people are confusing mutual funds with bank certificates of deposit and other insured products, causing concern at the National Association of Securities Dealers.
The N.A.S.D., a self-regulating group of the securities industry, has proposed rules intended for banks and others that sell a variety of investments, some insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and some uninsured.
Among other things, the proposal stipulates that banks should sell mutual funds in an area separate from where they take deposits. Even then, it says, customers should be told that the funds are not insured and are not deposits of the bank, meaning that customers could lose their money.
In addition, bank tellers or others without N.A.S.D. clearance could not be offered cash or any other incentive for customer referrals that result in fund sales.
 
Giving Israel A Chance
 The Growth Fund of Israel, from the New England Funds in conjunction with Bn'ai B'rith and the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, will invest in equities issued by companies based in Israel or that derive a large part of their revenues there.
The fund will be managed by David Herro and Adam Schor, both of Harris Associates, a Chicago unit of New England Mutual. Mr. Herro manages Oakmark International, and Mr. Schor has served as an analyst at that fund since 1992. Batucha Securities, a Tel Aviv money manager, serves as economic subadviser. The initial subscription period is scheduled to start Jan 15.
Since being acquired by New England Mutual, Harris has been busy. It is adding three funds to its Oakmark group, bringing the total to five. The new trio are Oakmark Balanced, which will own a mix of stocks and bonds; Oakmark Small Cap, which will own securities in companies with market capitalizations of less than $1 billion, and International Emerging Value, which looks for companies in the emerging markets or small-cap firms in any foreign country.
 
New Funds
 PBHG Technology and Communications will own shares of companies involved with computer software or hardware, network and cable broadcasting, military and aerospace, biotechnology and similar fields. It will be run by John Force and James Smith, both of whom recently joined the fund's sponsor, Pilgrim Baxter & Associates. Mr. Force was a vice president and portfolio manager at Fiduciary Management Associates. Mr. Smith was a senior vice president at Selected Financial Services. Both previously managed small-cap stock funds.
Kemper Value and Growth aims for growth of capital through a mix of growth stocks (issued by companies whose earnings are expected to grow rapidly) and value stocks (priced low relative to their predicted earnings). The growth portion of the portfolio is managed by Kemper and the value portion by Dreman Value Advisors, a recent acquisition of Kemper. Its sales charge equals 5.75 percent.
Phoenix Strategic Theme looks for stocks that the managers believe capitalize on social, economic and political trends, and Phoenix Small Cap invests in companies with a market capitalization of less than $500 million. The sales charge is 4.75 percent.
 
Manager Changes
 Jacques P. Perold, most recently vice president of structured trading for Fidelity Investments, was named manager of its Deutsche mark, Sterling and Yen Performance funds, succeeding Scott B. Kuldell, who keeps the reins of Fidelity Short-Term World Income.
Eric Ende, a senior analyst with First Pacific Advisers, has taken the reins of FPA Perennial from Chris Linden, who needed to reduce his role for health reasons.
P. Nicholas Edwards, formerly of Jardine Fleming Investment Advisers, Tokyo, has joined the management team of Warburg Pincus International Equity.
Robert J. Milnamow has taken over a top-performing fund from the Oppenheimer Management Corporation. Mr. Milnamow is managing the Main Street Income & Growth fund, recently vacated by John Wallace. Mr. Milnamow was formerly the manager of another growth-and-income fund, Phoenix Total Return.
 
Merger
 The Oppenheimer Management Corporation signed an agreement to acquire the Rochester Funds, subject to approval by Rochester shareholders. The funds to be acquired are Rochester Fund Municipals, Limited Term New York Municipal and the Bond Fund for Growth.
 
In Brief
 Janus 20, a fund closed to new investors since January 1993, reopened on Nov. 1.
Multiple Class Calculator, a computer program that examines the cost to investors of various fund payment plans, like A shares versus D shares, is available for Windows from Money Marketing Inc. of Brooklyn.
Prudential Securities has a Virtual Branch Office on the World Wide Web (http://www.prusec.com) with daily market commentary by Prudential market analysts and an educational section on investments, including an investment personality quiz. In the first quarter of next year, Prudential expects to provide clients with access to statements, portfolio allocations and E-mail to financial advisers, among other things.
The Value Line Fund Analyzer, a software program for Windows, lets investors rank, analyze and track mutual fund performance. It includes graphs illustrating historical risk, written analyses of more than 1,500 funds and "portfolio modules," which allow investors to construct and evaluate various fund portfolios. The program is linked to Value Line Online, a service that gives users access to weekly data updates, technical support, recent fund news and more. The CD-ROM package costs $295; an enhanced version, which will display and print full-page research reports on funds covered by the Value Line Mutual Fund Survey, costs $395.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 34; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The Plain Truth About Wellesley

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was pleased to be highlighted in your article "How to Succeed? Go to Wellesley" (Oct. 29). Please note, however, that I am not above the glass ceiling, just scrunched more tightly underneath it. Were I a man, I would be the chief economist for all of CS First Boston, not just for the equities department. Wall Street is still diversity unfriendly at the top. 
 More generally, you missed the common denominator for why Wellesley graduates succeed in business -- ordinary, boring diligence. I majored in chemistry, not economics, never formed any network from college or among fellow alums whom I met after college -- nor did other women I knew. The dominant characteristic I have observed in Wellesley graduates is that we all work like crazy. The school obviously selects on this basis, perpetuating its record.
If this hypothesis is correct, it should serve as advice to others. A fancy education, a sharp mind, associating with like-minded acquaintances will help in business success. But nothing is more valuable than hard work.
 
ROSANNE M. CAHN
Manhattan, Oct. 31
 
The writer is a member of the Wellesley class of 1966.
