HEADLINE: Euro-Slash;
Deficit-Cutting's International

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THE proclamations of Europe's political leaders these days could make House Republicans in Washington sound almost profligate.
"The priority of priorities is to cut deficits," said President Jacques Chirac of France, adding that the country would have to live with high unemployment and a leaner social welfare system while it got its finances under control. 
 "The Government has sought to achieve a careful but firm balance between financial discipline and the social sustainability of budget deficit reduction," said Prime Minister Lamberto Dini of Italy, "but there is no intention to relent in the effort to cut the budget deficit further."
Even Sweden's left-leaning Prime Minister, Ingvar Carlsson, who helped build one of the world's most lavish social welfare systems, has gotten that deficit-cutting religion. "We don't want to dismantle our system, but we can't spend where we don't have the income," he said.
The rise of deficit reduction to the top of the national agenda has reshaped American politics, and the current political brinksmanship between the White House and Congress over how to achieve it now threatens to shut down the Government. But the scale of United States' problem is modest compared to the deficits being run this year by many other industrialized nations, particularly those in Western Europe.
So of necessity Europe has caught budget-cutting fever too, but with a difference: It has no Newt Gingrich. Instead of political ideology, the primary engine of change in Europe is the global financial market -- which of course also motivates the Americans, since high deficits anywhere bring high interest rates and divert investment from its most productive uses. But because European economies are much more dependent on exports -- and because of the European Union's efforts to forge a single currency -- European governments of all ideological stripes are held hostage even more tightly than Washington by bond and currency traders, who daily pass ruthless judgment about economic and political performance by sending interest and exchange rates up and down.
And as the European governments come under increasing pressure from the markets to reduce their budget shortfalls, they are sending shock waves through their political, economic and social firmaments.
Although a conservative, Mr. Chirac, for example, was elected on a platform of creating jobs and reducing France's stubbornly high unemployment rate. But late last month he did a complete about-face, saying deficit cutting had to come first. Last week Mr. Chirac shook up his floundering Cabinet under Prime Minister Alain Juppe in an attempt to strengthen and streamline his government before it announces painful tax increases and spending cuts on Tuesday.
Across Europe, deficit reduction is clouding the prospects for economic growth and reducing high unemployment rates. It has put on the chopping block Europe's generous systems of health care, pensions, unemployment benefits and other social welfare. It has forced left-wing parties to adopt centrist economic policies. And it has imperiled the European Union's cherished goal of knitting its members inextricably together through the planned single currency.
"It's a fundamental issue," said Stanley Crossick, head of the Belmont European Policy Center, a research group in Brussels. "It puts into play the fundamental conflict western society faces today, which is how to achieve the balance between economic and social necessity."
As in the United States, most citizens seem to recognize the need for deficit reduction and to support it -- at least to the point that it begins biting into their most cherished benefits. And the cuts are starting to bite.
The British Government is planning to slash funding for road building and for welfare payments to single mothers and people injured on the job. The German Government just proposed cutting unemployment compensation by 5 percent for people out of work more than a year. Sweden cut $17 off the $100 monthly payment it makes to every family for each child regardless of need.
As the cuts hit home, the middle and working classes are taking notice, and popular support for many political leaders is ebbing. French unions are planning a day of protest on Tuesday when the Chirac government lays out its austerity program.
The scale of the problem remains daunting. In the United States, the 1995 deficit amounts to about 1.8 percent of gross domestic product. The comparable figure in Germany, Europe's economic powerhouse, is 2.3 percent. In France it is 5.0 percent, in Italy 7.8 percent, in Britain 4.2 percent and in Sweden 9.2 percent.
The accumulated public debt run up by the United States now amounts to 63 percent of the nation's economic output, and that ratio is just slightly less in Germany and France. Italy's debt equals 122 percent of output, and Belgium's 138 percent. Any person applying for a mortgage with that kind of credit record would be laughed out of the bank.
Efforts to make progress in Europe come against a difficult backdrop. Unemployment in many countries is high; in France it is 11.5 percent, compared with 5.6 percent in the United States. Cutting spending and raising taxes only slows growth and inhibits job creation, at least in the short run.
At the same time, the deficit cutting inevitably means reductions in social welfare at a time when unemployment, rising immigration and the breakdown of traditional family patterns is causing growing unrest in some areas. In the suburbs of Paris, scarred by joblessness and drug abuse, hooliganism and other unrest among young people has become almost a nightly affair.
For all the political repercussions already rippling through Europe, left and right broadly agree that there is no need -- yet -- to radically remake the expansive systems of health care, pensions, unemployment insurance and family aid that have defined European social and economic policy since World War II. While reducing the size of government was a central plank of the Contract With America that helped sweep the Republicans into power in Congress a year ago, no European government besides Britain's was elected on a similar platform.
The urgency of Europe's efforts to get its finances under control can be traced largely to the European Union's decision nearly four years ago to seek a single currency. Monetary union was seen as a logical next step in a decades-long effort to bind European countries so closely together that another war would become unthinkable; in particular it was seen as a means for France to attach itself firmly to Germany.
But creating a single currency requires the economies of the participating nations to be stable, healthy and moving more or less in lockstep. So in the Treaty of Maastricht four years ago the European Union set out a series of strict criteria for membership in a currency union. One of the requirements was a budget deficit of less than 3 percent of gross domestic product by 2000.
Then Europe got walloped by a recession that sent unemployment soaring, tax revenues plummeting and budget deficits rapidly upwards. The question ever since has been how to keep alive the hope of monetary union without inflicting further economic and social pain.
Of the big countries, only Germany seems certain of meeting all the criteria, including deficit reduction. If France cannot make it, the idea of a single currency will probably collapse -- and that it something Mr. Chirac clearly does not want to be blamed for.
"European economic and monetary union is not just some idea or other," said Klaus Kinkel, Germany's Foreign Minister, "but the central European political goal of coming years."

HEADLINE: Political Stakes Are High In Mexican State Election

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MORELIA, Mexico, Nov. 8

 BODY:
This is the land of monarchs and peasants, a place of brooding mountains and gentle lakes that is also one of the most traditional places in Mexico and its most radical.
The Pacific coast state of Michoacan is the setting for elections on Sunday that are taking on dimensions as broad as the wave of monarch butterflies that began arriving by the million here last week on their yearly cross-continental migration. 
 On the ballot are candidates for governor, the state assembly and 113 mayors. At stake, in the eyes of many, is the future of the Mexican political system.
The three major parties have a lot riding on the outcome.
For the battered and chaotic leftist Party of the Democratic Revolution, the P.R.D., the elections probably represent its only chance in this generation to win control of one of Mexico's 31 states. A loss here in the birthplace of the party, after last year's third-place finish in the presidential election, could mean the end of the party as it now is organized.
For the right-leaning National Action Party, or PAN, Michoacan is an important prelude. A victory or a strong showing here in the mostly Indian, mostly poor, often violent southern half of Mexico would give the party true national standing.
Of four state elections held so far in 1995, the PAN has won three, all in the north. A victory here would put the party in an advantageous position for the important 1997 midterm elections and then the presidential race in the year 2000.
Then there is the Institutional Revolutionary Party, the PRI, which has ruled Michoacan, and Mexico, for 66 years. A loss by the PRI would cap a devastating year in which severe economic suffering, compounded by corruption and violence in the party, turned Mexican voters away from it in droves.
An PRI victory, seen in independent polls by the University of Guadalajara and the independent Mexico City newspaper Reforma as increasingly likely, would breathe new life into the party and its leadership.
In 1992, the PRI's candidate for Governor officially won but P.R.D. protests prevented him from physically taking office for three weeks. Carlos Salinas de Gortari, then President, eventually appointed an interim PRI Governor.
The biggest surprise of the campaign has come from the conservative party, which instead of putting up a figurehead candidate for governor brought in a former congressman, Felipe Calderon Hinojosa, 33.
Some analysts have said Mr. Calderon is just a spoiler who will siphon enough votes away from the P.R.D. candidate, Cristobal Arias Solis, a 41-year-old senator, to allow the PRI to win with Victor Manuel Tinoco Rubi. But Mr. Calderon said that "we are in it to win."
Most polls show Mr. Tinoco, 49 and also a senator, ahead with a small lead.
The people of Michoacan say they are ready for a change, but many, like Raul Sanchez Cabezas, 35, who has lived here all his life, retain a grudging admiration for the PRI's ability to stage as grand a show as Mr. Tinoco's rally here on Tuesday.
"Even after all that's happened, with crime, with the economy, with dirty politics, so many people still come out for the PRI," he said.
Nearby, workers swept up the thousands of campaign placards and empty water bottles that were left behind after Mr. Tinoco's rally ended and the peasants returned home. Just then, a few monarch butterflies crisscrossed overhead.

HEADLINE: Farm Issues Are Taking Center Stage

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
On Thursday, as the Federal Government teetered at the edge of shutting down and defaulting on its debts, several powerful Republicans spent nearly two hours bickering about the price of milk.
The chairmen of the House Rules Committee, Appropriations Committee, Agriculture Committee and the House Republican Conference met with a dozen other Republicans in the office of Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon of New York, the chairman of the Rules Committee. They set a simple rule: anyone who yelled loudly enough or pounded the table hard enough to cause the room's giant chandelier to tremble would be ejected. 
 While nobody was ejected, "it started out calm, cool and collected -- by the time it was over, I think everyone's temperature had elevated 20 degrees," said Representative Sherwood L. Boehlert, a New York Republican who participated in the meeting.
Farm issues have been eclipsed in the public budget debates by Medicare, Medicaid and welfare, but by today the Republicans from the Senate and the House had finished most of the work on compromises for welfare and Medicaid. But there was no word of progress on the farm bill. With roughly one-third of the Republicans in the House and Senate representing heavily rural areas, farm issues are tying up the negotiations as some Republicans show a marked willingness to vote against legislation if it will hurt their farmers.
Two of the 10 Republicans who voted against the budget on the House floor were from upstate New York and objected to the dairy provisions -- Mr. Boehlert and Representative John M. McHugh. They and other New York Republicans threatened late this week to sink the budget bill if changes in the milk provisions were not made. With Democrats nearly united against the spending cuts, the Republican leadership cannot afford to alienate more members over farm policy.
Peanuts, sugar and dairy products like milk, butter and cheese have emerged as the sticking points in a budget conference between House and Senate agriculture committee leaders that was supposed to end on Friday. Now they are just hoping they can finish on Monday.
House Republicans are divided among themselves, to say nothing of their differences with Senate Republicans. This autumn the House Agriculture Committee never succeeded in agreeing on any budget legislation, and the budget bill passed by the full House included agriculture provisions that the committee had defeated by a vote of 27 to 22.
Now those divisions are reappearing. Lawmakers from peanut-producing states are quarreling with urban lawmakers who complain that the Federal program has made peanut butter prices too high. Members of Congress from sugar-producing states are trying to defend price supports and fend off efforts to protect the Florida Everglades from the pesticide and fertilizer runoff from giant sugar farms.
No farm program took deeper cuts in the Senate than the dairy program. The House budget bill also cuts dairy subsidies, but goes even further in eliminating the current system of fixing milk prices at high levels to keep each state's milk farmers in business.
The system keeps prices highest in the Northeast and Southeast, where dairy farmers have particularly high costs. Lawmakers from these regions waged a vigorous campaign last week to force House leaders to yield on this issue to the Senate, which would continue limiting regional competition in milk prices.
Mr. Solomon began threatening late this week to lead a group of upstate Republicans in voting against the final budget unless milk farmers were allowed to keep their current system for holding up milk prices. "Never in my life have I ever joined a rump group," he said on Friday night. "For the first time in my life I have done that, because it's a matter of life or death."
Dairy districts tend to be politically placid places that re-elect their representatives year after year, allowing them to gain considerable seniority and turning dairy policy disputes into high-level battles.
For all the acrimony, the meeting on Thursday settled nothing. Representative Pat Roberts of Kansas, the Agriculture Committee chairman and an advocate of sweeping farm-policy deregulation, declared at the end that Speaker Newt Gingrich would have to arbitrate the dispute.
The betting on Capitol Hill now is that the northeastern dairy farmers will eventually get what they want. Whenever a group of senior congressmen feel strongly about blocking legislation that affects their constituents, there is usually little to be done by colleagues who are arguing in the name of public policy theories and economic efficiency.

HEADLINE: Casino Issues Spotlight Rift In the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Trapped in the poor southeastern corner of Fairfield County, the people of Bridgeport are pinning their hopes for economic salvation on an unlikely ally. The predominantly Democratic city is counting on the new Republican Governor, John G. Rowland, to win approval for a law to bring what could be the world's most profitable casino to Bridgeport.
To the west, the county's wealthy bedrock Republican towns are not at all pleased with the man they helped elect. Many prominent Republicans are fighting the casino proposal that Mr. Rowland, the state's first Republican Governor in 20 years, has said is vital to Connecticut's prosperity. 
 "This would be an economic Chernobyl," State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Greenwich Republican, said at a recent news conference. He said the $875 million casino proposed by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians would create traffic and other problems that would hurt the region's economy.
The rift over gambling comes as casinos have emerged as a divisive issue nationally for the party. In Connecticut, it pits the urban Republicanism of Mr. Rowland, who rose to power by appealing to conservative Democrats in the blue-collar city of Waterbury, against the affluent suburbanites who have been the Republican Party's backbone.
At stake for Mr. Rowland is the success of his plans for welfare reform and urban renewal: his plan to force more than 40,000 people off public assistance. To undertake that program, which features a 29-month time limit on welfare, the country's strictest, Mr. Rowland needs jobs.
"You have to do more than just kick people off welfare," Paul Green, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, said. "Voting against the casino will very much undercut what we are trying to do in these other efforts. It will send a message, 'Drop dead, Bridgeport,' and we don't want that."
Mr. Nickerson and other anti-casino Republicans say they are following their conscience on gambling, as they would on issues like abortion or gun control.
But there are hints that the split may represent deeper differences about the state party's direction. While Mr. Rowland has strongly endorsed Senator Bob Dole's bid for the Presidency, Mr. Nickerson and two other top State Senate Republicans who oppose the casino had said they wanted to see if Gen. Colin L. Powell was going to run.
In Washington, Senator Richard G. Lugar, another Presidential candidate, has used the rapid growth of the casino industry as an issue to attack Mr. Dole, who has received more than $500,000 in contributions from gaming interests. While Mr. Lugar has called on the Christian Coalition to oppose casinos' expansion on moral grounds, Mr. Dole has defended gaming as a legitimate industry.
There may be few places where anti-casino sentiment is stronger than lower Fairfield County, a Republican stronghold, once home to George Bush and still the home of William F. Buckley Jr. and the corporate headquarters for a host of Fortune 500 companies. In a survey of his district conducted by Mr. Nickerson, 72 percent were opposed to the Bridgeport proposal, in contrast to a statewide poll that showed a slight majority favoring it.
Some of the anti-casino feelings are based on principle. "It's immoral," said Charles P. Stetson, a Republican from Fairfield and chairman of the Family Institute of Connecticut, a group affiliated with the national evangelical group Focus on the Family. "I thought the Republican Party was the party of responsibility, but I'm beginning to wonder."
But perhaps more important to the anti-casino movement are the fears about its impact on quality of life.
"It would turn I-95 into a parking lot," said Chris Bruhl, chief executive of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association, a Fairfield business group. Already the highway is operating at 165 percent of intended capacity, traffic is routinely slowed to a crawl during rush hours and the 19-mile trip from Fairfield to Stamford can take more than an hour.
The thousands of new visitors to a casino would create insurmountable gridlock, Mr. Bruhl said, quelling the economic growth in the county, particularly in Stamford.
He added: "They're feeling desperate in Bridgeport now, and desperate people are willing to take gambles. But please don't underestimate how desperate we feel about traffic. Don't underestimate the desperation of people prepared to fight for what they have."
Tom Ragland, First Selectman-elect of Greenwich, said recently that people in his town were not open to changing their commuting habits: "You've got a Bimmer in one driveway and a Mercedes in another, you're not going to grab a bus. You've earned a place in this world and carved out a life style."
The opposition goes beyond such concerns. Mr. Nickerson has argued that casinos take money from other industries, cause a net loss in jobs and are bad public policy. While casino supporters tout the 10,000 jobs the Pequots created with their Foxwoods Resort Casino in eastern Connecticut, Mr. Nickerson has pointed to poverty and crime in Atlantic City as proof that casinos do not help urban development.
"This is the wrong medicine for a sick patient," he said.
Casino supporters, including some Republicans, dismiss those arguments as cover for wealthy suburbanites who don't care about Bridgeport and don't want a casino in their back yard.
"We don't buy the traffic argument," Mr. Green, the Governor's aide, said. "It's a convenient push-button issue." The State Transportation Commissioner, J. Williams Burns, a Democrat appointed by Mr. Rowland, said the problems, while serious, could be overcome.
Jack E. McGregor, a prominent Republican who was co-chairman of Mr. Rowland's transition team and heads a Bridgeport water company, said he was "totally outraged" by his neighbors' opposition. "This is a quintessential Greenwich-Stamford example of their total lack of resolve to address Bridgeport's problems," he said.
When the General Assembly approved tax incentives last year to lure the North American headquarters of Swiss Bank to Stamford, no one in Bridgeport objected, he said, and traffic from the 2,000 new jobs was never mentioned. "We have not done anything but be totally cooperative in the economic rebirth of Stamford," he said. "It's about time that those roadways became two-way roadways."
In a sign that Mr. Rowland's argument may be influencing some party members, State Senator Judy Freedman, a Westport Republican who was believed to be leaning against the casino, sounded almost positive about it after meeting with Mr. Rowland.
Noting that in a referendum in Bridgeport, 82 percent endorsed a casino, Ms. Freedman said: "We all believe in local control. That's Republicanism. If Greenwich voted for something, would Bill Nickerson want the state to come in and criticize it?"
While opponents contend that Bridgeport has exaggerated its problems -- they note that crime has been dropping -- Mr. Rowland has said that only casino operators are prepared to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in the state's most distressed city. Since 1989, one-fifth of Bridgeport's jobs have disappeared, and last year it was ranked seventh among American cities in percentage of population lost.
With the Legislature in special session to consider the casino issue, Mr. Rowland has appeared to pick up momentum in a debate that had appeared unwinnable.
The Pequots have agreed to increase the money they would pay the state, estimating that their payments to the state from Foxwoods and the Bridgeport casino would total $3.4 billion over the next 10 years.
But Mr. Rowland remains short of the votes he needs and has taken a political risk by pushing the issue so vigorously.
It is a Connecticut truism that elections are lost in Fairfield County, and Republicans there have abandoned their party before. In 1954, Fairfield Republicans cost Gov. John Lodge his re-election, partly out of anger over his building of I-95 through their towns. In 1988, they voted against Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Greenwich and helped a Democrat, Joseph I. Lieberman, stage an upset.
Yet Mr. Rowland may also pick up votes in Bridgeport, where he did remarkably well for a Republican in the last election, losing the city to his Democratic opponent by 1,642 votes.
The proposal may signal a new type of Republicanism in the state. "The Governor's approach distinguishes him not only from Democrats, who would make poverty worse by continuing dependency on welfare, but also from some Republicans," Mr. Green said. "They talk about cutting programs and tax breaks, but they don't show enough sympathy for the poor. They're not creating opportunities in our cities."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 15, 1995

 CORRECTION:
Because of a production error, an article on Sunday about a casino proposed for Bridgeport, Conn., omitted a reference in some copies to a casino proponent who said other Fairfield County communities have not supported Bridgeport. He is Jack E. McGregor, president of the Aquarion Company. The article also omitted a comment by State Transportation Commissioner William Burns. He said traffic problems relating to the casino could be overcome.
In addition, the article misstated the duration limit for welfare payments under a new Connecticut law. It is 21 months, not 29.

HEADLINE: The Homeless Huddle at City's Margins

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Monica Links gave up on trying to live in Central Park. After one run-in too many with the police, she moved two months ago to her current crate, set near festering garbage and rotting rags on an abandoned Hudson River pier. So far, no one bothers her there.
Kelly and Joe Mullen used to inhabit the entryway of a private building at 34th Street and Fifth Avenue. Now, chased from there, they live in a kind of cave, fabricated largely from cast-off comforters, on another crumbling pier -- taking refuge, like Ms. Links, at the very edge of Manhattan. 
 "Pretty soon we're going to be living in rowboats in the river," Mr. Mullen said.
In a campaign that began under the Dinkins administration and intensified under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the most visible clusters of homeless people in the most trafficked parts of the city have been cleared away.
It would appear at first glance that New York has made notable progress toward solving its homelessness problem. But homeless people and their advocates say that much of that apparent progress is illusion, and city officials acknowledge that there is no evidence of a radical decline in the number of homeless people on the streets.
Rather, the geography of Manhattan's homeless population has changed.
The shanties are gone from Columbus Circle and Tompkins Square, and the tattered people with cardboard mats no longer bed down on Grand Central's marble floors or in boutique doorways along Madison Avenue. The southern half of Central Park is relatively free of nighttime inhabitants.
But many have simply been pushed out to the periphery of the island, settling on piers, in nooks along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and in crannies beneath the bridges, fashioning new homes far enough out of the way to be left alone by the police.
Some have learned to hide better, moving deeper into parks or underground into disused tunnels; others find doorways in Harlem or far downtown, where the police do not move them along. Many now wander as loners or in pairs, giving up the larger groups that afford more safety but also invite more attention.
"They're pushing people to the margins of the island," said Mary Brosnahan, director of the Coalition for the Homeless.
In the view of the homeless and their advocates, the city is playing a kind of three-card monte game with the issue of homelessness, by spurring vagrants to move more often and find better hiding places.
"The Mayor's definition of quality of life is to get us out of sight," said William Andrew Card, 57 and homeless for six years, as he waited for a free dinner at St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue. "His idea of quality of life is that Dagwood and Blondie don't have to look at it."
But city officials see the shift in homeless populations differently. Some homeless people do simply hide, said Joan Malin, the Commissioner of Homeless Services, but others have been reached by the intensified efforts of roving teams of social workers.
"The message is out that it's wrong to be on the streets," she said. "Not, 'We're moving you away,' but 'Come on in,' " into the shelter system or other housing and into substance abuse programs.
"If someone is ready to come in, there are four or five ways to get into the system that didn't exist five years ago," she said. "There are also people who flat out don't want to participate in services, do not want to be part of the system, are actively drug-abusing and have opted not to be part of this, and moved off into the parks or further away from sight."
Neither advocates for the homeless nor city officials can conclusively map out the new whereabouts of elusive vagrants, or even estimate how many there are. But they can piece together some of the new geography.
Riding the two Coalition for the Homeless vans that provide soup and sandwiches to several hundred people each night, Michael Polenberg, director of the group's food program, has noticed a definite shift. The lines in midtown have shrunk precipitously, and those near Housing Court in lower Manhattan and up in Harlem have grown, he said.
Numbers have swelled under the F.D.R. Drive near the South Street Seaport. Under the Manhattan Bridge, tiny cottages that look like glorified doghouses are at full occupancy, even boasting an ironic sign: "Homeless Hills, Phase I -- Sold Out."
Frequent police sweeps bring a mix of shame and anger to many homeless people, even as they accept that they have no right to live on property they do not own.
"They just don't leave us alone," said Leo Thomas, 63, as he prepared recently to bunk down in the doorway of a church on First Avenue until 7 a.m., when he and his cardboard covering must be gone. "I used to sleep on 47th and Second -- got chased out of there. Then on 42d Street by the river park, used to sleep there, but now they hassle you. And down on 36th Street -- I used to sleep there, but now they have barricades there."
Neither the street people nor those who try to help them object to the basic idea of getting vagrants off midtown sidewalks and out of train stations and parks.
"They should get the homeless off the streets," said Kelly Mullen, who has been homeless for nearly three years.
"But," she added, "are they taking them off just to make a pretty city or to have compassion and understanding for people in crippling situations?"
Social workers worry that when street people are rousted repeatedly, they become far more difficult to reach with aid.
"It's become more difficult to engage people because they're more frightened," said Barbara Rinehart of the Goddard Riverside Neighborhood Center, a settlement house on Columbus Avenue.
Terry Troia, executive director of Project Hospitality of Staten Island, said her teams have noticed that "it's a lot harder to draw people out" so they can receive food, counseling or health care.
"So while it's not in the public eye," she said, "the problem's not solved -- but it's a lot harder to do the outreach."
Groups helping the homeless acknowledge that city shelter services and programs to help drug and alcohol abusers have expanded; the problem, they say, is that once the programs end, there is still little housing to move into, and people end up back on the streets. The city offered 1,997 rehabilitated apartments to the homeless in the 1995 fiscal year, against 2,563 in 1994, city management reports show.
And though Ms. Malin said the shelter system has become more hospitable, many homeless people still shun the shelters as dangerous centers of drug abuse, violence and thievery, preferring the streets even as winter approaches.
"I was in a shelter for three days and all my stuff was stolen," said Ms. Links, a 21-year-old Bronx native who has been homeless for more than six months and recently lost a job as a pizza waitress.
So the remaining homeless continue to scatter to undisturbed spots. Even when they are out of sight, however, the nests many homeless people fashion for themselves are often not secure.
The two dozen inhabitants of the Hudson River piers where Ms. Links and the Mullens live, just off West Street, have been told by Sanitation Department workers that they will probably have to leave in a month or so.
"It's hard because Giuliani is making it very hard," Kelly Mullen said. "I hope he'll let us ride out the winter here; I pray every day."
It is not exactly heaven, despite its river views, but the pier does offer some amenities, such as they are: Kelly Mullen sometimes bathes in the salty river, she said; a few yards away, walls of milk crates provide a modicum of privacy around a makeshift toilet sitting over a hole in the pier's concrete. A Department of Sanitation plant next door lets them have drinking water. On what they call the "gay pier," some of the dozen inhabitants -- who include Sylvia Rivera of Stonewall fame -- say they go out "canning" for returnable bottles together, and otherwise help each other out.
Ms. Links, over on what might be considered the young people's pier, contemplated the prospect of a forced move with regret. Her shed is decorated with hand-drawn hearts and a declaration of "friends forever" with Roger, a 21-year-old gay man from Union City, her neighbor.
There is no going back to Central Park.
"They told me next time they'd catch me they'd incarcerate me," she said, "and I just don't like the bullpens."
On a recent evening, she had just finished one of her many writings, this one a paragraph titled "Reality." It said:
"When the night falls it finds me all alone, and makes me wonder if I'll ever have a home. I set out into this crazy world thinking it was so easy. But instead I've been made into a destroyer. My world empty and cold with only a small gleaming light at the bottom called Reality."
Near the Port Authority bus terminal, Larry Jackson, an unemployed and homeless former messenger, said it seemed to him that "it's a job in itself to move your belongings from one place to another."
But homeless people develop a certain savvy, he said, learning what areas are heavily policed only at certain times. They flood to the Port Authority on the weekends, he said; otherwise, they are tending to move to places like 125th Street and Lenox in Harlem, where they are rarely disturbed. Most do not leave Manhattan, preferring to stay as close as they can to familiar territory and known sources of help.
In the more desirable shantytowns, like the one under the Manhattan Bridge, the residents are so aware of their real estate's appeal that they say they band together to keep out would-be interlopers. "You got to know who you're letting in," said Pedro Maldonado, who lives in one of the closet-sized cottages there. "There's a lot of dog eat dog here, too -- we're not angels."
The Homeless Hills settlement, with its sheltered location under the bridge and an accessible supermarket bathroom nearby, is considered one of the best, its residents said, despite the danger of a drunken fall into the water and the annoyance of passing buses of gawking, photo-snapping tourists.
But there is also the advantage of being highly visible -- attracting enough contributions that one resident joked, "We gain 15 pounds at Christmastime."
Neither the shack-dwellers of Homeless Hills nor those of the Hudson pier plan to use the shelters if they are kicked out.
Kelly and Joe Mullen supposed that when they had to leave, they would move to some park, though that would mean giving up most of their scavenged possessions. It was a dreary prospect, another move.
"You get worn down," Kelly Mullen said. "It's a message sent to you: you're no good, you're not acceptable, you're perverted, you're disgusting. So you go with your tail between your legs, and want to give up."

HEADLINE: Trouble at the Guggenheim Foundation

 BODY:
For 70 years the Guggenheim Foundation has been a renowned Midas of the creative world, handing out grants to 13,500 artists, scientists and scholars, from Aaron Copland to Linus Pauling to James Baldwin, as well as 40 Nobel laureates. These days, however, the Guggenheim Foundation has fallen on, if not yet hard times (its endowment is $150 million), then surely very pinched times.
For years the foundation spent too generously, way exceeding the legal requirement that a foundation spend at least 5 percent of its assets annually. At the same time it invested too conservatively, putting all its assets in the hands of one bank money manager instead of trying for more diversification and a more aggressive investment strategy. Some years the investment earnings did not even cover the grants awarded, which the foundation kept adjusting for inflation and which it maintained at 300 a year. 
 Obviously, the foundation could not continue on its spendthrift path, which is why it is now embarked on cost-cutting and more strategic investment. It is attempting to raise $10 million to $20 million for its endowment and, sadly, handing out about half the previous number of fellowships. It is the loss of fellowships that especially galls Joel Conarroe, the foundation's president. "We're all aware of how many brilliant people we have to turn away every year," he said. "We feel a particular urgency not only to give more awards but larger ones."
The need is urgent indeed because even in the best of times America's artists and thinkers do not have many places to turn to for help in writing a book, mounting a dance, or working out a theory. But with the Federal Government beginning to relinquish its role as a supporter and enthusiast for this nation's arts and humanities, these are among the worst of times. The National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities have endured both deep cuts and the calumnies of those who feel threatened by the talented, the imaginative and the occasionally unsettling.
Fortunately for those whose hopes for their work are pinned on getting a Guggenheim, the foundation is slowly amassing contributions from what it calls its "friends and family," among them 1,776 Guggenheim fellows. Unfortunately for many of those "brilliant people" of whom Mr. Conarroe speaks, the N.E.A. and the N.E.H. have few such friends in Congress.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
High-Turnover General Managers

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Even the people in the room may not be able to tell the general managers without a scorecard at the general managers' meetings in Scottsdale, Ariz., this week.
The position has become so volatile that two clubs, barring last-minute decisions, won't even have general managers in the room because they haven't filled their vacancies. Four general managers have been named to their jobs in the last month. Two of them will attend for the first time as general managers; the other two have participated before but for different teams. 
 The lineup is even more jumbled than it was a year ago, when four new general managers went to the meetings having been hired in the previous month. A fifth had been hired two months earlier.
"General managers are the ones whom owners have put in charge of their purse strings," John Schuerholz of the Atlanta Braves said. "That's why they're flying in and out of office like managers used to."
Schuerholz, with 14 years in the position, has become the dean of general managers. "How about that? Isn't that amazing?" he said, finding it hard to believe himself.
But Schuerholz has divided his time between the Braves and the Kansas City Royals, leaving Sandy Alderson, the Oakland Athletics' general manager for 12 years, as the senior man in terms of continuous service.
At the other end of the service scale, 13 of the 28 clubs have changed general managers in the last two years. Four changes have occurred in the last month, and two jobs still have to be filled. Bill Bavasi, who became the California Angels' general manager less than two years ago, on Jan. 12, 1994, ranks 16th on the seniority list in terms of continuous service.
Alderson, Fred Claire of Los Angeles, Woody Woodward of Seattle and Lee Thomas of Philadelphia are the only general managers who were hired by their current employer before 1990.
"As a result of the dramatically increased financial obligations that owners have, they have in turn placed far more importance, and therefore greater pressure, on winning and delivering a winning product," Schuerholz said, discussing the turnover. "That pressure falls squarely in the lap of general managers."
Alderson, whose team is undergoing a change in ownership, attributed the turnover in general managers to the turnover in owners in the last 10 years.
"Many owners have gotten themselves more involved in baseball decision-making," Alderson said. "As a consequence, the general manager has become a more specialized individual. He's probably less a generalist and more a specialized baseball-experienced individual. Often the tenure of someone of that type is a function of team performance."
As impatient owners change general managers, they often have sought younger men whose outlook might be different from the veteran general managers who used to hold their jobs for years. Of the changes made in the last two years, eight new general managers came from jobs as assistant general manager or player development director.
At age 34, Jim Bowden of Cincinnati is one of the youngest general managers in the league. In his three years working for Marge Schott, he has done a remarkable job under difficult circumstances.
"The game has become very business-oriented," he said. "Every time you do a deal or sign a player, the first issue now is financial. It's not player talent. The game is ever changing. What ownership looks for in a general manager is changing. Twenty-five years ago the emphasis was on trading and player evaluation. Now the scope has to be widened."
Despite his youth, Bowden said he believes in the older general manager.
"The key is experience," he said. "People like myself have the disadvantage of not having been around 25, 30 years. That doesn't mean I would give back my job because I like my job. But I've surrounded myself with older, more experienced people."
Schuerholz agreed that there is a "very different breed" of general manager.
"The owners are going away from the old standard mold of the veteran, deeply schooled, well-experienced, well-grounded baseball guy to someone who has more modern-day appeal," he said. "Whether that's intellectual appeal, communicative skills or whatever that may be, you see a larger number of younger and less experienced guys being thrust into a position that demands, from time to time, reliance on experience and long-standing knowledge and instincts that are developed over time. Sometimes the young guys who are put in these jobs can't develop those skills to satisfy the owners."
Two of the recent changes were forced by resignations, an unusual development in a field that totals only 28 jobs. Randy Smith left the San Diego Padres because he was not comfortable working under Larry Lucchino, the club's new chief executive officer, and Kevin Malone gave up the Montreal Expos' job, saying he wanted to build a team, not tear it down in the Expos' method of economic operation.
Smith is Detroit's new general manager, but Malone remains unemployed. He is one of three finalists for the Baltimore vacancy, the others being Joe Klein, whom Smith replaced, and John Barr, the Mets' scouting director.
 
Vaughn Is Truly Valuable
 When the American League's most valuable player is announced Thursday, if his name is not Albert Belle, instant critics should remember the award is not for the player of the year.
Belle, who led the league in home runs, total bases and slugging percentage and tied for the lead in runs batted in, runs scored and doubles, clearly was the best player in the league. But was he more valuable than or as valuable as Mo Vaughn?
Belle had much more help in leading Cleveland to the A.L. Central championship than Vaughn had in getting Boston to the East Division championship. That does not detract from what Belle did, but any time a team has as many fine hitters as the Indians had, the value of each is diminished by the sum of the parts.
One example to illustrate: Belle and Manny Ramirez each hit his 28th home run Aug. 20, helping the Indians increase their lead to 19 games. At the time, Ramirez was outhitting Belle, .328 to .323, and had driven in more runs, 91 to 85. Ramirez proceeded to skid into a lengthy slump while Belle continued bashing the baseball, but when the Indians were breaking open the division race, Ramirez was at least equally as valuable as Belle.
If some baseball writers who otherwise might have voted for Belle did not because of his menacing behavior, they might be less than objective, but they also would be human.
 
Mattingly or McGriff?
 Thirteen years after they traded him away to a career that would glitter in three other major league cities, the Yankees would like Fred McGriff back. There's one problem, though. George Steinbrenner also wants Don Mattingly back.
"He knows he can't do both," Jim Krivacs, the agent for both first basemen, said. "He's thinking Donnie's going to play. If that doesn't happen, that changes things."
Mattingly plans to decide in the next few weeks if he wants to continue playing. If the answer is yes, he will play for the Yankees, even though he could go elsewhere as a free agent.
McGriff, who has played for the Braves the last two and a half seasons, also is a free agent.
"Oh yeah, we want to sign him," John Schuerholz, the Braves' general manager, said. "We've let it be known to him and his agent we want to sign him. But there's a question because there's an economic marketplace at play out there."
Krivacs said McGriff, 32, likes Atlanta but added, "We have some decisions to make. The big thing we're trying to get a handle on is where the market is now."
The Yankees drafted McGriff out of high school in 1981. After he led the Gulf Coast rookie league in runs batted in and home runs in 1982, they traded him to Toronto with Dave Collins and Mike Morgan for Tom Dodd and Dale Murray. It remains one of the most memorable trades in the Steinbrenner era.

HEADLINE: Islands Lapped by Tides of Change

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
NOLAN PARK is so quiet you can hear a squirrel's footfall in the golden leaves. Now that late autumn has come, sunlight pierces the heavy canopy of sycamore, oak and maple. It warms the eggnog-yellow clapboard houses around the park, with their gabled rooftops and curlicue woodwork. It dapples the red-brick sidewalks and deep front porches, festooned with American flags. It glints off the World Trade Center nearby.
Nolan Park is not just an uncommonly pretty neighborhood. It is less than 10 minutes from lower Manhattan. 
 Small wonder that developers and urbanists began dreaming last month when it was announced that Nolan Park and the rest of Governors Island, which has been off-limits to civilians since it was garrisoned by the Army in 1794, would become available in 1998, after the Coast Guard closes its base there.
It is a rare day indeed when the opportunity arises to incorporate an entire new island into the civic fabric.
But New York is a city of many islands -- only the Bronx is attached to the mainland -- and much else is happening on this insular real estate.
A master plan is to be prepared for Randalls and Wards Islands, where officials envision a much improved sports and recreation center. On Ellis Island, the enormous Baggage and Dormitory Building may be restored. A 600-bed addition to the West Facility at Rikers Island was recently completed. Landlords on City Island are requesting new commercial zoning. The Parks Department has its eye on North Brother Island (the Bronx), South Brother Island (Queens) and the Island of Meadows (Staten Island) as part of a five-island rookery.
And Roosevelt Island played host last month to 85 builders, financiers, designers, planners and officials from around the nation. Their mission, in a daylong workshop, was to recommend development scenarios to the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, which is trying to decide how to resume construction after six becalmed years.
"There is an urgent need to build out the island to a critical mass," said Jean Lerman, president and chief operating officer of the corporation. "The tram could handle more riders. The garage could handle more cars. The stores could clearly use more business. What is buildable that could enhance the island?"
The question of what is buildable is also being asked on City Island, where some landlords want the city to change the M1 manufacturing zoning -- a throwback to the vanished boat-building industry, they say -- to C3 commercial zoning, which permits residential development.
"We feel M1 is archaic and restricts our potential," said Herbert A. Hild, president of Hild Sails, who owns about 2.5 acres on the east side of the island, between Pelham Cemetery and the slip for the Harts Island ferry. Mr. Hild has been in the sailmaking business for 50 years. "It's not that we're going to turn around and build condos," he said. "It's just that we feel we're in an obsolete type of zoning."
Such tensions reflect the changing way in which New Yorkers will be using the islands around them. "Are islands going to be viewed as enclaves?" asked Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission. "Are they refuges for the people who live there, or tourist attractions, or recreational and wildlife space, or places where you isolate and dump as many undesirable land uses as you can?"
Roosevelt Island served for most of its existence as a place where the city isolated the poor, the criminal, the insane and the diseased. For 20 years, it has slowly been transformed into a residential quarter. There are now some 8,200 people living in 3,248 units in 18 apartment buildings. In 1989, the operating corporation solicited proposals for a 2,000-unit residential project on a 19-acre parcel called Southtown, between the existing towers and the Queensboro Bridge, which would have added 4,400 residents to the island.
DEVELOPERS didn't bite at the time, but that reluctance may be changing.
"There was a great deal of interest in pursuing Southtown," said Alyce M. Russo, director of planning and development at Roosevelt Island, as she described the workshop. "That exceeded our expectations -- pleasantly." Among its strong points, Southtown has both the tram terminal and a subway station, served by B and Q trains.
One of the most difficult questions will be whether to preserve the existing mix of low- , middle- and upper-income residents or lift the 25 percent ceiling on market-rate housing, thereby permitting proportionally more higher-priced units and making the economics more enticing to developers.
One participant in favor of lifting the cap was Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center, who is a former New York City Housing Commissioner and Deputy Mayor. "It's not realistic from a housing finance standpoint to assume anything but market-rate housing," he said, "which, on Roosevelt Island, is middle class."
Alexander Cooper, of Cooper, Robertson & Partners, who was co-architect of the master plan of Battery Park City, said it would be helpful to waive the current mix and modify the master plan.
Defending the existing master plan and the economic mix was Edward J. Logue, the former president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, who is regarded as the father of the Roosevelt Island project. He traveled to the workshop from another island, Martha's Vineyard, where he now lives.
Mr. Logue conceded that it was difficult, if not impossible, to build affordable housing at a time when Government subsidies have dried up, but he did not think that was a reason to abandon the vision of economically integrated communities.
"To restore the social health to our cities, we've got to have this mix," Mr. Logue said. Mr. Cooper suggested that co-op owners be permitted to make a profit when reselling their units and that the density on the island be increased to 6,000 or 7,000 units.
Con Howe, Director of Planning for the City of Los Angeles, urged care in apportioning development sites. "If you don't preserve lots of the island as completely open space," he said, "you'd lose one of the fundamental reasons anyone would want to live there."
Mr. Howe was once executive director of the New York City Planning Department. He was disappointed by his return to Main Street, which serves as the spine of Roosevelt Island's residential area. "The architecture hasn't weathered well," he said, "and you don't feel connections either to open space or to the waterfront."
Some teams at the workshop focused on details like the five mini-schools that have been empty since 1992, when a new grammar and intermediate school opened. "We would take them all down," Mr. Leventhal said. "To have prime waterfront space taken up by vacant schools is something we didn't want to sit still for another moment."
P ARTICIPANTS also looked more generally at the governance of the island. Robert Davis, the founder and president of the Seaside Community Development Corporation, which created the new town of Seaside in Florida, said a stronger governing body was needed -- "something like the Battery Park City Authority, with that kind of entrepreneurial initiative and degree of control."
"Ed Logue had that kind of wheeling and dealing power and then some," he added.
For his part, Mr. Logue said, "My solution is that the island ought to have self-rule; make a compact with the State of New York and just let them go."
Whatever happens on Roosevelt Island, it is almost certain to occur long before the redevelopment of Governors Island. "What makes Roosevelt Island different is that it has a subway stop -- that's fundamental," said Alexander Garvin, a member of the City Planning Commission and the author of a book, "The American City: What Works, What Doesn't." He and Bethami Probst coordinated the Oct. 17 workshop.
Roosevelt Island also has a tram and, like City Island and Randalls Island, a bridge to the rest of the city. "You'd have to go a long way to produce the same result on Governors Island," Mr. Garvin said. "We're talking about hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars to produce a bridge."
"Also, you're beginning with a vision in the case of Roosevelt and Randalls Islands that you can build on," he said. "You've got a long time before you can come up with anything like that for Governors Island."
That is not to say there haven't been visions. Proposals have ranged from the prosaic -- a residential enclave -- to the fantastic: a Disney theme park, an ecology park and convention center, a movie studio complex or a site for the city's sex businesses and a casino.
City officials have tried to dampen any speculative discussion, however.
"It's very, very premature," said Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, who heads the Governors Island task force for the Giuliani administration and was given a tour by Coast Guard officers last Monday. "We don't even know yet under what circumstances the property is going to be conveyed."
The Coast Guard will begin moving next spring and plans to turn the island over to the General Services Administration. But it is not clear how the Government will then dispose of the island, to whom, under what circumstances and at what price (although an estimate of $500 million was advanced by the Congressional Budget Office).
Mr. Rose said his more immediate concern was the transferring of many Coast Guard operations to New Jersey, Virginia and South Carolina, along with a $70 million annual payroll.
For now, Governors Island is a small town of about 4,000 residents, to which 1,800 commuters travel daily. There are some 800 housing units over its 170 acres. Much of the residential stock is modern and unremarkable. There is an array of two-story town houses on the east side, a cluster of 10 three-story apartment houses on the southern tip and, overlooking the harbor, a trio of seven-story buildings and a T-shaped 10-story structure that is the island's skyscraper.
What gives Governors Island its exceptional character are the historic structures. The frame houses of Nolan Park are for senior officers, as are the sturdy brick homes along Colonels' Row, which got its name before the Army turned the island over to the Coast Guard in 1966, after which the captains moved in.
Quarters 1 is the designation of the Admiral's House, a 155-year-old, 27-room mansion overlooking Buttermilk Channel, with two-story-high Tuscan colonnades front and rear. Quarters 2, home to the base commander, is a more modest brick house nearby. It has been much altered over the years but may have been begun in 1708 as the home of the provincial governor and is known as the Governor's House.
The most unusual housing on the island is undoubtedly the quadrangle within the walls of Fort Jay, a five-pointed, star-shaped fortification that was completed in 1798 and rebuilt in 1803. The apartments are reached by crossing a dry moat. Surrounding the fort is a nine-hole golf course.
F ORT JAY is one of three fortifications on the island. Castle Williams, on the north shore, is a semicircular structure that was completed in 1811 along with Castle Clinton in Manhattan to protect New York from a British invasion. The South Battery of 1812 is the officers' club.
Across the harbor is another island laden with landmarks. Although the reopening of Ellis Island in 1990 attracted worldwide attention, there are many structures beside the Main Building, with its cavernous Registry Hall, that have yet to be restored.
"It's not over yet," said Michael Adlerstein, associate field director of the National Park Service's northeast area.
The largest unrestored structure is the 87-year-old Baggage and Dormitory Building, which adjoins the Main Building and once housed 5,000 immigrants at a time, usually those who had arrived too late of an evening to be processed. Later used by the Navy as a brig, it was abandoned in 1954. The 125,000-square-foot building has only three stories, but each floor is 20 feet high. Because it has a flat roof, it has been subject to considerable weather damage.
"It will be wonderful if we can save it," Mr. Adlerstein said. Discussions are under way, he said, with the private Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, which has raised money for the restoration projects.
Underneath the Triborough Bridge, another foundation has a role in determining the future of another set of islands. The Randalls Island Sports Foundation is a semi-public organization formed in 1992 to help the Parks and Recreation Department maintain, operate and improve the 400-acre Randalls and Wards Islands Parks. (Although now a single land mass at the confluence of the East and Harlem Rivers, Randalls and Wards were separated until the 1940's by the Little Hell Gate Channel.)
Aimee Boden, the director of the parks, said the foundation hopes to get $800,000 from City Hall for a master plan that would look at ways to improve access to the island and create new sports installations that could be financially self-sustaining.
SOME possibilities include ferry and bus service, roadway improvements and parking expansion, the reconstruction or replacement of the 21,000-seat Downing Stadium and a new field house with 4,000 to 6,000 seats.
Although the islands have 27 softball and baseball fields, 11 tennis courts, 7 soccer and football fields, a golf driving range and a 400-meter running track, Ms. Boden conceded that "you would not know you were in a park -- it doesn't look like a park, feel like a park or smell like a park." In part, that is because the islands are also home to the Triborough toll plazas, the Manhattan Psychiatric Hospital, a waste-water treatment plant and the Fire Department's training academy, among other things.
"There's got to be a way to look at all this mixed institutional use and make the park a cohesive facility," Ms. Boden said.
The Parks Department's involvement with islands does not stop at Randalls and Wards. During Henry J. Stern's first term as Parks Commissioner, in 1984, the agency acquired jurisdiction over Pralls Island, an 80-acre salt meadow and heron rookery in the Arthur Kill off Staten Island. In 1993, an agreement was reached to turn the 50-acre Shooter's Island, also off Staten Island, in the Kill Van Kull, into a wildlife sanctuary.
Now, the department would like to add the North and South Brother Islands and the Island of Meadows. "The combination of these five islands represents more than 2,000 breeding pairs of wading birds," said Marc A. Matsil, chief of the natural resources group. He said there were seven species of herons, egrets and ibises, representing roughly 20 percent of the entire breeding population in New England.
In addition to acquiring islands, Mr. Stern has actually added to the city's collection.
During the reconstruction six years ago of the Harlem Meer in Central Park, he saw to it that a 30-by-40-foot island was created. He named it Duck Island.
Now, Mr. Stern is at it again. As part of the reconstruction of the Great Lawn in Central Park, Turtle Pond is to be dredged and expanded by about 50 percent. An island will be built in the middle.
The reconfigured shoreline will include a new promontory that may be known as Turtle Neck, Mr. Stern said. Or, because it would be made of earth, it could be called Terra Peninsula.
If that were the case, the name of New York City's newest island would quickly suggest itself: Terrapin Insula.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:

LET'S MAKE A DEAL
 
Surf's Up!
Even in a year of frantic dealmaking, the tattoo of announcements was deafening, adding up to more than $20 billion worth of mergers and acquisitions. First Interstate Bancorp, which had been seeking alternatives to a hostile bid from Wells Fargo, found one with First Bank System of Minneapolis. But the sale price of $9.98 billion was less than what Wells Fargo is offering, and some large shareholders at First Interstate said they would vote against the deal if Wells Fargo makes a new bid.
Elsewhere on the corporate society page: International Paper agreed to pay $2.7 billion for Federal Paper Board; Central and South West, a Texas utility, $2.58 billion for Seeboard, a utility in the south of England; Softkey, a Japanese publisher and operator of trade shows, will pay $2.1 billion for Ziff-Davis Publishing; Cordis accepted a sweetened offer of $1.8 billion from Johnson & Johnson; Texas Utilities agreed to pay $1.55 billion for Eastern Energy of Australia; Learning Company accepted a $555 million offer from Broderbund Software, and Flower Industries and Artal Luxembourg said they would buy Keebler from United Biscuits for $500 million. And those were just the big ones.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Warning Lights Go On
In the latest sign that consumers may be moderating their spending, the Federal Reserve reported that new installment debt was sharply lower in September. And new claims for unemployment benefits shot up to the highest level since July 15. Neither is good news for retailers as the holiday season looms.
 
VOLATILITY
 
It's Down . . . No, It's Up!
Technology stocks stumbled badly after Cirrus Logic, a chipmaker, said one of its biggest customers was sharply reducing orders. The next day the Semiconductor Industry Association said chip orders were very strong, and technology soared for the rest of the week, pulling the Dow along as they went.
OPPORTUNITIES
 
Directors in Waiting?
Put off by the bickering and tawdriness of politics? Inspired to conduct surveillance of journalists' and the coverage? Sounds like the sort of credentials a corporate headhunter might admire. As Gen. Colin L. Powell and for-now Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary ponder their futures, are they attracted to those chairs around the boardroom tables?
 
TAXES
 
Not Something for Everyone
For all the talk during the budget debate about trimming taxes, the cuts envisioned in the bill approved by the Senate would leave unchanged the taxes paid by 55 percent of American households. An additional 10 percent would have taxes increased or Government tax credits lowered. The 43 million Americans whose taxes would be reduced would find the benefit amounts to about 68 cents a day, or $249 annually.
 
REAL ESTATE
 
A Deal for Rockefeller Center
Ending a months-long messy struggle for control of Rockefeller Center that began when Mitsubishi decided to walk away from its $2 billion investment, a group led by Goldman, Sachs agreed to buy the landmark development. The group, which includes David Rockefeller, with an offer of $306.1 million, was able to supersede an offer from the Chicago financier Sam Zell.
 
COMPETITIVENESS
 
$100 Million Gift to Princeton
Hoping to make American engineering more competitive with what he sees in Asia, Gordon Y. S. Wu, a Hong Kong businessman, gave $100 million to his alma mater, Princeton's School of Engineering and Applied Science. "You need top quality schools to stay at the top so others can follow," he said.
 
FINE ART
 
'Do I Hear $100 Million?'
Both Christie's and Sotheby's held auctions of fine art that broke the $100 million barrier for the first time since May 1990. Though Sotheby's took in $113.6 million with its offering of Impressionist and modern art, the total was well below what the auction house had anticipated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "COMPACTNESS: Does Detroit Feel the Squeeze?" -- Jeff Gibson climbs out of what he says is the world's smallest "street legal" car, the Arbet, outside the Kingdome in Seattle, where the 1995 International Auto Show opened on Thursday. The Arbet, hand built by Arliss Sluter, includes 5,000 handmade parts and is powered by a two-cylinder, 13-horsepower engine. Do not expect to see it in a showroom any time soon.
