HEADLINE: Grading the Public Schools

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann is a national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly.

 BODY:

DUMBING DOWN OUR KIDS
Why America's Children Feel Good About Themselves but Can't Read, Write, or Add.
By Charles J. Sykes.
341 pp. New York:
St. Martin's Press. $23.95.
 
POSSIBLE LIVES
The Promise of Public Education
in America.
By Mike Rose.
454 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company.
$24.95.
 
THE END OF EDUCATION
Redefining the Value of Schools.
By Neil Postman.
209 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $22.
 
THE MANUFACTURED CRISIS
Myths, Fraud, and the Attack on America's Public Schools.
By David C. Berliner and
Bruce J. Biddle.
414 pp. Reading, Mass.:
Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $25. 
 MORE than 40 million American children are enrolled in public school; it is one of the most universal of our experiences and a large industry (spending about $160 billion a year), as well as perhaps the single leading activity of government. Strangely, though, public school is also a topic about which it is possible to assert almost anything without being subjected to the reality testing that ordinarily applies in public discourse. One reason for this is that so many of the leading discoursers belong to the 1 percent of Americans who attended, or send their children to, expensive nonsectarian private schools: public school is an abstraction to them. Another is that our public school system is so radically decentralized, compared with those of other industrial nations; it is under the control of 15,000 local boards of education rather than a central ministry whose policies are highly visible. Even public school parents have very little idea what their children do in class all day.
In these four books, we have a blind-men-and-the-elephant exercise that is hard to imagine taking place with any other issue so important and so close at hand. In "Dumbing Down Our Kids," Charles J. Sykes presents us with a nightmarish picture of a public school system standing close to ruin, thanks to the dominance of destructive liberal ideas that prevent any real learning from going on. Mike Rose, in "Possible Lives," conducts a detailed national tour of public education, especially in poor areas, and finds it to be triumphantly, inspiringly successful. David C. Berliner and Bruce J. Biddle, taking the same side as Mr. Rose but striking a different tone, argue in "The Manufactured Crisis" that the very notion of an educational crisis is a frightening example of the potency of the big lie technique. Neil Postman would probably agree with Mr. Sykes that there is a crisis, but in "The End of Education" he defines it in exactly the opposite way, as consisting of an insufficiency of the humanist ethos in schools.
There is so much public education going on in this country that it would be possible for everybody to be correct in a narrow literal sense: the system probably does contain in its vastness some example of every conceivable kind of success and failure. But there is also an underlying philosophical issue that may explain, better than the actual conditions do, the striking differences between these books.
The two Founding Fathers who were most interested in education, Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin, both believed in disseminating schooling widely among the people, but they had distinctly different purposes in mind: in Franklin's case, training students "to enter the World" as economic actors, in Jefferson's, teaching them "how to work out their greatest happiness" as citizens. Universal public education didn't become established until the 19th century, when educators of a Jeffersonian bent, most notably Horace Mann, learned how to play the Franklin card -- stressing the practical benefits of education as a way of persuading the public to pay taxes for it. So from the very beginning there has been a tension in public education: educators are mostly Jeffersons and the taxpayers whose support they need are mostly Franklins.
The one conservative in this crowd, Mr. Sykes, a journalist and radio talk show host who is the author of several books on education, believes that the purpose of public school is to teach children concrete skills that will be useful -- to them individually in the job market and to the national economy as a whole. One reason he and the others disagree about everything is that they see the purpose of public school as being fundamentally different, in fact almost opposite: "to find and promote large, inclusive narratives for all students to believe in" (Postman); to be "preparatory arenas for civic life" (Rose); "to promote the joy of learning for its own sake" (Berliner and Biddle, on higher education in particular). All three liberal books explicitly and repeatedly reject the idea that schools exist to prepare young people for the marketplace, and treat as dubious the idea that education confers economic benefits. Mr. Sykes wants public schools to be part of the mainstream economic culture; the other authors want schools to stand apart from, even provide an alternative to, the idea that America is about business.
Although Mr. Sykes's book is packaged as the latest attack on political correctness, he is quite forthright in stating that the educational trends he finds alarming are not products of the 60's counterculture. As he points out, the 1950's, usually the halcyon past in conservative discourse, were a nightmare decade by his lights because of the popularity of the undemanding Life Adjustment theory of education. For him the real starting point for everything alarming was the adoption, by a subcommittee of the National Education Association, of a series of progressive-education "Cardinal Principles" -- in 1918!
Today the villains, to Mr. Sykes, are the latest iterations of progressivism. He is very good at making fun of jargony new movements like Outcome-Based Education and Whole Language, along with other manifestations of educational mediocrity and therapeutic excess that he has dug up: an education school doctoral thesis on golf, a textbook that seeks to instruct small children in masturbation, a teachers' magazine that promotes "collaborative writing" because it means fewer papers to grade. What we ought to do, Mr. Sykes says, is junk all this feel-good nonsense and focus on teaching basic skills to students segregated into ability groups, and then subject the schools to tough evaluation in the form of standardized tests.
 IT is hard to tell how much of public education Mr. Sykes has seen directly -- he appears to be working mainly from materials in the library. His book is a prime example of what Mike Rose says is the tendency of education writers who aren't teachers to operate at a "high level of generality and opinion." Also, Mr. Sykes leaves out an important factor underlying the softening of academic rigor in public education during the 20th century, which is the enormous expansion and ethnic diversification of the school population under the banner of universalizing opportunity. Until World War II, only about half of all students entering high school nationwide graduated, and only a fifth started college; today it's three-quarters and three-fifths. Suddenly given the difficult task of making practically every American child into a little Franklin, teachers have responded by shifting the mission to turning out Jeffersons.
Mr. Rose's book operates at a high level of specificity and nonjudgmental ism. It is the product of immense labor -- he examines nine separate educational settings scattered all over the country -- undertaken, Mr. Rose says, to answer a "desperate need of rich, detailed images of possibility" in public education. A former schoolteacher himself (as is Neil Postman) and now with the Graduate School of Education at the University of California, Los Angeles, he began his project by asking his contacts to nominate good schools for him to visit; he didn't go looking for bad news, and he didn't find any.
 ALMOST all of the book consists of long, leisurely, heavily quotational, elegantly rendered accounts of Mr. Rose's visits to schools. It is not his style to make his points directly, but he does answer some of Mr. Sykes's arguments implicitly by showing us students on the South Side of Chicago rigorously explicating a dead white European male text ("As I Lay Dying"); the civil rights hero Bob Moses teaching youngsters in the Mississippi Delta about prime numbers and factor trees; bilingual education students in California mastering English.
Although it is quite clear that Mr. Rose judges schools by a different standard from Mr. Sykes (if a test score is mentioned anywhere in "Possible Lives" I didn't see it), his evidence from the field does suggest that perhaps the dichotomy between traditional and trendy in education may be a false one. It is possible for public schools (the ones my kids go to, anyway) to embrace publicly every possible buzzword and vogue of the moment while still teaching children to spell and multiply. The real question, in the schools Mr. Rose visited, is whether the students' minds are awake or asleep, and he's persuasive that the teacher, not educational doctrine, is the main determinant of that.
Mr. Postman writes in a voice similar to Mr. Rose's -- informal, clear, one that self-consciously avoids educationese -- but he hasn't done the legwork that Mr. Rose has. He is working in the tradition of the casual essayist, the honorable amateur, and this lends his book both its considerable charm and a vague, digressive feeling. "The End of Education" must be the only book that admiringly discusses the work of both Robert Fulghum, the homespun philosopher, and Count Alfred Korzybski, the semanticist.
What Mr. Postman, University Professor and chairman of the department of culture and communication at New York University, has to say about education, he asserts rather than demonstrating; his determination to eschew the sweaty academic tone is so powerful that it sometimes leads him into a don't-bother-me-with-the-facts position. He writes, for example, that "the Germans and Japanese are opening huge automobile plants in America, and in states not famous for the excellence of their educational systems" -- but Tennessee, the most successful lurer of plants, instituted a major school reform precisely to attract foreign auto manufacturers. In another place Mr. Postman writes, "I refer, for example, to Saul Bellow's rhetorical question concerning the absence of Swahili novels (or was it Navajo novels?) that are the equal or superior to the novels of Proust." The studied inaccuracy is meant to be winning, but Mr. Bellow's remark was about Papuans.
Mr. Postman's previous book, "Technopoly," has got him put into the neo-Luddite category, along with anti-computer writers like Kirkpatrick Sale and Wendell Berry. Part of what he is up to in "The End of Education" is revising and extending his remarks on technology so as to make himself seem less automatically technophobic, and he does a good job of this. There is a good fit between the idea that people and machines are not natural allies and the idea that schools should teach thinking rather than specific skills. Mr. Postman's ideas about education are not the world's most practicable, but they're appealingly fresh: he wants to abolish textbooks and elevate anthropology and linguistics to a primary position in the curriculum. He still comes across as hostile to personal computers, though, usually assuming that computer courses would have to have a shop-class aspect rather than teaching just the kind of understanding of "discourse" (in computer languages) that he most values.
"The Manufactured Crisis" hasn't got a shred of Mike Rose's or Neil Postman's gentility and reasonableness. It represents liberals who have learned how to write the kind of book conservatives based in think tanks have been publishing successfully for a decade -- the all-out attack on the other side. Its first sentence is "This book was written in outrage." That isn't false advertising.
Mr. Berliner, a professor of psychology and education at Arizona State University, and Mr. Biddle, a professor of psychology and sociology at the University of Missouri, are out to refute the idea that the quality of American public schools is shamefully low. They spend most of their book picking apart a line of conservative (or, to use their term, "far right") education writing that began, roughly, with the publication of the Reagan Education Department's 1983 report, "A Nation at Risk." School spending has gone up so much, they say, mainly because of the enormous growth of special education, not because the money is being wasted by bureaucrats. S.A.T. scores are steady, not declining, and aren't a good measure of educational quality anyway, because the takers are a self-selected group. The story everybody has heard about a survey in the 1940's that showed the biggest problems in public high schools to be talking and gum chewing is simply apocryphal. Mr. Berliner and Mr. Biddle are at their best when they are spiritedly refuting the kinds of studies that are usually treated as gospel by a statistics-intimidated press.
The problem isn't just that the conservative critique of public education is wrong, Mr. Berliner and Mr. Biddle say; they go a step farther and accuse the conservatives' recent work of being intentionally wrong, "a deliberate disinformation campaign." In one place they accuse two of their betes noires, John Chubb and Terry Moe, of willfully distorting their statistical findings. These are grave charges, indicative of a rage at the conservatives that goes far beyond the stagy, amiable ideological warfare of the television talk shows.
 THE English-only movement, to Mr. Berliner and Mr. Biddle, "represents merely the old wines of racial hatred and bigotry in new bottles." When the Bush Administration won't release a report it commissioned because it contradicts administration dogma on education, it reminds Mr. Berliner and Mr. Biddle of more egregious Government cover-ups, which leads to the thought, "Somewhere down this road one finds totalitarianism and the Nazi death camps."
Some of the outline of an agreed-upon reality can be detected beneath the surface of "The Manufactured Crisis." Mr. Berliner and Mr. Biddle don't, for example, really argue that public schools are getting better, only that they aren't getting worse, which they see as an achievement in light of the problems that have been dumped in the schools' laps by "a society that is falling apart." They answer the conservative argument about the poor quality of schools of education with a non sequitur: "The vast majority of . . . teachers have completed undergraduate degrees." They rest their opposition to a longer school year on the questionable assumption that the curriculum wouldn't change. The feeling that emerges from "The Manufactured Crisis" is that Mr. Berliner and Mr. Biddle, with their mastery of the education literature, know perfectly well what the strengths and weaknesses of the public schools are, but feel they have to declare the critics of education to be 100 percent wrong. All teacher evaluation, competency testing and merit pay, any hint of an instrumental view of public education as preparing people for the work force, they entirely resist, because of mistrust of the motives of people who favor those ideas. The tone of "The Manufactured Crisis" demonstrates that there are, perhaps more than most people realize, angry men on the left too.
Education was supposed to be one of several issues on which we were witnessing the emergence of a new consensus, whose political embodiment was Bill Clinton. Mr. Clinton's education reform efforts in Arkansas are what made him a plausible Presidential candidate. These books demonstrate that on education the consensus may now be thin to the point of nonexistence; the two sides despise each other and disagree completely on the essential question of what the main purpose of public education is. It won't do, however, to assume that the only answer is to let public education fade away. As two of the books forcefully remind us, public schools are functional institutions to a much greater extent than many of us may think -- and they are still where practically everybody is educated. Allowing them to deteriorate is a luxury we don't have.

HEADLINE: Mexico City Isn't Artists' Sole Patron

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Nov. 8 Ocotlan Journal, on the artist Rodolfo Morales: The assertion that the Mexican Government overwhelming sponsors and controls the arts has been untrue for nearly a half-century.
When muralism and nationalist themes dominated Mexican art in the 1920's, 30's and 40's, various government bodies had widespread control over the all-important public artistic commissions. At mid-century, however, numerous political, economic and cultural factors led to the adoption among a new generation of painters and sculptors of more international styles of art. 
 Since then the Government has provided much-needed support to museums and to individual artists; nevertheless, an increasing number of commercial galleries and corporate and private donors have also played an important role.
Several leading artists in the last decade are known for the critical attitude in their work toward Mexico's culture and government. Works containing such often-biting criticism could not be displayed in major public institutions if the Government exerted the kind of control your article suggests.
 
ELIZABETH FERRER
Fairfield, Conn., Nov. 8, 1995
 
The writer is head of the visual arts department, Americas Society.

HEADLINE: Latest Offer Is Spurned in Budget Talks

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
The White House invited Republican Congressional leaders late today to meet on Monday to try to avert a pending Government shutdown, but only if the Republicans agreed to scrap their plan to raise Medicare premiums for the elderly.
But the Republicans said no deal, not until the President was willing to meet the leaders unconditionally and without Congressional Democrats. 
 The White House invitation, which was issued shortly after 5 P.M., "had no other intent than to try to spin the 6 o'clock news," said Tony Blankley, a spokesman for Speaker Newt Gingrich.
Asked if Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, would show up at the White House on Monday, Mr. Blankley said: "Absolutely not. Not until he says he wants to talk with the Speaker and the majority leader unconditionally and without his Democratic chaperones."
The spurned invitation followed a series of back-and-forth barbs on television programs today, with the Clinton Administration and Republican leaders stating their bottom-line demands for averting a shutdown of the Government early Tuesday, which now seems all but inevitable.
The Administration demanded that the Republicans drop what Democrats describe as an $11-a-month increase in Medicare premiums; the Republicans said President Clinton must agree to work toward a budget that would be balanced in seven years.
The Republicans say there is no Medicare premium increase contained in the continuing resolution -- a temporary budget to keep the Government functioning -- they plan to send to President Clinton on Monday. They say that the rate of Medicare Part B program costs that the elderly would pay would be the same as it is now. The dollar amount, however, would increase, from $46.10 a month now to $53.50, while under current law it would fall to $42.50.
As for the Administration, the President has suggested that he was willing to consider a seven-year balanced budget, but only if it preserved certain programs involving Medicare, the environment and education.
It was not clear whether or by how much either side was willing to budge after a weekend of digging in their heels in the increasingly vituperative spending standoff. Republicans believe that if they back off their promise to balance the budget in seven years, they face ruin at the polls; the President's advisers believe he must stand firm both to counter his image as a man of no convictions and to uphold those programs vital to his natural constituency.
The temporary spending bill, which the House passed on Friday and the Senate is expected to pass on Monday, includes items Democrats call "ideological bells and whistles," like the Medicare proposal, that the White House considers unacceptable. With public opinion polls on his side, President Clinton has vowed to veto the bill when he receives it sometime Monday, setting the stage for the Government shutdown.
"This is the Republicans against the American people," Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, told reporters today after a television appearance as he explained the President's resolve to veto any measure that, as he described it, raised Medicare premiums and cut aid to education and the environment.
Mr. Gingrich saw the matter differently, saying the dispute marked a clear-cut fork in the road. The Republicans, he said on NBC's "Meet the Press," were offering "a major choice for America, whether you want to go to a balanced budget, which we do, or whether you want to continue year after year of borrowing money from your children and, frankly, in the long run keeping interest rates higher and, ultimately, we think, breaking the country financially."
Mr. Gingrich said he would be willing to renegotiate everything else in the bill if Mr. Clinton would agree to the principle of reaching a balanced budget in seven years. "Everything would clearly be on the table at that point, as long as he agreed to seven years of an honest balanced budget that was real," he said.
If the President vetoes the measure and no last-minute agreement is reached on Monday, all Federal workers across the country would still report for work on Tuesday, but about 800,000 "nonessential" workers -- about 40 percent of the nonmilitary Government payroll -- would then be sent home. About half of them work in the Washington area.
The Administration said the mail would still be delivered, Amtrak trains would run, active servicemen and women would remain on duty, air traffic controllers would remain on the job, the Internal Revenue Service would still process tax forms and Social Security checks would be sent out. Welfare checks and food stamps would still be issued but no new applications would be processed.
Other functions classified as nonessential would cease. National parks, monuments and museums like the Smithsonian Institution would shut. Veterans' benefits would not be mailed. Much of the State Department work force would be furloughed, cutting off the issuance of passports unless citizens produce an airline ticket showing an imminent departure overseas.
One person planning a foreign trip is President Clinton, who has scheduled events later this week in Japan. Mr. Gingrich said today that if the budget crisis was not resolved, Mr. Clinton should cancel his trip. Mr. Panetta said the Administration's foreign policy would not be "held hostage" to the Republicans' implacable stance on the budget, but he suggested that the trip might be cut short.
Mr. Clinton had planned to leave on Thursday for a five-day visit that included an economic summit meeting in Osaka with 17 Asian and Pacific leaders to set up a free-trade zone and a state visit in Tokyo that included ceremonial talks with Emperor Akihito, working talks with the Prime Minister and a speech to United States and Japanese forces on the aircraft carrier Independence.
Asian leaders would almost certainly take a cancellation as a sign that the United States is not as committed to its relationships in the Pacific as Mr. Clinton has insisted. And Japanese leaders could be especially upset at the sign of a Presidential slight at a time when relations between Washington and Tokyo are already strained over several incidents, including the involvement of three American servicemen in the rape of a 12-year-old girl on Okinawa.
If Mr. Clinton goes, he can expect to be excoriated by Republican leaders. When Mr. Clinton headed for a golf outing on Friday, Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole quickly appeared at a news conference holding golf clubs and mocking the President for absenteeism in the middle of a crisis. Administration officials said they were waiting for the Republicans to act and that there was nothing for the President to do.
The blame game continued throughout the weekend, with both sides sounding more insistent on the rightness of their positions and saying it was up to the other side to end the stalemate.
When Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole said that they were shocked that the President essentially "hung up" on them on Saturday and that they stood willing to talk, Mr. Panetta said that there was "nothing to talk about" as long as the Republicans insisted on raising Medicare premiums.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, issued a statement late today saying that the President was unwilling to increase Medicare premiums by $11 per month "on every Medicare beneficiary as a condition for keeping the Government running."
Senator Dole said President Clinton was "playing politics over a little Medicare provision that doesn't raise anyone's premium."

HEADLINE: Uncertainty on Treasury Sales

 BODY:
Treasury auctions are up in the air pending resolution of the dispute between the White House and the Republican Congressional leadership over the Federal budget and the debt.
The only auction scheduled for this week was today's regular sale of three- and six-month bills. Traders said that by the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.40 percent and the six-month bill was at 5.29 percent.

HEADLINE: Without Powell in Race, What's a Centrist to Do?

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Charles J. Kelly Jr., managing director of Citizens for Colin Powell and a veteran of the draft-Eisenhower campaign, has not quite figured out what to do with all the volunteers who enlisted in the Powell-for-President movement.
"We'll have to think about how not to lose the positive energy he brought into people's lives," he said. 
 Mr. Kelly's quandary underscores the predicament for Republican voters who call themselves moderates and for voters of various political beliefs who say they are most comfortable in the centrist camp. Now that General Powell has decided not to run in 1996, what's a die-hard Powell moderate supposed to do?
For the moment, the choices are familiar. Democrats as well as Republicans will try to capture the centrist energy generated by the possibility of General Powell's candidacy. But analysts across the political spectrum feel that neither party and no candidate is offering a true centrist program.
As quiet as they keep it, most Americans wear the moderate label. In a New York Times/CBS News Poll last month, 44 percent of Americans called themselves moderates compared with 16 percent who picked the liberal label and 34 percent who described themselves as conservative. In the same poll, General Powell was rated favorably by 43 percent of the public.
Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator and Democratic Presidential candidate in 1992, said Republicans and Democrats did not understand where a majority of Americans were. "There is a clear consensus and it's right in the middle -- socially liberal, fiscally conservative, pro-environment, pro-campaign reform," said Mr. Tsongas. "The problem is neither party fits the paradigm." So far this year, he said, he has tested this view in 25 states in speeches before diverse audiences. "You see people nodding everywhere you go," he said.
In the long term, some Republican politicians expect their front-runner, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, to win over moderates who were attracted to a Powell candidacy. But other politicians and observers believe that Republican moderates and centrists in general will be shopping for a candidate who subscribes to the middle-of-the-road views General Powell sketched out on his book tour this fall.
The New York Times/CBS News poll included 418 self-identified Republicans in the survey sample of 1,269 respondents. Of the 418 Republicans, 50 percent called themselves conservatives, 38 percent described themselves as moderates, 8 percent said they were liberals and 4 percent said they did not know what to call themselves.
Picking General Powell's political beneficiary is an easy call for some seasoned politicians. "Dole is the leader of the pack," said Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican and a Dole supporter. "Most will move that direction." Though she is not exactly sure where moderate energy will go in the Republican primaries, she said she expected it to "surface more in the general election."
Her moderate Republican colleague from Maine, Senator William S. Cohen, said he also expected Mr. Dole to inherit a lot of Powell supporters because Mr. Dole is the front-runner and "a classic conservative with Midwest roots and a good heart" who understands how to help people on the lower rungs of the economic ladder.
But because Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, are challenging Mr. Dole from the right, Mr. Cohen's view comes with a caveat. Mr. Dole's chances of inheriting Powell supporters, especially in the general election, "assumes that Dole doesn't go further off to the right to preempt Gramm and Buchanan," Mr. Cohen said.
The Cohen-Kassebaum take on the campaign after General Powell's decision last Wednesday is by no means the only scenario circulating these days.
Larry Sabato, a professor of political science at the University of Virginia, is not alone in his belief that many moderates in the Republican Party and lots of centrists in the electorate are now homeless.
"The centrists have turned off to Clinton and off to Dole for essentially the same reason," Professor Sabato said. "They view Clinton as a captive of the left and Dole as the captive of the right. So the question is: Where do they go?"
Mr. Sabato's 1996 election scenario follows two plot lines.
While General Powell's spectator position helps Mr. Dole in the short term, he said, moderate Republicans could help a Candidate X who could emerge from the second tier of Republican candidates to become Mr. Dole's principal challenger after the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. Under these circumstances, Mr. Sabato said, the Republican Presidential candidates with a chance to upset Mr. Dole and inherit centrist support are Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee and Steve Forbes, the scion of the Forbes publishing fortune.
"Candidate Y," Mr. Sabato said, "is the independent candidate who will inherit centrist support if the party nominees turn out to be Clinton and Dole." He said voters will not like President Clinton's triangulation strategy -- moving to the center and keeping himself at arm's length from Congressional Democrats and Republicans. Nor will they appreciate Mr. Dole's running to the right just to survive the Republican primaries and shifting to the center for the general election.
"At a certain point, voters know you don't mean it," Mr. Sabato said. "They realize that you are everywhere and therefore nowhere philosophically.
"If the choice is Clinton or Dole, you're going to hear a collective sigh audible from coast to coast: 'Is that all there is? Don't we have another choice?' And that is the genesis of Candidate Y."
In a CBS News Poll conducted after Mr. Powell announced his decision, 57 percent of Republican primary voters said they were satisfied with the choices they had, while 39 percent said they wished others would join the race.
Mr. Sabato's take on the 1996 Presidential race resonates with a number of politicians, including Mr. Tsongas and Thomas Kean, the former two-term Republican Governor of New Jersey. Mr. Kean, president of Drew University, said, "If the parties don't adjust themselves, the people will." He said that poll numbers show that General Powell's centrist views represent perhaps the majority of Republican voters and that many such voters agree with General Powell on hot-button issues as well. Republicans Mr. Kean talks to like and respect Mr. Dole but "rightly or wrongly" are not sure Mr. Dole can win a general election, he said.
Before General Powell declined to run, Mr. Tsongas said that Democrats and Republicans alike would approach him about the possibility of a Powell candidacy. He described them as Democratic Party activists who believe in fiscal responsibility and see their children's future at risk and as Republicans "upset at environmental trashing."

HEADLINE: SUNY's New Trustees to Press for More Campus Independence

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki does not yet control the governing board of the State University of New York. But his seven appointees have made their agenda clear: bringing a free-market approach to the government-run university system.
Beginning in June, Mr. Pataki took advantage of an unusual opportunity to name a large proportion of the SUNY board at once, because his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, had not filled some vacancies. With two more openings to be filled, the Governor could have a majority on the 16-member board by December. 
 His appointees so far come from traditional Republican backgrounds, including Edward Cox, a corporate lawyer married to Richard M. Nixon's daughter Patricia; Thomas F. Egan, an investment banker from Westchester County and former member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, and Erland E. Kailbourne, the chairman of Fleet Bank and the only Pataki appointee with an undergraduate degree from a SUNY campus.
Already, the new trustees are shaking up the university. In a set of proposals released last week, they advocated giving the campuses more freedom to do everything from setting their own tuitions to keeping any surpluses.
Candace de Russy, a new member who lives in Bronxville, N.Y., and has a doctorate in French, called the vision "radical campus autonomy."
The proposals are an attempt to set the board's agenda as it considers a major multiyear plan for the system of 64 campuses and 400,000 students. The trustees will discuss the plan and may vote on some of its elements at a meeting to be held this afternoon at the Sagamore Hotel in Bolton Landing, N.Y., north of Albany. The plan is to be released to the State Legislature on Dec. 1.
The first indication that new board members were flexing their muscles came last month, when, joined by two older members, they refused to approve a routine budget request to the Governor's Division of the Budget, saying they had not had enough time to consider the numbers.
"We had to know what we were approving," said Dr. Harvey Wachsman, a physician and lawyer who is one of the board's newest members. "It turned out that it was the first thing that showed that things were going to change."
Because of the vote against the budget last month, the trustees convened a finance committee that had been dormant for some years. And at the committee's meeting on Nov. 1, the new board members again pushed for change, suggesting that the university ask for much less money than it received this year.
It was a radical proposal. Normally, the State University system -- like other state agencies -- writes a budget wish list, which is then cut by the Governor or the Legislature. In the spring, after the state budget passes, university officials must scramble to fill in any gaps, by cutting spending or raising tuition, which they did last year, boosting its annual cost by $750 to $3,400 for four-year schools.
This year, the Division of the Budget imposed new restrictions on the request. It asked for, and SUNY administrators prepared, a request that used the 1995-96 numbers with 1.6 percent added for inflation, for a total of $1.5 billion.
But the new trustees argued for a new approach: be realistic.
"It is best for our students that we take a hold of our numbers and we tell the Division of the Budget that we're serious," said Mr. Cox. "We should say, 'This is what we want, this is all we want, no more.' We'd be making a statement by doing it."
He also said that since many trustees believed another tuition increase was inevitable, they should account for it now. But Arnold Gardner, the chairman of the finance committee, who was named to the board by Gov. Hugh L. Carey in 1980, said that if the trustees did not advocate on SUNY's behalf, no one would.
When the new trustees talk about "making the campuses responsive to their individual markets," Mr. Gardner said, "to me that means, 'We won't close any campuses, but we'll let the forces of nature close them if they can't survive.'
"It's a Darwinian approach," he said.
The budget argument and last week's proposals for revamping the university have set off alarms among some old members and Democrats in the Legislature. Frederic Salerno, a vice chairman of Nynex who has led the board since 1990, said that some new trustees did not understand how the board had done business in the past.
"There is the idea among some of the new members that the old trustees didn't do anything but rubber-stamp what SUNY central wanted," Mr. Salerno said, speaking of the central administration. "And, boy, it's an unfair observation."
In the State Legislature, where most of the major proposals for changing the university would have to be approved, Democrats are watching the trustees carefully.
In an interview, Edward C. Sullivan, the Manhattan Democrat who leads the Assembly's higher education committee, delivered a warning: "These proposals would in effect destroy the university as we know it and leave behind a collection of semiprivate colleges, some technical colleges and several closed campuses. It won't happen in one year, but the handwriting's on the wall."

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS TACTICS TO AVOID DEFAULT WITHOUT DEBT BILL

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin indicated today that he was preparing to carry out a costly emergency plan to forestall a national default at midweek by juggling the Federal Government's books to pay off investors.
Mr. Rubin's comments came as Speaker Newt Gingrich forwarded to President Clinton a bill passed by Congress on Friday to raise the debt ceiling temporarily, a bill that is laden with restrictions on the Treasury's ability to use its small arsenal of weapons to delay default. Mr. Clinton has vowed to veto the measure, probably on Monday, because he views it as an effort by Congressional Republicans to corner him into signing their version of the Federal budget or being forced into default next month. 
 The positions of the Republican majority in Congress and the White House continued to harden today, with only a few glimmers of possible compromise. The Government seems almost certain to begin a partial shutdown early Tuesday morning after Republicans and the Administration spent the weekend dueling on talk shows and at news conferences and rejecting each other's preconditions for talks to work out their differences.
President Clinton invited Congressional leaders of both parties to meet him in the Oval Office on Monday, but only if Republicans drop an increase in Medicare premiums from a spending bill that would keep the Government functioning. Mr. Gingrich rejected that condition. [Page A20.]
Earlier, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, had offered to drop the restrictions from the debt ceiling bill if Mr. Clinton would agree to the Republican timetable of seven years for a balanced budget. The White House rejected that suggestion, as it had a similar notion put forward by Mr. Gingrich the day before.
While a Government shutdown would have ramifications for Federal services around the country, Administration officials are increasingly focused on the risks of a default, which could reverberate in markets around the world. Mr. Rubin's emergency plan, which may kick into action as early as Monday, involves "disinvestments" from two huge Government-administered retirement funds and other steps that Mr. Rubin himself said several weeks ago "raise serious, unresolved legal and practical issues."
Today, he repeated those warnings, adding with resignation, "This is no way to run a country."
Mr. Rubin is clearly walking a fine line, hoping to scare Congress into action but to avoid shaking the markets. The signal that an imminent default could be forestalled seemed to be part of that balancing act.
Mr. Rubin's decision comes as he and the Republican majority have sketched out wildly different notions of how the bond and stock markets might react to the threat of default. The Treasury Secretary, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, has warned for weeks that Americans would pay for a default "for years and years to come," in the form of higher interest rates that borrowers would charge to the United States because of the increased risk that repayment would not come on time.
His position seemed bolstered late Friday when a leading credit-rating agency, Standard & Poor's, warned that the United States was in jeopardy of losing its triple-A credit rating because of investor concerns that debt payments would be held hostage to political arguments over the budget.
Even an increase of only a half a percentage point on the rates the Government pays could cost the United States $25 billion more a year and increase the cost for homeowners holding variable-rate mortgages. The Clinton Administration is betting that angry voters would blame the Republicans for those higher payments. A surge in interest rates would also clobber investors holding existing Treasury bonds, because the price of those securities would tumble.
A radically different view is held by Mr. Gingrich and endorsed by a number of leading Republican financiers. They insist Mr. Rubin is deliberately trying to scare the markets to bolster his political agenda. And they claim that the markets will yawn rather than panic, viewing a Federal default as just another part of Washington's giant game of fiscal chicken as Congress and the White House argue over budget priorities. If the result of that argument is a commitment to faster deficit reduction, they claim, interest rates will even be driven lower.
Senator Dole reiterated that view again today on ABC's "This Week with David Brinkley" declaring that "the markets have changed" and that a balanced budget would mean that "interest rates are going to drop a couple of percentage points."
"This whole idea that there would be a permanent rise in interest rates is nonsense," Stanley Druckenmiller, managing director of the Soros Fund, said during a visit to Washington to brief Mr. Gingrich. "Today, we buy Argentinian and Brazilian debt," he said, naming two countries that were in desperate financial shape a decade ago. "The whole idea is absurd."
But the immediate question is whether Mr. Gingrich, Mr. Dole and their allies have the intestinal fortitude to test the theory in real life. If they are wrong and the markets go haywire in coming weeks, it could derail both their budget battle and Mr. Dole's run for the Presidency.
Analysts have used military analogies to underline the seriousness of this particular showdown. The most alarming hark back to the early days of the cold war, when many believed that the United States had the power to deliver a pre-emptive nuclear strike that would wipe out the former Soviet Union's missiles without devastating retaliation. But no political leader ever seriously considered testing it for fear of being wrong in such a winner-take-all calculation.
In the past decade, Congress has also briefly threatened to withhold approving an increase in the debt limit, but both market analysts and political experts say the issue has never reached the crisis point it is at today. The difference is that containing the nation's borrowing authority has been seized by the freshmen and sophomore classes in Congress as a symbol of their deficit-cutting fervor, even though the borrowing are simply a reflection of how much Congress has spent beyond the revenue the Government brings in. The White House points out that even the budget proposed by the Republicans would require a huge increase in the debt ceiling over the next seven years.
Meanwhile, Mr. Rubin is carefully talking around questions about what kind of financial tricks to avoid default he is keeping in his silos.
For example, Treasury officials have described one way they may try to get through the next few days without defaulting on roughly $25 billion in interest payments due Wednesday and $40 billion in principal on Treasury securities due on Thursday.
The first line of defense would be an order from Mr. Rubin to cease the nightly investment, in overnight securities, of the so-called "G-fund," a $21.5 billion retirement fund for Federal employees. That would allow the Treasury to issue securities in the same amount without crossing the current debt ceiling limit, $4.9 trillion.
That sum is not enough to meet the payments due on Wednesday. So Mr. Rubin would have to reach into other funds. His next step would probably be to disinvest holdings in the $350 billion Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. Mr. Rubin would first have to declare, however, that he believes the debt limit crisis would last months or more before he could legally sell some of the fund's securities. Eventually, under current law, Congress would have to pay back to both funds the interest they lost because of this maneuver.
Then, there are nearly 180 other funds the Government oversees. But meddling with them could open the Administration to charges that it was violating its fiduciary responsibility to people whose savings are kept in those funds. That leaves aside the giant Social Security trust fund, which Mr. Rubin has vowed not to use "for any purpose other than to insure the payment of benefits to Social Security recipients."
"We will work our way through Nov. 15 but it will be through taking extraordinary actions," Mr. Rubin said today.
One of the big concerns is how foreign investors view the manipulations. In the year ended June 30, foreigners bought 65.6 percent of the new securities issued by the Treasury. If they decided that the risk of letting their money get caught up in a political dispute was too great they could precipitate a selloff.
So far that has not happened, partly because investors seem to feel that Mr. Rubin would not allow a default to occur under any circumstances. Unfortunately for Mr. Rubin, what's reassuring to the markets is also bad politics. By constantly moving back the date when a default is certain, he has opened himself up to criticism from Mr. Gingrich that he is manufacturing the crisis.
"Secretary Rubin has the authority to avoid default," Mr. Gingrich said, brushing past the point that the debt-limit bill he sent to the White House today would strip away that authority in the future. "In fact, he's now privately telling the President not to worry."

HEADLINE: Insecurity Rocks Mexico's Cradle-to-Coffin System

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12

 BODY:
By late afternoon, when the coffins are gone and a cleaning man is vacuuming the carpets, Felipe Flores Duran finally has time to finish the paperwork. Of the three funeral parlors on his Mexico City intersection, the one run by the Mexican Social Security Institute is by far the biggest and classiest, with seven viewing rooms and a snack bar, and in this quiet moment, Mr. Flores Duran, its director, says that is how it should be.
"Having the best possible service for the dead is something that's really important to Mexicans," he said. 
 During the last half-century, Mexico's Social Security system has evolved into a lifelong security blanket that includes hospitals in which one out of every three Mexicans is born, and a chain of 16 funeral parlors that, like the one run by Mr. Flores Duran, offer $73 pine coffins and dignified $52 wakes.
The system also tends to the basic business of collecting and managing retirement pensions, but poor management and the fact that Mexicans are living longer have left Social Security so close to financial collapse that President Ernesto Zedillo has proposed a sweeping overhaul.
The President says business and labor support changes that will hand over some pensions to private managers and make the system more efficient. A new law was introduced on Thursday. But for many of the 37 million Mexicans currently enrolled, the system and its branch services are an untouchable birthright.
If American politicians face a storm of protest whenever they suggest changing Social Security in the United States, imagine what awaits Mr. Zedillo as he takes on an institution that includes not only the Mexican equivalent of Social Security, but also Medicare, Medicaid, the National Endowment for the Arts and even Club Med and Wal-Mart.
"I'm afraid of the changes," said Procopio Ramirez, 64, a construction worker from Mexico City who is about to retire and is not sure he will receive the pension he thinks he qualifies for. "It seems like they might privatize Social Security and if they do that, the medical help won't be the same and the pensions won't be as much."
Felipe Arias Bertrand, who spent most of his life working for the Social Security agency, is now a leader in a movement to block the proposed changes, which he says go too far.
"We recognize that the system needs a profound revision," he said, "but in order to remake it, what the Government now proposes will destroy the system."
Besides reflecting the dreams and desires of millions of Mexicans, the Social Security system today also underscores some of the profound changes that have taken place in the 52 years since it was created.
In 1950 the average life expectancy of Mexicans was 49.6 years, which meant that few who contributed to the system lived long enough to collect. By 1993, an improved standard of living and better medical care largely provided by the agency's 1,764 hospitals and clinics had helped raise life expectancy to 70.5. The number of insured workers and their families who rely on the Social Security pensions has come close to exceeding the contributions being made by active workers.
An analysis by the agency in March estimated that by the year 2002, the system will be bankrupt. This is a problem shared by social security systems in the United States and Europe. But in Mexico, it is a recent phenomenon.
During the years when contributions exceeded payouts, the Mexican agency was flush with money and decided to expand into health care and the other diverse components that now are part of the system. As demographics changed, the system raided the pension funds to support the hospitals and other services.
The medical part is also under stress. In 1950, the leading causes of death were diarrhea and pneumonia, which typically struck the young. Today, with an older population, the leading causes are heart disease and cancer, which can require long and expensive hospitalization.
Mr. Zedillo sees Social Security reform as an essential step toward recovering from the economic crisis that followed the devaluation of the peso in December. By allowing workers to open individual retirement accounts that would be professionally managed and offer higher interest rates than the current system, Mr. Zedillo expects to be able to increase Mexico's low rate of domestic savings. More savings would be used to finance investments.
To improve health care, Mr. Zedillo wants to broaden the base of those covered by Social Security. Now only salaried workers and their families can join the system, leaving millions of Mexicans without access to the hospitals.
Contributing workers and their families are entitled to medical care at most of the nation's hospitals and clinics and to a minimum pension of $2 dollars a day after age 65 or in case of a disability. Access to the stores, day-care centers, vacation centers and funeral parlors run by Social Security is available to all Mexicans.
Contributions to Social Security, made by workers, employers and the Government, total more than 25 percent of salary, and evasion is widespread. For a clerical worker who makes about $185 a month, the total social security tax is around $45 a month, of which the worker pays about $11.
Proposed changes would lower costs and extend coverage to self-employed workers and people in the huge informal economy.
The fate of the ancillary programs that the agency has acquired during the last five decades is uncertain. The in-house analysis done in March made it clear that they are a huge drain on the system.
About the only service that actually turned a profit last year were the funeral parlors. Perhaps that is why Mr. Flores Duran, the Mexico City director, does not worry about the coming changes. "It's a fact that the Mexican system will undergo a great change," Mr. Flores Duran said, "but most of the changes will have to do with living people. I don't think they'll do anything to the funeral service."

HEADLINE: Professor Talked of Understanding But Now Reveals Ties to Terrorists

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
When the radical organization Islamic Jihad selected a new leader late last month, its choice struck people at the University of South Florida like a sucker punch, a painful blow out of the blue.
News reports from Syria showed a face of jaw-dropping familiarity: the face of a bespectacled man known on campus as Ramadan Abdullah, an adjunct professor who taught Middle Eastern politics until he left last spring. Now identified by his full name, Ramadan Abdullah Shallah, he vowed a "hard war" against Israel, which he accused of killing Islamic Jihad's founder, Fathi Shiqaqi, on Oct. 26 in Malta. 
 Dr. Shallah applauded the assassination on Nov. 4 of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel by an Israeli law student.
With his violent words, Dr. Shallah exploded the image he had carefully cultivated for four years as a soft-spoken scholar who preached understanding and eschewed militant rhetoric, a genial man who won student plaudits and invitations to lunch with professors. When Dr. Shallah's wife, Maha, gave birth to a daughter last February, faculty members sent cards.
Now, people at the state-run university are wrestling with the realization that they had unwittingly played host to the person who became the leader of Islamic Jihad, an Iranian-backed organization whose suicide bombers have killed Israeli soldiers, civilians and an American college student.
"We couldn't be more surprised," said Mark T. Orr, a retired U.S. Air Force colonel who directs the university's international studies center. "There was never any indication that he had any sympathy with acts of terror for anyone's cause."
Paul Eckelkamp, a former Navy intelligence specialist who was one of Dr. Shallah's students, voiced a similar view. "He didn't seem like a radical to me," said Mr. Eckelkamp, a 25-year-old junior. "He seemed like a very well-educated man who was concerned about how Islam was viewed around the world."
Up to a point, that would describe Dr. Shallah, who was born 37 years ago in the Gaza Strip, then under Egyptian administration.
His resume lists impressive distinctions: a 1990 doctoral degree in Islamic and Middle Eastern studies from the University of Durham in England, authorship of scholarly articles on Middle Eastern economics and fluency in English, Arabic and Hebrew, with reading ability in Persian.
He also taught economics at the Islamic University of Gaza from 1982 to 1986 -- just when Islamic Jihad was being formed in the area by young intellectuals who admired Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the spiritual leader of Iran. Dr. Shallah has recently been reported to have been among its earliest leaders.
When he arrived in Tampa in the summer of 1991, apparently carrying an Egyptian passport, Dr. Shallah came at an opportune time to slip into an academic role.
A year earlier, several Palestinian scholars in Tampa had founded the World and Islam Studies Enterprise, a small research institute in a minimall here.
One of the institute's founders was Khalil Shiqaqi, a visiting scholar at the University of South Florida and a brother of Islamic Jihad founder Fathi Shiqaqi. Khalil Shiqaqi has been considered a political moderate, without connections to Islamic Jihad. He now teaches in Nablus, on the West Bank.
Another institute founder was Sami al-Arian, 37, a Kuwaiti-born Palestinian who is a tenured professor of engineering at the University of South Florida. Dr. Arian said Dr. Shallah had offered to work without pay for the institute. "He was one of the best things you can ever imagine, someone who wants to give his time and volunteer," said Dr. Arian, who added that he had never suspected him of being anything other than a scholar. "It's unbelievable to me."
Dr. Shallah became the institute's director of administration, with an office, a computer and a fax machine. He published heavily footnoted articles on economics in the institute's quarterly, an Arabic-language journal. And he gained access through his position to the university.
About the time he arrived, the institute came to the attention of the university's Committee for Middle Eastern Studies. Formed in 1991, the committee's mission included the possibility of setting up a Middle East center, according to its guidelines.
In these circumstances, the World and Islam Studies Enterprise "was a godsend," said Arthur J. Lowrie, an adjunct professor who retired from the United States Foreign Service. Its scholars, devout Muslims knowledgeable about Middle Eastern affairs, offered "the kind of expertise it would be rare to find among American academics," he said.
In March 1992, university officials signed an agreement with the institute to hold conferences and exchange faculty members "by appointing them to temporary teaching or research positions." Dr. Shallah signed on the institute's behalf.
At a conference, Dr. Shallah introduced a speaker with these words: "We believe cooperation and intellectual dialogue help Americans and Muslims reach common grounds of understanding."
Last May, the agreement became controversial, after The Tampa Tribune charged that the institute had a connection, mainly through Dr. Arian, to the Islamic Committee for Palestine, a local group that had sponsored conferences supporting the intifada, the 1988-93 Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza. The Tribune suggested that the committee had ties to Islamic Jihad and Hamas, another militant group. Dr. Arian vigorously denied any link to those organizations, as did the institute.
Nevertheless, the university, citing procedural errors, suspended its agreement with the World and Islam Studies Enterprise in June.
That month, Dr. Shallah left the United States, telling friends he needed to tend to his gravely ill father in Gaza. Mr. Lowrie and Dr. Arian said they had heard nothing from him after that but had thought he had a job offer in Europe.
But Alaa Saftawi, a senior member of Islamic Jihad, told The Associated Press recently that Dr. Shallah had shelved his academic career last summer to work full time for Islamic Jihad. News of Dr. Shallah's selection to head the organization and his connection to the university was reported in the Nov. 3 issue of The Forward, the Jewish weekly published in New York.
In the semester before he left, Dr. Shallah taught Middle East history and politics at the university, just as he had during the spring semester of 1994. He also signed a loyalty oath, swearing that he supported the United States Constitution.
"Like all universities, we're vulnerable," said President Betty Castor, a former Florida Commissioner of Education. "Here was someone who had credentials which were examined at the departmental level. People around here feel a little betrayed right now."
A university spokesman, Todd Simmons, said students' written evaluations of Dr. Shallah's courses had praised his teaching.
But some students now recall oddities in Dr. Shallah's methods. "I never remember him discussing Israel," Mr. Eckelkamp said. "He would a lot of the time discuss 'the Palestine area.' "
Similar complaints reached Daniel J. Berman, director of the campus chapter of the Hillel Foundation. That worried him, he said, because "a lot of students are coming here and getting their first exposure to Middle East politics from the professors."
Still, Dr. Shallah did little else to call attention to himself. No one remembers him speaking out in favor of any militant group. Off campus, he lived modestly, renting a two-bedroom apartment on a quiet residential street. Colleagues respected his privacy. He received only $2,300 for each of his courses, but no one inquired too closely about how he supported himself.
Now the question most often heard is why a top figure in a terrorist organization spent four years in central Florida. "Why Tampa?" Dr. Orr asked.
One professor, Abdelwahab Hechiche, who teaches government and international affairs, offered a possible answer. "Everywhere in America, people who work hard can be in touch with the whole world," he said. "See, many people visit here from Europe and the Middle East."
"At the same time, Tampa is not Washington, D.C.; it is not New York," said Dr. Hechiche, who was born in Tunisia. "This is an atmosphere for anonymity."
That would fit a scenario described by Yehudit Barsky, a senior research analyst with the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. Around 1988, she said, organizations like Islamic Jihad began moving leaders not directly involved in terrorism abroad.
These men living in the West had access to fax machines and personal computers, enabling them to communicate with one another and publish work for distribution in the Middle East, she said, adding that it paid to keep a low profile.
That still leaves a question in the mind of Mr. Lowrie, who befriended Dr. Shallah. Mr. Lowrie is concerned that Muslims are often portrayed harshly in the United States, with the vast majority of peaceful believers smeared with the broad brush of violence caused by a few, and Dr. Shallah had said that he shared this concern.
"What about the damage he's done to understanding Islam, getting rid of the stereotypical thing?" Mr. Lowrie said. "Instead, his actions have played into the hands of his most direct enemies."

HEADLINE: In Utah, a Pitched Battle Over Public Lands

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: ESCALANTE, Utah

 BODY:
One of the last blank spots left on the map of the mainland United States is a big swath of sandstone skyscrapers, rust-colored canyons and cake layers of earthly turmoil.
The cartographers of this region must have been in a perpetual funk, trying to attach names like Devil's Backbone, Deadman Ridge and Carcass Canyon to the luminous landscape of southern Utah. But what looked useless and forlorn to Mormon pioneers of the 19th century is shaping up, in the last years of the 20th century, as a treasure at the center of the biggest land fight now before Congress. 
 John Ford tried to capture this region in his western movies, and Ansel Adams attempted to do the same thing with a still camera. What Congress is poised to do now is pass a bill that will essentially zone 22 million acres of public land here in such a way as to determine how nature and commerce will interact for decades to come.
A land of dinosaur tracks and ancient Anasazi ruins, most of the red rock canyon country of southern Utah is run by the Federal Bureau of Land Management. And most of it is wild and open country, with very little development. The bill before Congress, sponsored by the Utah Congressional delegation, would set aside 1.8 million acres as protected wilderness but allow mining, road building and other industrial developments in the remaining 20 million acres of bureau land. A Dutch-owned company, Andalex Resources, is awaiting approval to construct a huge coal-mining operation in the heart of this largely roadless area.
The bill has been approved by a House subcommittee and is awaiting similar action in the Senate. A much broader bill that would set aside 5.7 million acres for protection is being proposed by a coalition of environmental groups and members of Congress.
But the conflict in Utah is more than just the biggest single public land issue before Congress this year. The delegation-sponsored bill would set a precedent, opponents say, altering the intent of the 1964 Wilderness Act. Opponents say it would allow roads, reservoirs and power lines even inside protected wilderness, areas that are supposed to be places "where man himself is but a visitor," according to the law.
Also, the bill would take 18 million acres of Federal land out of consideration for any future wilderness designation, directing the Bureau of Land Management to manage it for miners, ranchers, timber companies and other users.
Wilderness used to be an issue of less conflict. Scientists, photographers and outdoor lovers of both parties found open doors in Washington when lobbying for wild land. The late Western writer Wallace Stegner appealed to President John F. Kennedy for the first of the nation's wilderness bills by writing that, "Something will have gone out of us as a people if we ever let the remaining wilderness areas be destroyed."
Since then, about 39 million acres outside of Alaska have been preserved, areas where hunting, fishing and hiking are allowed, but activities that would leave lasting scars are not. The people who ride snowmobiles or motorcycles, and who prospect for minerals, say they have been shut out.
This year the tables have turned, and it is wilderness advocates who are being shunned -- at least in Washington. A onetime taxidermist, Representative Don Young of Alaska, a Republican, is trying to weaken the Endangered Species Act, and a former pesticide salesman, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, has been trying to reduce the enforcement power of the Environmental Protection Agency.
Both men, who are in leadership positions in the House, chafe at being characterized as despoilers, and say what they are trying to do is restore balance. Also, they say too much public land is already under the restrictive rule of the Federal Government, especially in the West.
When Terry Tempest Williams, the Utah nature essayist who traces her Mormon roots to 1847, went to testify before the parks and public lands subcommittee this year on behalf of the broader bill, Representative James V. Hansen, the Utah Republican who is the panel's chairman, left the room. At a later public hearing in Utah, he told Ms. Williams that he could not understand what she was talking about. She is the naturalist in residence at the Utah Natural History Museum.
Out of power for decades, Western Republicans who now control the chief public land committees are in a rush to overturn years of conservation law. They have proposed oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, and are setting up a commission to close or sell off some national parks.
"It's like having Dracula in charge of the blood bank," said Ken Rait of the Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, one of 90 groups pushing for the broader bill.
"There is a vindictiveness, a kind of mean-spirited sense of getting even with environmentalists," said Robert Redford, the actor and part-time Utah resident who has been fighting Western land battles for nearly 30 years.
The Utah wilderness has become a flashpoint, because it is the first time that Congress has tried to tackle the issue of protecting land on the nearly 300 million acres run by the B.L.M. Most wilderness areas are on Forest Service land or in national parks.
"People don't come to Utah for wilderness," Mr. Hansen said. He said that he loved the outdoors as much as any native Westerner, but that the lands that environmental groups wanted to protect did not really qualify as true wilderness.
"They sure don't come here to look at coal mines and clear-cut logging," said Mr. Redford, whose portrayal of the Sundance Kid as a foil to Paul Newman's Butch Cassidy in the popular movie helped spawn a multimillion dollar spinoff of tours along the old outlaws' trail.
Of late, people have been coming to Utah's wild lands in record numbers. More than five million people visited southern Utah in the last year, a threefold increase over a decade. They were drawn to five national parks, Bryce Canyon and Zion among them, and to the countless slickrock domes, empty canyons and broad vistas in the desert air.
"The old-timers who have been here forever can't believe what's going on," said Jack Pollock, a maintenance worker in Boulder, a little ranching town that sits at 6,600 feet. "People used to be afraid to come here because they thought it was nothing but rattlesnakes and Mormons."
Boulder was one of the last towns in the mainland United States to gain automobile access. It was depressed, as was much of this broad region known as the Colorado Plateau, after uranium miners abandoned the area in the 1950's. Now, sportsmen, mountain bikers and retirees flock here, a place where it is said you can look for nearly a hundred miles in most directions at night and not see a light generated by a human source.
"I get letters every day from people in my district who say, 'Jim, we need more wilderness,' " Mr. Hansen said. "I say if you can find it, fine. But there is not much true wilderness on this B.L.M. land."
Not true, said Jim Baca, who was director of the Bureau of Land Management in the first two years of the Clinton Administration.
"This particular crew in Congress is hateful, in a lot of respects, and they are listening to the fringe groups now making a lot of noise," he said. "They need to be reminded that the names of every American are on the deeds to those lands."
When Mr. Hansen and Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Utah's powerful senior senator, toured their home state last summer, they found there was far more support for wilderness than they had imagined. But Mr. Hatch still favors a small wilderness bill, saying there are oil, coal and mineral deposits on public land that are too rich to be go undeveloped.
Many of the new businesses that rely on unspoiled land say their voices are not being heard on the wilderness issue. Of the 22,000 public comments received over the last year, more than 70 percent of those were in favor of a large wilderness area -- a percentage that roughly matches polls taken by Salt Lake City news organizations.
By contrast, mining, logging and grazing interests have found open doors, after years of saying they were not listened to by environment-friendly Congressional committees.
"This coal mine is going to bring several hundred crucial jobs to our area," said Roger Carter, president of the southwest Utah chapter of People for the West, a prodevelopment group financed by mining, timber and ranching interests.
He was referring to the mine planned by Andalex Resources. The company envisions tapping into one of the richest coal veins in the United States, here in the Kaiparowits Plateau area, and then trucking the ore 240 miles to a railhead for eventual shipment to Asia. It would cause only minimal environmental damage, Mr. Carter said.
"For the 20 or 30 people who actually visit the plateau this far in, it could be a problem, but not for everyone else," he said.
But the emptiness, Ms. Williams noted, is precisely what gives southern Utah value beyond mere economic reasons. "If you knew wilderness in the way that you know love, you would be unwilling to let it go," she said at a recent hearing in Utah. "We are talking about the body of the beloved, not real estate."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In America;
Welfare Stampede

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
"Our children and our country cannot afford another four years of neglect from Washington," said Bill Clinton, in the campaign book he put together in 1992 with Al Gore. "The next generation of young people should not be America's first to grow up with less hope than their parents. It's time to act to help our children."
That last sentence was the important one. I misunderstood it when I first read it on page 47 of the amusingly titled book "Putting People First." I did not understand at the time that the future President's idea of helping children was to support legislation that would push another 1.2 million of them into poverty. 
 The Republicans who crafted the cruel welfare "reform" legislation that is now in the hands of Congressional conferees deserve the obloquy of decent and compassionate Americans. But it should not be forgotten that these Republicans passed quickly and joyfully through a conceptual door that was opened by Mr. Clinton, who promised repeatedly in his campaign to "end welfare as we know it."
It was his biggest applause line. And as he delivered it with a finesse that could be envied by the most skilled demagogue, Mr. Clinton had to know that the screaming, whistling, foot-stomping audiences were cheering something quite different from the detailed plan that Mr. Clinton's aides were handing out to more thoughtful observers.
Those campaign audiences were cheering what they thought they were hearing -- that Mr. Clinton planned to cut off welfare benefits to them. They did not realize that the detailed plan, which provided for education, job training, job placement, even job creation, would cost much, much more than welfare as we knew it. Had they known, they would have booed.
To watch Mr. Clinton do his welfare dance is to understand why his detractors call him Slick Willie.
In any event, the Republicans saw the door marked "End Welfare As We Know It" and they charged through it, not even thinking about the resources that were supposed to be provided to keep poor people from being left in the lurch. The Republicans are being followed by huge numbers of Congressional Democrats, who recognize a political stampede when they see one, and even by Mr. Clinton, who is now looking furtively around for a safe way to slip through the door himself.
If he does, which is to say, if he signs any version of the welfare legislation that is being hashed around in conference, it will be a betrayal and a disgrace that will leave Mr. Clinton on the wrong side of history. He will have done more harm to children with one stroke of his pen than Presidents Reagan and Bush combined.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan stated the matter clearly: "For the first time since it was enacted in 1935, we are about to repeal a core provision of the Social Security Act -- Aid to Families With Dependent Children."
The Senator described this as "an obscene act of social regression." He said it "visits upon children the wrath of an electorate disillusioned with government and lost to principle."
A report prepared for Congress by the Office of Management and Budget estimates that the welfare bill passed by the Senate could push as many as 1.2 million children into poverty, and the House bill as many as 2.1 million. Those estimates are conservative.
As Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, noted: "The report assumes no recession in the next decade, which is unprecedented. It assumes that all states have time limits no shorter than five years, although a number of states have already proposed two-year time limits."
And, she said, "it assumes 100 percent maintenance of effort" by the states, even though on Friday House and Senate conferees agreed that states would only have to maintain at 75 percent of last year's level.
The White House is threatening to veto legislation that is moving in conference toward the House version. But Mr. Clinton's press secretary has said the President "may have to accept" a bill that is close to the Senate version.
Well, of course, he doesn't have to. And he wouldn't if he believed, as James Agee did, that "in every child who is born, under no matter what circumstances, and of no matter what parents, the potentiality of the human race is born again."
