HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
From the Graham Repertory, a Study in Contrasts

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF 

 BODY:
Four and a half years after its founder's death, the Martha Graham Dance Company continues superbly to preserve the Graham repertory. The proof was on hand again Friday night, when the company presented two strikingly different Graham works: the lyric 1949 "Diversion of Angels" and the recently revived excerpts from a 1936 social-protest piece, "Chronicle."
Every audience, nonetheless, demands what the impresario Sol Hurok used to call "novelties." The Graham troupe's three-day season at City Center, which closed Saturday night, was used mainly to give New Yorkers a view of the world premiere that Robert Wilson, as guest choreographer, created for the company earlier at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. 
 Reviewed in Washington, the Wilson piece, "Snow on the Mesa," is subtitled "Portrait of Martha." It was placed in a new context at City Center, and not always to its advantage. At the Kennedy Center, "Mesa" was preceded by the 1944 Graham classic "Appalachian Spring," whose distilled dramatic image of a pioneer roof-raising has a visible if indirect link to Mr. Wilson's theater of images.
But "Diversion" and "Chronicle" are essays in emotion conveyed entirely through abstract movement, and their power sets up an anticipation of kinetic expression that Mr. Wilson's pictorial approach to movement was not intended to resemble.
Surprisingly, an essentially green cast in "Diversion" went beyond expectation in an especially well-defined performance of Graham's ode to love in its many aspects.
Fang-Yi Sheu, a newcomer, was the woman in red, emblematic of passion whose sharp contractions and swiftness were so striking. Miki Orihara, whose form is always superb, and the especially promising Marc Mann rightly elicited gasps with their playful and energized "yellow" duet. Peter London and Katherine Crockett (serene as the woman in white) had a majesty in the architectonic shapes of their own duet and epitomized a deeper love.
It was the articulate vitality of the entire cast that made this performance so dazzling. The ensemble included Martin Lofsnes, Gary Galbraith, Elizabeth Auclair, Sandra Kaufmann, Alessandra Prosperi and Amanda Thomas. Norman Dello Joio's music was heard on tape.
Powerful is the word for "Sketches From Chronicle," revived for the "Radical Graham" season last year at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. In 1936, Graham saw a world in turmoil and recalled World War I. The first segment is, in fact, titled "Specter 1914" and turns a lamenting woman reclining on a platform into a red-shrouded specter of death. Terese Capucilli's mesmerizing performance is anything but basic; it expands Graham's fabled economy of movement into a poetic dimension.
"Drums-Red Shroud-Lament," this segment's subtitle, echoes the spare style of music and dance in the 1930's that Graham used to contemporary effect in the section "Steps in the Street." Rika Okamoto was the woman absorbed into the patterns of the ensemble, danced to Wallingford Riegger's music. The subtitles of that section ("Devastation-Homelessness-Exile") are superseded by "Prelude to Action," which speaks of "Unity-Pledge to the Future." Here, a larger female group is exhorted by Ms. Capucilli, no longer in white as she was last year but in a suitably flaming red dress.
An audience new to Graham would have to realize that "Chronicle," a 1930's period piece, and "Diversion of Angels" present only a limited view of Graham's range. It is a range hinted at by "Snow on the Mesa." In one scene, "Very Young: Kachina Clowns," Mr. Wilson lets loose a swarm of grotesque dancers who cavort to the sound of breaking glass by Brad Fields. They are both tragic and comic.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terese Capucilli of the Martha Graham Dance Company at City Center, in "Sketches From Chronicle," choreographed by Graham in 1936. (Jack Vartoogian for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE TREASURY;
Delicate Juggling Act For U.S. Credit Rating

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
So how long can Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin keep up his juggling act?
The answer to that question is at the heart of the Clinton Administration's strategy of holding off the Republican-dominated Congress without actually ruining the impeccable credit rating the country has had since 1789. Every few days for the past month, Mr. Rubin has proclaimed that default is imminent, unless he takes extraordinary, and costly, action. And every few days, showing just a few cards at a time, he has come up with a strategy that keeps the United States afloat, and the markets and Congress guessing. 
 Today, he announced the outline of a strategy that would allow the Treasury to pay out $102 billion to investors on Wednesday and Thursday, not a bad trick for a country that technically can no longer borrow enough to buy a used car.
To pull it off, he is juggling accounts in two huge retirement funds, liquidating their investments so that the Government has more room to borrow without crossing its $4.9 trillion debt ceiling. He is using those funds because, under legislation passed a decade ago, Congress has committed the country to repaying any interest the two funds lose because of financial footwork of this kind.
But if this standoff lasts for several more weeks or months, Mr. Rubin will find himself running into dubious legal ground and shaky political territory. And there is always the lurking possibility that the bond markets, which rose today on the news that default has again been deferred, will suddenly decide that Mr. Rubin has run out of maneuvering room.
"You are watching a very intricate game of poker, with Gingrich and the markets occupying the other seats at the table," one of the Administration's senior economic officials said the other day. "And the hand that beats one doesn't necessarily beat the other."
So for Mr. Rubin, the challenge is clear. He must constantly proclaim that disaster is nigh, to keep the political pressure on Congress. And he must constantly keep that disaster a week or so away, to give his boss some room to operate without fear of a backlash for messing with retirement funds entrusted to the Government.
The elements of that strategy are dribbling out piece by piece, as Mr. Rubin shows just enough of his hand to keep the markets calm. By early Wednesday morning, assuming that no last-minute deal is struck with Congress, he will stop investing the Federal Employees Retirement System's fund in Government bonds. That will allow him to borrow up to $21.5 billion. That has been done before, and it is politically risk-free, because Congress passed legislation in 1985 to refund any lost interest to the fund. Unfortunately for Mr. Rubin, that money will barely get him through the end of the day on Wednesday.
After that, the Treasury Secretary dips into new territory. The same 1985 legislation allows him to declare a fiscal emergency, giving him the right to disinvest the $350 billion Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. No one has tried it before, and there are restrictions: the amount he can withdraw depends on how long he estimates the emergency -- the possibility of imminent default -- will continue. "The law does not say when, how, or in what amounts" the Secretary can liquidate the funds, creating more room to borrow, a senior Administration official dealing with the issue said today.
As a result, the Treasury is taking the position that the Secretary has broad discretion. Exactly how broad? Mr. Rubin's aides will not say.
They are being evasive for several reasons. The first is that Mr. Rubin's legal authority will almost certainly be challenged. Republicans, seeking to tie his hands in the bigger budget battle, are already encouraging suits charging that Mr. Rubin is violating his fiduciary responsibility to the Federal employees whose retirement money is stashed in the giant fund.
"The people on behalf of whom the trust fund is held may take an interest," the House majority leader, Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, said today.
Mr. Rubin is likely to respond that while he must protect the retirement fund, he also has a fiduciary responsibility to keep the United States out of default.
But as time goes on, Mr. Rubin will begin to run out of both political and legal room. There are more than 160 other trust funds, but none of the others are protected by legislation insuring that any interest lost in the name of preventing default would eventually be paid back to those funds. As a result, President Clinton will be loathe to touch that money, knowing it would create an outcry.
Even more complicated is the question of how to keep the markets happy. So far, investors have shrugged the whole situation off as inside-the-Beltway maneuvering. As long as Mr. Rubin keeps sending reassuring signals that he can meet the next payment, that view is unlikely to change.
But the minute the markets get nervous, Mr. Rubin and his sparring partner, Speaker Newt Gingrich, may quickly run out of options. Neither wants to be blamed for causing a market run, which could be felt by ordinary investors, holders of variable-rate mortgages and allies who hold hundreds of billions of dollars in Treasury securities.
In private, Mr. Rubin's aides seem most worried about foreign investors. The fear is that those investors will simply not want to take the risk of getting involved in the crossfire between Congress and the White House. They could voice their protest with their checkbooks, parking their national reserves in other currencies -- German marks, Japanese yen or the currency of a country that does not allow domestic politics to cast a pall on its creditworthiness.
The reaction of foreign investors, in the end, could be the measure of how much the debt-limit argument has affected American power in an age in which markets speak as loudly as military might.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE MARKETS;
Debt Bill Veto Brings Relief As Federal Default Is Avoided

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
President Clinton's veto of legislation to raise the Federal debt ceiling was greeted yesterday with relief by investors and financial markets.
Although the bill Mr. Clinton vetoed would have temporarily increased the Government's borrowing authority, it would also have taken away the Treasury's flexibility to avoid default by juggling funds. If Mr. Clinton had signed the bill, once the temporary increase expired, the threat of default would have been more intense than it is now. 
 Traders and investors have known for days that by tapping into various Government trust funds it administers, the Treasury could remain current on interest payments without increasing the borrowing authority.
But uncertainty remained about the Treasury's ability to tap into those funds until Mr. Clinton rejected the Republican bills yesterday. Now the Treasury can make payments due tomorrow and on Nov. 30. With this flexibility, Wall Street analysts predict that the Government is likely to avoid default without raising the debt ceiling through the middle of next month, at least. But at some point, the Treasury will face default unless the debt ceiling is raised.
In response to the veto, traders and investors bid up the price of outstanding securities yesterday, and pushed the yield on the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction of prices, down to 6.27 percent from 6.33 percent on Friday. The rally followed two successive days of falling prices and rising interest rates at the end of last week, when talk about default reached its zenith.
Playing politics with the debt ceiling is an old game, but the current impasse between Congress and the White House is so deep-seated that Wall Street is focusing on the potential of a default as never before.
Because the struggle is widely viewed as having more to do with political differences than with the economic ability of the United States Government to honor its debts, some analysts and money managers believe that the effects of a default would last only as long as the crisis itself. And those effects would be more than offset, these people argue, by the benefits of an agreement to balance the Federal budget by 2002.
But others are not so certain. James R. Capra, president of Capra Asset Management, a money management firm in Rye, N.Y., said yesterday that failure to veto the bills "would have increased the probability of default." He added, "And I am not sure I would want to endure three or four days of half-point increases in interest rates."
A default, even if temporary, would in all likelihood force a reassessment at financial institutions worldwide of the wisdom of holding debt issued by the United States.
"If you default for five seconds, the next time you can default for five days," said William Gross, a managing director at the Pacific Investment Management Company, a money management firm based in Newport Beach, Calif., with $70 billion in debt securities issued by the United States and other sovereign governments in its portfolio.
With yesterday's veto, Mr. Gross said, the "chances of default are about as close to zero as you can get for the next several months." He continued, "But if you told me the odds were higher than that, there is no doubt I would be selling securities, because it would have a disastrous effect on capital markets in the United States for decades to come."
While the danger of default has receded for now, money managers could get nervous again if the Treasury's ability to maneuver to avoid a default is challenged in court.
"If there is a restraining order placed on the Treasury, the market would get more worried," Mr. Capra said.
At the least, a default would likely force big buyers of Treasuries and other Government securities, like mutual funds, to question the wisdom of future investment in those securities.
Under the terms of the Investment Company Act of 1940, after default, directors at mutual fund companies would have to dispose of holdings of Government debt unless such sales were seen as not being in the best interests of the fund.
As of the end of September, figures from the Investment Company Institute show that mutual funds held nearly $375 billion worth of Government securities that potentially would be effected by a default.
In addition to forcing a review of current holdings, a default would preclude the purchase of any new debt securities by some of the biggest mutual fund companies.

HEADLINE: With 6 Boys and a Football, Tiny Texas Towns Stay Alive

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: ACKERLY, Tex., Nov. 11

 BODY:
This cotton-farming town on the Texas prairie has lost three of its four cafes, all three gas stations, both pharmacies, both barber shops, the three-story Coleman Hotel and its picture show. It has lost more than two-thirds of its peak population and about half its school football team.
But only half. 
 All of which goes to explain why nearly the entire town of 243 people turned out in a rattling West Texas wind on Friday night to watch the undefeated hometown Mustangs take on the undefeated Klondike Cougars for the Division 5-A championship of the state Six-Man Football League.
Six-man football, a throwback to the Depression years, is enjoying a resurgence here on the Great Plains, in a broad arc of the country curving from eastern Colorado down into the remote reaches of far West Texas. Paradoxically, the sport is growing in popularity precisely because in the past few decades these towns have been losing people.
"We used to play 11-man ball here," explained 92-year-old Cartis White, a retired cotton farmer. "But we're running out of boys."
The six-a-side game is played on a smaller field than regular football and the scoring is slightly different, with field goals counting 4 points and the value of points after touchdowns reversed. Every player is eligible to receive a pass, and the pace and high scores seem more akin to basketball.
The fans here in Ackerly -- the younger ones huddled in blankets against the wind, the older ones seated in the heated cabs of pickup trucks that ring the 80-yard field -- insist they would not go back to 11-man football even if they could.
"I love this game," said Zelda Bilbo, the principal of the elementary school. "I watch the Dallas Cowboys on TV and I think, 'What's going on there? There are just too many guys out on the field.' "
In Texas, where Friday night football is a revered institution, 84 public high schools, from Cotton Center to Lazbuddie and Sierra Blanca to Buena Vista, are now preserving the ritual by playing six-a-side football. Under state regulations for six-man ball, schools must have 79 or fewer students enrolled in grades 9 through 12. (Ackerly has 59.)
In the past 15 years, 27 schools have shifted to six-man ball and at least six more Texas schools are expected to switch next fall. Several dozen more schools in Colorado, Kansas, Nebraska and New Mexico have six-man teams.
Although the towns are tiny, the interest tends to be intense and some games, like the championship here, drew several hundred more people from surrounding counties.
In September, at a sort of Super Bowl exhibition of six-man football, 7,832 people turned out to watch the Mullin, Tex., Bulldogs play the Warriors of Weldona, Colo., two towns whose combined population is 343. The Colorado boys won, 58-44.
But big cities and the suburbs barely follow the sport, and many feats of athletic achievement on the small gridiron garner virtually no notice outside the farm and ranch communities where they happen.
"There are some amazing stories," said Granger Huntress, the editor and publisher of the Huntress Report, the weekly bible of six-man football in Texas.
"Petey Salaiz just eclipsed 10,000 yards rushing for his high school career this weekend," Mr. Huntress said, referring to a superstar on the Mullin Bulldogs. "It's incredible, the numbers he's running up. But nobody's talking about it, because it's six-man football."
A similar lament can be heard from the players themselves, who have no less natural talent or brawn than many schoolboys in other Texas towns where 11-man games are attended by college recruiters.
"There's not much chance of getting recognized when you play six-man, I guess," said Josh Richter of Ackerly, a 16-year-old tailback with a blond crew cut and bulging muscles who dreams of playing college ball for Texas Tech. "Not many people have ever heard of it."
On the day of the big game here, wisps of cotton from the harvest blow through the town like snow and gather on the vacant lots and near the empty buildings of Main Street.
"That there used to be the hardware store, and the building next door was a drug store with a soda fountain in it," said Laferne Webb, the assistant postmaster, pointing in the direction of some boarded-up buildings.
"There used to be a lot of stuff here, but now there's hardly nothing at all," she said of the town that is about 70 miles south of Lubbock.
In a wide region here known as Texas's Rolling Plains, all 28 counties lost population between 1980 and 1994 except Scurry County, which had a net gain of 10 people, according to United States Census figures.
At the sole surviving cotton gin in a town that used to have five, the consensus among farmers is that Ackerly has lost people because of "progress" of a sort -- farms are far more mechanized and efficient.
"It used to be that 100 acres was a good-sized family farm," said M. E. Dyer, an Ackerly resident for 72 of his 75 years. "Now my son, he's farming 1,800 acres of cotton, and that's about an average-sized farm these days."
Joe Zant, 62, paused from a battle between his swatter and a fly to add with a small laugh, "But he doesn't make any more money than if he had 80 acres."
Others said people had left the dusty plains simply because they did not need to live here anymore. "Supermarkets and paved roads, that's what did us in," Mr. White said.
As the afternoon wears on, an enormous dust storm blows in from the north, turning the big sky from blue to brown.
But none of the town's economic problems or the quickly dropping temperatures seem to matter much once it is time for the pep rally at the Sands Independent District School.
The gymnasium is packed with people of all ages and the crowd goes wild when Eric Herm, a 1992 graduate of the school whom defensive coordinator Jerry Gooch calls "the epitome of football," rises to speak.
Mr. Herm played fullback and middle linebacker and led the Mustangs to the state semifinals in 1991 before making the Abilene Christian University team as a walk-on.
"I know your heart is going 100 miles per hour right now," Mr. Herm told the Mustang players. "Every weight you lifted, every sprint you ran, every drop of sweat that came out of your head is not going to mean anything if you get beat tonight."
The Mustangs had enjoyed a ferociously successful season, winning all nine games, eight under a special "mercy rule" in six-man ball that ends the contest early if a team builds up a 45-point lead at any point after halftime. Its last five victories had been 52-6, 49-0, 49-0, 46-0 and 50-0.
Asked in the locker room why the team had done so well, the players turned solemn.
"Dedication," offered 17-year-old Dallas Hopper, a running back and linebacker.
"Attitude," said Jessie Cuellar, the team's kicker and both an offensive and defensive end.
At kickoff time, the wind is howling and the ball will not even stay on the tee. Despite the cold, it is a beautiful starry night in Texas and the moon is rising. The time for football has come.
The game starts well for the Mustangs, who score the first two touchdowns, the second one on a Dallas Hopper back-flip into the end zone.
The Mustangs carry an 18-14 lead into the locker room at halftime, but after that, fortunes turn. The game is all Klondike -- itself a powerful 9-0 team, four games won under the 45-point rule. Tanner Etheredge, a 190-pound Cougar who can run, pass and kick the ball into the end zone, turns the Mustangs' dream to nightmare, and Klondike wins, 40-24.
In the lockroom after the game, the Ackerly players are disconsolate, but all is not lost. With a 9-1 record, the team still makes the bi-district playoffs, and it is just possible they will get a rematch with the Cougars.
"You don't have a choice, guys, you have to get through this," said Billy Barnett, the head coach and high school principal. "You're going to deal with setbacks all the way through your adult life, and times like this are going to help you through it."
Outside, the fans are already talking of revenge in the playoffs.
"This town still has great spirit," said Leon Bodine, 86, a retired cotton farmer. "What's left of it does, anyway."

HEADLINE: New Subway Fare Brings Headaches but No Chaos

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Michael Williams, who is raising five children on a messenger's wages, stood in the morning cold at 125th Street in Harlem and called the $1.50 subway fare murderous. On Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, Pentland Phillip, 78th on line and late for his trip to the unemployment office, said he felt "no better than a slave." In Flushing, Queens, Norma Chassagne said the fare increase for the subways and buses should have been a nickel, although she said she would pay $2 a trip if the system actually worked.
Bedlam was averted yesterday on the first working day that the new fare took effect. But lines to buy tokens were still long and subway riders were grumpy about handing over an extra 25 cents per trip. As they swept through turnstiles during the morning rush hour, riders seemed particularly moved to gripe about service, provoked by the day's inconveniences and the added cost to their daily lives. 
 "They want $1.50; we want the subway clean," said Anthony Lombardi, 65, of Queens, who added that he had spent 40 years riding the subway. "On the 8:30 G train from Forest Hills, there was one car filthy, garbage all over. Food. Bags. Coca-Cola. Pigs.
"We have got to do something about this as New Yorkers. This is robbery, a dollar and a half. This is a disgrace."
Transit Authority officials, who had braced for calamity along with the rest of the city, absorbed the fury and clung to a diluted, tenuous victory. There were no major disruptions.
"Chaos didn't come," said Carol Meltzer, chief station officer for the Transit Authority.
The Transit Authority had averted the predicted chaos by deploying 300 extra token booth clerks and 75 additional supervisors and opening 250 extra windows. And at 50 of the busiest stations, tables were set up alongside the booths to handle sales of the new tokens.
But there were pockets of problems across the city. At the Jamaica station in Queens, people waited 40 minutes to purchase tokens. At the Utica Avenue station in Brooklyn, lines extended out both exits and onto the streets, where an instant, although joyless, entrepreneurial spirit took hold and people sold tokens to the desperately late for premium prices. Customers at several stations said clerks declined to sell them more than two tokens at a time.
As a result, some people said they missed job interviews, jury duty, college classes and more. A panel of Federal judges will hear arguments today as they decide whether the fare should be returned to $1.25 until a ruling is made on whether the increase is discriminatory. But some were so exasperated by yesterday's experience that even the prospect that the fare increase might be overturned did not sound appealing.
"Back to the old prices, and with refunds given out -- that's a fiasco I don't want to be a part of," said Valerie Vaggart, a paralegal in Brooklyn.
Again and again yesterday, people sounded the same theme: any increase in costs hurt, but a greater expense for increasingly inadequate service was a sham.
Last year, the Transit Authority cut 1,500 jobs, with the elimination of 1,500 more, many of whom will be maintenance and cleaning workers, scheduled for next year. The Transit Authority has also this year instituted the first widespread cutbacks in service in decades, with nearly a dozen subway lines operating less regularly, if at all. A recent survey of those lines by The New York Times indicated that they were not even functioning at their reduced level.
Kim Husbands, who works at a retail jewelry store in Manhattan, filled out a postcard for Gov. George E. Pataki at an event staged at Rockefeller Center by the Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group for subway riders. Her card read: "I would rather walk home four nights a week than to give to your pet monopoly another penny."
Mr. Williams, who makes $7 an hour and is raising five children in the Manhattanville projects in Harlem, called his plight at the turnstiles "suicide without the gun."
"It's no win as far as poor people go," Mr. Williams said. "The service is miserable, there are delays every morning, overcrowded, nasty trains. You can't sit down half the time, and you stand a good chance of getting your pocket picked. If you ride the train after midnight, you take your life in your hands."
The scenes at stations throughout the city yesterday varied greatly. Some stations, perhaps because of the advance bulletins of impending madness, were almost eerily empty and undistressed.
Other stations were packed and tense, with many turnstiles still inoperable, token vending machines not working and police officers standing guard over the makeshift tables set up with new tokens. People with tokens were sneered at by those on line. At other stops, it was a proselytizer's paradise, the audiences captive by circumstance and not belief.
In Brooklyn, Yvonne B., who has sold scarves and hats outside a stop on Eastern Parkway for five years, expanded her inventory yesterday to include new tokens she had bought in bulk. She charged $2 and had a steady supply of business yesterday but may not have won many long-term customers.
The workers manning the additional token tables, many of whom were supervisors pressed into duty, sounded like carnival barkers. "New tokens only, no exchanges," one supervisor shouted on the No. 2 line in Brooklyn. "Give me your old token and 25 cents right here, don't stand in line," another hollered at the Main Street stop in Queens.
The clerks, scores of whom worked double shifts, said they absorbed quite a bit of abuse. They were cursed and had their math skills and even their politics questioned.
"We're the low man, and they treated us like it was our fault," said Monica Goodlett, a clerk at the Archer Avenue station in Queens. "Every last clerk is being affected by this emotionally. The stress and strain is too much."
The assortment of dramas was comic and serious, much like the subways themselves. One rider in Flushing mistakenly tried to jam a $10 bill into a fare box and was kindly told by a supervisor that, "we don't want that much more from you."
At 157th Street in Manhattan, a token clerk who was experiencing chest pains continued to sell tokens as he waited for a replacement. As paramedics waited to take him to the hospital, panic grew on the token line.
"Officer, what's going on with this man?" one man cried out. "He's going to leave the booth?"
"He's going to have a heart attack, man," a police officer answered.
"Officer, what's going to happen to us?" the man shouted back, and the crowd grew anxious.
But within seconds, a replacement clerk arrived.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Some subway riders complained that fares rose as service and upkeep were cut. Directions were scrawled in paint at a station at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue. (Linda Rosier/The New York Times); Under the new subway math, three fingers still mean three tokens. Three tokens, however, now cost three quarters extra. (Thomas Dallal for The New York Times) (pg. B1)

Graph: "AT A GLANCE: Transit Fare's Journey to the Courts"
 
THE BACKGROUND -- Last month, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved a set of fare increases for its mass transit system. The increases, which took effect on Sunday, raised the price of subway and bus tokens by 25 cents, to $1.50, a 20 percent increase, while the price of trips on the suburban commuter rail lines rose about 9 percent.
 
THE LAWSUIT -- Shortly after the new fares were approved, the New York Urban League and the Straphangers Campaign filed a Federal lawsuit, saying that they violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964. The suit contended that because the percentage increase for suburban riders was lower than it was for bus and subway passengers, the new fares "had the effect of discriminating against the predominantly minority riders" of the New York City subway and bus system. The suit also argued that the distribution of transit subsidies by the state unfairly favored the predominantly white riders of the suburban rail lines.
 
THE INJUNCTION -- Last Wednesday, Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction against the M.T.A., blocking the fare increase until a full trial is held on the civil rights lawsuit. The judge said that it appeared that the fare increase would have a disproportionate impact on black and Hispanic passengers in New York City and that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed in their case once it came to a full trial. He also said the injunction was necessary to prevent "irreparable harm" to the riders who would be forced to buy the new $1.50 tokens.
 
THE APPEAL -- The next day, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit blocked the injunction, pending a full hearing today. The court seemed to accept the argument by the M.T.A. that if the court ultimately rolled back the increase, there would be no irreparable harm, because the additional money riders would have to pay for the new tokens could be refunded. The judges ordered the agency to develop a refund plan.
 
THE FUTURE, PART 1 -- Another three-judge panel will hold a full hearing today on whether to overturn or uphold Judge Patterson's injunction. If the panel finds in favor of the M.T.A., the injunction is dead and the fare increase that took effect on Sunday stays in effect. But if the injunction is upheld, the fares would roll back to $1.25, and the M.T.A. would have to refund riders for the excess costs of the new token. The appeals court ruling could come as early as Thursday, but next week is considered more likely.
 
THE FUTURE, PART 2 -- No matter what happens after today's hearing, Judge Patterson will hold a trial, possibly by the end of the year, on the merits of the civil rights case. If he follows the logic of his ruling on the injunction and finds that the fare increase violates civil rights law, he can order the M.T.A. to return the fare to $1.25. But if he accepts the arguments of M.T.A. lawyers, the fare increase will remain in effect.
 
THE FUTURE, PART 3 -- However Judge Patterson rules, either side can appeal. (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: Bankers Trust Shuffles Top Management

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation has reassigned top executives of its $200 billion asset management business, people at the bank said. The bank's executives declined to comment.
The reorganization -- the second in two years -- comes as Bankers Trust is trying to increase profits by increasing the amount of assets it actively manages, the people said. About half the assets Bankers Trust manages, or $100 billion, are in passive investments, such as tracking stock indexes, which earn lower fees. 
 Ian Martin, who runs funds management at the profitable BT Australia Ltd. unit, will now oversee asset management worldwide, a new position, the people said. Frank Minard, who is chief executive of Mitchell Hutchins Asset Management in New York, will oversee American Funds Management.
The current head of American Funds Management, Ivan Wheen, will be transferred to Singapore to oversee Bankers Trust's business strategy in Southeast Asia, the people said.
In September 1993, Mr. Wheen, then head of securities trading in London, was promoted to oversee the global investment management unit, which includes the roughly $180 billion in funds managed in the United States.
The bank had hoped he would parlay his trading skills into using Bankers Trust's expertise in complex derivatives to bolster returns from managing assets for pension funds, big companies and other investors. In the past year, however, high-profile derivatives losses by several of the bank's clients led institutional investors to shy away from derivatives, people at the bank said. Derivatives are contracts whose performance is linked to the underlying performance of other securities, interest rates or indexes.

HEADLINE: Traders Focus on Budget Impasse, but Dow Keeps Rising

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks were little changed yesterday even as the Dow Jones industrial average reached a new high for the fourth consecutive session.
"There were crosscurrents throughout the day, but the market reached an equilibrium," said Ricky Harrington, senior vice president of Interstate/Johnson Lane in Charlotte, N.C. "It was almost an exact carbon copy of Friday's action." 
 Wall Street remained concerned about the budget impasse in Washington. A rally in bonds, which came after the Treasury Department announced plans to stave off a debt default this week, provided stocks with some support.
Shares of financial and banking companies were weighed down, though, by worries that the impasse on the budget and the nation's debt limit would prevent the Federal Reserve from lowering short-term interest rates in the coming months. Technology stocks were also weaker yesterday.
The Dow inched up 2.53 points, or five-hundredths of 1 percent, to 4,872.90. Among the broader market measures, the Standard & Poor's index of 50 stocks eased 0.42 point, to 592.30, and the Nasdaq composite index, rich in technology issues, slipped 5.41 points, to 1,058.46.
Nasdaq's member brokerage firms were unable to update prices for 15 minutes near the end of the day as a flaw at its computer center in Trumbull, Conn., shut down the system. This year, Nasdaq has suffered a number of such incidents, which it has attributed to heavy trading volume.
Declining issues exceeded advancers on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,253 to 1,027. Big Board trading was once again modest, with turnover of 295.8 million shares, compared with 298.7 million shares on Friday.
The mixed performance came as bond prices rose sharply. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 25/32 , and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, dropped to 6.27 percent, from 6.33 percent Friday.
Some technology stocks fell on profit taking yesterday. Shares of Micron Technology Inc. declined 3, to 61 5/8; those of Sun Microsystems Inc. plunged 5, to 84 7/8; Texas Instruments Inc. gave up 1 5/8, to 62 1/4, and Motorola Inc. fell 1 3/4, to 66.
Shares of financial-services companies were also weaker. J. P. Morgan & Company closed at 76, down 1 1/8; the Nationsbank Corporation closed at 69, down 3/8, and the First Union Corporation closed at 53, down 1/4. Wells Fargo & Company, which yesterday announced a sweetened bid for First Interstate Bancorp, fell 5 a share, to 210 3/8; First Interstate fell 1 3/8 a share, to 133 3/8.
A number of money managers rotated funds into consumer-product stocks, and the Morgan Stanley consumer-product index rose 0.42 point to 592.30. The Coca-Cola Company increased 1 1/8 a share, to 73 7/8, and the Procter & Gamble Company advanced 1 3/8, to 84 3/8.
Some oil companies, which had in recent days shown declines, turned upward. Shares of the Mobil Corporation closed at 106 1/8, up 2, and those of the Exxon Corporation closed at 76 3/8, up 7/8.
The Kmart Corporation, the day's most active stock, gained 5/8 a share, to 8 1/4, on reports of a new $20 million advertising campaign. The Vigoro Corporation, which plans to be acquired by IMC Global Inc., jumped 9 3/4 a share, to 55; IMC Global fell 1 5/8 a share, to 73.
Shares of Videolan Technologies Inc. hit a new high of 47 1/2 before going into an unexplained steep decline at midday and finishing the session at 37, down 7 7/8. The company, which became publicly owned in August, is demonstrating its developmental desktop multimedia products this week at the Comdex electronics show in Las Vegas, Nev.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asia Guide Calls Local Partners Key to Success

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 13

 BODY:
When Jim Rohwer was writing about Asia from the genteel surroundings of the London offices of The Economist, he was convinced he knew what he was doing. It turned out, he confesses now, that he did not.
"I realized within three or four months of arriving in Asia that I understood nothing about it at all," he said recently. "The same is generally true about Western business people who haven't set foot here." 
 After four years in Asia, three for The Economist, the weekly news magazine owned by Economist Newspaper Ltd., and the last as the chief economist for the CS First Boston Corporation, Mr. Rohwer now seeks to share his epiphany with Western readers. (Asians already pretty much know what he has discovered.) In short, he wants to explain why Asia has become, in his words, "the miracle" of late-20th-century free markets and economic development.
In a new book, "Asia Rising: Why America Will Prosper as Asia's Economies Boom" (Simon & Schuster), Mr. Rohwer explores the fundamental causes of Asia's prodigious growth and suggests how America's economy, and companies, can benefit from the jarring transformation of the global economy.
His analysis and suggestions might trouble Westerners, but that discomfort is essential, he said, if they are to grapple with Asia's complexities.
Indeed, the successful companies here, the ones that are defining how business is done and how economies are shaped, are not the multinationals of the United States and Europe, but the great conglomerates of Asia, like the Charoen Pokphand Group of Bangkok, Thailand, which have been built mostly by a vast diaspora of Chinese-born business families. Moreover, his analysis largely diminishes Japan's role in Asia, a view that runs counter to most judgments about growth in the region.
Mr. Rohwer is emphatic that his work is not a prescription for American companies, but he does believe there is one fundamental tenet that emerges from his book. "The biggest single thing for companies to do is to figure out how they can plug themselves into local conditions," he said. "Mostly that means finding the right partner, someone to guide you through that maze in Asia."
Yet, he cautioned, "this is very much a book of strategy more than a book on how to do it."
In an interview, Mr. Rohwer called Asia's success dependent on "being open, especially in terms of trade, investment and technology transfer. Second, it's linked to not providing protection -- social protection, protection from competition, protection from change. And third, it is having a very small role for government. The family is central and not government institutions in absorbing the shock of change."
Across Asia, government spending accounts for a very small share of gross domestic product, usually less than 20 percent, Mr. Rohwer said, compared with Western economies in which it ranges from 30 percent to 50 percent.
"How did this develop? These countries were under threats to their survival," he said. "Their backs were to the wall and they had choices of fighting or collapsing. Secondly, America's role in the cold war of defending them gave them a stable structure. There also was a tremendous amount of American generosity. But far more important was the willingness to protect these countries and absorb their exports. And this was grounded in very strong family-based societies, where learning and hard work were highly valued.
"And last -- and this is the thing Americans have the hardest time understanding -- most places are run by highly authoritarian governments that unlike authoritarians in Africa or the Middle East were actually committed to the national interest."
Economies that have thrived under the apparently paradoxical combination of political and social authoritarianism and market freedoms are apparent: Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore, Malaysia and China. In Mr. Rohwer's view, the countries destined to follow these examples are Indonesia, which is well on the road to sustained economic growth, and Vietnam.
The great Asian failure, Mr. Rohwer argues, is India, which has too long practiced oppressive planning and a cloistered approach to economic development. As a result, he said, India has been left behind.
Driving the growth, Mr. Rohwer said, have been the multitude of Chinese families that turned small businesses into vibrant conglomerates across Asia. Together, the World Bank estimates that this "greater China" had a gross domestic product of $2.5 trillion in 1990, nearly half that of the G.D.P. of the United States in 1990.
"It's one of the most interesting business phenomena in the world," he said. "Scattered across Southeast Asia are 50 to 60 million Chinese. They have as a group created one of the most successful business empires in the world. It's the business equivalent of a neural network and the Chinese have come to dominate business, finance and commerce throughout Asia, outside Japan, even though they are a minority."
For American companies, Mr. Rohwer contends, Asia is the future. But protectionist impulses in the United States could damage the possibilities for American companies. Indeed, he said, the emergence of a huge Asian middle class augurs both great opportunity for American business -- and great competition.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jim Rohwer, in a new book, "Asia Rising," calls Asia "the miracle" of late-20th-century free markets and economic development and suggests strategies by which American companies can prosper in the region. (Amy Toensing for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mexico to Break Up State Rail And Sell It, Starting Early in '96

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Mexican Government announced today that it would break up its creaky 16,000-mile railroad system into four lines that would be sold to private investors, probably including American companies, starting next year.
In announcing the terms of the railroad privatization, Carlos Ruiz Sacristan, Mexico's communications and transportation minister, said the first bids would be accepted early in 1996. The concessions are to last at least 50 years. 
 Breaking up the current rail system, Ferrocarriles Nacionales de Mexico, is intended to reassure potential United States buyers, who had expressed interest in profitable lines that started at the Texas border, but did not want to invest in money-losing lines south of Mexico City. Mexican investors were concerned that selling the entire system to one buyer would have simply changed a public monopoly into a private one.
Of the four lines envisioned, one would serve northeastern Mexico, including the busy route from the Texas border to Mexico City. Another would serve northern and western Mexico, including Guadalajara. A third would travel the southeast below Mexico City, and the fourth would handle traffic in the capital itself.
Some big Mexican construction companies have registered an interest in taking part in the railroad privatization, and some of them have established joint ventures with rail companies in the United States.
An issue of concern involves the railroad's work force, which includes 55,000 active employees and 45,000 retirees. Mr. Ruiz said that the Government would assume responsibility for pensions but that potential buyers would have to negotiate layoffs directly with the railroad workers' union.
In the equity markets here today, the main Mexico City stock index fell 56.03 points, or 2.43 percent, to 2,254.07, on low volume as overnight interest rates rose to 75 percent. It was a bad day, as well, on the broader market, where 52 issues declined and only 7 rose.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE PRESIDENT;
Budget Crisis Jeopardizes Clinton's Diplomatic Plans

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
For months, President Clinton planned to devote late November to foreign policy. First there would be a six-day visit to Japan to discuss trade in Asia and to renew the Japanese-American security alliance. Next would come a swing through Great Britain and Ireland to highlight America's commitment to peace in troubled regions.
But with Mr. Clinton and Congress on a collision course that threatens to lead to a prolonged Government shutdown, White House officials made some quick political calculations about the trip to Japan on Thursday: 
 Could Mr. Clinton afford to be seen at a state dinner at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo at the same time Federal workers idled at home and default loomed?
Yet, could he risk offending the Japanese by skipping the visit at a time that relations between the two powers have been strained by American economic espionage and the abduction and rape of an Okinawa teen-ager by American servicemen?
Would he look like a hostage of the Republican Congress if he canceled his plans?
With those considerations in mind, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, announced today that Mr. Clinton's six-day trip to Osaka and Tokyo would be compressed into one long weekend of diplomacy.
Mr. Clinton is now scheduled to leave Washington at 11 P.M. on Friday. He will be in Osaka for a Sunday meeting of the leaders of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum and in Tokyo on Monday to meet with Prime Minister Murayama and attend a state dinner with Emperor Akihito.
After dinner, Mr. Clinton will immediately board Air Force One, returning to Washington by 2 A.M. Tuesday because he crosses the international dateline.
While no one knows how long the budget deadlock will continue, Mr. Clinton tellingly let it slip that his second trip might be endangered.

HEADLINE: From Chickens to Chemicals;
Family Conglomerate Finds Fast Growth in China

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: SONGJIANG, China

 BODY:
Under their adobe tile roofs, the barracks seem to stretch to the horizon in this bleak suburb of Shanghai. Inside, hundreds of thousands of chickens shuffle about noisily, and aromatically, pecking at feeding machines, plumping themselves for the city's woks.
A few hours to the north, black motorcycle frames move along an assembly line. The motorcycles bounce off the line, their gleaming red tanks emblazoned with the word "Xingfu," or "Happiness." 
 These two wildly different enterprises are fragments of one of Asia's largest and most successful business empires, the Charoen Pokphand Group, based in Bangkok, Thailand. From chickens to shrimp, petrochemicals to motorcycles, telecommunications to retail marketing, the C.P. Group, as it is known, embraces a cornucopia of industries. Its investments swaddle the globe, but its most dominant presence, by far, is in Asia. The group, barely known in the United States or Europe, is probably the largest foreign investor in China.
It is just such family conglomerates, not American or European multinationals, that are shaping Asia. They feed its people, build roads and houses, put up phone lines and power stations, open stores and malls -- in short, weave the very fabric of Asia's phenomenal economic expansion. Family empires from Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and the Philippines, many of them run by overseas Chinese, have moved aggressively and steadily throughout Asia, establishing themselves as the core of the region's economic growth.
C.P.'s approach has been deceptively simple. In China it began with the basic idea of a chicken in every wok and, from there, branched out in every imaginable direction.
"In 1979," said an animated Sumet Jiaravanon (pronounced Soo-MEHT GEE-rah-wahnon), the group's pencil-thin president, "we saw that China was very poor. But we knew, we overseas Chinese knew, that China would be very important one day.
"We knew the Chinese ate only one-quarter of a kilo of meat per year," continued Mr. Sumet, who, along with his brother, Dhanin Chearavanont (TA-ninn GEE-rah-wahnon), oversees the group. "The market potential was enormous."
Mr. Dhanin put it more succinctly. "C.P. is always looking for opportunity," he said. "We saw opportunity in Taiwan. When Suharto came to power we went to Indonesia. We always see opportunity first."
One secret of the ability of C.P. to gain access to these markets is that it builds personal ties, said Thirayuth Phitya-Isarakul, a C.P. director and head of the company's agribusiness group. "Our business has to be seen as important by the local government," he added. "We are bringing in technical know-how, management skills and low costs. So they never think we are trying to cheat them."
Across China, C.P. has absorbed crippled local enterprises and involved local officials.
From its first venture in southern China in 1979, C.P.'s agribusiness group has grown to 80 companies throughout China, including feed mills, breeder farms, broiler chicken farms, processing factories, even chicken fast-food shops. Of 3 billion chickens eaten in China last year, C.P.'s companies produced 300 million. And this does not include the other investments by C.P., which elevate its outlay in China toward the $1 billion mark.
The group's beginnings were far more modest.
In the 1920's, a young man named Chia Ek Chor left Shantou in southern China and moved to Bangkok. He took with him seeds from his family's farms, for the cabbages, parsnips, radishes, turnips and cauliflower so loved by Chinese, but so scarce throughout Southeast Asia. Bangkok's Chinese community welcomed him and his seeds, which he began to sell, and the brother he left behind became his supplier.
It remained a modest family concern until 1953, when Mr. Chia's eldest son, Jaran Chiaravanont, set up a feed mill for chickens and registered the expanding businesses under the name Charoen Pokphand.
Next came chickens -- raising and processing them for a population starting to shake off poverty. The first international link came in 1970 with Arbor Acres, a leading chicken breeder based in Connecticut. Exports followed, then feed mills and chicken breeding in Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Taiwan and China.
Then it was real estate, petrochemicals, trading and retail stores, and shrimp farming. In recent years C.P. has expanded into telecommunications and motorcycles.
In the last three years, annual revenue at the group's publicly traded companies has doubled, to $6.5 billion. More than 65,000 people draw C.P. paychecks in 20 countries. Fourteen companies are publicly traded, six in Bangkok, one each in Taipei and Shanghai, two in Jakarta and three in Hong Kong. And shares of Ek Chor China Motorcycle trade on the New York Stock Exchange, where they closed yesterday at $11.625.
The Telecom Asia Corporation, a joint venture with the Nynex Corporation, has a market capitalization that is now about $6.6 billion but at times has approached $10 billion, greater than that of Nynex. And the families of Mr. Dhanin and Mr. Sumet -- grandsons of the founder -- are the wealthiest in Thailand, and among the wealthiest in the world. Forbes magazine puts their combined net worth at about $5.5 billion.
C.P.'s success and its spectacular growth have depended on people like Chingchai Lohawatanakul, president of C.P.'s Aquaculture group.
"I joined C.P. in 1964 as a clerk," Mr. Chingchai said. And later, "I became a technician in the feed mills."
In Asia in the 1980's, C.P. saw a rapidly rising consumption of shrimp, in addition to chickens. Mr. Chingchai was put in charge of aquaculture, spending three years building an operation that started in Taiwan, then the world's largest shrimp producer. But that business later collapsed in Taiwan and China, because of disease-ravaged farms. After that, "I thought that the shrimp business was very, very risky," he said. "I was afraid for my job."
But last year, Mr. Chingchai found a place to raise shrimp, 60,000 acres in southern Sumatra, one of the Indonesian islands, and he is hiring 15,000 farmers and building towns and villages for them. When he is done, he intends to be Asia's biggest shrimp producer. It may take years, but as Mr. Sumet said simply, "Our goals are long term."
China was seen as a very long-term prospect.
When Mr. Sumet went to Shenzhen in 1979 to look at the site of C.P.'s first exploratory investment, he was stunned. "There was nothing," he recalled. "There were fishermen and a few fields. Nothing else. But I had some confidence in the Chinese Government to change, one step at a time."
"If you want successful economic development and a successful business, you need technology, capital and the market," he said. "In Thailand, we organized farm families into groups, we brought in technology, we guaranteed loans to farmers, we provided breeders and purchased the chickens they raised. We processed the chickens and sold them. It was completely integrated."
"We brought this model to China," he said. From his offices in a golden-mirrored tower near Hong Kong's harbor, his walls filled with ceremonial pictures of himself with China's leaders, from Deng Xiaoping on down, he said he expected China to become C.P.'s largest market.
Mr. Sumet attributes C.P.'s fairly easy growth in China to the inflexibility of non-Asian companies. "American and European companies have adapted themselves to a very sophisticated legal-based society," he said. "In China there is no law. There is no system. It is a government by individuals, by people."
Mr. Thirayut, the C.P. director, said American companies in particular were unlikely to succeed in Asia.
"For Western companies," he said, "once they don't make a profit for three years they can't go on. High executives shift very often from company to company. Our top executives work for 20, 30 years." Mr. Thirayut, who began 32 years ago as a clerk, added, "The reason everyone works so long for this company is that it is still like a family."
A recent study by the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade pointed to a number of reasons for the dominance of Chinese families in Asian business. "Most ethnic Chinese," the report said, "are culturally empathetic with one another, write the same language and have a range of community mechanisms" that make things easier."
Of course, C.P.'s skepticism about American business does not preclude joint ventures, as witness the project with Nynex to install 2.6 million fiber optic lines in Bangkok.
"C.P. has traditionally been viewed as based on agriculture," said Ajva Taulananda, the president of Telecom Asia. "But Thailand needs telephones."
After winning a Government license -- a license that critics suggest was secured by illegal contributions to Government ministers, which Mr. Ajva denies -- C.P. teamed up with Nynex.
"The chances of Nynex getting the license were zero," said Frederic V. Salerno, the vice chairman of Nynex and of Telecom Asia. "The people over there are almost family."
Since 1992, the joint venture has installed 1.4 million lines and, after a slow start, signed up 700,000 customers. When the Thai Government telepone company -- which will take possession of the lines, but not the revenue, after the project is completed -- tried to manage customer subscriptions, it floundered. C.P. put 24-hour subscription desks in its chain of convenience stores and solved that problem.
Already, Telecom Asia is moving into cable television; video on demand and videotext are next.
And, Mr. Dhanin said, C.P. is taking this telecommunications expertise to other countries, starting with Indonesia and the Philippines.
The group has defied many efforts to analyze its operations and performance. Ravi Narain, who heads China and Hong Kong research for Peregrine Brokerage Ltd., said it was hard to see C.P.'s operations clearly because of "a constant flow of asset injections from other parts of the group."
Kent Chan, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said simply, "They are too complicated."

HEADLINE: Tremors in Saudi Arabia

 BODY:
It is too early to draw firm conclusions about the explosion that rocked Saudi Arabia's capital yesterday, destroying a United States-run National Guard training building and killing four Americans. They were part of a group of about 100 Americans training Saudi forces in the use of weapons imported from the United States. Two obscure Islamic groups claimed responsibility. Both Washington and Riyadh continue to investigate the incident.
The attack is a reminder of the inherent vulnerability of the American position in Saudi Arabia, the world's leading oil producer and the largest pro-Western state in the Persian Gulf region. As the gulf war made clear, the Saudi regime depends on American military protection against larger neighbors like Iran and Iraq. Yet the regime, while it remains firmly in control, has seen its grip challenged in recent years by the radical brand of political Islam that is sweeping the Middle East. 
 Some Saudi Islamic groups are home-grown, others receive substantial support from Iran and Sudan. In recent months these groups have threatened violence, issued ultimatums against the presence of Americans and carried out at least one terrorist operation.
Under present circumstances, Washington has little choice but to maintain close relations with the Saudi monarchy. The United States economy depends on benign Saudi oil pricing policies. Yet despite big arms purchases from the United States, the sparsely populated kingdom is incapable of defending itself against much larger neighbors.
Saudi political considerations rule out basing large numbers of American troops on Saudi soil. So Washington sells enormous quantities of advanced weapons and helps train Saudi troops.
The regime faces increasing challenge at home as well as from abroad. Open political discussion is largely limited to issues concerning religious doctrine and practice, especially the role of women. But more prosaic issues, like corruption and the management of fiscal resources that have been less flush since the oil price drop of the mid-1980's and the huge expenses of the gulf war, are often at play beneath the surface.
These challenges push American policy in two potentially conflicting directions. To reduce the risk of future upheavals Washington needs to encourage a more open political system and more prudent economic management, as well as more effective self-defense. Yet to avoid provoking Islamic sensitivities, it needs to keep its advice and its presence low-key. It will not be any easier to maintain that balance after yesterday's attack.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Gain As Treasury Will Resume Its Auctions

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury virtually removed chances of a default this week with an 11th-hour announcement yesterday that it would resume its auctions. Prices rose immediately, for the first time in three days, as investors rushed to buy Government securities.
Traders said the announcement by the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, erased early losses brought on by the President's veto of a bill that would have raised the debt ceiling. Word of the veto led to selling as investors sought to protect themselves against a possible default. The Treasury's announcement of the revised auction plans not only overcame concerns of a default this week, but also led to short-covering, which contributed to the rally. 
 The Treasury went ahead with its regular weekly auction of $29.2 billion in three-month and six-month bills yesterday and prepared for the sale today of $31.5 billion in nine-day cash management bills and $26 billion of 36-day cash management bills. Tomorrow the Treasury will sell $18.75 billion of new one-year bills. Occasionally the Government sells the cash management bills to meet cash flow shortages when it needs to meet interest rate and principal payments.
Traders said the Treasury's revised auction schedule would allow the Government to make the $102 billion of payments due on Wednesday and Thursday, and end concern for now. Next week the Treasury will sell $18 billion of three-year notes on Monday and $13.5 billion of 10-year notes on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 25/32 of a percentage point, to 108 2/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.27 percent, from 6.33 percent on Friday when the market felt the pressure of a threatened Government default.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said the Administration was able to stop the clock on a default and gain some time by disinvesting. The Treasury said it was lowering obligations to two Government employee funds to avoid exceeding the current debt limit; that also buys some time to negotiate a compromise on the budget impasse.
Mr. Chan noted that the dollar had gained strength, and the Commodity Research Bureau index, which is considered a barometer of future inflation pressures, fell to 242.82, down 1.05 points, "which was music to the ears of the credit markets."
Mr. Chan cautioned, however, that "if the legality of using Government trust funds to circumvent the debt limit is successfully challenged, then sentiment is likely to move back the other way with a frenzy." And the outcome of a political struggle can be hard to predict, he added.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist CS First Boston, said it was clear that "a default would bring a fall in the dollar and a rise in interest rates," and that the longer-term implications were still not known. "While the Treasury has come up with an interesting way of meeting its obligations," he continued, "we're not sure what the ultimate resolution of the budget debate will be."
Indeed, he said, the parties in the budget debate appear to be moving farther apart.
The supply of new issues to market, Mr. Alexy said, should not weigh on prices, since it had all been scheduled to come to market anyway and was delayed. "The demand," he said, "is there."
Rates rose at yesterday's auction of new three- and six-month bills. To delay reaching the debt limit, foreign central bankers were prohibited at yesterday's auction from purchasing any bills in excess of the maturing bills they already held.
The average rate for a three-month issue rose to 5.43 percent from 5.36 percent, while a six-month issue went to 5.33 percent from 5.29 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Up After Treasury Takes Steps to Avoid a Default

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday after the Clinton Administration took steps to avoid a default on debt payments this week.
The dollar's gain against the yen was helped in part by large trades by hedge funds. But against the German mark, the dollar retreated from earlier gains. Political and economic uncertainty in the United States typically bolsters the mark. 
 On Thursday, the dollar fell sharply as anxieties over an impasse on the United States budget finally affected world currency markets. But the dollar recovered somewhat on Friday on confidence that a debt default by the United States could be avoided.
Yesterday, the Treasury Department announced that it would sell $137 billion in new securities during the next nine days, more than enough to pay off $102 billion in principal and interest due this week.
The Administration's maneuvers "addressed the market's immediate concerns about the default threat by using extraordinary measures to avoid the absolutely unacceptable possibility of default," said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc.
The Treasury's plans set off a rally in the bond market, driving the yield of the 30-year Treasury down to 6.27 percent, from 6.33 percent on Friday. That surge also bolstered the dollar.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 101.91 yen from 100.90 yen on Friday. The dollar edged up to 1.4185 marks from 1.4176 marks and to 1.1441 Swiss francs from 1.1390 Swiss francs. The British pound slippped to $1.5529 from $1.5665.
In other trading, the Mexican peso, which had dragged the dollar down last week, weakened yesterday. The peso settled at 7.77 pesos to the dollar, from 7.55 pesos to the dollar on Friday.
While the currency markets expressed relief that the United States had avoided default at least this week, concern over the budget impasse remained.
Still, market participants also feel that the United States is, relatively, not in a bad position economically. Its accumulated public debt, as a percentage of gross domestic product, fares favorably in comparison with other leading industrial countries.
"Certainly the market feels the U.S. has a foreign debt problem, but the public debt problem has been overstated," said John Rothfield, an international economist with Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago. "This isn't a bad problem for the U.S. to have."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Pacific Vision in Search of Reality

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Leaders of 18 nations in the Pacific region will meet in Osaka, Japan, this week in an effort to keep their grand vision of a vast trans-Pacific free trade zone from unraveling.
President Clinton and the 17 other leaders of the countries belonging to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or APEC, met a year ago in Bogor, Indonesia, and announced a "declaration of common resolve" to achieve "free and open trade and investment" among themselves by the year 2020, with the industrial nations in the group realizing that goal 10 years earlier. 
 This year, APEC members are to draw up an agenda for action, one that will turn the vision into reality. But achieving free trade is expected to be a far more painstaking process than enunciating the goal.
Already, there are signs that the "common resolve" at Bogor is dissolving. Japan, the host country this year, is eluding any commitment to fully open its politically sensitive rice market. South Korea, China and Taiwan also want exemptions to enable them to continue protecting their farmers.
"We think in the process of liberalization we have to be practical and pragmatic," said Katsuhisa Uchida, representative for international trade and economics in Japan's Foreign Ministry.
But the United States and Australia argue that if some countries are allowed to make exceptions, others will as well, leading to an unraveling of the free trade plan.
"If you exclude any sectors, either directly or by fuzz words, you create a political dynamic that will ultimately erode APEC," an American official said. He added that with a free trade deadline 15 or 25 years away, the group's members already had flexibility. "Why water down the principle at the beginning?" he asked.
There are other disputes over how to actually liberalize trade and whether the benefits of lowered barriers should be available to nations outside the regional forum.
Unwilling to give up on last year's grand declaration so soon, the APEC members are likely to work out compromises on all these questions. Regarding agriculture, the wording is expected to allow some flexibility; with industry, it is likely to retain the principle that the goal of free trade should apply to all sectors.
Japan, which already has a reputation as an unfair trader, is under particular pressure to engineer a compromise, lest as host country it is blamed for a failure of APEC.
Subcabinet-level officials from the 18 nations are meeting in Osaka today and Tuesday to try to arrange a compromise. What they cannot resolve will be passed on to foreign and trade ministers, who will meet from Wednesday night through Friday. The heads of government will convene for an informal summit meeting on Sunday in a guest house on the grounds of Osaka Castle.
But the so-called action agenda mainly lists the principles to be followed in achieving free trade. If that is proving difficult, then truly troublesome problems might be seen at next year's meeting in the Philippines. By then, each country is to have come up with a specific plan to eliminate its tariffs and other barriers.
APEC was started as an informal discussion group in 1989. The fact that its somewhat awkward sounding name, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, does not end in "association" or "organization" or a similar noun suggests the founders' reluctance to create a formal institution. But gradually, APEC is becoming that.
A big step came at the 1993 meeting in Seattle, when President Clinton elevated what had been a round of ministers' talks into one involving the heads of state. On windswept Blake Island, the leaders, dressed in casual clothing, met in an Indian long house to endorse Mr. Clinton's vision of an Asian-Pacific community.
The next year, clad in batik shirts and meeting in a colonial-era palace 40 miles south of Jakarta, the leaders issued the Bogor Declaration, at once audacious and meaningless.
It was audacious in that it aimed to create a free trade zone among nations that account for more than half the world's economic output and more than 40 percent of total trade.
But the timetable for freeing trade, by 2010 or 2020, was so distant that it seemed like something the leaders could proclaim and not have to worry about carrying out. As one Prime Minister quipped last year, the Sultan of Brunei was the only leader of the 18 at the meeting with a chance of still being in office in 2020.
There are numerous other obstacles. APEC covers countries as geographically distant as Chile and South Korea, Australia and Canada. Its members vary from China, with 1.2 billion people, to Brunei, with less than 300,000. The group encompasses economic superpowers like Japan and the United States, and poor nations like Papua New Guinea and the Philippines.
Moreover, APEC is still a voluntary organization with no legal authority. If anything is accomplished, it will be by peer pressure rather than by a legally binding trade treaty or agreement. Malaysia, for instance, has said that it will not be bound by the 2020 deadline.
For the Asia-Pacific region as a whole, free trade is seen as a way of accelerating growth in an already dynamic area. The nations of East Asia are getting so big and prosperous that they can no longer rely for growth solely on exporting products to the United States, but must trade more among themselves.
For the United States, APEC seemed like a way of opening the markets of East Asia to its exports.
But some analysts think that the United States is already lowering its expectations of what it can accomplish with APEC and may instead stick to tough trade negotiations with particular countries, which have greater appeal to voters.
To allay such suspicions, President Clinton is taking great pains to come to Japan, planning two days in Osaka and Tokyo on Sunday and Monday, despite the budget crisis with Republican leaders of Congress.
Aother concern is that business executives may lose faith if action toward Pacific trade liberalization is too slow. "The business community hasn't seen any tangible results of the APEC process yet," said Takeshi Kondo, general manager of economic and political research at Itochu, a giant Japanese trading company. "We don't need any dramatic statements. We had one last year and the year before that."
The members of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum are the United States, Canada, Mexico, Chile, Australia and New Zealand. Asian members are Japan, China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei, Singapore, the Philippines and Papua New Guinea.

GRAPHIC: Photo: As leaders of 18 nations in the Pacific region prepare to meet this week in Osaka, Japan, security has been stepped up. A diver on Sunday searched the waters near Kansai International Airport outside Osaka. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yankees Are No. 1, On Payday, at Least

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Yankees and the Mets stood in stark contrast to each other today in baseball's salary standings. In a season when the average major league salary dropped more than 5 percent, the Yankees had a runaway No. 1 average salary and payroll that were more than four times the Mets' figures, which ranked 27th.
Payroll figures, which have everyone's attention in baseball because of the continued economic impact of the labor dispute, were presented to the general managers today at the start of their annual meetings. The general managers are most immediately affected by the figures because club owners are constantly telling them to reduce their payrolls. 
 Computed by the Player Relations Committee, the figures show the Yankees with a 1995 payroll of $54,889,849 and an average salary of $1,960,351; the Mets had a $13,040,444 payroll and an average salary of $465,730. Only the Montreal Expos were below the Mets with a $12,956,557 payroll and a $404,892 average salary.
The P.R.C. figures were not quite complete. Bonuses earned for post-season awards were not included because not all the awards have been given. But when those bonuses are included, the figures won't change significantly.
The total payroll of the 28 teams rose slightly, by $19 million, from 1994 to 1995 for the players who were on rosters or disabled lists on Aug. 31. But that was because there were more players this year than last. The average salary computed to $1,089,621, or 5.6 percent less than last year's $1,154,486.
Even if, say, $3 million in bonuses were added, the average still would have dropped slightly more than 5 percent.
Looking ahead to his first signing season as the new Yankees' general manager, Bob Watson said: "The P.R.C. figure of $55 million will be less. I haven't got a definite number on dollars I'll have at my disposal to spend. That should come in the near future."
In terms of real dollars spent on salaries, the Yankees don't have to spend less than they actually did this year to have a smaller payroll. Although their total read nearly $55 million, it was really "only" $49 million because the 1995 payroll was inflated by their acquisition of David Cone three-fifths into the season.
Because of the computation method used by the P.R.C. and the Players Association, if a player is traded, his entire salary is charged to his new team no matter when the trade is made. Furthermore, a prorated share of a player's signing bonus also is charged to the new team, even if the former team had paid the entire bonus.
That was the case with Cone. When the Kansas City Royals signed the pitcher in December, 1992, they gave him a $9 million signing bonus, payable immediately. Yet a third of that bonus was charged on the Yankees' payroll, as was about $3 million in salary that the Toronto Blue Jays paid him for the first three months of the season.
Subtract $6 million from the payroll, and the Yankees' average salary would have been $1,746,066, which would have been second to Atlanta's $1,856,937.
Cone was listed as the Yankees' highest-paid player at $8 million, a $5 million salary and $3 million from the signing bonus. Ruben Sierra was next at $6.2 million, though he, too, was a late acquisition. Jack McDowell, at $5.4 million, was the highest-paid member of the Yankees who spent the entire season with the team.
The Mets had only three players at $1 million or more, and the salaries of Pete Harnisch, John Franco and Jose Vizcaino amounted to less than $7 million combined. The Mets had nine players at the $109,000 minimum, more than the Expos' seven.
Before the general managers heard from John Westhoff, Lou Melendez and Barbara Ernst, they had other visitors today.
At the start of the first day of meetings, Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, and Rob Manfred, the owners' chief labor lawyer, gave them an update on the labor situation and said the clubs soon would make a new proposal to the union.
Randy Levine, the clubs' new chief labor executive, arrived in town later in the day and is scheduled to meet with the general managers Tuesday.
