HEADLINE: Biodiversity Study Sees More Species in Danger

BYLINE: By TIM HILCHEY 

 BODY:
HUMAN activities like farming, logging and commercial fishing are endangering plants, animals and entire ecosystems at much higher rates than ever before in recorded history, according to a report issued by the United Nations Environment Program.
The document, the Global Biodiversity Assessment (Cambridge University Press, $44.95), is being described by the United Nations as the first comprehensive, peer-reviewed report ever to examine earth's biodiversity. 
 "This is the first time that a thousand scientists from more than 50 countries have gotten together to write a single document on the state of biological diversity," said Robert T. Watson, a member of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy who headed the Global Biodiversity Assessment project.
Since genetic variation is the basis for evolution, diversity of genes and species "affects the ability of ecological communities to resist or recover from environmental change, including long-term climatic change," said a summary that accompanied the report.
The document is being released today at the second Conference of Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity, which is being held in Jakarta, Indonesia. Some 1,000 governmental officials worldwide are attending the two-week conference, which will end on Friday.
Although the United States Senate has not ratified the Convention on Biological Diversity, which was signed by some 160 countries at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development held in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, Dr. Watson and other representatives of the Clinton Administration are attending the meeting.
"There's an educational issue here and the U.S. and other rich nations must lead by example," Dr. Watson said in a telephone interview. "We should not only conserve and protect our environment for moral, ethical and esthetic reasons, but also because there is more economic value in the protection of biodiversity than in its destruction."
Just as scientific reports on ozone depletion and global climate change have helped nations agree on policies to address these issues, Dr. Watson said, the contributors hope the biodiversity assessment will help people, from policy makers to farmers and fishermen, reach the three main objectives of the biodiversity convention: "the conservation of biological biodiversity, the sustainable use of its components and the fair and equitable sharing of benefits arising from utilization of genetic resources."
Among its many findings, the report concludes that at least 4,000 plants and 5,400 animals are threatened with extinction; that species have recently become extinct at 50 to 100 times the average expected natural rate; that only some 1.75 million, or about 13 percent of the 13 million to 14 million species on earth, have been scientifically identified, and that economic markets continue to underestimate the role biodiversity plays in major areas like air and water quality, global climate and scientific efforts to produce higher yielding, pest-resistant crops.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: INCOME TAXES;
Capital Gains Cuts Would Be Retroactive

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Investors and families could see part of the Republican tax cut soon after they filed their returns next spring under a tentative agreement reached by House and Senate negotiators, people familiar with the Congressional negotiations said today.
A 50 percent cut in capital gains taxes for individuals would be effective on Jan. 1, 1995, under a preliminary deal struck in long, closed sessions over the weekend to fuse separate House and Senate tax bills, those people said, and the Republicans' $500-per-child-tax credit would be retroactive to Oct. 1, 1995. 
 The negotiators refused to describe the tentative agreement in public. But Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, said, "I think the investment community is going to be pleased with the final product."
Analysts at the Congressional Budget Office are evaluating the package. Individual provisions could be changed if the measures add up to more than the Republicans' seven-year, $245-billion target for the tax cut. Both Bob Dole, majority leader in the Senate, and Representative Dick Armey, majority leader in the House, had been strong advocates of putting at least part of the tax cut into voters pockets before the 1996 election.
Parents could claim a fourth of the credit -- $125 -- on their 1995 returns for each child younger than 18. But refund checks covering the credit would not be mailed out until next Oct. 1 in order to shift the cost into the 1997 budget year.
The per-child credit would total $147.6 billion in seven years. Single parents with incomes below $75,000 and two-parent families with incomes below $110,000 would be eligible for it.
The seven-year cost of the cut in the tax rate on capital gains would be $35.7 billion. The negotiators accepted a House proposal to index such gains to eliminate the effects of inflation, but not until 2001. The maximum capital gains tax rate for individual investors would become 19.8 percent and the corporate tax rate on capital gains would be cut to 28 percent, not the 26 percent sought by the House.
Other provisions are:
$11.7 billion to expand Individual Retirement Accounts. That includes a new type of I.R.A. in which contributions would be taxable but earnings would accumulate tax-free. Eligibility for traditional deductible I.R.A.'s would be expanded, but not as much as under the Senate bill. Nonworking spouses would be eligible for a full $2,000-a-year I.R.A. contribution.
$11.8 billion for estate-tax breaks. The estate-tax exemption would be increased to $750,000 in six years from $600,000 and family-owned farms and businesses would get a bigger break, although not much as in the Senate version.
$8 billion to reduce the marriage penalty that hurts dual-income couples.
Another provision would increase the deductibility of health insurance for the self-employed to 50 percent from 30 percent.

HEADLINE: Clinton Makes Case to Congress For Putting U.S. Troops in Bosnia

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Wednesday, Nov. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton made his strongest and most detailed case to Congress on Tuesday for why 20,000 American troops should be sent to help enforce an eventual peace settlement in Bosnia, but acknowledged that he could not predict the number of casualties the United States might suffer in the course of the operation.
Mr. Clinton laid out his views in a nine-page letter to Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, the Speaker of the House. The letter was dated Monday and released on Tuesday. And at an Air Force base near Dayton, Secretary of State Warren Christopher met with Balkan leaders for 12 hours on Tuesday in an effort to move them closer to peace. 
 After three rounds of talks that touched on all core disputes over land and territory, Mr. Christopher failed to resolve any of the issues.
All major issues "remain on the table," a State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, told reporters early this morning after the talks ended past midnight. "The parties are going to have to work harder."
Shortly before midnight, Mr. Christopher left for a meeting in Osaka of 18 countries that make up the Asia-Pacific economic forum. Mr. Burns held open the possibility that Mr. Christopher might cut short his trip and return to Dayton from Osaka if an agreement was likely.
On Tuesday, Mr. Burns said the United States was prepared to have the talks continue into next week -- or even longer if necessary.
In his letter, Mr. Clinton said that American participation in the NATO-led operation would cost about $1.5 billion for one year. In testimony before Congress last month, Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the operation would cost between $1 billion and $1.5 billion.
Mr. Clinton also estimated that the United States would have to spend between $500 million and $600 million over several years for an international effort to rebuild Bosnia.
And as far as troop withdrawal was concerned, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that one year was an estimate, not a fixed deadline.
"We believe that approximately 12 months would be adequate to accomplish" the tasks of the NATO force and provide a self-sustaining peace, "although we cannot make that final judgment until the terms of the agreement are defined," Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton stressed that the final size and cost of the American troop deployment could only be determined after the parties make peace. "It is impossible to provide detailed information about aspects of a settlement that does not yet exist," he wrote. "I must reserve my decisions until the actual details of the agreement are clear."
Mr. Clinton did not offer any concrete proposal about how the United States would pay for the operation, except to say that he has not decided whether to ask Congress for a supplemental appropriation.
Aside from the financing issue, the issue most likely to elicit criticism from Congress is the fact that Mr. Clinton says he simply cannot predict how many American soldiers might die while keeping a still-undefined peace in Bosnia. The President argued that, given the size of the NATO-led force, the high quality of American and NATO troops and equipment, and the rules of engagement, "We would have created conditions that would offer the minimum possible risks to our soldiers."
But he did not gloss over the potential for casualties, saying, "It is not possible to make meaningful casualty predictions since casualty models for peace operations do not exist."
The proposal to send American troops to Bosnia has little support in Congress at the moment, as evidenced by a letter to Mr. Clinton on Monday from Mr. Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, saying that support in Congress for the mission "is virtually nil."
On Tuesday, Mr. Clinton invited 40 leading lawmakers of both parties to meetings at the White House to win Congressional support, and on Thursday, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, will begin a four-city speaking tour to make the Administration's case.
Even as the three Balkan Presidents argued over territorial demands, constitutional arrangements, elections and NATO implementation of a peace agreement, human rights issues have risen to the top of the agenda, complicating the talks.
Unknown to the American negotiators, on Tuesday President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia promoted an officer who was indicted on Monday as a war criminal by the International War Crimes Tribunal at the Hague.
Reuters reported from Zagreb that Mr. Tudjman promoted Gen. Tihomir Blaskic, the commander of the Bosnian Croat militia, as an inspector in the Croatian Army.
Asked about the promotion of the indicted officer, Mr. Burns told reporters that the United States was unaware of the action and that it had therefore not been raised by Mr. Christopher.
Judge Richard Goldstone, the chief prosecutor for the United Nations-sponsored tribunal, issued a strong warning on Tuesday against any peace deal for the former Yugoslavia that would shield suspected war criminals from trial. He told reporters in the Hague that any amnesty for the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and the Bosnian Serb military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, would be "abhorrent."
Mr. Goldstone will conduct two days of meetings with senior Administration officials in Washington today and on Thursday to air his complaints about the failure of the United States to turn over all relevant intelligence data for use in his cases.
Although there is no fixed deadline for the talks, American negotiators had hoped to conclude a peace agreement before President Clinton left for a meeting of 18 nations in Osaka on a trans-Pacific free-trade zone.
While some American officials, including Mr. Burns, the only official who is authorized to speak about the negotiations, seem to believe that the talks will continue for days, other officials say they could be concluded by the end of the week.
"We're at one of those breakdown-breakthrough moments," said one European official close to the talks.
A senior member of the Bosnian Government delegation said on Tuesday that he was not pleased with the American team, charging that American negotiators were exerting undue pressure on his Government as well as breaking the American-imposed news blackout by giving anonymous interviews to the press.
In particular, he said, American officials were mischaracterizing the Bosnian Government as inflexible on the status of the capital, Sarajevo, and on the issue of a strip of land between Serbia and Banja Luka, the largest Serbian-held city in Bosnia.
"We can't sit back and let them play this game," the official said. "They are trying to deprive us of the moral and political support we have in the United States with their so-called press embargo, that they themselves are violating."
Mr. Clinton's letter was a response to a lengthy letter from Mr. Gingrich written on Oct. 26 that asked for more detailed information about the Administration's plans to send troops to Bosnia.
Mr. Clinton reiterated his view that the United States must take a leading role in the NATO-led peacekeeping force both to prevent the war from spreading and to preserve NATO as an institution. Although he pledged that Congress would have ample time to debate the issue before American forces are sent, he added that a "small" number of communications and other support troops would be sent even before Congress acted.
His letter was met with skepticism by a number of Republicans, some of whom questioned the cost estimates.
"Mr. President, where's your black top hat and magic wand?" said Representative Bob Livingston, the Louisiana Republican and chairman of the House Appropriations Committee. Mr. Livingston also disputed the $1.5 billion estimate for the troop deployment, saying Pentagon officials have told him the operation would cost at least twice as much.
Mr. Clinton insisted that the United States would not allow "mission creep" that could result in a nation-building role for the troops, saying that they would not deal with the return of war prisoners or refugees, or retrain civilian police.
If there is a "significant breakdown" in compliance with the military aspects of the peace agreement, Mr. Clinton said, NATO's political body, the North Atlantic Council, would consider changing the operating procedures of the NATO peace force; if there were a "total breakdown in compliance," the allies agree the force would be withdrawn.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Secretary of State Warren Christopher, right, was met by Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke yesterday as he arrived at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base outside Dayton, Ohio, for Balkan peace talks. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Buenos Aires Journal;
Don't Cry, This Land Is Rich in Kims and Lees

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
Thirty years ago, the future seemed bleak for Sang Hyun Kim, a poor farm boy from South Korea, so he packed his bags and headed for Argentina, in search of the great American dream.
Today, it seems that Mr. Kim, who once worked on an Argentine peanut farm, has found that dream. Now 52 and an insurance entrepreneur, he is one of 35,000 South Korean immigrants who make up a prosperous and closely knit population here that is often the envy of other Argentines. 
 Since arriving in 1965, Mr. Kim, who speaks Spanish like a native, has brought nine of his siblings from Korea to Argentina, and all of them now own thriving businesses.
"In Korea, there were too many people and too few economic opportunities," Mr. Kim said. "When I arrived in Argentina, I thought it was a paradise, like virgin territory ripe for the harvesting if you were willing to work hard. And Koreans work very, very hard."
Indeed, the success of South Koreans in Argentina is particularly evident in the garment districts of Once and Flores here, where textile and retail businesses displaying Korean signs are quickly overshadowing establishments started decades ago by Jewish and Armenian immigrants.
The South Koreans operate more than 1,000 businesses in Argentina, including textile factories, electronics stores, pharmacies, real estate agencies, newspapers and a cable television channel, according to statistics provided by the South Korean Embassy. There are also 300 Korean cultural, athletic and business associations and 30 Protestant churches with predominantly Korean congregations.
Several shop owners in the largely Jewish garment district, speaking on condition of anonymity, complained that the South Koreans were "taking over the neighborhood."
The shop owners accused the South Koreans of selling merchandise at unfairly low prices because they reduced their costs by working 12 to 14 hours a day and hiring cheap labor from Bolivia.
Sociologists here say South Koreans represent the latest wave of skilled immigrants to come to Argentina since the huge influx of immigrants from Europe at the turn of the century.
To ease overcrowding in South Korea in the early 1960's, its Government sent missions to South America to forge immigration policies for its citizens. To persuade countries to accept South Koreans, the Government allowed its citizens to take as much as $40,000 with them to South America. The first to immigrate to South America went to Brazil in 1961. Argentina, Paraguay and Chile received the next wave four years later.
Many South Koreans chose to go to Argentina because there were fewer other Asians there, and thus what they saw as greater entrepreneurial opportunities.
From 1965 to 1985, about 6,000 South Koreans came to Argentina, and by 1985 the number had swelled to 50,000. But in the late 1980's the number of South Koreans in Argentina declined as many left for North America during the hard economic times caused by hyperinflation.
The sociologists attribute the success of the South Koreans to their entrepreneurship, access to shared credit and employment of family and cheap labor from neighboring countries.
"It is a community on the rise, both socially and economically," said Jorge Balan, a sociologist for the Center for Studies of State and Society, a think tank.
"Their great community cohesion and large families make them thrive in an informal economy. They contribute to the notion that we are still a place where immigrants want to come."
Still, settling in Argentina, where 90 percent of the population is of European stock, has not come easy for some South Koreans, who complain that they have encountered discrimination, which they say is partly owing to their race and partly to their good fortune here.
"There is discrimination because I am Korean, because I have an Oriental face," said Gunbae Kim, who came to Argentina three years ago and now imports mannequins from Korea.
He said, for example, that a Korean driver might be stopped more often than a native Argentine would be by a policemen looking for a bribe, even if the driver had not committed a traffic violation.
Adrianna Kim, 24, who runs a wholesale garment shop, said that after 10 years here, she feels basically at home.
"There is not so much discrimination in the streets, but there is always somebody who doesn't treat you well," she said. "At times, I did feel discrimination when I was at school."
Mr. Balan, the sociologist, said he believed that Koreans are experiencing the same amount of discrimination that other recent immigrants have felt in Argentina and in other countries.
"People don't throw tomatoes at them, but Koreans receive the same animosity and prejudices that the Jews had to go through," he said.
Perhaps some of that animosity toward Koreans stems from the current downturn in Argentina's economy and record level of unemployment.
"It's nice to have people from abroad but let Argentines get jobs first," said Victor Angel Orona, a taxi driver.
The image of South Koreans was hurt badly two years ago when local newspapers published a series of reports accusing several South Korean garment factories of operating sweat shops in which undocumented Bolivians were forced to work like "slaves."
Nico Kim, a 25-year-old student, who owns a film developing shop in the upscale Northside, said Argentines seem to see the Koreans as a monolith.
"Like in every race, there are good and bad Koreans," he said. "As people generally despise what they do not know, when some Koreans do something bad, there is a tendency to think that all Koreans are the same."
Now that the South Korean population has attained economic success in Argentina, its leaders say they are starting to focus their efforts on increasing education and political power.
Key Sung Cho, South Korean Ambassador to Argentina, said a major goal of South Koreans here is to send the second and third generations to college and eventually run a few candidates for public office.
Tony Kuo, who came to Argentina 22 years ago and owns a retailing shop, said that while his ethnic heritage is important to him and that he sends his children to a Korean school on the weekends, he is proud to be an Argentine citizen.
"When I returned to Korea in 1992, I missed Argentina," Mr. Kuo said. "The only reason I would leave Argentina is if I lose my business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Among the many successful Koreans in Argentina is Gunbae Kim, who operates a mannequin business. But the life is not perfect. "There is discrimination because I am Korean, because I have an Oriental face," he said. Horacio Paone for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Balkan Equation: Flawed Peace Hurts Less Than War

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The Balkan conflict has always been a three-way puzzle. Put one piece in place and another would be dislodged. Through more than four years of diplomacy, the reconciliation of Serbs, Croats and Muslims has proved impossible.
But now that the last difference between between Serbs and Croats has apparently been settled with an agreement on Eastern Slavonia, the political landscape has changed. For if Serbs and Croats really want and have reached peace, the potential for the Muslim-led Bosnian Government to fight on appears limited. 
 This is the grim equation faced by the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, in peace negotiations that began Nov. 1 here. He knows that the successes of the Bosnian Army against the Serbs this year have come only with the decisive support of Croatian forces. Without the Croats, who now appear to have little reason to continue the fight, even the long-term military outlook for the Bosnian Government may be dim.
A strong incentive to settle has thus been engineered by the Clinton Administration. More war now could be costly to the Bosnian Government, while peace, even an unsatisfactory one, would bring economic benefits and western military assistance. Beyond all the intractable difficulties over territory and governance that have stalled the talks in recent days, this somber realization suggests that an agreement may in the end be reached.
Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said today that "self-interest" should propel the parties toward a settlement. For the first time since the Yugoslav wars began in 1991, this may indeed be true.
Initially, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia was ruthlessly committed to defending the Serbs of Croatia and joining the land they inhabited with Serbia. The "Croatian nation" could secede from Yugoslavia, he said in March 1991. But, he added, "I want to make it completely clear that it should not occur to anyone that a part of the Serbian nation will be allowed to go with them."
To prove that point, the town of Vukovar in Eastern Slavonia was flattened by the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army and then captured in November 1991. Fighting laid waste to vast areas of Croatia and forced large numbers of Croats from their homes. About 30 percent of Croatia fell into Serbian hands during the 1991 Croatian war, only to be given up with scarcely a whimper during the last six months.
This surrender has amounted to an extraordinary, largely unexplained shift by Mr. Milosevic. To compare the sheer volume of munitions expended during the three-month siege of Vukovar with the Serbs' quiet agreement on Sunday to give up the town and the surrounding area to Croatia within the next two years is to gain a sense of the huge political journey undertaken by the Serbian President.
It is this journey that has opened the way to peace in the Balkans. If Serbia had fought against Croatia for Western Slavonia in May or for the Krajina in August, if it had decided to fight for Eastern Slavonia rather than give it up, then negotiations would never have come this far.
But Serbia seems committed, at least for now, to ending the Balkan wars. As a result, the decades-old conflict, sometimes overt, sometimes concealed, between Serbs and Croats seems to have been settled.
In the process, the Serbian minority in Croatia, about 13 percent of the population at the beginning of the war, has been reduced to about 3 percent. Like every resolution now envisaged in the Balkans, this was a settlement built on widespread eviction and killing.
But it is a settlement nonetheless, and it now begs the question: Can Bosnia's Muslims afford to fight on if the dominant forces in the area, the Serbs and Croats, are really committed to peace?
The Bosnian Government, its forces strengthened by 42 months of war and its determination reinforced by repeated Serbian atrocities against Muslim civilians, will not be pushed easily into an accord. It may calculate that the Serbian-Croatian agreement is tenuous and that the Bosnian Government's Croatian allies will eventually be ready to fight again to extend the territory of the Muslim-Croat federation.
Moreover, Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic, in particular, retains a deep emotional commitment to the unity of Bosnia as a multiethnic state, a commitment he has shown repeatedly here, officials said. Any peace proposal that appears to open the way for the permanent division of the state will therefore face great obstacles. Talks in Bosnia have made scant headway in recent days.
But there are some hard numbers at work, and they are now militating for peace. When Yugoslavia was founded in 1918, the Muslims accounted for 6 percent of the population. When it fell apart 73 years later, they accounted for 9 percent. The Muslim-led Bosnian Army cannot reasonably hope to prevail if confronted by Serbian resistance and Croatian passivity.
Croats and Serbs tore Yugoslavia apart and made war inescapable. Their reconciliation, in turn, however bitter it may be, may make peace inevitable.

HEADLINE: Catholic Bishops Urge Congress to Reject Social Cutbacks

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The National Conference of Catholic Bishops today urged Congress and the President to reject the limits on welfare and the cuts in the earned income tax credit that emerged this week from the Congressional reconciliation process.
The bishops also affirmed the major themes in the pastoral letter on economic justice passed 10 years ago, and they elected as president and vice president of their conference two bishops known for their commitments to fighting social and economic inequities. 
 The bishops' belief that poor people, children, immigrants and the unborn are threatened by the changes arising from Capitol Hill has injected a strong note of urgency and unanimity into a semiannual meeting of the nation's Roman Catholic bishops that otherwise promised to be a monotonous series of administrative tasks.
"If the Congress does not reject this fatally flawed legislation, we urge the President to veto it," the bishops said in a letter to all senators and representatives. "While the label is reform, the reality is cutting resources and shifting responsibilities."
The bishops objected in particular to the provisions mandating family caps in welfare payments, the reduction of the earned-income tax credit by $32 billion, measures making legal immigrants ineligible for some public benefits and "the block granting of a major share of Federal programs that protect and rescue children from abuse and neglect."
The cumulative effect of these changes, as well as cuts in the food stamp program and plans to replace guaranteed welfare and Medicaid benefits to all who qualify with lump-sum grants to the states, "will be devastating to poor and working families," the letter said.
Although written in the name of the conference, which brings together some bishops from all 188 dioceses, the letter was signed by Auxiliary Bishop John H. Ricard of Baltimore, chairman of the bishops' Domestic Policy Committee, and Roger Cardinal Mahony of Los Angeles, who heads the bishops' Committee on Pro-Life Activities.
The letter challenged proponents of the welfare family cap who "insist that young women will base their decisions about childbearing on the availability of welfare assistance, and then claim that the denial of assistance will not influence their decision to end the lives of their unborn children."
The semiannual meetings of the Catholic bishops have increasingly become affairs where the prelates follow an agenda prepared well in advance, and work their way meticulously through piles of reports and proposals.
Last June some of the bishops complained that this style was making the conference more of a place for bureaucratic housekeeping than for addressing pressing problems of both church and society.
This concern may have been reflected in Cardinal Mahony's request on Monday to alter an agenda heavily weighted with reports on the pensions of retired bishops, the sale of church-owned television property and the translation from the Latin of certain prayers at Mass.
He called for a statement "in response to the current unprecedented dismantling by Congress of essential health care, educational and social service programs."
The statement will be presented and debated on Wednesday, but it has already given the gathering a new life and coherence. What might have been a routine document marking the 10th anniversary of "Economic Justice for All," the conference's pastoral letter on the American economy, took on immediate relevance.
In a passage Bishop Ricard quoted on the floor here, the anniversary document warns that "the power and productivity of the U.S. economy sometimes seems to be leading to three nations living side by side" -- a nation of the prosperous, a nation of those "squeezed" and perpetually insecure and a nation of the desperately poor.
Insisting that the economic debate is mired in "false choices and ideological polarization," the anniversary document juxtaposes themes from different ends of the political spectrum in what has become virtually a signature motif of bishops' statements:
"Our tradition emphasizes both rights and responsibilities, works for increased charity and insists on greater justice, advocates greater personal responsibility and broader social responsibility. We recognize the vital roles and limits of markets, government and voluntary groups.
The document underlines the word "and" in each sentence. All but two bishops voted in favor of it.
Although the appointment of more conservative bishops by Pope John Paul II has made the bishops' conference less adventurous and more riven by theological disputes, the bishops' concern for issues of social and economic welfare remains a strong factor of unity and continuity.
That was reflected in the election today of Bishop Anthony M. Pilla of Cleveland as the conference's new president and Bishop Joseph A. Fiorenza of the Galveston-Houston area as its vice president.
Both bishops have the reputation of being centrists. Bishop Pilla has undertaken a major project joining the urban and rural parts of the Cleveland diocese with the suburbs to build a sense of common well-being.
Bishop Fiorenza, who is 64, heads a diocese in which roughly 6 out 7 Catholics are Hispanic. He was was chairman of the bishops' committee that oversaw the Campaign for Human Development, a program that distributes more than $10 million collected in parishes to local antipoverty projects around the country. As current vice president of the bishops' conference, Bishop Pilla was expected to succeed William Cardinal Keeler of Baltimore in the top post. But Bishop Fiorenza's election as vice president -- and quite likely as president three years from now -- signals that although the conference has grown gradually more conservative over the past 15 years, its leadership will remain centrist and pastoral in outlook.

HEADLINE: Returning From Decline, 42d Street Is Now a Magnet for Merchants

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In the latest sign that the long-stalled revitalization of 42d Street is close to becoming reality, developers said yesterday that 18 merchants had leased space in buildings at the intersection of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, and that a bidding war had broken out for space in another building nearby.
On the growing list of entertainment companies that want space on the street -- the fabled block between Broadway and Eighth Avenue -- is RKO Pictures, a major Hollywood studio. The developers said they hope to lease space for a complex of theme restaurants, which would be called the RKO Hollywood Palace. 
 The complex would be sandwiched between two other entertainment projects already under contract -- a Madame Tussaud's wax museum and a movie complex operated by the American Multi-Theater Company.
But the negotiations with RKO, first reported yesterday in The New York Post, comes amid a flood of bids by restaurant operators, theaters and others hoping for a spot on a street that for decades had been a tawdry reminder of urban decline.
"I have never seen such extensive interest among tenants, or such interesting interest," said Bruce Ratner, president of Forest City Ratner, a development company designated by city and state officials to renovate three theaters and to build new commercial space along a 370-foot strip on the south side of 42d Street, midway between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
Mr. Ratner said RKO was one of 20 companies that had submitted proposals for restaurants or what he called off-beat attractions. Final selection is to be made and construction begin by July, he said. At the intersection of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, a development group that includes the Prudential Insurance Company of America and George Klein, a Manhattan builder, is completing the renovation and new construction of 19 stores. Nearly all the stores are already committed to retailers and restaurants, the developers said yesterday.
"The interest has been extrordinary," said Michelle Demilly, a spokeswoman for the development group, Times Square Center Associates.
Foot Loose, a clothing store specializing in socks and leg wear, opened on Monday, the first of the new stores to do so. Others that have signed on for space at the intersection include Old Navy Clothing Company, a clothing store chain owned by The Gap; Hansen's Brewery, a German pub; Alien New York, a virtual reality emporium, and Magic Max, a magic store. A delicatessen, theater gift shop and a branch of Ferrara's, the cafe based in Little Italy, are also among tenants soon to move to the 42d Street corners, Ms. Demilly said.
She said all 19 stores would be occupied within six months.
The growing momentum toward a revitalized, family oriented entertainment strip on 42d Street comes after two development milestones in the last year.
The first came a year ago when Mr. Klein and Prudential agreed to renovate the 19 stores clustering around the intersection of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue intersection, and to contribute more than $10 million for the renovation of historic 42d Street theaters, in an agreement that indefinitely postponed their plans for huge office towers at the intersection.
That plan, hatched in the early 1970's, involved huge long-term property tax breaks for the developers. But the office project was delayed by dozens of lawsuits, and ultimately by the steep economic downturn and office glut that emerged at the end of the 1980's.
More important, according to government officials and developers, was a commitment signed in July by the Walt Disney Company to renovate the New Amsterdam theater, on the south side of 42d Street, as a base for its own productions like "Beauty and the Beast."
Since then, Disney has joined a partnership with the Tishman Urban Development Company, to build a hotel at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Given a stamp of approval by Disney, developers say, 42nd Street has become a powerful magnet for other companies.
"Before Disney came in, just about the only expressions of interest in the theaters were mud wrestling clubs," said Cora Cahan, president of the New 42d Street Inc., a not-for-profit group designated by the state in 1990 to supervise the renovation of six historic 42d Street theaters. "Now the street has been reinvented."
Since Disney first expressed interest in the New Amsterdam a year ago, all but two of the nine 42d Street theaters have been committed in long-term leases. Besides Disney's, the largest commitment has been by Livent, a Toronto-based production company that plans to renovate and combine the Lyric Theater and the Academy Theater for musical productions.

SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

HEADLINE: Divorced Father's Case Raises Difficult Issues Of Who Pays Tuition

BYLINE: By LINDA MATHEWS 

 BODY:
When Amber Kline turned 18 in 1992, her father, Philip, went to court in Pennsylvania to terminate the order that required him to pay $375 a month for her support. He argued that she had become an adult, in the eyes of the law, and that he should not be forced to put her through college or contribute in any way to her living expenses.
Meanwhile, the Pennsylvania Legislature was taking a different view of parental obligations. In 1993, the Legislature enacted a law that made divorced parents responsible for their children's college expenses, or at least as much of those expenses as the parents could afford. 
 That law, Act 62, did not discourage Mr. Kline. "I'm not big on having the government in my face, telling me what to do," he said recently.
Mr. Kline, who owns a company that sells industrial equipment, broadened his original case to challenge the new statute, and last month he won a ruling from the Pennsylvania Supreme Court that the law violated his rights and the rights of all divorced parents under the 14th Amendment's equal protection clause.
The state Supreme Court, on a 4-to-2 vote, adopted Mr. Kline's reasoning that since parents who are still married to each other cannot be ordered to pay their children's college bills, parents who are divorced should not be subject to such orders.
The court's ruling applies only to Pennsylvanians, but it is being studied elsewhere. That is because the issue of who should be responsible for paying college expenses is debated not only by the children of divorce and their parents but also by matrimonial lawyers, college financial aid offices and state legislatures.
Across the country, the picture is confused. A divorced parent's obligation to a college-age child often depends on where they live. At least nine state legislatures have decreed that noncustodial parents, usually fathers, can be ordered to help pay for college. In other states, including New York and New Jersey, state courts routinely require parents to pay for college if they have the means. But in New Jersey, the Legislature is considering reversing that rule and freeing noncustodial parents from any obligation.
The parent's duty may also depend on where the child goes to college. Even if there is no legal obligation, most private colleges, in distributing financial aid, demand that both parents help meet a child's expenses. Public universities, on the other hand, ask only the custodial parent to help.
Legally, in most states, parents are required to support only their minor children. As soon as a child turns 18 or graduates from high school, the obligation of parents, married or divorced, vanishes. But in an era when most high school graduates go on to college, there is a widespread expectation that children will depend on their parents financially into their early 20's.
Ultimately, that is what happened to the Klines. After not speaking with Amber for eight years, Mr. Kline reconciled with her during the litigation. Now 21, she works for him at Philip H. Kline & Company, and he voluntarily pays her tuition at Kutztown University.
But the Klines are hardly typical.
The children of divorce are less likely to attend college than children from intact families. A 1992 study by the Federal Department of Education showed that 71 percent of the offspring of intact families went to college, as opposed to 54 percent of those whose parents were divorced. Money was a major obstacle for the children of divorce; their family incomes were consistently lower than those of intact families, and only 6 percent of the custodial parents said they expected their former spouses to help pay college bills.
"Clearly, the children of divided families face greater economic and emotional obstacles in pursuing post-secondary schooling," said Albert Momjian, a Philadelphia divorce lawyer and past president of the Pennsylvania chapter of the American Academy of Matrimonial Lawyers. "That's why you have state legislatures getting involved, and why it seems to us there's a rational basis for these laws."
Like divorce lawyers, college deans complain that they get caught up in battles over whether both parents will pay the bills.
"This is one of the most difficult issues facing financial aid administrators," said David F. Charlow, director of student financial planning at Columbia College and the School of Engineering. "There are parents who act as if they have divorced their kids as well as their spouses."
Jim Tilton, director of undergraduate financial aid at Yale University, said, "We've seen more and more of these cases in the past two or three years, perhaps because of the sheer number of divorces."
In unraveling the problem of how much each parent should pay, colleges get very little guidance from the courts. "Often, there was no agreement when the marriage broke up about whether the noncustodial parent would contribute to the cost of college," said Cynthia A. Rife, assistant director of financial aid at Stanford University.
"But our view is that it doesn't matter whether the parent has a legal obligation to contribute to the child's expenses," Ms. Rife added. "We think there's a moral obligation for each parent, both the custodial parent and the noncustodial parent, to contribute."
Nearly all private colleges and universities follow the same rule. "If the parent is involved in the child's life after the divorce, then he's morally obligated" to help pay college bills, said Mr. Charlow, the Columbia financial aid director. "A parent can't choose to be involved in some aspects of a kid's life and uninvolved in other aspects."
Exceptions to that rule are rare. "Only if there is a history of abuse or a long-term history of nonsupport and noninvolvement do we say, 'Forget it,' " said James S. Miller, financial aid director at Harvard College.
But when a parent who can afford to pay something "absolutely balks," Mr. Charlow said, "that unwillingness won't result" in a bigger scholarship.
"Instead, we work with the other parent to figure out a strategy for the family to cover the bills," he said. "Sometimes it means the student or the custodial parent takes a bigger loan."
At a high-cost private college, a typical financial aid package includes a scholarship, which is an outright gift that need not be paid back, as well as a loan and a part-time job for the student. Both parents are also expected to contribute from their current income, savings or assets, and the student must use some savings or summer earnings.
Colleges have not always been so insistent that both parties to a divorce pitch in. "Ten years ago, we never asked a noncustodial parent to contribute," said Ms. Rife of Stanford. "Our policy changed for pragmatic reasons. We need to stretch our funds further. There are more people who need financial aid."
Public universities are less insistent that both parents contribute. The University of California at Berkeley, for example, expects only the custodial parent to help pay for college and makes no effort to pursue the noncustodial parent, even if that parent's income is higher.
The university follows the example of the Federal Government, said Richard Black, director of financial aid at the university. The form students fill out to qualify for Federal grants and loans -- the Free Application for Federal Student Aid -- requires information only about the income of the custodial parent and, if he or she has remarried, the stepparent. Nothing is expected from the noncustodial parent.
"If an absent parent says, 'No, I'm not paying for my kid to go to Harvard or Columbia,' the family has a fallback position," said Mr. Black, the author of "The Complete Family Guide to College Financial Aid" (Perigee). "They can send the kid to Cal or the State University of New York or the public university in their state. Public universities see ourselves as the place that will guarantee a talented kid a first-rate education for relatively little money, no matter what his parents contribute."
Chris Knickerbocker, director of student financial aid and employment at SUNY Binghamton, said the SUNY system had what she called a "don't-ask, don't-tell" standard. "We don't ask for information about the noncustodial parent even if we know he could afford to pay," Ms. Knickerbocker said. "And we don't tell him what he should pay."
The Federal standard is so loose, Ms. Knickerbocker said, that "if you're Donald Trump and you have a student in college, you can get some Federal financial aid in the form of a loan."
College administrators say that divorced parents are far less likely to help with college bills if they have been estranged from their children. That was the case with Mr. Kline, who said he did not "see or even talk to my children for eight years after I separated from my wife."
Mr. Kline had adopted Amber and her brother, Jason, soon after he married their mother, Bonita, in 1977. The Klines then had a child of their own, Rebecca, now 15, before separating in 1984.
He blames his former wife, who has remarried and is now known as Bonita Curtis, for discouraging contact but admits that he was also responsible for losing contact.
"I was just boiling over with anger, especially when the kids told me they didn't want to see me again," Mr. Kline recalled. "Their mother put them up to it, and although I'm not angry anymore, I don't think I'll ever completely forgive her."
Mrs. Curtis declined to comment.
Mr. Kline first tried to modify the $850-a-month support order for the three children when Jason, now 23, reached college age. A court reduced the amount by $100, but ordered Mr. Kline to continue to pay $375 a month for each girl. He renewed his legal attack when Amber finished high school. That request led to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court decision.
Mr. Kline reconciled with his children soon after a hearing where Amber burst into tears on the witness stand while describing her troubled relationship with her father. "I decided she wasn't faking it, that she really believed I didn't want to see her," he said. "And I figured it was up to me to set things right."
He said his relationship with all three children was now better than ever. Amber lives with her mother and helps with receiving and shipping three days a week at Mr. Kline's business while attending art classes part time. Mr. Kline also pays her tuition at Kutztown and has helped her buy a car.
"Everything has turned out wonderfully, far better than I would ever have predicted," Amber Kline said.
Jason, who graduated in June from West Chester University, works as a geographer and mapmaker in California.
If Jason were to go to graduate school, "I would help him in a minute," Mr. Kline said, and "there's no doubt that I will help pay for Rebecca's college."
"What I objected to all along was that the burden of supporting the kids seemed to be entirely on me," he added. "I could afford to support them. I could afford to send them to college. But I hated the idea that a court was meddling in my business."

HEADLINE: Putting the Squeeze on Small Discounters

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

DATELINE: MOHEGAN LAKE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Leaning against her shopping cart, surrounded by bright orange going-out-of-business signs, Maryann Dickman gave her eulogy for the Jamesway discount store here in northern Westchester County.
"I liked it here once," said Mrs. Dickman, an office manager from nearby Putnam Valley. "But everything's changed. There's no selection, they haven't kept it up at all, and the quality isn't good. Wal-Mart is a half-hour away and Jamesway is five minutes, but I would rather go to Wal-Mart. I just like it. Even my husband finds it better." 
 The Jamesway Corporation, the 34-year-old company that was until recently one of the country's largest regional discount chains, is now unloading everything from the simulated-wood desks in its corporate offices to the economy packs of toilet tissue and the racks they are stocked on in its 90 stores.
Jamesway is just the latest and worst example of what has happened during the last few years to nearly every discount store in the Northeast, the birthplace of regional discounting. Each of the largest chains -- Bradlees, Ames, Caldor and Hills -- has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection at some point, and it is almost certain that at least one of them will join Jamesway in the retailing graveyard.
The conventional wisdom is that Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the discount giant that has plodded its way into the region in recent years, has consumed its competitors' market share. Much of the remainder was lapped up by the Kmart Corporation, which won over shoppers with price cuts that grew deeper as its own fortunes faltered, and by "category killer" specialty stores like Bed, Bath and Beyond and the Sports Authority, which focus on one type of merchandise.
But in fact, regional discount chains have also shared a myriad of other problems: dingy stores, mediocre customer service and critical strategic errors, like the relentless accumulation of more and more stores in the late 1980's with money that would have been better spent on inventory and distribution systems, and a seeming inability to reshuffle merchandise to better serve rapidly evolving consumer preferences.
A close look at Jamesway, which sought Chapter 11 protection twice before finally going under this month, reveals a company that was a victim of poor retail conditions, bad management and perhaps a touch of hubris -- all things shared by its ailing competitors.
"There are so many factors in place with the failure of discount stores," said Peter Schaeffer, a retail analyst at Dillon, Read. "You can't just say anymore, 'Oh, it will turn around.' Because I don't think it can."
In a recent interview at Jamesway's corporate headquarters in Secaucus, N.J., Kevin Kulinowski, vice president of operations, recalled Christmas 1990, a moment he now views as the turning point for the company.
The economy was in disarray, joblessness was growing and Jamesway's previous business decisions were starting to catch up with it. "I remember we had two promotions right before Christmas, and one Sunday everything was 20 percent off," he said. "We had tons of business and made no money. And I thought to myself, 'O.K., this is how we are going to do things from now on.' "
Wal-Mart, whose enormous size lets it spread fixed central costs and gives it tremendous buying power and muscle in securing prime real estate -- to say nothing of low prices -- was still a threat looming in the distance. But by 1990 it was already winning an important technological war that other discounters did not seem to know was on.
"Wal-Mart has the most advanced inventory technology in the business and they have invested billions in it," said Kurt Barnard, president of the Barnard Retail Marketing Report, a trade publication. "Even Herb Fisher did not take into consideration that the future was destined to have technology as its central role," he said of the late and much beloved founder of Jamesway, Herbert Fisher.
With a few keystrokes, Wal-Mart's distribution workers can figure out what items are needed by any of the company's stores -- and then see to their speedy delivery. By contrast, Jamesway's antiquated methods of tracking stock hurt the company badly as customers' likes and dislikes changed toward the end of the decade, and as the need to unload inventory became more urgent.
"What we never knew in this company was what actually sold," said John Sipala, a senior vice president who is now the company's chief financial officer.
Consequently, merchandise that moved well was suddenly put on sale, which resulted in a needless surrender of margins. And popular items were eliminated; one day, for instance, Jamesway decided that it would no longer sell yarn, to the great vexation of many of its elderly customers.
Instead of inventory systems, Jamesway and its competitors spent their profits on real estate in the 80's. By the end of the decade, the company had placed 90 discount stores throughout the Northeast, some in the backyards of Kmart and Caldor.
Likewise, Ames Department Stores Inc., based in Rocky Hill, Conn., went into 32 months of bankruptcy protection in 1990 as a result of debt created by the 1988 purchase of the former Zayre chain of discount stores. Bradlees, based in Braintree, Mass., also expanded, adding a sprawling store in Manhattan even when other discounters were already sinking.
But asking discounters why they continued to open new stores is akin to asking New Yorkers why they stand in the gutter while waiting to cross the street: It doesn't get them any where faster, but it creates a comforting illusion of progress. "There was this urge to compete, to be bigger, to get the leases before the competition," Mr. Kulinowski said. "And now we're all paying for it."
Now, as the discounters face financial crises, the storefronts are ballast, too small to entice a Wal-Mart or Target to acquire them. And the names themselves lack the cachet that would draw buyers.
Simple esthetic questions also plague the discounters. Stores like the one here were ignored, left with a dated feel that was only deepened by poor lighting, unattractive floor designs and piped-in elevator music.
"We didn't put a lot of money into remodeling stores," Mr. Sipala acknowledged. "It's amazing how when a customer feels good in a store, they want to spend money there."
Nor did customer service enhance the shopping experience. "It was always a hassle here," said Robin Vogt, as she cruised the discount toy aisles here with her husband, Don. "There was never anyone at the cash register. No one was helpful."
By the time the discounters finally got around to reacting to Wal-Mart and Kmart, the "category killers" stepped in, with their huge inventories of discounted specialty merchandise.
And department stores, deeply wounded in the consolidation fever that struck in the beginning of the 1990's, began beating discounters at their own game. They brought down prices and overhead, largely through the consolidation of giant operations, and started snacking on discounters' market shares.
During times of turmoil, Jamesway clearly needed good leadership. In 1990, the company's president, Arlie Lazarus, left, and Mr. Fisher temporarily came out of retirement. From there, four different presidents came through the door, including Peter Hollis, who had lost credibility in the retail community with mishaps at Ames, where he was president, and other discounters. None of the men were seen to have the merchandising panache or the interpersonal skills of Mr. Fisher.
Now that a pattern has been set with troubled discounters, suppliers and the factors that buy their receivables have begun running for lifeboats in situations that just a few years ago would have left them merely tapping anxiously on the deck.
The Caldor Corporation, for example, filed for Chapter 11 in September, surprising some investors who thought the store was more liquid than some of its competitors. But suppliers, reacting to Wall Street gossip that placed Caldor executives at the bank looking for debtor-in-possession cash, quickly pulled the plug on the company.
Bradlees Inc., though perhaps in worse shape than Caldor, may have been similarly shoved into bankruptcy.
"The Northeast has become sort of a burial ground," Mr. Barnard said.
Some chains are making attempts to shed or narrowly focus their discount-store image in an effort to differentiate themselves from competitors. Venture Stores Inc., a 25-year-old chain based in Fallon, Mo., has ditched its no-name merchandise and will try to upgrade its image by focusing on name-brand sports apparel and private label cookware. Kmart is test-marketing a new "pantry concept," hoping that potato chips and other consumable goods will bring in new customers.
Both plans are suspect, relying on products with slim margins or on creating whole new images for familiar stores. "But if you're standing on the window ledge of a four-story building and it's burning, you can jump and you might die, but if you stay, you'll burn to death," said Barry Bryant, senior director of institutional equity sales at Rodman & Renshaw Inc.
Many retail experts believe that in the end regional discount stores are undergoing an organic cycle, with the strongest and fittest surviving and the weakest dying a necessary death. As it is, today's struggling chains in the Northeast are really survivors of an earlier round of consolidations in the 1970's and 80's, when Zayre, Arlan's Department Stores and Mammoth Mart Inc. went out of business.
"Regional department stores have a reason to be," said Mr. Schaeffer of Dillon, Read, "because they can offer local tastes. But there is no need for regional discounters. Motor oil is the same in New York as it is in Florida. Now they can offer the assortment that Wal-mart does, but they can't offer the price, and the bottom line is, the consumer is getting sick of being ripped off."

HEADLINE: F.D.I.C. Cuts Commercial Bank Premiums

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation decided today to virtually eliminate deposit insurance premiums for most commercial banks after concluding that its insurance fund had enough money to cover bank failures in the coming months.
Bankers welcomed the unanimous decision by the agency's board, which will take effect on Jan. 1 and save them $946 million a year in premiums. Industry lobbyists waged a vigorous campaign to eliminate the premiums, arguing that they were unnecessary after the Bank Insurance Fund late last spring reached its Congressionally mandated target of $1.25 in reserves for every $100 of insured deposits. 
 Ricki Helfer, the chairman of the F.D.I.C., said premiums needed to be reduced because of the banking industry's current health, the economy's strength and the expectation of F.D.I.C. examiners that few banks would fail soon. Premiums will still be collected for some banks with risky business practices and less solid finances. Still, the income from premiums as a share of insured deposits will fall to the lowest level in the 62 years of Federal deposit insurance.
Consumer activists and even some of the board's members criticized the decision. "Under a better system, we would be allowed to build up a surplus in better times that we would run off in bad times," said Jonathan L. Fiechter, the acting director of the Office of Thrift Supervision and one of the four sitting members of the F.D.I.C.'s board.
But Mr. Fiechter voted for the premium reduction anyway, saying that current law left the board with little choice once the fund had clearly met the target for reserves.
Ralph Nader, the consumer activist, contended that the $25.08 billion now in the Bank Insurance Fund could be exhausted easily by the collapse of one or two of the giant banks now forming from the industry's many mergers, leaving taxpayers with the burden of paying for any further failures. Today's decision "is a prescription for another round of corporate bank welfare," he said.
For complicated political reasons, savings institution executives welcomed today's fee reduction even though it did not immediately help them and could even hurt them in the short run. The savings industry's insurance fund, which the F.D.I.C. also oversees, has only 37 cents in reserves for every $100 in insured deposits, and is growing slowly.
As a result, even healthy savings institutions are paying 23 cents in premiums for every $100 in deposits and will continue to do so. Healthy banks paid roughly the same premium until last summer, when it was reduced to 4 cents for every $100.
The latest reduction in bank fees gives banks a temporary competitive advantage over savings institutions. But legislation now moving through Congress would impose a one-time assessment of $5.7 billion early next year on savings institutions to bring their insurance fund up to the target of $1.25 for every $100 of deposits. So savings institutions have an incentive for premiums to be as low as possible once the target is reached.
The F.D.I.C. board voted today to eliminate the remaining 4-cent premium and replace it with a $2,000 fee for each healthy bank regardless of size -- the lowest assessment that the agency is allowed by law to collect. The board puts 92 percent of the nation's banks, with 94.6 percent of the nation's insured deposits, in its top category of financial health, for which premiums will be virtually eliminated.
The healthiest banks are those with good records of avoiding risky business practices and with high ratios of capital -- their cushion against losses -- to assets. The F.D.I.C. also reduced slightly but did not eliminate the premiums for banks with less capital and with business records that are not so safe.
Premiums for the weakest, riskiest banks will fall to 27 cents for every $100 of insured deposits from 31 cents; premiums for the weakest savings institutions will stay at 31 cents.

HEADLINE: Most Retailers' Profits Shrink as Competition Heats Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
The fierce competition that has kept consumers awash in bargains has taken a heavy toll on retailers, industry figures showed today.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest chain, eked out a modest increase in profits for its third fiscal quarter, but the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the J. C. Penney Company and the Woolworth Corporation all posted declines. 
 In another sign of a possibly dispiriting holiday sales season, the Commerce Department reported today a larger-than-expected sag in retail sales during October, with nonautomotive goods recording the biggest decline since February.
"We're losing steam on the consumer side," said Bob Buchanan, senior retail analyst at NatWest Securities in New York. "It's down, heading into the most important period of the year."
Meanwhile, a later though narrower gauge suggested that colder weather may have stirred consumers a bit. A Johnson Redbook Service survey found that store sales climbed 2.2 percent during the two weeks ended Saturday, compared with the period a month earlier.
But the mood remained subdued as industry analysts cited a number of trends that weighed down retailers while providing consumers with hope for large preholiday discounts.
High consumer debt and lagging incomes leave little room for splurging on gifts, while the aging of the baby-boom generation -- its elders turn 50 next year -- means less spending for the stylish products of youth and more need to think of college tuitions and nursing homes.
Clothing sales have been particularly hard hit, suffering also from the trend toward more casual business and other apparel at a time of ferocious foreign competition.
"We've got just too many apparel stores," said Karen Sack, who analyzes stocks of retailers for Standard & Poor's. "These companies cannot raise prices."
The two-tenths of 1 percent decline in retail sales last month came in spite of the strong housing market, reflected in the number of existing and new homes changing hands. Typically, the repair and decoration associated with moving generate substantial spending but this did not occur in October.
Merchants selling furniture and other goods for the home saw volume fall eight-tenths of 1 percent while those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes had a sales drop of four-tenths of 1 percent.
The only category of durable goods to show an increase was in automotive sales, which rebounded seven-tenths of 1 percent following a 2 percent decline in September. Since producers previously reported selling fewer cars last month, the rise reflected a combination of price increases, more sales of higher-priced models and seasonal adjustments, analysts said.
Excluding the automotive sector, retail sales in October slumped five-tenths of 1 percent, the worst performance in eight months.
Among nondurables, or items not expected to last three years, sales increased at only drug and variety stores, up eight-tenths of 1 percent, and food stores, up seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Sales dropped 2.4 percent at stores selling apparel and accessories, 1.5 percent at gasoline service stations (partly reflecting lower prices), 1.1 percent at department stores and other outlets selling general merchandise, and three-tenths of 1 percent at bars and restaurants.
The figures are adjusted for seasonal variation and for holidays but not for inflation. In the latest 12 months, retail sales increased 3 percent -- but only half of this is higher volume because inflation for consumer goods ran at 1.5 percent for the year that ended in September.
The Commerce Department, which said it would not issue any more economic reports until the Government reopens for normal business, trimmed its estimate of the rise in September retail sales to one-tenth of 1 percent from three-tenths of 1 percent, while raising its estimate of August sales by the same amount to seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Meanwhile, Wal-Mart used its muscle to capture customers from mostly weaker competitors, enabling it to report an earnings gain of 4.1 percent in its fiscal third quarter. Net income totaled $612 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $588 million, or 26 cents, in the third quarter of 1994.
The company, which has long enjoyed double-digit profit gains, is investing heavily in new stores in this country and abroad, Ms. Sack said.
Sales at the discount giant's 1,965 Wal-Mart stores rose 12 percent, to $16.2 billion, while Sam's Wholesale Club sales rose 3 percent, to $4.7 billion.
But Dayton Hudson, whose largest property is the Target chain, saw its earnings decline 34.3 percent. Net income totaled $44 million, or 45 cents a share, down from $67 million, or 86 cents, in the comparable 1994 quarter. Revenues, however, advanced to $5.6 billion, 10 percent higher for all stores and 4 percent higher on a same-store basis.
The Minneapolis-based company called Target's performance "solid" while Mervyn's was "slightly below plan" and the department stores were "weak."
For J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., quarterly earnings slipped 12.4 percent. Net income fell to $240 million, or $1 a share, from $274 million, or $1.11, a year earlier.
"While we are disappointed with our third-quarter performance, our expenses are under control and our inventories are in line with current sales expectations," James E. Oesterreicher, vice chairman and chief executive, said.
Sales edged down four-tenths of 1 percent, to $5.1 billion. Analysts said Penney had lost apparel sales to Wal-Mart and Sears, Roebuck & Company, both of which have been significantly stepping up their efforts in soft goods.
At Woolworth, earnings slipped 8.1 percent. Net income fell to $34 million, or 26 cents a share, from $37 million, or 28 cents, in the comparable 1994 quarter. Revenue dropped 1.1 percent, to $2.1 billion.
Analysts said profits, about a nickel below Wall Street expectations, were hurt by weak back-to-school sales and the need to cut prices.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Says Its Banks' Woes Aren't as Bad as They Seemed

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Despite the Japanese banking industry's much publicized difficulties, the Ministry of Finance announced today that the industry's operating profits had soared and that total bad loans were below its previous estimate.
Today's announcements seemed aimed both at trying to reshape the ministry's image, which has been tarnished recently by the Daiwa Bank scandal, and at improving the view abroad of Japanese banks. 
 "We can't change the criticism and opinion immediately," Sei Nakai, a senior banking official in the Ministry of Finance, said today. "But by repeating this kind of practice, we'd like to gradually resume our trust not only among the Japanese people, but among the people all over the world."
The new figures, which the ministry said were based on reports from financial institutions and local governments, seem to suggest that the bad-debt problem is not as large as many foreign bankers had thought. Still, a skeptical foreign banking community, which has recently tightened credit and raised the interest rates on loans to Japanese institutions, is not likely to be convinced immediately.
Mr. Nakai said that bad debts at the end of September totaled 37.4 trillion yen, roughly $367 billion.
The ministry once put the total amount of bad debt as high as $490 billion and the amount of unrecoverable loans at $98 billion to $147 billion. But those figures, the ministry emphasized today, were simply estimates and were not based on data from individual institutions.
Bad debts include those in which repayment is late but is expected eventually. In the new numbers, the bad debts estimated to be unrecoverable, or never to be repaid, rose from previous estimates, to 18.29 trillion yen, about $179 billion. That is the equivalent of 3.9 percent of the national economic output last year.
Some foreign analysts have estimated that bad debts could run as high as $650 billion, but Mr. Nakai disagreed today.
"They are wrong," he said. "We have collected reports from all the banks, and if their report is a false one, then they will be subject to our penalty."
Partly because of the recent scandal at Daiwa Bank, where a New York-based trader hid $1.1 billion in losses for more than 11 years, foreign institutions have become increasingly suspicious of Japanese accounting practices and financial statements.
"The biggest problem is this concern that banks do not always disclose accurate numbers," said Paul Heaton, an analyst at Deutsche Bank Capital Markets (Asia) Ltd.
The ministry also released preliminary figures today showing that all banks' net operating profits for the six months that ended in September rose nearly 50 percent, to $33 billion.
Net income for the six months, however, was up just 2.8 percent, to $4.6 billion. The disposal of bad loans reduced the large operating profits.
Partly out of embarrassment, many Japanese banks have hesitated to disclose all their bad debt and reworked loans; many foreign analysts say such figures are crucial in evaluating the creditworthiness of an institution.
But some creditworthy Japanese banks may want to increase financial disclosure voluntarily to distinguish themselves and shave off some of the "Japan premium" that foreign banks charge on loans to Japanese banks.
Both the ministry and the Bank of Japan, the central bank, have called upon the banking industry to increase disclosure and publicize its plans for disposing of bad debt.
"Now is the time for individual financial institutions to specifically present the way and the timing for the disposal of bad loans," Toshihiko Fukui, senior deputy governor of the Bank of Japan, said Monday.
The Bank of Japan has been helping the banks by keeping interest rates low. When asked today about the central bank's virtual subsidy to the banks, Mr. Nakai of the Finance Ministry replied that a similar policy was adopted in the United States in the early 1990's.
"We have just started," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Some Philadelphia hotels withhold a magazine from rooms of travel agents at a convention.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
EACH month free copies of Philadelphia magazine are put in the guest rooms of Center City hotels in Philadelphia, but the November issue was withheld from a number of hotels last week.
The reason? The American Society of Travel Agents was in town for a weeklong convention, its first in Philadelphia, and some hoteliers as well as the president of the Philadelphia Convention and Visitors Bureau, Tom Muldoon, regarded the magazine's cover article inappropriate for the 6,300 delegates. 
 Titled "The Issue Is Race," the cover features a photograph of two boys, one black and one white, with the black boy's arms around the white boy. "The civil rights movement was 30 years ago," the cover says, concluding, "In 1995, why can't Philadelphians see beyond black and white?"
Mr. Muldoon did not respond to telephone calls seeking comment. But R. C. Staab, a bureau spokesman, said that Mr. Muldoon did not ask hoteliers to bar the magazine. "He asked them to read it first and decide whether it was appropriate to put in rooms," Mr. Staab said. He added that Mr. Muldoon described as "inaccurate" an article titled "Tourist Trap," which contrasts the Convention Center (which the magazine said was widely perceived as "upscale and white") with the nearby Gallery shopping mall (widely perceived as "downscale and black").
Several hotels put the magazine in rooms, as usual, but the Ritz-Carlton, Four Seasons, Latham and Warwick did not. Jim Beley, the general manager of the Ritz-Carlton, said yesterday: "I don't think of it as censorship; it was an issue of economics. We didn't feel the content was appropriate at a time when the city has invested so much to bring A.S.T.A. here, in hopes of attracting tourists and convention business."
Eliot Kaplan, the editor of Philadelphia magazine, said of the timing: "We weren't even thinking of A.S.T.A. We saw the issue as an attempt to open a dialogue on race. But apparently in parts of the birthplace of freedom, you still can't have a dialogue about it."
 
A Security Riddle
With airports security at its tightest since the Persian Gulf war, the following sounds like an example of that Churchillian "riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma":
After being dropped off at the ramp at the Delta Air Lines terminal at New York's Kennedy International Airport on Oct. 14, Leif Wassermann, the commercial attache at the Danish Consulate in New York, said he walked upstairs to the ticket counter and, after checking in to get his boarding pass, went directly to the gate to board Flight 68 for Copenhagen -- without passing through metal detectors or undergoing a security check of any kind.
In a letter to Ronald W. Allen, Delta's chairman, Mr. Wassermann described himself as "amazed, anguished and shocked with the lack of security at Delta J.F.K." In a subsequent telephone interview, Mr. Wassermann said he saw security checks at other entrances to the terminal, but none along the route he took from the ramp to the gate. Nor was he mollified by a letter from Delta that arrived on Monday, essentially saying that it is impossible to board a flight without passing through a security screen.
"I can't explain how I did it," Mr. Wassermann said, "but why after I wrote Delta a letter and followed up with two phone calls, didn't they ask me to come out to the airport and show how I did it?"
Told of Mr. Wassermann's story earlier this week, a Delta spokesman, Bill Berry, reacted with incredulity. More than a month ago Delta began demanding identification of every adult passenger, even on domestic flights, rather than leaving it to the discretion of individual ticket agents, as Federal laws allows. "I can't believe it," Mr. Berry said. "It just doesn't seem possible."
Yesterday Mr. Berry said that Delta security officials at Kennedy ran a series of tests and insisted that security was not breached and could not be breached unintentionally. "They wonder if Mr. Wassermann is thinking of the more obvious, two-step security procedures used in Europe," Mr. Berry said, "compared with what is often a one-step procedure used in exiting the U.S."
In any event, Mr. Berry said that Delta's chief of security at Kennedy would soon telephone Mr. Wassermann and invite him to the airport.
 
Airlines Are Rated
Only two United States airlines ranked among the top 20 in Conde Nast Traveler's latest poll: Midwest Express, in 15th place, and Alaska Airlines, No. 17. Midwest Express, based in Milwaukee, scored high in cabin comfort, as well as service and food. Alaska, based in Seattle, scored high in punctuality, scheduling and baggage handling.
Singapore Airlines was voted the top-ranking carrier and Swissair second, reversing last year's first- and second-place finishes. Quantas, Air New Zealand and Cathay Pacific rounded out the top five.
