HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Anxiety Over Budget Impasse Lowers Dollar vs. Yen and Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened broadly yesterday, hurt by growing investor nervousness over the budget impasse in Washington and new pessimism about the Mexican economy.
Currency traders said the lack of progress to reach a budget compromise, which forced a partial shutdown of the Federal Government, was creating increased anxiety among holders of dollar-denominated investments. 
 Although the Treasury took strong steps on Monday to avert default on payment of its credit obligations, which helped reassure the financial markets, the effects of those steps were seen as temporary. Yesterday, currency traders looked for hints that the crisis would soon be over, but found none.
"I'm surprised that anybody wants to hold dollars," said Elena Shperling, chief currency trader at the New York branch of the Banco di Sicilia. "It's not that the Treasury is in such grave danger. But the Government looks pretty bad to outsiders. A lot of people in Europe are wondering what's going on here."
Wayne Grigull, director of foreign exchange sales at Merrill Lynch & Company, said, "I think the market is impatient for something substantive to come out of Washington." When traders saw no progress, he said, "they sold the dollar."
In New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 101.51 Japanese yen from 101.91 yen on Monday. It also fell to 1.4130 German marks from 1.4185 marks and to 1.1407 Swiss francs from 1.1441 francs. The British pound rose to $1.5601 from $1.5529.
Traders followed the Treasury bond market, which was also looking for signs of progress on the budget. Treasury prices ended mixed yesterday.
The dollar was also undermined by concern about the Mexican economy, stemming from revised Mexican Government predictions of lower growth.
Despite peso buying by the Mexican central bank, the peso fell yesterday to a rate of 7.81 to the dollar -- a closing low -- from 7.77 to the dollar on Monday.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz said the Mexican economy would shrink 6 percent this year, not 5 percent as he had said earlier. He predicted a 3 percent growth rate in 1996. Many private economists consider that optimistic.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Mixed In Partial Federal Closing

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as the Government partly shut down its operations. The impasse in Washington over budget proposals and extending the debt ceiling kept downward pressure on the long bond, while intermediate and shorter maturities were mostly higher.
Traders noted that the stalemate between the Administration and Congress has dominated trading in Government securities in recent days and disrupted the sale of new Treasury securities. Sales resumed yesterday after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin announced a revised schedule of auctions and the use of two Government employees' funds to remain under the current debt ceiling. 
 The 30-year bond fell 6/32, to a price of 107 28/32 to yield 6.29 percent, up from 6.27 percent on Monday.
Yesterday the Treasury sold $57.5 billion of 9-day and 36-day cash management bills. The Government occasionally sells such bills to meet cash flow shortages when it needs to meet interest and principal payments.
The Government found yesterday just how expensive borrowing could get when there was so much uncertainty and nervousness in the credit markets. The average rate for a 9-day bill was 5.77 percent and 5.64 percent for a 36-day bills. Traders said the rates were higher than those at the weekly auction of three- and six-month bills on Monday, reflecting the premium investors are demanding for the Treasury's use of their money during this crisis.
Today the Treasury will auction $18.75 billion in new one-year bills. Last week's delayed quarterly refunding will be early next week. On Monday, $18 billion in new 3-year notes are to be sold, and on Tuesday $13.5 billion in 10-year notes. Late in the day, in when-issued trading ahead of next week's sales, the 3-year was offered at a price to yield 5.54 percent and the 10, at a price to yield 5.92 percent.
The partial Government shutdown will also affect the release of economic data, since some of the offices that compute the data may have to close. Yesterday, the Commerce Department reported that October retail sales were down two-tenths of 1 percent.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said those numbers were "clearly on the weakside," adding, "It was another piece of evidence indicating slower consumer spending in the fourth quarter."
Mr. Fine said, "If this continues as expected, it will give more credence to a Fed easing on Dec. 19, which I continue to expect."
The Labor Department will be releasing October's consumer price report today, and the Fed, which is meeting today will also release October industrial production and capacity utilization. But the Commerce Department has postponed today's business inventories report for Septmber, as well as Friday's housing starts for October. Tomorrow the Labor department will not be releasing its initial weekly claims for unemployment insurance.
Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, said the market reacted favorably to the weaker-than-expected retail sales data, and that the official furlough of Government workers had little impact on the market.
"The Street," Mr. Hamilton said, "was unable to hold its better posture however, due to profit taking and a somewhat greater-than-expected weekly Redbook data." Yesterday the Johnson Redbook said retail sales rose two-tenths of 1 percent for the two-week period ended Nov. 11.
Mr. Hamilton said today's activity should remain somewhat sidelined pending the outcome of the F.O.M.C. meeting and any resolution to the continuing Government budget partial shutdown.

HEADLINE: Contemporary Art Lags at Auction

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Last night's driving rain and high winds didn't keep the droves of passionate art collectors and dealers from Christie's salesroom. Standing room was three deep as the crowd watched the contemporary-art market continue to struggle.
Gone was the crackle and excitement of last week's Impressionist and modern art sales. Last night's auction was a tepid affair that totaled $14.5 million, far below Christie's estimate of $19.8 million to $26 million. Of the 60 works for sale, 46 found buyers. 
 "Clearly this was a different market from last week, but we knew that going into the sale," said Christopher Burge, chairman of Christie's in New York, who was the evening's auctioneer. "On the whole it was a very solid sale, but with some obvious disappointments."
The material last night was just a bit too familiar: 25 percent of the works offered had been auctioned within the last 10 years, most of them in the boom years of the late 1980's. Artists who were stars of the 80's fared badly; works by Eric Fischl, Jeff Koons and Julian Schnabel barely raised any bids. And estimates were still a bit too high: few works sold for more than their low estimates, and many brought far less.
"Nothing went gangbusters," said Joan Washburn, a Manhattan dealer. "The sale was flat. It reflects the market in general."
An obvious dearth of star-quality works has been the contemporary-art market's biggest problem for five years.
Last night's auction highlighted more works from the 1950's and 1960's, a smart move, but even these contemporary classics had their ups and downs. The biggest success came about halfway through the evening when Barnett Newman's "Word II" (1954), a hard-edged Color Field painting, sold for $3 million, right at the low estimate and a record for the artist. The buyer was believed to be Samuel J. Heyman, a New York collector who is the chairman of GAF Corporation.
By contrast, the evening's most expensive painting, Jackson Pollock's "No. 1, 1952," from the collection of Frank Stanton, the former president of CBS, failed to sell. The drip painting, a rich tangle of yellow, red, white and black, was expected to bring $4 million to $6 million. Mr. Burge came within a hair's breadth of selling it. Several people were interested, but no one would budge beyond $3.3 million. "By tomorrow it will have been sold," Mr. Burge said.
(Final prices include the auction house's commission: 15 percent of the first $50,000 and 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
The Pollock wasn't the only 1950's painting unsold. Willem de Kooning's "Duck Pond," a 1958 landscape from the "Parkways" series, didn't find a buyer, either. The painting, with broad strokes of yellow and blue, was estimated at $700,000 to $900,000. Bidding never went past $500,000.
Several works last night were being sold by Shigeki Kameyama, a Japanese collector and dealer, who spent top dollar for many of them at the height of the market. Last week, at Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern art, Mr. Kameyama sold Picasso's "Mirror" (1932) for $20 million. He had bought the painting in 1989 for $26.4 million.
Among the works he sold last night were Claes Oldenburg's "Bacon and Egg," a 1961 relief. Christie's had estimated it would bring $180,000 to $250,000. It sold for $288,500 to an unidentified bidder. The work set a record for the artist when Mr. Kameyama bought it at Sotheby's in New York in May 1989 for $495,000, well above its $300,000 estimate. A year later, Sotheby's tried to sell it again, but it failed to sell.
Mr. Kameyama was also selling George Segal's "Subway" (1968). In 1989 he bought the life-sized environmental sculpture at Christie's in New York for $528,000. Last night the estimate was $250,000 to $350,000; the work sold to an unidentified bidder for $310,500.
While prices for many artists have obviously plunged over the years, Calder has been recession-proof. His "Wheat," a standing mobile circa 1948, which Mr. Kameyama bought seven years ago at Sotheby's for $150,000, was expected to sell for $80,000 to $120,000 last night; a telephone bidder paid $217,000.
Another Calder standing mobile, "Laocoon" (1947), provided a welcome competitive moment. Four people vied for the work, estimated at $750,000 to $950,000. It finally sold to Eli Broad, the Los Angeles-based collector, for $992,500. It wasn't the mobile's first appearance at auction. In 1990 it failed to sell at Sotheby's. Back then, bidding never went higher than $1.6 million.
Another work that performed well was Robert Rauschenberg's "Glider," a 1962 silk screen. Estimated at $800,000 to $1.2 million, it sold to an unidentified bidder for $827,500.
At several fleeting moments, the salesroom came alive. Many people competed to buy Robert Graham's "Fountain Figure II," a 1983 bronze sculpture of a man jumping. Estimated at $50,000 to $70,000, it sold for $112,500, a record for the artist. A gem of a Warhol, "Red Airmail Stamps," a 1962 silk screen, went to an unidentified bidder for $178,500, almost twice its high estimate of $100,000.
There were also some bargains. Clyfford Still's "1955-D," a large Color Field painting of a modulating field of fiery red, failed to sell at Christie's five years ago, when no one was willing to pay more than $1.1 million. Last night, it carried an estimate of $700,000 to $900,000. Jeffrey Deitch, a New York dealer, snapped it up for $684,500.
"It was an erratic night," Mr. Broad said. "Certainly the great locomotive energy from last week was not enough to pull contemporary art to a new high ground. But who knows? Tomorrow is another night." The sales continue tonight at Sotheby's.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Federal Workers Sent Home
Because of Budget Impasse
Nearly half the civilian functions of the Federal Government halted as President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress remained at loggerheads over spending priorities and appeared to put off any resolution until next week. "We are at an impasse," Leon Panetta, the White House chief of staff, said. Some 800,000 employees were suspended. [Page A1.]
 
The Treasury's long bond slipped in price in reaction to the shutdown, sending the yield up to 6.29 percent from 6.27 percent on Monday. The Government sold $57.5 billion of cash-management bills to meet its shortage. [D18.]
 
Stock prices also fell in reaction. Technology stocks, particularly chip makers, tumbled, sending the Nasdaq composite index down 17.84 points to 1,040.62. The Dow industrials eased 1.09 points, closing at 4,871.81. [D8.]
 
Intervention for Mexican Peso
The peso weakened to a little over 12 cents, but rebounded when the Mexican central bank intervened for the second time this month. A budget speech by Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz, insisting that Mexico would stick to tight fiscal policies, did not impress investors. [D6.]
 
For Retailers, a Sad Season
Retailers are taking a drubbing from the competition that has kept consumers awash in bargains. Retail sales slipped two-tenths of 1 percent in October. Wal-Mart had a modest profit, but Dayton Hudson, J. C. Penney and Woolworth had declines. [D4.]
 
New Competition
In Cellular Service
The Washington area is becoming the first market in the nation where cellular telephone users will be able to choose a carrier from three wireless phone networks, rather than just two. The question is, will anybody care? Billions of dollars hang on the answer, which will not come for some time. Sprint and American Personal Communications are offering a novel service using a new band of microwave frequencies. [D5.]
 
Banks' Bonus: No Premiums
The F.D.I.C. decided to end deposit insurance premiums for most commercial banks, on grounds that its insurance fund has enough money to cover failures. Banks will save nearly $946 million in yearly premiums. [D2.]
 
Delay Urged on Single Currency
The exclusive use of a single European currency should not go into effect until 2002, the European Monetary Institute recommended. [D7.]
 
USAir, a British Albatross
British Airways' shares have suffered even though the carrier is regarded as one of the world's best run. The reason is its investments in other airlines like USAir, from which UAL backed away on Monday. [D6.]
 
Japanese Bank Profits Rise
Japanese banks' operating profits soared, and the industry's bad debts were below previous estimates in the six months though September, the Finance Ministry said. [D6.]
 
A Mutual Fund for College Savings
Investors in A.I.G. Children's World Fund, American International's new fund for college savings, will receive all their original investment back if they stay with the fund 10 years and reinvest all dividends. [D5.]
 
The City of Brotherly Contention?
Philadelphia hoteliers worked so hard to attract a convention of the American Society of Travel Agents that some decided not to put out free copies of Philadelphia magazine. It criticizes the city on race relations. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D6.]
 
Developing an E.D.S. Identity
Electronic Data Systems is turning to Bates Worldwide to help it develop an image beyond the company that Ross Perot founded and sold to G.M. Advertising. [D7.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 505 words

HEADLINE: Endless Recess

 BODY:
While educators are calling for higher standards and more demanding classes, tens of thousands of New York City teen-agers are being shut out of class altogether, given short schedules for only a few hours of instruction a day. The system not only allows these students to fail, it practically begs them to drop out.
The city has long allowed high school students to take a light schedule for a handful of good reasons, such as needing only a few credits to graduate, or participating in a vocational school work-study program. But this year 77,000 students, 28 percent of all high school students, are in school for less than the 5 1/2 hours the state requires. Surely there are not 77,000 youngsters with plausible reasons to leave early. 
 The suspicion, indeed the near-certainty, is that high schools are giving students fewer classes because this year they suffered budget cuts that in some cases exceeded 20 percent. School buildings around the city are jammed, and classes frequently have more than the 34 students allowed under teaching contracts. The United Federation of Teachers contends that some of its members have been told by their principals that they must choose between putting students on short schedules and enduring even more overcrowded classes.
State law requires that students attend high school for seven 45-minute periods a day, one of them for lunch. But in some New York City schools, a full third of the student body are taking fewer classes, sometimes three or even two. The Board of Education appears to have very little information about who these students are and why their class load has been cut back. Indeed, officials are unable even to say whether the number of short schedules has grown over the last few years.
Anecdotal information suggests that the students given short schedules are often the very ones who need more, not less, attention. They are the youngsters who failed several courses in the preceding year, who had unusual stretches of absence early in the school year or who registered after school began.
Insuring students a full day of school is a bottom-line requirement for city government. If the high schools do not have enough teachers to do the job, the board must hire them, or find administrators who can be reassigned to teaching duty. If the board does not have enough resources, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani must find the money elsewhere. If the Mayor continues to insist that there would be plenty of resources if only the board streamlined its bureaucracy, he has an obligation to work with the new school leadership to find economies.
Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and State Education Commissioner Richard Mills have been outspoken in their calls for tougher high school standards and graduation requirements. Those ideas, no matter how commendable, seem remote from the reality of a system that cannot give 77,000 of its students a full day in class, and where the response to children in educational trouble is to tell them to spend less time in school.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Keep It Simple

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
At an American base in Hohenfels, Germany, the U.S. Army has set up a remarkable training facility -- a mini-Bosnia. The Hollywood-like set consists of villages with burned-out cars, shot-up houses and NATO soldiers in costumes playing different roles, including the mayor, refugees, black-marketeers, snipers, a CNN reporter and warring factions. Units of the U.S. Army's First Armored Division, which will be the backbone of the U.S. peacekeeping force in Bosnia, have to spend time practicing in the villages and are scored on how few of their men get hit by pretend snipers using laser guns. Secretary of Defense William Perry told me that the motto of the U.S. commanders running mini-Bosnia is that "the scrimmage should be harder than the game."
A month ago President Clinton implied that if the Bosnian factions negotiating in Dayton, Ohio, reach an agreement, U.S. peacekeeping troops in Bosnia would be like the U.S. peacekeepers separating Egypt and Israel in the Sinai Desert, who spend their days counting camels. That no longer seems to be the Administration's approach. The argument now, which Mr. Perry laid out in an interview, is that this mission is going to be dangerous, and that even with a peace accord there will be some local pockets of opposition -- but it is worth doing because to not go in will lead to more killing in Bosnia, a spreading of the war and a debasing of American leadership. 
 "The problem I don't want to have to deal with," said Mr. Perry, "is, 'Why didn't you tell me about this? You told me it was going to be a Sunday school picnic, and what happened? Somebody's shooting at us after we get there. . . .' It is not that I am callous about the risks. It's that I recognize the risks of not going in are greater." Those risks, he added, involve "not just feeling bad about the continuing slaughter in Bosnia. There's a very real danger of this war spreading beyond Bosnia." Anyone who blocks this mission, said Mr. Perry, "is now saying 'I want the war to continue in Bosnia.' "
If anyone is sitting back waiting for the Administration to make that one knockout argument for sending troops to Bosnia that will wow the public and Congress so effectively that their reservations will melt away, he is waiting in vain. Mr. Perry's blunt talk is the argument.
Will it sell? I think the U.S. public can be persuaded -- reluctantly, very reluctantly -- to send troops to Bosnia to support a peace accord, provided that the risk of casualties is minimal and the U.S. mission is confined to simply separating the parties and consolidating the cease-fire. That is a mission people can intuitively understand -- separating combatants, preventing further massacres and giving the parties enough security so they might start relating to each other differently.
Where, I think, the public will draw a line is anything that goes beyond simple peacekeeping into nation-building. If the parties will only agree to sign the peace treaty if the U.S. contributes forces to separate the warring factions, that is one thing. If the parties will only sign the peace treaty if the U.S. contributes forces to put Bosnia back together again -- to guarantee elections, to guarantee constitutional arrangements, to guarantee a return of refugees, to hunt war criminals, to impose arms control measures -- that is going to be a hard sell. Those are all worthy goals. And U.S. diplomats, using economic leverage, should be assigned to promote them. But they will have to be achieved by the parties, at their own speed.
The Bosnia peacekeeping debate highlights the disconnect in America today between the foreign-policy elites and the public. The elites see all sorts of opportunities in Bosnia -- from finding new ways to cooperate with Russia to finding a new mission for NATO and U.S. troops in Europe. The elites believe that because the cold war is over we can do all of these things. But the public believes that because the cold war is over we don't have to do all these things.
Bridging that gap is the Administration's challenge. I think it is bridgeable -- barely. But the message to U.S. negotiators now trying to work out a Bosnia peace deal has to be: Keep it simple. Any U.S. peacekeeping mission that requires an expert from the Brookings Institution to explain is going to be a problem. Don't negotiate a deal in Dayton that you can't sell in Dayton.

HEADLINE: School Money Is Serving Social Needs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Much of the increased school spending in the last 25 years has gone not to regular classrooms but for educating disabled children, counseling and other social welfare functions, an economists' group said today.
Researchers said the study by the Economic Policy Institute helped show that schools handled many tasks beyond academics. Their arguments dispute claims by conservatives that regular school spending has jumped dramatically while learning has plummeted. And the study drew immediate criticism. 
 "Certainly, special education accounts for a piece of the growth," said Chester Finn, a former Reagan Administration education official who works for the conservative Hudson Institute. "But even when you discount that, the growth in spending is very substantial, and schools have not improved."
An Economic Policy Institute researcher, Richard Rothstein, disputed that, saying, "The widespread belief that there have been vast new amounts of money poured into regular education with no results is just wrong."
In addition to fueling fights over school spending, the findings worried advocates for disabled children, who have already said that they are concerned about what they call slipping support for a 1975 Federal anti-discrimination law.
"Our kids are not using more than their share of resources, when you look at individual districts," said Jamie Ruppman, a mother in Fairfax, Va. "And what's the alternative? Denying them education?"
Parents and superintendents in a handful of districts have begun disputing the amount they must spend on mentally and physically disabled students under the 1975 law.
Schools in Westchester County, N.Y., for example, have questioned whether they must send children to a special school for the blind and disabled at a cost of $175,000 a year.
Mr. Finn noted that more children each year were being classified as learning disabled. "Once a child is classified, they have essentially a prior claim on the school budget before anything else is paid for," he said. "How fair is that?"
Mr. Rothstein spent three years examining spending in nine school districts from 1967 to 1991. In that time, actual average school expenditures climbed to $5,000 per student from $687.
When accounting for inflation through the Consumer Price Index, that translated to a 100 percent increase in real spending. But arguing that the index does not reflect the labor intensiveness of schools, Mr. Rothstein substituted a price index focusing on the service industry. Under that measure, which Mr. Finn criticized, expenditures rose by 60 percent since 1967.
Of the new spending, the Economic Policy Institute study found that 38 percent went to educate disabled children, while 19 percent went to educate other special groups, including vocational students or pregnant teen-agers in alternative programs.
The study looked at spending in Anne Arundel County, Md.; Bettendorf, Iowa; Boulder, Colo.; Claiborne County, Tenn.; East Baton Rouge, La.; Fall River, Mass.; Los Angeles; Middletown, N.Y., and Spring Branch, Tex.
The Economic Policy Institute, founded in 1986 by the economists Lester C. Thurow and Robert B. Reich, who is now Labor Secretary, received money for the study from the Metropolitan Life Foundation, an affiliate of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Seeing No Set Pattern in Market

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Nov. 14

 BODY:
During a discussion of the free-agent market last week, a club executive brought up Dante Bichette and the new contract he recently accepted that kept him out of the market.
"He might be the m.v.p. and he got $11 million," the executive said, suggesting the money seemed low for a player in Bichette's position. "Is that going to be the going rate for top players?" 
 Bichette agreed to the Colorado Rockies' offer of $11.1 million for three years, an average of $3.7 million a year. The same question might have been asked the other day when Atlanta gave Marquis Grissom a new contract for $4.8 million a year for four years.
Emerging from their second day of meetings today, general managers saw the signings differently but generally agreed that whether the contracts were good signings for the clubs or good signings for the players, they would not have a significant impact on clubs and free agents in their coming negotiations.
"I think it's still to be determined," Gord Ash of Toronto said of the market. "There's the situation with the basic supply and demand. Some of the players probably will sign relatively quickly for the dollars we've seen. But there probably will be a number of players still available. It's kind of wait and see."
Dan Duquette, Boston's general manager, said he sees each case as an individual negotiation. "But," he added, "the signs I've seen so far are related to the overall income in the industry, and the income has been down a little bit."
Considering the year Bichette had -- a .340 batting average and a league-leading 40 home runs and 128 runs batted in -- under normal circumstances he could reasonably have expected to be pursued as a free agent with offers in the $5 million-a-year neighborhood.
But he has a chronically bad left knee, and the ailment is noted in his contract in the form of a higher salary for the third year if the knee has not limited his playing time before that season.
Grissom, on the other hand, had his second-worst season, a .258 batting average and 29 stolen bases, and he was 11 days short of being eligible for free agency. He might have fared better financially waiting a year, figuring he would have a better season and then he would be an attractive free agent. But he wanted a long-term contract now.
Even though some agents and general managers saw those signings as beneficial to the clubs, Bob Quinn, the San Francisco Giants' general manager, perceived them otherwise.
"Heck, no," Quinn said when asked whether he thought those signings would set the going rate for players this winter. "It depends on the financial wherewithal of the club in question as to whether or not they can afford the player. Atlanta and Colorado are two fairly successful clubs, financially speaking. There are those who don't have the wherewithal to do what those clubs did. You know what your constraints are and you have to act fiscally responsible as it pertains to your club, not what Colorado or Atlanta or anyone else can do."
Obviously, some free agents believe the market will bear much more economically for top players.
Craig Biggio, Houston's second baseman, became a free agent after rejecting the Astros' four-year, $20 million offer. He clearly believes he can do at least that well in the open market, and with teams like the Yankees and the Mets competing for him, he just might be right.
But Joe McIlvaine said he did not foresee the Mets becoming involved in a bidding war for any player. "You have to be prepared to offer him what you think you can offer him," the Met general manager said. "If that's acceptable, fine. If not, then you have to think of another way."
Bill Bavasi of California took the same position in discussing the Angels' pending negotiations with Chuck Finley, the free-agent pitcher they would like to keep.
Ash, the Blue Jays' general manager, said he thought the market could move slowly.
"There's this aura of normalcy that's crept into the business because of the World Series and the television contract," he said, "but you have that same concern of where are we going laborwise. I think there's still a large degree of uncertainty."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE MARKETS;
Wall St. Tries To Handicap Budget Fight

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
As politicians on both sides dug in their heels, analysts and economists on Wall Street began yesterday to gauge the likely impact on financial markets of a protracted impasse in passing a Federal budget.
While a long delay would be a serious disappointment, Wall Street economists and analysts said yesterday that it would not necessarily be all bad news for financial markets. 
 Despite the partisan wrangling, Wall Street is optimistic that compromises on proposed tax and spending cuts will be reached within several weeks and that threats of Government default -- an event that is almost uniformly feared -- will not reappear.
But the divisions that separate the two sides in Washington are so deep that many analysts are beginning to think that the only deal possible is what is called a continuing budget resolution, which would keep the Government going through the rest of the current fiscal year at a somewhat lower level of spending than the level in last year's budget.
"The House of Representatives is polarized," said Edward McKelvey, a vice president and senior economist at Goldman Sachs & Company, adding that the chances of the budget debate continuing into next year's Presidential elections are about one in three.
"On the right, there are a core of Republicans who are disinclined to compromise on the deficit," he said. "And on the left, you have Congressional Democrats whose allegiance to the President isn't that strong. It remains to be seen whether the leadership in the House, the Senate and the White House can produce a deal that will be acceptable to the two poles."
Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, a Wall Street economic consulting firm, said, "The initial reaction in the bond market to that sort of a scenario would be pretty negative."
Mr. Crandall said long-term interest rates would probably rise by one-quarter of a percentage point if Congress and the White House failed to adopt a long-term budget.
The Republican majority insists that its plan would achieve a balanced Federal budget by 2002. The Democrats say that the cuts and too drastic in the Republican plan and that some of the savings would go to a tax cut for the wealthy.
But as the year progresses, interest rates would probably reverse direction, Mr. Crandall and others said, as the effects of a slight reduction in Government spending and the absence of off-setting tax cuts worked their way into the economy and slow it down. Bond traders like slow growth because they believe that means inflation will remain in check.
A stalemate on the budget is also likely to slow moves by the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates, which would help spur economic growth.
Recent data, including yesterday's weak retail sales report for October, suggest that the pace of economic activity is slowing in the fourth quarter.
Under other circumstances, analysts said, the numbers might be sufficient to persuade the Federal Reserve, whose policy makers meet in Washington today, to cut short-term interest rates immediately. But the continuing uncertainty about the budget effectively rules out that option, the analysts said.
In a report sent to clients last night, Mr. McKelvy and other economists at Goldman Sachs said: "We believe that Fed officials will wait for the outcome of the budget debate before easing monetary policy further.
More important, the implications of no budget deal for economic growth and inflation suggest that the next round of easing would not be the last."
Efforts to curb Government spending have been applauded by Wall Street in the past, and the current effort has been taken particularly seriously, if only because it is led by a Republican-controlled Congress.
At least some of the recent drop in interest rates has been due to a perception on Wall Street that momentum in Washington to balance the budget was building. But economists say the positive impact has been less than what Republican leaders in Congress claim.
In 12 months, long-term bond yields have fallen by nearly two full percentage points, to 6.28 percent yesterday.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
Federal Workers Go Home as Budget Impasse Stiffens

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Nearly half the civilian functions of the Federal Government ground to a sputtering halt today as President Clinton and the Republican-controlled Congress remained deadlocked over spending priorities and appeared to push off any possible resolution until at least the end of the week.
It was a day of dueling televised oratory, fitful negotiations and mutual accusations of bad faith, and the price was the closing of Government offices, parks, museums and laboratories and the furloughing of some 800,000 employees, who reported for work only to be sent home, their desks eerily empty and their suites dark by midmorning. Vital functions, from mail delivery to air traffic control, continued uninterrupted. 
 Nevertheless, thousands of Americans who needed Government services that seemed vital to them -- locating tax records, applying for Social Security benefits, obtaining passports -- found themselves frustrated and sometimes furious because of a battle in Washington that most did not profess to understand. [Page B9.]
"We are at an impasse," Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, told reporters late this afternoon, after his second meetings of the day with Congressional budget leaders on Capitol Hill. "I believe we are looking at a situation in which they are going to continue to try to put their budget together, send it to the President and the President will veto that budget."
Late Monday, Mr. Clinton vetoed a stopgap spending measure that would have kept the Government running until the end of the month because, he said, the Republicans had attached unacceptable conditions and cuts in programs he favors.
At midafternoon, Mr. Clinton appeared in the White House briefing room to accuse the Republicans of putting "ideology ahead of common sense and shared values." He said he vetoed the temporary spending measure, and another that would have extended the Government's borrowing authority until mid-December, "because America can never accept under pressure what it would not accept in free and open debate." He vowed to "continue to fight for the right kind of balanced budget," and added, "It is my solemn responsibility to stand against a budget plan that is bad for America."
He had no sooner finished speaking than an angry Speaker Newt Gingrich accused him of "deliberate misrepresentation" and "a phony argument about fantasy cuts." And Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said Mr. Clinton "didn't make it any easier" to get an agreement to keep the Government running. Both sides said they could not predict when the shutdown, the fifth since 1981 but apparently the most serious, would end.
The temporary spending authority is needed because only 3 of the 13 annual appropriations bills have been passed by Congress and signed by Mr. Clinton, and an interim measure to keep the Government running expired at midnight on Monday. On Wednesday, the Government is expected to exceed its $4.9 trillion ceiling on borrowing, but Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin has taken emergency steps to raise cash in the meantime.
All day today, wispy suggestions for compromise evaporated in the heat of the Republicans' insistence that Mr. Clinton accept their goal of balancing the Federal budget in seven years, and of Mr. Clinton's equally emphatic insistence that the Republicans strip any temporary spending or borrowing measures of amendments embodying their longer-term budget priorities, like curtailing the growth of spending for Medicare.
Mr. Gingrich said tonight that he would prepare separate legislation to reopen the parts of the Government whose absence is producing the most complaints.
Tony Blankley, a spokesman for Mr. Gingrich, said tonight that the legislation would provide money for these essential services through September 1996. "We will target the legislation very precisely to programs and services that every American agrees should be continued," he said.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, responded skeptically. "That's about the 10th idea we've heard today," he said. "We're not sure any of them are serious. The President's view is that we need to restore Government services to the American people and to do it across the board, not piecemeal."
At one point today, the back-and-forth debate grew so absurd that Mr. Gingrich proposed as an olive branch a measure sure to draw Mr. Clinton's fire. He offered to present temporary spending and borrowing provisions without conditions, but said he would attach them to the sweeping budget bill that Congress hopes to send to the White House by the end of the week. Mr. Clinton has repeatedly vowed to veto that measure as unduly harsh on programs for education, health care, the elderly, children and the environment, and the White House made it clear that any such move by Mr. Gingrich would also fail.
White House aides agreed that Mr. Gingrich's proposal appeared to make it all but certain that no progress could be made on resolving the short-term credit-and-spending crisis until Mr. Clinton went through the ritual of vetoing the Republicans' broader plan to balance the budget by 2002, thus effectively blocking all the major provisions of their Contract With America.
Only then, both sides suggested today, might real negotiations on both the short- and long-term disputes bear fruit. The President's veto could come by the weekend.
Though Mr. Clinton expressed concern about the disruption and hardship the shutdown is causing, Mr. McCurry said it might be lengthy if the Republicans refused to bend.
"The President just now has told you that those priorities reflected in that budget will not be accepted," Mr. McCurry said. "And he has point-blank told them that this President is willing to give up his Presidency on that proposition, rather than accept those budget priorities."
At stake are intense and deeply divergent arguments about the direction of the country, on the eve of the 1996 election year. Republicans hope to paint Mr. Clinton as intransigent and not committed to balancing the budget, while he seeks to portray them as cruelly dismantling three generations of social programs.
Each side has been convinced that it has the political merits on its side, though initial opinion surveys have found that more Americans blame Congress than the President for the impasse and that the Administration's bare-knuckles attack on the specifics of the Republicans' spending plans appears to have borne fruit.
The Republican and Democratic parties sought to drive home their positions in dueling advertisements. The Democratic National Committee this week began running a 30-second nationally televised commercial that purports to tell "the truth on Medicare."
The narrator says: "Republicans threaten to close the Government down if the President won't cut Medicare and education. No deal. The President will do right by our elderly and our children. Threat or no threat." Party officials would not disclose how much money they are spending on the commercial.
The Republican National Committee, meanwhile, paid for a full-page advertisement published today in USA Today that features a grainy photograph of the Washington Monument and this headline: "This morning, the President spent $607 million and closed the Washington Monument. It would have been cheaper to balance the budget."
An hourlong meeting this morning on Capitol Hill between Mr. Panetta and the leaders of the Congressional budget committees produced little more than an agreement to meet again this afternoon, and after the second meeting, both sides acknowledged a deadlock.
Some of the discussion revolved around what is likely to be the essence of any eventual compromise on the overall budget: the two camps' differing assumptions about how the economy will perform in the coming years. Mr. Clinton's projections are rosier than those of the Congressional Budget Office, though only a bit, but they are less optimistic than some private economic forecasts.
But such small distinctions translate over time into great differences in the depth of spending cuts needed to produce a balanced budget, and the White House had made it clear that adjusting them was the only way that Mr. Clinton could preserve his priorities and Congress protect its own.
So far, however, House Republicans in particular have been unyielding. This afternoon, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, held a news conference with charts purporting to show Mr. Clinton as favoring annual deficits of $200 billion far into the future, while the Republicans would produce balance. Mr. Clinton contends that his plan would balance the budget in nine years and that the differences are purely a matter of underlying assumptions.
The Senate minority leader, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, said that the bipartisan Congressional leadership had a good discussion about the issue with Mr. Clinton in the White House late Monday but that "it really led nowhere."
"We're not any closer today than we were 24 hours ago," he added.
Like other Congressional leaders and White House aides, Mr. Daschle said he saw few prospects for even an interim solution soon, and he went so far as to predict that Congress's planned Thanksgiving recess would be canceled.
"We'll be here next week," he said, "carving up more than one turkey."

An article on Wednesday about the partial shutdown of the Federal Government misstated the Federal debt ceiling in some editions. It is $4.9 trillion, not $4.9 billion.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Soars Past 4,900; S.& P. 500 Sets Record
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 4,900 for the first time, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a record. Benign news on last month's inflation rate put traders in a buying mood.
The Dow climbed 50.94 points -- more than 1 percent -- to 4,922.75, for its 57th high this year. The S.& P. 500 rose 4.67, to 593.96, and the Nasdaq composite edged higher. [Page D10.]
 
Treasury Averts Default
The Treasury averted default by tapping two civil service retirement funds to cover interest payments on the Federal debt. Congress and the Administration made no progress in resolving their basic disputes over spending levels and priorities. [A1.]
 
Giant Buyouts Offered at AT&T
In the latest sign that corporate job cuts are becoming a fixture on the business landscape, AT&T said it was offering 77,800 managers -- half its supervisory work force -- financial incentives to leave by Jan. 13. The company is breaking itself into three pieces. Only a small number of managers is expected to take the offer, but the plan sent shivers of insecurity through AT&T's managerial ranks. [A1.]
 
Generic Drug Merger Falls Apart
Plans to create a large generic drug company collapsed when Ivax of Miami and Hafslund of Norway ended their merger agreement, which would have created a company with $2.5 billion in combined sales. But the companies agreed to a number of licensing and collaborative agreements, an approach that analysts found preferable. [D2.]
 
Cholesterol Drug May Help Heart
A potent cholesterol-lowering drug can prevent heart attacks and deaths in men who are apparently healthy but have elevated cholesterol levels, new research shows. The finding is applicable to at least one-quarter of American men. The drug, sold as Pravachol by Bristol-Myers Squibb, is one of a new class of such drugs. [A1.]
 
Japan's Trade Gap Shrinks
Japan's trade deficit with the United States narrowed 44.2 percent in October from a year earlier, its biggest decline in more than five years, as auto exports fell. [D6.]]
Tokyo, as the host of regional trade talks beginning in Osaka, finds itself caught in a web of competing interests. [A6.]
 
CBS Producer Defends Interview The CBS producer of the rejected "60 Minutes" segment featuring an interview with a former tobacco executive said the program's lawyers told him they had no problem with his news gathering. [A16.]
 
A CBS station in Los Angeles resumed broadcasting a commercial against smoking. The station, KCBS-TV, discontinued the commercial last week, after running it for five weeks. [D9.]
 
Sony and Visa Venture on the Net
Sony of America formed an alliance with Visa U.S.A. to create an information and entertainment center on the World Wide Web. Starting next spring, computer users would be able to preview and discuss music CD's, television programs and films, shop for Sony products, and play interactive games. [D8.]
 
Euro Disney Turns a Profit
Euro Disney made an annual profit for the first time since it opened in 1992. But shares of the theme park fell 14 percent. Analysts said earnings were growing too slowly to justify its current stock price. The profit was helped by a special gain. [D7.]
 
On-Line Ads, on the TV
America Online's new television commercials may be outstanding or may be egregious, but in any case, they are the most eye-catching effort in the young business of marketing computer online services. America Online said it wanted the campaign, developed by TBWA Chiat Day of New York, "to show diversity and humanity and fun." Advertising. [D9.]
 
Corporate Jets by the Week
Gulfstream joined forces with Executive Jet to offer time sharing of corporate aircraft, which is a rapidly growing market. The new company will offer an eighth of a share in a jet costing $27.5 million for $3.5 million, plus costs, for 100 hours of flying time a year. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs Past 4,900 for First Time With a 50.94 Surge

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average soared past 4,900 for the first time yesterday, and the broader-based Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a record.
Benign news on inflation put traders in a buying mood, even though the Federal Reserve took no action on cutting interest rates at yesterday's meeting of its Federal Open Market Committee and the debt squabble in Washington was unresolved. In addition, four rounds of computer-guided "buy" orders in advance of tomorrow's double-witching options expiration helped push the stock market upward late in the day. 
 Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers, suggested the Fed would be ready to reduce rates once an agreement had been reached to balance the Federal budget. "Such a move would make the total return on stocks more competitive than the return on bonds."
Bond prices and yields showed little movement during the day. The yield on the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 6.29 percent.
The Dow climbed 50.94 points, or more than 1 percent, to 4,922.75, its top level of the day and its 57th new high this year. It surged through the 4,800 milestone just two months ago. Although a gain of 50 points or more is supposed to set off a New York Stock Exchange rule that curbs stock-index arbitrage, the 30-stock average did not pass the 50-point mark until the market had closed, when last-minute orders were reflected in the final prices.
The S.& P. 500 rose 4.67 points, to 593.96, surpassing the record of 593.26 it set last Thursday. The Nasdaq composite index increased 1.23 points, to 1,041.85.
Advancing issues outnumbered declines on the Big Board, 1,194 to 1,060. Trading was heavy, as 376.1 million shares changed hands, compared with 354.4 million shares on Tuesday.
"It appears that in early November investors found those rose-colored glasses that they've worn for the better part of the last year, which had been temporarily misplaced in October," said Charles G. Crane, senior vice president of Spears, Benzak, Salomon & Farrell. "Rotation could become a weekly event."
Consumer-product stocks, which traditionally have stable earnings whatever the economic environment, were yesterday's standouts. McDonald's rose 1, to 43 3/8; Philip Morris increased 1 3/4, to 89 5/8, and Coca-Cola advanced 1/4, to 74 1/4. The Morgan Stanley Consumer Index advanced 2.52 points, or almost 1 percent, to 276.14.
Drug stocks, perceived as defensive issues, also finished higher. Eli Lilly closed at 99 1/2, up 2 1/2; Pfizer closed at 60 7/8, up 1 7/8, and Merck closed at 60, up 3/4.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Moves Lower as Traders Await Outcome of Budget Fight

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped yesterday on increasing concerns over United States budget negotiations, but it was also hurt by the renewed ascent of the German mark against other European currencies.
The dollar received some support in the afternoon, however, after the Federal Reserve, as expected, left short-term interest rates unchanged. 
 The American currency slumped during Asian and European trading sessions, as players chose to stay clear of it amid an increasingly tense budget battle between the White House and Congress.
"The big move came overnight," said Tim Hughes, chief dealer at National Bank of Detroit. "Everybody is waiting to see what will happen with the budget situation."
Some currency traders said they were concerned that a prolonged impasse would hurt the chances for a big reduction in the budget deficit.
"The risk of watered-down deficit-cutting could be quite negative," said Amy Smith Beaumont of IDEA Inc. "That's what people fear the most."
Marc Chandler, senior currency analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said, "Even though it seems clear the U.S. Government is not going to default, people are still concerned about the budget."
In New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 101.38 Japanese yen from 101.66 yen on Tuesday. The dollar also slipped to 1.4062 marks from 1.4141 marks and to 1.1377 Swiss francs from 1.1419 Swiss francs. The British pound edged up to $1.5570 from $1.5586.
In other trading, the mark flexed its muscles against the pound, Swiss franc and other European currencies, adding to the pressure on the dollar. But the dollar benefited from a rally in the French franc against the mark.
The franc, and French financial markets, rallied after Prime Minister Alain Juppe pledged sharp spending cuts in France's welfare system as well as a new tax to wipe out accumulated debts.
Analysts praised the package, saying Mr. Juppe had paved the way for a stronger franc by putting the emphasis on cost-cutting and efficiency.
"It's not a new dawn," said Christopher Potts, an analyst at Cheuvreux de Virieu in Paris. "But it's a little better than expected; there is something for everyone in this."

HEADLINE: Fed Maintains Rates, Though More Signs of Sluggishness Emerge

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Despite mounting evidence of some economic slowing, the Federal Reserve decided today against lowering interest rates, which would have made borrowing less costly at the start of the holiday shopping season.
Analysts generally attributed the decision to the Federal Government's stalemated budget negotiations and to the absence of compelling evidence that the economy needs to be spurred, though it is less robust than during the summer. 
 "It looks like they're waiting until some of the uncertainty over fiscal policy and the economy is cleared up," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan. "It's debatable whether the economy needs any stimulus."
Others disagreed, pointing to weak retail sales and heavy levels of consumer debt, and to fresh figures released today that showed flat industrial production and subdued inflation in October. Consumer prices were up three-tenths of 1 percent in the month, a bit more than expected, but not enough to bother economists.
The central bank has cut short-term interest rates only once this year, by one-quarter of a percentage point in early July, after a 12-month pre-emptive strike against inflation in which it had doubled the Federal funds rate, the benchmark overnight lending rate for the banking system, to 6 percent.
The Fed signaled its decision today with its customary terse statement: "The Federal Open Market Committee meeting ended at 1:30, and there will be no further announcement."
Representative Pete Stark of California, the ranking Democrat on the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, expressed dismay at the result, which left the Federal funds rate at what he regarded as an overly restrictive 5 3/4 percent.
"The negative indicators are starting to pile up," he said. "The Fed should have taken action today."
One possibility is that the Open Market Committee has decided to lean toward an easing of monetary policy, without actually cutting interest rates. That would give Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, discretion to make a cut before the next scheduled meeting, on Dec. 19, should he think conditions warrant it.
Most analysts expect the Fed to cut rates at that meeting, assuming that there is some progress toward reducing the Federal budget deficit, and that there is not a sudden burst of economic vigor. A surge of growth seems unlikely, even though the fourth quarters of 1992, 1993 and 1994 all turned out to be the strongest of the year by a wide margin.
This year the quarter has gotten off to a weak start. The latest evidence was the Fed's report today that production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell three-tenths of 1 percent in October.
That was the first decline since April, though several months have shown negligible gains or no increases and the September result was initially reported as a modest decline that was revised to a small gain. The severity of the October decline, however, was magnified by a strike at the Boeing Company, without which it would have been just one-tenth of 1 percent.
Nonetheless, analysts found little comfort in the report, which also showed that factory output was down two-tenths of 1 percent and about unchanged excluding the aircraft strike.
"Production was weak across the board," Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said in a statement. "This traces back to the fact that inventories were not drawn down in the third quarter. Consequently, industrialists are adopting a cautious posture, keeping production lean until the existing stocks are sold off."
He said the possibility of slack consumer demand in the coming weeks was "an additional disincentive" to stepped-up output.
A decline in the assembly of motor vehicles, to an annual rate of 11.6 million from 12 million, was the biggest factor in the weakened output of consumer goods.
The Fed's report also showed that the utilization rate, which represents the percentage of capacity at which industry is operating, fell to 83.6 percent last month from 84.1 percent in September. That matched the July pace as the lowest of the year and was nearly two points below the cyclical peak posted in December 1994 and January 1995.
The operating rate is closely watched as a sign of possible future inflation. While inflationary pressure ebbed in industry, at the consumer level, prices edged up last month.
The Labor Department reported that the Consumer Price Index climbed three-tenths of 1 percent on an overall basis as well as with the erratic food and energy components excluded.
While the increase was a bit bigger than expected, analysts found little to fret about, noting that some of the chief contributors -- airline fares, apparel and meat -- could be expected to reverse course in November.
"We do not believe this signals significantly higher inflation," Laurence H. Meyer & Associates, a St. Louis consultancy, told clients.
Energy prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent, after three months of declines, while food prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, after an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in September. Meat prices jumped 1.2 percent, but Patrick C. Jackman, a senior compiler of the index, said he knew of no reason for this to continue.
Prices of medical care rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the same rate as in September, with professional services showing less rapid gains and medical commodities rising more rapidly.
In the New York area, consumer prices moved up two-tenths of 1 percent in October and 2.6 percent over the last 12 months, compared with 2.8 percent for the nation as a whole.
Unlike the Federal Reserve, which generates its own budget and is operating normally despite the partial shutdown of the Government over the budget dispute, the Labor Department will issue no further figures until its statisticians are recalled to work. Mr. Jackman said that if the shutdown extended into next week, the report on consumer prices for November would be jeopardized. Only about half the data had been collected before today.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Duramed Pharmaceuticals faces some harsh terms to raise cash.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
WHEN a company has significant financial problems, but great hopes for the future, it can find itself facing harsh terms to raise cash. That is what has happened to Duramed Pharmaceuticals, which disclosed yesterday that despite making big concessions on terms, it had not raised all the money it needed.
Duramed said it had raised $10 million by selling convertible preferred stock. The amount was far less than the $25 million that the company was trying to sell, and it was forced to make already generous terms even more generous. The company added that it hoped to sell $15 million more within 90 days. 
 Duramed, based in Cincinnati, is in a difficult position because it badly needs money. If it does not pay $7 million it owes to its bank by the end of this year, it must start paying interest rates of 36.4 percent and more. "It's a pretty severe penalty," conceded Tom Arington, Duramed's chairman and chief executive, in an interview early this week.
But yesterday, in announcing the sale of the preferred stock, the company said the money would go to capital expenditures, the development of products and expenses for a drug on which the company has pinned its hopes: a generic version of Premarin, or conjugated estrogen, which is used by many women to fight the effects of menopause and to prevent osteoporosis. No mention was made of paying the bank. Asked about that, a company spokesman said Duramed hoped to renegotiate the loan agreement.
Approval of the conjugated estrogen drug is bitterly opposed by American Home Products, the company that makes the prescription drug. It argues that the generic version proposed by Duramed does not include an ingredient called Delta 8,9 DHES. Duramed says there is no evidence that ingredient has any effect, and notes that the Food and Drug Administration has classified its presence in Premarin as being an impurity.
Duramed stock has risen and fallen on hopes of approval of its drug, climbing from less than $7 in mid-1994 to a high of $25.50 last July, just before a meeting of an F.D.A. panel that it was hoped would conclude that American Home Products' complaint was invalid. Instead, the panel said it did not have enough information to rule, and the stock fell back. Yesterday, it fell 75 cents, to $15.75, in Nasdaq trading.
To the bulls on the stock, approval is likely to come soon and open the way to big profits. Bears, illustrated by a rising number of short-sellers, question whether it will be approved at all, and doubt the profit estimates if it is approved.
While awaiting F.D.A. action, the company must keep functioning with a relatively small sales base of other drugs. It came very close to going broke a few years ago as a result of production problems and regulatory issues, and pleaded guilty to three misdemeanors in connection with the testing and manufacturing of drugs.
Duramed's deal with Provident Bancorp calls for it to begin paying a big penalty on $7 million of its borrowing if that money is not paid back by the end of the year. The rate, now prime plus 2 percent, or 10.75 percent, would rise to 36.5 percent, and, if the money is still not repaid, gradually escalate to 53.6 percent.
In the preferred stock sold yesterday, it was the conversion rate that was the most unusual. Instead of fixing the conversion price at the outset, that price will be set later, based on the market price of the common stock. The timing is at the choice of the holder of the preferred.
Those who bought the preferred will get an 8 percent dividend payment for up to two years. After 90 days they may convert half of it to common stock; after 120 days, all of it can be converted.
The conversion price will be 15 percent below the average common stock price over a 10-day period ending 2 days before the holder asks for conversion, but not lower than $7.50 or higher than $20. Those figures are down -- an advantage for the buyer -- from the range of $10 to $25 the company had sought.
The floating below-market conversion price is the beauty of the deal for buyers who believe in the company. If Duramed does get F.D.A. approval, causing its share price to leap, the preferred holders who act quickly can convert at a price based on trading before the approval was known.
On the other hand, delays that depress the share price only make the eventual conversion more attractive -- and more dilutive to existing shareholders -- by allowing the holder to get more common shares. And any time the conversion is made it will be at a discount to market, so that there is little risk of loss if the stock stays above $7.50.
A generous deal. But when a company otherwise must pay usurious interest rates, it has little choice.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Little Changed As the Fed Lets Rates Stand

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices were little changed yesterday as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged.
While the outcome of the Fed's policy-committee meeting was expected, it did hold down prices by turning the market's attention back to the impasse on the Federal budget and debt limit, as well as to the next Federal Open Market Committee policy meeting. 
 "In terms of the Fed easing, the question is now whether they will ease at the Dec. 19 F.O.M.C. meeting," said Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Money Watch in New York, a market research and analysis firm.
The price of the 30-year bond slipped 1/32 , to 10727/32 , leaving its yield unchanged at 6.29 percent.
Treasury prices were also weighed down by a report on consumer prices for October that was above expectations. The Labor Department said its Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts had expected an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent. The core rate, which excludes the volatile categories of food and energy prices, also rose three-tenths of 1 percent for the month.
"What the C.P.I. numbers did underscore," Mr. Palash of MCM Money Watch said, "was that there are still inflation risks in the economic outlook."
"In particular, with retail inventories on the lean side there shouldn't be a lot of discounting during the upcoming holiday season," he said. As a result, the inflation rate could end the year at 3 percent, up from 2.7 percent in 1994, he said.
"Bottom line, it suggest that the low inflation numbers we saw over the summer might have been a lag effect of the economic slowdown in the spring," Mr. Palash added.
Other data released yesterday were October industrial production output, which fell three-tenths of 1 percent, and capacity use, which fell to an 83.6 percent rate. The production number had been forecast as being down two-tenths of 1 percent and capacity was forecast at an 83.4 percent rate.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $18.75 billion of one-year bills, with an average rate of 5.15 percent, down from 5.30 percent last month and the lowest since almost 18 months. The sale of the bills was well received, traders and analysts said, but it had little effect on the overall market.
The Treasury plans to resume its delayed quarterly sales of three-year notes and 10-year notes next week. The three-year notes will be sold on Monday, in addition to the regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills. The 10-year notes will be sold on Tuesday.
In-when issued trading yesterday, the three-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.59 percent and the 10-year notes at a price to yield 5.96 percent.
The Treasury auctions were made possible after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin tapped $60 billion out of two Federal retirement trust funds yesterday, enabling the Government to pay its debts through the end of the year.
Following are the results of yesteray's Treasury auction of new one-year bills:

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Do tax cuts raise revenue? The supply-side war continues.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
FISCAL conservatism is in: Polls show that most Americans are willing to forgo tax cuts to balance the budget. But supply-side economics, the good-news gospel that equated low tax rates with high tax revenues and rapid growth, is still alive and kicking. And the economists delivering the latest variation on the theme are hardly wild-eyed evangelicals.
One is Martin S. Feldstein, a Harvard professor and former adviser to President Ronald Reagan who ironically was hounded from the White House by supply-side zealots. The other is Daniel R. Feenberg, a widely respected expert on tax data. Their study, released by the nonpartisan National Bureau of Economic Research, calculates that raising the taxes of the rich in 1993 collected just one-third of the revenues expected if taxpayers had not changed their economic behavior. 
 Are they right? Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told a meeting of tax specialists in Washington last week that the two men "have no basis whatsoever for their conclusions." And details of the Treasury's rebuttal, provided by Eric Toder, the Deputy Assistant Secretary for Tax Analysis, buttress Mr. Summers's contention. But the controversy is a reminder that the war over the efficacy of progressive taxes is far from over.
The deficit reduction package pushed through Congress in 1993 raised the top Federal income tax bracket to 36 percent from 31 percent for families with taxable incomes between $150,000 and $250,000, and to 39.6 percent for those with incomes over $250,000. In addition, the ceiling on the Medicare payroll tax was eliminated, effectively raising the marginal tax rate by 2.9 percent for incomes over $135,000.
By contrast, the levy on the merely affluent did not change. Mr. Feldstein and Mr. Feenberg suggest that this group offers a suitable control for a natural experiment in the effect of higher rates on tax revenue.
If the adjusted gross income of the rich (here defined as those with adjusted gross incomes exceeding $200,000) had marched in lockstep with that of the upper middle class ($50,000 to $200,000), it would have grown by 2.9 percent. In fact, the taxable income of the $200,000-plus group fell short by $31 billion. So instead of collecting an extra $16 billion in taxes from this group, Uncle Sam received just $5 billion.
What's more, the higher tax rate widened the gap between what rich people earned and what they kept, supposedly inducing them to work less. Mr. Feldstein and Mr. Feenberg estimate that the deadweight loss -- the income never earned that was not offset by the estimated value of the gain in leisure -- equaled $17 billion. Put it another way: in adding a dollar to tax revenues, the law reduced national income by $3.
It is a plausible story, but is it true? One problem, Mr. Toder says, is that the estimate critically depends on the base year. If 1991 (rather than 1992) is compared with 1993, there is no shortfall in expected income and thus no shortfall in revenue or loss in output.
Another problem is the possibility of tax-shifting. President Clinton was elected in November 1992. If high income earners anticipated higher tax rates in 1993 as a consequence, they presumably would have tried to realize the income in 1992. And there is evidence they did.
Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan's business school, cites a New York State survey showing that two-thirds of Wall Street's year-end bonuses were paid in December 1992, in contrast to the one-third typically paid before the New Year. Mr. Toder adds that a heretofore obscure statistic from the Commerce Department's national income accounts suggests that, all told, $20 billion was shifted.
By the Treasury's reckoning, then, most of the income that Mr. Feldstein and Mr. Feenberg argue was effectively destroyed by higher tax rates was realized a year early. The rest, Mr. Toder estimates, was transformed from ordinary income to capital gains, which was excluded from the Feldstein-Feenberg calculation because the tax rate did not change.
Mr. Feldstein is not about to pack up his computer files and abandon the fight. He argues that no one else has an adequate explanation for the interruption in 1993 of the trend toward ever-increasing income concentration. And he says that an another way of pinpointing income-shifting back to 1992 -- tracking changes in fourth-quarter estimated tax payments -- does not confirm the Commerce Department's results.
Truth is, there is too much room for interpretation in studies of taxpayer behavior to change many minds. The original supply-side Pollyannas were almost certainly wrong: tax revenues never recovered after the cuts in the early 1980's. But economists still do not know what price America pays for sharply progressive income taxes in terms of distorted incentives and slower growth.
