HEADLINE: Russians Vie for Votes, and Anything Goes

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin cherishes his stodgy, button-down reputation. He is not young, he is not funky, and he most definitely does not "rock the house."
And that is why it was a bit surprising that Mr. Chernomyrdin's campaign hired the American rapper Hammer to enliven the image of Our Home Is Russia, the centrist political party.
Against a glowing red, white and blue Our Home Is Russia backdrop at the Rossiya concert hall, Hammer bellowed, "We feel like bustin' loose!" His bewildered audience, mostly made up of middle-aged Russian bureaucrats and campaign workers, did not. 
 The campaign for Russia's parliamentary elections, which are scheduled for Dec. 17, has begun, with about 5,000 candidates struggling for the attention of voters. And although almost all of them are wrapping themselves in patriotism, nationalism and fierce anti-Western slogans, their campaigns have gone completely Hollywood.
In television advertising, sex, money and fear-mongering are far more prominent this year than issues and platforms. Although Russia has experimented with American-style campaign tactics before, this campaign is beginning to look like a Soviet propagandist's worst caricature of the American democratic process.
Some politicians, like the extreme nationalist Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, are selling themselves with the kind of erotic imagery usually reserved for car advertisements and music videos. Others, including the popular nationalist general, Aleksandr Lebed, are using slick, scary spots about crime and corruption. And almost every party is using celebrities. Pop stars and actors are not just endorsing candidates, they are running for office on almost every party list.
Even the Communists are not immune to showbiz. Nikolai Gubenka, a popular actor and theater director, is a top party candidate.
The obscure nationalist party My Fatherland is led by a dissident general, Boris Gromov, and one of its candidates is Iosif Kobzon, a flamboyant crooner who was denied a visa to the United States because of allegations that he had mob connections. When asked at a press conference on Tuesday why he was running, Mr. Kobzon replied, "Honestly speaking, who the hell knows?"
Forty-three parties will be on the December ballot, competing for 450 seats in the lower house of Parliament. Of that number, 225 deputies are elected from party lists and the remaining 225 are chosen from among independent candidates.
"Except for the Communist Party, there is such weak party identity in Russia that candidates have to sell personalities, not political platforms," said Michael McFaul, an expert on Russian politics at Stanford University. "It becomes Hollywood glitzy -- what personality can make us famous?"
Our Home Is Russia is known as the "party of power" because it is made up of Government officials, is backed by the major Russian banks and has political clout and money, but it has fared poorly in most public opinion polls.
The party has recruited Nikita Mikhalkov, the Oscar-winning actor in "Burnt by the Sun" and the movie's director, as well as Ludmila Zykina, a famous anthem singer who was the Soviet Kate Smith.
Its managers are chasing the vote of the disaffected youth in a way that would make Gary Hart blush.
"We have to use different, unusual means to wake the voters up," said Yuri Shuvalov, 30, a campaign strategist.
Besides Hammer, the campaign has hired Kool and the Gang and other American pop groups as part of its costly "cultural initiative."
Hammer said he was never told that his three concerts were part of a Russian political campaign. He had never heard of Mr. Chernomyrdin.
"What party is this?" he asked worriedly in a quiet moment backstage. "Is it a radical extremist group?" Assured that it was a centrist movement backed by President Boris N. Yeltsin, Hammer regained his poise. "If America can do business with them," he said jauntily, "Hammer can do business with them."
Hammer has done less business of late and his star has been fading since the rise of gangsta rap. His last tour was in 1991, and that one was cut short, and his latest release did not register on the Billboard chart of the country's top 200 albums.
One Russian entertainment figure who is close to the campaign said that Hammer alone was paid $150,000 per concert.
Spending limits and advertising rules were vague and only vaguely observed in Russia's 1993 elections. The Russian central election commission has issued new spending guidelines for this election year, giving each party 80 million rubles, or about $17,000, to cover election costs, and imposed an 11 billion ruble, or $2.5 million, spending limit.
But this year, as before, there are few reliable mechanisms for monitoring campaign fund-raising and spending. Parties are required to report foreign income, but need not identify Russian backers.
The central election commission is supposed to monitor campaign spending and use of broadcast time every 10 days, but inspection and enforcement rules are loose. The commission seems to be relying mainly on tattletales to spot cheaters.
"We are sure we can catch violations because every electoral bloc and movement will inform us about abuses by their rivals," said Parmen Shenshin, the commission's press secretary.
But in contrast to the 1993 campaign, when Mr. Zhirinovsky took advantage of his rivals' inexperience, flooded the airwaves with clever ads and won 22.8 percent of the vote, the Government has drawn up rules to restrict and control the use of airtime.
The state-owned television and radio stations, including ORT, Russia's largest network, which was formerly state-owned and is now partly owned by a consortium of banks sympathetic to the Government, will each give free airtime to all parties -- a maximum of one hour a month. They also will sell additional, paid, airtime to campaigns, but ORT has determined that candidates and parties can only buy three minutes of additional airtime. Candidates and their parties are free to buy airtime on Russia's private networks, but only ORT is broadcast nationwide.
If many of the candidate's paid advertisements look like flashy MTV videos, the taped appeals on free airtime that began appearing today looked more like late-night public-access television. Politicians like Yegor T. Gaidar of the democratic Russia's Choice party, and Ivan Rybkin, the Speaker of Parliament, running with his own centrist party, fumbled with their notes, fidgeted in their pockets and looked in the wrong cameras.
Though all the major parties are producing slick television advertisements that concentrate on image more than substance, Mr. Zhirinovsky still leads the pack. His first television advertisement, broadcast on the Moscow channel last week, features a sexy cabaret singer, purring a love song to him ("The world would be so boring without you/you are my idol") as she teasingly unzips her blouse. Behind her, a giant screen flickers with clips of Mr. Zhirinovsky in action, including the time he flung a glass of orange juice in the face of his opponent during a televised debate.
Despite his contempt for the West, General Lebed's advertisements also owe a lot to Madison Avenue. One shows money being placed in an outstretched hand, with a voice-over saying, "They warned bureaucrats not to take bribes." The next shot is of jail bars clanking shut, with the general's own distinctive deep voice saying, "We already warned you."
Even Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an economist and the leader of Yabloko, a democratic party, is preparing advertisements that are "substance-lite." He will not appear in them.
"People already know who he is," said a campaign strategist who declined to be identified. "We want something happy and unusual. We don't want our propaganda to be too serious; we want it to be interesting."

HEADLINE: 2 Towns, Symbols of Serbian Killings, Snag Balkan Talks

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The towns of Srebrenica and Zepa are symbols of the Serbian slaughter of Muslim civilians during the Bosnian war. Now, with the negotiations to end the conflict at a critical phase, the towns have become symbols of the price of peace.
Officials involved in the talks said today that the recovery of Srebrenica and Zepa, eastern Bosnian towns overrun by the Serbs this summer, was among the territorial demands on which the Muslim-led Bosnian Government has refused to compromise. The Serbs will not relinquish the towns because they are determined that their territory adjoining Serbia be as cohesive as possible. 
 "The Bosnians are still asking for Zepa and Srebrenica, and of course the moral reasons are clear and absolutely justifiable," said one official. "But there comes a time when you have to chose between some absolute justice and moving forward in peace."
This territorial conflict, officials said, was among those that blocked a 14-hour effort on Tuesday by Secretary of State Warren Christopher to bring the two-week-old negotiations to a conclusion. At times, the officials said, a breakthrough appeared within reach, but in the end it became clear that it was not.
"We had the sense that they were trying to rush us to a closure," said one Bosnian official. "We feel more comfortable now that some of that pressure has been removed and we have the time to work through these very important territorial issues."
Western officials said the new goal was to end the talks over the weekend. Mr. Christopher, who has gone to Japan for economic talks, is planning to return on Friday in order to be present for the end of the talks.
"We are not going to go into next week," one American official said.
But bridging the remaining gaps will not be easy. The issue of Zepa and Srebrenica, enclaves where several thousand Muslims were killed this summer, bringing the war and United States policy to a turning point, illustrates the difficulty of trying to end a war whose wounds are still raw.
It also seems to demonstrate that, for all the recent protestations and determined efforts of American officials, peace and justice are largely irreconcilable at this late stage.
Put bluntly, Bosnian control of Srebrenica and Zepa now makes no sense politically or diplomatically, because the towns would be vulnerable islands surrounded by Serbs and the likely seeds of renewed violence.
But by every standard of morality or justice, Bosnian control of the towns makes complete sense, because they were the scenes of Serbian atrocities against Muslim civilians. Many of those victims had already fled the Serbian onslaught of 1992 and were among the few survivors of the once-thriving Muslim communities in eastern Bosnian towns including Bijeljina, Zvornik, Rogatica, Vlasenica and Foca.
Those towns, now inhabited almost exclusively by Serbs, are the living symbols of what Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott this month described in unusually candid terms: "In a word -- and it is the right word -- it is genocide in our time, genocide on the continent of Europe."
Yet, after 42 months of fighting, the United States seems inclined to set aside the genocide issue in order to focus on the hard facts and thus prod the parties to make peace.
"We will not forget the past," said one Western official. "But our aim now should be the creation of a territorially coherent Muslim-Croat federation and taking it from there. Instead of focusing on guarantees for the future, the Bosnian delegation often seems to focus on symbolism."
The Bosnian official said the postion of his Government was that a map prepared in 1994 should remain the basis for negotiation until a new map is agreed on. The 1994 map, he pointed out, accorded Srebrenica and Zepa, and much land around them, to the Bosnian Government.
But that plan has been largely superseded by military changes on the ground. Victories against the Serbs by the Bosnian and Croatian armies have reduced the Serbs' share of territory from the 70 percent they held when the 1994 map was drawn up to about 48 percent. As a result, the map has quietly been discarded by American and European officials.
Those officials said that the Bosnian Government has not been asked to give up any of the land it now holds. But, they added, its claims to towns now controlled by the Serbs appear almost impossible to satisfy if peace is to be achieved.
In principle, Bosnia is to be divided between a Muslim-Croat federation with 51 percent of the territory and a Serbian republic with 49 percent, overseen by a central government.
Other territorial issues, including the status of Sarajevo and the extent of a Serbian corridor south of the town of Brcko, also remain unresolved, the officials said. But progress was made by Mr. Christopher, particularly on a compromise for Sarajevo.
"These people are so close to a deal and so unwilling to make it, it's just unbelievable," said one official. "Sarajevo could have been settled last night. But the Bosnians grew up in war, they've known nothing else, and their political survival was forged in it. They're not yet reconciled to the fact that they will have to give up claims to certain land."
Of course, those claims could still be pursued, but only through a prolonged war.
The western officials said Haris Silajdzic, the Bosnian Prime Minister, had emerged as the key figure -- or "swing vote" -- in the Bosnian delegation. A brilliant, whimsical man, with a Hamlet-like tendency to speak in riddles, Mr. Silajdzic is deeply committed to the idea of a single Bosnian state in which Muslims, Serbs and Croats live together.
He is profoundly cognizant of the "genocide" of which Mr. Talbott spoke this month and deeply reluctant to accept any compromise -- such as abandoning Zepa and Srebrenica -- that would appear to condone it. But he also knows that prolonging the war will only make the multiethnic society he wants less and less likely, while Islamic extremism is almost certain to grow.
The officials said Richard C. Holbrooke, the Assistant Secretary of State who has led diplomatic efforts to end the war since August, would now focus his efforts on securing a compromise from Mr. Silajdzic.
The theme of justice will certainly be an important one in these discussions. American officials have insisted in recent weeks that the compromises necessary for a settlement would not be accompanied by any compromise on the activities of the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.
But tension between the court's activities and Western political goals have risen in the last week as indictments were handed down to three officers of the Serbian Army and several Bosnian Croats. If followed up the chain of command, those indictments might eventually lead to the highest political authorties in Zagreb and Belgrade. Despite the indictments, the Croatian Government promoted a general on Tuesday who had been indicted on Monday for crimes against humanity.
 Washington responded today by criticizing Croatia and its President, Franjo Tudjman, for the promotion of Gen. Tihomir Blaskic.
Judge Richard Golstone, the tribunal's prosecutor, arrived today in Washington to discuss those issues and to press the Clinton Administration to hand over all relevant intelligence data to the tribunal. The State Department has promised to cooperate, but Judge Goldstone has recently complained of delays and apparent omissions.
Clearly, the court's actions will be important to American officials in trying to convince the Bosnian Government that justice will not be entirely forgotten in a settlement. But it is still unclear how convincing such arguments may prove in that only one of the more than 50 people indicted is in custody in The Hague.
Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the military leader, were indicted this summer, but have continued in their posts. Their fate is the still object of intense negotiation here.

HEADLINE: Japan Torn Between U.S. And Asians

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 15

 BODY:
As the most advanced nation in East Asia, Japan has long seen itself as a bridge between the industrialized world of the West and the developing economies of Asia. Now, as the host of this year's Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting, Japan is playing such a role and is finding itself caught in the crossfire of competing camps.
As trade and foreign ministers of the 18 member countries began meeting here tonight, one focus was whether Japan would be able to exercise the leadership needed to move the economic forum toward its goal of achieving free trade among its members by 2010 for developed nations and 2020 for developing ones. There are doubts about whether Japan is up to the task. 
 "This is a very good opportunity for Japan to show it can take initiatives which other Asia-Pacific nations can accept or welcome," said Susumu Yamakage, a professor of international relations at Tokyo University. "But the Government doesn't seem to take the initiative."
Rather than push toward free trade, Japan's critics say, it is trying to slow progress toward that goal.
Japan is trying to win flexible treatment to allow it to protect its rice farmers. Although some officials say Japan still intends to meet the 2010 deadline for opening its rice market, Tokyo's stand has drawn criticism from the United States, Australia and some other countries that say no exceptions should be allowed to the free trade goal.
At the same time, the countries that also want to protect their farmers, particularly South Korea and China, are not very happy with Japan either.
President Kim Young Sam of South Korea threatened to cancel a meeting here later this week with Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama because a Cabinet minister had said Japan "did some good" during its occupation of Korea from 1910 to 1945. The minister, Takami Eto, resigned on Monday, so the meeting between Mr. Kim and Mr. Murayama will go on.
The main task at this year's economic forum is to set out the ground rules for achieving free trade. Officials said today that members were getting closer to compromises on the remaining disputes.
"We have begun to close any gaps that existed when we arrived," a senior United States official said.
To be sure, many officials, including the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, say Japan is doing a good job in moving the agenda toward completion.
Japan's difficulty reflects the fact that there are two camps in the forum. The United States, which sees it as a means to break down trade barriers, favors the free trade deadline and wants to make the forum into an institution with some binding force. Other backers of free trade include Australia, Canada, Singapore and Hong Kong.
But many of the developing countries of East Asia, led by Malaysia and China, remain suspicious of the free trade goal. They want to keep the economic forum more of a voluntary organization.
Japan is probably more in the Asian camp. Instead of a bold free trade goal, it has been more interested in using the forum to foster economic development in Asia and improve things like customs clearance procedures.
At this year's meeting, Japan is planning to announce that it is giving 10 billion yen, or about $100 million, to the forum to help train people in the developing Asian nations about intellectual property protection, customs procedures and other areas.
The United States at first expressed concern about this program, "Partners for Progress," fearing that it was an effort to help Japan dominate the region economically. But as Japan has said the money would go only for specific projects aimed at promoting free trade, Washington now says it welcomes the program.
Japan's situation at the economic forum somewhat mirrors its foreign policy in general.
Until now, most of Japan's focus has been on the United States. But with trade tensions never seeming to abate, some Japanese Government and industry officials have urged Japan to link its future more with fast-growing Asia. Already, Japan exports more to East Asia than to the United States, and its companies have built factories and supply networks throughout the region.
Still, while Japan likes to think of itself as the leader of Asia, it is not well accepted by other Asians. Almost every month, it seems, a Japanese politician angers other Asians with an ill-considered remark defending Japan's behavior in World War II. And Asian countries, while thankful for Japanese investment and foreign aid, would like to see Japan open its market more to their products.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Trade Surplus With U.S. Shrinks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus with the United States fell 44.2 percent in October, the biggest decline in more than five years, as Japan's auto exports dropped and its imports of automobiles, office equipment and meat rose, the Japanese Finance Ministry said today.
It also said Japan's global trade surplus fell 42.4 percent in October, the biggest decline since January. 
 The declines were bigger than economists' expectations, and the dollar rose in Asian trading today.
"I think this news will gradually work to boost the dollar," said Masahiro Yamaguchi, the manager for foreign exchange at Tokai Bank.
A shrinking surplus is good news for the dollar because it leaves fewer dollars for Japanese exporters to sell for yen.
The Japanese trade surplus with the United States totaled $2.66 billion in October, compared with $4.77 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said. It was the fifth consecutive decline and the biggest since April 1990, when the surplus shrank 46.5 percent, the Finance Ministry said.
The ministry said Japan's global trade surplus fell to $5.33 billion, from $9.25 billion a year earlier. The declines exceeded economists' expectations.
The decline in the surplus was accentuated by a sharp fall in the export of seagoing ships and a surge in meat imports, said Akio Egawa, a ministry official. While coming months may remain volatile, the general trend of the trade gap is one of contraction, he said.
"Continued modest growth in the U.S. and Europe should keep the surplus falling, although growth in Asia may act as a partial brake on the decline," said Ronald Bevacqua, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company in Tokyo.
Japan's trade surplus with the European Union fell 28.2 percent last month, while the surplus with Asia rose 3.5 percent.
In October, worldwide imports to Japan jumped 17.8 percent, to $29.9 billion, compared with comparable period in 1994. Exports rose 1.7 percent, to $35.23 billion, the ministry said. But exports of autos fell 20.5 percent.
The strong yen put a damper on Japanese exports. Exports to the United States fell 8.9 percent in October, their biggest decline since April 1990.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE POLITICS;
A Murky Impasse: Data vs. Principle

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Sooner or later, President Clinton and the Republican Congress will find a way out of the entanglement that has caused much of the Government to close down. What is blocking the bill giving the Government authority to spend money temporarily is a disagreement over dollar amounts and economic projections. When differences can be boiled down to numbers, politicians can usually find ways to split the difference and save face.
But it is nearly impossible to fathom the elements of a long-term solution to the division between the President and his Republican opponents. Here, the dispute is over principle -- over what role the American Government should play in the lives of its citizens. Compromising on principles is much more difficult than compromising on numbers. 
 First, consider the immediate impasse.
The departments and agencies do not have money to spend because Congress has not approved the necessary appropriations. On Monday, the lawmakers passed a temporary spending bill. The President vetoed it because it would have also raised Medicare premiums.
Republican leaders then said they would not insist on the Medicare provision if Mr. Clinton would agree to balance the budget in seven years, using the accounting procedures of the Congressional Budget Office. Mr. Clinton did not say "no" absolutely to the number of years. In fact, at a news conference on Oct. 19, he said that producing a balanced budget within seven years was clearly possible. But he insists on using the accounting methods of his appointees at the Office of Management and Budget.
This is not a small distinction. Balancing the budget under Congress's terms would require $349 billion more in spending cuts or tax increases over seven years than it would using the Administration's methods.
Neither has juggled the books. The expert forecasters at the Congressional Budget Office and the Office of Management and Budget have made slightly different judgments about how much the economy will grow each year, what the rate of inflation will be and how much more medicine will cost. Projecting what the economy will be like seven years from now is hardly an exact science.
The Administration predicts average growth of 2.4 percent or 2.5 percent a year; Congress predicts 2.3 percent. The Administration predicts that prices will rise 3.1 percent most years; Congress figures 3.2 percent. Congress guesses that without changes in the law, Medicare costs would rise 10.3 percent a year and Medicaid 10 percent; the comparable Administration figures are 9.8 percent and 9.2 percent.
In any one year, the differences are tiny. But compounded over seven years, they become huge. By the Administration's reckoning, Mr. Clinton's budget proposals would lead to balance in 10 years. By Congress's accounting, his proposals would result in continued deficits of more than $200 billion a year.
Prudence might dictate giving more credence to the more conservative estimates of the Congressional Budget Office. This is not because its estimators are more honest or skillful but because over the years, unexpected developments in spending and revenues have worsened the deficit outlook more often than they have improved it.
For instance, neither of this year's estimates allows for a recession before 2002, an event that would make achieving a balanced budget far more difficult. The last recession ended in 1991. Since World War II, the country has never gone 11 straight years without a recession.
Still, if Congress and the President are ever going to reach an agreement on the budget, they will have to agree on the same forecasts. If Congressional leaders accept slightly more favorable projections, Mr. Clinton might find a way to adopt a program that, at least on paper, would lead to a balanced budget in seven years.
That would permit approval of a temporary spending measure. And furloughed Government employees could go back to work.
But now consider the long-term problem.
An agreement on a temporary spending bill would not solve the fundamental policy differences between the President and the Republicans. Further, the public name-calling and finger-pointing this week might have worsened the prospects of a long-term solution to the battle of the budget.
"What we've had is a premature outbreak of hostilities," said Robert D. Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office who is now a scholar at the Brookings Institution, a research group. "Both sides have locked themselves into positions, reducing their flexibility."
The real fight will come after Congress passes its big budget bill, expected by the end of this week, and the President vetoes it. The changes embraced in this legislation and in other measures the President is sure to veto this fall would be as great as any Congress has ever tried at once -- as sweeping as those at the beginning of the New Deal in 1933 or the Great Society in 1965. This is what is at stake:
Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled, would be placed on a fixed annual budget. For the first time in 30 years, retired people would not be guaranteed all the medical care they wanted, or needed. In fact, the Republicans would allow retirees to opt out of the Medicare system altogether if they wished.
There would no longer be certainty that every child and every pregnant woman would be cared for under Medicaid, which covers health bills for the poor and most of the nation's nursing home expenses, or that long-term care would be found for every aged invalid.
The 60-year-old commitment that every destitute person could go on relief and receive Federal assistance would be abandoned.
Income, capital gains and estate taxes would be reduced, benefiting wealthy investors and middle-income families with many children, but forcing much deeper cuts in Government spending than would otherwise be necessary to reach a balanced budget.
Rules governing the environment would be weakened, permitting more economic development and offering less protection to natural resources.
Federal efforts in education, employment training and technology development, which Mr. Clinton wants to expand, would instead be scaled back.
This is the core of the Republican revolution -- a smaller Federal Government, more authority for the states, more reasons for poor people to lift themselves out of poverty, fewer restraints on economic activity by individuals and businesses.
It would cut to the heart of Democratic Party principles in place for generations and undermine what is sure to be the platform of Mr. Clinton's campaign for re-election.
Both sides seem to believe they have the upper hand politically. So they are prepared to put these issues to the voters next year. That makes compromise problematic, to say the least.
"They will only compromise," said Stanley E. Collender, a Federal budget expert at Price Waterhouse, "when they think it is in their interest to do so."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE LEGISLATION;
Republicans Reveal Details Of Agreements on Tax Cuts

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress today disclosed details of tax cuts that would primarily benefit large middle-income families and investors, even as they prepared to take final action on a huge bill to balance the Federal budget in seven years.
The tax cuts, totaling $245 billion over seven years, are part of the budget bill, and they significantly increase the difficulty of balancing the budget. But the Republicans say they are irrevocably committed to both goals, cutting taxes and eliminating the deficit. 
 Over seven years, the budget bill would cut $270 billion from projected spending on Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly; $170 billion from Medicaid, the health program for the poor, and $81.5 billion from welfare programs. The bill would also impose new limits on Federal aid to college students, farmers, veterans and other beneficiaries of other Government programs.
Unveiling the tax cuts approved by Republican negotiators from the House and the Senate, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today: "We want to strengthen America's families. That's why we target the lion's share of this relief to families. Seventy-two percent of the tax reductions in this bill go to families."
The bill includes a tax credit of $500 for each child under the age of 18. The credit would be available to people with adjusted gross incomes up to $75,000 a year and couples with incomes up to $110,000, Mr. Archer said.
The credit would be retroactive to Oct. 1, 1995, so families could claim one-fourth of the credit, or $125 for each child, on their 1995 tax returns. A $125 tax credit reduces a person's tax liability by $125, and families with more children would obviously receive more benefit from this provision.
Refund checks covering the tax credit would be sent out in October 1996, just before the Presidential and Congressional elections. But Mr. Archer said, "It's not timed to fall before next year's election." Rather, he said, Republicans want to "move the cost" into the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1, 1996.
Mr. Archer said families would have to file separate forms to claim the new tax credit, because it was too late to include the change in regular tax forms. The future of the tax credit is uncertain because President Clinton has vowed, for other reasons, to veto the budget bill of which it is part.
The huge budget bill would overhaul most farm subsidy programs, particularly for grain and cotton crops. It would eliminate the current system of paying farmers not to plant some fields and paying larger subsidies when crop prices fall. Instead, farmers would receive fixed payments, though slightly smaller, regardless of prices and how much they grew.
But budget negotiators chose to make relatively few changes in the Federal programs benefiting sugar and peanut farmers, and no changes were made in the dairy program.
The dairy industry won a special exemption from budget cuts. House and Senate budget negotiators had planned $800 million in dairy subsidy cuts over the next seven years. But when New York Republicans threatened to vote against the budget if the cuts went through, the House and Senate leadership granted a special waiver to agriculture budget negotiators. The leaders told them to leave the dairy program unchanged.
Other farm subsidies will not be cut to offset the waiver. The leadership agreed to find the savings elsewhere, aides said.
Speaker Newt Gingrich said he would try again, after Thanksgiving, to change the dairy program. "Obviously it is unfair for one part of American agriculture to block reform in its programs as we are pursuing change across the rest of American agriculture," he said.
The proposed child tax credit would cost the Government $148 billion over seven years, lawmakers said. The next biggest item of tax relief is the Republican plan to cut the maximum tax on capital gains, which represent profits from the sale of stock, property and other assets. For individuals, the top rate on such income would be reduced to 19.8 percent, from the current 28 percent.
Mr. Archer said this change would "stimulate the creation of new high-paying jobs" and benefit nine million taxpayers, of whom six million have incomes less than $100,000 a year.
The conferees accepted a House proposal to change the computation of capital gains so that investors would not be taxed on the portion of such gains attributable to inflation. But the bill delays this change to the year 2001.
Congressional tax experts said the reductions in capital gains taxes, taken together, would cost the Government $36 billion over seven years.
Mr. Archer and other Republicans said the tax bill also included these provisions:
Two million more people would become eligible for individual retirement accounts. In addition, a new type of I.R.A. would be created. Contributions to such accounts would not be deductible, but people could make tax-free withdrawals from them to help pay the costs of college education or long-term care, retirement expenses or the first-time purchase of a home.
Those who have sold their homes at a loss would, for the first time, be able to deduct up to $3,000 a year as a "capital loss."
Families adopting children could obtain tax credits of $5,000 for each child to help offset adoption expenses.
Taxpayers who incur expenses in caring for ill parents at home could take a deduction of $1,000 for each such parent. There would also be new tax breaks for people buying insurance to cover the cost of nursing home care. Insurance companies and nursing homes have long advocated such tax breaks.
Self-employed people would eventually be allowed to take tax deductions for half of the cost of health insurance. Corporations can deduct the full cost of such health benefits for their employees.
In addition, the bill would reduce the "alternative minimum tax" paid by some companies, especially manufacturers, that would otherwise have enough tax breaks to wipe out their tax liabilities.
Referring to this change, Mr. Archer said: "Companies that depreciate tools and technology needed to create more jobs will not be penalized at the end of the year by paying a punitive penalty tax on the purchase of that equipment and the depreciation. This will go a long way toward making us more competitive in the international marketplace."
House and Senate negotiators accepted a proposal in the House bill that would allow some companies to withdraw surplus money from their pension funds to help pay other costs. But the bill sets more stringent standards than the House proposed for such withdrawals, and the money could be used only for health care and other employee benefits.
Mr. Archer said the tax bill would end a tax credit now available to developers of housing for low-income families. It would also end the earned-income tax credit for low-income workers who have no children, he said.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
TREASURY TAKES RETIREMENT FUNDS TO AVERT DEFAULT

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Treasury Department averted a national default on Wednesday by tapping two civil service retirement funds to cover interest payments on the Federal debt.
But Congress and the Clinton Administration made no progress in resolving their basic disputes over spending levels and priorities that kept the Government partly shut for a second day. 
 Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said he had resorted to "extraordinary" actions, more sweeping than any required of his predecessors, in taking $61.3 billion from the retirement funds and replacing them with i.o.u.'s that do not count against the national debt limit of $4.9 trillion. He took enough to pay $25 billion in interest due on Wednesday and to meet bills coming due in the next few weeks.
"Based on current projections," he said, "those amounts enable operations to go forward through late December." But he added, "This is no way for a great nation to manage its financial affairs."
Because of the impasse with Congress, President Clinton on Wednesday canceled his weekend trip to the Asian economic conference in Osaka, Japan. Vice President Al Gore will go instead. White House officials said Mr. Clinton decided he simply could not afford to be out of the country at such a delicate moment, but the cancellation is sure to worsen what has already been a badly strained year in Japanese-American relations. [Page A7.]
Republicans and Democrats each accused the other of manufacturing a crisis through intransigence and political opportunism, but no end was in sight. And on the second business day of the partial shutdown -- longer than any in the past -- Mr. Rubin said he had to take very broad steps to protect the nation's credit.
Mr. Rubin urged Congress to pass new legislation to raise the debt limit and to drop the provisions that led the President to veto a debt bill on Monday night. They included regulatory changes and a prohibition on the sort of actions that Mr. Rubin took on Wednesday to keep the Government afloat.
Congress was not focusing on the debt, but on ways to ameliorate the practical and political effects of the spending halts that have closed some Government offices and kept 800,000 Federal workers home.
The House passed a new stopgap spending bill shortly after midnight today, but included terms that Mr. Clinton said would require him to veto it. Speaker Newt Gingrich had told reporters this morning that the shutdown "could easily last 90 days."
Mr. Clinton, asked about that time estimate in an interview on the CBS Evening News, said he would not give in to the Republicans' "huge cuts in Medicare, Medicaid, education, the environment." He added, "I'm not going to do it, even if it's 90 days, 120 days or 180 days."
"If we take it right into the next election, let the American people decide," he continued. "If the American people want the budget they have proposed to be the law of the land, they're entitled to another President, and that's the only way they are going to get it."
On Capitol Hill, Republicans, stung by criticism from Mr. Clinton and Congressional Democrats that they had fallen far behind schedule on passing the regular spending bills, started pushing those bills along.
The House and the Senate passed a measure financing the Departments of State and Treasury after deleting a provision barring "political advocacy" by recipients of Federal grants, an issue that had stalled the bill for 10 weeks. The $23.2 billion measure, once it is signed by the President, will put 190,000 employees back to work.
The Republicans also met to try to break a deadlock over abortion that is holding up the military spending bill, and they sent Mr. Clinton a $13.1 billion bill for the Transportation Department that they passed two weeks ago but held at the Capitol to avoid the publicity of a possible veto. Mr. Clinton signed the bill, and now 4 of the 13 regular appropriations bills have been signed into law, while another has been vetoed.
Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland said, "Federal workers are at home for just one reason: we haven't gotten our work done."
The White House-Congress impasse also intruded on the Republican Presidential race. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader who is the front-runner in the race, is considering whether to put off a planned weekend trip to Florida, where the Republicans are holding a straw poll for the Presidential primary. The Florida straw poll is considered by many to be the most important event in the campaign for the rest of 1995.
At a breakfast on Wednesday, Mr. Gingrich told reporters that Congress might start to pass narrow spending bills to reopen Government services that the public needed, such as passport and veterans offices and offices for making Social Security and Medicare applications.
"We'll start finding those parts of the Government that the country misses and reopen them," he said. "Those that the country doesn't miss, we probably won't open."
But that plan was quickly dismissed by Congressional Democrats and the White House. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, called it "only the latest in a series of silly ideas emanating from the Speaker's office."
The new Republican stopgap spending plan drew scorn from the President. The Republican bill was very similar to the one he vetoed on Monday morning. But the new version, while retaining cuts of up to 40 percent in some programs, omits a section increasing the Medicare Part B premium, covering insurance for doctor and laboratory bills. Democrats attacked that provision loud and long.
But the Republicans insisted on retaining a provision committing Mr. Clinton to a seven-year balanced budget as calculated by the Congressional Budget Office. The President's veto insisted that such calculations would force him to accept Republican priorities, and he told CBS News on Wednesday that he still found that approach "highly objectionable."
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said: "We will talk to the President about how to balance the budget in seven years. We will not talk to the President about whether to balance the budget in seven years."
Mr. Gingrich, at a news conference, said, "The President, having yesterday said 16 times in five minutes that he was for a balanced budget, ought to now, frankly, sign on in getting to a balanced budget."
The House passed the bill, 277 to 151, but the total for the bill was 12 votes shy of the number needed to override a veto. Forty-eight Democrats joined 229 Republicans in voting for the bill. Voting no were 3 Republicans, 147 Democrats and 1 independent. The Senate will consider it later today.
The Speaker made another promise on Wednesday that the House failed to carry out. He told reporters that it would pass the $12.1 billion bill for the Interior Department and other agencies so national parks and museums could reopen. But Republican defections caused the House to reject the bill on Wednesday night, for a second time, because of provisions favoring mining and logging on public lands.
The bill was sent back to House-Senate conferees on a 230-to-199 vote as 48 Republicans joined 181 Democrats and 1 independent in opposing it. Fifteen Democrats joined 184 Republicans in backing the bill.
Passage would have been no more than a political gesture anyway. The President has vowed to veto it because of its cuts in programs for American Indians, the arts and endangered species.
At the White House, Michael D. McCurry, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, described the impact of the partial closure this way:
"There were 28,000 people who would have made applications for Social Security benefits that didn't. There were 1,613 people, on an average day, who would make claims for compensation and pension benefits. And they didn't get served yesterday."
He said 726,000 people would have visited national parks, 55,000 tourists would have visited the Washington Monument or museums here, 22,000 people would have got passports and 700 people would have joined the armed services.
"So, did we make it through the day?" he said. "Yeah, we made it through the day, but that's a lousy way to do business."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE VOTERS
The Sharp Fault Line That Separates Clinton's and the G.O.P.'s Supporters;
In Michigan, Some G.O.P. Allies Are Soured by Tactics

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., Nov. 15

 BODY:
His friends had predicted that their fourth for coffee and cigarettes this morning would show his stripes as a "liberal pinko commie," and when Neil Dempsey slid into the booth at Mount Clemens Coney Island restaurant, he did not disappoint them.
"I support the President," Mr. Dempsey said, ignoring their smoky guffaws to take his stand on the impasse in Washington. But as he detailed his objections to the Republicans' tactics and his fears of higher Medicare and other health care costs, his friends just kept grinning. 
 "You ought to put a commission together," chortled Ken Flynn, from across the table. "Maybe put Hillary in charge of it."
While Mr. Dempsey got little empathy from his old friends, interviews here in the capital of right-leaning, blue-collar Macomb County, just northeast of Detroit, suggest that he is far from alone. Among these people, President Clinton's position on Medicare appears to be attracting sympathy his way.
Voters here are viewed by pollsters and pundits as archetypal "Reagan Democrats," but no Democratic Presidential candidate has carried this overwhelmingly white county since Hubert H. Humphrey did in 1968. Still, voters retain an independent streak. Mount Clemens is also the home of Representative David E. Bonior, the House minority whip, who is Speaker Newt Gingrich's chief antagonist in the House.
And polling here last month showed that most voters in Mr. Bonior's district, which includes most of Macomb and all of smaller St. Clair County, are unhappy with the Republican-controlled Congress.
"I'm not a Clinton fan at all, but I have to support him on this one," said Bill Visnaw, the owner of Bill Visnaw's Styling Barbershop, who voted for Ross Perot in 1992 and approves of the Republicans' Contract With America. He said he thought Medicare needed fixing, but not during a budget fight.
"To use the budget, the expiration of it, as a lever -- this is supposed to be something that is sat down and thought out and discussed and compromised on," Mr. Visnaw said. "Gingrich seems to be on the rampage, flexing a little too much power."
Views here of the standoff in Washington seemed to turn less on whom voters support than on whom they blame less. Some seemed chagrined to discover that they saw Mr. Clinton as the lesser malefactor.
"I never liked him -- I can't stand him -- but right now I'd vote for him over what's running," said one woman, who added that she worried about Medicare as she neared retirement from a job with the county. She declined to give her name. "Not the way I talked about Clinton," she said.
The one universal sentiment was frustration over the impasse, widely seen not as a clash of principles but as a means to score political points.
"The way we look around the world, we look like a bunch of little boys in the sandbox," said Mr. Flynn, one of the group in the restaurant who were chiding Mr. Dempsey.
Mr. Flynn, who runs a real estate agency, added, "The only thing Republicans and Democrats agree on in this thing is that 60 percent of the Medicare cost is fraud." But Mr. Dempsey, a banker, glimpsed a chance to get a little of his own back and demurred. He said he could not imagine that "Republican doctors" were overcharging. "I just can't," he said.
Behind the cash register, Nick Raptis, 66, said he was willing to pay a little more for his Medicare benefits, even though he already worked part time to get by. "I think Clinton should give in on some things," he said. "I don't mind paying more for Medicare, if it will help them."
Because the local economy is underpinned by parts plants supplying the healthy automobile industry, Macomb County is booming, with an unemployment rate of only 4 percent. Voters here rate crime and drugs as their top concerns.
But in an opinion poll last month for The Detroit News, far more voters said they worried most about "health care reform, including Medicare and Medicaid," than said they worried most about Federal taxes, the deficit, or the economy.
Only 40 percent gave the Republican-controlled Congress a positive rating. "I think that has to be the Medicare issue," said Bernie Porn, president of EPIC/MRA, which conducted the poll. Similarly, he said, a statewide poll by the firm last month showed Mr. Clinton taking a lead of 50 percent to 38 percent over the Republican front-runner, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, because of elderly voters, Mr. Porn said.
Mr. Bonior has been highlighting Medicare here. "We've been harping on that issue for like six or seven months, and it's now coming to a head," said Leo R. Lalonde, chairman of the Macomb County Democratic Committee.
But Susy Heintz, the leader of the state Republican Party, waved off the apparent success. "It's a nice scare technique to use on the public, and in a way it's worked well," she said. "But I don't think in the long term it's good for the country or that it will work."
She said similar tactics had driven down the approval ratings of Michigan's Governor, John Engler. But Mr. Engler, a Republican, stuck to plans to cut back Michigan's welfare system, and his ratings have rebounded to above 60 percent -- including in Mr. Bonior's district.

"I'm not a Clinton fan at all, but I have to support him on this one," he said. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Hong Kong's Future

BYLINE: By Philip Taubman 

DATELINE: Hong Kong

 BODY:
Hong Kong residents like to talk about their insurance policies, but not the types that cover cars, homes or health. In Hong Kong, insurance means protection against China. The most popular policy is a foreign passport.
The transfer of Hong Kong from Britain to China on July 1, 1997, promises to be a great test of China's maturity as a world power. If China takes possession of Hong Kong while letting the city retain its entrepreneurial spirit, fair judiciary, free press and incipient democracy, Beijing will reassure a world wary of its Communist leaders. If China erases the rule of law in Hong Kong and strangles civil liberties, the city's commercial energy may not survive and China's place among nations will be compromised. 
 Even a brief visit here makes clear that China has everything to gain by leaving Hong Kong intact. Half of China's exports are shipped through Hong Kong, and two-thirds of foreign direct investments in China already pass through Hong Kong businesses and financial institutions. Most Hong Kong manufacturing companies have moved their factories to southern China in recent years, transferring jobs and wealth as they went. The Hong Kong stock market promises to be a primary source of capital for new and growing Chinese companies. As Chinese commercial centers like Shanghai struggle to achieve world-class rank, Hong Kong is there right now, alongside New York, London and Tokyo.
Business leaders like Victor Fung, chairman of the Hong Kong Trade Development Council, have great faith in the strength and durability of the city's capitalist character. The traders, bankers, brokers and builders of Hong Kong cannot imagine why China would want to spoil such a powerful engine of economic growth. In economic terms they are right, but they may underestimate the political hazards ahead.
The British implanted a free press and judiciary in Hong Kong. After a century and a half of imperial rule Britain has belatedly introduced a touch of democratic governance in recent years under the leadership of Chris Patten, London's 28th and last Governor of Hong Kong.
While Mr. Patten has not turned Hong Kong into a democracy, he has uncorked a desire for greater self-determination among its citizens, and made it possible for progressive local political leaders like Martin Lee, the chairman of the Hong Kong Democratic Party, to step forward as 1997 nears.
The danger is that China, skittish about political dissent and democratic process, will roughly toss aside Mr. Lee and others like him and enforce strict ideological conformity in Hong Kong. That could quickly chill relations between Beijing and Washington, where many in Congress are spoiling for a fight with China, and shake foreign investors' confidence in Hong Kong. From there, it would not take much to panic the Hong Kong real estate market, and with it the city's wealth.
Resentment about Hong Kong runs strong in China, and the Chinese Government has made clear it has no intention of preserving Mr. Patten's innovations, including an increase in directly elected seats in a local legislative body that has given citizens some say in city governance. Chinese officials say dissent will be tolerated in Hong Kong, provided it is not part of an effort to undermine the Government in Beijing. That sounds like a formula easily interpreted to stifle free expression.
Hong Kong is an economic phenomenon, one that a practical and increasingly commercial China can appreciate and preserve. But Hong Kong is also six million people who have lived in a more open and tolerant society than the one they will join in 1997.
Under terms of the transfer, China agreed to give Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy for 50 years, except in matters of foreign affairs and defense. "One country, two systems" was the way the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping described the plan when Britain and China reached agreement in 1984. It will be a sad day for Hong Kong and a senseless loss for China if Beijing fails to honor Mr. Deng's word. PHILIP TAUBMAN

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Bad Budget Bill Gets Worse

 BODY:
The face-off between President Clinton and the Republicans over the debt-ceiling and temporary spending bills is a sideshow compared with the negotiations over the permanent budget going on among Republican leaders of the House and Senate. They are hammering out a reconciliation measure -- a mammoth package of cuts in entitlements, like Medicare and Medicaid, and skewed tax cuts that would bring the budget into balance over seven years. Judging from news leaks, they have seized some of the worst parts of the separate bills passed by the two houses.
Whatever bill the G.O.P. sends to the White House for the President's signature this week or next will be vetoed. Both sides want to look tough before their constituents. But the provisions of the initial bill will set the boundaries for further negotiations with the Administration. That is why decisions that the Republican leaders have made this week on taxes, Medicare, Medicaid, welfare and agriculture are disheartening. 
 Taxes. The leaders have, as expected, embraced the unaffordable $245 billion cut passed by the House and Senate. Then they took an unnecessary cut in the tax on capital gains and made it substantially worse. They applied the tax break to old investments, which is nothing more than a wasteful giveaway to wealthy investors. They have also reportedly decided to index the capital gains tax for inflation, starting in 2001. That would open an enormous loophole: Investors would be allowed to correct the amount of income they report for inflation, but would not be required to correct their reported deductions for the cost of their investments. Finally, the leaders have settled on huge cuts in tax credits for working poor families, effectively raising their taxes.
Medicaid. The House would abolish Federal guarantees of health insurance for the poor. The Senate would guarantee coverage for pregnant women, poor children and the disabled. The conferees apparently will drop the disabled. Exactly what health benefits, if any, the women and children would be entitled to receive is unclear.
Medicare. Besides approving recklessly large cuts, the conferees are likely to adopt rules that would allow doctors who are not in business with each other to discuss what prices they charge and what services they will insist patients buy under an unusually loose set of antitrust rules. That is good for the doctors, and bad for everyone else.
Agriculture. To their credit, the Republicans may propose dismantling key components of the welfare system -- price supports, import limits and production quotas -- that has kept farm income elevated. But the powerful dairy industry will get off without a nick, retaining the bizarre system that keeps milk prices high, especially in the Northeast. The conferees apparently plan to cut school lunches for needy children so they can maintain subsidies to farmers of up to $250,000 per person in each farm household.
Welfare. Conferees have reportedly settled on huge cuts in food stamps and removed them as a safety net for the long-term unemployed. They plan to cut most aid to legal immigrants and propose changes to throw more than 300,000 poor children out of the Federal program for the disabled.
The conferees appear headed toward a viciously unbalanced budget. According to Administration estimates, the House G.O.P. budget will take about $900 worth of benefits, on average, from families earning less than $30,000, but only $155 from families earning above $100,000. At the same time it will cut taxes by virtually nothing on the low-income families, but cut them by about $1,600 for high-income families.
The existing entitlement programs and taxes will remain in place until Congress passes a bill that the President signs. If the Republicans insist on extreme measures, Mr. Clinton should veto that bill until the day he stands for re-election.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Reflections on Luck and Lucking Out

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

LUCK: The Brilliant Randomness of Everyday Life
By Nicholas Rescher
237 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.
 
THE LUCK BUSINESS: The Devastating Consequences and Broken Promises of America's Gambling Explosion
By Robert Goodman
273 pages. Marvin Kessler Books/The Free Press. $23.
Such is the attraction of luck in our lives that a book called "Luck: The Brilliant Randomness of Everyday Life" sounds appealing from its title alone. Yet Nicholas Rescher, a philosophy professor at the University of Pittsburgh, reminds us here that much more is needed for a good book than luck. 
 With his wordily prosaic style and his meandering organization, he unluckily succeeds in making the subject of luck dull. Or is it that luck matters so much that little about it remains to be explored? Certainly we already know, as Mr. Rescher reminds us, that "success or failure in situations of competition and conflict often hinges on matters of fortuitous happenstance." Or that "there is enormous scope for luck in warfare."
Eventually, Mr. Rescher does wend his way to the slightly less obvious conclusion that life without luck would be unbearable for humans. "Our psychological and emotional condition is such that we would not want to live in a preprogrammed world, a world where the rest of our fate and future is preordained and indeed prediscernible in the realities of the present," he writes. "Even at the price of falling victim to chance and haphazard, we yearn for novelty and innovation, for a liberation from an inevitability programmed by the settled determination of the past."
Yet such is the power of his prose to snuff out the promise of surprise that one finds it a struggle to remain awake long enough to arrive at this conclusion.
Further pitfalls of luck become evident in Robert Goodman's new book, "The Luck Business: The Devastating Consequences and Broken Promises of America's Gambling Explosion." Mr. Goodman, who teaches environmental design and planning at Hampshire College, was director of the United States Gambling Study, and the results of that survey of legalized gambling as a strategy for economic development inform his well-reasoned book.
What he learned is that a decade or so ago Las Vegas's success as a gambling enterprise began to inspire other locales to copy it as a way of reviving economically depressed communities. As a result, between 1988 and 1994 the number of states authorizing casinos to operate rose to 23 from 2, and the total yearly casino revenues went to $15 billion from $8 billion.
But what the new gambling locales failed to allow for, he reasons, was that Las Vegas attracted tourists from out of state and that the enterprises their money nourished did not compete with an existing developed economy. Moreover, he adds, "those tourists who either had or would develop pathological gambling problems took their problems -- such as losing their jobs, getting involved in criminal activities to pay off debts and a host of other costly consequences -- back home with them."
By contrast, Mr. Goodman writes, gamblers who go to Atlantic City, for example, tend to be "day trippers" from other parts of the state, so that "instead of providing a jump start for local economic development," the Atlantic City casinos actually drain resources from enterprises that already exist. Moreover, Mr. Goodman concludes, because these gamblers live in the state, New Jersey has to bear the costs of problem gambling generated by the casinos.
These drawbacks are obvious, he says, but the lesson has failed to sink in. More and more American communities have turned to legalized gambling as a superficial solution for shrinking revenues from a dying industrial base. As Indian communities (like the Mashantucket Pequot tribe in Ledyard, Conn.) have won the right to run high-stakes gambling establishments (like the hugely successful Foxwoods Casino), neighboring locales have competed to protect themselves.
Yet never does the impulse for legalized gambling come from any grass-roots popular movement, Mr. Goodman found. The pressure always comes from above, from the highly organized gambling industry. And once communities succumb, they must begin to behave like bad poker players chasing their losses. "They legalize new games or they get rid of restrictions and betting limits on their old ones," the author writes. "As the chasing process progresses, more hard-core forms of gambling are rapidly legalized in a copycat race by state after state. As each state's gambling menu expands, its gambling policy begins to spin out of control, and governments and state residents soon find themselves with gambling enterprises they never imagined when their process of legalization first began."
Near the end of his compelling study, Mr. Goodman steps back and reasons that the lust for legalized gambling has risen as the prospects of succeeding through hard work have declined in this country. And deplorably enough, in his view, governments, instead of discouraging speculation, are now promoting the fantasy of getting rich on a bet, as witness New York State's advertising slogan: "All you need is a dollar and a dream."
Since he is not opposed to gambling in all forms, Mr. Goodman proposes a lottery in which some of the income is lent to local businesses. Such linking of legalized gambling to a form of industrial policy sounds appealing if only because something would be created, in contrast to present forms of legalized gambling, where, in the author's view, nothing is created and money is taken from the poor.
Further, such a lottery as he proposes would put luck in the proper place that Branch Rickey, the late baseball executive, once assigned it when he made his shrewd observation that luck at its best is "the residue of design." Which comment, when you stop to think about it, pretty well sums up the wisest things that both these books have to say on the subject of luck.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Soars to 4,969.36, Its 58th Record This Year
The stock market barreled ahead, once again, extending record closings of the Dow Jones industrial average to 58 so far this year, just one shy of the 20th century record of 59 set in 1925 and 1964.
The Dow soared 46.61 points to close at 4,969.36. The S.&P. 500 and Nasdaq composite indexes also gained ahead of today's double witching. Airline and banking stocks rose, while technology shares lagged. [Page D6.]
 
The bond market also strengthened as the yield on the long bond fell to 6.22 percent, nearly a two-year low. [D16.]
 
Russia Will Repay $32.5 Billion
Russia agreed to repay $32.5 billion in loans taken out by the former Soviet republics. By signing a rescheduling agreement in Frankfurt with 600 creditor banks, Moscow ended its financial isolation and virtually guaranteed it would be able to borrow on world capital markets. [D6.]
 
Upheaval at MCA Music Unit
The chairman of MCA Inc.'s music division, Al Teller, quit suddenly and was replaced by Doug Morris, who was dismissed a few months ago as head of Time Warner's music division. The upheaval came after months of building of MCA by its new owner, Seagram. [D5.]
 
Republicans Complete Budget Bill
Republicans completed their plan to erase the Federal budget deficit by 2002, while overhauling scores of social programs. Both houses approved a new Republican-sponsored temporary spending bill to finance Government agencies and bring all Federal employees back to work. But the measure competed for attention with the continued dueling between G.O.P. leaders and President Clinton, who has vowed to veto the bill. [A1.]
 
Pacific Free Trade Zone Planned
A pan-Pacific free-trade zone spanning countries with more than two billion people and over half the world's economic output would be created under voluntary guidelines agreed to by 18 Asia-Pacific nations. [A9.]
 
Physicians' Earnings Slide
Doctors' incomes are falling as managed care organizations tighten their grip on the nation's health-care system. The American Medical Association said the median earnings of all physicians dropped 3.8 percent last year to $150,000, from $156,000 in 1993. [A1.]
 
Medical school slots should be slashed by 20 to 25 percent over the next 10 years, a study by the Pew Health Professions Commission recommended, contending that a surplus of doctors was driving up medical costs. [D2.]
 
Behind CBS's '60 Minutes' Decision
CBS canceled a "60 Minutes" interview with a tobacco company executive last weekend because of fear of being sued under a legal theory called tortious interference with contracts, legal experts said. [B14.]
 
Media analysts' warnings that aggressive news coverage is in jeopardy were recalled by the image of CBS lawyers overpowering "60 Minutes" and Mike Wallace. [B14.]
 
More Utilities Flock to Australia
More American utilities are ready to make major investments in Australia. Pacificorp of Oregon agreed to buy Powercor for $1.6 billion, and Entergy of New Orleans is said to be set to buy Citipower for about $1.16 billion. [D18.]
 
Denver Officials Criticize Levitt
Denver officials accused Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the S.E.C., of being "prejudiced and biased," and argued he should be barred from considering a pending enforcement action concerning the sale of Denver International Airport bonds. [D15.]
 
Nuclear Tests Cut Beaujolais Sales
The ballyhoo over Beaujolais nouveau was upstaged this year in many places, including Japan, the Netherlands and Scandinavia, by boycotts to protest French nuclear tests in the Pacific, dealers said. [A10.]

HEADLINE: Medical Schools Are Urged To Cut Admissions by 20%

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN 

 BODY:
In a move that would radically change the system of training doctors in this country, a panel of national health care experts called yesterday for slashing the number of medical school slots by 20 to 25 percent over the next 10 years, asserting that there is an oversupply of doctors that contributes to the inefficiency of medical care.
The recommendation by the Pew Health Professions Commission comes with an added sting -- the proposal that these cuts be achieved by closing entire schools and training programs, an echo of the closing of military bases. Any such closings are sure to face opposition in communities that are economically dependent on medical schools. 
 The 21-member commission also recommended trimming the physician surfeit by significantly scaling back doctor training programs, better known as residency programs, primarily by cutting the number of positions open to graduates of foreign medical schools.
The report by the Pew Commission comes as Congress has voted far-reaching cuts in public subsidizing of graduate medical education through the Medicare program and as health care experts are lamenting the poor distribution of doctors that leaves some areas with a glut and others in dire need.
The recommendations also run counter to a surge in applications to medical schools. Last year, 45,365 people applied for the roughly 16,000 slots in American medical schools, a record number of applicants and more than double what it was eight years ago.
Experts say that the current ratio of doctors to patients nationwide is about 250 per 100,000, well above the 150 to 100,000 ratio that many consider optimum. If the medical education system keeps growing at its current pace, experts say the ratio will reach 290 for every 100,000 people over the next decade, causing inefficiency and inflated costs.
"We've added 150,000 doctors over the last decade, and areas with a shortage of doctors have increased from 2,110 to 2,271," said Richard D. Lamm, the former Governor of Colorado, who is chairman of the commission. "The fact is there is an oversupply of doctors and oversupply of our educational training that has to be set right to respond to the changing health system. Anybody who tries to keep unnecessary military bases, or unnecessary hospitals or medical schools, is asking for inefficiency and trouble."
The commission -- which includes former government officials, medical educators, public health professionals and insurance company executives -- was started five years ago by the Pew Charitable Trusts to research health care issues and to make policy recommendations. Other members include William Gradison, president of the Health Insurance Association of America; Pamela J. Maraldo, past president of Planned Parenthood Federation of America, and Dr. John P. Howe 3d, president of the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio.
Although the panel has no power of enforcement, experts say that its recommendations are likely to be taken seriously.
Medical school administrators and doctors said that adopting the panel's recommendations would cause a maelstrom in the world of medical academia. The proposals were embraced by some as painful but necessary and criticized by others as drastic and destabilizing.
"Are the Pew Commission's recommendations necessary? Yes," said Dr. Jane Henney, vice president for health sciences at the University of New Mexico. "Will they be easy to put in motion? No. But should that be done? Yes."
Dr. Ralph Snyderman, dean of the medical school at Duke University, said that what the commission accurately recognized was that "the upheaval in health care delivery must reach into the academic world."
Duke has already decided to cut its residency program, which now trains 495 doctors annually, by 30 percent over the next four years in response to marketplace shifts and an expected drop in Medicare training subsidies.
Dr. Snyderman said that while he might quibble with some of the numbers the panel proposed, the report was "an important document that will focus attention on a subject that many are reluctant to face."
But Dr. Jordan J. Cohen, president of the Association of American Medical Colleges, called the Pew report "a misguided policy and an affront to reason."
He agreed that it was necessary to reduce the number of residency posts for foreign medical school graduates. At the end of last year, there were 23,499 international medical graduates training in the United States, double the number of five years ago.
"But there is no factual basis to justify this drastic level of cutbacks in American medical school slots," he said. "It would dismantle a system that has done nothing but respond to the needs of the American people."
The panel also called for raising the number of primary care practitioners in the country, with the goal of achieving an even balance of specialists and generalists. Graduating medical school students are already pushing the balance in that direction.
Recognizing the devastating impact that these recommendations would have on inner-city and public hospitals -- since they depend on residents, primarily graduates of foreign medical schools, to deliver much of the front-line care to their impoverished patients -- the panel also proposed expanding the National Health Service Corps, a federally financed program that sends health professionals to underserved areas.
