HEADLINE: Doctors' Incomes Fall as Managed Care Grows

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
For the first time in the 14 years that the American Medical Association has been keeping track, doctors' incomes are falling as managed care organizations tighten their grip on the nation's health care system.
The median earnings of all physicians, from front-line general practitioners to highly paid specialists like brain surgeons, dropped 3.8 percent last year to $150,000, from $156,000 in 1993, according to preliminary results from the A.M.A.'s latest annual survey. The median income -- the point at which half of all doctors make more and half make less -- had risen 2 percent in 1993 and had surged 7.9 percent in 1992. 
 And with managed health care spreading, some say the outlook for physicians could become even grimmer. Edward O'Neil, executive director of the Center for the Health Professions at the University of California at San Francisco, said managed care companies in the state were projecting charges 20 to 30 percent below current levels over the next three to five years.
"It's not just California," he said. "In places like Georgia, the Pacific Northwest and Minnesota, they are saying that to be competitive, we've got to go with this 20 to 30 percent range of reductions."
The pressure on pay comes mostly from outside the profession: employers are demanding lower insurance premiums, and insurers are leaning on health care providers to cut costs.
But another factor is at work from within: an explosion in America's doctor population over the last 30 years. The number of physicians has soared to 660,582 today, or 252 for each 100,000 Americans -- not counting Federal Government doctors -- compared with 266,045, or 139 for each 100,000, in 1965.
Thrown on the defensive, many doctors are fighting back by joining medical groups, by selling their practices to hospitals and investor-owned management companies or by organizing their own health maintenance organizations. Others are retreating to backwaters that desperately need them, or even dropping out of the job market.
Still others struggle along, often at surprisingly low compensation levels. Although few tears are likely to flow for the millionaire California specialist who recently retired to Mexico rather than absorb a 50 percent drop to $500,000 a year, many people are likely to feel sympathy for doctors like Andrea Leeds, a Bellmore, L.I., pediatrician.
Dr. Leeds, a daughter and sister of doctors, said she could double her income, to $71,000, by returning to school teaching, which she gave up for "a calling rather than a career" that includes treating children in emergencies at 2 A.M.
Under the latest insurance company payment schedules, she said, "I won't be able to maintain the level of care I am giving, just to make the overhead costs" in the home office that took all her savings to build and furnish.
One company is offering a low $7 a month, or $84 a year, for each child enrolled aged 2 or older. "What am I supposed to do if the child comes in to see me four times?" Dr. Leeds asked. "I am a board-certified pediatrician with top credentials, but I am still viewed as surplus by the insurance companies. They say they have enough physicians."
Many doctors say the insurers push them to deny care to sick patients, but advocates for managed care say that on the contrary, it enhances the quality of care by promoting preventive medicine, tracking successful treatments and eliminating tests and procedures deemed unnecessary.
Health maintenance organizations in many parts of the country say they are still assuring handsome incomes to primary care physicians like Dr. Leeds. But in markets dominated by the H.M.O.'s, like San Diego, the payers have stomped on the revenues of both primary and specialty doctors.
Companies that were paying H.M.O. premiums of $120 a month for each employee two years ago are paying $105 now, and some are down to the low $90's, said Dr. Donald C. Balfour 3d, president of Sharp-Rees-Stealy, a big San Diego medical group with 285 physicians, including 114 in primary care.
The health-maintenance organizations passed along most of the cuts to hospitals and doctors. Dr. Balfour said the revenues of his group had gone "downhill" for two years and were expected to fall by 5 to 10 percent in 1996. When revenues fell short for the year that ended on Sept. 30, the Sharp-Rees physicians swallowed an 8 percent pay cut.
Still, primary care physicians in big San Diego medical groups earn $150,000 a year, well above the national average for that group, and specialists earn even more. Dr. Balfour conceded that there was "not a lot of sympathy" for people making that much money, but, he said, "our physicians obviously work very hard to achieve that."
Deeply concerned about rising health costs, employers have increasingly embraced managed care restraints that essentially reduce the doctors' former freedom to call the shots in ordering tests and treatments for patients. Now the employers are forcing the H.M.O.'s to lower prices.
"Everyone is going to get less money except the C.E.O. of the health plan," said Dr. James Hay, a family practitioner who heads a group of 80 doctors, North County Physicians Medical Group, in Encinitas in San Diego County.
"California and a few other places like Minnesota led the country in managed care," Dr. Hay added, "but it's coming much faster everywhere else. Now the health plans can establish managed care very quickly, in a year or two."
Rob Levy, a consultant in Atlanta with the Foster Higgins benefits consulting firm, said, "We're seeing prices fall in almost every market for both managed care premiums and compensation to physicians."
In Baltimore, for example, which is rapidly moving to managed care, primary care doctors who do not have partners "are coming to us, concerned that their incomes are going down," said Scott Rifkin, an internist who is chairman of the Doctors Health System, a doctor-owned company that manages physician practices.
Primary care doctors -- mainly family physicians, internists and pediatricians -- who got more than half of their gross income from managed care patients lost 15 percent of their income this year, according to a recent survey of 89 big physician groups, H.M.O.'s, hospitals and health care systems. The survey was conducted by Ernst & Young, the benefits-consulting and accounting firm.
Experts take such studies with a grain of salt. Even James A. Rodeghero, the Ernst & Young consultant who directed the study, warned that the decline could reflect "a statistical blip." Although it covered 10,520 doctors, the study was not rigorously designed to reflect the entire profession.
Even so, other surveys reported a similar trend. For example, a study by the Hay Group, also a consulting firm, of big medical organizations that include 25,000 doctors showed pediatricians' incomes down 1.5 percent this year from 1994, and internists down 1.3 percent. But earnings of family-practice doctors rose 1 percent.
Doctors' pay slipped last year even as American households enjoyed a slight increase in income, of seven-tenths of a percent, albeit from a much lower base, to a median $32,264, from $32,041 in 1993, according to the Census Bureau. The A.M.A. said its preliminary results also showed that the average incomes of physicians fell last year, also by about 4 percent.
Mr. Levy said many primary care doctors were defending their incomes by joining medical groups, negotiating multiyear salary arrangements and selling their practices to hospitals and physician management companies like Phycor Inc., Caremark International and Medpartners Inc.
Medical associations in many states are helping doctors to organize their own H.M.O.'s, hoping to eliminate the middleman and deal directly with employers. Many hospitals are trying a similar tack. Lobbyists for the physicians and hospitals recently persuaded Congress to encourage these ventures in the pending Medicare legislation.
Doctors in a group "have more negotiating clout" with the H.M.O.'s on fee schedules or the flat monthly rates per enrollee that are increasingly popular, said Paul B. Ginsburg, a Washington-based economist who heads the Center for Studying Health System Change. Also, there are more physicians to share the costs of treating patients with expensive illnesses.
Some are moving away from areas where managed care is rampant and the squeeze on physicians is strong. At least 50 doctors left the Sacramento, Calif., region last year, for example, for rural corners of Northern California, Montana and other states.
In Los Angeles, Dr. Marvin Kazmin said he "saw the handwriting on the wall" at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center when the hospital omitted him and 40 fellow urologists from a new managed care group that it organized last year.
"Either I moved or I retired," he said. "I was too peppy to quit." Dr. Kazmin, 61, moved to Mercy Hospital in Willard, Ohio, a semirural area where he is now the sole urologist for miles around.
At Phycor, Joseph C. Hutts, the chairman, said primary care doctors' incomes were rising in the company's 44 medical groups across the country. But he said specialists' incomes were flat.
Both the Ernst & Young and Hay Group studies showed many specialists' incomes rising this year, after a decline. But James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said "the big gap between generalists' and specialists' " incomes would probably narrow. American specialists' earnings are about 2.5 times those of general practitioners, compared with a much smaller 1.5-to-1 ratio in Europe and Canada.
"This is not going to be a lot of fun for people," said Gail Wilensky, who heads a Congressional advisory commission on Medicare payments to physicians. "A lot of individuals who have not done anything wrong are going to find themselves on the short end of the stick.
"It happened in the defense industry and in corporate America when companies were attempting to downsize," she added. "But people in health care thought it would never happen to them."

HEADLINE: Asian Nations And U.S. Plan Freer Trade

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Despite some misgivings, ministers from 18 nations in the Asia-Pacific region agreed today on voluntary guidelines for a pan-Pacific free-trade zone spanning countries with more than two billion people and over half the world's economic output.
American officials say the agenda strongly reaffirms the goal of achieving free trade by 2010 for developed nations and by 2020 for developing ones, and makes it clear that all industries should be covered. 
 "The train is gaining speed," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "No derailment at all -- in fact, just the opposite. We have made a major step forward here at Osaka."
Others say the guidelines are not that strong.
On the principal of allowing for "flexibility," the free-trade camp says this means that countries can delay lowering trade barriers until close to the target date but must still meet the deadline. But critics say such "flexibility" constitutes a way to escape any commitments.
"I believe there will be several different interpretations of what has been agreed," said Long Yongtu, Assistant Minister for Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation of China.
The document does not even define what is meant by "free and open trade." While that might seem to mean no tariffs, the forum's goal is only to reduce tariffs, not eliminate them. "That could mean zero," an American official said. "It could mean something more than zero."
Moreover, the agreement is not binding and the organization has no means of enforcement. It would not be a formal free-trade zone like the European Union, but would rely on voluntary action and peer pressure, with all the members scrutinizing and discussing one another's plans. This has been called a "unique" Asian way.
Free trade, at least in theory, should allow for faster growth in already booming East Asia. American officials hope that lower trade barriers will allow American companies to export more products, creating more jobs in the United States. Already, Mr. Kantor said, more than two million American jobs are linked to exports to Asia.
But the luster from the success in forging the guidelines was dimmed by the announcement that President Clinton will not attend Sunday's meeting of the leaders of the nations that make up trade forum. Vice President Al Gore will come instead, while the President stays home to deal with the budget crisis. It was Mr. Clinton who convened the first such summit meeting, two years ago in Seattle, thus raising the prominence of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
Officials from Japan and other nations said they understood the cancellation was not meant as a snub.
The announcement of the cancellation came just as trade and foreign ministers convened today to approve the "action agenda" for turning last year's free-trae vision into reality.
The agenda, which will not be made public until after the leaders meet on Sunday, lays out the basic principles by which the countries will strive to lower trade barriers. It also lists 15 areas to be covered by liberalization efforts, including tariffs and government purchases. Each country is supposed to announce a plan for reducing its own barriers at next year's meeting, in Manila.
Up until only a few days ago, there was a concern among supporters of the free-trade vision that some countries would win exceptions for sensitive industries; China, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan had been seeking exceptions for agriculture. Other countries would also then demand exceptions, setting off a chain reaction that would unravel the effort.
Rafidah Abdul Aziz, the Minister of International Trade and Industry of Malaysia, was quoted by the Kyodo News Service as calling the agenda a "comedown" for "hard-liners who have insisted on free trade, regimented deadlines, targets and hard and fast rules.
To arrive at today's agreement, the ministers had to overcome other sticking points. Japan, which had been criticized as lacking leadership, won praise for its role in guiding the members to compromise.
One sticking point was a dispute between the United States and China. China had wanted language stating that the benefits of lower trade barriers would apply to all members without discrimination. But Washington said it could not agree to lower trade barriers automatically for China because United States law requires that the decision on granting favorable trade status to China be reviewed every year.
The agreed wording states that members "will apply or endeavor to apply" the principle of nondiscrimination, which gives Washington a way out and means that China's trade status will still face yearly reviews.

HEADLINE: China Rebukes Four Other Nuclear Powers on Arms Control

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Issuing a major policy statement on arms control, China tonight sharply rebuked the United States, Russia, Britain and France for continuing to develop "nuclear weapons and outer space weapons, including guided missile defense systems," while seeking in some cases to deny the peaceful use of nuclear technology to the developing world.
The policy document, issued by the official New China News Agency, said the world's major nuclear powers "on the one hand, vie with one another in dumping their advanced weapons on the international market, even using weapons transfers as a means to interfere in other nations' domestic affairs." 
 "On the other," it continued, "they resort to discriminative anti-proliferation and arms control measures, directing the spearhead of arms control at the developing countries."
Without mentioning Taiwan, the document implicitly warned Washington that Beijing regards continuing arms sales to the island as interference in China's internal affairs.
For the first time, the policy declaration also appeared to express China's formal opposition to an American proposal to deploy ballistic missile defense systems in Asia to protect Japan and American military forces there, principally against North Korea.
Beijing fears that such a missile defense system could undermine Chinese strategic nuclear forces, which were developed to hold American, Japanese and Russian targets at risk of retaliation in any nuclear conflict.
Chinese officials were alarmed when President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a communique in May saying Washington and Moscow should cooperate in developing ballistic missile defenses.
In a larger context, China's policy presentation was made to a world and regional audience that is very much concerned with fundamental security questions in Asia. They include the rising military tensions between China and Taiwan; the territorial conflicts in the South China Sea, where there are rich deposits of oil, and China's competition with Japan for regional dominance. The role of American forces in Asia is connected to each one of these issues.
China's policy statement may have also been timed in part to blunt the international criticism that will resume when Beijing detonates its expected third underground nuclear warhead this year, part of a final series of tests leading up to the conclusion in 1996 of a nuclear test ban treaty, which China has pledged to sign. Preparations at the Lop Nor testing range in the far west of China have been observed by American reconnaissance satellites, foreign diplomats here say.
Concerning its own nuclear cooperation with such countries as Iran and Pakistan, both of which have nuclear weapons programs, the document pledged that China would combat the spread of weapons of mass destruction. But it asserted, "There must not be a double standard whereby anti-nuclear proliferation is used as a pretext to limit or retard the peaceful use of nuclear energy by developing nations."
China defended its level of military spending, which has increased about 50 percent, taking inflation into account, since the late 1980's, according to estimates by Central Intelligence Agency.
"China needs a peaceful environment in order to be able to devote itself completely to its socialist modernization program," the document said. "As long as there is no serious threat to China's sovereignty or security, China will not increase its defense spending substantially or by a big margin. It will never threaten nor invade any other country."

HEADLINE: Broad-Based Stock Rally Is Continuing

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Although President Clinton and Congress are still at an impasse over the debt ceiling, the stock market nevertheless barreled ahead yesterday, extending its broad-based rally.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which soared 50.94 points on Wednesday, surged an additional 46.61 points yesterday to a high of 4,969.36. When the Dow scores its next gain -- assuming it does so this year -- it will have tied the 20th-century record of 59 new highs in one year, previously achieved only in 1925 and 1964. 
 Among the other major indicators, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.38 points, to 597.34, its second consecutive record. The Nasdaq composite index increased 2.63 points, to 1,044.48.
"The market continues to kick over negatives and climb a wall of worry," said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president of Fahnestock & Company. "The battle of the budget so far has not been enough to pull the market down."
The bond market also strengthened yesterday, amid expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates to stimulate economic growth after the two sides in Washington resolve their differences. The 30-year Treasury bond jumped 31/32, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slid to 6.22 percent, from 6.29 percent Wednesday.
A round of computer-assisted "buy" orders related to today's double-witching options expiration was a factor in the stock rally. Options on both stocks and individual stock indexes will expire at the end of today's session.
One result was heavy volume, with yesterday's turnover on the New York Stock Exchange at 423.3 million shares, up from 376.1 million shares on Wednesday. Big Board advances topped declines by 1,535 to 809.
Traders were attracted to the shares of both McDonnell Douglas and Boeing, which have been holding talks regarding an exchange of assets or a merger. McDonnell Douglas climbed 4 3/8, to 90 5/8, and Boeing advanced 1 7/8, to 75 7/8.
Airline stocks benefited from the general market optimism. Delta Air Lines added 3/4, to 69 1/4; AMR, the holding company for American Airlines, gained 1 1/4, to 67 1/4, and UAL, the holding company for United Airlines, rose 5, to 190.
Money center banks, which usually have an increase in earnings when borrowing costs are in transition, were strong. Citicorp picked up 1 3/4, to 67 1/4, and BankAmerica advanced 1 1/8, to 60 1/2.
Portfolio managers also turned to oil issues, which have generally lagged behind the overall stock market. Royal Dutch/Shell closed at 127 1/2, up 2 1/8; Mobil closed at 107, up 2 1/8, and Triton closed at 53 1/8, up 1 1/8.
In contrast, many technology stocks dropped on profit taking. Micron fell 1 5/8, to 55 1/4; Intel declined 1 7/8, to 62 7/8; Apple gave up 1 1/16, to 39 15/16, and Compaq lost 1 5/8, to 50 1/4. Microsoft, which was downgraded by Goldman, Sachs, dipped 4 1/8, to 89 7/8.
Some retail stocks were also lower. Kmart, which reported a wider-than-expected loss for its fiscal third quarter, fell 1/8, to 7 5/8 and was the most active stock on the New York exchange. J. C. Penney dropped 5/8, to 46 3/8.
Norton McNaughton slumped 2, to 14, after announcing that it expected lower fiscal fourth-quarter profits. And Material Sciences, which was downgraded by Dillon, Read, declined 2 5/8, to 13.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, Ignoring Budget Impasse, Gains on Stock and Bond Rallies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against other leading currencies yesterday, bolstered by rallies in American stock and bond markets.
The dollar was aided in its climb against the Japanese yen by a sizable cut in Japan's trade surplus. It was helped higher against the German mark by falling interest rates in Europe. 
 But strong gains for stock and bonds helped turn the attention of currency traders away from the battle in Washington over the budget. The rising markets increased demand for dollars to buy the securities.
"You've got to think that all this budget impasse has little effect on them, that a budget deal is inevitable," said Margaret Kudaraskas, senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data in Boston. "Clearly, they must be thinking that."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 46.61 points yesterday, to 4,969.36. Treasury prices also surged, driving the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to 6.22 percent, from 6.29 percent on Wednesday.
"The demand for U.S. dollar-denominated assets usually supports the dollar," Ms. Kudaraskas said.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 102.09 yen from 101.38 yen on Wednesday. The dollar edged up to 1.4069 marks from 1.4062 marks and to 1.1385 Swiss francs from 1.1377 Swiss francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5557 from $1.5570.
The dollar began its rise in Asian trading.
In Japan, the Government reported that its trade surplus plunged 42 percent in October and 44 percent with the United States alone. That was the fourth consecutive monthly decline in the overall trade surplus compared with October last year.
A narrower trade surplus means that Japanese exporters have fewer dollars to sell for yen when they take profits home.
In Europe, economic data released yesterday indicated that lower interest rates were forthcoming. Indeed, the Netherlands and France cut rates yesterday, following Denmark, which lowered rates last week. Traders said that there was speculation that Britain and Switzerland could follow suit.
Traders subsequently reversed their recent move into the German currency.
In comparison, despite signs of some weakening, the "U.S. economy seems to be motoring along at a fairly good pace," said John Rothfield, an international economist at the Chicago office of Nationsbanc-CRT. "That seems to be good for the dollar," he said.

HEADLINE: St. Croix Journal;
For One Island, Storms Bring a Tourism Windfall

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: FREDERIKSTED, V.I., Nov. 10

 BODY:
About 40 students from Eulalie Rivera Elementary School came to greet two cruise ships at the pier here with gifts for the captains and songs and dances for the passengers. The students hoped to get a chance to board the ships, the Star Princess and the Regal Princess, but they had a mission first: charm the tourists into a repeat visit.
"Welcome! -- To our island! -- St. Croix!" the students cheered, stepping and clapping as about 3,000 travelers poured from the ships. 
 This winter season, St. Croix, one of the three United States Virgin Islands, expects to get more than four times its usual number of visitors because of damage in September by Hurricanes Luis and Marilyn to more popular travel destinations in the Caribbean. And as the misfortune of others creates an economic boom here, this island of more than 60,000 people is determined to seize the moment and a bigger piece of the growing Caribbean tourist business.
"St. Croix is probably going to have its best tourist season in six years," said David L. Edgell, tourism commissioner for the United States Virgin Islands.
Six years ago, Hurricane Hugo devastated St. Croix just as the island was poised to build up tourism and catch up with its two sister islands, St. Thomas and St. John. In 1994, 1.7 million people visited St. Thomas and St. John, compared with 193,000 who came here, bringing a combined $1 billion a year to the American territory.
Now, two other hurricanes have restored St. Croix's momentum by causing only moderate damage here but wreaking destruction in St. Thomas, Antigua and the divided island of St. Martin/St. Maarten. Two major hotels in St. John, which tourists usually reach through St. Thomas, are still closed.
As cruise lines look for substitutes, they are delivering two to three ships a day to St. Croix with up to 6,000 passengers. The island expects 370 calls from cruise ships, up from 80 last year.
The welcome mat is out throughout the island. In Frederiksted, the port city, economic depression is being lifted by signs like the one in a vacant corner storefront announcing, "Coming soon. Colombia Emeralds International." The business is one of 26 planned new stores and restaurants in Frederiksted and Christiansted.
In Cane Bay Beach, to the north, Philip Lipari was renovating his Cane Bay Beach Bar and expanding the kitchen. "This is a chance for us to shine and we need to take advantage of it," Mr. Lipari said.
St. Croix may not have the commercial appeal of St. Thomas, with its duty-free shopping, or the beauty of St. John, most of which is an unspoiled national park. But as the biggest of the three United States Virgin Islands, St. Croix is less crowded and more relaxing than St. Thomas, its residents say. It also offers great snorkling like St. John, they note, and less predictable Caribbean attractions, like West Indian and Danish colonial historic sites.
St. Croix's residents tend to attribute their island's lack of recognition relative to other Caribbean islands to government neglect and inadequate marketing in the United States. Some also said the island's business community had not been as aggressive -- or greedy -- as its counterpart in St. Thomas.
"St. Thomas sometimes has eight ships and St. Croix has not had one," said Myron Woodley, a taxi driver. "If you love your neighbor so much, why don't they say, 'Let's divert one ship to St. Croix?' What I'm saying is, let's share."
But the rivalry may be evening out. The territorial government is in the midst of a push to lure more tourism to St. Croix and recently authorized casino gambling on this island only. More hotels are planned, the airport is undergoing a $16 million expansion and a new 122-passenger catamaran ferry is scheduled to start island tours and runs to St. Thomas before Christmas.
There has also been a scramble to diversify attractions to fill visitors' days. On a recent morning, tour operators at the pier sold a stop at Mount Pellier Hot Domino Club, a restaurant that boasts beer-drinking pigs. A welcoming board at the Frederiksted pier listed round-trip taxi fares around the island: "Christiansted, $10," "Buccaneer Beach, $14" and "Kmart, $6."
Kmart?
"Some tourists want to go there," a cab driver said with a shrug.
Visitors like Robert and Anna Scinto, honeymooners from Connecticut and veterans of five cruises, said they would come back.
"It's a little bit quieter," Mr. Scinto, 37, said. "It's nice."
Mrs. Scinto, 32, said, "The shopping is not of the quality of St. Thomas, but for a peaceful beach day, it was perfect."
Many in St. Croix worry that cruise ships will flock back to St. Thomas when that island is again deemed suitable. But at least one line has decided on St. Croix as a regular stop for the 1996 winter season for some of its ships even before this year's hurricanes.
"We thought it'd be very attractive for our passengers to visit all three of the U.S. Virgin Islands," said Julie Benson, a spokeswoman for Princess Cruises. "We think it's a good selling point."

These students from Eulalie Rivera Elementary School recently greeted two cruise ships with songs and dances. (Carol Lee for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Soar; Yields Near A 2-Year Low

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Technical buying, optimism on the budget battle and another sign of economic weakness combined yesterday to drive Treasury prices sharply higher.
The rally pushed the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.22 percent, from 6.29 percent on Wednesday, the lowest level in nearly two years. The price of the 30-year bond ended at 10820/32 , up 31/32 . 
 Prices of shorter-term maturities also rose. The price of the two-year note rose 3/32 , to 10010/32 , for a yield of 5.45 percent, down from 5.50 percent, and the 10-year note rose 18/32 , to 10413/32 , for a yield of 5.90 percent, down from 5.97 percent.
Overseas buying before the opening of the United States market gave prices a jump-start, prompting the covering of short positions. Short- sellers sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back at a lower price. When prices rise, as they did early yesterday, the short-seller needs to buy securities to limit his losses.
"A lot of hedge funds went home short yesterday afternoon and they got squeezed pretty good by that uptick overnight," said James Hale, senior fixed-income strategist at MMS International.
Foreign investors might have bought Treasury securities, analysts said, after learning that President Clinton had canceled his trip to Japan this weekend for a major Asian-Pacific regional meeting, interpreting the move as increasing chances for a compromise on the budget.
Prices were further bolstered after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia released its survey of regional conditions, which suggested continued weakness in manufacturing. The Philadelphia Fed's index of current manufacturing business activity fell sharply in November, to 7.9, from 25.5 in October. The November new orders and shipments indexes also fell from October levels.
The data provided further evidence of moderate economic growth and inflation and kept alive hopes that the Federal Reserve could reduce short-term interest rates in coming months. That possibility depends on a budget agreement being reached. Traders remained optimistic yesterday, even as a partial shutdown of the Government entered its third day.
Treasury prices surged after the release of the Philadelphia Fed report, piercing important resistance levels and setting off a technical rally, which sent bonds to their session highs.
"As we continued climbing, the technical picture turned extremely bullish," said John Canavan, an analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc.
The positive tone of the bond market was reinforced by a sluggish November survey from the Home Builders Association, a trade group, and by a strengthening in the dollar. The Home Builders' housing market index fell 7 points in November, to 50, from October.
In the corporate debt market, prices followed Treasury securities higher.
The debt of McDonnell Douglas surged in price, with yields falling 5 to 10 basis points, dealers said, on a report in The Wall Street Journal that the company was in talks with Boeing on a merger or business combination. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Georgia Gulf Corporation priced $100 million in 10-year notes yesterday, its lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. The notes, which are noncallable, have a 7.625 percent coupon and were priced at 99.735 to yield 7.663 percent, or 175 basis points over a comparable Treasury security. The notes are rated Ba1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB- by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Pataki Will Not Open Books on Inaugural Fund

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki took office last January with the most lavish inaugural party in state history, a three-day pageant of feasting and music for 13,000 people. Despite its splendor, he used no government money for the event.
The Governor paid the bill by establishing a private corporation that solicited donations to a special inaugural fund. And as the Governor and his aides set it up a year ago, they made two promises. They pledged to abide strictly by state campaign finance laws, and they promised to open the fund's books to the public. 
 A year later, they have done neither.
The inaugural fund collected an estimated $500,000, donated by lobbyists, campaign contributors and businesses. Interviews with many of the companies that contributed the money show that at least five companies, and probably several more, gave far more to the inaugural fund than state campaign finance limits allow. Two companies gave $25,000 to the event, five times the maximum allowed under state campaign laws.
And according to state records, N.Y. Inaugural '95 may have used some of its money for political purposes. The fund gave $25,000 to the state Republican Committee late last year.
At the same time, despite requests from lawmakers and journalists over the last six months -- including one today -- the Governor's office has refused to make the inaugural committee's records public. In fact, the Governor's aides dissolved the corporation late last month -- just three weeks before they would have had to file an annual report that would have included information about its operations. Because the corporation was dissolved before the one-year deadline, no report will ever have to be filed.
Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for Mr. Pataki, said today that the inaugural fund would not release the names of contributors. She said it was a private corporation and not required to make such disclosures. In fact, she said, the information was kept from the Governor, too.
For "ethical reasons," she said, the corporation's former chief officer, Robert E. Boyle, a member of Mr. Pataki's cabinet, decided that it was best that Mr. Pataki and the rest of his cabinet not know the names of people or organizations that gave to the inauguration.
Told that some of the contributors' names had been printed in the official inaugural program, Ms. Mucha said, "I didn't know that." Later, she said that the program listed only "a small fraction" of the contributors.
Ms. Mucha also said the fund's $25,000 contribution to the state Republican Committee was to repay the party for its help in organizing the inauguration. But the party reported spending only $7,415 during December, the busiest period for inaugural preparations, and an itemized list published by the committee did not show that any of the money was spent on the inauguration.
The inaugural fund's activities have stirred a debate over the propriety of allowing the Governor or his aides to solicit, without public disclosure, large sums of money from companies that routinely do business with his office.
"What it does is it cements a relationship -- a potential payback relationship -- between the donors and the celebrant," said Ellen S. Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a Washington-based group that studies the role of money in politics. "There are no limits on how much you can give to these accounts. The more you can give, the more insidious it is."
Critics contend that the inaugural should have been subject to state campaign laws not only to prevent conflicts, but also because it played a fundamentally political purpose: to promote Mr. Pataki and to burnish his image after a mud-spattered campaign.
A Democratic lawmaker charged today that N.Y. Inaugural '95 was established solely to circumvent state campaign restrictions and should be investigated for possible violations of state election laws.
"This was really an account created for the benefit of a political candidate who happened to have won an election," said State Senator Richard A. Dollinger, Democrat of Rochester.
Contributors countered that they were not trying to curry favor with the new Governor. They said they were driven by a public-spirited desire to make the inauguration open to as many people as possible.
"It allowed all of the citizens of Albany to partake in the inaugural," said Gene Swanzey, director of governmental affairs at Chase Manhattan Bank, which contributed $7,000 to the event, $2,000 more than the state campaign maximum. "It was amazing, if you walked all along that mall and saw all the citizens. It reminded me of Andrew Jackson's inauguration."
Mr. Pataki was certainly not the first politician to raise private funds for his inaugural. Presidents have been doing it at least since the late 1970's. In 1992, Bill Clinton's inaugural committee raised $2.5 million from corporations and borrowed another $17 million in interest-free loans. The Clinton inaugural committee released a full list of contributors.
But in New York State, previous governors held swearing-in ceremonies in legislative chambers or private offices, while Mr. Pataki's was in an Albany sports arena, attended by 13,000 people. The event included a laser light show, a performance by the Albany Symphony Orchestra and a 19-gun salute.
In a three-day period, there were also performances of children's music, private parties for the Governor's friends, a black-tie gala and a "People's Reception" with dozens of food vendors and musical groups in the underground concourse of the Empire State Plaza.
Charles A. Gargano, who as Mr. Pataki's campaign finance chairman helped raise $14.5 million for last year's race, was chairman of the committee that organized and raised money for the inauguration. Mr. Gargano is now State Commissioner for Economic Development.
But interviews with more than a dozen companies that contributed to the inauguration shows that many were not major contributors to Mr. Pataki's campaign. Almost all, however, have direct interests in state government, whether as regulated industries, advocates for new legislation or as vendors selling products and services to the state.
For instance, Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceutical company, gave $25,000 to the inaugural corporation, five times the campaign contribution limit.
Bristol-Myers has contracts worth about $1.7 million with the state to provide medical products and other services. It is also regulated by several state agencies. Recently, the company asked the State Department of Environmental Conservation to curtail a program that requires it to pay the salaries of two full-time state workers who monitor pollution at one of its Syracuse plants.
Charisse Richardson, a spokeswoman for Bristol-Myers, said the company did not expect favorable treatment in exchange for its contribution. "We have been supportive of both parties and will continue to be in the future, provided they undertake efforts that are in the best interest of the state and provide growth opportunities for our company," she said.
Chase Manhattan and three other companies also said they gave inaugural donations that exceeded campaign limits. They were the New York State Business Group-Conference Associates, a Patchogue company that sells health insurance to small businesses, $25,000; Chemical Bank, $10,000; and AT&T, $10,000.
The state deposits millions of dollars from pension funds and other accounts at Chase Manhattan Bank, and it uses Chemical to administer low-interest loan programs for small businesses. AT&T provides phone services worth about $2.4 million to a variety of state agencies.
Despite their vow to abide voluntarily by campaign finance laws, officials with N.Y. Inaugural '95 did not ask contributors to keep their donations within state campaign contribution limits, people who assisted in fund raising said.
"It was up to the individual companies" to decide how much to give, said Richard Alteri, president of the Cable Television Association of New York.
At a time when Mr. Pataki was considering making deep cuts in health care spending, doctors and health care companies were among the biggest contributors. The Medical Society of New York State gave $11,200, while the members of the New York State H.M.O. Conference gave a total of $25,000.
The Coca-Cola Company and the Pepsi-Cola Company were both corporate sponsors of the inauguration. Officials with Coca-Cola said they donated about 100 cases of soda for the event. Pepsi-Cola would not disclose what it contributed.
Last June, Mr. Pataki signed a budget that included a cut in soft-drink taxes that will eventually be worth $26 million a year. Both Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola lobbied aggressively for the cut.
Construction companies also gave. Jerome A. Gannon, president of A-J Construction Company in Manhattan, and Angelo Silveri, president of Silverite Construction Company in Hicksville, L.,I., belonged to the inaugural committee. Both companies have said that they are interested in getting state contracts, though neither has succeeded yet.
Other contributors included Fleet Bank, $5,000, Pfizer Company, $5,000, Kodak, which donated photographs, and International Paper, which donated paper products.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George E. Pataki celebrated his election with the most lavish inaugural party in state history. Some of the money collected by a private company established for the event paid for a cake bearing his likeness. (Jim Estrin/The New York Times)(pg. B10)

HEADLINE: Man Is Charged With Impersonating Priest

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
During the summer months, he sat outside the Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx and befriended young people in the predominantly Italian neighborhood. In clerical garb, he spoke to them in the erudite words of the Jesuit priest he claimed to be and in the gentle tone of one capable of infinite compassion.
"He spoke about God and religion like he was a real priest," said Gina Demalijaj, a church employee. 
 Yesterday the man, who called himself Father Giustino Visconti and said he taught canon law at nearby Fordham University, was arrested and charged with criminal impersonation and grand larceny.
In the last five years, the police said, the man -- whom they identified as John Fortune, 35, an unemployed man with no religious training -- performed a baptism, said as many as five Masses and heard confessions in the Fordham section of the Bronx.
In addition, the police said, he bilked a 52-year-old widow, a mother of three, of her retirement savings.
Mr. Fortune's double life came to an end yesterday afternoon when the police stopped him near his apartment and handcuffed him, in his priest's clothing, on the corner of East 196th Street and the Grand Concourse.
It began at least five years ago, when Mr. Fortune met the widow through a mutual friend, Police Capt. John Creegan said at a news conference last night. The widow, a mother of three who retired as a kitchen helper at a home for the elderly, turned to Mr. Fortune for guidance. Mr. Fortune gradually became a part of the family and began investing the widow's retirement savings -- $12,000 in all, the police said.
Meanwhile, about four years ago, Mr. Fortune became a well-liked fixture at Mount Carmel at 627 East 187th Street, where he introduced himself to the pastor as a visiting priest from Fordham and was invited to say Mass, Ms. Demalijaj said. But Mr. Fortune stumbled and made mistakes in the liturgy, she said, raising doubts about his background. Though the pastor did not report him to the police, Mr. Fortune was no longer asked to say Mass, she said. Still, he continued to visit the church until last year.
With his initial success in his impersonation, Mr. Fortune apparently grew more confident and reckless, the police said. Early this year, at a small chapel, he baptized a baby. But the parents began to suspect an impostor when their repeated requests for the baptismal certificate were not met.
The widow, meanwhile, had heard rumors that he was an impostor. She finally believed them last June, Captain Creegan said, after she asked him to perform her son's marriage -- and Mr. Fortune canceled at the last minute.
Mr. Fortune, who the police said had apparently not held a job in years, told a detective who arrested him that he had studied philosophy in Rome for three years. "He seems to be a wanna-be priest," Detective John Scianimanico said.

HEADLINE: Religious or Not, West Bank Settlers Feel Betrayed by Israel

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: GANIM, West Bank, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The unthinkable became reality last week for the 33 Jewish families of Ganim when armed Palestinians took charge of nearby Jenin.
What if the Palestinian police tried to stop them, as they were allowed to do under the peace agreement that brought the police to Jenin? Something akin to a groan passed through the clutch of residents gathered outside the administration office of the small, armed Israeli settlement in the north of the West Bank. 
 "It's a creepy feeling," confessed Mihal Bronstein, a nurse who has lived in Ganim for 14 years, including the seven when the Palestinian uprising made traveling outside the enclave dangerous and just living there tense. "They're terrorists, not police. They were trained in terror camps, and now the Government has decided to call them police!"
The people of Ganim are hardly the bellicose settlers of Hebron who speak of Palestinians as "foreigners" and spew the violent religious ideology that fired Yigal Amir, the confessed assassin of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin.
Secular for the most part, most of them came as much to take advantage of inexpensive housing in a striking hill-top setting within commuting distance of the Israeli city of Afula as to fulfill the romantic Zionist dream of building pioneering settlements in the Promised Land.
 
United in Opposing Peace Agreements
 But secular or religious, the 147,000 Israeli Jews who people the archipelago of 145 settlements across the West Bank have become united in a sense of betrayal by the Labor Government and in opposition to the peace agreements with the Palestinians.
Though the peace agreements reached so far leave the settlements intact -- and in fact improve their lot somewhat by bringing them new "bypass roads" that connect them more safely with Israel -- the fears and passions of the settlers are at the heart of the bitter dispute that has severed the nation, and that cost Mr. Rabin his life.
"We have to be careful of using words like 'betrayal' these days, but there's a clear divide today in Israeli society between those looking for a new Israel of Israelis and those looking for a Jewish Israel, between 'Yisraeli' and 'Yehudi' -- Israeli and Jew," said Yechiel Leiter, 36, a settler originally from Scranton, Pa., who serves as a spokesman for the Yesha Council, which represents settlers in the West Bank and Gaza.
The distinction he drew was between a vision of Israel as the modern, prosperous, secular state of which Tel Aviv is the spiritual capital -- the vision with which the left wing is associated -- and a Jewish state in the biblical Land of Israel of which religious nationalists dream, including the West Bank regions of Judea and Samaria, with Jerusalem as its heart.
"The debate is over the national character of the country, not where the final borderline is drawn," Mr. Leiter said. "The horns are locked over much, much broader issues than drawing a line in the sand or Oslo 1 and 2," he said, using Israeli shorthand for the two Israeli-Palestinian agreements reached so far. "The debate is over the very core of our existence."
That is not what they had in mind when they came out here, Mihal Bronstein and her husband, Alan, acknowledged. Mr. Bronstein regarded himself as a liberal when he left Los Angeles 25 years earlier to cast his lot with Israel, and he met his wife in a left-wing kibbutz.
 
'Ideology Comes With Being Here'
 Now Mr. Bronstein carries a gun when driving to Israel, and would not dream of voting for the Labor Party. "The ideology comes with being here," he explained. "Living here grows on you."
The Bronsteins moved to the young settlement of Ganim in 1981, when moving to the West Bank was the thing to do; housing was cheap, mortgages were easy, the Palestinians were relatively peaceable and, most important, settling in the historic Jewish lands of Judea and Samaria carried the romantic aura of pioneering Zionism and the blessing of the Government and the nation.
Then in 1987, the intifada, as the Palestinian uprising against Israel is known, turned benign neighbors into dangerous enemies. A Ganim settler named Motti Biton was killed by Palestinians when he stopped at an Arab store, and many others found their cars stoned.
Wire fences were thrown up around settlements, and both men and women learned to use and carry guns. New bypass roads were built for millions of dollars. Today, Ganim children are bused to grade school in another settlement under military escort, an hour each way.
In 1992 a Labor Government came to power under Prime Minister Rabin and began treating the settlers not as a national vanguard, but as a nuisance -- a drain on the army and an obstacle to peace with Palestinians. Mr. Rabin called the settlers "crybabies," and he declared that their settlements "add nothing, absolutely nothing, to Israel's security."
He called the West Bank "the territories," not Judea and Samaria, and he drew a line between "security" settlements, like those in the Jordan Valley and around Jerusalem, and "political" settlements, which were built under the ideology of his predecessor, Yitzhak Shamir, who promised to settle Israelis "to the horizon's edge." Mr. Rabin froze housing construction, and "political" settlements lost special benefits like tax and mortgage incentives.
In Ganim, a row of completed houses have stood vacant since 1992. Suddenly, the proud outposts of Jewish redemption in Judea and Samaria found themselves a neglected archipelago of 145 isolated, armed and bitter hilltop islands, neglected and alienated by the brash, commercial Israel of Tel Aviv with its punk haircuts and cosmopolitan cafes.
The Jewish settlements are hard to miss in the rugged, hilly West Bank countryside. They sit atop the hills, their ordered rows of red-tile roofs setting them sharply apart from the haphazard old Arab villages dotting hillsides or valleys. At night, bright halogen lights identify the Israeli hilltops.
Last week, when the Israeli Army pulled out of Jenin under the September agreement with the Palestinians and Palestinian soldiers moved in with flags, portraits of Yasir Arafat and automatic weapons, Israeli soldiers stopped settlers from traveling into the new Palestinian zone. It was partly for their own sake, but partly because neither side wanted them there any more.
It is that humiliation, that sense of being thrust aside in a new, secular Israel, that is really the crux of the settlers' angst, more than any specific aspects of the agreements.
In fact, the risk that any settler will get stopped by an armed Palestinian policeman is negligible. Under the current agreement, the Palestinian police will have authority only in their own cities and villages, which settlers have been avoiding in any case for several years now, and which they will now be able to detour around altogether.
The agreement, moreover, follows in broad outlines what most moderate settlers had advocated for years -- granting the Palestinians self-rule in Arab-populated areas while keeping overall security in Israeli hands, and keeping the settlements intact.
"If they keep to the current plan, I can live with it," said Yisrael Harel, a founder of the Yesha Council and editor of a settler newspaper, Nekudah. But like many settlers, Mr. Harel believed the Rabin Government was really moving toward abandoning the settlements and the greater dream of the Land of Israel.
 
Arab Sovereignty Is Not Acceptable
 "The late Prime Minister didn't say it openly," Mr. Harel said. "In the talks we had he hinted that he was not going to uproot the settlements, that his solution was that those areas would be transferred to the Palestinians, and we would be welcome to stay where we are if we were willing to accept another sovereignty.
"I will not. I did not come to this country for this, those Americans didn't come from the luxury of the United States to the hills of Judea and Samaria, to intifada, to be under Arafat's sovereignty."
The reference to Americans was not chance. While Jews who came from the United States form a relatively small share of settlers, between 8 and 12 percent, they have been prominent in organizations and protests. The reason, according to Yehudit Tayar, a native of Chicago and a resident of the Beit Horon settlement, northwest of Jerusalem, is that Americans are taught, "If you believe in something, you have to go out and be active, not sit on the sidelines."
Mrs. Tayar's history suggests another explanation, that those Jews who leave the comforts of America to come to Israel are usually not interested in the alternative comforts of Tel Aviv, but in fulfilling a quest.
"There's a link between why you come and who you are," she said. "It's not a religious question, but a Jewish question. I'm here because I'm Jewish, and if I'm Jewish, I seek to live in the most meaningful place for me -- Jerusalem, or Hebron, or Yesha," she said, referring to the settlements.
Americans have also figured prominently among the militant religious nationalists in Hebron, though none of those rounded up after Mr. Rabin's death have been from the United States. A settler from Brooklyn, Baruch Goldstein, achieved infamy when he opened fire on Muslim worshipers in Hebron last year, killing 29.
To David Wilder, a resident of the Qiryat Arba settlement adjacent to Hebron who is originally from New Jersey, Hebron is the "front line" in a struggle for the Land of Israel.
"If Hebron falls, then Jerusalem would fall, and the entire Jewish state," he said. "This is the front line."
Though they grab the most publicity, neither the militants of Hebron nor the activist Americans are typical. Settler leaders deny that there is a stereotypical settler at all.
According to Mr. Leiter of the Yesha Council, about 35 percent of the Jewish settlers are religious, a term that in the Israeli context refers to strict adherents of Jewish law, and about 65 percent are secular. The religious, he said, virtually all moved to the settlements out of conviction, while about half of the secular settlers came for ideological reasons and the rest for the economic advantages.
Rabbi Abraham Tzuriel is one of those who came for religious reasons, to settle near the site of the ancient Jewish capital, Samaria. Eight years ago the young rabbi, now 32, settled at Shavey Shomron, a religious settlement whose name means "Returnees to Samaria."
A gentle father of five, he dreamed of peaceful coexistence with Arabs.
Gazing over the rolling Samarian hills in the evening light, he ponders now the political shifts that had transformed the settlers from pioneers into "enemies of peace."
But he would never leave, he said. "The dream hasn't changed," he said. "It's the reality that's always changing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A girl stood yesterday inside a security fence around Ganim, a settlement in the northern West Bank. (Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times)
 
Map: "A CLOSER LOOK -- Dividing the Land: Who Gets Control"
Israeli and Palestinian authorities have agreed on a plan to cede Israeli authority over nearly a third of the West Bank. Virtually all the 1.8 million West Bank Palestinians live on that land. All of the Jewish settlements and about 50,000 Palestinians are in the 70 percent that will remain under total Israeli control.
 First, eight cities are being turned over to the Palestinians. Israel has withdrawn from Jericho and Jenin. By Dec. 31 five others will be turned over. The eighth city, Hebron, is to be under Palestinian control by March.
 Those cities are 3 percent of the land in the West Bank. Sometime in 1996 Israel will turn over civil control of another 27 percent of the land, which includes 465 Palestinian towns and villages. Israel will retain responsibility for military security in this area. Under the agreement, Israel keeps complete authority over the remaining 70 percent of the West Bank.

HEADLINE: For Pequots' Point Man, No Task Is Too Small;
Casino Boss Drives Hard, Whether to Expand to Bridgeport or Ease Wedding Plans

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 16

 BODY:
On a recent morning, G. Michael Brown, the top executive in the Mashantucket Pequot Indians' gambling empire, barked orders to an ever-changing audience of lawyers, accountants, architects and lobbyists as he juggled a series of projects that would make rival developers' eyes bulge.
Rising outside his office at the Foxwoods Resort Casino in eastern Connecticut was a 17-story, 1,229-room hotel, supposed to be the largest in New England under a single roof. Next door, work on the nation's first smoke-free gaming rooms was on schedule for a New Year's Eve opening. 
 And there was the intense lobbying drive to win approval from a hostile Legislature for an $875 million casino in Bridgeport -- an issue that is to come to a vote on Friday in the State Senate with the outcome very much in doubt.
But when a call came from a tribal member who was having trouble getting a reservation at the casino for her daughter's wedding, Mr. Brown dropped everything. "Clear that up immediately," he snapped at an assistant. "Find out what's going on."
Minutes later, Mr. Brown called the concerned mother and promised her a beautiful wedding.
This is how things work at Foxwoods, the nation's most profitable casino. On the one hand, Mr. Brown is the driving force behind a gambling juggernaut and the point man in the tribe's efforts to expand to Bridgeport. On the other, he is an employee of the 370-member tribe and answerable to them.
It is this tremendous wealth and influence concentrated in the hands of a small tribe and its advisers that has some lawmakers balking at extending the Pequots' gambling franchise to Bridgeport. They fear that they will be creating an economic Frankenstein's monster by giving the Pequots one of the most desirable gambling sites in the nation, an hour from New York City and its tens of thousands of passionate gamblers.
"If we win this," Mr. Brown remarked, "we would control more gaming business than any other casino company in the world."
The opposition, though, is not just about gambling. Asked for his view on the resistance to the tribe's proposal, Mr. Brown responded bluntly: "Racism."
"People don't want these rich Indians making more money," he said. "If we were General Dynamics and were going to build a factory there, they'd be hugging us and lining up to offer tax abatements."
Overcoming this opposition is the latest challenge to the quirky marriage between Mr. Brown, a gruff former New Jersey prosecutor, and the Pequots, a tribe that once had been thought extinct, who together have created Foxwoods, a casino that this year has already attracted more visitors than the combined population of New York City, Los Angeles and Chicago.
Until three years ago, Gerard Michael Brown, known to friends and colleagues as Mickey, had never imagined running a casino. Today, he is paid about $1.5 million a year, making him roughly the 15th-highest-paid gaming executive in the country. He manages every aspect of Foxwoods, from checking ticket sales for a Cyndi Lauper concert to looking for a an Arizona resort to house 30 of the casino's highest rollers for a Super Bowl junket.
While Mr. Brown's predecessor left under fire over failing to heed the tribe's advice, the seven-member Tribal Council just renewed Mr. Brown's contract. Richard (Skip) Hayward, the council's chairman, described him as "someone you can trust with your life."
Mr. Brown, 53, does not fit the popular image of a casino chief. His wardrobe of pin-striped suits comes from A.& S. in New Jersey, where he goes once a year and has the same employee, a woman named Ethel, pick them out. Home is the same modest two-story Cape Cod in Sea Girt, N.J., he has owned for 20 years, where he spends weekends. For work, he rents a two-bedroom town house in Mystic, Conn.
"I drink Coors Lite beer and like steak," he said. His one concession to affluence: a 1995 Cadillac Seville "with everything on it."
Mr. Brown is emblematic of a new generation of gaming executives who are more likely to have accounting degrees and ties to law enforcement than a shady past and a showman's panache. He spent much of his career prosecuting mobsters, not mingling with them.
Still, some lawmakers insist that the industry is corrupt. "Don't tell me the mob isn't involved," said State Senator James T. Fleming, a Simsbury Republican who is the Senate majority leader. "It's a dirty, dirty business."
Told of the comment, Mr. Brown shrugged. Foxwoods, he said, is the most "vigorously controlled gaming entity in the world," and his staff includes a retired F.B.I. senior agent and a former New Jersey deputy attorney general.
It has been his mission for more than a decade to show that casinos can be run cleanly. After winning a mob trial in 1980, in which he heralded the conviction of four gangsters as proof that the Mafia is "not a figment of Hollywood's imagination," he became New Jersey's chief regulator of the gaming industry in Atlantic City.
When a new state administration came in, Mr. Brown went into private practice, advising gambling companies on how to keep their businesses free of corruption.
The Pequots became his client in the early 1990's, seeking his help to turn their bingo hall into a full-fledged casino. Eventually, he was called in to broker a deal with Lowell P. Weicker Jr., then the Governor and a staunch foe of gambling, who told Mr. Brown at their first meeting, "I would not bring my dog to Atlantic City -- that's what I think of you and what you've done down there."
But weeks later, the tribe and Governor Weicker had struck a deal that suited both their interests. In exchange for a 25 percent cut of slot machine revenue, the Governor gave the Pequots a monopoly on slot machines in the state, undercutting efforts to allow other casinos in Connecticut.
The deal laid the foundation for the current success of Foxwoods: 50,000 visitors a day, about 10,000 employees, the largest single contributor of revenue to the state's budget.
Now, the tribe wants to extend its monopoly to Bridgeport.
So for the last two months, Mr. Brown has desperately tried to convince a skeptical Legislature that his casino plan is too good for them to pass up. What started as an unwinnable fight, with only 3 of the 36 state senators behind them, now faces a vote in the Senate that will likely be decided by a few votes.
The turnaround is due, in large measure, to the relentless campaign the Pequots have waged. Every day, two of their lobbyists, from the law firm of Robinson & Cole, which receives $100,000 a month, prowl the halls of the Capitol. Limousines carrying Tribal Council members, lawyers and Mr. Brown make daily runs to Hartford to meet with legislators and the Governor. And the tribe has run television commercials and sent out a direct mail appeal.
Most important, whenever the process has appeared to be derailing, Mr. Brown has been there, ready to promise the state more money. In waging the legislative battle, the tribe has raised by $1.1 billion the amount it would pay over the next 10 years, to $3.4 billion.
And for much of the last two days, Mr. Brown has been closeted with lawmakers and the Legislature's lawyer, rewriting the bill, trying to address the concerns of various legislators.
But the critics remain. State Senator George C. Jepsen, a Stamford Democrat, brushed aside the millions the Pequots had offered, saying, "This amount is nothing compared to the resources they have."
State Senator William I. DiBella, a Hartford Democrat who is undecided on this issue, dismissed Mr. Brown's charges of racism and said there were serious concerns about giving the tribe too much clout. "Would we be giving them an economic power that would make them an overbearing presence?" he asked.
These are arguments that Mr. Brown has heard repeatedly over the last few weeks, and his response is almost rote. The Pequots live in Connecticut, care about it and will keep pumping their profits into the state, he says.
Mr. Brown grants that he will be disappointed if they lose the Senate vote. But, as he acknowledges, even a defeat will be a victory, with Foxwoods still the only casino in the state. And on the evening after the vote, his life will go on.
"Win or lose, I'm having dinner with Tony Bennett Saturday night," he said. "And on Sunday, I'm at the Patriots game."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Calm in the Eye of the N.F.L. Storm

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH 

 BODY:
From the outside looking in, it appears that chaos reigns in the National Football League. There are franchise shifts, lawsuits and an owner's revolt in Dallas.
From the inside looking out, Paul Tagliabue sees it differently. The league's commissioner considers the upheaval in the league's economic and geographic landscape a natural consequence of its success. 
 "Over all, I think that most of what we're going through now is a product of growth, expansion and success," Tagliabue said. "You wouldn't like to have those issues happen during play of the season. I don't mean to minimize the issues out there, but sometimes we tend to look at things too narrowly and not understand what the process of growth in a sports league is."
But consider the growing pains. Just this year, two N.F.L. teams have changed cities and two more have set the wheels in motion. The Los Angeles area, the nation's No. 2 television market, is without a team. Last week the Browns announced they were moving from Cleveland, a bedrock of pro football tradition for half a century, to Baltimore for a new $200 million stadium with a 30-year, rent-free lease. Yesterday the Oilers announced they were relocating from Houston to Nashville to play in a new $292 million, 65,000-seat stadium to be completed by 1998.
Other teams are reportedly considering changes of venue -- the Chicago Bears to a new stadium outside Gary, Ind.; the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to Orlando, Fla.; the Seattle Seahawks possibly to Los Angeles. All of it could happen next year.
Add to this the more than $1 billion in lawsuits that pit the Raiders against the league, the league against the Dallas owner Jerry Jones, and Jones against the league, his fellow owners and NFL Properties, the marketing arm of the league.
As he begins his second term as N.F.L. commissioner, Tagliabue, 54, is shepherding changes that will significantly alter the league as it heads into the next century. These problems are part of that process, he said, the 1990's version of the ones that confronted the league in previous decades.
"Houston talked a few years ago about going to Jacksonville," Tagliabue said yesterday in a wide-ranging interview at the league's Park Avenue headquarters. "Houston has had a stadium problem for a number of years. Over all you have to keep some perspective on these things. We had similar stadium issues in the 80's. We had those three moves in the 80's. Go back to the 70's, people thought there was 'turmoil.' You had the Giants going to the Yale Bowl. That wasn't exactly regarded as normal times.
"What we're dealing with is the normal process of growth and the fruits of success, frankly."
Tagliabue said the court's ruling in the 1982 Raiders case, affirming the team's right to move from Oakland, Calif., to Los Angeles, influenced the league then and now.
It was the threat of a $2 billion antitrust lawsuit by the Missouri Attorney General's office that forced the league to reconsider its initial no-vote on the Rams' move to St. Louis this past May. That threat looms as well with both the Browns and the Oilers. And it is powerful.
" '60 Minutes' just pulled a show on Sunday night," Tagliabue said. "Mike Wallace and Morley Safer were on 'Charlie Rose' saying they did it because of the threat of litigation. I'm sure The New York Times pulls stories every day because of the threat of libel lawsuits. It doesn't mean that you are in a state of crisis or a state of turmoil. That is part of your business."
When he was asked whether the threat of lawsuits had lessened his authority as commissioner, Tagliabue replied sternly: "No. I don't think it has lessened my authority any more than it lessened Pete Rozelle's authority when we litigated the players association in the Mackey case in the mid-70's."
When Tagliabue took the job in 1989, there were five items on his personal "to-do" list: to achieve labor peace; secure a lucrative and diversified television package; maintain the appeal of the game; expand the league, and get new stadiums as they were needed around the league.
With a rich television contract running through 1997 and a collective bargaining agreement through 1998, with scoring up and two expansion teams competing this season, it's the stadium issue that threatens to turn the league upside down. Some N.F.L. owners, seeking new sources of revenue, are becoming modern day Forty Niners.
But Tagliabue points out that the teams are moving to cities that were identified by the league as attractive sites for relocation. He said of the 12 locations that the league considered viable for expansion in 1993, five were considered top areas -- St. Louis, Baltimore, Jacksonville, the Carolinas and Tennessee.
"So, there is logic there in terms of the strength of the markets," he said.
From that perspective, Tagliabue can't stand in the way of owners who seek to relocate to those markets. Those moves would do nothing to damage the league's stability, he said. However, the relocations create hardened feelings among the loyal fans that teams leave behind.
The move from Cleveland is particularly wrenching for Browns fans who had loyally supported the team for the past 50 years. Tagliabue said it would be "jumping ahead" to talk about putting another team in Cleveland.
"The big 'if' is whether this move goes forward or not," he said. "Until we have the kind of report that I filed on the Rams and Raiders earlier this year and until we get to that league meeting in January, it is premature to assume that this is over and done with."
Asked to deal hypothetically with a Browns move to Baltimore, Tagliabue said he would have to get assurances from Government entities there that a total renovation would be made to Cleveland Stadium before he could make assurances about getting another N.F.L. team for the city. He said there are meetings scheduled for December with Cleveland Mayor Michael R. White and other city officials.
Any immediate placement of N.F.L. teams in cities that have lost them would have to come from the existing teams. Tagliabue said there won't be another round of expansion until the turn of the century.
After filing a $750 million antitrust lawsuit against the N.F.L. and NFL Properties, Jerry Jones said his plan to generate new sources of revenue through increased marketing by individual teams would head off the need of owners to seek a quick cash infusion by seeking new stadium deals in other cities.
"Jerry's views aggravate the problem and don't help solve the problem because there are two underlying realities about a sports league that you have to recognize to be successful," Tagliabue said. "You have to operate in markets of different sizes. And No. 2, winning and losing is cyclical. And by definition you're always going to have losing teams in a sports league. You have to sustain your stability in individual markets even when you are losing."
Tagliabue said he thinks a settlement of the lawsuits involving Jones is possible.
"When you say Jerry wants to dismantle Properties, it is a disservice to Jerry," Tagliabue said. "Jerry wants to build something new, which is what we have been doing here."
Tagliabue looks at all these issues confronting the league and puts them in historical perspective.
"If you go back 10 years we had the U.S.F.L. and other issues," he said, referring to the United States Football League. "Twenty years ago we had work stoppages and players strikes in the N.F.L. and the draft being ruled illegal. Going back 30 years, we had the A.F.L.-N.F.L. war. You always have issues. That is part of the reason this job is challenging."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Commissioner Paul Tagliabue said yesterday that N.F.L. upheaval is "a product of growth, expansion and success." (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)
