HEADLINE: CHELSEA DAWNING;
Digging for Flea-Market Treasures

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
London has Portobello Road and Paris the Marche aux Puces. In New York City, Chelsea is where many shoppers go for flea-market wares, collectibles and affordable antiques. What began almost 20 years ago as a one-block flea market, on the Avenue of the Americas from 24th to 25th Streets, has mushroomed into a three-block affair, from 24th to 27th Streets. It has also spilled around the corner: on 26th Street east of Avenue of the Americas, an old Con Edison power substation now holds something called the Annex, four parking lots filled with 400 to 500 open-air booths.
And that's just the tip of the iceberg. Over the years, a host of indoor antiques malls have opened in the neighborhood. Now there are such haunts as the Garage, at 112 West 25th Street; the Metropolitan Art and Antiques Pavilion, at 110 West 19th Street, and the Chelsea Antiques building, at 110 West 25th Street. As in the flea markets, the quality and selection at these indoor emporiums vary from week to week. Some days it's possible to find good pieces at bargain prices, other days it seems as though all the junk in the world has landed in Chelsea. 
 The weekend is when most of the action takes place. But a few spots, like the Chelsea Antiques Building, are open during the week, too. Buyers range from serious collectors, who are neighborhood regulars, to decorators shopping for clients and young couples furnishing their first apartments.
Often a celebrity makes a surprise appearance. Last weekend, Michael Jackson and an entourage of security guards arrived at the Garage in a nondescript van for an afternoon of shopping. Other recognizable regulars include Drew Barrymore, Barbra Streisand, Brad Pitt, Joanne Woodward and Bette Midler.
"Chelsea has become very vibrant," said Alan Boss, who owns and runs the two-year-old Garage, the open-air Annex Antiques Fair and Flea Market and the Metropolitan Art and Antiques Pavilion, which he opened in 1992. "Despite the shaky economy, I've noticed an upsurge in attendance."
Mr. Boss said that the charisma of outdoor markets is what drew everyone to Chelsea in the first place, but that now his Garage -- two 10,000-square-foot floors -- is filled with 125 dealers from Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey, Massachusetts and Connecticut. From time to time, European dealers from places like London and Amsterdam have exhibited, too. The merchandise in the Garage is similar to that in the outdoor flea market.
Whether outdoors or in, the shopping atmosphere is friendly. Dealers are more than happy to hear that magic sentence: "What's the best you can do?" And buyers invariably harbor secret fantasies of unearthing a discarded treasure that could be worth a fortune.
"The demographics of buyers have changed in tandem with the American economy," Mr. Boss said. "Decorative arts is the byword, rather than high-end antiques. So dealers now are trying to keep things accessible." That's not to say there isn't the occasional highly priced gem: a sapphire and platinum necklace can still command $10,000 to $15,000. But that kind of expensive item is not as easy to find as it was during the boom years of the late 1980's.
Many of the seasoned dealers cite a change in buyers over the years. With tourism rising in Manhattan, there are more foreign shoppers, and it's not unusual to hear many languages being spoken.
The three-block Avenue of the Americas flea market is usually their first stop. Here, it's possible to find everything from vintage clothes to bedroom sets and martini shakers. It's also a great spot for antique silver. On a recent Saturday, there were Victorian silver candlesticks for $40; silver ashtrays for as little as $10; silver Victorian picture frames from $4 to $35.
Furniture tends to vary a lot from week to week. There's usually a selection of 1920's wrought iron garden furniture and the odd sofa and chairs. Painted chests and vanities are usually plentiful, too.
One of the biggest categories by far is jewelry, everything from metal Victorian chokers and earrings to 1940's watches and Art Deco bracelets. Around the corner, at the Weekend Antiques Show on 25th Street, just east of the Avenue of the Americas, is a newer mart, with variations on the merchandise carried on the avenue itself. Silver is a big seller here, too. An Art Deco silver candy dish comes with a $225 price tag; a Gorham serving platter can be had for $165. Porcelains from the 19th and 20th centuries come in every shape imaginable, from dancing couples to cows. So do salt and pepper shakers, dating from World War II to the 1970's. Downstairs, along one wall, are prints and lithographs marked "Investment Grade Art." A recent selection included Chagall prints from $350 to $600 and a Francis Bacon lithograph for $475.
The Chelsea Antiques Building, at 110 West 25th Street, is open daily from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and consists of 12 floors (11 of them for dealers and one devoted to the Lubin Galleries Auction House.) There's also a little cafe for snacking. The building bills itself as "12 floors of exceptional estate treasures."
The assortment of goods is enormous. There's everything from grandma's standard oak Victoriana to Steuben glass and jewelry, from Russian icons to advertising tins and collectible toys, from Esthetic Movement and Art Nouveau lighting to vintage cookie jars. One particularly interesting floor is an antiquarian book arcade, a consortium of more than 62 dealers managed by the Bohemian Bookworm, run by Myrna Adolph-Morris and Ronald Morris, her husband. The business, which began almost three years ago, has every title computer-filed for easy access.
"We have a free search service," Mr. Morris said, adding that among current popular titles were Charles Dickens's "Christmas Carol," priced at $25 to $400 depending on the edition and its condition; Diana Vreeland's "DV," which sells for $65 to $75, and her "Allure," priced anywhere from $400 to $600. Detective stories are also hot. Patricia Cornwell's early works can fetch as much as $300.
"We came here because we wanted to take a chance and see whether antiques and fine books could mix," Mr. Morris said. "This area is proliferating. New Yorkers could do very well just shopping in Chelsea. All it takes is a discerning eye and patience."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
LOWER ESTIMATE FOR SHIPMENTS OF WINDOWS 95

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif., reduced by a third yesterday its forecast of Windows 95 shipments this year, saying sales of the Microsoft Corporation's operating system were slower than expected. Dataquest, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, said that Microsoft would ship fewer than 20 million copies by the end of the year, down from a projection of 30 million. Microsoft's shares fell $4.125 yesterday, to $89.875, as about 12.2 million shares were traded on Nasdaq. The slide was attributed primarily to a reduction in the stock's rating by Richard Sherlund, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company. Mr. Sherlund said Microsoft faced "a serious threat" from smaller, more nimble companies in Internet software.

HEADLINE: U.S. Should Embargo Nigerian Oil for Hanging

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The trial, conviction and hanging of Ken Saro-Wiwa by the discredited Nigerian regime of Gen. Sani Abacha (front page and editorial, Nov. 11) has provoked international outrage within Africa and beyond, including President Clinton's withdrawal of our Ambassador from Lagos and discussion of a condemnatory resolution by the United Nations Security Council.
But the United States can and should go further. The only language the Abacha regime understands is that of money and force, using the latter to divert the nation's oil revenues into private coffers as Nigeria's civil society continues to deteriorate. Let us hit this military strongman where it counts. 
 We should impose economic sanctions and an oil embargo immediately, and watch as the noose of political opposition and economic austerity tightens around General Abacha's neck. With our oil imports responsible for nearly half of Nigeria's petroleum revenues, an embargo would have immediate consequences.
Ken Saro-Wiwa should not be allowed to have struggled and died in vain. Poet, novelist, critic and activist in company with the likes of Wole Soyinka, Mr. Saro-Wiwa showed how oil, once Nigeria's lifeblood, has become the bad blood of rampant political corruption, financial fraud and environmental degradation.
And now, with his execution (following the military government's genocidal campaigns against the Ogoni people), Nigeria's oil revenues have become blood money.
Moreover, General Abacha's crackdown is just beginning. Mr. Saro-Wiwa's unconscionable death by the gallows represents a Mobutu-style leadership in the making, with wider purges of critics and pro-democracy activists -- many already jailed -- soon to follow. General Abacha must go. A few extra cents at our gasoline pumps is a small price to pay.
 
ANDREW APTER
Chicago, Nov. 11, 1995
 
The writer, an assistant professor of anthropology at the University of Chicago, specializes in Nigeria.

HEADLINE: Beijing Journal;
For 6, You Too Can Be a Sichuan-Style Sardine

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 16

 BODY:
"Hey, don't you know how to ride a train?" the woman on the Beijing subway yelled as she pushed past two peasants so overloaded with luggage that they were blocking the door. "Move over and make room for those of us who want to get off!"
It is rush hour in the Chinese capital and Beijingers, like so many surly sardines, are trying to get in and out of their frightfully overburdened subway system. 
 Riding on a mere 26 miles of underground track, the dilapidated trains of the Beijing subway are now carrying 1.46 million people a day. An estimated 70 percent of them are the transient laborers who have flooded the city to work at thousands of construction sites.
The Beijing system carries about 40 percent of New York City's passenger load, but on only 4 percent of New York's track miles. The average rail car here, designed to carry 180 people, now consumes about 300 passengers during rush hour.
Full body contact and brief, terrifying stampedes for the door are part of commuting life now, along with stale air and, perhaps, the whiff of a cow patty still wedged in the shoe leather of a visiting farmer.
"Most of the young women in my hospital don't take the subway because so many country bumpkins ride the subway, and they wear dirty clothes and carry dirty luggage," said Zhang Mei, a 27-year-old nurse from Beijing Hospital.
"You can't wear your pretty clothes and take the subway. By the time you get to work, your pretty clothes are filthy."
Her eyes narrowed as she spied her adversary.
"Look at those teen-agers," she said. "They are the typical bumpkins I am talking about."
The unkempt teen-agers are from Sichuan Province, population 105 million. Their hair stands as a tangled rebellion above ruddy cheeks. Each carries a quilt stuffed in a plastic fertilizer bag, standard luggage for frugal peasants who don't mind sleeping on sidewalks.
"We are all from Sichuan, but I don't want to give you my name," a 19-year-old said, in the thick patois of the southwest. "We do odd jobs and we live near the railway station," he said, quickly disappearing into the crowd.
Now that the harvest is over, the migrant population flooding into Beijing will push toward the two million mark and the capital's public transportation system, already overloaded, is approaching its limits.
"This job can be very tough," said 32-year-old Qi Yuan, who wore a smart, aquamarine uniform on the platform at a subway stop named Build the Nation. Her job is to yell at passengers to "hurry up!" and "don't push!" as they enter and exit the trains. When the doors stop banging against the body parts hanging over the threshold, Ms. Qi holds up a green paddle that serves as the "all clear" signal to the train conductor.
"When a train comes in, so many people rush the entrance that it can be dangerous," she said. "A lot of these country people simply don't know the safety rules and sometimes they get into fights over the seating."
Many Beijingers today attribute much of the surliness in the city to the clash between China's rural and urban populations as the country's economic boom sends more and more surplus farm laborers to the cities.
The "waidiren," which literally means "outsiders," are blamed for rising incivility, petty crime, drug addiction and the offense that really steams any Beijinger: bicycle theft.
This week the Beijing Youth Daily criticized the lack of "civilized behavior" in the subways. The semi-official newspaper lamented the fate of a ticket collector named Ms. Wang, who tried to apprehend four youths who dashed past the ticket booth without paying.
When she caught up with them, "instead of paying, the youths hit Ms. Wang and pushed her down into the rail pit, where she was so seriously injured that she was unconscious for more than two hours," the newspaper said.
Landing in the rail pit, the newspaper pointed out, is a loathsome predicament as many passengers find it a convenient place to spit and throw garbage.
While New Yorkers this month are howling over the $1.50 they now have to pay to ride one of the largest subway systems in the world, they might consider what becomes of a system that never raises its fares.
For one thing, it never becomes a system.
Beijing's subway, now 30 years old, could more aptly be described as a line with a loop and a lot of unfulfilled aspirations. It costs only 6 cents to buy a ticket to ride from one end to the other, or in a continuous loop. The eastern part of the city has no service; neither does the north nor the south.
The Beijing government has repeatedly suggested fare increases to finance operations and expansion, but the central Government, fearing a negative reaction from the masses, has demurred. A modest expansion that began in 1993 is already a year behind schedule.
A master plan that would more than triple the size of the current system gets reprinted in the newspapers every few years, but remains unfinanced.
To Beijingers of 50 and over, it is a well-known secret that when Mao Zedong first ordered construction of the subway in 1965, the project was part of his elaborate preparations for nuclear war, which he feared would be launched by the Soviet Union.
Initially, many Beijingers thought it strange that a single underground rail line was built from the western edge of downtown to the mountain range that flanks the city, a lopsided route that was inconvenient to more than half the city's dwellers.
But word spread from thousands of workers that Mao was using the subway construction to mask the building of an underground highway, parallel to the subway line. This highway would allow the Communist Party leadership to flee the city in the event of nuclear attack.
The highway is now used to ferry the leaders out to their golf resorts and weekend bungalows in the Western Hills.
As for the straphanging masses, many have moved above ground to join the gridlock on Beijing's once placid boulevards and others, like Li Li, a 27-year-old city accountant, travel off peak when they can.
At 10:43 A.M. one day this week, Miss Li was just heading for the office, more than two hours late.
"That's one of the advantages of working for the Government," she said in a tone that lacked the slightest trace of surliness. "We don't earn big money like those who work for foreign companies, but we don't have stress because we don't work very hard."

LENGTH: 1001 words

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Army Reported to Aid Bosnian Serbs Despite Promises

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG with KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
As President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia negotiates a peace settlement in Dayton, the army under his control is rebuilding the Bosnian Serb military in violation of Mr. Milosevic's own pledges, American and United Nations officials said today.
Yugoslav Army technicians have replaced the communications links blown up by NATO warplanes in air strikes two months ago and have repaired some of the air defense systems, the officials said. 
 The Yugoslav Army has also been routinely sending helicopters and transport planes loaded with supplies to the Bosnian Serb stronghold of Banja Luka, United Nations officials said.
American officials, however, said NATO radar had not picked up any flights into that airfield by transport aircraft. The officials said they have spotted some helicopters, and assume that others are flying low enough to evade detection.
American officials said they believed that the resupply of the Bosnian Serbs was on a comparatively small scale. "While we don't like it, it's wrong, and it's illegal," one official said, "it's not enough to justify torpedoing the peace process."
Another official said: "It's happening. But we don't think they're bringing in the heavy stuff. We don't think they're bringing in more howitzers and tanks."
A confidential United Nations report dated Oct. 30 -- two days before the peace talks opened at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base outside Dayton -- says that United Nations military observers on the ground have spotted "regular flights of military transport aircraft and helicopters into Banja Luka at night." Those flights have continued into this month, a United Nations official in the region said.
The report said the Bosnian Serb army's communications systems "have been resurrected by the Yugoslav Army, whose personnel are involved."
The document, which was signed by a senior military officer serving with the United Nations, said the Yugoslav Army was supplying spare parts to maintain the Bosnian Serbs' small fleet of warplanes.
Yugoslav Army technicians, the report said, were working on the planes at the Banja Luka airfield.
While the United States vociferously protested the Yugoslav Army's efforts to help the Bosnian Serbs rebuild after the NATO bombing, the criticism has been muted since the peace talks began.
One senior official speculated that Mr. Milosevic was allowing some ties between the Yugoslav Army and Bosnian Serb Army to persist as a means of preserving his credentials with his own military while he makes significant concessions in the peace talks.
"He has to tolerate a certain amount of activity to maintain control," one official said. "He's got to watch his back."
Mr. Milosevic promised to end such assistance to the Bosnian Serbs earlier this year in exchange for the lifting of some economic sanctions against his country. But American officials with access to intelligence reports say that, while Mr. Milosevic did not keep his word, he has curtailed the flow of fuel and ammunition in recent months.
The Yugoslav Army's continuing supply of arms and expertise to the Bosnian Serb military raises questions about both Mr. Milosevic and the stability of any peace treaty.
American officials acknowledge that the ultimate success of their peace effort depends largely on whether Mr. Milosevic delivers on his latest assurances in ways he has not done in the past. American officials argue that there are several reasons to believe that he will do this, including the proposed presence of a 60,000 NATO troops in Bosnia to enforce any peace plan and his desire to end his isolation from other countries.
Still, it remains unclear how the peace agreement would address the issue. A senior American official said the proposed peace settlement would bar the Yugoslav Army from sending military supplies and assistance to the Bosnian Serbs.
But Pentagon officials have made it clear that the international force will not be involved in patrolling the international borders, disarming the combatants, or blocking arms shipments.
American officials said they have circulated proposals to the parties that would set numerical limits on various categories of weapons each side could keep in its arsenal, just as the United States and Russia have reduced their conventional forces in Europe. Monitoring these limits, however, would probably be left up to international organizations like the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
The United States is likely to be the nation to bring the sides to parity by training and arming the Bosnian Government. A Bosnian official said today the European nations were resisting this proposal.
Paradoxically, deployment of the 60,000-member international force might actually make it easier for the Yugoslav Army to move military supplies to the Bosnian Serbs.
A principal demand of the Bosnian Serbs has been for the widening and safeguarding of the narrow corridor of land across Northern Bosnia through which most of the fuel and supplies from Yugoslavia have been flown or trucked. Croat and Bosnian government forces consider this stretch of land to be one of the most strategic in Bosnia, and have shelled and attacked what is called the Posavina corridor for most of the war.
The United Nations put monitors at the narrowest point of the corridor on Nov. 7, and during three days reported seeing large convoys of fuel trucks that are believed to have originated in Serbia. The monitors, a United Nations official said, were removed a few days later at the request of the Bosnian Serb Army.
The United Nations official said military observers in the region have spotted two types of transport helicopters flying into Banja Luka and some flights by fixed wing aircraft.
"These guys are mainly flying at night," he said. "But some of them are bold enough to come in during the day. We don't understand why NATO says they don't see them, because they are plainly visible and carrying Yugoslav Army inventory."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Congress and White House In Talks to End Impasse
 As the first cracks developed in the deadlock between the White House and Congress that has partly shut down the Government, the House of Representatives gave final approval to the mammoth Republican legislation to reverse the course of the American Government, and the Senate began its final debate on an identical bill. 
 President Clinton repeated that he would veto the bill. But top White House officials were at the Capitol negotiating a way to break the impasse and continue Government spending into December. [Page 1.]
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed as market participants awaited signs of progress on the budget negotiations. [38.]
 
Approval of Fat Substitute Backed
 The F.D.A.'s Food Advisory Committee recommended approval of a fat substitute, olestra, made by Procter & Gamble, despite testing by the company that showed some adverse gastrointestinal effects on people who consumed the product. The committee's recommendation is not binding, but the agency generally accepts its advice. [11.]
 
Brouhaha at CBS Grows Nastier
 The in-fighting grew nastier at CBS, where a management decision to block an interview on "60 Minutes" with a former tobacco- industry executive has led to widespread debate and recriminations. Morley Safer, a correspondent on the program, accused his longtime colleague, Mike Wallace, of using deceit to get him to complain publicly about the cancellation. [10.]
 
A Shift at RJR Nabisco Holdings
 RJR Nabisco Holdings said H. John Greeniaus, the 50-year-old food-marketing expert who has overseen the company's tobacco operations as well as its food business since July, would refocus his efforts entirely on food. Some analysts said the company might be preparing to spin off the food business, as the financiers Carl C. Icahn and Bennett S. LeBow have demanded. [37.]
 
California Threatens Insurers
 In California, where insurers and regulators have been at loggerheads since voters approved a proposition in 1988 giving the regulators powers to set profit targets and order price cuts and rebates, the state's Insurance Department threatened reprisals against companies that miss a meeting next week to discuss their progress. [37.]
 
Prudential Settlement Approved
 A Federal judge in Manhattan gave final approval to a $110 million settlement by Prudential Securities with thousands of investors participating in a class action lawsuit. The suit accused Prudential of engaging in a racketeering conspiracy in its fraudulent sale of limited partnerships in the 1980's. [36.]
 
Hewlett-Packard Net Up; Stock Off
 Hewlett-Packard reported a 42 percent profit jump to $678 million, or $1.29 a share, for its fourth quarter, exceeding analyst estimates, but Wall Street was not happy. The profit margin was under pressure, because much of the growth came from personal computers, which have lower margins than other computers, and the stock fell $4.75 to $88.50. [36.]
 
Polish Economy on Stable Course
 Poland's fiercely contested presidential runoff election is likely to make little difference to investors or to the country's economic outlook, business executives and analysts say. The country's economy has matured, and foreign investment is growing rapidly. [36.]
 
Fed Was Unanimous on Rates
 The Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, voted 11 to 0 to leave the target for the Federal funds rate at 5.75 percent on Sept. 26, minutes of the meeting showed. The rate, which applies to overnight bank loans, is the Fed's main vehicle for influencing interest rates. [38.]

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: MEDICAL CARE;
In G.O.P. Plan, Some See a Widening Gap Between Sick and Healthy

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB 

 BODY:
Along with reinventing the way medical care is provided to the elderly and poor, the Medicare and Medicaid legislation agreed to by House and Senate negotiators would profoundly change the nation's health insurance system, allowing companies to vastly increase the marketing of an encyclopedic array of policies to the nation's sickest people.
Republicans and other proponents hail the changes as fostering competition, creating greater personal choice and containing costs. But many critics, including consumer advocates and Democrats, fear that the changes would push the healthy and sick into different forms of coverage, which would tear at an underpinning of insurance: that the healthy subsidize the less healthy in plans to which they all belong. 
 The agreement was reached on Thursday by negotiators for the Republican majorities in the House and Senate, after the two chambers passed differing versions of legislation that would slash $435 billion in anticipated growth in seven years from Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, and Medicaid, which covers many poor people, the disabled and residents of nursing homes. The revised legislation is expected to be voted upon by both houses shortly.
Under the Medicare provision, 37 million elderly Americans would be allowed to leave the traditional Medicare program and use money from that program to sign up for managed care plans; plans of various sorts run by doctors; plans offered by unions and associations; traditional plans where members pay for each service they receive, or medical savings accounts, a favorite of Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Republican leadership.
They could also more easily buy "dread disease" policies, which insure against specific illnesses like cancer, but which have been strongly criticized by consumer groups.
To Republicans, opening this marketplace of options would hold down health care costs by making the elderly more responsible for their medical choices. "What comes out of all of this is a more innovative way to deliver more health care to more people at lower costs," said Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who heads the House Commerce Committee.
But critics worry that healthier Medicare recipients would join private plans, which would court them actively, leaving most of the sickest people isolated in the Government-run program. This, they say, could threaten the viability of the traditional program over time by causing escalating deficits. One result, they say, would be lower payments to doctors and hospitals that could lead them to leave the program.
The critics also contend that cuts in anticipated growth in Medicaid would lead states to curtail their rolls, creating what some social scientists predict would be millions more uninsured.
Republicans strongly dispute this, maintaining no one would lose insurance.
Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution, a Washington research center, was not as hopeful.
"Insurance companies and public programs will become leaner and quite literally meaner," Mr. Aaron said, "not because they're run by mean people, but because competitive pressures will force them to be so."
President Clinton has vowed to veto the final legislation. In an interview before the negotiators reached their agreement, Mr. Clinton's special assistant for health care, Chris Jennings, said the President had "grave concerns" about medical savings accounts and the prospect of "millions more uninsured" as a result of changes in Medicaid.
 
 
 
Encouraging a Shift To Private Plans
A hallmark of the Medicare legislation is the encouragement of private health plans, which now cover 10 percent of the program's recipients, grouped in a few regions.
Under the legislation, the elderly would be able to take an annual credit, on average more than $4,500, and use it to buy coverage. If the beneficiary signed with a managed care plan, the money would probably cover an annual payment for services at least equal to those under current Medicare, but access to doctors would probably be limited.
The Government would provide selection advice to recipients, monitor the plans' marketing and administer enrollment.
Larry Mayewski, an analyst with A. M. Best & Company, an insurance rating agency, estimated conservatively that 30 percent of Medicare recipients, or more than 10 million people, would enroll in the plans. Others predict more than twice the interest. Plans would likely try to entice consumers by offering more benefits than Medicare, like prescription drugs and eyeglasses, that would obviate the need for the supplemental policies that 70 percent of the program's recipients now buy.
But many experts fear a balkanization of healthy and sick.
A 1993 study of Medicare recipients who had joined health maintenance organizations found that healthier people disproportionately were attracted to the plans, causing the Government to lose rather than save money. Indeed, critics say, plans often target the healthy by offering items like credit for exercise classes.
While the managed-care industry disputed the findings of the 1993 study, Randall S. Brown, of Mathematica Policy Research Inc., who headed the effort, said he believed that sicker recipients stayed in the conventional program to insure that they could keep their own doctors, which is often impossible in managed care plans.
"If you're an 80-year-old person and you suffered a heart attack three years ago and a doctor saved your life, you're not going to give up that doctor for $50 a month," Mr. Brown said.
The ability of private associations to organize coverage for their members is a particular concern to many who are critical of the privatization, because, they say, groups representing the more affluent, who are generally healthier, could negotiate for better coverage. This would cause their members to leave the general pool even more quickly.
Uwe Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University, also said that cost figures almost compelled private plans to seek out the healthy.
In 1993, when the average Medicare expenditure per person was $4,030, the average for the healthiest 90 percent of recipients was only $1,430; the average for the sickest 10 percent was $28,000.
Gail Wilensky, who ran Medicare during the Bush Administration, said, "This is probably the single most serious technical problem we have to deal with, but the answer isn't to say, 'My God, we can't have choice.' "
Rather, Ms. Wilensky said, the Government should calibrate more finely payments for the elderly that reflect their health status. If healthier people sign with private plans, she said, they should take reduced sums with them, while sicker people should be credited with a total that reflects their cost of care.
Many professionals say that such analyses, while being explored, are extremely difficult to execute well.
 
 
 
Individual Approach To Containing Costs
 If some experts worry that managed care plans would skim healthy recipients from the conventional Medicare program, many of the large plans are concerned that the healthy would be skimmed from them by medical savings accounts.
These accounts have been championed by the Golden Rule Insurance Company of Indiana, whose political action committee contributed $621,775 to the Republican and Democratic National Committees since 1991, according to the public interest group Common Cause. All but $46,000 went to Republicans.
Since 1985, the committee has given $309,526 to Congressional candidates, including Mr. Gingrich. In addition, Golden Rule was the sponsor of a television show presided over by Mr. Gingrich, and company officials gave $35,000 this year to Gopac, the political committee Mr. Gingrich headed until last May.
The Speaker praised the savings account idea in his recent book.
Under the legislation, Medicare recipients could buy a high deductible plan, contributed to by Medicare, as long as they opened a medical savings account that the program could help fund with money left over after the insurance premium was covered. Interest on account balances would be tax free and surpluses could be rolled over each year.
Account money could be spent on anything, but nonmedical expenses would be subject to income taxes.
To proponents, the concept would work wonders at containing costs, because the elderly would have incentives not to seek unneeded care -- and would also have the security of catastrophic coverage.
"What medical savings accounts do is give seniors more control over their health care dollars," said Merrill Matthews Jr., health policy director of the National Center for Policy Analysis, a Dallas research group that has championed the idea and that also receives contributions from Golden Rule. "It gives them the ability to benefit financially from being a prudent health care shopper."
A study commissioned by the center, which included assumptions that its author wrote involved "significant uncertainty," predicted that the savings accounts would result in Medicare savings of $134 billion to $195 billion over seven years. But the Congressional Budget Office estimated that the bill would cost taxpayers $4 billion in that time.
Although Mr. Matthews said the accounts would be popular with sick and healthy alike, the budget office estimated that only 2 percent of Medicare beneficiaries would be interested and that they would likely be among the healthiest.
E. Richard Brown, head of the American Public Health Association, which represents public health professionals, said that in addition to siphoning the healthy and putting the traditional Medicare program at risk, the account concept "creates all the wrong incentives, incentives for people not to get preventive care" by allowing them to keep money they do not use.
The bill would also broaden the range of policies that could legally be sold to the elderly. And, in the eyes of critics, it would weaken a requirement that other policies include cautionary statements that they could duplicate coverage under Medicare or other plans.
Gail Shearer of Consumers Union, an advocacy group, said this provision would open up the sale of hospital indemnity and dread-disease policies to older people. Because these policies are more profitable to insurers than other types of insurance, Consumers Union has called them the worst buy in the market. State insurance commissioners have also criticized these policies.
From the mid-70's to the late 80's, scandals erupted in many states when older people, pressured by fear-mongering sales tactics, bought stacks of these policies, which often proved worthless.
Proponents of these policies argue that many plans have provided extra money for co-payments, deductibles and compensation for lost income. The excesses, they say, were caused by a few bad apples, and, they maintain, Congress never intended to simply outlaw the policies when it enacted safeguards five years ago.
Aflac, a Columbus, Ga., insurance company whose political action committee has contributed at least $1.76 million to candidates since 1987, is the country's largest cancer insurance carrier and has lobbied to relax restrictions on these policies.
 
 
 
Some See Millions Becoming Uninsured
In the Medicaid proposals, the $170 billion cut in projected spending over seven years has led many experts to fear that millions would become uninsured. The Urban Institute, a Washington research organization, estimated that more than eight million people who would have been covered by Medicaid in 2002 would likely be without insurance because hard-pressed states would be forced to keep them from the rolls.
In a recent paper for the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, Kenneth E. Thorpe, of Tulane University, estimated that the number of people with no health insurance could rise from today's roughly 40 million to as many as 66 million in 2002, when changes in Medicaid are combined with the rising number of employees who do not receive coverage through work.
Congressional Republicans headedly dispute these findings.
"Nobody wants to increase the number of uninsured people -- that would be crazy," said Mike Collins, spokesman for the House Commerce Committee. "We believe the basic premise of these studies is flawed and states, by utilizing managed care options, will be able to deliver a lot more bang for the buck."
John Holihan, an author of the Urban Institute study, said the use of managed care had figured in the study's computations.
"What we're getting more and more from people," Mr. Holihan said, "is that our assumptions are optimistic."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Poland's Vote No Big Worry For Investors

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Nov. 17

 BODY:
In a measure of Poland's economic maturity, the outcome of Sunday's fiercely contested presidential runoff election is likely to make little difference to investors or the country's economic outlook, business executives and analysts say.
Only two years ago, the idea of a former Communist as president would have unnerved investors. But for the last year, a former Communist, Jozef Oleksy, has served as Prime Minister, and Poland is headed for its fourth consecutive year of robust growth. Foreign investment is flowing in at a faster rate this year than last. 
 "We keep on investing and we're still closing deals," said Jacek Siwicki, senior vice president of the money management firm of Enterprise Investors, shrugging off the significance of the election. "The Polish system becomes more and more like the Italian system. The politicians fight each other and the economy goes on regardless."
Both President Lech Walesa, and his strong challenger, Aleksander Kwasniewski, a Communist turned social democrat, promise to continue the market-oriented economic policies of the last five years. Both eagerly want Poland to join the European Union and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which are regarded as the signature of acceptance from the West.
Mr. Siwicki, whose company has invested $270 million for the Polish American Enterprise Fund, a private corporation created by the United States Government to encourage Polish development, said he detected little apprehension among foreign investors about the possibility of a former Communist becoming Poland's President.
For most voters, the election revolves around symbols of the past. Mr. Walesa, 52, is viewed as the man who as head of the Solidarity movement ejected the Communists. Mr. Kwasniewski, 40, is seen as a university student who joined the Communist Party, became a top official, and now says the Communist era is dead and buried.
Many Walesa voters favor the President because they are uneasy about having former Communists control Parliament, the prime ministership and the presidency. The party of Mr. Oleksy and Mr. Kwasniewski, the Democratic Left Alliance, is composed of former Communists and dominates Parliament.
But business leaders, particularly those heading foreign companies, say ideology matters little. It was the Government, headed by Mr. Oleksy, that influenced exchange rates and inflation. The president's power is largely limited to the right to initiate and veto legislation.
If Mr. Kwasniewski wins, it is unlikely that his presidency will dampen economic growth, which is expected to exceed 6.5 percent this year, business leaders said. Reservations about Poland among foreign investors began to fall away this year, with $1 billion pouring in during the first five months compared with $1.3 billion for all of 1994. Exports were up nearly 39 percent in dollar terms in the first half of 1995 and industrial production rose 13 percent in the same period.
"With stable growth and a huge market, Poland is seen as the place to be," said Louisa Vinton, editor of Business Eastern Europe, a weekly report on finance in the region. "Kwasniewki's party are reform Communists and they know a good system when they see it. If he wins, the wheels will keep on moving in the way they have."
The head of GE Capital's new office here, Leslaw Kuzaj, said he was confident that the economy would continue to grow whatever the result.
"We won't have any problems either way -- if Kwasniewski wins or Walesa wins," he said. "Both candidates have declared their openness to the West. In the very beginning of the transition everything was so fragile but now we see a steady course."
Mr. Kuzaj said that with the Polish economy "so closely tied to the West, it's really unthinkable that the guy who wins can change course."
"The only thing we could expect," he added, "is some slowing down but I don't see that because everyone wants to join the European Union."
The Gerber Products Company, one of the early foreign investors, has doubled production of baby food at its plant in the southeast in the last year, and its managing director, Ryszard Wojtkowski, himself a former Government official, said that the company's growth would continue whoever was president.
If Mr. Kwasniewski wins, it is possible that privatization of big Government-owned entities -- already off to a slow start -- may falter a bit more, Mr. Wojtkowski said. Similarly, the former Communist may have to heed the trade unions' worries about job cutbacks. But these were matters of shading, he suggested.
In the stock market, which has been in a slump since mid-September, there are few signs of discomfort from investors about a former Communist gaining the presidency.
"We had an autumn conference for investors and we asked what they thought if Kwasniewski won," said David Young, director of Wood & Company, a brokerage house run by Americans. "They didn't see that much difference. They look at his policies, they see that he knows what he's doing, that he knows how to handle himself with the unions."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Business leaders say they are not concerned about Sunday's presidential runoff election in Poland, between President Lech Walesa, right, and Aleksander Kwasniewski, a Communist turned social democrat. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: At Bosnian Peace Talks, the Tunnel With the Light at the End Is Very Long

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President, has a new joke: "You know what Dick is short for?" he asks, referring to Richard C. Holbrooke, the American mediator at the Bosnian peace talks here. "Dictator!"
Over the last several days Mr. Holbrooke, an Assistant Secretary of State, has tried every shade of bullying diplomacy to bridge the differences between Serbs, Muslims and Croats. He has harassed his interlocutors day and night; he has cajoled; he has wined and dined. 
 But differences that have killed more than 200,000 people remain.
"The parties have a very clear sense that it's now or never," said one senior official. "But it's still possible they will choose never."
That choice, in all likelihood, has to be made this weekend. Secretary of State Warren Christopher arrived this evening, and he is expected to remain until the end of the talks.
With the talks in their third week, Defense Secretary William J. Perry and Gen. George A. Joulwan, the commander of NATO forces in Europe, came to Dayton today for a one-day visit. Their presence, officials said, is intended as much to convey a sense of American power and that power's determination to achieve a settlement, as to deliver any 11th-hour formula for peace.
Bosnian officials said they asked Mr. Perry for a memorandum setting out how American military assistance would be provided to the Bosnian Army after any settlement. The United States has indicated it would be ready to assist the Muslim-Croat federation to achieve a balance of power with the Serbs.
The officials said Mr. Perry expressed understanding but made no firm commitments.
Other, deeper problems remain: land and justice.
In a letter sent today by the Foreign Minister, Muhamed Sacirbey, to Mr. Holbrooke, Bosnia demanded that "any agreement, and especially as it relates to any potential easing of sanctions, must include a commitment from the parties to fully cooperate and comply with the war crimes tribunal and its orders." Among those indicted by the tribunal is the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic.
The Clinton Administration has taken the position that those indicted must be "excluded from the political process" in Bosnia. The Administration is also insisting that those who sign any peace accord must "cooperate" with the tribunal.
But the Bosnian Government says this falls far short of ordering compliance. Bosnia insists that any state harboring the suspects face economic isolation until those indicted are handed over to the tribunal.
Territorial issues remain even more difficult. Throughout Yugoslavia's disintegration, not an inch of territory has changed hands through anything but force.
The Serbs have now promised to yield Eastern Slavonia, the last part of Croatia they still hold. But that is not yet done. And Mr. Holbrooke and his aides are still trying to persuade Serbs and Muslims to cede Bosnian land now in the interests of peace.
The land the Serbs have to give up lies in eastern Bosnia. At the very least, officials said, the Serbs have to provide the Government with a corridor to link Sarajevo with Gorazde, the one surviving Muslim enclave.
But the Serbs' position, as summed up by one official, has been, "Don't worry, we'll let people come and go from Gorazde." Of late, after more than three years of siege, the Serbs have indeed done that -- but the Government wants access to Gorazde that it controls and can secure.
Inch by inch, therefore, Gen. Wesley Clark, the official on Mr. Holbrooke's team who deals mainly with "map questions," has been trying to fashion an acceptable corridor. This effort has made some progress but is still a long way from success.
A central problem is that the Serbs, who seek complete control of eastern Bosnia, have deep misgivings about Gorazde's remaining a Government-controlled city. Mr. Milosevic, according to one person who has spent time with him, regularly refers to it with a vulgarity as "that place at the end of the world."
The land the Government has to cede lies around the narrow corridor south of Brcko that connects Serbia with Banja Luka, the main Serb-held city in Bosnia. The Serbs want to widen the corridor; the Government would prefer to eliminate it and thus gain access to the Sava River. "If the Gorazde corridor is still a sticky issue, the Brcko corridor is even stickier," one official said.
Behind these arguments lies the fact that the logic of war is far from eliminated in the minds of officials here: some of the worst fighting and worst massacres of the war have taken place in the last six months.
Gorazde is more than a mere town: it is, for the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, a potential strategic gateway to eastern Bosnia and cities from which hundreds of thousands of Muslims have been chased. If Sarajevo can supply Gorazde, which already has an arms factory, the balance of power in the area may eventually shift.
Similarly, the Serbian corridor at Brcko is more than a strip of land: it is the last slender strand by which President Milosevic's vision of an enlarged Serbia hangs after the loss of Serb-held territory in Croatia. If this connection to Banja Luka is lost or remains vulnerable, the Serbs may prove unable to keep the 48 percent of Bosnia they still hold.
Mr. Holbrooke has been trying to push a vision of peace as healer. He is asking the Balkan leaders to look forward rather than back, to honor the dead through construction of a civil society rather than with a long struggle for revenge.
To this end, Mr. Holbrooke took Haris Silajdzic, the Bosnian Prime Minister, out to dinner Wednesday at L'Auberge, a giant leap from the fast-food places that surround Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, where the talks are being held. The Assistant Secretary of State ordered caviar; he talked of the future.
Afterward Christopher Hill, another member of Mr. Holbrooke's team, was dispatched to Mr. Silajdzic's suite, clutching a map. The Prime Minister in an excellent mood. Compromise was in the air. But in the light of day, old difficulties keep returning.

HEADLINE: Trenton Seeks H.M.O. Disclosure Of Doctors' Financial Incentives

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
In an effort to strengthen the hand of patients dealing with the state's rapidly growing health maintenance organizations, New Jersey health officials today proposed requiring that H.M.O.'s disclose any financial incentives they offer participating physicians to hold down medical expenses.
The proposed disclosure rules were among a series of provisions made public today as the state announced its first overhaul of the rules governing H.M.O.'s in more than two decades. Health maintenance organizations, which provide services in exchange for a fixed fee, are the fastest growing segment of the state's health care industry. Enrollment has increased from 100,000 in 1974, when the state first began regulating health maintenance organizations, to 1.4 million today. The state expects membership to exceed two million by the end of next year. 
 Some physicians and consumer groups have said disclosure is necessary so that patients know whether a doctor has any financial incentive to limit treatment or services and so that patients understand that some organizations pressure doctors. New York State, which has already revamped its regulations on H.M.O.'s, is also considering adopting a similar disclosure rule.
Under the proposed New Jersey rules, patients would be able to appeal to the state when they believe they have had services curtailed or denied, but the state's recommendation would be nonbinding. The health maintenance organizations would be required to file extensive reports with the state on services ranging from the number of children they immunize to the number of women receiving mammographies. In addition, the organizations would have to be recertified every three years. The state also plans to conduct membership surveys and publish a consumer guide to H.M.O.'s. "We have a package that I believe is the most progressive, consumer-oriented set of regulations ever proposed in this country," said State Health Commissioner Len Fishman. "We need to promote consumer protection and consumer confidence in H.M.O.'s."
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said the regulations were needed to assure fairness for patients while shielding New Jersey's 26 H.M.O.'s from undue state interference.
"What the commissioner is seeking to achieve with these regulations is a balance that will allow the citizens to feel comfortable that they are going to be well cared for within the H.M.O. structure, that they will have a voice," Governor Whitman said in a radio interview this afternoon.
At the same time, the Governor said, the regulations are intended to assure that H.M.O.'s retain "the flexibility to capture the kinds of savings that are unique to their organizations."
The financial disclosure segment of the regulations would require health maintenance organizations to provide details of their arrangements with doctors not only to the state but also in advertising and marketing materials to subscribers. Some health maintenance organizations now award bonuses to physicians who use less than the amount of funds allocated to cover payment for referrals to specialists and some services. State officials said this arrangement might influence physicians to refer fewer patients to specialists. Under the old fee-for-service system, doctors had virtually no reason not to refer patients to a specialist when they deemed it appropriate.
Neil Weisfeld, deputy executive director of the Medical Society of New Jersey, said the change is needed. "Physicians feel that they are under pressure," Mr. Weisfeld said, "and when they make a decision that is in the patient's interest but may not be in the H.M.O.'s interest, they are going to pay the price for that."
The new rules would prohibit H.M.O.'s from retaliating against doctors who side with the patient in a dispute over care. And the rules would require that only a state-licensed physician could deny or limit a request for a proposed course of medical service.
The Medical Society, which represents 9,500 doctors in the state, also welcomed the proposed changes.
"We are cautiously optimistic that the proposed regulations will require all H.M.O.'s operating in New Jersey to guarantee patients and providers various rights concerning their health care treatment and options," said Dr. Fred M. Palace, a past president of the society and a member of the Health Department's H.M.O. advisory committee.
But some health maintenance organizations complained that the proposed regulations tilted state policy in favor of the traditional fee-for-service doctors, who would be able to operate under a simpler regulatory burden.
"We're going to have, on one side, 'everything you ever wanted to know about H.M.O.'s but were afraid to ask,' but nothing about the fee-for-service practitioners," said George Strumpf, vice president of H.I.P. Health Plan, which operates large H.M.O.'s in New York and Florida, as well as in New Jersey.
Mr. Fishman said the extensive reporting requirements would produce a body of data that, for the first time, would give the state a clear picture of how health care is being delivered to a major segment of the population, and would also enable the state to monitor the evolving health care marketplace.
Dale Florio, spokesman for the New Jersey H.M.O. Association, said that the association was still reviewing the proposed regulations and would probably seek some changes. Mr. Florio's association is a member of a 32-member H.M.O. advisory committee made up of labor unions, physicians and other health industry officials that will offer recommendations for changes in the proposed rules by the end of December.
The rules will then be made available for public comment for 30 to 60 days, before becoming final next May.
Both Mr. Florio and Dr. Allan L. Hillman, director of the Center for Health Policy at the University of Pennsylvania, warned that imposing regulations on health maintenance organizations without regulating other forms of health care delivery would create inequities in the marketplace.
"Everyone should have the burden of regulations or we should stay out of it," Mr. Hillman said. "They are making it harder for H.M.O.'s to be a profitable and efficient business. It is the marketplace that is running health care now."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Pound Off Sharply vs. the Mark, Diverting Attention From Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday, as a sharp drop in the British pound against the German mark diverted currency traders' attention from the budget impasse in Washington.
The pound fell as low as 2.1680 marks -- below its previous low of 2.1755 marks, set in May -- on concerns that the budget being prepared for Britain would include tax cuts. There was further pressure on the pound from speculation that British interest rates would be moving downward. The pound, which had been falling in previous sessions, later recovered slightly. 
 "We've been close to the lows for the better part of the week," said David Gilmore, partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics. "People were just looking for an opportunity to take them out. It doesn't come as much of a surprise."
 Dealers said the selling of the pound started after the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, spoke favorably about current policy on setting inflation targets. The markets interpreted the comments as a sign that British interest rates could fall early next year.
The dollar gained against the pound, which slipped to $1.5445 in New York, from $1.5557 on Thursday.
The dollar lost ground against the mark for most of the day, but regained strength after holding above the key level of 1.3975 marks, where huge orders to sell would have set in.
"Dollar/mark looked as if it was going to take a leap off the precipice but it pulled back," a dealer at a major investment bank said.
 In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.4060 marks, down from 1.4069 marks on Thursday. The dollar slipped to 102.05 Japanese yen from 102.09 yen. It also fell to 1.1387 Swiss francs from 1.1385.
While concerns over the budget impasse in Washington dragged the dollar down earlier in the week, some traders were heartened yesterday by what they saw as signs of movement by Republican Congressional leaders and the White House.
President Clinton sent his own stopgap legislation to Congress that would end the partial Government shutdown, while Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, said the Senate might soon vote on a piecemeal spending bill.
"Some of the news out of Washington was interpreted as fairly positive," said Lizbeth Goldberg, a dealer at Bayerrische Hypobank. "That's one reason why we traded up a little bit."

HEADLINE: Blue-Collar Bridgeport Loses Catalyzing Jobs

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Cases of juices and platters of pastries had barely been wheeled into the State Senate chamber this morning when Gov. John G. Rowland, in shirt sleeves, entered a caucus room to make his final argument for a casino in Bridgeport, the state's largest city.
"The issue today is jobs," Mr. Rowland said. And if Bridgeport did not get a casino, he did not know where else the city would find any. 
 "You've heard me say a thousand times where are the businesses that are moving into Bridgeport?" Mr. Rowland said. "If this goes down today I don't know what's next for Bridgeport."
Hours later the Senate rejected casino gambling in Connecticut outside of Indian reservations, killing an $875 million casino plan with 10,000 jobs proposed for Bridgeport. The manufacturing city has lost 70 percent of its factory jobs over the last 25 years.
To the casino's impassioned supporters, the rejection was a brutal slap at a blue-collar city that has never had the respect of its wealthy suburban neighbors in Fairfield County, much less of the state. While legislators approve tax breaks for the Swiss Bank to move to corporate Stamford and train subsidies for commuters to Manhattan, the casino advocates said, Bridgeport's hard-working residents, who want only to earn living wages in their own city, get nothing.
"Its residents are not thought of in the context of your neighbors," Senator Alvin W. Penn, Democrat of Bridgeport, said in a plea laced with bitterness and anger. "It's always negative. What do we have to do to be part of the State of Connecticut?"
But the 24-to-10 vote against a casino was not a vote against Bridgeport, people on both sides said, as much as a declaration that however badly the city needs an economic catalyst, a casino as proposed in this bill was not worth the perceived cost to the rest of the state.
Opposition from the parimutuel industry melded with concerns about the casino's possible effects on traffic, the wisdom of the state's relying on gambling revenue as casinos multiply, moral objections and doubts that a single casino could turn around Bridgeport, when 12 had not rebuilt much smaller Atlantic City.
"As long as this was cast as a vote about Bridgeport and about jobs, that was putting the bill in its most favorable light," said Senator George C. Jepsen, Democrat of Stamford, who voted no. "To state the obvious, although a casino may have been located in Bridgeport its impact would be much wider. The people who voted against it did so for a hundred reasons."
Mr. Jepsen said Mr. Rowland could have swung the vote the other way, had he done more to use his office's influence. As the day of the vote neared, Mr. Jepsen said, opponents had 19 votes in the Senate, 2 more than they needed to avoid a 17-17 tie that Lieut. Gov. M. Jodi Rell would have broken in favor of a casino.
Mr. Rowland agreed on the magnitude. "We were expecting either a 24-10 vote or a 17-17 vote," he said afterward, explaining that several senators had offered to be the 17th vote for a casino if the administration had 16, but had then switched to the winning side when it was clear the bill would fail.
Mr. Rowland, however, also insisted that he had not overstated the dire condition of Bridgeport and its lack of alternatives. But the Legislature is focusing on the need to find new industries for the city, he said, and his administration will propose concrete solutions in the next session.
Even as Bridgeport advocates like Senator Lee Scarpetti complained that suburban legislators were selfishly denying her city an opportunity to help itself, others noted that Bridgeport itself had been focused on a casino as its sole solution for years.
"One of the things that has held off development for years has been the question of whether a casino was going to come in," said Senator James T. Fleming, Republican, an opponent of casino gambling. "We now can get on with other forms of economic development."
Bridgeport has a long tradition of wishing for new businesses that run up against its gritty industrial image and its notoriety as Connecticut's murder capital in the early 1990's, when drug gangs took over the poorest neighborhoods.
Bridgeport has a detailed 10-year strategic plan for economic development, drawn up last year in a bid to win a Federal "economic empowerment" zone. But one goal, in a city that readily acknowledges that suburbanites fear it, is to establish a downtown theater district. Another goal is to attract telecommunications industries. A third objective calls for developing tourism.
In the casino vote, however, the city found again that the rest of the state did not share its faith in large visions. Although residents boast of living in the state's largest city -- a distinction gained because New Haven and Hartford have lost population faster -- even Mr. Rowland challenged senators to recall the last time that they had stopped in the city for dinner.
The distance from the centers of the state's life leaves many residents still unsure of the source of their calamity or whom to blame. "They're trying to isolate Bridgeport and kill it," said Fred Thibodeaux, one of 300 residents who traveled here today to rally in support of a casino. "For some reason or other, we are low on the food chain, very low on the food chain."

HEADLINE: Another Day Of Records For Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average flirted with the 5,000 level yesterday as the Standard & Poor's composite index reached its own milestone, surpassing 600 for the first time.
The Dow rose as high as 4,996.81 during the afternoon but finished at 4,989.95, up 20.59 points for the day. That close still set a new high for the 59th time in 1995, matching the record for new highs in one year -- set in 1925 and tied in 1964. But the champagne bought to celebrate 5,000 had to be kept on ice for at least one more weekend. 
 The S.& P. 500, an index followed more by money managers, rose 2.73 points, to 600.07. The milestone was the second for the index this year; the S.& P. first reached 500 less than eight months ago.
Both the Dow and the S.& P. are now up more than 30 percent in 1995. For much of the year, it was technology stocks -- particularly semiconductor issues -- that led the way. But the most recent advances have come despite softness in that sector. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index fell 2.13, to 229.19, and is now down 24 percent from the record set in September.
"The emotional moves are being felt with money coming out of high-tech areas, and moving into the oils," said David J. Olderman, the chairman of Carret & Company, an investment management firm in New York. "Financial stocks are holding their own and still going up."
Much of the strength in the Dow came from oil stocks. Texaco rose 1 1/8, to 71, while Exxon gained 1 1/2, to 79 3/8. Du Pont, the owner of Conoco, added 1 1/8, to 64 1/2. Oil prices have been strong in advance of a meeting next week of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
But I.B.M. was down 1/2, to 95 1/8, and Hewlett-Packard fell 4 3/4, to 88 1/2, after warning of a profit margin squeeze in personal computers.
The lag in technology stocks has also been seen in the indexes of smaller stocks. The Nasdaq composite climbed just 0.55 point yesterday, to 1,045.03, while the American Stock Exchange market value index added 2.50, to 531.96. The Russell 2,000 index of smaller companies climbed 1.04, to 303.84. All three indexes are well below peaks reached in mid-September.
Nonetheless, the attention was on the bigger stock indexes yesterday. The Dow put on a strong run that began shortly after 3:30 P.M., aided by buying related to expiration of stock index futures and options. The index rose to almost 4,997 a bit before 3:45, but it then fell back.
The bond market was quiet, with the price of the 30-year Treasury bond falling only slightly as the yield inched up to 6.23 percent, from 6.22 percent on Thursday, its lowest level since early 1994, just before the Federal Reserve began to tighten credit. Many market participants now believe that the Fed will resume easing credit as soon as the current budget battle in Washington is resolved. Despite much rhetoric, that fight has so far not alarmed investors.
Most of Wall Street remains firmly bullish on stocks, pointing both to the continued inflow of cash into mutual funds and to economic factors. "This economic cycle has a long way to go," said Abby Joseph Cohen, co-head of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The economy is slow, but will accelerate. Profit growth will accelerate. Inflation is under very good control. Interest rates are benign from the standpoint of the equity markets."
The market for initial public offerings remained strong. Estee Lauder, the cosmetics company, sold shares at $26 but they never traded in the open market below 32 3/8 and closed at 34 1/2. Canadian National Railways, a Government privatization, was sold in an offering at 12, but ended the first day of trading at 15.
But the most amazing initial public offering was from Secure Computing, a company that provides products intended to protect computers from unauthorized users. It is viewed as a play on the Internet -- an area that has not gone soft among technology stocks. Last month, Secure said it would sell stock at $13 to $15 a share. It wound up going public at 16, and closed yesterday at 48 1/4, more than triple the offering price.
The new stock sales came at the end of the busiest week for initial public offerings in almost two years, as 21 companies sold shares to raise almost $3 billion.

HEADLINE: Fed Panel's September Vote Was 11-0 for Steady Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in holding an important short-term interest rate steady on Sept. 26, minutes of the meeting showed today.
The Fed's policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, voted 11 to 0 to leave the target for the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans at 5.75 percent. By changing the interest rates it controls, the Fed's actions translate into lower or higher borrowing costs on everything from home mortgages to industrial loans. 
 The committee meets eight times a year at intervals of five to eight weeks. While its meetings are closed, minutes are released several weeks later.
At the most recent meeting on Wednesday, committee members again decided to leave the target for the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans unchanged. The Federal Open Market Committee next meets Dec. 19.
Minutes from Sept. 26 showed the Fed officials decided to maintain a neutral policy stance, meaning they were neither inclined to raise nor lower interest rates.
But some panel members suggested that interest rates might have to be lowered eventually, "in light of the downside risks that they saw in the economy and a current policy stance that they viewed as slightly restrictive."
The Federal Open Market Committee last lowered rates at its July 6 session, the first reduction in three years. The quarter-point cut, to 5.75 percent from 6 percent, was intended to prevent the economy from falling into recession.
Throughout 1994 and early this year, the Fed increased rates a total of seven times in an effort to slow the economy's growth rate to a pace of about 2.5 percent a year, well below last year's 4.1 percent rate.
When Fed officials decide to lower the Federal funds target rate, they direct the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to buy Treasury bills, notes and bonds on the Fed's behalf in financial markets.
This action pumps money into the banking system, pushing rates lower and allowing commercial banks to charge each other a lower interest rate on overnight loans.

HEADLINE: A BID for Reform

 BODY:
Business Improvement Districts have been a godsend during a time of municipal austerity. There are 34 BID's in New York City. Commercial property owners pool their resources to hire extra street cleaners, security guards and graffiti removers. The BID's can take partial credit for some of the city's most conspicuous success stories, including Bryant Park, the revitalized Times Square and the upbeat look along 14th Street.
But a survey by the City Council Finance Committee has disclosed a troubling side to the BID phenomenon. A few BID's are in financial chaos. Others spend much of their income on overhead and little on actual services. One BID in Brooklyn employed sweepers who demanded extra money from store owners for cleaning sidewalks they had already been paid to sweep. Another in Queens was mired in conflicts of interest. 
 Many of the problems spotlighted in the Council report -- high directors' salaries, ineffective marketing programs -- are non-issues as long as the people paying for the BID are satisfied with the way it works. It seems clear that some of the smaller BID's exist mainly to decorate commercial areas for the holidays and organize parades, which is fine if those are the members' priorities. But the Council raises serious questions about whether property owners are always properly informed about what they are paying for.
The most important issue is governance. Boards of directors ought to be broadly representative of the communities they serve and must operate under procedures that are open and accountable. Their executive committees must meet frequently enough to exert meaningful influence.
The BID's themselves are attempting to establish criteria for proper management and open government. Such self-policing should be encouraged. But the city should hold BID's accountable for their performance and step in if they fall short. The city not only charters the BID's, it serves as their collection agency, sending property owners assessment bills and imposing fines for late payment. As long as the city plays that role, it has a responsibility to make sure the BID members are not suffering from taxation without representation.
Some of the report's proposals are too detailed for organizations that already struggle with more than their share of city paperwork. It would be wiser to give the new self-regulation a chance before adding too many more requirements. But others, like banning BID's from contracting out services outside their boundaries, should be adopted immediately. The districts are supposed to be economic development vehicles, not mini-municipalities unto themselves. On the whole, the Council report is a rare and welcome example of the over sight the city's legislature is supposed to exercise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Loyalty Issue Crystallizes On Mattingly

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

 BODY:
WHEN Bob Watson, the Yankees' new general manager, says that he plans to take the team in a new, bold direction, I say "Amen."
Even if it means reassigning the congenial Gene Michael, even it means pushing the hard-working company man Buck Showalter to the desert. And yes, even if it means drastically reducing the role of Don Mattingly, the team's most consistent symbol of Yankee tradition. 
 Mattingly and the Yankees will eventually determine a course. The public posture is that the veteran first baseman will tell the Yankees whether he will return next season. The bottom line, however, is that the Yankees will tell Mattingly under what circumstances they will allow him to return.
Watson, a forthright, straight shooter as a player and as a successful general manager, has grand plans for the Yankees.
I like the Yankees' talk of New Directions.
When it was time to hire a new general manager, George Steinbrenner, to his credit, didn't dip into the old, old-boy network. He hired a successful new face, the best person for the job. A former Yankee.
Watson wants to acquire a second baseman, he wants to bolster his pitching staff, he wants to dramatically increase run production.
Russ Davis, the 26-year-old third baseman, must be in the lineup in the spring. Will Wade Boggs move to first? Will he remain at third? Will the Yankees sign a Fred McGriff-caliber first baseman?
Mattingly, the author of a brilliant 13-year career, must determine how, or if, he fits into the new scheme. Even if the Yankees decide to keep him, where will he play and how often?
More offense. A veteran coaching staff. The Yankees are almost where they need to be.
Showalter is where he needs to be, too: out of the major leagues for the next two seasons, preparing to take over an expansion team.
The Yankees, on the other hand, are close -- maybe a run producer away.
The issue before the Yankees is: What do they owe Mattingly? What do they owe the fans? This is not a matter of performance, but of loyalty.
"If he wants to come back," Watson said on Thursday, "he understands that the money can't be astronomical. He understands that it has to make some kind of economic sense and baseball sense."
For team owners, agents and athletes, balancing economic sense with sports sense and loyalty is the great challenge of the 90's. The mission has become a breathtaking, heartbreaking process of trial and error.
Everyone, including Mattingly, knows that he is not the great player he was. The issue before the Yankees, then, is not a performance issue, but a fundamental issue of loyalty. The question for the franchise is how important is loyalty when you're trying to win a pennant.
And for the so-called downtrodden, misused fans, the question is do you want relics or a championship? Fans will invariably choose winning.
Players were once prisoners of the owners. They fought and won free agency. Franchises were prisoners of the notion that movement was the exception, not the rule. They, too, have rebelled and have created a class of free-agent teams.
The last tinge of pain I felt in sports came when the Colts moved from Baltimore to Indianapolis. It occurred to me then that nothing was sacred. Baltimore is now getting the Browns from Cleveland, Nashville is getting the Oilers from Houston. (Won't somebody please take the Jets?)
"It makes you wonder what happened to loyalty," said Art Taylor, an associate director of the Center for the Study of Sport in Society. "What happens to the fans in those cities who totally identify with those teams?"
The fans will wait for another team or another Mattingly. Pro sports is simply strip mining. There are no rules, no regulations. Loyalty is not the central theme of this game, not for players, not for fans.
Perhaps part of the Yankees' new direction should be keeping Mattingly, for tradition's sake, getting out of him what they can get on the field and sending him into the bloodstream of the city. Tradition is important.
I never cried over sports heroes; the heroic act was always more appealing than the hero. Traditional values were also appealing: it's not whether you win or lose but how you play the game that counts. That sentiment must coexist with Al Davis's admonition to "Just win, baby."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
