HEADLINE: Observer;
Let's Get Sore!

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
It's time to give class warfare a chance. The Republicans had me muzzled a long time on this subject, but no more.
"Let the class warfare begin!" is my cry to all who are fed up with outrageously overpaid rock stars and industrial tycoons, with $12 million lunkheads in jockstraps and overgrown boy billionaire egomaniacs from Hollywood. 
 And let's not forget investment bankers and Wall Street lawyers drawing down zillions for merger-and-acquisition paperwork. It's time for class warfare on them all.
Let there be class warfare too on the gazillionaires for whom the abovementioned overpaid flunkeys toil so that great companies may be successfully merged, acquired and ruined and flattering newspaper articles composed to honor these masters of the superbuck way of life.
The Republicans say it is demagogic to complain about this disgusting redistribution of the country's wealth. A few years ago Republicans would have called such discussion "Communistic." A few years ago, however, is ancient history as Americans now measure time, and few can remember the shivers of terror that racked us when someone in that ancient past said "Communistic."
Instead, Republicans now talk of "class warfare." It invites "class warfare," they say, to mention the obvious about the economy; to wit, that while the rich are getting richer and the poor getting poorer, middle-class families now need two incomes just to stand still.
What finally emboldens me to cry out for class warfare is the news that the AT&T Corporation is going to dump 77,800 workers -- half its supervisory work force. For people like me, it is a murderous blow to our faith in American capitalism.
For people like me, faith in AT&T was once as unshakable as the faith of our fathers in ages past. Neighbors and relatives who had jobs with "the telephone company" were thought to be blessed. Even people who hated Wall Street owned a few shares of AT&T, if they could afford it.
It was the great corporation as the embodiment of security, dependability, loyalty and competence. It was capitalism as an ideal. It was big business as everyone's friend.
And now -- nearly 78,000 workers gone. And managerial workers too. All to be dumped on a labor market offering few hopes for the kind of people accustomed to thinking of life as a steadily upward progress.
It tempts me to shout, like some demented football coach, "Hey! What's happening to America when AT&T dumps on its own people?"
Well, the usual answer is: "Good things are happening to the country, coach. It's just people that bad things are happening to."
The misfortunes of people are what economists dismiss as "anecdotal evidence" about the state of the nation. It is statistics, not people with their irrelevant anecdotal problems, that tell the real story. Which goes like this:
The "downsizing" of the country's work force has been under way for several years, and for sound and excellent reasons. To compete in a world market, American industry must increase productivity, and firing people is one way of doing it. If the economic statistics are right -- and sometimes they are -- productivity has indeed risen in the United States since the "downsizing" began.
So runs the comfy tale of the statistics. If you are in the market for class warfare, there are other statistics that may sharpen your urge to set up the guillotine. For instance, though productivity has increased, wages have barely risen at all, except among top corporate executives who in some cases have treated themselves to startlingly big paydays, presumably to reward themselves for the agonizing toil of firing so many.
A rash of recent articles on the changing economy deals with the fact that there is a new overclass, of which the C.E.O.'s are only one element. What distinguishes this overclass is that it is raking down money at constantly increasing rates just when most Americans are struggling not to lose ground.
Is the guillotine the proper weapon for dealing with this new aristocracy? Or is it time for the ultimate weapon -- a new obscene-income tax?

HEADLINE: Admiral Has to Quit Over His Comments On Okinawa Rape

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The commander of United States forces in the Pacific was forced to step down today after he said the recent rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan girl could have been avoided if the American servicemen involved had simply paid for a prostitute.
The commander, Adm. Richard C. Macke, apologized after members of Congress and Japanese officials complained, but it was too late. 
 Admiral Macke, a 57-year-old Annapolis graduate and combat veteran of the war in Vietnam, announced late in the day that he had decided to take early retirement, and both White House and the Defense Department made clear that he had been forced to do so.
Admiral Macke declined to comment on the matter this evening.
A senior White House official said tonight that Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, had heard of Admiral Macke's remarks and told the Defense Department that the statements were "not acceptable."
The official added, "They didn't have to be coaxed," and Admiral Macke was forced to step down.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry said tonight that Admiral Macke had acknowledged that he had made a "serious mistake."
"This evening Admiral Macke and I discussed the comment and its impact on our valued relations with Japan and Okinawa," he said. "We decided that his lapse of judgment was so serious that he would be unable to perform effectively his duties as Commander in Chief of U.S. Forces in the Pacific. As a result, Admiral Macke offered to retire, and I accepted his early retirement."
Admiral Macke later issued a statement apologizing for his comment. "I made a serious mistake this morning," the statement said. "My recent comment was the result of my frustration over the stupidity of this heinous and incomprehensible crime against the young lady. I regret any misunderstanding my comment may have cause."
Admiral Macke also noted that he had repeatedly expressed sympathy for the girl.
The immediate reaction in Japan was subdued. Japanese television reported the admiral's resignation without mentioning his comments on the rape.
Still, a Foreign Ministry spokesman criticized the admiral's comments. "The remarks by Admiral Macke are most inappropriate in view of the terrible incident that took place in Okinawa," the spokesman, Takeshi Nakane, said.
The episode caused yet another strain in United States relations with Japan. First, there was the rape itself. On Nov. 7, the three American servicemen pleaded guilty to conspiring to kidnap and rape the girl.
Then on Wednesday, President Clinton canceled a planned trip to Japan for a Pacific Rim economic conference because of his long-running stalemate with the Republicans in Congress over the budget.
Then came the admiral's statement to reporters today. "I think that it was absolutely stupid, I've said several times," Admiral Macke said of the rape. "For the price they paid to rent the car they could have had a girl."
A Defense Department official said Admiral Macke had made his comment toward the end of a breakfast meeting with reporters this morning.
The official said that after Secretary Perry was told of it, he spoke by telephone with the United States Ambassador to Japan, Walter F. Mondale. Then Mr. Perry called Mr. Clinton and recommended that Admiral Macke be made to retire, and the President concurred, the official said.
Before the resignation was reported, Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, said she was stunned by the admiral's remarks condoning prostitution.
"I would say to Navy Secretary John Dalton, 'Your guys still don't get it,' " she said. "You better teach them, or else. Rape isn't about money and it isn't about sex. It's about power over women, and it's a very degrading, terrible, major felony."
Admiral Macke is the latest naval officer to become involved in a matter involving insensitivity toward women or outright assault.
The Navy was racked by the Tailhook scandal in 1991, when dozens of women were sexually assaulted by naval officers. Most recently, the Navy Secretary canceled the promotion of the officer in charge of equal opportunity, even after he was acquitted in a court martial on charges of sexually harassing a woman who worked for him.

HEADLINE: Bonanza: Panama Canal Zone Up for Sale

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
It is a colossal windfall that stirs old dreams of instant riches for this small country: 569 square miles of land abutting one of the world's most strategic waterways and more than 7,000 buildings, every last bit of which the United States must hand over to Panama by the end of 1999.
There are airports and harbors, hospitals and warehouses, shopping malls and hotels, apartments and schools, all originally built by American engineers and soldiers as part of what was once the Panama Canal Zone. 
 Now, as nearly a century of American domination draws to a close, the Panamanian Government is offering them for sale or lease to the highest bidder.
"We look upon this as the biggest real-estate operation of the century," said Maria Mercedes Morales de Morgan, promotion and marketing director for the Panamanian Government agency that is supervising the turnover.
But in a country with a long history of corruption and misrule since President Theodore Roosevelt maneuvered its creation in 1903, skeptical Panamanians also fear that the long-awaited bonanza will be mismanaged and end up benefiting only those in power.
"The shenanigans are already bubbling about," a diplomat here said. "There is that ethos here, and we keep hearing talk about payoffs and sweetheart deals and maneuvering and infighting to see who gets what."
Under the Panama Canal treaties of 1977, the United States must transfer control of the canal and all other American installations here to Panama no later than Dec. 31, 1999. That process was interrupted for nearly a decade by the dictatorship of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but the pace has picked up in recent years, and in September the United States handed over two of its 10 military bases here.
With visions of untold wealth dancing in their heads, journalists, business leaders and politicians have suggested that the United States properties could be worth as much as $30 billion, more than four times the size of the Panamanian economy. In a fever that a Foreign Ministry official likens to the Oklahoma land rush, nearly every one of Panama's 2.5 million people, it seems, has hatched a scheme to capitalize on the return of what are known as the "reverted areas."
The Government, for instance, talks of creating a "City of Knowledge," an international center for research and scholarship, out of a motley collection of barracks.
Real-estate developers look at the pristine Pacific Ocean beachfront near Fort Amador and envision condominiums rising. Some populist politicians argue that the military housing being abandoned by the Americans should be raffled off to the poor.
There is even a plan to turn the former site of the School of the Americas, the alma mater of many Latin American officers including past military dictators, into a luxury hotel and ecotourism center. Some officials, though, are warning that the process is neither as simple nor as sure-fire as it looks.
"Ideally, we will have investors and businesses ready to move in the day after the Americans leave," said Nicolas Ardito Barletta, a former President of Panama who this spring was appointed director of the Inter- oceanic Regional Authority, the Government agency supervising the turnover. "But the reverted areas are only going to be worth what we make them produce."
Though legal procedures to dispose of the reverted areas are still incomplete, a handful of projects have already been approved or are up and running. A consortium led by an auto dealership has transformed a former submarine base across from Colon into a container port, one section of Fort Davis has been leased to Taiwan companies for use as an industrial park, and Swiss interests are negotiating to use part of Fort Gulick for a school to train hotel and tourism workers.
But many Panamanians scoff at the notion that the governing Revolutionary Democratic Party, or P.R.D., will oversee the transfer honestly and efficiently. Burdened by a long history of thievery and thuggery, especially when General Noriega was at its helm, the party was returned to power in the presidential election last year despite winning only a third of the vote.
"I just don't trust them to manage this for the benefit of the nation," said Juan de Dios Rivera, a parking-lot attendant in the capital. "This is a country where the house always takes its cut, and the P.R.D. is the worst of the lot, a nest of pirates. They've spent 23 years in power, and they're still permeated with a hunger for domination and wealth."
Panama's President, Ernesto Perez Balladares, maintains that "there is a lot of misunderstanding about our philosophy in the P.R.D.." He attributed much of his party's negative image to "the stupidities of Noriega and his regime," and predicted that both Panamanians and foreign investors would change their minds once "they start to see the end results."
"Yes, I understand that I have a lot of resistance, because people are used to dishonest governments and an easy-buck mindset," said Mr. Perez Balladares, 49, an economist and banker educated at the University of Notre Dame.
"That's their point of reference, and I can't erase it all in five years," he said. "But I can get a head start and convince them this is different."
Panamanians agree that finding productive uses for the area is essential to the country's prosperity. Some 8,000 American troops plus an even larger number of dependents are scheduled to leave by 1999, and Panama sorely needs a replacement for the more than $300 million that the American presence is estimated to pump into the economy each year.
Since the canal opened in 1914, American troops, numbering as many as 50,000 during World War II, have been responsible for its defense and security. After 1999, however, that responsibility will pass to Panama, which recently abolished its army, unless Mr. Perez Balladares and Washington agree to an extension of the American military presence here.
The troop and bases question, which Mr. Perez Balladares has said he is willing to discuss with Washington, is also important to international shipping companies, which in the last year sent 13,631 vessels through the canal.
They worry that when the Americans leave, no Panamanian Government after the year 2000 will be able to resist the temptation to dip into canal revenues, currently $463 million a year, to make up any shortfall.
Mr. Perez Balladares said such concerns are unfounded.
"We're not going to do that," he said. "We know what the market can bear, we know that we have agreements with the international community, we know that we have to have a Panama Canal that operates with sufficient revenue to make it efficient."
Panamanians now make up nearly 90 percent of the canal's 7,500 employees, and are eager to see the waterway remain outside politics when the Americans leave. If allowed to run the canal without political interference, they are likely to continue the current policy of investing the bulk of revenues in maintenance and modernization.
"They realize they could easily kill the goose that lays the golden egg if they are shortsighted in canal management after 1999," Joseph W. Cornelison, a Deputy Administrator of the Panama Canal Commission, the United States agency that operates the canal, said in an interview at the agency's headquarters.
But Mr. Perez Balladares' many critics have detected signs elsewhere of what they regard as the old business-as-usual approach. Earlier this year, the P.R.D.-dominated National Assembly revised the charter of the Interoceanic Regional Authority, removing some of the agency's independence and leaving it open to strict political control.
As for the areas surrounding the canal, the dangers of their mismanagement are on display across the isthmus at Fort Gulick. The first part of that base, renamed Fort Espinar, was returned to Panama in 1984, at the height of the Noriega era, and has lain abandoned for nearly a dozen years.
At building after building, including the former site of the School of the Americas, vandals have broken in and made off with all of the plumbing and electrical fixtures. Roofs have fallen, windows are broken, tiles have been smashed, garbage has piled up, and bird droppings foul the floors.
But Mr. Barletta, director of the Government agency supervising the turnover, said he was not alarmed.
"Just remember Singapore," he said. "The British walked out in 1963, but they knew in Singapore how to take advantage of their strategic location, and the rest is history. If we do this right, we too can be a developed nation."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
HOUSE AND SENATE APPROVE G.O.P.'S 7-YEAR BUDGET PLAN; PRESIDENT PROMISES A VETO

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
As the first cracks developed in the deadlock between the White House and Congress that has caused a partial Government shutdown, Congress today approved mammoth Republican budget legislation to change the course of the American Government.
President Clinton said today that he would veto the legislation. "We should balance the budget in a way that reflects our values," he said in a statement. 
 But top White House officials spent the afternoon and evening in the Capitol working with Congressional leaders on a way to break the impasse that has kept the Government partially closed since Tuesday. An agreement seemed near between the President and his Republican antagonists to continue Government spending until sometime next month. But when the meetings broke up about 10 P.M., details still needed to be worked out.
"The bottom line is we're going to stand firm for a balanced budget over the next seven years," said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader.
But the word at the White House was that it was the Republicans in the House, more zealous than those in the Senate, who were blocking a compromise. Negotiations are expected to continue on Saturday.
The House approved the seven-year budget bill, 237 to 189, essentially following party lines. The measure, the fulfillment of the Republicans' promise to shrink Government and alter its priorities, would eliminate the Federal deficit by 2002, cut taxes for many and sharply limit spending on social programs.
The Senate passed the legislation, 52 to 47. The vote was along party lines, except that Senator William S. Cohen, a Republican from Maine, voted against it.
The Senate made a technical change in the bill tonight. It will be returned to the House for a final vote on Saturday.
Since Republicans do not hold large enough majorities in Congress to override the veto, the bill will never become law. Still, it is one of the most important pieces of legislation in years. It lays down the basis for Republicans' negotiations with the White House, which are expected to begin after Thanksgiving.
"Today is as important a vote as any day since 1933," said Speaker Newt Gingrich. "I think this is an enormous accomplishment."
Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who heads the Budget Committee, wrapped up the debate in the House to a standing ovation from his side. "Balancing the budget and slowing the growth of Federal spending," he said, "is the key to making sure young people's future continues to look bright."
To some extent, the approval of this monumental legislation was overshadowed by the question of whether Congress and the President could arrange to get the Government back to work temporarily.
The issues are integrally entwined. If the President's veto of the big budget legislation is sustained, he will more or less have his way, and the Republicans will have little chance of overhauling Medicare and welfare, cutting a wide range of taxes and putting in place a seven-year plan to balance the budget.
With that in mind, Republicans have insisted on forcing the President's hand by attaching budget conditions to temporary spending legislation that must be enacted to give the Government's departments and agencies money to operate.
Congress has approved two temporary spending bills, called continuing resolutions, to put the Government back in business until next month. The President vetoed the first, leading to this week's partial Government shutdown, and has promised to veto the second.
Mr. Clinton refused to accept the condition Republicans attached to the legislation committing him to produce a seven-year balanced-budget plan using a conservative accounting method adopted by Congress.
Such a commitment, the President maintains, would force cuts the country cannot afford in Medicare and programs protecting the poor.
Two of the President's top assistants, Leon E. Panetta, his chief of staff, and George Stephanopoulos, his senior adviser, spent several hours in the Capitol this afternoon and evening working with lawmakers on a compromise.
"We believe we can find a way to break the impasse that's a win-win situation," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Senator John B. Breaux, a Democrat from Louisiana, said this evening that an agreement was near in which the President would agree to a balanced budget within seven years if "mutually agreeable economic assumptions" were used.
The Administration's economic forecasts, made by the Office of Management and Budget, are more optimistic and would thus allow more flexibility than those of the Congressional Budget Office, which Republican leaders have been insisting on using.
Republicans in the House were said to have balked at the Breaux prescription on the ground that it would give the President a way to back out of a pledge to put forward a balanced-budget plan.
With an agreement in the wind, the oratory on both sides was distinctly modulated today, compared with the shootout style of earlier in the week. Perhaps that was because the switchboards at the White House and Congress have been flooded with calls from people saying they are tired of the squabbling.
For the first time all week, Mr. Gingrich did not attack the President personally, and Mr. Clinton did not make a contentious statement.
"We are looking for ways," said Michael D. McCurry, the President's spokesman, speaking especially deliberately, "that we can work through this current crisis and come up with a continuing resolution acceptable to the Congress and acceptable to the President."
The seven-year budget legislation would sharply limit spending on Medicare and Medicaid, the Government's main health programs for the elderly and poor, respectively, and would turn many Federal social programs over to the states with restricted funds. Student loans, aid to farmers and environmental regulations would be changed.
Taxes would be cut by $245 billion over the seven-year period. Middle-income families with many children and wealthy investors would get most of the benefits. Most taxpayers, however, would get little if any benefit from the new tax breaks.
In the House debate, Republicans seemed determined to present themselves not as firebrands but as thoughtful legislators determined to protect the country's future.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the Republican majority leader, said: "Nobody doubts for a moment that this is our best effort to do what we know is the right and necessary thing to do -- that we have been governed by our best motives, our hardest work, our best effort and frankly our most sincere prayers."
Mr. Kasich adopted a similar mien. "This is not business as usual," he said. "Both sides are fighting on deeply held principles. To the American people, this is what you sent us here to do, to stand up for our heart-felt beliefs."
Democrats took issue with the notion that by reversing direction, Republicans were improving the course of the country. But they also mainly criticized the legislation, not the motives of their opponents.
The main issue, said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, should not be how many years it would take to balance the budget but whether the priorities in the legislation were properly balanced.
"Do we take care of the disabled?" Mr. Gephardt asked. "Do we take care of the seniors? Do we take care of the children?"
The answer was "no," he said. "It asks too much of people in the middle class and people asking to get into the middle class and it does too much to give privileges and breaks to people who have done well."
In the Senate, Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat, made a similar argument. "The Republican budget plan," he said, "is a program to sacrifice senior citizens, students, children and working families in order to pay for lavish tax breaks for the wealthiest individuals and corporations in America.
 
HIGHLIGHTS
Major Provisions of the Bill
 
The House-Senate budget bill would balance the Federal budget in seven years, but President Clinton has threatened to veto it. Here are some of its major provisions.
 
MEDICARE
Encourages elderly people to enroll in private health plans and permits doctors and hospitals to establish their own health plans to serve Medicare patients. Increases premiums to 53.50 a month from 46.10.
Seven-year savings $270 billion
 
MEDICAID
Provides a lump sum of Federal money to earch state to finanace health care for poor people. States would have wide discretion to specify benefits but would be required to cover pregnant women and children under the age of 13. Would restrict the growth in spending to 5 percent a year from the current 10 percent a year.
Seven-year savings $163.4 billion
 
WELFARE
Eliminates the Federal guarantee of cash assistance to poor children. Gives states fixed grants to run their own programs, and requires them to spend at least 75 percent of current spending. No family could receive welfare for more than five years.
Seven-year savings $81.5 billion
 
EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT
Reduces eligibility. Families without children would no longer qualify.
Seven year savings $32 billion
 
NUTRITION
Cuts cost-of-living adjustments for food stamps, reduces aid for school lunchs and meals at day care centers. Sets conditions under which states could replace food stamp program with their own aid programs.
Seven-years savings $36.2 billion
 
AGRICULTURE
Sets fixed payments for most crops, eliminating payments for fallow fields; sugar, peanut and dairy programs are protected.
Seven-year savings $12.3 billion
 
STUDENT LOANS
Limits Government loans to 10 percent of all loans, down from 30 percent.
Seven-year savings $4.9 billion
 
ENVIRONMENT
Opens Artic refuge to oil and gass drilling, with some proceeds going to the Federal Governemtn.
Seven year savings $1.3 billion
 
TAX CUTS
Would grant a $500 tax credit for each child under 18 to families under certain income limits and would establish a $5,000 tax credit for adoptions
Seven year costs to Government $245 billion

HEADLINE: VOTE IN HARTFORD BY SENATE REJECTS BRIDGEPORT CASINO

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The Connecticut Senate today overwhelmingly rejected Gov. John G. Rowland's proposal for a casino in Bridgeport, ending more than four years of debate over whether to allow casinos in the state outside of Indian reservations.
The 24-to-10 vote crushed Bridgeport residents' hopes of seeing their ailing city, one hour from New York, become a gambling mecca. But for Atlantic City, it meant that a potential competitor, which experts said could have siphoned away as much as 30 percent of its business, had been stopped. 
 It was of particular interest in New York State, where debate over legalizing casinos in resort areas like the Catskills began earlier this year and where the Legislature must decide in 1997 whether to schedule a statewide referendum on the issue.
For New York, however, the meaning of today's action was by no means clear-cut. While the defeat of the Bridgeport proposal means less competition for potential casinos in New York, it also points out how difficult a fight casino supporters may face in Albany. The Bridgeport plan's strongest opposition came from the parimutuel industry in Connecticut -- two dog tracks, a jai alai fronton and two teletracks, where bettors watch live horse races on large television screens -- which feared that they could not compete against a casino. In New York, similar resistance has emerged from the powerful horse racing industry.
Today's vote was a major defeat for Mr. Rowland, who had worked furiously over the last three weeks to persuade senators that only a casino could provide the jobs needed to revive Bridgeport. He has said he will not consider any other casino proposals, adding today: "The proposal is dead. I am not going to put the State Senate through this again."
Carol Balboni, owner of Conte's Package Store on Madison Avenue, said: "I thought it would be different this time. I really believed the casino was going to be approved and we would finally get the chance to dig out from under our economic downfall. You might as well just build a wall around Bridgeport and shut down, now."
Although the $875 million casino would not have been on Indian land, the developer would have been the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, the owners of the immensely successful Foxwoods casino in eastern Connecticut. But even in defeat, the tribe was a winner. Without a casino in Bridgeport, the Pequots, along with another Connecticut tribe, the Mohegans, will retain a monopoly on casino gambling in the state.
The action in Connecticut was the latest in a series of defeats for the gaming industry nationally. In last week's elections, opponents of gambling won several referendums, stopping casino proposals in Springfield, Mass.; two counties in Indiana; Jefferson City, Mo., and in Washington State, where the proponents promised every resident $100 a year if the measure passed. Last year, Florida also voted down a pro-gaming referendum.
"It adds up to a pretty grim picture for casinos," Charles J. Anderer, editor of International Gaming and Wagering Business magazine, said today. "This will definitely contribute to the slowing of the growth of gaming."
The casino was opposed by a broad coalition from across the state. Some objected to expanding casino gaming, saying it would lead to an array of social ills, including increased crime and compulsive gambling. While Mr. Rowland argued that it would create 10,000 jobs, opponents said casino gambling took money from other businesses and would cost the state jobs.
Others opposed the measure because they were troubled about giving more power to the Pequots. And suburban Fairfield County lawmakers complained that the casino would worsen traffic and increase air pollution.
These issues overwhelmed Mr. Rowland's effort to cast the proposal as the last hope for Bridgeport.
"The focus has always been on one thing," Mr. Rowland said after the vote. "Jobs for Bridgeport."
The debate today was wrenching, cutting across party lines, pitting many of the state's most prominent Republicans against their Republican Governor and Bridgeport senators against their suburban neighbors.
Senator Judith G. Freedman, Republican of Westport, told the Senate, "I cannot support this, because it will hurt us more than it will help the city that we all have bleeding hearts for at this time." A few minutes later, Senator Alvin Penn, Democrat of Bridgeport, criticized her for caring more about traffic than jobs and said: "Folks can't drive their Bimmers. That's too bad."
Since it was first proposed in 1992, the casino issue has obsessed many in the legislature, resulting in dozens of hearings and more than $13 million in lobbying.
Mr. Rowland, bitterly disappointed, said the vote was an opportunity lost, costing the state billions of dollars. Asked if any place stood to gain from his defeat, he said: "Unfortunately, New York City is the big winner here. They may get the jobs, they may get the revenue. It could have gone to Bridgeport."
The Oneida Indians now operate a casino, as permitted by Federal law, on their reservation near Syracuse, and both they and the St. Regis Mohawk Indians have moved to open another in the Catskills. But Gov. George E. Pataki, whose approval would be required for such an expansion of Indian gaming, has said he would oppose the tribes' plans.
There is also a movement in the state to legalize non-Indian casino gaming. In June, the New York State Legislature took the first step, approving a constitutional amendment allowing casinos. The measure must also be approved by the next legislature to be elected, which comes into office in 1997, and then it would have to pass a statewide referendum.
The resolution designated Niagara Falls and the Catskills as potential sites, but did not include New York City. Mr. Pataki has said it should be amended to include the city, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has not taken any position on a New York City casino, though he has been exploring the idea of "casino cruises," during which betting would take place offshore.
But the Pequots' defeat may also suggest a larger trend that could help Atlantic City and undercut expanded gaming in New York: a growing backlash to casinos.
Over the last eight years, growth in the gaming industry has been remarkable. Iowa, Colorado, Mississippi, Louisiana and Illinois have approved non-Indian casinos, and at least 123 tribes have opened casinos in 24 states. But in response to the boom, a substantial anti-gaming movement has recently emerged.

HEADLINE: Union Members Express Dismay at Terms

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As details of New York City's tentative new labor agreement with 17 of its unions began to filter down to the rank and file late yesterday, the immediate reaction of some workers was disbelief, followed by a simmering defiance that union leaders said could endanger ratification.
"There is no way I would vote for something like this," said Celeste James, an assistant in the City Clerk's Office in Brooklyn and a chairwoman of the executive board of Local 1549, which represents clerical workers. "To us, it's a slap in the face, totally." 
 Though the five-year agreement fell short of the major concessions on work rules and benefits that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had pledged, its offer of no raises for the first two years provoked dismay among many workers.
That initial dismay signaled a greater than usual uncertainty about the contract's chances of being ratified. And it virtually guaranteed that the leaders of the 17 unions, led by District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, would face a difficult sales campaign.
At the 11 P.M. press conference yesterday in which union leaders stood with the Mayor to announce the agreement, Stanley Hill, executive director of the district council, predicted that it would be accepted when the membership votes in the weeks ahead. "There's anger at first sight, but we're going to educate and communicate," he said. "Union members are angry, but union members are also realistic."
Yet some leaders of large locals in the council, including James Butler, president of Local 420 of the hospital workers' union, and Arthur Cheliotes, president of Local 1180 of the Communications Workers of America, voted against the deal and said that they would urge their members not to support the pact.
Mr. Cheliotes said that district council leaders would most likely try to convince workers to approve the agreement by telling them that it was the best that could be reached under the circumstances. "They're going to say: can anyone do any better?" he said. "And I think they don't think that anyone can. They can point to the teachers and to the state workers and to New Jersey."
But with the Mayor supporting raises for himself and other top officials at the same time that workers confront a seeming litany of higher living costs, such as the subway fare increase, some union leaders said it is a pitch that will fall on deaf ears.
While it is rare for the city's union members to reject contracts, said one official who spoke on condition of anonymity, if Mr. Butler of the hospital workers' union "really organizes against this, it's not going to be easy to pass."
Members of several locals represented by District Council 37 said that while they recognized the economic straits that bound the negotiations, they felt the union leadership had sold them out.
"I don't feel like they fought for us at all," said Mary Ann Barrucco, who works in the office of the City Register in Brooklyn. She echoed the sentiments of others who said they held a newfound distrust of the district council leadership.
Linda Dawkins, a clerical aide for the Department of Health, said she and her fellow employees had begun to feel as if City Hall and union leaders have become "just one big clique."
"It seems like they're trying to make each other look good, and we're losing out," she said.
Ms. Barrucco added that the work force in city offices had already been whittled significantly by attrition in recent years, and that workers are now "doing the job of three with no more money" in real terms than they had a decade ago.
Ms. James said she had received angry calls all morning from members who wanted to know when an agreement would come and what it would say.
But she had little to tell them, she said; unlike the practice in previous contract negotiations, her board had mostly been kept in the dark. "Today was the first I heard of all this," said Ms. James. "And I think that's because they knew there would be a lot of screaming."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Man Held in Parents' Deaths

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

DATELINE: WEST LONG BRANCH

 BODY:
A man fatally shot his elderly parents and a nurse Thursday afternoon, then shot and critically wounded himself, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Stephen Spranger, 54, was charged in the shooting deaths of his mother, Madeline, 89, his father, Harvey, 85, and Marcia Granucci, 45, who was employed to assist the couple. The suspect, who is unemployed and lived with his parents, was in critical condition yesterday with a bullet wound to the head. The authorities said they do not know the motive for the killings, The Associated Press reported. 
 The bodies were found in different rooms by officers who came to the Spranger home to inquire about Mrs. Granucci, whose husband had called the police to report that she had not returned to their Wall Township home after work.

HEADLINE: Budget Worries Leave Treasury Prices Flat

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday in a lackluster trading session as market participants awaited signs of progress on budget negotiations in Washington.
"I think most people came into the day expecting little and they got little," said Joshua Stiles, an economist with the consulting firm of IDEA Inc. "A lot of people would prefer to stay where they are until Monday," he said, because if a breakthrough on the budget occurred over the weekend, "it would trip people up." 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 1/32 , to 10823/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, edged up to 6.23 percent, from 6.22 percent on Thursday, but still near a two-year low.
Shorter-term maturities fared a little better yesterday. The price of the two-year note rose 1/32 , to 10011/32 , pushing down its yield to 5.43 percent from 5.45 percent. The price of the 10-year bond also edged up 1/32 , to 10413/32 , with its yield unchanged at 5.90 percent.
With so much uncertainty surrounding the Federal budget and the national debt limit, analysts said dealers who typically set up short positions ahead of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills were hesitant. In taking a short position, a dealer sells borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back at a lower price.
"I can name a handful of dealers who would have sold a couple hundred three-years today and bought them back again on Monday cheaper," Mr. Stiles of IDEA said. "But you don't want to get too aggressive shorting" if there is a chance of progress on the budget this weekend, he said.
The Treasury also plans to auction $18 billion of three-year notes on Monday and $13.5 billion of 10-year notes on Tuesday.
Still, the market took some encouragement from comments by the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who held out hope of a compromise with Republicans on a stopgap financing bill yesterday, saying President Clinton might be willing to back away from demands for a bill without any Republican conditions.
And Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, said the Senate might vote today on a piecemeal spending bill to pay for agencies that process Social Security, veterans' benefits and Medicare claims.
The expiration of December Treasury bond futures options yesterday had little effect on the cash market, analysts said.
In the corporate bond market, prices were marginally weaker in light trading.
But Delta Air Lines was a big gainer, trading up to a 99.5 bid on its 12.5 percent notes on the news that Moody's Investors Service might upgrade the carrier's Ba1 senior unsecured debt, traders said.
New issues continued at a brisk pace yesterday.
ITT Destinations raised $1.75 billion in a four-part debt deal led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. ITT Destinations is one of three new companies being formed by the split-up of the ITT Corporation.
The debt issue was guaranteed by ITT, and was rated Baa1 by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's.
The size of the offering was increased from $1.3 billion as a result of high interest from investors.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 25, 1995, Saturday

HEADLINE: Mumford and the Master

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger; Paul Goldberger is the chief cultural correspondent of The New York Times.

 BODY:

LEWIS MUMFORD AND PATRICK GEDDES
The Correspondence.
Edited by Frank G. Novak Jr.
Illustrated. 383 pp. New York:
Routledge.
$45. 
 THERE are epistolary novels and there are books in which the correspondence of great figures is reverently assembled, and one rarely has much to do with the other. The letters that make up an epistolary novel are expected to deal in the routine, even trite, minutiae of daily life but together tell a larger story. Collections of the correspondence between celebrated people are often the opposite: we assume that each and every letter will stand as a work on its own, demonstrating in capsule form why its writer deserves our attention.
One of the most pleasing things about "Lewis Mumford and Patrick Geddes: The Correspondence" is the way in which it fails to meet this standard, and provides only sporadic glimpses of its writers' greatness. This book contains neither Mumford's best prose nor Geddes's most lucid presentation of his ideas. Yet it manages, slowly and firmly, if not always clearly, to record a remarkable relationship in American intellectual history. It is a story, in spite of itself.
And the story is a universal one: a mating dance, full of joy and sadness, progressing over the course of 17 years from infatuation to connection to disillusionment. That the romance was an intellectual one, driven not by eros but by the desire for mental stimulus and career advancement, matters not at all. These were two heterosexual men who wanted as much out of each other as lovers do, and in some ways forged a bond every bit as tight. The connection between Geddes, teacher, and Mumford, acolyte, is one of the great master-protege relationships in modern cultural history, ranking with that of Louis Sullivan and Frank Lloyd Wright; its long evolution sheds light on every anguished exchange between a pupil who has worshiped his teacher and then been disappointed by him.
Mumford, who died at 95 in 1990 -- he would have been 100 a month ago today -- was perhaps the strongest and most powerful general humanist of the 20th century. Best known as an architecture critic and urban historian, he was also a social commentator, literary critic, philosopher and poet, a student of technology and an unstinting moral voice. His refusal to be constrained by narrow definitions of subject and his determination to use scholarship as the springboard for an active civic life came in large part from Geddes, 41 years his senior, a biologist, urban planner, sociologist and determined outsider to the academy, who argued passionately that all subjects were intertwined and spent much of his life trying to formulate a rational system for the synthesis of knowledge and human experience.
Mumford first encountered Geddes's work in 1914, when he was a student at City College in New York. Geddes managed to rouse "something in my soul that no one else had yet touched," Mumford wrote later. "What Geddes's voice did was to lead me away from the well-paved avenue to professional success: his was the Song of the Open Road. . . . Geddes believed that abstract thinking must be enriched by wider experience, clarified by reflective criticism, and completed by communal action."
Mumford wrote to Geddes's secretary in 1915 for an explanation of how a student might arrange to study with him. But not until 1917 did Mumford write directly to the man he was later to address as Master, and that first letter was marked by a striking combination of obsequiousness and eagerness. Significantly, Mumford introduced in this very first letter a subject that was to continue as a leitmotif throughout the years of their relationship: the belief, shared by both men, that great cities are entities unto themselves, with an economic, social and cultural power that transcends the nations of which they are, technically, a part, and that the regions that naturally surround cities can be more appropriate political units than the artificial boundaries of nations and states. Geddes responded with some brevity to Mumford's riff on his theories, but with cautious encouragement -- enough, in fact, to unleash a torrent of further words from Mumford.
And soon they were off to the races. Thousands of words poured back and forth, revealing in both men a constant hunger for ideas and an almost desperate desire to exchange information. Not the least intriguing aspect of this entire correspondence is the extent to which it reveals the scarcity of scholarly information in the early decades of this century and the slowness with which theories were propagated. No doubt the fact that Geddes spent many of those years in Bombay, planning cities in India, contributed to his eagerness to turn Mumford into a pipeline for information about colleagues, news of new books and their reviews and gossip. But obtaining information is really a kind of theme throughout the letters of both men; in this age of information overload they stand as a reminder of how recently the challenge was not to sift through too much information but to get enough of it in the first place.
It is almost too obvious to say that Mumford, who never knew his father, found in Geddes a surrogate parent, and that Geddes saw in Mumford a replacement for his elder son, who had been killed in World War I, before the correspondence began. In this sense their contact seems almost fated. Yet both men seem to have viewed this aspect of their relationship with some discomfort if not, at times, denial. Each struggled to be free of the other even as he clung to his identity as master or student. In 1921 Mumford would ask Geddes to "forgive the brusqueness of a young man who intellectually speaking is scarcely fit to wash out a beaker in your laboratory," laying before Geddes all his problems, personal and financial as well as intellectual. Yet he would feel free to offer up his own ideas, and while they were presented with an obvious eye toward the older man's approval, he made no effort to tailor them to fit Geddes's own theories.
 THE two did not actually meet until Geddes came to New York in 1923, to lecture at the New School on a trip Mumford had helped to arrange. Geddes had repeatedly invited Mumford to join him in Bombay as well as in Palestine, where he was helping to plan what became the Hebrew University, but for various reasons, mainly connected to the uncertainty of both Mumford's health and his finances, none of the trips came off. By the time they actually laid eyes on each other, they had spent six years concocting various plans for collaboration, for the editing of Geddes's voluminous papers and for the creation of a book that would pull together all of his diverse ideas -- during which time neither man had ever even heard the other's voice.
Their first face-to-face encounter was a moment of high drama that marked, in a way, the beginning of Mumford's disillusionment: he found Geddes vain, self-centered, rigid and disorganized. Mumford was at that point approaching 30, and increasingly committing himself to a life centered on writing; he was less interested in serving as Geddes's acolyte than in being perceived as his intellectual heir. Geddes could never quite comprehend Mumford's increasing independence, and while he referred to him as a collaborator, as the years went on his notion of the joint work they would undertake seemed more and more to be focused on Geddes's alone. Once Geddes cruelly, if unintentionally, slighted Mumford when he forgot to appear at Mumford's apartment in Brooklyn Heights for a planned Sunday afternoon visit, not even telephoning his regrets. Yet Mumford never seemed quite able to acknowledge directly to Geddes the scope of his intellectual debt, which might have mellowed the older man's outlook. Mumford's letters are filled with florid praise (for a while he closed them with the phrase, "Yours in discipleship") but there is always a formal tone, and hence an odd distance.
 THE letters are, alas, rather unrevealing about this difficult visit; we know more of this interlude from Mumford's other writings, and from the excellent and wide-ranging introductory essay by Frank G. Novak Jr., a professor of English at George Pepperdine University, who edited this volume. While Geddes was in New York Mumford wrote him only once. But this letter is among the best in the book, for Mumford here did not hesitate to say what was on his mind. On July 6, after Geddes had been in New York for two months, Mumford wrote, "In one sense, I have the feeling that we have yet to meet. . . . My respect for you is so great that it reduces my mental reactions in your presence to those I used to feel in the presence of my teacher when I was 12 years old -- that is, complete paralysis!" Later in the letter comes one of the rare moments when Mumford takes Geddes on: "If instead of thinking of me as a quack journalist you'd conceive of me rather as a young scholar who publishes his notes and lectures instead of speaking to a class; and if you'd see that I have chosen to get a living in this manner because it is for me the one means by which I can work at my own pace and keep at least a third of my time free for thinking and studying of a different sort, there might still be a little exaggeration in the picture, but it would be an exaggeration towards the truth."
Geddes answered with praise, and the statement that "I don't want mere secretaryship . . . but your maturer development above all," but that was enough to hold things together only for a while, for Mumford knew better than to take Geddes at his word. Yet the relationship continued, and in its odd way flourished; after the New York visit, Geddes finally began to address Mumford as "Lewis," and Mumford, who had a lifelong tendency toward stuffiness, assumed a tone that was at least a little bit less stuffy. When Mumford's son was born in 1925, he named him Geddes, and Geddes's acknowledgment of this fact in his letters, if terse, seems to reflect genuine pleasure.
The correspondence continued until Geddes's death at the age of 77 in 1932, the year he received a knighthood, one of the few public acknowledgments of his stature. By then the disappointment both men felt for their failure to produce creative work together was an established fact, but so was the affection and admiration they continued to hold for each other. The tone was relaxed and almost mellow toward the end; since Geddes's death was sudden, there were no farewells, no cathartic moments in print. In the end, for all their struggles with each other, it really was the exchange of ideas that motivated both Geddes and Mumford. They whined and complained and talked endlessly of logistical complications, but in the best letters in this volume ideas break through, and you can clearly sense the thrill.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: THE RICH;
How Their Kids Are Just Like Them

BYLINE: By ROBERT SULLIVAN; Robert Sullivan's last piece for the Magazine was about television writers. He lives in Portland, Ore.

 BODY:
With its red-brick New England-style buildings and its leafy campus setting, the Lakeside School, a private institution for grades 5 through 12 in north Seattle, looks like the quintessential East Coast prep school -- an Ivy League steppingstone from the other side of the continent. But the similarities end at the tall white doors of the main building, called Bliss Hall. On the East Coast, an expensive private-school education is considered a rung on the ladder to upper-crust America, and in the halls of such places the quiet codes of high-society conduct are imparted along with lessons in trigonometry and French. At Lakeside, the tone is distinctly . . . well, there isn't tone. There are faded T-shirts and lots of neo-grunge flannel and every make of athletic shoe imaginable -- and not a blue blazer in sight. There is no one, in fact, who is dressed or talking as rich kids do, or are thought to. There are garden burgers being prepared in the cafeteria and scores of computers booting up and, on the stage in the community meeting room this particular morning in September, a girl named Katie Coxon. She is describing for about 200 middle-schoolers a brainstorming session at which she and other eighth graders worked up a list of adjectives with which they hoped to describe their lives come the year 2005: relaxed, bold, talented, friendly, productive.
Lakeside is expensive (about $12,000 a year). And Lakeside is proud of its alumni, who include Bill Gates, his founding partner at Microsoft, Paul Allen, and Craig McCaw, the founder of McCaw Cellular Communications, bought last year by AT&T for $12.6 billion. 
 But Lakeside is not Groton or Spence. It doesn't have the subtle Anglophile trappings -- the ones the East Coast prep schools make a point of not pointing to too expressively. It doesn't feel exclusive, just as a Microsoft millionaire can convey that sense -- with his jeans and knowledge of takeout food -- of not seeming rich.
Robin Ballard, a Lakeside ninth grader, was perhaps alluding to this more casual style of American affluence as it is manifesting itself in the Pacific Northwest when she said, "My dad works at Microsoft, and it looks like a lot of fun."
Keith Grinstein, a 1978 Lakeside graduate who is now president of the aviation communications division of AT&T wireless services as well as a member of Lakeside's development committee, observes: "When I got to Yale, I had no idea what the Fence Club was. I didn't know what secret societies were. Lakeside didn't prepare me for eating lunch at the Yale or the Harvard Club in New York City. The school is not designed to train legions of cultural or economic elite."
Like the space needle, Lakeside is singular in Seattle, for private school is not a tradition among the city's upper-income families. In the East, public schools were mostly built after private ones. In the Northwest, the educational system is a remnant of the original layout of the territory: each settlement included a plot of land set aside for the benefit of public education. The educational past here is markedly egalitarian. Lumber barons and banking magnates sometimes sent their children east for prep-school educations, but more often than not they sent them to a public school close to home. As a result, Seattle has only a few private schools like Lakeside, whereas Eastern cities of similar size and wealth are apt to have at least a dozen.
The Lakeside School was begun in 1919 as the Moran-Lakeside School; it was for boys only and set on the shore of Lake Washington in the old-money neighborhood of Denny Blaine. (The school moved to its present site in 1930 and went co-ed in 1971.) Today the enrollment is 693, with 160 faculty and staff members, a 33,500-volume library and some 200 computers (although most of the computers at Gates's alma mater are not on the cutting edge but on the edge of obsolescence). The list of courses is liberal-arts-meets-continuing-multicultural education. In the middle school, at 10 A.M., a sixth-grade class studies the budgets of foreign countries on the World Wide Web.
If the prep-school culture of Boston mirrors the culture of its firms and corporations, so the culture at Lakeside mirrors that of business in the Northwest. In Seattle and Portland, professionals attend creative seminars and go on kayaking retreats; at Lakeside, students are sent into the forests of Washington State to commune with nature and one another, and in-school work teams and frequent sessions of "free writing" emphasize creativity and intellectual nimbleness.
"I think we do a pretty good job of encouraging kids who like to play with ideas," Fred Wright, the math teacher who taught Gates in the 70's, says.
Peter Hodges is the director of curriculum for Lakeside's lower school. He walks the halls waving and chatting with students who call him by his first name and comment on his neckties -- today, a relic from a 1968 Janis Joplin Winterland concert.
"We're trying to tell them that it's really O.K. to be curious," Hodges says. "Most kids at this time are showing their separation and disdain for the adult world. But our kids are engaged."
BETWEEN 8 AND 8:15 A.M., WHEN THE upperschool kids pull off the highway after their trips from the big homes in Broadmoor, Denny Blaine and Washington Park and from suburbs like Bellevue, the intersection of Northeast 130th Street and First Avenue, just down the street from the school, is jammed with shining four-wheel-drive vehicles of every kind. Ford Explorers, Isuzu Troopers -- it's as if the school were reachable only by dirt road. Eventually those cars jam the parking lot, behind the Refectory, which is the cafeteria -- and which by lunch time is filled with 9th, 10th, 11th and 12th graders who are similar in their scrubbed unkemptness.
The kids are smart and relaxed about that.
"You're not, like, labeled as a dork if you want to learn stuff," Hannah Elmer says.
The science class is as likely to entail pondering mayfly larvae at a nearby creek as hitting the books.
"I only have two academic courses today, math and philosophy," Amity Burr says, relishing the freedom of her new management-style schedule. "My dad hates my schedule, but I actually learn a lot."
When the subjects of family income and tuition are raised, Bunnie Curtis, poised and soft-spoken, points out that 17 percent of the students, herself included, are on financial aid. She recalls that the students at her previous school, a public one, told her not to apply: "They said: 'Oh, it's a bunch of rich kids. You won't like it.' And a lot of them didn't try to apply. But it's not like that."
Income was something of a sore point at the school just then, after a small controversy over a "kickoff" dinner for the parents of seniors held in the Highlands, Seattle's gated and most exclusive neighborhood. There was an admission charge of $40 per couple, not to mention valet parking. According to the student paper, The Tatler, the cost kept some parents away, and the reporting of this led to soul-searching all around. The student government was reported to be in the process of drafting a letter to the organizers asking them to consider "the feelings of the entire community."
At day's end at Lakeside, there is noise on the soccer field and the sound of sports-utility vehicles being started and driven away. To the lake or the hills for a mountain-bike ride -- but first a stop at the local Starbucks for a little something to go.

HEADLINE: THE BIG CITY;
Number Theory

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
YOUNG investment bankers don't like to mention the Number in polite society. They know how appalling their calculations sound. But in private, after a few drinks, they will ask one another: How much money do you need to leave your job? What sum will make you a permanent member of New York's leisure class? What is . . . the Number?
The Number is often used interchangeably with another term, an unprintable one that describes the sum you need to be able to tell your boss you've had enough. Its family-newspaper approximation would be Forget You Money. But linguistic purists on Wall Street insist there's a difference between the two concepts. "It doesn't take much money to tell your boss to get lost," one money manager explains. "With a million in the bank you can afford to look for another job. But if you want to live the rest of your life without worrying about money, you need the Number." 
 You can think of the Number as the inverse of the poverty line: the subsistence-wealth line. Subsistence, of course, is a highly relative concept in New York. In the novel he's now writing, Tom Wolfe has a character struggling for upper-middle-class status on $225,000 a year. "He's not a socialite," Wolfe says. "He has not all that grand a co-op apartment. He's just someone who wants to send his two kids to private school and have an apartment in which each child has a bedroom. He'd like to have a car and to take a vacation every now and then. He explains to himself why a civilized life in New York is impossible on $225,000 year, and I think it's quite reasonable." In "Bonfire of the Vanities," Sherman McCoy was barely surviving in the 1980's on $980,000 a year -- the co-op loan payments were crushing him -- and Wolfe believes today's socialite would need more money still: "I said Sherman's two-story apartment at Park Avenue and 75th Street cost $2.6 million, but that was already too low by the time the book came out. It might be $3.5 million now."
The Masters of the Universe I consulted agree that Sherman would be in trouble today. A million a year starts to look like chump change once you deduct the taxes and the loan payments on a couple of homes. When calculating the Number, they talk in after-tax dollars and assume that the co-op and the country house are already paid off.
"If there's no mortgage, you can figure your normal monthly expenses at $8,000," an investment banker explained over his third beer at the Royalton Hotel bar. "That covers the nanny and food and leaves plenty of room for $300 dinners at Bouley. Figure $50,000 to $100,000 a year on major expenses like furniture and cars. Give yourself 50 days of vacation at $1,200 a day -- that's another $60,000. Add it up and you see you can live quite comfortably on $250,000."
"But that's not even subsistence level," a colleague at the bar protested. "What about the $30,000 for school tuition? What about the $25,000 a stud like you has to spend on the country club? That brings it up to $300,000 minimum. And if you get a jet ----."
"No jet. The jet will kill you. Then your wife wants a $2,000 gown for every charity event and a $25,000 donation to put your name on the program. You start buying art -- there's no limit once you get the jet. I'm talking about a very basic kind of guy here."
They finally agreed that this basic guy could survive on $400,000 a year. To generate this income, assuming a 4 percent after-tax return on short-term Treasury bills, you would need $10 million. This was the same Number I heard from some other Wall Streeters too. In fact, it's roughly equivalent to the pre-inflation Numbers used last century by two rich New Yorkers.
"I have had no real gratification or enjoyment," William Henry Vanderbilt said in the 1880's, "more than my neighbor on the next block who is worth only half a million." Earlier in the century John Jacob Astor declared that "a man who has a million dollars is as well off as if he were rich." In today's dollars their estimates would translate, respectively, into $8 million and $14 million.
So is $10 million the Number? Maybe for this year. But what about future inflation? "You really need $25 million," a banker told me. "That gives you a million in after-tax income this year -- $400,000 to spend, $600,000 to reinvest so you compensate for inflation. And if you want to be really safe, you should be prepared to lose half your money in a divorce. That means you have to start out with $50 million."
Fifty million seems an incontrovertibly comfortable figure for the subsistence-wealth line. It looks very much like the Number. But what happens to those who reach it? A few do leave Wall Street to tend a vineyard or run a country inn, but not many stay away for long. They develop new urges. They start thinking about reaching $100 million (a sum known as a Hunge) or a billion (a Bill). They speak of becoming a Player in games in which the Number is merely the ante. They begin to understand the practical reasons for having that jet. "If you're someone who can make the Number," says John Spooner, a senior vice president at Smith Barney, "you're probably someone who can't stop there." You're like the client of Spooner who tried retiring and soon called to say he was depressed: "I've made my Number, but no one returns my phone calls."
In the spring I was at a dinner party with an investment banker in his mid-40's who had just quit with his Number safely in the bank. "I worked so hard that the last 25 years are a blur," he told the impoverished journalists at the table. "I shouldn't look so much older than you guys. I've got to slow down." His wife smiled as he talked about their plans to travel. He was going to read, relax with his kids, maybe start a leisurely second career in education. "I'm going to take my time and figure out what I really want to do with my life."
Two months later I saw his name in the paper. He had taken a high-pressure job overhauling one of the giant new global conglomerates. I don't know if he has figured out his life yet -- his assistant said he didn't have time to return my phone call -- but I suspect that his hiatus enabled him to glimpse the true mathematical equation: The Number = A Little More.

HEADLINE: On Language;
Spookspeak in Deutchland

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
NEITHER THE NIO for warning nor any of the SIBlings knew that this article was being prepared for publication. Transmitted outside the WASHFAX, it has not appeared in the latest SNIE and was done with no knowledge in Deutchland.
"Deutchland" is what the surly set at the Central Intelligence Agency calls the mole-shocked agency in its post-Ames era. John Deutch, the new D.C.I. (Director of Central Intelligence), is a hearty fellow from M.I.T. and the Pentagon, given to hugging and back-rubbing insecure case officers, who suspiciously refer to such physical reassurance as "the hug of death." 
As the agency staggers from being penetrated by the K.G.B. to being rigorously examined by CODELS (Congressional Delegations), one element of its culture remains sacrosanct: spookspeak. In the land of acronyms, we now have FUSS (Fleet Undersea Surveillance System) and FORMICA (not the counter-top material, but Foreign Military Intelligence Collection Activity). But initialese -- without the creative acronymic word-formation -- is rampant.
Take it from the top: within the NIC, or National Intelligence Council, there are NIO's, or National Intelligence Officers: the guy who tries to keep the Government from any blind-siding by the competition or the media is the NIO for warning. He is in close touch with members of the Strategic Intelligence Board, or SIB, whose brothers under the skin are SIBlings, and they all share SNIE's -- Special National Intelligence Estimates.
A WASHFAX is a secure, encrypted telephone fax line that nobody in the intelligence community trusts. If the communication was until recently labeled WNINTEL/ ORCON/PROPIN, the spooks felt better hand-carrying it over. WNINTEL meant that remote sensing technology -- like a long-distance bug -- was used to gather the information. ORCON meant "originator controlled," with the writer to be consulted about future clearances. PROPIN meant "contains proprietary information," like the formula for Coca-Cola syrup or the sketches for a French designer's collection.
The INT, for "intelligence," is a standard acronym-former: HUMINT is "human intelligence," SIGINT "signal intelligence," which includes "KEYHOLE," the code word for data derived from an imagery satellite, and MASINT, "measurement and signature intelligence," the telltale clues to identity picked up by acoustic, nuclear and seismic sensors, hand-carried over (not the WASHFAX, stupid) to the A.S.D. (C3I) who is Assistant Secretary of Defense for Command, Control, Communications and Intelligence, who was hugged by Deutch and survived. An unofficial usage is RUMINT -- for "rumor intelligence," the gossip and scuttlebutt that often proved more reliable than the HUMINT sent in by one of the K.G.B. or Stasi double agents who the D.D.O. (Deputy Director for Operations) thought was working for us. (A House Intelligence staff member has pledged to review the C.I.A. "INT by INT.")
The word from DODIPP (the Department of Defense Intelligence Production Program) is that PROPIN is no longer used. The intelligence community's sort-of-secret budget ($28 billion and change) will depend on how well it does on the economic stuff; because its plan is to set up more "front" companies to run agents abroad, future phony corporate entities like the Deutchland Seismic Sensor and Escort Service will be sourced in agency documents with a word that does not indicate anything to do with "proprietary." I do not include the new code word here because I am not eager to help French counterintelligence.
The key element in many intel estimates is probability. Within the community, the word used for the lowest probability is conceivably. A less-than-50 percent chance draws a possibly, and just over 50 percent a probably. In the 60 to 70 percent range, spooks use likely, and in the 80's it gets to almost certainly. An estimated sure thing is no doubt, a rarity.
One member of the community, not in the Defense Intelligence Agency, defines conceivably this way: "Nobody but D.I.A. believes this, but if we didn't put it in, they wouldn't coordinate, and we figured it wasn't worth the fight because no sane reader would take it seriously."
 
Early Rap Artist
 Hold on to your cigar -- we may have discovered an unexpectedly early rap artist.
This is the sort of find that sends a frisson of delight through the entire Phrasedick Brigade and causes lexicographers the world over to rejigger their computer files.
It concerns the slang verb to rap, which has led to rap session and rap artist. Though the noun rap dates back to Middle English, with meanings ranging from "a sharp blow" to "a rebuke" to the undeserved reputation of "a bum rap," a criminal charge that is sometimes beaten, the slang or colloquial verb is a product of recent black English, especially in the music world. In the Oxford English Dictionary Supplement, the modern noun rap is defined as "a special style of verbal display, repartee. . . . More generally, impromptu dialogue, talk or discussion." The earliest citation in this sense of shooting pyrotechnic breeze is in a 1967 article in the magazine Trans Action.
This sense is rooted, I think, in a more general usage of rap, to mean "to talk freely and frankly." To back up this definition from Merriam-Webster's 10th Collegiate, here is a 1929 citation from Damon Runyon: "I wish Moosh a hello, and he never raps to me but only bows, and takes my hat."
Alistair Cooke, an active member of OLBOM -- On Language's Board of Octogenarian Mentors -- was reading "one of my bed books," presumably one he keeps handy for reading in bed. It was "Churchill at Large," a collection of essays, newspaper articles and other writings by Winston Churchill.
In a piece dated Aug. 5, 1933, Churchill wrote about a Washington dinner party in 1931, at which "after the dinner was over, the whole company formed a half-circle round me . . . and for two hours we wrestled strenuously, unsparingly, but in the best of tempers with each other." In that admixture of controversy and camaraderie, he concluded, "The priceless gift of a common language, and the pervading atmosphere of good sense and fellow [sic] feeling enabled us to rap all the most delicate topics without the slightest offense given or received."
That's it: rap meaning "discuss" in the writing of a master of English letters. "Astonishing in Churchill," notes Cooke. "I never heard it used at all until about 15 years ago, and then from a jazz drummer."
Ah, those elegant Washington dinner parties, where the latest slang was tossed about in the rapt half-circles around an articulate source. Those days went out with Joe Alsop.
