HEADLINE: THE RICH: How They Spend It;
A-Z: What a Lot of Money Can Buy

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL; Peter Passell writes about economics and other topics for The Times.

 BODY:

ACCESS
 A cellular phone is fine as long as you're within a few miles of a transmitter. But the truly rich don't need to be shackled to civilation. Comsat's 25-pound, briefcase-size Mobile Link provides a connection to anywhere in the wrold through Inmarsat's system of high-earth-orbit satellites. Cost, with 1,000 minutes of air time: $13,850.
 
BOY TOY
 The wealthy have long lusted to own sports teams, and for a while Madonna was rumored to be interested in buying an N.B.A. franchise. But it has since become clear that she was less interested in teamwork than in individual performances, especially by the likes of the irrepressible Dennis Rodman (then with the San Antonio Spurs). "She had ways of making you feel like you're King Tut," Rodman once told an interviewer, "but she also wanted to cuddle and be held."
 

COHIBA
 When Cuba's leisure class left for Miami, it was widely assumed that all the great cigar makers went too. Not so. The worl's most coveted cigars - and the most expensive - are Cohibas, originally produced exclusively for Fidel Castro. They've been commercially available since the early 1980's, selling for about $25 to $30 apiece insmoke shops abroad; they regularly find their way back to the United States in the luggage of discerning travelers.
 
DEMOCRACY
 For the man who has everything, like the billionaire currency speculator George Soros, there's only one logical way to spend your money: is the world. Soros spends some $300 million a year - more than the Ford Foundation - on his own private foreign policy. Having already promoted democracy in Eastern Europe for several years, he is quietly becoming a major player in South Africa, pledging up to $50 million in mortgage insurance guarantees to help replace tin shacks with more substantial housing.
 
EAVESDROPPING
 You never know what's in that van parked on you block. With just $200,000, a good underground electronics expert can be hired - not through the Yellow Pages, mind you - to put together a surveillance vehicle that enables the jealous, the suspicious or the paranoidj to monitor their enemy's activities. Options include a movement - sensitive pinhole camera and a scanner that intercepts phone numbers and digital mesages; there's also $15,000 night-vision goggles and an $18,000 car-tracking satellite system. For what it's worth: most of these items are now or soon will be illegal.
 
FEMALE ROLE MODELS
 Bill Koch, a Kansas-bred businessman and self-described rebel, wanted to drum up interest in yacht racing while breaking down th esport's good-old-boy image. So he spent $5 million-plus to assemble an all-female crew for his 1995 America team, which had won the previous Americas Cup, in 1992. Mighty Mary, the team's lead boat this year, didn't fare well - even after a new tactician, a man, was installed at the 11th hour. Still, all was not lost: after the races, team members toured the country, running leadership - training classes for high-school girls.
 
GLORY
 In 1983, in a well-publicized act of wish fulfillment, Gilbert Kaplan, the founder of Institutional Investor magazine, took some music lessons and spent $125,000 to conduct Gustav Mahler's intricate Symphony No. 2 in C Orchestra. But don't call him a dilettante: Kaplan has since conducted the symphony with 26 orchestras, at their invitation, and next year will conduct the opening concert of the 1996 Salzburg Festival. His critically praised recording with the London Symphony Orchestra, has sold 140,000 copies.
 
HONEYMOON
 Why wed at some boring old watering hole like the Plaze? No reason, if you can afford to hire Bill Fischer to plan the event. New York's travel agent to the stars recently arranged a movable feast for a client, his bride-to-be and 38 of their closest friends. The group first flew to Rome to pick up a 450-foot yacht for a cruise to Antibes, where the couple were married at the Hotel du Cap. Fischer had persuaded the management to surrender several previously booked rooms (the Cannes Film Festival was under way) and shut down the dining room for the wedding reception. The newlyweds spent the next three and a half months touring Europe, Africa, the Greek and Turkish isles, Bali, Singapore and the Great Barrier Reef, traveling by private jet, boat, helicopter andhot-air balloon. Desiring some comfort on their arduous journey, they had asked Fischer to hire a butler for them just like the one at the Lanesborough Hotel in London. What they got was that very butler, who quit his job to join the couple full time. Total cost: $3.5 million, including commissions.
 
IMMORTALITY
 Monuments crumble, but nature is forever. The Nature Conservancy, a Virginia-based environmental group, is willing to accommodate those who appreciate this distinction. It recently accepted a gift of 512 pristine acres on Martha's Vineyard form Bob N. Woods, a Califronia rancher andvintner. The land, worth about $18 million if developed, is dedicated to the memory of Wood's mother.
 
JUNK
 Mitchell Woflson Jr., whose family made millions through an entertainment jconglomerate, has spent nearly his entire life accumulating some 70,000. . . well, objets. What to do now? Charge admission. The $10-million-plus Wolfsonian museum, which opened last weekend in Miami Beach, will show including the first Scotch tape dispenser, a Braille version of "Mein Kampf" and King Farouk's matchbook collection.
 
KICK
 When the consumption starts getting too conspicuous, it's always safe to retreat to the quiet luxury practiced by the English lord, strolling the estate on a crisp morning with his hunting dogs at his side. And clutching, of course, a $45,500 custom-fitted shotgun from James Purdey and Sons of London, replete with a hand-carved stock of walnut from the Dordogne region of France.
 
LOOPHOLE
 Anyone with a few hundred thousand to spend on lobbying has a shot at creating his own private tax loophole. It takes real insider status to hang on to a tax break that has been closed to everyone else. Rupert Murdoch and Quincy Jones were the lucky recipients of just such a break this year when Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois jconvinced Congress to permit one last tax-exempt sale of television licenses to a minority-owned business. The deal hasn't gone through yet, but it appears very likely; Murdoch, the seller, would reap $30 million in tax savings while Jones and his partner would have $12 million knocked off the price tag.
 
MMMM
 Forward-looking enophiles are discovering the exotic sweet whites of Alsace made from overripe grapes, at about $180 a half bottle. But most wine drinkers with money to spare still go for that icon of Burgundy, Romanee-Conti from the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti. At Restaurant Daniel in New York, a bottle from 1929 will set you back $3,500; a case of the 1985 vintage recently sold at auction for $18,000.
 
THE NEW WIFE
 Maybe it all started with Hillary, but the days of the old-fashioned trophy wife - long on glamour, short on resume - are on the wane. Betsy McCaughey, New York's Lieutenant Governor, remains the state's No. 1 bachelorette after breaking off her engagement this summer. Then there's Marie-Josee Drouin (left) - an economist, newspaper columnist, member of the board of Ford Motor Company and, as of last year, Mrs. Henry Kravis.
 
ORDERING OFF THE MENU
 Being rich means never having to settle for the catch of the day. One prominent New YOrk widow has long exercised this privilege. Every Wedenday night, she arrives by Mercedes limousine at the Rainbow Room and proceeds to roder dishes that are listed nowhere on the menu. She might begin with sauteed quail eggs and beluga caviar, at $160, and move on to risotto toppedj with shredded white truffles, for $100. Then the widow and her escort - she hires a different dance instructor each week - walz and tango the night away, invariably repairing next door to Rainbow and Stars for one last bottle of 1982 Krug Brut Champagne. ($190).
 
PEARLS
 A girl's newest best friend is a strand of the lustrous, almost-iridescent colored pearls from the South Pacific. AT Tiffany & Company, $365,000 buys a particulary chic necklace of large Black South Sea pearls, even offering a concession to traditional tastes: the clasp is hidden in a platinum ball studded with 40 diamonds.
 
RISK REDUCTION
 Shrewd casino gamblers play only baccarat or blackjack, where the house advantage is razor thin. But a truly high roller can improve even those odds, buying the privilege to play fewer hands at higher stakes than the house limit. A Japanese gambler named Akio Kashiwagi used to play baccarat at Trump Plaza for $200,000 a hand. (In 1992, Kashiwagi was stabbed to death in Japan, owing some $9 million to American casinos.)
 
SAFETY
 It's no longer a luxury to own the gadget that turns on the yard lights when a raccoon wanders by. Visions Innovative Electronic Environments, in North Palm Beach, Fla, wraps an entire house in industrial-strength electronics. When the house is empty, the system switches to guard mode, faking the lighting and television-use patterns of the occupants. And video cameras, linked to special computers, allow owners to view their possessions in real time from anywhere in the world.
 
TIME
 This most precious commodity, of course, is irreplaceable. So how best to take advantage of It? The Agusta A109C is the ultimate timesaver, a $2.7 million Italian-built helicopter with twin engines, airplanelike streamlining and a top speed of 175 m.p.h. There's plenty of room on board to do business, and no ugly delays at the airport. For longer hops, the $25-million-plus Gulfstream IV-SP jet, with shower and bedroom (or a dozen seats), can fly nonstop from Chicago to Paris at 80 percent of the speed of sound. Next year, owners of the IV-SP can trade up to the even roomeier Gulfstream V, the first personal jet able to fly nonstop form New York to Tokyo. The price tag: about $30 million, plus decorating.
 
UNCTION
 When life is on the line, it's far from clear that the rich have an edge over the well-insured middle class. Doctors willing to be at beck and call for a price are rarely the most skilled. And while donating a bundle to a hospital does insure V.I.P. treatment, it might also lead to treatment-by-committee - which is often dangerously conservative. What money can buy is Claridge's-like lodgings and service insituations in which other patients must settle for Motel 6. At Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center's McKeen Pavilion, whose long-term patients include Sunny von Bulow, there is even a pianist to tinkle away the cocktail-hour gloom.
 
VROOM
 In the 1980's, Ferraris were better status symbols than cars. The seats were uncomfortable, shifting gears required muscular forearms and when driven by amateurs the cars had an unfortunate propensity to spin out of control. But now the rich want their status symbols to be practical as well, and Ferrari has responded with the very drivable 456 GT, a plush, power-everything four-seater with the acceleration of a Porsche and the road manners of a Lexus. And all for just $207,000 (plus $3,400 air freight for those who can't bear to delay gratification).
 
WORLD ON A WRIST
 A $20 Casio keeps better time than the best mechanical watches, so why would anyone pay 10,000 times as much? For some, it's a celebration of the marvels of Victorian technology: a watch's value is largely determined by how many functions - what the Swiss Call complications - can fit inside the most elegant case. Date, moon phase, dual time zones and multiple stopwatches are child's play; "les grandes complications" include a perpetual calendar, a "tourbilon" mechanism, which compensates for the differing impact of gravity when the watch is held in various positions, and a "repeater" mechanism that chimes the hour and minutes with the push of a button. I.W.C.'s Grande Complication platinum watch, whose features include a repeater and perpetual calendar, goes for about $195,000 at Tourneau (or $275,000 with hand-finished platinum bracet).
 
XANADU
 Well-heeled jbody worshippers from either coast gravitate to Canyon Ranch in Tucson, Aris. Southern California's matrons flock to the Golden Door in Escondido, while their counterparts in Texas go to the Greenhouse inDallas. But the spa of the moment is clearly Cal-a-Vie, a "Provencal" village set among 150 landscaped acres north of San Diego. What does $3,950 a week buy? All the usual spa treats, to be sure, plus some unusual pampering. The individual jcottages are decorated in French country; the cuisine is built around fruits and vegetables from the spa's garden. And there are no fewer than four staff members to every client. Barbra Streisand slept here. So did Donna Karan, Nan Kempner, Angelica Houston, Michelle Pfeiffer, Julia Roberts and Oprah Winfrey.
 
YES MEN
 Like most movie stars, Eddie Murphy spends freely on the usual trappings of wealth. He also employs a cre of famously devout "personal assistants" who are always eager to second their boss's opinion, from where he should eat to what movie he should make. This may help explain the string of bombs he has starred in lately. As one review of his recent "Vampire in Brooklyn" put it, "Next time, maybe Murphy's entourage will include better scriptwriters and fewer personal assistants."
 
ZEBRAS, ETC.
 Michael Steinhardt, the recently retired hedge-fund operator, maintains a wildlife preserve on half of his 50-plus-acre estate in Bedford, N.Y. Four acres are devoted to birds (including African cranes and a cereopsis goose), mammals (wallabies, kangaroos, alpacas, antelopes, zebras and camels) roam the rest. And it's not just his own animals that he supports: last year he bought two islands in the Falklands as a refuge for penguins, seals and the black-browed albatross.

HEADLINE: In Co-ops, Renting Is a Growing Concern

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
LORETTA KRIARIS thought she was doing her fellow co-op owners a favor two years ago by capping -- at eight -- the number of apartments that could be rented at any given time in her 115-unit building in the Briarwood section of Queens.
After all, a high percentage of rentals had made it difficult for her co-op to refinance its mortgage, for apartment owners to sell their units and for prospective buyers to get loans. 
 "It was highly restrictive," said Ms. Kriaris, who was board president at the time. "But it was in the context of seeking refinancing. It was a last-ditch effort to stave off default and get rid of an exorbitant rate of interest that the co-op was paying on the underlying mortgage."
There was also, Ms. Kriaris said, the matter of the building's ambiance with many of the apartments occupied by renters. "They have a different feeling and attitude toward the building than the owner-occupants do," she said.
Surprisingly, perhaps, the eight-unit cap was not appreciated by the majority of shareholders in the building, which is at 143-50 Hoover Avenue. About 57 percent of the apartments are rented out. And three months ago, a new board was elected that eliminated the cap.
"It is troubling," Ms. Kriaris said. "If there is no scrutiny and no control, ultimately this will have a deleterious effect on the building, and the number of rentals will escalate."
The conflict inside co-ops between unit owners who rent out their apartments and those who live in them is one of the most vexing issues in the co-op world today. Many boards in recent years have loosened sublease policies to extend relief to apartment owners facing financial hardship. At the same time, though, some boards have tightened the rules for a variety of financial and lifestyle reasons.
"I consider this to be the next big emerging co-op problem," said Marc J. Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
He estimated that from 1,000 to 2,000 buildings have some sort of serious conflict between renters and owners. There are 8,080 co-op buildings in the city, half of them in Manhattan, containing about 416,000 apartments. About 15 percent of the city lives in co-op units -- but almost half of them are renters.
There are also 1,040 condominium complexes, which sometimes have similar conflicts between renters and owners. Such conflicts arise less frequently in condominiums, however, because buyers often opt for condos because of the freedom to rent the units out with few restrictions.
Still, resident owners of condos can get just as annoyed as co-op owners if renters dominate a building, as is the case at Park Avenue Court, a 223-unit condominium in the old Gimbels store at 120 East 87th Street on the East Side of Manhattan. There a consortium of Hong Kong investors bought 118 units and is renting them out; the developer had filed for bankruptcy.
"The building is not being maintained to the standard that it would if it were owner-occupied," said Joanna Townshend-Boegner, an apartment owner.
Such problems are much more prevalent and contentious at co-ops, however. And the problems are not limited to New York City. Many co-ops exist in the New Jersey suburbs and in Westchester County.
"The subletting issue is indeed one of the most difficult that co-op boards now face," said Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
Subleasing -- the technical term for renting a co-op unit, because the owners are the actual tenants -- isn't always a panacea for apartment owners who can't sell their units and must move or sell. Some co-op boards have refused to allow sublets. Others have tacked on fees. And even with the strong rental market, sometimes the rent doesn't cover the apartment owner's combined maintenance and share loan payment. Moreover, many co-op and condo owners are unaccustomed to acting as landlord, especially when it comes to dealing with tenants.
Subletting, however, can be even more of a headache for the co-op.
First, banks generally do not make "share" or "end" loans for individual units -- the equivalent of the mortgages used by owners to buy private houses -- if a building has more than 50 or 60 percent of its units occupied by subtenants. In a market where buyers are still often hard to come by, that can be a deal-killer for tenants who are trying to sell their apartments.
Second, a high percentage of subtenants may also endanger a co-op's ability to refinance its underlying mortgage -- the loan taken out by the co-op corporation to buy the building from the sponsor or the converter.
Third, renters, generally, have a reputation, perhaps ill-deserved, for lacking as much pride or concern for a building's appearance and operation as owners do. Worldwide Plaza, a condominium at 350 West 50th Street in Manhattan, last year tightened up its screening of rental tenants and its house rules after some tenants were spotted roller-blading in the hallways.
Fourth, in buildings where the sponsor has defaulted and subtenants still live in unsold units, such apartments revert back to the co-op. This, however, frequently creates a financial crunch because the board usually collects rents on these apartments that do not match what shareholders pay in maintenance; this is because the subtenants are generally living in rent-stabilized units that rent for significantly less than they would bring on the open market.
IF such apartments are vacated and the co-op corporation decides not to sell them, market-rate rents can be charged, as is the case with investor-owned units, and such rents can be equal to or even more than the maintenance that would be charged if the unit were a co-op.
But the far more common situation, according to Ms. Rothman and others familiar with co-op issues, is for rentals to fall short of expenses. This shortfall in revenue from subtenants, Ms. Rothman says, often causes the co-op board to raise the maintenance on all owners of apartments in the building.
"You have the shareholders subsidizing the renters," said Stuart Saft, a lawyer who serves as chairman of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
He added that co-op boards cannot even cut services because of the discrepancy between the amount of revenue collected from renters and the monthly maintenance paid by shareholders.
"If they do, the renters can then seek rent reductions," he said.
The wave of sponsor co-op defaults in the early 90's exacerbated this problem, as unsold units were often sold to investors who, rather than sell them, continued to rent them because of the strong market for rentals and the soft, albeit improving, market for co-ops.
Mr. Saft noted that the owners of co-op units, because of an exemption in the state's rent-regulation laws, can collect market rents for those apartments once the original rent-stabilized tenants vacate.
This exemption, he said, has created a disincentive for the owners to sell their units.
"During the downturn the last few years, no one was pressuring anyone to sell," he said. "But now the market has gotten better and the wave of sponsor defaults are mostly past. And still some owners aren't selling their units because of the rents they can get."
Mr. Luxemburg questioned whether the intent of the framers of the rent-regulation laws had been to allow an exemption from controls after an apartment is vacated in order to allow an investor or a sponsor to utilize co-ops as a permanent source of market-rent income.
He also said that continuing to rent these units rather than making a good-faith effort to sell them was inconsistent with the sponsor's obligation to the co-op and existing tenant-shareholders, even though sponsors are usually obligated to sell only a minimum of 15 percent of their units to make the co-op conversion legal.
"The sponsor put out an offering plan to convert the building to co-op status, but did that mean 100 percent co-op status or something less?" Mr. Luxemburg asked. "I would think an ordinary person reading an offering plan would think that the entire building would be converted.
"I find it surprising that the offering plans or regulations don't say that in so many words," Mr. Luxemburg said. "The problem is that it should be explicit but it is not."
Mr. Saft added that the growing role of co-op boards and unit owners as reluctant landlords could make them lobby for changes in the state's rent-regulation laws, which come up for renewal in the spring of 1997.
"Co-ops have never been involved in this issue before," he said. "It was always landlord-tenant groups going at it.
"But now there are a half-million co-op and condo owners who have an interest in seeing the regulations eliminated or curtailed," he said. "I think you will have an incredible fight in a year and a half, and I think you will see a fundamental change in rent control laws because of this."
MR. SAFT speculated that vacancy decontrol might be expanded beyond the current exemption. (Gov. George E. Pataki's Transition Committee on Housing and Community Development last year recommended phasing out rent regulations completely through vacancy decontrol -- the lifting of controls on all apartments as they become vacant. Currently apartments renting for more than $2,000 a month are, under the 1993 law, decontrolled when they become vacant.)
This may not have a direct impact on co-ops since they are already decontrolled upon vacancy, but it may remove an incentive some sponsors have for turning rental buildings into co-ops. "One of the reasons some sponsors converted to co-ops was to get vacancy decontrol," said Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in real estate issues. "If vacancy decontrol applies to all rental apartments, then there is no reason to convert, if vacancy decontrol was the major reason they were doing it."
Mr. Saft also urged that the the threshold on household income for rent-controlled and rent-stabilized units be lowered "to more like $75,000." (Rent controls for apartments renting for $2,000 or more a month that are occupied by tenants whose household income was more than $250,000 for two years running were effectively lifted in 1993.)
He said that if changes were made in rent-regulation that allowed co-op boards to charge higher rents to tenants now covered by rent regulation, then occupants of those rental units would either be spurred to buy their apartments, or they would pay the higher unregulated rents, which would go into the co-op's coffers.
"Either way, co-ops get bailed out," he said.

HEADLINE: N.J. LAW;
Do Walls Keep Out Crime, or Just Neighbors?

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
The place where Hoboken wants to build a wall is sort of in the middle of nowhere, which is both the point and the problem.
It is near railroad tracks that lie at the base of a cliff at the back of town, several hundred feet west of the city's cluster of public housing projects. At the top of the cliff is a Jersey City neighborhood called the Heights, and since the dawn of local history, residents of the two communities have climbed up and down the cliff on a system of improvised staircases and paths. Some of the travelers, residents and officials say, are drug dealers or customers looking for a low-profile route. 
 Recently, there has been more serious trouble. The Hoboken wall was proposed in August after three young visitors from the Heights argued with some Hoboken youths, then went up the hill, got their guns, walked back down the cliff, and shot and wounded three people before fleeing. The incident rocked a neighborhood that has been largely free of the gunplay that often plagues public housing in bigger cities.
The wall envisioned by the city -- no construction specifics have been mentioned yet -- would run for four blocks, from one end of the housing project to the other. It wouldn't keep people out altogether -- the difficult-to-patrol cliff runs the whole length of Hoboken's mile-and-a-half border -- but it would make it harder for pedestrians to get into and out of heart of the housing project and easier for police to pursue criminals.
"Drug dealers are using that back way as an easy egress route," Mayor Anthony Russo said. "Building the wall would make it a little more difficult for that to continue."
The wall will not be built for a while, if at all. Mayor Russo, who estimated the cost at $300,000 to $500,000, has asked New Jersey Transit, which is in the process of buying the freight tracks from Conrail, if it would be interested in paying for part of the construction. (The wall is also being touted as a deterrent to the gangs who loot the Conrail freight trains). The state Department of Transportation, which oversees the transit agency, is considering its options.
Many residents of the projects welcome the wall proposal.
"A lot of people come down off the tracks to either buy or sell their drugs, and it's infested down here in the community already," said Cindy Willis, vice president of United Sisters, a group based in the projects that works to keep young people out of trouble. "We don't need any out-of-towners to make the problem any worse than it already is, and if that wall keeps a little of the activity out, I'm all for it."
Walled cities, of course, are nearly as old as civilization itself. But more and more communities in the state seem to be turning to fortification to address their social ills.
In Monmouth County, Neptune Township and the religious shore community of Ocean Grove, which is part of the township, are considering a proposal to erect gates on the footbridges that connect Ocean Grove to Asbury Park, and lock them from midnight to 5 A.M. Officials in mostly black Asbury Park have criticized the concept as racist.
Last year, Pennsauken, a suburb of crime-plagued Camden, toyed with the idea of walling itself off but abandoned it after a wave of bad publicity. And in 1993, Maplewood approved the installation of traffic barriers that were intended to keep drivers from using a once-placid neighborhood as a thoroughfare, but also happened to close off part of the border with Newark, ruffling feathers there.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, says wall-building is a suburban response to crime and trespassing.
"If you live in a high-rise apartment in Manhattan, essentially you're walled off from the street," he said. "When you're in lower-density environments, if people want a similar feeling of security, they feel that all they can do is a put up a wall. The difference is that one comes off very distasteful and the other comes off as business as usual."
In Hoboken, it is not a question ofkeeping out the underclass. The economically and culturally diverse Heights, in fact, is considerably more gentrified than the housing project. Rather, residents are simply trying to find a way to control crime.
A similar project has been tried in New Brunswick. Last year, the New Brunswick Housing Authority, at the request of residents, put a high wrought-iron fence around two garden apartment complexes to keep drug dealers and buyers from the adjoining neighborhood out.
It didn't work.
"People just took saws and cut right through it," said Shirley Cargile, the manager of the two complexes. "We keep repairing it, though, because if they have to go all the way around, the cops could catch them a lot easier."
A Hoboken police officer who spoke on the condition that his name not be used said he doubted that a wall would do any good.
"It's just a big waste of money, because if you give people any kind of time, they can get through any material in a manner of minutes -- cinder blocks, concrete, whatever," he said. "Where there's a will, there's a way."

HEADLINE: UP FRONTCHATTER;
Holiday Shopping: How Much?

 BODY:
Will this Christmas be extravagant or economical? Tell Chatter about your plans for holiday shopping.
 
Joy on a Budget
Christmas 1995: Extravagant in its joy, economical in its jingle.
 
EMMET WARD
Wall
 
The Short List 
 Christmas will be economical this year. I am saving to get married next year and have cut back on my Christmas list. Also, I have been buying earlier this year and looking for more bargains. Everyone is still getting wonderful gifts, and no one will guess what I paid.
 
JUNE SANNS
Ridgefield Park
 
Fewer Temptations
I miss the mall madness! We moved from northern New Jersey in 1990. Nothing compares to the hustle and bustle during the holidays in northern New Jersey.
Christmas will be lighter this year due to time and, somewhat, to money. Then again, I don't have the temptations that were around me at Paramus Park, the Garden State Plaza, the Fashion Center and a trip to New York City.
 
AL GETLER

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2961 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Patience? This Man Practically Invented It

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
THE blue eyes sparkle, the chuckles begin somewhere deep inside his throat, then churn through his body like waves of delight. He sits in front of a slab of rare roast beef and a mountain range of mashed potatoes. The bearish fellow -- indisputably seasoned enough to ignore broccoli sprigs and anything else he chooses -- is having lunch in the Marco Polo Club, started by his friend Lowell Thomas, the explorer.
On Nov. 28, Philip L. Carret will celebrate his 99th birthday -- though, for the eighth time now, he is calling it his 100th. Worried that he would miss the big party, he had his first centennial bash when he was 92, and now he feels ahead of the game. "Phil Carret Turns 100 -- Again!" read the headline of a fake newspaper last year. 
 This is a life so full that friends in his industry joke that when Mr. Carret (rhymes with beret) reaches 100, he'll split the stock. This is a man whose grandfather was born in the 18th century, who flew a Sopwith Camel in World War I, met President Coolidge ("Any President who takes afternoon naps can't be all bad"), helped give birth to the mutual fund industry by founding the awesomely successful Pioneer Fund back when the Dow Jones industrial average was at 197, works more than 40 hours a week and cooks most of his own meals.
And it is a life that is still in flux. He is writing his fourth book, "The Patient Investor," by hand on yellow legal pads. Two weeks ago, he returned from Borneo, where he viewed his 19th total eclipse of the sun, his passion since 1925. His career is hardly over: each week, he heads a meeting of investment advisers, often picking apart theories and demanding more information.
It seems like yesterday, but it was a half century ago that Mr. Carret stopped in Omaha to meet Howard Buffett, a broker who recommended a few stocks.
Mr. Carret stayed in touch with the Buffett family, thank you very much. Berkshire Hathaway, managed by Mr. Buffett's son Warren -- a teen-ager when Mr. Carret met him -- is perhaps Mr. Carret's most successful investment, soaring from $2,000 a share less than a decade ago to more than $30,000 now.
Warren Buffett's famous philosophy of buying rock-solid stocks and sitting on them echoes Mr. Carret's strategy, described in his first book, "The Art of Investing," in 1930.
Luck matters, but luck alone cannot explain Mr. Carret's success: he operates under strict self-imposed standards. "Phil has the best long-term investment record of anyone in America," Mr. Buffett said in 1991.
Two years later, in a note to Mr. Carret, he said, "You are the Lou Gehrig of investing."
Here, for the record, are Mr. Carret's views on the current market: "In the short term, it's in a very delicate position. In recent weeks, we've had a flood of hundreds of millions of dollars of new offerings. This glut pushes down prices in the short run. Also, the market is very high in historical valuations. But in the longer run, I'm bullish. America has about 100 good years left."
It is always the long view that matters. "Trading in and out of the market is the pinnacle of stupidity," he scoffed. This old man buys enduring companies, not faceless stocks. He has seen it all and then some: his professional life has spanned 31 bull markets, 30 bear markets, 20 recessions and the Depression. He remembers when bicycles had one speed, T-shirts carried no messages, and electric lights, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Federal Reserve did not exist. Options, financial derivatives and the like baffle the daylights out of him.
"My grandfather does not understand why anyone thinks they need a cellular phone," said his 42-year-old granddaughter, Renee Carret, a portfolio manager in the family firm.
For a man who is one of the legendary stock pickers, his secret is not elusive. Quality, conservatively defined, is Mr. Carret's prey: strong balance sheets, steady earnings, clever market strategies and committed managers with hefty investments in their own companies, at least a year's salary, by Mr. Carret's standards. Their own money, too. No stock options or other corporate handouts.
Mr. Carret's success combines intense work -- only recently did he stop commuting six days a week from Scarsdale in Westchester County -- and a capriciousness of spirit. A few years ago, he noticed lots of North American Van Lines trucks on the highway, researched the company and bought some of its shares -- just before Pepsico noticed the same thing and acquired the company at a premium. He made a nice profit on Neutrogena, later bought by Johnson & Johnson; he liked the soap in a hotel room. Another time, he noticed the bottle on top of the water cooler in his office: he bought the stock of its manufacturer, Liqui-Box, for $10.50 and sold it for $120.
Not to say there have been no disasters. More than 60 years ago, Mr. Carret acted on a tip from his bookkeeper and bought an oil stock -- he does not remember which one -- for $20. He does remember exactly what he sold it for: 12 1/2 cents. He ended up firing the bookkeeper, but not for the bum tip; he was caught embezzling.
More recently, Mr. Carret hit on the notion that the Bank of New England could not make all bad loans -- a wildly wrong guess. The bank failed in 1991.
Today, though he has given up all administrative responsibility at Carret & Company, which handles investment portfolios of at least $500,000, he is still at his small, cluttered desk every Monday through Friday promptly at 9, picking stocks.
He has no interest in a stock unless he thinks it will at least double, but he is willing to wait for that. He looks on in disapproval and no small measure of befuddlement at the whiz kids managing funds worth hundreds of millions who dart in and out of a market that, in their short careers, has only gone up. "They buy at 10:15 A.M. and sell at 3:45 P.M.," he said, shaking his huge head. "Crazy."
One of Mr. Carret's few recreational activities has been mountain climbing -- "but only the kind where you put one foot in front of the other and walk; I have never hung off the edge of cliffs." He neither smokes nor drinks, and buys no tobacco or alcohol stocks.
He takes only vitamins, but could not help noticing his peers were a strong market for drugs. So about a year ago, he bought stock in Merck, which had been depressed by concerns over managed-health care. The stock met his financial yardsticks and its management impressed him when he paid a visit. Since the purchase, the shares have risen 70 percent. "Most people my age are practically drowning in drugs," he said.
Mr. Carret has no answer to why he has outlived almost everyone, including several doctors. A year and a half ago, he said, he received a mysterious message in his brain, that he would die on April 15. He woke up on tax-deadline day and noticed he was still alive, then spent the day at home, keeping an eye on himself.
"It was a false alarm," Mr. Carret said. "Maybe next year."
The long view is in his genes: virtually all his direct ancestors have lived into their 80's. His father, a lawyer, was 22 when Lincoln gave his Gettysburg Address, and his grandfather, the son of Napoleon's paymaster general, was born in 1797. His mother, a social worker who became one of the nation's first probation officers, was 39 when she gave birth to him, her only child.
"I was brought up by old people, my grandmother, old-maid aunts, you name it," he said.
Mr. Carret, born in Lynn, Mass., embodies long New England traditions, becoming a Congregationalist after growing up in the more-liberal Unitarian faith and, like others in his well-off family, attending Harvard. The family's earliest Harvard man, he said, was the Rev. Daniel Gookin, class of 1669. As a freshman in 1914, he was at the new Yale Bowl for its first contest, Harvard-Yale.
In four years, he finished his undergraduate degree and a year at the brand-new business school -- enough, by his reckoning. Chemistry, his first choice, struck him as hopelessly declasse after he visited a grimy gas company laboratory and noticed his tour guide wore a celluloid collar, that era's equivalent of the clip-on tie. "The absolute nadir of sartorial elegance," Mr. Carret said, wincing.
In 1917, he entered the Army Signal Corps, a predecessor to the Air Force. He learned to shoot a machine gun while piloting a Sopwith Camel and was sent to France, but the war ended before he saw combat.
After discharge, he went to work for a small securities firm in Boston, starting at $15 a week. After five months, he got a raise to $20. "I was insulted," at the paltry amount, he said, and took off to roam America, working in mining camps and the like, eventually landing a job selling bonds in Seattle.
It was there, in 1920, that he met Florence Elisabeth Osgood, the granddaughter of a Civil War general and Vermont governor and a 1918 graduate of Wellesley College. They were married in 1922, and had 63 years together before she died in 1986.
They had two sons, a daughter, 12 grandchildren and, as of now, 12 great grandchildren.
Mr. Carret likes to say that Betty, as he called her, was 99.99 percent perfect because only God is 100 percent. "In truth, I never detected a flaw that could represent a 0.01 percent shortfall," he quickly added.
After his marriage, he returned to Boston to the firm he had left, this time in sales. He quit in four months, and went to work at Barron's, the new financial weekly owned by Clarence W. Barron. Mr. Carret, who wrote feature articles, loves to tell stories about his flamboyant boss, who weighed well in excess of 300 pounds and had a flowing white beard.
On one train ride to New York, he recalled, Mr. Barron ensconced himself in his compartment and played bridge most of the trip. But at dinner time, he emerged and walked briskly to the dining car with two colleagues and a secretary, proceeding to dictate letters and issue rapid-fire orders between hurried bites.
"What a workaholic!" people would marvel. "What a phony," Mr. Carret says now.
The most valuable lesson from Mr. Carret's journalistic career came the day Sherman Adams, no relation to Eisenhower's chief of staff, visited the newsroom. Mr. Carret could not help overhearing Mr. Adams describing his idea for a new financial company, which became Massachusetts Investors Trust, one of the first mutual funds.
In 1928, Mr. Carret scraped together $25,000 from family and friends and started his own fund. It was first called Fidelity Investment Trust (no relation to today's Fidelity), and was later renamed Pioneer Fund. It started strongly with blue chips like Maytag preferred and Firestone Tire and Rubber, and its value moved briskly upward. Even after the 1929 crash, it was still ahead by 11 percent, but by the beginning of 1932 an original investment of $1,000 on Jan. 1, 1929, would have fallen to $470.
But after the market hit bottom that year, the fund bounced back 37 percent. Today, that original $1,000 would be worth more than $2 million, making Pioneer by far the most profitable of the old-timer funds, according to Mutual Funds Magazine.
Mr. Carret never looked back. He picked stocks for himself, for Pioneer and later for Carret & Company, which he began in 1963, the year he sold control of Pioneer's management company. In 1983, he stepped down as chairman of Pioneer, though he still attends monthly board meetings.
His nuts-and-bolts message came to be called value investing, and he wanted to make sure it would continue for his well-heeled clients. Among other attractions are individual accounts for each client, set up by one of a dozen investment analysts familiar with the client's particular needs. Another is a flat fee of 1 percent for the first $5 million of the market value of investments, sliding downward to four-tenths of 1 percent for amounts over $25 million. There is no transaction fee and no profit-sharing. The firm Continued on Next Page
 
Continued from Preceding Page
manages $600 million, up from $180 million a decade ago, with a large part of the asset growth presumably coming from stock-market gains.
"We're performance-driven, not transaction-driven," said Frank H. Betz, the managing director, who added that Carret was a company "where gray hair is valued." The average age of the nine principals is the mid-60's, not counting Mr. Carret.
Mr. Carret spent two years searching for a successor to buy the firm, of which he owned half. Neither his son Gerard, who died of cancer in 1991 at 70, nor his other son, Donald, now 66 -- both of whom owned a quarter of the firm -- wanted the helm. The elder Mr. Carret was most curious about the religious and moral convictions of possible buyers. Price was never the principal object, because he gives away everything he makes to Harvard, Wellesley and charities. But he wanted someone true to value investing.
He found David J. Olderman, now 58, who had been vice chairman of Stone & Webster Inc., then retired to Florida. The first thing Mr. Olderman did on retirement was earn a master's degree in moral theology.
Mr. Olderman found the chance to carry on the Carret name and mission irresistible, and bought the firm. Mr. Carret draws no salary, but all the others do, including Donald and Renee Carret.
Mr. Olderman became president and chief executive in 1988 and chairman in 1993. "Things don't change," he said said. "Good people make good companies. Great people make great companies."
Lunch with Mr. Carret and a few colleagues is a soothing blend of memory, insight and plain delight. F.D.R., he says, was wrong: "There was plenty to fear. Everyone was just scared out of their wits."
He regards government as a barely necessary evil, calling himself an anarchist. But he does not entirely resent S.E.C. disclosure rules, which prevent investors with more access to detailed data from profiting at the expense of the less informed by discovering hidden assets.
When asked about government securities, he reverts to his curmudgeon mode. "I don't like to invest in the operations of insolvent organizations," he snorted.
President Clinton? Mr. Carret remembers being charmed sitting next to the candidate at dinner a few years ago and writing a check for $1,000. "Never again," he said of the man he calls a disaster because of his weak economic policies.
Though he abhors war, he thinks it only sensible to profit from them. In 1939, for instance, he found a Cuban sugar company whose stock was available at $1.75. He bought some, then a lot more at $7 to $8. He sold most for $60, and the last little bit for $200. "One thing that goes up in a war is sugar," he said, "because it's a very concentrated form of energy and everybody likes the stuff."
He tells of one stock Howard Buffett recommended: Greif Brothers. He bought it almost 50 years ago, following his usual guidelines and knowing there would always be demand for their main product, barrels, and has been buying it ever since. It has not exactly worked as planned, but Greif has switched successfully into fiberboard drums and containers. Although Mr. Betz said it had been an "absolute dog for the last five years," it is the classic Carret stock: a steady grower with steady management bought at a reasonable price. Each share Mr. Carret bought at around 68 cents is now worth $25.625.
Arrogance is what most alienates Mr. Carret from a stock. He remembers reading I.B.M.'s 1991 letter to shareholders, in which John Akers, then the chairman, promised no dividend cut. Within two years, Big Blue had lost money and slashed the payout. By contrast, the next chief, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., in a speech to investment advisers, said only, "I think we can do it." Mr. Carret had already bought some I.B.M. stock simply because it was so cheap, but that speech was his signal to buy more.
Mr. Carret lives alone in his Scarsdale apartment. Each week "a gal" stops in to help clean. A driver takes him to work and back. Each of his six rooms is covered top to bottom with books. The one he is reading now is "God: A Biography," by Jack Miles. He also has old copies of Value Line Investment Survey evaluations, office castoffs, strewn about, and trade publications like Oil and Gas Journal.
He delights in reading annual reports of odd investments, and spent years pondering the annual report of Howe Caverns, which operates a cave in upstate New York. That report routinely included revenues from pay toilets, and Mr. Carret, for reasons he will not describe, tried mightily to find a link between this statistic and overall admissions. "The correlation was practically zero," he said.
His social life is sometimes not so tame as he would like. "I get invited out occasionally, mostly by widows," he said. "Only one of them really made a pass at me. She scared the hell out of me."
And there are those eclipses. Mr. Carret and his wife saw their first one in Westerly, R.I., in 1925. He has now seen them in every corner of the world, from the Amazon to Antarctica to Siberia and, most recently, in Borneo. He happily concedes that they are all pretty much the same but insists no sight compares with the inexorable march of the moon across the sun. Then comes what eclipse buffs call "totality," four minutes or so of night in the middle of day. A diamond ring effect is created by the groove between two lunar mountains.
But eclipses remain forever mysterious. "You see shadow bands on the surface of the earth, which I don't understand," Mr. Carret said, Pushing aside his uneaten roast beef, Mr. Carret headed back to his desk to study annual reports, a patient investor on the prowl.
"I haven't done anything brilliant lately," the almost 99-year-old man said with a wink.

HEADLINE: Washington, Watch What You Wish For

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
"BEWARE, lest stern heaven hate you enough to hear your prayers!" Anatole France said it 114 years ago, but the warning still resonates in the current battle over the Federal budget.
For more than a decade, mainstream economists have been begging, pleading, demanding that the chronic deficit opened in the Reagan years be closed. "Cutting the deficit will boost growth and help restore confidence that our elected representatives know how to run the store," explains Henry Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington. 
 But now that the Republican-controlled Congress has formally resolved to balance the budget by the year 2002 -- a stand that
has led to the current impasse with the White House over the shape, the size and the pace of spending cuts -- many of those same economists are having second thoughts.
In part, they are reacting to the proposed means rather than to the end: the Republican budget, which is intended to shrink the Federal Government and give more authority to the states, would cut deeply into traditional programs supplementing the incomes of the poor, even as it reduced taxes on capital gains and for middle-income families. The White House wants a different mix and a smaller amount of savings spread out over a longer period and a much more modest tax cut. The gulf remains so wide that the fundamental issue may ultimately not be resolved until the voters choose sides in November 1996.
In part, the economists fear that fixing a path to a balanced budget would inhibit Government efforts to cushion the economy and protect the losers if there is a downturn in the next few years. "A recession would be no time to cut the deficit," frets Robert Solow, the Nobel Prize-winning economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
But in large measure, the shift reflects skepticism over the capacity of Republicans -- or Democrats -- to shrink the Government in rational ways.
What the economists who helped lay the intellectual foundation for the current drive to balance the budget wanted was to inhibit Uncle Sam's inclination to support high living today at the expense of future generations. What they fear they are getting is a smaller Government that cuts tangible and intangible investment -- everything from advanced technology to adequate medical care for pregnant women -- far more than private consumption, which it helps subsidize through Social Security and other ballooning entitlement programs for the middle class. That approach, they say, will undermine rather than enhance the capacity of the economy to grow.
"The task of public policy should not be a balanced budget come hell or high water," warns William Nordhaus, a Yale economist. The challenge, he argues, "is to weed out low-yield public investments and to reduce inefficient public subsidies" -- a challenge yet to be embraced by the current budget-balancers on either end of Pennsylvania Avenue.
The modern debate over budget deficits was born in the early 1980's, with the big Reagan tax cut. The initial worry was that the resulting Government borrowing to bridge the gap between tax revenues and Government outlays, which rose from $38 billion in 1979 to $212 billion in 1985, would "crowd out" productivity-enhancing private investment.
In fact, foreigners came to the rescue. America's "current account" on international financial transactions was roughly in balance in 1979. Six years later, foreigners invested $122 billion more in America than Americans invested abroad, as everyone from Argentine cattle barons to Japanese bankers bought large amounts of Government and private American securities.
That shifted the debate to the question of sustainability. Stephen Marris, senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, predicted a "hard landing" in which foreign cash would dry up and interest rates would soar, triggering severe recession. "We came close in 1987," he recalls, "but I underestimated the creditworthiness of the Government."
The bang no longer seems realistic, even with talk these days, courtesy of the budget impasse, of a Government default on Treasury obligations. But most economists still worry a lot about a demographic whimper later on.
INDEED, the current indictment of budget deficits -- one more or less accepted by most economists -- is based on the calculation that Americans are not saving enough to meet their own expectations for the future. They are counting on Social Security and Medicare to sustain their living standard a quarter-century down the road, when the number of workers supporting each retiree will be nearly halved and the taxes needed to cover pay-as-you-go financing of promised benefits would make a Swedish socialist blush.
Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat, estimates that in the year 2012, entitlement programs (mostly Social Security and Medicare) plus interest payments on the debt would exceed 100 percent of projected tax revenues, leaving not a penny for the traditional activities of government. That would be the case under either the Republicans' 7-year plan to end the deficit or the 10-year alternative favored by the White House, since spending cuts under both plans, deep as they are, go only so far, allowing the deficit to flare again, and hugely so, almost as soon as it goes away.
"We will have a fiscal nightmare on our hands," says Lawrence Kotlikoff, a Boston University economist.
The only plausible solution from this perspective is to use long-term fiscal policy to offset private profligacy, reducing private consumption and raising growth-enhancing investment, both private and public. Delay, the deficit hawks argue, will only compound the political problem by forcing greater levels of sacrifice.
"Anyone who says there's no hurry to do something about the deficit is, in effect, conceding the Government isn't going to pay its obligations," concludes Paul Krugman, an economist at Stanford University.
Indeed, that is exactly the argument made by the Republicans at the forefront of the drive to bring the budget into balance by 2002. "The biggest risk our nation faces is that we not balance our budget and that we continue to spend our children's and our grandchildren's money to pay for programs we cannot afford," said Senator Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico and chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
But the closer one looks at the mechanics of doing the right thing by future generations, the more problematic it appears.
A straightforward objection comes from those who fear that deficit reduction would aggravate the business cycle. Economists have mostly given up the Keynesian idea of using discretionary fiscal policy -- temporary reductions in tax rates or increases in Government spending -- to smooth the economy. Dozens of Federal programs, however, quickly and automatically adjust spending to buffer changes in private spending. And once Washington is locked politically on a path toward zero deficit, some of this buffer is likely to be stripped away.
Brad DeLong, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, estimates that 25 to 30 percent of personal income lost in recessions is offset by the lower tax bite on those reduced earnings, while roughly 7 percent is made up in Government transfers. And "that 7 percent, mostly unemployment insurance and food stamps, goes to people who really need it," he argues.
Still others are dismayed with the way the new Republican majority in Congress has built an antideficit coalition at the expense of the lower third of the income distribution. Businesses with close ties to the Republicans -- from sugar beet growers to distillers of ethanol for motor fuel -- will retain their perquisites. Investors will be tossed a long-awaited bone in the form of a cut in the capital gains tax. And even families with six-figure incomes will get tax credits for children.
To pay for this lagniappe, welfare, college grants for the poor and Medicaid will take heavy hits. And low-wage workers will lose part of what was once seen as the conservatives' answer to dependence on Washington, the earned income tax credit.
Those sympathetic with the Republican approach defend the need to get Uncle Sam off the backs of both the middle class and the rich. "In my view, the tax cuts don't go far enough to encourage work and investment," said Dean Stansel, a fiscal policy analyst at the libertarian CATO Institute in Washington.
But the distributional impact has many veterans from the deficit wars shaking their heads.
"The family tax cut is wasted money," argues Dale Jorgensen, a Harvard economist. "It uses a lot of revenue with no payoff in economic growth."
Paul Tsongas, the former Democratic Senator from Massachusetts who now leads a bipartisan lobbying group for deficit reduction, adds that the tax cuts "have undermined the sense of shared sacrifice."
Probably the most damning attack on deficit reduction, though, comes from economists who fear Washington has been miscast as a wastrel -- and that budget cuts are likely to lead to lower, not higher, national savings.
To clarify the point, look at the (often abused) analogy between the Government's budget and that of a family. If a family earns $50,000, spends $60,000 and has nothing to show for it at year-end except more credit card debt, it has "dissaved" $10,000. Suppose, though, the family earns $50,000, spends $40,000 and uses the rest for a down payment on a $100,000 house.
The family is out-of-pocket $140,000, but no one would say it has negative savings of $90,000 -- the difference between income and outlays. Its assets have grown by $100,000, while its debts have risen just $90,000, implying that the family is $10,000 richer. By contrast, the Federal budget makes no distinction between consumption and savings and investment. Hence a change in the deficit may reflect a change in consumption (pension checks) or a change in public wealth (buildings).
Robert Eisner, a former president of the American Economic Association, has argued that government gets a bum rap largely because its investments exceed the depreciation of government-generated assets.
He notes that spending at all levels of government exceeded revenues by $193 billion in 1991. He estimates, however, that governments invested $530 billion in everything from B-2's to teachers' salaries while existing government assets depreciated by a lesser amount -- $361 billion. Figured the way a family (or corporation) would calculate its budget, the true deficit is $193 billion less the increase in government wealth ($530 billion minus $361 billion). And this comes to just $24 billion.
THESE calculations are necessarily crude. There is no generally accepted method for writing off nuclear missiles. Nor is there an obvious way of deciding what portion of Medicaid represents compassion, and what portion is an investment in future productivity.
But Mr. Nordhaus of Yale offers a way of finessing such details. He notes that anxiety with budget deficits derives from concern that the national savings rate, both public and private, is too low. And if that is the case, he suggests, the degree of anxiety ought to be linked to the trend in savings rather than the absolute level.
Conventional estimates of gross savings show the rate has indeed fallen from 17.3 percent of national income in 1955 to a measly 12.5 percent in 1993. Mr. Nordhaus, however, believes that the estimates, which dismiss investments in education, the military and health as consumption, distort the trend. Adding back in these intangible contributions to future welfare, Mr. Nordhaus concludes that "the genuine savings rate is essentially constant."
Deficit hawks like Mr. Kotlikoff of Boston University are not impressed. The bottom line, they stress, is not the trend in the savings rate, but whether savings are adequate to keep the economy growing fast enough to pay for the retirement of the baby boomers. Mr. Eisner concedes the point, but argues that the path of least political resistance to deficit reduction is as likely to reduce the rate of growth as it is to raise it. And here, he has quiet allies in President Clinton's economists.
According to the Council of Economic Advisers, by the time the Republicans balanced the budget, Federal investments on research and development would be down by a third. And the politics of the process make it likely that the programs that remain are the least productive -- like NASA's space station. By the same token, Republican cuts in grants for education would hit a productive form of investment.
A different approach -- one that raised taxes on private consumption and curtailed Government transfer payments (in particular, Social Security) -- would hurt Federal investments less and thus might increase the economy's capacity to grow.
But while the Administration is more sensitive to the pitfalls of cutting Government investment, Democrats, too, are under pressure to keep Social Security cuts and tax increases off the table. That largely explains why Mr. Solow is prepared to pull his punches on deficit reduction. "If Americans won't pay for education with taxes," he explains, "I'd pay for it by borrowing."
All this may leave politically aware Americans uneasy. Deficit reduction has become the mantra of responsible government. But the real goal, generating enough savings to prepare America to meet its looming economic obligations, is several steps removed from the process. And the politics of getting from here to there are tortuous.
THE consequences of failing to prepare for tomorrow's problems cannot be entirely lost on either President Clinton or the Republican leadership. Even accounting for the Republicans' proposed whack at Medicare, a long-term solution to the deficit is not at hand.
"Every year of delay shifts another percentage point of the budget from discretionary spending to entitlements that largely benefit the middle class," reminds Senator Kerrey. Hence many analysts remain hopeful that after this budget impasse is broken, deficit reduction will focus on curtailing consumption by Americans who can afford it.
"This is just the appetizer to the main course ahead," suggests Robert Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office. "Success now would help to make the meal digestible."
 
A Sea of Red Ink, or Just a Puddle?
 The combined 1991 state and Federal budget deficits were just over $193 billion, according to Government figures. But if Washington accounted for public finances the way most businesses do, the gap would narrow sharply, according to a study by Robert Eisner of Northwestern Universtiy. Instead of treating long-term investments like education, research and infrastructure as expenses that get charged to the books immediately, the Governemtn could capitalize those items. They then would be charged over time, or depreciated, as the benefits of the investments are enjoyed.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Remember The 50's? Stocks Sure Do

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Prices went up and up. And never was seen a discouraging trend.
So it is for the stock market in 1995. Last week, with the Washington politicians squabbling worse than ever, with talk of a possible default on Treasury securities, interest rates fell and the Dow neared 5,000. 
 In fact, few investors take the current budget battle seriously. There is great confidence that something will be worked out, bringing down the deficit and averting default. So while prices rise, Wall Street tells jokes. Did you hear about the new types of Treasury bonds to be issued to avoid default? The Gingrich bonds have no maturity, the Dole bonds bear no interest, and the Clinton bonds have no principle.
To those brought up on traditional theories of value, reading the stock tables can seem like a joke as well. The Internet stocks -- a category no one ever heard of before this year -- show amazing levitation. Uunet, an Internet-access company, went public in May with insiders selling shares at $14. What fools these insiders be. The shares traded over $95 on Friday. The company has yet to earn an operating profit. Spyglass, a competitor, is making money. Its insiders sold at $17 in May, but the stock hit $102 Friday. That's 204 times profits.
But the most amazing part of the 1995 stock market has been the relentless way it rises. So far this year, the largest drop in the Standard & Poor's 500 -- the worst you could have done in those stocks with abysmal market timing -- has been a dip of 2.4 percent. There has never been a year without a bigger fall than that. The old record is 3.6 percent, set in 1964.
To be sure, prices do fall some days. The S.& P. 500 has shown drops in 38 percent of the trading days so far this year. But that too is close to a record. Only in four years -- 1945 and three times in the placid 1950's -- has the market managed such consistent rises that the proportion of down days was below 40 percent. In three of the four following years -- all but 1946 -- share prices rose.
Added to this is the fact that the stock market has had an unprecedented run of never embarrassing a bull, even briefly. Barring a sharp plunge in the remaining six weeks, this will be the fifth consecutive year that the S.& P. 500 has not had a 10 percent drop. Never before had there been even three consecutive years that were so mild.
This is occurring because of the massive commitment of individual investors to the stock market, largely through mutual funds. It is a trend brought on by baby boomers worryied about retirement and convinced that stocks are the only long-term answer. And it is a reminder to market seers that stocks go up because there are buyers willing to pay more, a fact that may or may not be related to such things as profits and dividends.
On Wall Street, there is starting to be talk about budget cuts bringing on a recession, if not in 1996 then in 1997. Recessions, market historians know, end bull markets. But this one conceivably could spur stock purchases, simply by making the baby boomers worry even more about retirement.
All elderly people depend on Medicare for health care, and many who were forced into nursing homes have turned to Medicaid to pay those huge bills. Now, as the decisions are left to the states, that nursing home protection may vanish. In any case, Medicare seems certain to cost more.
This is the most phenomenal bull market ever, and the Internet stocks show there are some real excesses. But maybe the fearful boomers will keep it going for a long time.
