HEADLINE: Harlem on Her Mind

BYLINE: By LISA ANDERSON 

 BODY:
THE ride from the airport was almost over. We were near home -- at least the place that would be my home for the next year. My new landlady, a friend of my aunt, had picked me up at La Guardia and was giving me a brief tour of the neighborhood.
 "This is Striver's Row," she said, as we passed Volvos and other imports dotting a street that appeared more arboreous than its neighbors. 
 "And there is Eddie," she added, as we rounded the corner onto a street that was noticeably less tranquil. "I'm sure you'll meet him soon." I followed her gaze to a shabby, bespectacled man pushing an oversize shopping cart filled with a broom, garbage bags and odds and ends. "Yeah, right," I thought. "I'm going to bond with the street man!"
I didn't know what I was getting into on Aug. 23, 1994, when I moved to New York City to go to graduate school at Columbia and rented a room in a brownstone on 140th Street between Frederick Douglass Boulevard and Edgecombe Avenue. The only New York I knew, from family and college trips and a razzle-dazzle scholarship tour, was the one of Broadway theaters, the Pierre Hotel, Macy's and Windows on the World.
I was 22 years old, the child of well-traveled, hard-working West Indian professionals, the product of secure Houston suburbs, private schools and four years at Princeton. In my world were the black folk who were the nurses and the scientists, the teachers and the engineers, the lawyers and the corporate vice presidents. In my world, professionals didn't live around the corner from the underclass. The only ghetto my sister or I ever saw as children was the gritty Fifth Ward in Houston; my father wanted to encourage us to keep working rigorously. These worn houses, he said, were where bad grades could send us.
To put it simply, when it came to Harlem, I was clueless.
I had never seen used condoms or crack vials on the ground on a simple walk to the mailbox. I had never been in a place where people had to grab their home-delivered newspapers before thieves took them to sell. I had never thought I would fear clusters of black men at my subway exit. I had never before come head to head with a world so unlike my own. And it repulsed me.
My reflection in that world was disquieting. It bounced back as limited, elitist. If I were white, it wouldn't have surprised anyone that I didn't bond with the locals. If I had lived on Striver's Row, the "street-comfy" people would have kept some distance. But I wasn't white, and I wasn't on Striver's Row.
Sifting through my year in Harlem made me aware of my unspoken assumptions and beliefs about who I was, as an educated woman, as a black woman. I lost the comfortable illusion that we were all one big, classless society, and that made me realize how much easier it is to talk about race than class, how much you have to reveal about yourself to talk about class.
I look back on that year with some regret about my aloofness. But even now, I don't think I could have been any other way.
Two days after I moved in, I met Eddie. He was the Harlem professional's dream: a self-appointed protector and handyman, ears to the ground, eyes-on-your-front-porch neighborhood gem. He was a kind of buffer who was "down" with those on the street, but knew and respected the concerns of better-off, homeowning families.
It took me months to figure out that this man, who pushed an oversize shopping cart, had a sick mother in Westchester and a home to go to at night.
The people I stayed with let him use their phone in emergencies, and, when he asked for money, hired him to do odd jobs.
They were sophisticated Midwesterners, people who sent their daughter to prep school at Exeter, then to Brown University. They were kind and admirable. How many people with the means to live elsewhere would choose to live in Harlem, to support a struggling neighborhood that was not even a place of their youth? They patronized the local barber, baker and dry cleaner. They accepted with grace inconveniences that irritated me: A guy at Domino's told me he wouldn't deliver to my address; I had to walk several blocks to find an ATM; there were diners but no bookish cafes.
They wrestled with unenthusiastic bankers to get the money to renovate their house, a historic three-story brick home with a basement apartment. They made a point of using local plumbers, electricians and other service people. They kept track of developments in the area, like the distinctively new, orangish low-rises that they explained were low-to-moderate-income housing units.
But they didn't pretend the area was problem-free. They took their son to the Harlem School of the Arts to dance, but not to public school. The only street-comfy people I saw them chat with were Eddie and a woman who came by to ask for money.
Eddie was their ears and eyes. Eddie knew everything. And, in a sense, he measured the distance between their beautifully stained front door and the boarded-up building at the end of the block.
I was getting a snack in the kitchen at 3:15 A.M. one day in those first months, and heard clanging. I peeked out to see Eddie hauling trash. It was just one of the jobs he did as he roamed the surrounding blocks night and day -- washing cars, sweeping sidewalks, fixing what was broken and on a few occasions opening the taxi door when I came home after dark.
This was Eddie's domain. And he knew that there were people in his domain who would hassle me and that there would be times when I was afraid.
Like the dusky evening in early September, just a few weeks after my arrival. "This place might not be so bad," I thought, strolling past neat, prim brownstones to the subway. Suddenly, a voice crept out of the walls like God out of nowhere: "I saw you pass this way earlier. I'm watching you."
I panicked. I had no idea who or where he was. There was no one on the steps. No one behind me. No one in front. The only place left to look was a cornerful of shadows by a basement apartment. And I wasn't about to look there. I walked, fast, out. So I wasn't sneering at any offers of protection. "Just tell them that Eddie said to leave you alone," he'd say, and I would nod politely.
It didn't take me long to realize that Eddie was an interesting character. He said he had lived in the area as a youth and graduated from a local high school.
But I never found out why he spent his time patrolling the streets. The truth was that I didn't really want to know about Eddie's life, at least not badly enough to befriend him. I was studying journalism, and the newshound in me was ashamed, for not pursuing a source that would clearly bring me stories far more real than the ones I tapped out at school. The Christian in me was guilty, for not having the guts to be kind to someone who was difficult to be kind to.
Eddie probed to find out where I had been and where I was going. He stood and watched and gave patronizing advice as I fumbled with my keys to get into the house. He told me to "stop walking so fast," because my midtown pace was out of place among the languorous gaits around me. He was a constant reminder of the fear I had of my foreign surroundings.
One day he said that "his men" had told him I came in past midnight from a night on the town. I freaked.
Eddie reminded me too much of the stereotypical black street culture. I looked at him and his cart, his crooked teeth and worn clothes, and I saw the people who hung out on their stoops instead of working 9 to 9, and the teen-age girls pushing their baby carriages in the subway. The only way anyone would confuse me with any of that is: I'm black.
If I couldn't deal with Eddie like I dealt with other people in my world -- with a basic level of respect -- then it was pointless to deal with him at all. If I didn't make some kind of natural space for Eddie in my world, then I would have to acknowledge a very strong class distinction. And I didn't want to deal with that.
I blew up at him and told him to leave me alone. And then I just didn't deal with Eddie.
 
DIFFERENT DREAMS
 Harlem means a lot more to a lot of people than its buildings and environs. It's almost a black archetype. But not to me. I was born in the West Indies. I don't know what family stories the people born here are told, but my stories were of Jamaica.
We moved to the United States in '79 -- and not to New York. We moved to a conservative, almost all-white Houston suburb. I could count the other black students in my private high school on one hand. My best friends included a Hispanic girl and a girl from Laos. One year, there was a girl from Thailand, but she hated America. When she left, it significantly reduced the school's minority population.
There were points when other black people made me feel that I wasn't black enough, like the athlete who said that I was the studious type "they" liked. The one time I ran into lots of black people was at track meets. My need to focus before a race would be interpreted as standoffishness. They would hear me talk, and I didn't sound like them. They saw me hanging out with my white teammates. I felt bad vibes from them, and that was annoying. I didn't have to prove that I was black. In my mind, and in my parents minds', I was doing what every child, black or white, should do. I was part of a culture of people who worked hard, studied, accomplished things. Conforming to other people's ideas of blackness wasn't going to make me any more black.
At Princeton, there was a black lunch table, but I ate with friends from my dorm -- a blond Californian, a black woman from Trenton, a clean-cut girl from Pennsylvania, an Italian from New York, a Pakistani Bostonian. I felt like I was getting looks from the black table. I wanted to be friends with some of the people there, but I wanted to get to know them in a more natural way -- from classes or parties or non-race-related interests. I wasn't going to go sit at the black table.
In my college years, I started reading more about race. I reveled in classes on black literature and developed a penchant for books by contemporary black authors. I read a lot of Toni Morrison, Maya Angelou, Stephen Carter, Arthur Ashe, Ellis Cose, Henry Louis Gates Jr. and a lot of academic stuff. Many books referred to Harlem in the 20's. It took on an almost mythological aura of greatness, with great clubs and famous people. I got a sense of economic and social stability. But I never felt driven to get a clear picture of what it was all about. I knew, and respected, that many people dreamed of recreating the Harlem Renaissance. But they weren't my dreams. And if my aunt's friends hadn't paved my road into Harlem, I would never have come.
 
ON THE STREET
 After I got there, I was mystified when one new neighbor said he had moved to Harlem because of its sense of community. When people called it a good place to live, I thought, "What? Are you kidding?" It was one thing to shop on 125th Street and visit the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, Riverside Church and the Studio Museum in Harlem. It was another altogether to walk home at night and hear a young braggart assuring his female companion that the alias he had concocted would help him avoid the police.
My insides convulsed with disgust when I walked to the mailbox on the next block. Children played tag on mangled sidewalks -- the concrete shattered, as though something below were sucking it under. There were some renovated apartment houses, but the unrenovated ones were more striking. They exuded a stench of mustiness, urine, something aged and something unknown. I could not believe people actually lived in them until I saw heads poking out of windows and heard voices calling to neighbors.
On the street, men called to me. It was more than the catcalls you could expect anywhere. There's nothing like being a black woman in an all-black part of town. The men seemed to expect interaction, because I was a "sistah." When I did not respond, some men helpfully repeated their comments in Spanish.
For refusing to answer, I won insults about my uppityness and conjectures about my affinity for people of my own race.
One day, I ignored persistent crescendos of "Hey Half Pint!" When the yeller finally had to admit that audibility was not the problem, he changed his cry to: "She thinks she is all that! So it's like that, huh? You ain't all that beautiful! You're nothing!"
A passerby joined in. "Now, if he hadn't called you Half Pint, you probably would have responded, now, wouldn't you?" I shrugged; he didn't give up. "How should we brothers address you? Tell us so that we know what we are supposed say. How about, 'Good afternoon, my beautiful sister'?"
I gave up and said hello. But I was thinking: "He doesn't get it. I don't want to be called anything on these streets. Period."
The rare times I did interact, I felt safer talking to women. Even so, I was still suspicious of the woman who called to me from a parked car on St. Nicholas Avenue. I was sure she was in cahoots with someone lurking in her back seat. I stood in my skates, a respectable distance from her window, teetering backwards dangerously close to traffic and skeptically asked her what she wanted. My overreaction was clear. She only wanted to know what kind of skates I had bought and how much a pair would cost her.
 
AT THE EDGE
 I told myself that I could do anything for one year, but I almost gave up on Harlem early last winter when two local crimes prompted me, sobbing and shaken with fear, to call my parents at 2 A.M.
In January the body of a 16-year-old girl was found in St. Nicholas Park just two blocks west of where I lived. My usual jog was on a path near that park. One month later, a woman riding the downtown C train was stabbed to death as it entered the 135th Street station at 6:16 in the evening. She was stabbed in the third car -- the one that stopped just a few feet away from the lone downtown bench, a bench I would have been occupying at 6:15 that night -- but my professor had canceled class.
Three days later, a check arrived from my grandmother: taxi money. I began to rethink my policy of subway before 11 P.M., taxi after. Each night before I made the decision, I asked myself, "Do I want to be leaving a Harlem subway at this time tonight?" And I debated which train to take. Sometimes the wait for a local to 135th, where I usually felt safer, seemed endless. The five blocks from the express stop at 145th had its own set of obstacles.
At night, the scene there was usually the same. On one side of the walk a long line of hungry patrons followed the whiff of fried fish to a basement stand. On the other side a group of leering men leaned on cars and hurled innuendoes. They could see I despised them, and that made it worse.
I knew there were things to be edgy about, but sometimes I wished I could deal with it better. But I had a moment of reprieve one day, when I saw a woman suddenly startled by a thunderous pop as we left the 135th Street station. She looked hesitantly around, and we began chatting. She was a real Harlem resident, and she was scared, too.
 
PRIDE, OR REGRET
 I didn't pack up in the middle of the semester. The people I lived with were an absolute joy. Nowhere else would I have gotten so much in return for giving so little.
Friends said they admired me for "sticking it out" -- but I wasn't proud of how I'd handled it.
Then there were the words of my college roommate, who listened sympathetically during our incessant phone calls, but chided me gently: "There but for the grace of God." She didn't have to say any more.
In August, two weeks before my father arrived in a U-Haul to help me move out, I was enjoying a sunny Sunday afternoon, walking home after church. As I rounded the corner, I saw two cops chasing a man in bright yellow pants. He clambered up the fence, but the two managed to bring him down. I ran inside, and when I looked out the window, two cops had turned into eight, all with batons. All for the arrest of this lone black man. A mix of suspicions and relief overwhelmed me. I was always glad to see the cops sitting at the top of the hill at 140th Street. Many mornings I had walked out the front door and breathed, "I'm glad you guys are on that hill today." But three squad cars and eight cops? For one graying, middle-aged man? I couldn't help but wonder.
I left Harlem in August -- unharmed, relieved and regretful. My fears had driven me to ignore, despise and imagine the worst about all the people I saw. I didn't make any attempt to differentiate between the truly malicious and those who would have done me no harm. I ignored, along with the whistles, the good mornings and the good afternoons and most decisively, the humanity of the people I passed.
Eddie was still there, and I still didn't deal with Eddie. I wished I could cut him some slack, but by then, it would have been too much work. I would have had to at least explain why, after months of avoidance, I would even give him the time of day. It was the same with the rest of the street-comfy people. As far as I was concerned, we were from different worlds and had nothing in common other than darkened pigment. There were clear boundaries and I didn't want them breached.
But I couldn't escape my own nagging thoughts: it wouldn't have killed me to see the faces; it wouldn't have killed me to get to know some of the people who were locked into a world I feared, but could leave whenever I chose. It wouldn't have killed me to have befriended someone like Eddie.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
A Tale of Two Christopher Streets

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
IT'S lunchtime at Smil'in Jacks, a cafe at Christopher and Washington Streets, but George Tassone, the owner, is wearing an unmistakable frown. "Where is everybody?" he asks as he surveys empty tables at the restaurant he christened this month. "If I had known it was going to be this bad, I wouldn't have opened."
Most of Mr. Tassone's neighbors are also having a hard time making ends meet, and vacant storefronts litter this western spur of Christopher Street like broken teeth in an otherwise healthy mouth. But a few blocks east, on the other side of Hudson Street, things at the Espresso Bar couldn't be better. "Business is great," says the owner, Hugo Cory, as a dozen customers wait in a line. "We're busy morning, noon and night." 
 These days Christopher Street, the traditional heart of gay New York and one of Greenwich Village's main shopping thoroughfares, is a tale of two streets. East of Hudson Street, it is the best of times: crowds are thick and vacancies are rare. But to the west, from Hudson Street to the Hudson River, foot traffic slows to a trickle and nearly a quarter of the two dozen or so storefronts along the five forlorn blocks are begging for tenants.
"The two sides are like two different worlds," Mr. Cory said. "We're glad to be on this side." A 500-square-foot store that fetches $4,000 a month on Christopher's eastern end typically rents for $2,500 to the west, says Chuck Stephan, a broker with Montante, a real estate firm.
But even up and down Christopher Street's western stretch are signs that the worst of times may be coming to an end. Besides the newly arrived Smil'in Jacks, a dry cleaner and a coffee shop, Station Cafe, plan to open next month. And another newcomer to the street's western half, Dolly Rokkas, who opened Sweet Life Cafe nine months ago, is far more upbeat than Mr. Tassone. "In the beginning, we thought there would be problems," she said, "but business has been better than we expected."
Joel Laiter, who owns half the block between Hudson and Greenwich Streets, sees the area as poised for a resurgence. "For Rent" signs have come down from two of the three empty storefronts on the block. One will be occupied by the Station Cafe; the other by a restaurant. "This block could be awesome, like a bit of Paris," Mr. Laiter said. "It's the last frontier in the Village and it's ready to boom."
Christopher Street's troubles began in the early 1980's, when a police crackdown in Times Square drove petty thieves and drug dealers to the western corner of the Village, long considered a place where anything goes. "Every lowlife flocked here, and our crime went up 110 percent," said Dave Poster, who founded the volunteer Christopher Street Patrol in 1990 to combat a rash of muggings and robberies. The patrol and an increased police presence have helped reduce crime significantly in the last five years, said Officer Mike Singer, community affairs officer at the Sixth Precinct.
But crime is just one element of Christopher Street's problems, which are also rooted in the AIDS epidemic and racial and class prejudice. AIDS has devastated a generation of gay men who once made Christopher Street on both sides of Hudson Street a chic shopping destination. And cheaper rents in Chelsea are drawing the younger generation of gay residents and merchants.
At the westernmost end of Christopher stands a sobering reminder of the epidemic -- Bailey House, a residence for homeless people with AIDS in what was once the River Hotel and its Grand Corniche restaurant, two glitzy ventures that went under in the early 1980's. "What was once a giddy walk to the piers now symbolically and literally ends with AIDS," said William K. Dobbs, a gay rights advocate. "Doesn't that say everything about Christopher Street?"
But many people say racism has played an even larger role in western Christopher Street's economic downturn. Over the last decade, the street has become a haven for gay black and Hispanic youths who flock to what is a corridor of tolerance. Local merchants complain that boisterous teen-agers who congregate on stoops and street corners scare away potential shoppers. The Neutral Zone, a storefront drop-in center for gay teen-agers at 162 Christopher Street, opened three years ago. But some merchants and residents say it has failed to solve the loitering problem and are pressing the center to leave the street.
Newly enacted zoning regulations that restrict adult businesses citywide would sweep away the half-dozen sex-related stores that now line the street, something that pleases many -- but not all -- merchants. Bob Kohler, who has owned the Loft, a Christopher Street clothing store, for 17 years, believes that sex-oriented businesses are part of the street's lifeblood. "These places help Christopher Street keep its gay identity and actually draw people with money to the neighborhood," he said. "Most of them blend right in."
The Archive, a luxury rental apartment building that takes up the block bounded by Greenwich, Washington, Christopher and Barrow Streets, was once heralded as an elixir to the street's problems. As it was developed in the early 80's, there was talk of large retailers like Bloomingdale's moving to the hulking, red-brick structure. But while all its 479 apartments were rented, most of its 40,000 square feet of commercial space remained dark until two years ago. Today, a gym, a theater and several businesses tied to the photography trade occupy its storefronts. "There just isn't enough life down here to support retail," said Patricia Dunphy, leasing director for Rockrose Development Corporation, which owns the Archive. Across the street at Smil'in Jacks, the manager, Eric Shaw, hopes to survive until warmer weather brings waterfront-bound crowds to the street. Food sales, at $200 a day, are less than a quarter of what was projected. "This is rough," he said. "If we could only get people to cross Hudson Street, we'd be in heaven."

HEADLINE: Deficits Have Kept Us Out of a Depression

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Deficit-Cutting's International" (Week in Review, Nov. 12) outlines how European countries are reducing deficit spending. You restate the common economic belief that deficits "bring high interest rates and divert investment from its most productive uses." 
 You acknowledge that budget cuts are "clouding the prospects for economic growth and reducing high unemployment rates." If the cuts produce such dire consequences and social unrest as well, are not the deficits more desirable?
You add that Italy's national debt, 122 precent of annual output, and Belgium's, 138 percent of output, would cause banks to laugh at individuals with such credit records. Maybe not. It is normal for individuals to take out home mortgages that are 300 percent of their incomes. The United States debt, 63 percent of output, is relatively trivial.
American budget-balancing and debt reduction in the 1920's was followed by the Great Depression of the 30's, a pattern common to all six major depressions in this country's history.
The virtually unbroken deficits since the 1930's may have enabled us to avoid another crash, the longest depression-free period in history.
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Visiting Prof., Public Administration
George Washington University
Washington, Nov. 13, 1995

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Today
 
Vice President Gore and ministers from 17 other nations in the Asian-Pacific region meet in Osaka, Japan, to set principles for lowering trade barriers. They are expected to decide on 15 areas to be covered by liberalization efforts, including tariffs and government purchases. The ultimate goal is to create a free-trade zone spanning countries with two billion people and half the world's economic output.
 
Monday
 
Some Federal workers are to return to work to process Social Security and veterans' claims, under a presidential order issued last week. But the budget standoff is going to cause some of the Government's major economic reports due this week to be postponed.
 
Tuesday
 
The Labor Department canceled the report on the September trade deficit that was due today.
 
Nick Leeson, the former trader for Barings, is scheduled to be extradited from Germany to Singapore for trial.
 
Wednesday
 
The Treasury Department is to report the budget deficit for October, but it is not clear whether it will do so or delay the announcement.
 
Thursday
 
The financial markets are closed in the United States for Thanksgiving Day.
 
The Japanese-language version of Microsoft's Windows 95 goes on sale in Japan.
 
Friday
 
France's largest confederation of unions is expected to hold a general strike to protest a Government plan to eliminate a $50 billion deficit in the social security system. To cut it, the government has called for a new tax on salaries above the poverty level and an increase of two and a half years in the time public employees have to work to collect pensions.
 
The Federal Reserve is expected to announce bank loan and money supply data.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: Mission Impassable;
After a Budget Side Show, This Way to the Egress

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FINALLY, the main event. Congress's votes to send President Clinton the Republicans' budget reconciliation bill, with its seven-year balanced budget, tax cut and sharp curbs of Medicare and Medicaid spending, will take a very serious fight beyond side issues.
The national debt and partial closing of the Government are hardly trivial, but as political problems they do not approach the one posed by the budget -- just how big a role the Federal Government should have in American life. 
 That is the issue, obscured by childish squabbles over tee times and face time, that must now be solved. For the choice, as Speaker Newt Gingrich contends, may be "the largest domestic decision since 1933," determining whether the central government remains the guarantor of basic standards in areas like health, welfare and the environment, or whether states and individuals can do it better.
Both sides underestimated their opposition's determination and climbed out on limbs. Each side's preferred solution, of course, is to push the other off the limb. But, as William Kristol, the conservative strategist, said last week, "I'm not sure either side has that much leverage."
That does not stop both sides from predicting victory. "I think the President will come our way," said Tony Blankley, Mr. Gingrich's press secretary. Democrats sound confident that Medicare is so important to voters that sooner or later Republicans will give up their plans to tamper with the program's future.
If neither side gives up -- and now that Mr. Clinton is swearing that he will veto the budget, some of the Congressmen who feared his inconstancy are getting weak in the knees -- there will be an impasse that makes this month's fights over debt and spending seem like no more than a morning traffic tie-up.
The problem is less the policy chasm between the two sides than the uncompromising political personalities of the 73 House Republican freshmen, and a leadership who that sometimes seem to lead by following them. Except for that signal characteristic of the 104th Congress, which reflects an almost Biblical sense of destiny after 40 years in the political wilderness, there would be ways to bridge the chasm.
In another political era, perhaps just last year, it would have been no trick at all to compromise the basic budget disputes between President Clinton and Congress.
The Republicans have voted to balance the budget in seven years, with $245 billion in tax cuts. That goal requires taking $270 billion from the growth of Medicare, and biting deeply into Medicaid, education and programs meant to protect the environment. Democrats say those cuts are too deep. But Democrats are increasingly eager to say they want a balanced budget, too.
So, what kind of a deal would you make?
Thomas S. Foley, whose career as Speaker was ended by the Republican revolution last election day, offered a simple prescription: "Think about the possibility of an eight-year period, without the tax cut." With this approach, each side could claim to have put the good of the country ahead of diehard stubbornness. Each side would have some political cover when spending reductions begin to pinch.
But Mr. Foley confesses that he does not know if such an approach is possible with the House's Republican freshman contingent, elected as sworn enemies of the compromise as evil business as usual.
Another Washington veteran, former Senator and Treasury secretary Lloyd Bentsen, a Democrat, says compromise cannot be achieved now: "First they have to find that they are not going to have their way on everything. It just doesn't work that way."
Things might also be fixed easily with some revisions in the economic assumptions provided by the Congressional Budget Office. Republicans have insisted on using its economic estimates, more conservative than most others, including the Administration's. Because they project less tax revenue, they require deeper spending cuts. A very light finger on the scales, if it put the C.B.O. at the middle of current economic forecasts instead of the bottom, would free up hundreds of billions of estimated dollars. But the C.B.O. has never played that way.
One recourse that requires neither compromise nor surrender -- just patience -- was offered from St. Louis by former Senator John C. Danforth. He argued that his fellow Republicans cannot compromise or give up their cause of cutting spending to balance the budget. But he said that if the President remains firm and his vetoes are sustained, they may have to wait until the Presidential election next year to finish that fight.
"We could take the high ground," Mr. Danforth said, "and say we are not going to allow the country to be hurt" by Government shutdowns and high-wire management of the national debt. Republicans could then go along with spending and debt measures that will last through the election, and allow the American people to show, he said, "whether they really mean it when they say they want to balance the budget, or to keep on spending."
President Clinton seems to like the idea of making the election a referendum.
In an interview last week with CBS News, Mr. Clinton said of the budget dispute, "If we take it right into the next election, let the American people decide." If the people want the Republican budget, he said, "they're entitled to another President, and that's the only way they are going to get it."
The idea has some appeal to conservatives outside Congress, like Mr. Kristol or Mickey Edwards, the former Republican Congressman from Oklahoma who now teaches at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
Mr. Edwards thinks the idea might sell, but only if President Clinton understands that Republicans have to have some immediate victory, like Representative Ernest Istook's amendment prohibiting political activity by recipients of Federal grants (a proposal whose foes say is so unconstitutional that it would immediately be enjoined anyway).
The Republican leaders "have to be able to show their freshmen members that 'we didn't win it all in one fell swoop, but we're on our way,' " Mr. Edwards said. "Outside of that, I don't think Newt has any flexibility."
 
Dole's Quiet Time
 The player with the least flexibility of all may be Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader and the most experienced deal-maker involved. Mr. Dole's hopes for the Presidency require him to court the absolutists in his party. Even so, his once-sharp tongue has been muted, at least by comparison to Mr. Gingrich's.
Another essential to agreement -- even if it is only agreeing to disagree -- is a greater level of civility.
On Friday night, House members got into a shoving match.
Yesterday, the House erupted into partisan shouting after Representative John L. Mica said of Mr. Clinton and his shifting views on budget balancing, "We're here to nail the little bugger down." He was ruled out of order, but the No. 3 Republican leader, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, pushed through a motion to let him resume speaking.
Any sort of agreement will not come easy, though. If both sides agree on a way to commit themselves to balancing the budget, and they may, the arguments over how to balance it will finally begin. And then, if nothing is settled by Christmas, the national debt and the threat of default will take center stage again.
No wonder Congress is keeping most of its staff on the payroll as essential.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Little Hope Pumps Up An Attitude

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA

 BODY:
FIDEL CASTRO seems to have a new spring in his step since returning from his recent visit to New York and the United Nations, and his brightened outlook has quickly percolated through a state and party apparatus that has always taken its cues from him. After enduring his six worst years since his revolution swept him to power nearly 37 years ago, Mr. Castro and his Government once again seem to be directing, rather than reacting to, events.
They also seem to have drawn a singular lesson from their recent successes: Perhaps there is no further need for their regime to loosen up, either toward political freedom, or toward more open markets. 
 Whether dealing with the Clinton Administration, Cuban exiles, the 11 million people on this island or the growing number of foreign businesses seeking a foothold here, "the Cuban Government is once again acting in a triumphalist manner," one foreign diplomat said. Last year's crisis of people fleeing the island on rafts is gradually fading in memory, as Mr. Castro, invigorated and even cocky, has begun reaping the benefits of the efforts he launched then to improve his position at home and abroad.
 
A Very Good Year
 His five-day foray in New York capped what has been an unusually active year for him on the international diplomatic stage, and the result has been a strengthening of Cuba's ties with the rest of the world, including some of America's closest allies. Since August alone, he has attended regional conferences of heads of state in Trinidad, Colombia and Argentina, and Cuba now has full diplomatic relations with almost every country in the hemisphere. Just last week, a European Union delegation arrived here to begin discussions on an economic cooperation agreement.
That can only whet the appetite of American business executives, who showed during his trip that they are eager for a loosening of the longstanding embargo on trade with and travel to Cuba -- a principal goal of Mr. Castro's Government. Indeed, with the United Nations having condemned the embargo again -- by a 117-3 vote this year -- Mr. Castro has taken to suggesting that the Clinton Administration, by discouraging private investment, has impeded Cuba's transformation from a doggedly Stalinist command economy to a Chinese-style "socialist market" economy.
At home, Mr. Castro has been bolstered by the recent performance of Cuba's economy, which had been in a virtual free fall since the Soviet bloc collapsed in 1989, contracting by more than one-third. Cuban officials now forecast 2.5 percent growth for 1995.
But the turnaround of the Cuban economy has been due principally to the impact of reforms about which Mr. Castro still harbors deep reservations, such as the 212 joint-venture and other investment agreements his Government has signed with foreign companies, and the opening of farmers' markets. For that reason, the spurt of growth appears to have slowed, not encouraged, the Government's willingness to undertake further economic reforms. Measures to broaden the right of self employment and slim the size of the Government work force, which six months ago were said to be close to ratification, are now on hold, for example.
"They seem to be drawing the wrong lessons from what has happened," said one frustrated Latin American diplomat here. "Instead of looking on the promising results they have obtained thus far as a signal to press on and open further, they appear to be telling themselves that they have now done all they need to get by."
 
A Very Bare Minimum
 On the human rights front too, Mr. Castro appears still inclined to cede no more than the absolute minimum, and that only under pressure. In a report last month, Human Rights Watch/Americas noted that in order to "facilitate its full integration into the world community -- and thus the world economy -- the Cuban Government is trying to improve its human rights image." The report identified some "positive developments" but pointed out that "the country's repressive legal structure remains unchanged" and suggested that "in the absence of real reform, this year's positive developments may be fleeting."
Recent efforts to set up independent press outlets have been stymied, for instance, and Mr. Castro remains adamant about keeping "dissidents or opposition" off the state controlled media. "I will be frank with you," Mr. Castro said in an interview with Telemundo, a Spanish-language TV network in the United States. "They have no access, and they will have none, because we are not going to give any opportunities to those who want to destroy the revolution."
Taken together, Mr. Castro's improved prospects at home and abroad, and the renewed self-confidence they have engendered, suggest it is going to be more difficult than ever to cajole him down the path of true change. If neither the carrot nor the stick seems to work, that means the rest of the world is going to have to take him -- or leave him -- as he is.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How Sanctions Bit -- Serbia's Neighbors

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: SKOPJE, Macedonia

 BODY:
GRANTED, three years of international trade sanctions may have helped to nudge Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian strongman, to peace talks in Dayton, Ohio. But at whose expense?
Ordinary Serbs were inconvenienced by shortages and higher prices, but there were no images of dying Serb children to truly undermine the Serbian President's hold on power. Nor did sanctions appreciably slow the Serb war machine (though the forces of Croatia and NATO did) because Serb forces never lacked for imported fuel and other supplies from the outside world. 
 Rather, the most lasting and overlooked damage of sanctions may have been the corruption they encouraged in surrounding countries like Albania, Bulgaria, Macedonia, Hungary and Romania. These countries -- all formerly Communist lands professing to be fledgling democracies, and all major trading partners of Serbia -- were ill-equipped to enforce sanctions from the outset and, in the end, fell victim to the irresistible temptation to evade them.
Should Mr. Milosevic sign a peace deal in Dayton and thereby win an end to the West's embargo, the economic consequences to Serbia's neighbors might well, in time, be overcome. But the criminality and criminal ethos that sanctions have fostered will be much harder to dispel.
During one recent week, according to a report of the European Union's sanctions-monitoring office in Brussels, 782 trucks moved from Macedonia into Serbia, laden with computers, food and chemicals, and 466 came out of Serbia into Macedonia, hauling everything from copper tubing to frozen raspberries. Commerce on such a scale could not take place without the complicity of Macedonian officials high and low. "Look at almost any company that has violated sanctions and you will find a member of Parliament is the head of it," said a Western diplomat here.
In Romania, international sanctions monitors discovered a creative Serbian fuel-smuggling scheme. Yugoslav Airlines passenger flights were flying daily -- with no passengers -- from Belgrade to the Romanian city of Timisoara. The route was lucrative nonetheless, for the planes returned to Belgrade with tanks brimming, up to 5,000 gallons of fuel on each flight. Romanian officials told Western officials there was nothing they could do about it because a senior Government minister was involved in the business.
In Albania, oil trade with Serbia is by far the country's largest enterprise. In impoverished northern Albania, which has more sheep than cars, there are 39 gas stations in less than 20 miles along a narrow road almost devoid of cars. The fuel is pumped into containers, taken to the river and then sent to Serbia. Diplomats and sanctions monitors in Tirana say that senior Albanian officials have their hands in the trade and that it is controlled by organized crime elements, which are more powerful than the fledgling state's police.
The formerly Communist states don't shoulder all the blame. Oil companies in Greece and Italy have supplied the oil going to Serbia through Albania. In August, Greek companies shipped more than 9,000 tons of oil to Albania, most of which was then smuggled to Serbia, European sanctions monitors say.
Greek officials have heatedly denied complicity in the illegal trade. Italian companies are the culprits, they say (which they were, until the Greek oil traders overtook them, according to European Union reports). Besides, the Greeks say, there is nothing illegal about trading with Albania. True enough, but, Western officials counter, if the oil were going from Albania to a Greek enemy -- say, Turkish Cyprus -- Greece would find a way to stop it.
International monitoring teams, including United States customs agents, have been stationed in each of the front-line countries but have been hampered by a limited mandate: They can't arrest anyone. Reports of violations go to the United Nations and Western governments, which for the most part make sure that no violating country is publicly embarrassed. The European head of one such team described his mission as: "To see and to know, but not to do anything."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Shortfall In the Grain Fields

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THANKS largely to rapidly increasing export demand, stores of American corn, wheat and soybeans are lower than they have been for two decades. The harvest farmers are just finishing would have been a record-setting bin-buster just 20 years ago, but it is a shortfall today, with roughly 1.5 billion more mouths to feed on the planet and a growing industrial market for vegetable oil and grain products. Grain reserves worldwide amount to a 48-day supply, the lowest level since measurements began in 1963, according to the Worldwatch Institute, a Washington-based environmental group. 
 What does it all mean? Not much, said Dennis Avery, head of the Center for Global Food Issues at the Hudson Institute in Indianapolis. "The world has more food security than at any time in history," he said, citing improvements in agricultural tools and techniques and the trend toward freer trade in agriculture.
 
The Sky Is Falling. Really!
 Nothing could be further from the truth, said Lester R. Brown, president of Worldwatch. "The politics of scarcity is already beginning to manifest itself," he said, referring to Vietnam's brief embargo on rice exports early this year and to reports that some inland Chinese provinces limited grain shipments to populous coastal provinces. "We are moving into a period so different from the last half century that we can't even imagine how different it will be."
Mr. Avery and Mr. Brown represent two extremes in a long-running battle that tangles the boundaries of science, politics and philosophy. Optimists like Mr. Avery believe the track record of the 20th century proves that the world can innovate and grow its way out of food shortages despite rising populations, especially if governments interfere less in agricultural markets. Mr. Brown and other disciples of Thomas Malthus, the 18th century philosopher who warned about the dangers of runaway population increases, see such arguments as a complacent prelude to war, massive famines and epidemic diseases.
One thing is clear: after a long run of successes that had kept prices low and encouraged politicians and many economists to ignore and even ridicule the Malthusians, a bad spring could sow second thoughts. Experts in agribusiness agree that the current, unusually high prices for grain could skyrocket. Add a troubled harvest in Brazil and other breadbaskets in South America -- or poor conditions in the winter wheat crop here next June -- and the price of food could become an election-year issue in the United States.
Sharply higher grain prices next spring might not immediately affect consumers. Grain is a very small part of the checkout counter cost of bread and breakfast cereal. Companies like Kellogg and the Interstate Bakeries, the maker of Wonder bread, might also shield shoppers from the impact by living with lower profits or even losses until their competitors seem ready to raise prices. At the same time, meat prices could fall as livestock and poultry producers dump animals into the market rather than feed them high-priced grain. The upward pressure on food prices for Americans might be delayed for months.
Big grain importers, however, like Indonesia, Russia and China would feel the consequences of higher prices almost immediately. Hard pressed to compete with wealthier countries for grain, these developing countries might respond by expanding their own planting, with little attention to the environmental costs. Satellite photos already suggest a sharp increase this year in fires to clear more farmland in Brazil's rain forests, a direct reaction to the rising price of grain.
To relieve some of the pressure, Washington has already set aside restrictions on how much land farmers can plant next year without losing their eligibility for subsidies, a move that will bring millions of acres back into production.
 
Listening to Malthus
 A shortfall next spring would make it harder than ever for environmental groups to defend rules that limit planting on wetlands. It could also undermine the already embattled Conservation Reserve Program, which pays farmers to idle 32 million acres of environmentally sensitive land. Much of this land, Mr. Avery and others say, could be farmed with little damage using current techniques. They argue that expanding American exports will protect rain forests and other environmentally vital areas.
Soaring prices might also make political life rough for defenders of a number of policies that have supported farmers by boosting demand in difficult times, from export subsidies to tax breaks for ethanol. Prominent members of that group are talking tough for now: Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman told the National Association of Farm Broadcasters convention in Kansas City this month, "I'm not in the mood to cut the legs from under all those people who have waited all these years for higher grain prices."
But farm groups fear that a tough spring in the fields would reconfigure political reality. Their biggest nightmare: an export embargo on grain supplies large enough to protect Americans from big price increases. Previous embargoes severely damaged the nation's reputation as a reliable supplier, allowing Europe and Brazil to capture a big chunk of the market.
"You can't just jump in and out of export markets," said John Keeling, director for agricultural policy at the National Corn Growers Association. "It would be very awkward for us politically, but we'd be arguing for higher food prices for Americans."
The chances of such actions seem remote for now, even if prices soar. But the stresses could easily rise to the level where the Malthusians once again get a more respectful hearing.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Capital Gangs;
They Started It. No, They Did. The Budget Debate Continues.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BUDGET negotiations between the Democratic White House and the Republican Congress had broken down and Federal buildings around the country were locked.
But the White House and the Capitol stayed open. Inside, by early Tuesday afternoon, politicians were pointing fingers. 
 Both sides were steeped in opinion polls, which show that the public favors a balanced budget by a large margin -- but is not willing to touch Medicare to reach the goal.
And so, just hours after Federal workers went home, President Clinton vetoed a new bill to keep the Government running, since it also raised Medicare premiums for the elderly. Then, in a 900-word statement, he said 16 different times that he favored a balanced budget.
The Republicans immediately struck back. And so on. What follows is a sampler of one afternoon's sloganeering. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM
Mr. Clinton took the lead in his statement:
Let me be clear: We must balance the budget. I proposed to Congress a balanced budget, but Congress refused to enact it. Congress has even refused to give me the line-item veto to help me achieve further deficit reduction. But we must balance this budget without unwise cuts in Medicare and Medicaid, in education and the environment. . . .
We can balance the budget without doing what they seek to do. We can balance the budget without the deep cuts in education, without the deep cuts in the environment, without letting Medicare wither on the vine, without imposing tax increases on the hardest-pressed working families in America. I am fighting for a balanced budget that is good for America and consistent with our values.
The line about letting Medicare wither on the vine was a slap at Speaker Newt Gingrich. It is what Mr. Gingrich seemed to say, in a speech last month, that he wanted to see happen, although he denies that is what he meant. As soon as the President finished his statement, Mr. Gingrich returned fire:
Because he can't win the argument between spending more and spending a whole lot more, he has to try to create a phony argument about fantasy cuts that do not exist in order to frighten people about problems that aren't real.
He talked about letting Medicare wither on the vine. The fact is that there is a 45 percent increase in general Medicare spending that is twice the inflation rate over the next seven years. Now, how anybody who has looked at the budget numbers could have this kind of gross misrepresentation is sobering.
The Republican plans would indeed permit a 45 percent increase in Medicare spending over seven years. But that is $270 billion, or 14 percent, less than what would be needed merely to keep pace with expected increases in medical costs and in the number of people eligible for the program.
As Mr. Gingrich spoke, Michael D. McCurry, the President's press secretary, had his daily briefing for reporters at the White House. He ducked a question as to whether Mr. Clinton: "would accept any increase in the Medicare premium at all."
No, no, there's, well -- how much, how technically and deeply do you want the answer to that question? I mean, it goes to the issue of current law. Current law, as you know, has got, in essence, a drop that is scheduled for Jan. 1. There was some discussion over the last 48 hours of freeze. That's off the table now because the President has vetoed the increase that was included by the Republican majority and the continuing resolution that they passed.
Here's what Mr. McCurry was talking about. The monthly Medicare premium withheld from retirees' Social Security checks is now $46.10. Unless the law is changed, it will drop to $42.50 on Jan. 1. Republicans want to raise it to $53.50. They want to do it on Jan. 1. And to do that, the increase must be enacted right away to give the Social Security Administration time to reprogram the computers.
If the premium does go up on Jan. 1, retirees might not notice it, since their Social Security checks would increase anyway. But if the premium drops on Jan. 1 and then is raised $11 later in the year, many retired people would see their Social Security checks shrink. Mr. Clinton could capitalize on that in the election year.
Some Republicans talked of freezing the premium at $46.10, but squelched the idea upon realizing they would still have the problem of smaller checks later in the year.
Meanwhile, in the Hart Office Building,the first and last meeting of the House-Senate conference committee on the big budget bill was taking place. Democrats complained that they had not the foggiest idea what was in the legislation they were being asked to vote on. That led to this exchange between Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, chairman of the Budget Committee, and Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida, the top Democrat on Ways and Means:
Mr. Domenici: Last time you all did a budget reconciliation bill, we were not participants and were not invited.
Mr. Gibbons: Two wrongs don't make a right.
On the floor of the House, Representative William M. Thomas, Republican of California, accused Mr. Clinton of "political game playing" on Medicare. He continued:
They will tell you it is for good and worthy purposes. It is for down-in-the-dirt gutter politics, and you people are going to pay.
Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, asked that Mr. Thomas's last words be struck from the official record on the ground that they violated the House rule against ad hominem attacks. The parliamentarian ruled that Mr. Thomas's remarks did not amount to a violation. This exchange (somewhat abridged here) followed:
Mr. Obey: I do want to observe that when the gentleman says that something was done for reasons of down-and-dirty gutter politics and then he points his finger over here and says, "You will pay," there is no doubt in my mind who he is talking about. He told me privately that he was not talking about us. He was talking about the President of the United States.
Mr. Thomas: I appreciate his at least being honest, indicating that I told you privately, and this gentleman certainly appreciates the way in which you honor private conversations, and it will be remembered.
Mr. Obey: I did not consider that to be a private conversation. I considered it to be a conversation made on the floor of the people's House.
Mr. Thomas: Why did you characterize it as that?
Mr. Obey: Get your own time.
Mr. Thomas: Why did you characterize it as that?
Mr. Obey: Get your own time. Once today you ought to follow the rules.
And so it went. As Walter Cronkite used to say on "You Are There," it was "a day like all days, filled with the events that alter and illuminate our time."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1258 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
For the U.S., Uncertainty May Cost a Certain Price

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR decades Wall Street and Washington have been on the lookout for the world's deadbeats, tinderboxes and questionable bets: They rescued Latin America from its debt crisis in the 80's, worked to stabilize Russia's economy in the 90's, and even now are pressing India to insure that American companies investing in power projects are not left with giant cement holes in the ground.
But risk is in the eye of the beholder, and now the telescope has suddenly swung in the other direction. Countries that America once worried about are beginning to worry about America. 
 No one is questioning Washington's ability to pay its debts. Instead, the worry focuses on whether the ideological hardening in Washington could make the United States an unpredictable debtor -- especially if the tactic of holding the country's repayments hostage to a budget deal becomes a habit.
So in a week dominated by images of guards shuttering the Smithsonian, everyone but the grizzly bears abandoning Yellowstone and Newt Gingrich complaining that he was relegated to the rear exit on Air Force One, the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said he thought the most striking development lay buried in a trickle of dry announcements from the world's credit-rating agencies.
For the first time, they put the United States on different varieties of "credit watch," warning that unless feuding politicians learn to get along, the country's good-as-gold rating would be in jeopardy. That, of course, is the nuclear threat of a financial age: A lower credit rating would almost certainly translate into higher interest rates when the Government borrows to finance its $4.9 trillion debt. And almost every vital statistic in the American economy is linked to those rates: variable rate mortgages, college and car loans, and, of course, the national economic growth rate.
 
Faith No More
 "Over the past 200 years, through wars, through the Depression, no one ever questioned the full faith and credit of the United States," Mr. Rubin said, justifying his decision to "disinvest" $63 billion from Federal retirement trust funds to enable the United States to pay off investors without violating the ceiling on the nation's borrowing limit. "It would be tragic if the lasting legacy of this fight over the budget is that we pay the price for years and years to come."
To many Republicans in Congress and some investors on Wall Street, Mr. Rubin is a scare-monger trying to terrify Mr. Gingrich's legions into backing down. "He's privately telling the President not to worry," the Speaker said of the former investment banker, after trooping out Wall Street experts of his own who proclaimed that the markets would shrug off default and were concerned only about balancing the budget.
Certainly there was plenty of politics at work in Mr. Rubin's maneuverings last week, and he can probably keep his accounting shell game going for months. Still, his critics had a hard time answering Standard & Poor's, known for keen assessments of the "political risk" of doing business around the world. It warned that "the global capital market's unquestioned faith in the United States Government's willingness to honor its financial obligations" has been tarnished for a while. Europe's largest rating concern was even harsher.
Some worried that even if all the talk about default was just talk, it could prove infectious. "Think of all the pressure on the Mexicans to walk away from their debts to ease their economic problems," said Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs & Co., Mr. Rubin's old firm. "Congress has now made it legitimate to think the unthinkable."
Americans can take heart: They are hardly the only invincible, triple-A-rated nation looking a bit vincible these days. Japan's biggest banks now pay a premium -- about a half a percentage point -- to attract investors, the result of Tokyo's unwillingness to level with investors about the depth of the banking industry's problems. "In our case and in Japan's, the details are different but the result is the same," a senior Administration official said. "You can be the biggest economy in the world, or the second biggest, but if you create uncertainty about the future, you pay a price."
Half a point may not sound like much, but with a debt as large as Washington's, it would amount to another $25 billion in interest payments every year. That's almost exactly the entire Federal budget for food stamps this year, and more than is spent on veterans or Aid to Families with Dependent Children.
All this is a reminder that markets are unforgiving of anything that smacks of uncertainty: Just ask Italy. While economically formidable, it is prone to revolving-door governments, which contribute to the lowest credit rating among the Group of Seven industrial nations and the highest borrowing costs. Markets are also uninterested in whether Medicare lives, Americorps dies or the Pentagon gets new fighters. The finance ministers, bankers and investors who hold American Treasury bonds care chiefly about getting paid on time, and perhaps in whether the budget gets balanced, because its sheer size affects interest rates and markets around the world.
 
Fragile Assumptions
 So far, the markets seem convinced of two things: that the Treasury Secretary will find a way to pay, no matter how long Congress and the President bicker over the debt limit, and that deep budget-cutting is on the way. But those are fragile assumptions. Any sign that either calculation could be wrong, many Wall Street analysts say, could trigger a broad market selloff, which would vastly change the politics of Washington gridlock.
If Mr. Rubin seems fanatical about avoiding any chance of default, perhaps it is because in his spare time he has been reading about the first Treasury Secretary, Alexander Hamilton, whose visage stares down on his desk every day from a giant portrait over the mantelpiece in the Treasury building.
It was Hamilton who insisted in the early 1790's -- over considerable objections -- that the Federal Government assume the debts of the Continental Congress, including I.O.U.'s. that had been issued by a broke George Washington to his troops. The troops, more confident in Washington's battlefield skills than his financial acumen, sold off most of those notes to speculators at a fraction of their face value, figuring a little hard cash was better than the full faith and credit of a country that did not yet exist. Ultimately, many of those notes ended up in the hands of foreign bankers -- sound familiar? -- who had been assured by Thomas Jefferson that the new nation's bonds were as good as its word.
The argument over whether Congress should pay off that debt -- and the debts of individual states that spent like drunken Colonials -- ripped apart the first sessions of Congress. Massachusetts and South Carolina threatened to secede. The whole thing was resolved only when Jefferson worked a compromise that called, among other things, for the creation of a capital along the Potomac, so that history would have a swampy place to repeat itself.
"It was Hamilton who first understood that it was crucial to the United States to establish its creditworthiness in world financial markets," Mr. Rubin said the other day, fresh from another seemingly endless negotiating session with Republican leaders. "That's why the finance minister of every emerging country will do whatever he can to avoid default. And it's why we have to take this issue off the table."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
CONGRESS CANCELS PLAN TO TAKE OFF FOR THE WEEKEND

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Despite signs on Friday that Congress and President Clinton were making progress on reopening Government offices, neither side reported getting any closer to agreement today and lawmakers were forced to put off plans to go home for the weekend.
In the early evening, Republicans sent the White House a new proposal. But when Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, was asked whether he thought the President would accept it, he said, "I doubt it." 
 In the House, where members had been promised that they could leave by 2 P.M., solid Democratic opposition to adjournment embarrassed Republicans into staying. The final vote was 361 to 32. The Senate was in recess for much of the afternoon, waiting for Senator Dole to return from a brief Presidential campaign appearance in Florida.
After the House vote, Republicans did not resume business but called an indefinite recess; later, they said it would last until Monday. Democrats stayed, shouting, "Work, work, work," then held a two-hour rally, although Republicans turned the television cameras off and ordered the House restaurant to close.
Representative Lloyd Doggett of Texas said: "There are countries in this world where the mikes are turned off and where the plugs are pulled on television. But have you ever known something like that to happen on the floor of the House of Representatives?"
Negotiations between the Administration and Republican leaders broke down on Friday night. President Clinton said in his radio address today that "it looks like this chance to reopen the Government may be slipping away."
Both sides said they still wanted to talk, but neither would give any ground publicly on the terms of an agreement to balance the budget.
Speaker Newt Gingrich, at a Capitol Hill news conference this morning, insisted that "there is no compromise on seven years and on having an honest number, scored an honest way." He complained that the Administration was hedging its commitment to a timetable and economic analysis.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff who had negotiated on Friday night with Republican leaders, said this afternoon: "The President urges the Congress, and will request the Congress, to stay in session in order to get this work done. This is not a time to leave on recess. This is not a time to cut out of this town while we are trying to resolve a very real crisis in this country."
While last week Mr. Clinton canceled a state visit to Japan because of the impasse, Senator Dole and other Republican Presidential hopefuls managed quick trips to Orlando, Fla., for a campaign straw poll.
The centerpiece of Republican plans -- the bill that would balance the budget in seven years, cut taxes and curb spending on Medicare and Medicaid -- did not win final passage because of a dispute that erupted when Representative John L. Mica, Republican of Florida, used a disparaging term in referring to the President. A final vote is now planned for Monday.
Before the adjournment motion was defeated, the House voted for a limited spending bill that would reopen for the entire fiscal year offices that deal with Medicare, Social Security and veterans claims. The vote was 416 to 0. A senior White House aide said that was already being done administratively, so Mr. Clinton would probably sign that bill.
In an interview with NBC News, President Clinton said he was trying to find "a legal way" to send Federal employees back to work on Monday. He attributed the stalemate to "the most intransigent members of the House" and said that Senate Republicans would "resolve this on honorable terms if they were free to do it."
The rump caucus meeting Democrats staged on the House floor was one of their most united, fiery sessions of the year. Speaking only to each other and a few reporters in the gallery, they assailed the Republicans for two hours.
Representative Sam M. Gibbons of Florida said the Republican message was that "the wealthy need more help." Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts said, "I have never seen democracy more grievously abused."
Representative John Lewis of Georgia said, "I stood up to Bull Connor in Birmingham. I stood up to Sheriff Clark in Selma. I stood up to George Wallace in Alabama. And I'm not about to run from Newt Gingrich."
When a technician turned on a microphone momentarily, Representative Bill Thomas, Republican of California and chairman of the House Oversight Committee, cried, "He's out of a job." But when Representative Harold E. Ford, a Tennessee Democrat, went up to the gallery and threw the switches, the microphones stayed on.
Twenty-eight Democrats hammered the Republicans for leaving instead of working to reopen Government offices. Mr. Gingrich dismissed their protests, saying, "They aren't helping anything; they aren't helping balance the budget. If they want to stay on the floor and make noise, then that's fine. At least it keeps them out of trouble."
Before the bedlam in the House, Mr. Clinton and the Republican leaders sought to convince the public that their dispute was serious, not petty.
Mr. Clinton said, "I know that for many people across our country, all this conflict and drama looks just like people in Washington are playing politics again. What every American has to realize is that this is way beyond politics. There are very profound fundamental issues involved. What's at stake is nothing less than two different visions of our country, and two different futures for our people."
Then he assailed the Republican budget plan because it "cuts funding for disabled children and school lunches, for Head Start for your youngest children, for college scholarships and loans, that doubles Medicare premiums and undermines the entire Medicaid program that provides for nursing home care and home health care for the elderly, the disabled and health care for poor children."
For those reasons, he said, the bill will be "dead on arrival" at the White House.
Mr. Gingrich described the importance of the debate in even grander terms. "This is the largest domestic decision since 1933," referring to the first year of the New Deal. "I think for two generations we have borrowed our children's money. We've built up a five-trillion-dollar debt, and we are now faced with a great choice of whether we begin to move power back out of Washington, back to state and local government, back to citizens, whether we begin to move to replace the welfare state and have a work requirement, whether we in fact balance the budget, stop using our children's money and get lower interest rates through a balanced budget bonus that is very real."
Mr. Dole said: "This is a fundamental change in the direction of government, and it seems to me we are going in the right direction. You talk about welfare reform, you talk about tax cuts for families with children, saving and preserving Medicare. The big item is balancing that budget in seven years. It's a challenge and an opportunity and a responsibility we have as the majority party."
The proposal that the Republicans submitted today, to get a stopgap spending bill approved and reopen Federal offices, would require Mr. Clinton to commit himself to a seven-year balanced-budget plan, to be judged by the Congressional Budget Office.
The Administration had proposed making both the plan and the issue of how compliance would be assessed subject to "mutual agreement." The Congressional Republicans gave a little ground, saying the Congressional Budget Office should consult with the White House budget office and other Government and private experts before announcing its findings.
Democratic Congressional aides agreed with Mr. Dole's assessment that the Administration would not accept the plan when Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, met with Republicans at the Capitol on Sunday afternoon. The Senate planned a rare Sunday afternoon schedule so it could act if there was any agreement to act upon.
Mr. Dole said, "There is ample room for compromise."
Asked about the $245 billion tax cut in the Republican plan, Mr. Gingrich said that everything would be on the table, "but I also think they have to recognize that we did sign a contract that did get us elected, and we are going to keep our word."

HEADLINE: Crime Continues to Decline, but Experts Warn of Coming 'Storm' of Juvenile Violence

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

 BODY:
The nation's overall crime rate dropped 2 percent in 1994, the third consecutive year it has fallen, with a 4 percent decrease in the rate of violent crimes, according to an annual report to be released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today.
The rate of violent crimes, which include murder, robbery, rape and assault, actually fell to its lowest level since 1989, the F.B.I. reported, and the murder rate itself continued its recent decline, similarly sinking to its lowest level since 1989, 9 murders per 100,000 inhabitants. 
 The F.B.I. data, part of the bureau's annual "Uniform Crime Report," are the latest indication that crime rates are receding after surging in the mid-1980's and early 1990's with the epidemic of crack cocaine and the increasing use of guns by young people.
Law-enforcement officials and criminologists agreed that the F.B.I. data showed that innovative police strategies generally known as community policing were beginning to produce results across the country. But the experts disagreed on whether a long-term improvement in crime rates had begun or whether they were simply seeing a normal statistical reaction after years of sharp increases.
"What is interesting about the data is that the numbers are definitely going down and there is every reason to believe the data are accurate," said John J. DiIulio Jr., professor of politics and public affairs at Princeton University. Professor DiIulio gave major credit to police leaders who had taken a more aggressive approach to their work, especially the New York City Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton.
But Professor DiIulio cautioned, "This is also the lull before the crime storm."
The professor said the reason for his concern was "40 million kids 10 years old and under" who are about to become teen-agers, the biggest group of adolescents in a generation, and many of them "fatherless, godless and jobless."
While it is true that the overall national number of violent crimes has been going down, Professor DiIulio said, the decline masks a more important underlying trend.
The decrease has been largely accounted for by a steady decline during the last 15 years in violent crimes by adults 24 years of age or older. But at the same time the number of violent crimes, especially those committed with guns, has been increasing among younger adolescents, and the number of teen-agers is about to climb rapidly.
The director of the F.B.I., Louis J. Freeh, also sounded a note of caution in remarks prepared to accompany the release of the report.
"The modest decreases in crime are, in large part, a tribute to the men and women in law enforcement who daily risk their lives for the public's safety," Mr. Freeh said, though He added that "the ominous increase in juvenile crime, coupled with population trends, portend future crime and violence at nearly unprecedented levels."
In a White House statement, President Clinton sought to give some of the credit for the reduced crime rates to his Administration. He cited the Crime Act, which is intended to put 100,000 more police officers on the street, as well as his efforts to ban the sale of assault weapons and insure passage of the Brady Bill, which requires a waiting period for handgun purchases.
But President Clinton also acknowledged that "all Americans must double their efforts to eliminate the scourge of juvenile violence."
According to the F.B.I. report, there were 14 million crimes in 1994, or a rate of 5,374 offenses for every 100,000 Americans, a decline of 2 percent compared with 1993.
Violent crime rates fell especially sharply in the nine cities with populations of more than one million people, declining 8 percent. But the overall crime rate was up 1 percent in the suburbs and 2 percent in rural counties, the F.B.I. said.
Geographically, the crime rate was highest in the West, with 6,152 crimes per 100,000 inhabitants, while it was lowest in the Northeast, with a rate of 4,344 per 100,000, the report said. The South had the highest murder rate, accounting for 42 percent of the nation's murders.
According to the report, the number of forcible rapes reported to law-enforcement authorities was 102,096, the lowest since 1989. Property crimes also fell in 1994, dropping to their lowest mark since 1984, the F.B.I. said.
Among serious crimes, the police reported the highest clearance rate for murder, 64 percent, and the lowest rate, 13 percent, for burglary. Clearance rate generally means a case is resolved, or closed, usually by an arrest.
During 1994, law-enforcement agencies made 14.6 million arrests, not including traffic violations, an increase of 6 percent over 1993. Of all people arrested during the year, 80 percent were male and 67 percent were white, the F.B.I. reported.
But for murder, the F.B.I said, 51 percent of the victims and 56 percent of the suspects arrested were black.
Professor DiIulio said these figures were especially alarming because they suggested that violent crime was becoming more concentrated in a few areas in the inner cities that already had many other signs of social distress, like poverty, unemployment and high rates of drug abuse.
"This makes it harder and harder to go after crime, because the criminals and their victims have even more chronic levels of illiteracy, joblessness and drug dependency," Professor DiIulio said.
But Joe Brann, the director of the Office of Community-Oriented Policing Services in the Justice Department, was more optimistic, noting that the biggest drops in crime had come in cities using the new strategies of community policing. "I am always cautious when I see these short-term crime figures," Mr. Brann said. "But I believe that with all the changes being made in law enforcement we are on the threshold of seeing even more significant reductions in crime and violence."
For example, Mr. Brann said that in Santa Ana, Calif., which pioneered the concept of community policing in the 1970's and where he served as an officer for many years, the city reduced the crime rate by 42 percent in 1994 compared with 1974.
