HEADLINE: Real Targets For Giuliani

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
By agreeing to unusually long union contracts this month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did more than simply secure labor peace until the next century. Having come to power vowing to transform the structure of government, he has now emphatically revealed where that transformation will take place, and where it will not.
The most intensive efforts at reducing and restructuring government will focus on those programs used mostly by the city's poorest residents: health care, social services and, to a lesser degree, education. The unionized employees, who deliver services related to so-called quality-of-life issues, will make only small sacrifices, and have agreed to step out of the way as Mr. Giuliani sells off public hospitals and puts welfare recipients to work. 
 For many, that statement of priorities is disappointing, and for varying reasons. Business leaders said they feared the Mayor was too generous with the unions and would eventually pay a financial price, while those who serve the poor said their clients were being asked to bear too heavy a portion of the budget-cutting pain.
"The Mayor is clearly willing to take big risks and break new ground when it comes to things like privatizing the hospitals," said Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker and former chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. "But when it comes to labor, it seems like very much of a holding operation, with no really new initiatives or changes from past practices."
The Rev. Kevin Sullivan, chief operating officer of Catholic Charities for the Archdiocese of New York, said that given the severe economic afflictions of those at the bottom of the ladder, he had expected the unions to give more.
"I was expecting that everyone was going to have to tighten their belts," Father Sullivan said, "so I was a little surprised that that was the situation. Our concern is always that we realize in hard times people have to make sacrifices, so you just have to be real careful that the major sacrifices aren't made by the most vulnerable among us."
Cementing a pattern that was glimpsed earlier in the year, the Mayor has agreed in two five-year contracts not to lay off, reduce the salary or cut the benefits of any teacher or unionized worker, with the notable exception of workers in the public hospitals.
Some employees will have to give up their premiums for working on Lincoln's Birthday in exchange for a day off later, and many union members are grumbling about having to wait two years before their 11.3 percent raises begin. But in general, the web of work rules and job protections Mr. Giuliani railed against as a candidate remains intact.
Having purchased labor peace, the Mayor is now free to pursue the items at the top of his agenda: eliminating the Board of Education and shrinking its budget, removing tens of thousands from the welfare rolls and putting the rest to work cleaning the city, cutting the city's Medicaid spending and selling the public hospitals to the private sector.
The Mayor and his aides argue that they have achieved a radical and historic turnaround in the city's relationship with labor. Randy L. Levine, the departing Labor Commissioner, said the city had cut spending for overtime, pensions and health benefits, all with the union's blessing. Most important, he said, the city has slashed its payroll costs, because far fewer people are working for the city.
Early in his term, Mr. Giuliani used money from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to pay about 17,000 workers to leave the city payroll. The new contract continues that pattern without the severance payments, assuming that 2,000 workers a year will leave of their own volition. That attrition will pay for $509 million of the contract's $830 million wage increase, said Marc V. Shaw, the city's Budget Director, with the rest coming from earlier health and pension agreements.
Peter J. Powers, the First Deputy Mayor, says the reduction constitutes a huge increase in worker productivity, because the remaining employees have to work harder to maintain the same level of services. Critics who want the city to be tough on the unions fail to credit the Mayor with achieving the same result through peaceful means, he said.
"Look at the end game here," Mr. Powers said. "We've got better services, with fewer employees, and a reduced budget."
Mr. Giuliani made the same point yesterday in a brief interview, saying the city saves only when there are fewer employees.
"If a smaller work force does the same job as a work force that was bloated by 8,000," he said, "then they are more productive. That's what productivity is."
But relying on severance payments and attrition is not the traditional definition of a productivity increase, because determining whether services have stayed even or declined is subjective. The Mayor said yesterday that there had been no reduction in services as the work force had shrunk, but a recent New York Times examination indicated otherwise.
"If they're counting attrition as productivity, well, it's hard to know what to make of that," said Robert R. Kiley, president of the New York City Partnership, an alliance of corporate executives, and former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. "That's the kind of thing the Dinkins administration used to do, and it doesn't have any real value without real changes in work rules or working conditions."
A more standard productivity change would have been getting the unions to agree to work longer days, or give up a holiday or a sick day. Though there are some modifications to overtime and holiday rules in the contract reached Friday night with the civilian workers, they do not produce a major savings.
Of course, the Republican Mayor gains a political premium through labor cooperation, particularly if the unions do not support a Democratic challenger in the next election. But beyond the ballot box, Mr. Giuliani's decision not to harm any existing worker has implications for the initiatives he holds most dear.
The civilian unions, for example, have now agreed not to object as the city puts welfare recipients to work cleaning up, sometimes in jobs once occupied by union members. The teachers' union has agreed with the Mayor that the governing structure of the school system must be overhauled, although it is still uncertain whether they will see eye-to-eye on a final proposal.
Most remarkably, the umbrella group known as the Bargaining Council of Municipal Labor Unions agreed in essence to abandon a major member, the hospital workers' union, which was left out of the no-layoff pledge contained in Friday's contract so that the city could sell its hospitals. Stanley Hill, chairman of the coalition, said the unions would work to find jobs for any displaced hospital employees, but the action made it clear that labor will not stand in the Mayor's way.
It is these areas -- health care, welfare and education -- that will be under the most pressure as Federal and state budget cuts make their way toward New York City in the months to come. And having agreed not to lay off most workers for three years or change any major work rules, the Mayor may find himself with no choice but to return to these areas again and again for cuts.
"The budget cuts coming from Washington seem to me inevitably to put the city under very, very significant pressure," Mr. Rohatyn said. "I would question whether the Mayor is actually able to keep the commitments being made here in these contracts without unleashing some other problems by skewing the sacrifices to programs under great pressure already, including those involving welfare recipients."

HEADLINE: Foster Care System Wary of Welfare Cuts

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Waiting for the school bus in a frosty dawn, 12-year-old Andy Munoz explained the secret of making a pair of shoes last when there is no money to buy new ones. "Try not to run in them," he said, shrinking into the hood of last year's winter jacket. "Try not to bend."
Andy has learned the lessons of poverty in a childhood shaped by slim paychecks that stop without warning and slimmer welfare checks that often come late. With his father gone, his mother, Olga L. Munoz, somehow manages between short-lived jobs, even when fuel bills eat up the grocery budget and rent money redeems the Christmas lay-away. 
 But five years ago, mistakenly caught in the machinery of a malfunctioning child protection system, Andy spent three weeks in a children's foster care shelter while his mother begged for his return. His greatest fear these days is that he will end up back in foster care, because without a welfare check to count on, how can his mother keep him?
"Welfare, I think it was made up so they can help people, and now they want to take it away," he said. "People can't pay their bills, and they'll lose everything."
Andy is not alone in being worried. The fear that refugees from the restructuring of welfare will flood an already overburdened foster care system is haunting state, county and municipal officials who preside over the nation's patchwork of child protection. By default, they say, they will be left holding the safety net for 9 million children who are losing their entitlement to welfare.
The Republican-led Congress has voted to end welfare as an entitlement with unlimited Federal funds, opting instead for limited cash payments to the states known as block grants. But at the same time, Congress would preserve unlimited Federal support for children who have been removed from their homes to shelters, foster homes or institutions.
With the changes, advocates and foster care officials say, fewer people would receive welfare, and more children would end up in foster care.
Thomas Brophy, former director of Milwaukee County Human Services, said bluntly that under that kind of strain "the foster care system that is now in a state of crisis would totally collapse." The county has seen its foster care caseload increase fivefold since 1986, as its child poverty rate soared to almost 28 percent.
The Republican architects of the welfare overhaul acknowledge that child protection systems will serve as the ultimate safety net, but they say that replacing welfare with work will lead to lower rates of the child neglect and abuse that lead to foster care. They say that the experiments already under way in many states ultimately will help families trapped in dependency work their way out of poverty and stop them from having children they cannot support.
But judges and child protection workers say that without any family right to aid, the blurry line between destitution and neglect will disappear altogether. Child protection statutes typically rule out parental poverty as a legal reason to take a child into government custody, but these laws are based on the assumption of an entitlement to public assistance that is being abolished.
"If we're going to take away income from a parent who refuses to cooperate, and I see three small kids in that home and no money coming in, I'm going to have to take them into custody," said Michael Malmstadt, chief judge of Milwaukee County's Children's Court, where a new state law has barred judges from appointing lawyers for poor parents at public expense.
 
Seeing More Problems For a System in Trouble
 These children will be moving into a foster care system that by all accounts is already deeply troubled. Between 1985 and 1992, the foster care population grew by 60 percent, to nearly 450,000 -- twice the growth rate of the welfare rolls. A child in foster care now costs the Federal Government 11 times more than a child on Aid to Families With Dependent Children, or A.F.D.C., the main cash assistance program. Federal spending on foster care ballooned to $2.55 billion in 1993 from $309 million in 1981 -- an eightfold increase.
"There's hardly an adequately functioning child welfare system in this country now," said Marcia Lowry, a lawyer who has pressed class action lawsuits against foster care systems in many states, and is director of Children's Rights Inc., a national nonprofit advocacy organization. "What is going to happen to these systems next year with the influx of children and with the elimination of other funding is unimaginable. It's not just that children are going to get dumped into this system and stay there, but that children in genuinely dangerous situations are not going to be taken in."
Milwaukee County is one of many jurisdictions in at least 22 states where lawsuits have caused officials to acknowledge that their overburdened child protection systems damage many of the children they are supposed to protect. But nowhere is the collision course between the foster care system and the campaign to end welfare more sharply etched than in Wisconsin, where Gov. Tommy Thompson, a Republican, has ridden his welfare agenda into national prominence, and county officials say the foster care system is in danger of collapsing under its unintended consequences.
"If foster care is intended to be the life raft for children who can no longer remain safely at home, then the boat is being swamped," said Mark Courtney, a University of Wisconsin professor who recently analyzed the relationship between national poverty policy and foster care for the Journal of the American Public Welfare Association.
There are no reliable national figures for the total cost of foster care, but according to the best estimates, the Federal share represents about 40 percent and goes to the care of children already eligible for A.F.D.C. -- about half the children in foster care.
"In essence, A.F.D.C. foster care is a program whereby the government takes over primary child-rearing responsibilities from low-income parents, based on the assumption that it can and must do better," Professor Courtney wrote. Even in the absence of welfare overhaul, he said, the Federal Government will soon be spending about one-fourth as much trying to raise the children of low-income families as it spends to keep them at home on A.F.D.C.
The kind of group home care Andy Munoz experienced when he was 7 costs between $2,000 and $6,000 a month, and he would still be entitled to it under the Republican bill. The median monthly A.F.D.C. payment is $212 for one child -- about $100 per month less than the median foster care rate.
 
An Array of Programs, Under Reconstruction
 Welfare as Andy knows it is more than Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Food stamps paid for the pancakes Mrs. Munoz made for his breakfast with the help of his 11-year-old sister Geneva, who has mild disabilities from a premature birth and receives Social Security. A Federally-subsidized lunch awaits the children at school. A $396 check from A.F.D.C. mainly allows the family to pay the rent on their bungalow, which faces a highway and the remains of an industrial skyline in a city where 53 percent of all children are dependent on A.F.D.C.
Now all this is being disassembled, shrunk or replaced. Governor Thompson has been ahead of the curve. He cut and froze A.F.D.C. benefits to political acclaim as Wisconsin's economy rebounded from the devastating recession of the early 1980's. He lobbied for block grants. Leading the way for governors in 34 other states, he obtained a fistful of Federal waivers from both the Bush and Clinton administrations to launch get-tough pilot projects with names like Learnfare and Work not Welfare. Voters loved them, though researchers have found the results equivocal at best.
Meanwhile, Clifford O'Connor, who recently succeeded Mr. Brophy as head of Milwaukee County Human Services, saw the foster care caseload in his county surge from about 1,200 in 1986 to nearly 6,000 last year, as the foster care costs paid for by property taxes increased tenfold, to $30 million from $3 million. County officials contend that they never saw new Federal foster care money because the state just used it to replace its own expenditures.
Now Wisconsin is on the verge of replacing Aid to Families With Dependent Children entirely with a jobs-only program called W-2, which eliminates A.F.D.C. entitlements to 76,000 families, including 72,000 children in Milwaukee County. Under the plan, which is expected to be approved by the legislature early next year, families will be eligible for some child care and health insurance subsidies, but these would not be entitlements, and could be cut if competing costs -- like the foster care budget -- grew too large. Mr. O'Connor estimates that an additional 10,800 children will flood his county's child protection system even if only 15 percent of A.F.D.C. households, or 5,400 adults, are judged "uncooperative" under the plan; that was the percentage of general assistance recipients who failed the mandatory work program the county ran until last month, when Wisconsin ended all cash relief to childless adults.
"We're very nervous," Mr. O'Connor said. "We can't handle the 6,000 we have now, let alone any more. The whole welfare reform thrust is based on changing adult behavior. It's a hard road to go down. If the parent doesn't cooperate, or they use up their time-limited benefits, or their family is too large to support on the minimum wage, or they're mentally ill and can't work, what are we going to do with the children? I only need a small number of people failing with welfare reform to get a large number of kids."
Milwaukee County social workers today have caseloads of 100 children, five times the national average, and have to abandon them all to the oblivion of an unstaffed "vacant zone" if they leave the agency. One 10-year-old plaintiff in an American Civil Liberties lawsuit against the system spent 11 months in a temporary shelter without hearing from the caseworker who was supposed to find him a foster family -- his fifth placement in five years. An aunt who could not care for the abused boy herself grew so desperate that she ran her own campaign to find him a foster home, distributing fliers in her neighborhood that read: "I'm a little boy. I like soccer. What I really need is a mom and dad."
 
'Positive Aspects' Seen From Tougher Programs
 Mr. Brophy, who is about to retire from decades of county service, talks like a man who sees two trains speeding, oblivious, toward an intersection.
"The welfare reform debate and its implementation is on one track, the child welfare reform and debate is on another. And what child welfare advocates in Wisconsin are saying is we must stop and look at the potential impact on the child welfare system of families who fail to make it in the reformed welfare system. We must at least begin to ask the questions."
State officials, who are defendants in the three-year-old suit by the civil liberties union, plan to take over the county's foster care system and privatize it. But they will not discuss the possibility that W-2 could swell the system's ranks. On the contrary, they assert that child neglect and abuse probably will decrease as parents on A.F.D.C. go to work under W-2, which expects to place 85 percent of participants in subsidized jobs paying between $2.98 and $3.19 per hour. Mothers will be required to go to work when their children are 12 weeks old.
"So many positive aspects come from feeling good about yourself and those feelings come from employment," argues Jean Rogers, Governor Thompson's appointee as the state's director of public assistance, which is soon to be folded into a new superagency, the Division of Labor and Job Development. "People when they feel better about themselves are much more likely to behave positively to the people around them. We're saying that on balance there will not be a negative impact."
The same pattern is repeated around the country. As Republican governors compete to design the toughest welfare system, their human services administrators say little about possible child protection consequences. But county officials are waking up in alarm to the unanticipated costs.
'All the talk of historic welfare reform is just about shifting the liability and risk to the local communities," said Rick Phelps, the president of National Association of Elected County Executives. "If a mom is forced to go to work and does not have adequate child care, the county will seize the child. Not only is that a human tragedy, but the county will pay the bill. And the state and Federal Government will be completely protected, because they have capped all of their risk."

HEADLINE: Haitian Leader's Angry Words Unnerve Elite and Worry Allies

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 18

 BODY:
With an emotional outburst at the funeral of a slain relative a week ago, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide set off an outbreak of street violence, provoked panic among Haiti's elite and undermined his relations with the United States and other members of the international coalition that restored him to power a year ago.
At least seven people have been killed and more than a score wounded in the unrest that erupted after Mr. Aristide urged his followers a week ago today to "go to the neighborhoods where there are big houses and heavy weapons" to help the police disarm "the big men with heavy weapons" and other suspected wrongdoers. 
 "Do not sit idly by, do not wait," he demanded in an impassioned eulogy for Jean-Hubert Feuille, a cousin and close political associate.
Since then, dozens of homes of suspected Aristide opponents have been burned or looted, a radio station critical of the President has been attacked and vigilante squads have erected roadblocks and stopped and searched vehicles. In the coastal town of Gonaives earlier this week, Nepalese soldiers who are part of the United Nations peacekeeping force clashed with a pro-Aristide mob, firing shots into the air to disperse them, while in the northern town of Limbe, 21 foreign relief workers, 16 of them Americans, took refuge in a hospital after a band of Aristide supporters became unruly.
Mr. Aristide's tirade also included sharp criticism of what he described as the failure of the United Nations mission here to disarm Tontons Macoutes and other members of hostile paramilitary groups. Foreign officials who have been working closely with the Aristide Government in efforts to build democracy here after nearly three decades of dictatorship described themselves as shocked and even betrayed by the President's unexpected behavior.
"He wanted to flex some muscle and take aim at an issue important to all Haitians, but he went way too far, and has brought the process of national reconciliation almost to a halt," one diplomat said. Another said: "He played with fire a little bit, and I'm sure he did it on purpose. He was sending everyone a message."
But a close aide to Mr. Aristide said he had not intended to encourage violence in the streets, only to get the attention of the international community before the scheduled departure of the United Nations troops at the end of February.
"Some slogans against the United Nations mission have been appearing, and he was telling them they must do more disarmament so that the people will kiss them and dance with them again," the aide said.
After meeting with Mr. Aristide on Monday, Lakhdar Brahimi, who heads the United Nations mission here, scoffed at the idea of a widening rift between Haiti's Government and the United Nations.
"We have no problems or difficulties," Mr. Brahimi said. Disarmament efforts will continue, he said, adding, "One cannot find things which are only said to be here or there." But he also urged Haitians not to respond to Mr. Aristide's call for vigilantism.
"The Constitution and the law say that it is the police who are responsible for keeping order, and not self-declared volunteers who say they are," he said.
With Haitians scheduled to go to the polls Dec. 17 to choose a successor to Mr. Aristide, "the latest violence has thrown a shadow over the presidential campaign," the Port-au-Prince newspaper Le Nouvelliste declared this week.
The incidents of violence by vigilantes and intimidation against perceived opponents of Mr. Aristide coincided with the registration period for presidential candidates, and dropped off as it came to an end on Wednesday. Many of Mr. Aristide's most fervent supporters have called for the vote to be canceled altogether so he would remain in office. Under Haiti's Constitution, the President cannot serve two consecutive terms.
The crisis began on Nov. 7, when Mr. Feuille, a newly seated member of Parliament, was shot and killed by unknown assailants as he arrived at the home of another lawmaker. The two men had earlier that day attended the swearing-in ceremony of Haiti's new Prime Minister, Claudette Werleigh, and stopped at a bank, where they withdrew several thousand dollars. That money disappeared in the shooting, but the Haitian Government has said it regarded Mr. Feuille's death as an assassination. Within hours, the police began searching for suspected arms caches among supporters of the former military rulers.
One of those whose arrest was sought was Gen. Prosper Avril, a former military dictator. But since taking refuge in the Colombian Embassy on the day of the killing, General Avril has been granted asylum and negotiations are under way to gain his safe passage out of the country.
Last Saturday's outburst was uncharacteristic for Mr. Aristide, who since returning from three years in exile on Oct. 15, 1994, has steadfastly preached reconciliation, peace and patience.
"It is the first time that I have spoken like this since my return to Haiti," he acknowledged toward the end of the eulogy, delivered from a church pulpit as Haitians cheered wildly and the diplomatic corps sat by silently and grimly.
For the political and economic elite that has always distrusted Mr. Aristide, his remarks stirred memories of the incendiary oratory he employed shortly before being overthrown by the military in September 1991. Fearing the worst, some prominent political and business figures have quietly left the country, while others have approached friends at foreign embassies, seeking guarantees of protection.
"The private sector has a great deal of fear," said a businessman who has generally supported Mr. Aristide. "Things are very tense."
Mr. Aristide's aides and supporters maintain that his outburst, and the violence it provoked, were spontaneous responses to a deeply felt personal tragedy.
"It was an emotional reaction," said Jean-Robert Sabalat, who was briefly Mr. Aristide's Foreign Minister in 1991 and is now a member of the Senate. "Now everything is calm and back to normal."
But Mr. Aristide's opponents argue that his real motives are otherwise. "There is a political strategy behind this campaign," intended to make the presidential election meaningless, said Evans Paul, a former ally and Mayor of Port-au-Prince who broke with the President after this summer's parliamentary elections.
On Wednesday, Mr. Aristide's Lavalas movement chose Rene Preval, a former Prime Minister who heads a foundation that finances small development projects, as its candidate, and he is expected to win handily. Most major opposition parties are boycotting the election, and the field of 14 includes candidates from such obscure entities as the Virgin Mary Party and Haitian Party of God as well as three senators running as independents.
Relations between Mr. Aristide's Government and the United Nations coalition that brought him back to power have been fraying since Prime Minister Smarck Michel stepped down last month. Mr. Michel resigned and was replaced by Mrs. Werleigh after failing to persuade Mr. Aristide to carry out an agreement signed with Haiti's creditors to privatize nine state companies.
As a result of the Government's failure to move ahead with that program, the United States is withholding $4.6 million in aid, some $100 million in other foreign assistance is also in jeopardy, and the value of the gourde has dropped by 20 percent. That has not only frustrated the Government, which sent Finance Jean-Marie Cherestal off to Taiwan in an unsuccessful quest for money, but also appears to have reduced the leverage of the United States and its allies over Mr. Aristide.
Mr. Aristide's funeral eulogy, which was broadcast repeatedly on television and radio for several days afterward, included what many interpreted as a jab at the United States Ambassador here, William L. Swing, and Mr. Brahimi, the chief of the United Nations mission, who were seated together at the funeral.
"I am reminding you that until further notice there are not two or three heads of state, but just one," Mr. Aristide said.
In addition, he suggested that a second term for the Clinton Administration is linked to his success or failure here.
"The month of November 1995 must be a month of peace, a month of success, so the month of November 1996 can be a success also in the United States," he said.
Mr. Aristide also pointedly reminded American and United Nations officials of the profound emotional hold and bond he has with the Haitian people. "Dear friends of the international community, I know you need me just as I need you," he said.
To many diplomats here, that is perhaps the chief lesson of the week's unrest.
"It doesn't matter whether Aristide is sitting in the presidential palace, or retires to his home in Tabarre" after his scheduled departure from office on Feb. 7, one diplomat said. "He will still be the one who has the power in this country."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE CLOSURES;
Canyon Becomes Peaceful, Pleasing Nobody

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE 

DATELINE: GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK, Ariz., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Nature's silence was profound, ethereal and serene, and frankly a bit eerie.
Such quietude is hardly typical of the Grand Canyon this time of year. Normally, about 8,000 people a day visit this national treasure, and there is hardly an inch not flanked by a crush of gawking visitors. Hotels are usually booked weeks ahead, and trails are crawling with hikers. Few come here anymore seeking solitude since they hardly see the canyon through the jumbo tour buses and encircling motels and fast-food restaurants. 
 That was until the park, a major source of tourism income in Arizona, was shut on Thursday because of the Federal budget impasse.
Indeed, for the first time in the country's history, all 369 national parks, monuments and recreation areas have been shut down. Although several parks have been closed temporarily because of fire, earthquakes or other natural catastrophes, never have they been closed at the same time in the 79-year history of the National Park Service.
Although it is impossible to say how many visitors ventured to the Grand Canyon today -- and some determined souls were hoping to force themselves into the park -- by any accounting, this was virtually a ghost town.
Except for some tour planes and helicopters, the quiet of the ages once found at the Grand Canyon's vast amphitheaters had abruptly returned, thanks to the budget brawl in Washington.
"It stinks," said Harry Miller, manager of the Eagle Canyon airlines office here. He said on a good day, the five carriers that work the area bring in several thousand people; today, only 37 passengers had arrived by midday.
"With them closing the park, it's put 3,800 people out of work," Mr. Miller said.
Not far away, Pat Noon, a manager for a helicopter service in the park and a 16-year resident of the area, said the budget impasse "is hurting a lot of innocent people."
"And the worst thing about it is that the politicians don't care," Mr. Noon said, "they're in this for their own political gain."
Sheila Taylor and her fiance, James Atwater, had been planning a tour of the south rim for months. Not only had the closing altered their plans, but it also had a decededly negative effect on their mood. "We've been bickering for the last two days about whether to stick around, hoping this thing will end and the park will open, or drive back to Los Angeles," Ms. Taylor said. "I want to go, but Jim doesn't. I guess it'll work itself out eventually. But frankly, I'm depressed."
On Friday, Interior Department officials rebuffed an effort by Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona to use National Guard troops and state employees to reopen the park, citing safety issues, financial problems and possible legal tangles.
The department's rejection came in a letter from John D. Leshy, the solicitor of the Interior Department to the Governor, a Republican, who arrived at the park's gates along with 50 or so National Guard troops he had ordered to the spectacular chasm.
The arrival of the guard troops in Humvee all-terrain vehicles, ambulances and personnel trucks seemed to suggest the possibility of a state takeover. But state officials said the troops were part of a transportation unit summoned to help workers return in the event the park was reopened.
A spokesman for the department said later that agency officials were willing to discuss an arrangement in which parts of the park could be reopened if the state paid the full operational and insurance costs.
In any event, the park will remain closed at least until Monday, Governor Symington told reporters at a news conference at Grand Cayon Airport on Friday, adding, "I think it's all a political game."
Amy Rezzonico, a spokeswoman for Governor Symington, told the Mesa Tribune that the closing of the Grand Canyon National Park meant the park and surrounding areas are losing between $950,000 and $1.25 million a day in tourism revenue.
At the park itself, the mood among the thousands who normally run the attractions was as gloomy as the day was bright.
"We have no guests in any of our 900 rooms," said Jane Gillespie, sales director for Grand Canyon National Park Lodges. "With weather like today, we normally have high occupancy. And Thanksgiving is usually sold out."
And after Thanksgiving, park attendance usually rises to 15,000 to 20,000 visitors a day.
"People are upset," she said. "They've prepaid for their rooms. A lot of people come here to get their winter fix."

HEADLINE: Bosnia Asks U.S. Arms Aid as Part of Any Peace Accord

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The Muslim-led Bosnian Government has formally asked the United States to provide "on an urgent basis, significant materiel, training and logistic support" to insure a balance of forces with the Serbs as part of any peace agreement.
The demand, made in a draft memorandum of understanding given to American officials, calls on the Clinton Administration to "move at once" to obtain a lifting of the arms embargo on Bosnia and Herzegovina and then "take immediate steps to facilitate the urgent delivery of defense articles and services." 
 Although Washington is ready to push for a lifting of the arms embargo in the event of a peace accord and work to achieve a balance of power in the Balkans, the Bosnian draft memorandum is unacceptable in its demand for American arms and training, senior officials said.
The issue is "a potential deal breaker," a Bosnian official said. It is one of several thorny questions, including the division of territory, that remain unresolved as an 18-day-old peace conference here moves toward a conclusion that is expected on Sunday or Monday, whether a settlement is reached or not.
"There are significant gaps among the parties, significant disagreements, and a substantial amount of work to do," said Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman. He was speaking after a meeting today between Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Slobodan Milosevic, Serbia's President.
But a senior European diplomat said that the talks were moving forward despite the difficulties and that there was still hope of an agreement by Sunday night and the initialing of it by the parties on Monday.
A member of the American delegation to the talks said, "The psychodrama in here is really quite amazing." As the hour of decisions approaches, the Bosnian Government, which has known nothing but war, appears particularly torn over what course to take.
The tension building at the conference was evident early today in the abrupt resignation of Muhamed Sacirbey, Bosnia's Foreign Minister. He announced his departure over a beer in the discotheque at a Holiday Inn near Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, where the talks are being held. It is not clear when the resignation will take effect.
Mr. Sacirbey said his decision stemmed from the need to install a Croat in a top government position in order to bolster the Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia.
"The country has to have a Croatian in one of its top three posts," he said. "The President isn't going and the Prime Minister doesn't want to go so I decided I would go."
But officials at the talks said the relationship between Bosnia's Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, and Mr. Sacirbey had been under acute strain during the 18 days of negotiations.
"Mr. Sacirbey had effectively been sidelined," said a person at the talks.
American officials have been focusing their diplomatic efforts on Mr. Silajdzic, whom they see as the key to persuading the Bosnian President, Alija Izetbegovic, that his country's future is best secured through peace rather than a continuation of 42 months of war. It appeared that this approach had not pleased the American-educated Mr. Sacirbey, 39, who 3 has proved extremely adroit at putting across the Bosnian point of view in countless television interviews.
Bosnian officials said the issue of American military support for the Bosnian Army after any peace deal had become critical. It was raised on Friday with Defense Secretary William J. Perry, and the day before with Anthony Lake, the national security adviser.
The draft memorandum makes clear the Bosnian demands by saying that "it is understood" that Bosnian forces are "particularly deficient with respect to armor, artillery, air mobility, communications, logistics and air defense."
The Clinton Administration at first said it was ready to provide military support for the Muslim-Croat federation after a peace deal. But several factors have since led it to an apparent modification of its position.
Among these factors are strong objections from Western European allies and the difficulty of combining participation in a neutral NATO force to enforce peace with active military support for one side in the conflict.
Moreover, in Congress, even among supporters of American participation in the NATO force and an immediate lifting of the embargo, there are serious misgivings about an active American role in arming and training the federation, senior officials said. The view of many on Capitol Hill is that peace enforcement and the training of one side are irreconcilable.
"Our position has evolved," said a senior Administration official. "Clearly, it would be a deal breaker if we were not prepared to do anything for the Bosnians. But how and when and who does it are critical factors. We are hoping that it will be enough for them to have the certainty that we will help them."
It thus appeared unlikely that any commitment in writing to provide arms and training, as requested in the memorandum, would be forthcoming from the Administration at this stage.
Mr. Burns, the State Department spokesman, said the Administration's preference was now to "build down" toward a rough military balance -- that is, presumably, to relieve the Bosnian Serbs of some of their considerable superiority in tanks and artillery.
The issue has been complicated by the fact that the Croatian Army has been present in large numbers in Bosnia for several months and has insured that, in fact, a rough military balance exists at this moment.
Unless a lasting military balance is contrived, it would be very difficult for NATO forces, including American troops, that would go in to police a peace to leave after one year, as they now hope to do.
In the event of an agreement, the United States and its allies are preparing to suspend trade sanctions on Serbia. Diplomats said a draft resolution had been prepared at the Security Council that would suspend all trade sanctions as soon as an accord is initialed. The sanctions have been in effect for more than three years and have inflicted considerable economic misery on Serbia.
The diplomats said the resolution would not affect financial sanctions on Serbia -- like its ineligibility for international loans. Those sanctions would remain in place until any accord has been fully carried out. Moreover, the suspension would be for a limited period and trade sanctions would be immediately reimposed if Mr. Milosevic did not sign the final peace agreement.

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE BUDGET;
Once Ignored, a Middle-Ground Budget Advances

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Even as President Clinton prepares to veto a huge budget-balancing bill, Administration officials are completing their own proposals to achieve a similar fiscal goal while protecting programs for poor people and the elderly.
The President has yet to give in to the Republican demand that a balanced budget be achieved in seven years, but his aides are crafting just such a proposal that would, among other things, dramatically reduce the size of Republican tax cuts. 
 In preparation for negotiations with Congress after the veto, White House officials say Mr. Clinton is being forced to set his priorities more firmly than ever before, deciding, for example, which programs he really wants to protect, which Republican proposals he can tolerate and which are unacceptable.
"If you get to a negotiation, you want to have your homework done," said the deputy assistant to the President for economic policy, Gene B. Sperling. "If you have a negotiation, you want to know what proposals of theirs could be acceptable if they made the right concessions and which ones are absolutely unacceptable."
And in figuring out a new budget, the White House has been inspired by a largely unnoticed alternative budget offered in October by moderate and conservative Democrats in the House. In the middle of the current turmoil, the proposal looks more and more like a promising middle ground between the White House and Congressional Republicans. It would eliminate the Federal budget deficit in seven years, as the Republicans want, while requiring less drastic cuts in social programs because it is without tax cuts. By contrast, both houses of Congress have voted to cut taxes by $245 billion over seven years, and Mr. Clinton wants to cut taxes by $105 billion.
While this will not be the last word on the budget, Republicans and Democrats admit this is the direction where a compromise is heading.
Representative Tim Roemer, Democrat of Indiana, described the basic logic of the alternative budget: "If you delay tax cuts till after the budget is balanced, then you don't have to devastate Medicare, student loans and farm programs."
Many Democrats say that even Mr. Clinton's tax proposal is too expensive. "Every Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee opposes the President's tax proposal," said Representative Benjamin L. Cardin, Democrat of Maryland, a member of the committee. Aides to Alice M. Rivlin, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said she tended to agree with these Democrats. For every dollar given away in tax cuts, they said, another dollar must be cut from Medicare, education, farm programs or some other Government activity.
The alternative budget was developed by a group of conservative Democrats known as the Coalition. It won surprising support from Democratic liberals when offered as an alternative to the Republican budget on the House floor on Oct. 26. Then 68 Democrats voted for the measure including more liberal lawmakers like Mr. Cardin, John D. Dingell of Michigan, Vic Fazio of California, the chairman of the House Democratic Caucus, and Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, the ranking Democrat on the Budget Committee.
Only four Republicans voted for the Coalition budget, but many praised its authors.
Its supporters in the Senate include Paul Simon of Illinois, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Kent Conrad of North Dakota. Mr. Cardin claims that cuts in the Republican budget were so deep they could not be sustained over the seven-year life of the budget plan. "Bureaucrats will find a way to get their money back," he said in an interview. "I don't want to go through all the pain and suffering of budget cuts and still have large deficits in the future."
Likewise, Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, which has supplied liberal Democrats with some of their most powerful arguments against the Republicans' social welfare policies, said the Coalition budget "sets the right priorities on a lot of issues."
"It doesn't savage means-tested entitlement programs" like food stamps, welfare and Medicaid, Mr. Greenstein said.
The Republicans would control the cost of welfare and Medicaid by giving each state a fixed amount of Federal money, known as a block grant, to run its own programs with a minimum of Federal supervision, and they would allow states to replace the food stamp program with similar grants. People now receiving assistance would not necessarily be entitled to benefits in the future.
The alternative Coalition budget would preserve such entitlements, but restrain the cost. One of the Coalition's most significant proposals would slow the growth of Social Security benefits paid to 43 million people. The Coalition would base the annual cost-of-living adjustment on the change in the Consumer Price Index minus one-half of one percentage point in each of the next three years. Currently the annual cost-of-living adjustment for several entitlement programs is based on the Consumer Price Index, which many economists say overstates inflation.
Representative Charles W. Stenholm, Democrat of Texas and a strong supporter of the Coalition budget, made the principal argument in the budget's favor saying it offered Mr. Clinton "a middle ground that protects some of his priorities and principles" while satisfying the Republican demand for a balanced budget in seven years.
The Federal budget deficit has declined in each of the last three years. The Republican budget package would balance the budget in 2002 but estimates by the Congressional Budget Office show that the Republican plan would actually increase the deficit in 1996 and 1997, partly because of the tax cuts.
The budget bill approved this week in both houses of Congress would cut projected spending on Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, by $270 billion over seven years. The Coalition would cut $168 billion, and Mr. Clinton would cut $124 billion.
Republicans in Congress would cut projected spending on Medicaid, the program for the poor, by $163 billion over seven years. By contrast, the Coalition would cut $85 billion, and Mr. Clinton would cut $54 billion.
Republicans would cut $32 billion from the earned-income tax credit, a valuable form of assistance for low-income workers. The Coalition would cut $2 billion, and Mr. Clinton would cut $3 billion.
In his budget request in February, just three months after a Republican landslide, Mr. Clinton evidently misjudged the mood of Congress and proposed spending and tax policies that would generate deficits of at least $190 billion a year through 2005.
In mid-June, Mr. Clinton suddenly shifted course and proposed to balance the budget in 10 years, but offered a sketchy outline of how to do it. In late July, he said he could achieve a balanced budget in nine years because the economy was performing better than expected, and the Government was spending less than expected for benefit programs and debt service.
On Medicaid, it is relatively easy to see room for compromise between Congress and the President. Republicans want to limit the growth of the program overall. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, would limit the growth in the average Federal payment for each Medicaid recipient, and the Coalition also favors a "per capita cap." A limit on per capita spending would help control costs, but would still allow Medicaid to expand automatically if the need increased because of a recession or an epidemic.
Administration officials have several proposals to control Medicaid costs, including a reduction in special Medicaid payments to hospitals that serve large numbers of indigent patients.
The Administration might curb Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and home health agencies that care for elderly people but with far smaller reductions than those planned by the Republicans.
Mr. Clinton and the Coalition recommend a small raise in the basic premium for Medicare beneficiaries, less than what the Republicans want. Like the Republicans, the Coalition, would establish higher Medicare premiums for people with higher incomes, a step not recommended by Mr. Clinton.
Finally, under the budget bill just passed by Congress, discretionary spending would decline to $515 billion in 2002, from $546 billion in the fiscal year 1995, which ended on Sept. 30. This spending is some one-third of the budget and covers activities like education, law enforcement, environmental protection, scientific research and national defense. To keep up with inflation, the Congressional Budget Office says, such spending would have to rise to $631 billion in 2002.
Martha H. Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan organization that lobbies for a balanced budget, said it was unrealistic to think that discretionary spending would decline for seven years, given pressures from Federal agencies and citizens who benefit from such spending.
"One wonders how Congress could possibly stay on that course for more than a few years," Mrs. Phillips said. "It's a starvation diet, like skipping two meals a day for the next seven years."

HEADLINE: Town Built on Steel Industry Resigns Itself to End of an Era

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 18

 BODY:
There is not much fire-and-tongs fight left in Local 2599 anymore. Old steelmen like Rebel, Chico and the union boss Danny Mills know they have lost their battle to preserve a livelihood, and with it a way of life.
"There was a time when we were unbeatable," said Mr. Mills, pointing to framed black-and-white photos of steelworkers toppling police cars and hurling bricks during their first walkout, in 1941. 
 "Those men didn't fight for something like this to happen," Mr. Mills said, his voice echoing in the dim corridor of the quiet United Steelworkers union hall.
Early today, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation shut down the last blast furnace at its flagship plant here, sending home 1,800 workers and ending an operation that had been pouring steel since before the Civil War.
Chances are that almost any major bridge or skyscraper in America contains some Bethlehem steel. Metal forged here went into landmarks like the Golden Gate and George Washington Bridges, into missile silos and more than 1,000 naval and merchant ships in World War II.
Having bailed out the company with economic concessions in the 1980's, Bethlehem workers feel betrayed by the closing.
The hot-metal workers and the big-beam shapers were the latest to fall to the cutbacks that have shrunk the Bethlehem plant in northeastern Pennsylvania from 31,000 workers at its postwar heyday in the 1960's to the 1,200 workers who were left after today's shutdown. The skeleton crew will continue nonsteelmaking operations, like running a coke furnace and a combine mill that rolls unfinished steel.
Bethlehem was once America's No. 2 steelmaker, during a time when 85 percent of all goods manufactured in the United States contained steel and 40 percent of the nation's work force owed its wages, directly or indirectly, to steel.
But in the past 30 years, American giants like Bethlehem and United States Steel have been caught in what an industry expert, Paul Tiffany, called "the twin pincers of foreign steel and the mini-mills." Making iron and steel, he said, "is the most labor-intensive part of the industry, and Bethlehem was far out of the running."
America has now largely ceded heavy steelmaking to the Japanese. Some steelmakers in the United States have formed joint ventures with foreign competitors.
Bethlehem's chief executive, Curtis H. Barnette, acknowledged that "the unions did their part when we asked them" to make concessions. But rather than try to modernize the antiquated Bethlehem plant, Mr. Barnette decided to build a mini-mill in Steelton, Pa., and refurbish the steel plant in Burns Harbor, Ind., which is near the major auto manufacturers.
Bethlehem's restructuring has enabled the company to rebound somewhat. For the first nine months of 1995, the corporation posted profits of $147 million.
But for the newly laid-off workers it's a different story. More than half have opted for early retirement, figuring that their specialized training made them unemployable in the Bethlehem area.
"I don't know what will happen to these men with kids in school, mortgages to pay," said a 48-year-old furnace operator, Larry Brandon. "We've got guys here with little ones, and that little nickel job they're going to find won't go too far."
The lucky ones will find jobs through the company's four-year-old retraining and placement program. But Mr. Brandon believes many will simply leave Bethlehem, a city of about 70,000 people.
"There's nothing here for them anymore," he said. "Just a town looking over a graveyard."

HEADLINE: NYC;
Horror Cabbies Add to Burdens Of Honest Ones

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
NEW YORK'S taxi drivers have been taking it on the collective chin.
First, the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission reported last week that 5 percent of cabbies in the yellow fleets lack valid driver's licenses. Then it issued a list of 10 drivers who are the top code violators, quickly dubbed "cabbies from hell." 
 Tahir Sohail, cruising mid-Manhattan in his yellow cab, applauded the agency for going after the bad guys. (Thankfully, he applauded at a red light, keeping hands on the wheel while driving.) "It's good they do this," he said. "It's good for the nice people who want to drive well."
But before cabby-hating goes too far, Mr. Sohail points out that driving 12 hours a day for a living is no simple task. It was easier back in Lahore, Pakistan, which he left seven years ago for this city where the streets, once thought by immigrants to be paved with gold, are sometimes barely paved at all.
"It was better in Lahore," he said. "There is no double-parking there. And the police treat you nicer."
With the taxi commission debating whether to raise fares as much as 27 percent, attention has turned once again to the caliber of the 40,000 drivers -- overwhelmingly foreign born, with 40 percent having come from the Indian subcontinent alone.
SOME newspaper and magazine writers delving into the industry's complicated economics have concluded that the fare, which has gone up only twice since 1980, should stay put. Any increase, they say, would go to the owners of the 11,787 taxi medallions, those coveted licenses to accept street hails. Each is now worth as much as $220,000 because the number of medallions has been unchanged since 1937, thanks to political faintheartedness before a powerful taxi-owner lobby.
It just so happens that many of those opposed to a fare increase are guys in suits who take cabs a lot. The suits didn't ask Embadul Shahan what he thought.
Mr. Shahan, who came eight years ago from Bangladesh, also worries that a good part of any raise will go to the man who leases him his yellow cab. But at least he will get some extra money, and he can use every penny.
For him, the economics lesson starts with the $450 leasing fee each week. He also pays about $20 a day for gas, and is sometimes hit by the cab owner with extra charges like "a deposit" for using the meter. It means that he must pick up at least $100 a day in fares and tips just to climb back to zero.
His situation is typical, as are his earnings of $75 to $90 for a 12-hour shift. "If I work six days, maybe I can make $500," he said as he ended a break at an Indian restaurant on Lexington Avenue.
A sympathetic Christopher R. Lynn, chairman of the taxi commission, says that if the city wants better cabs and more qualified drivers, it must have a fare structure that gives cabbies more than their present average of $6.25 an hour.
Ah, but what about all those fringe benefits that Mr. Shahan receives? Like abuse from veteran New Yorkers because his English, which is perfectly fine, does not meet loftier standards. Being told by some New Yawkers that you don't speak well is bit like being called ugly by a frog. But that does not stop the diatribes, often wildly exaggerated, about the quality of English behind the wheel.
"THE most liberal people in the world can be the most nativist when it comes to taxi drivers," said Anne Morris of the Center for Logistics and Transportation at the City University's graduate school.
No one denies that some yellow cab drivers indeed speak poorly. Some are abusive. Some are fare-gougers. Some confuse Manhattan's avenues for the Indy 500. Many have no idea how to get to Carnegie Hall, except maybe practice. Many will not go to Brooklyn.
But Manhattan cabbies never liked going to Brooklyn, including the cigar-chomping fellow of misguided nostalgia. A recent survey by the taxi commission shows that most riders are amply satisfied with the service. Besides, if some cabbies do not know their way around, don't city monitors share the blame for having tolerated it for so long?
Standards are now being tightened, Mr. Lynn pledges. But that is not so easy in a city that habitually thumbs its nose at traffic laws. By police estimate, 15 percent of all New York drivers do not have valid licenses.
At only 5 percent, the cabbies suddenly look pretty good.

HEADLINE: LIBERTIES;
Mr. Speaker, May I?

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
It is Nov. 19, 1996. The Federal Government has been shut down for a year. The landscape is bleak, the city a trash heap. Rats chew on rep ties and sensible pumps. The rubble of old health care plans and $600 toilet seats are strewn across Pennsylvania Avenue. The neo-classical buildings are shells. Wild bands of unemployed bureaucrats roam the streets, forcing innocent passers-by to fill out huge volumes of paperwork. A gang war has broken out between the G-6's and the G-7's. Besides bonfires, the only pools of light are in the Capitol and the White House, where the two sides in the budget standoff are hunkered down. How did a once-great nation sink into this dystopia? Follow me back, as I explain:
Nov. 15, 1995: Newt Gingrich admits that pique over how he was treated by the President on the trip to Israel provoked him into writing a tougher spending bill -- which Mr. Clinton vetoed, causing parts of the Government to close. The Speaker, aggrieved that he had to disembark by the back ramp, wails: "Where is their sense of manners? Where is their sense of courtesy?" 
 Nov. 23, 1995: The President tries to make peace by inviting the Speaker to the White House for Thanksgiving. All goes well until Mr. Gingrich spies a demitasse spoon above his plate. Jumping up and throwing down his linen napkin, he cries: "Don't you know that a teaspoon has no place at a formal table? What kind of a rube do you take me for?"
Dec. 20, 1995: Under pressure to end the impasse by Christmas, Mr. Gingrich invites the Clintons to a holiday cocktail party at the Capitol. The merriment ends abruptly when the Speaker confronts the President at the hors d'oeuvre table. "You pathetic vulgarian! Asparagus may be taken in the fingers, but you never take a long drooping stalk, hold it up in the air and catch the end of it in your mouth like a fish. Marianne, get our guests their coats."
PUB-DATE: March 15, 1996:
PUB-DATE: April 7, 1996:
PUB-DATE: June 2, 1996:
Nov. 5, 1996: Elections are canceled after Congress refuses to pass a bill sponsored by Bob Dole providing Federal funds to open polling places. There is dancing in the streets. A furious Senator Dole demands that Mr. Gingrich be tested for emotional intelligence. But the Speaker is squirreled away, working on his new book: "To the Manners Born: How to Treat the Speaker When the Nation's Economy Is at Stake."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 563 words

HEADLINE: How to Soften a Harsh Budget

 BODY:
The Republicans have fulfilled their campaign promise by giving initial approval to a "reconciliation" bill that eliminates the deficit in seven years without gimmicks. The bill, which changes entitlement programs and taxes, is not devoid of merit. For example, it targets two programs popular among Republicans, Medicare and farm subsidies. But the bill is also needlessly harsh and horribly unfair. President Clinton's veto pen is the final defense.
Mr. Clinton has moved toward much of the G.O.P.'s plan -- its seven-year horizon, huge tax cuts, large Medicare cuts and the end of federally guaranteed cash aid to the poor. But the bill goes far beyond anything he has endorsed. It pummels poverty programs and shovels tax cuts to the rich. The President has to draw lines where the G.O.P. has gone too far. Here are five such areas. 
 The Safety Net. Under the bill, Washington would turn over a fixed block of money to states for welfare but no longer pump more money into states experiencing soaring welfare rolls during recession. Sadly, Mr. Clinton will go along. But he must then insist that Congress preserve other parts of the safety net, such as food stamps and Medicaid, for every poor family. Congress could put a cap on, for example, Medicaid spending per recipient. That way, Congress limits its outlays but provides added help to states with rising poverty.
Means-Tested Spending. The G.O.P. would cut spending on food stamps, school lunches, Medicaid, foster care and other programs for the needy by about 25 percent. Yet these programs represent only 13 percent of the Federal budget. Slamming the poor twice as hard as everyone else is unconscionable.
Legal Immigrants. The Republicans would deny legal immigrants Medicaid, food stamps, cash aid and other services for at least five years. Mr. Clinton should insist that sponsors of legal immigrants assume financial responsibility for keeping them off poverty rolls. But if sponsors go bankrupt or die, immigrants should qualify for at least food stamps and Medicaid.
Medicare. The bill invites retirees to leave traditional Medicare to set up -- with Government money -- medical savings accounts, which combine catastrophic coverage with tax-free deposits from which to pay ordinary medical expenses. The bill also loosens the antitrust laws governing voluntary associations of doctors. The combination of these two provisions would be deadly. Doctors would flee traditional Medicare and serve only healthy and wealthy retirees, at inflated prices no one else could afford.
Capital-Gains Taxes. The G.O.P. wants to immunize investors from the impact of inflation, a protection it would not extend to bondholders or anyone else. The bill would also needlessly cut taxes on the sale of old investments. The first provision would wreck the tax code. The second would provide a multibillion-dollar giveaway to wealthy investors. Both warrant a veto.
The Republicans themselves could meet these tests by massively scaling back their tax cut and defense plans. Even if they agreed, however, their budget plan would still be unsatisfactory. It would spend too little on public investments in infrastructure, worker training and research and too much on subsidies to corporations, dairy farmers and other special interests.
But at least with these modifications the bill would be less cruel.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Governor Pataki's Mystery Donors

 BODY:
Politicians can deal with ethics laws in one of two ways. They can use them as guideposts, charting the road to open government. Or they can view them as roadblocks to be skirted with the aid of every possible legal loophole.
Gov. George Pataki is a member of the loophole-loving camp. Mr. Pataki's latest blow to the spirit of New York's campaign finance law involves his glitzy inauguration ceremonies last January in Albany. An extravaganza by the capital's dowdy standards, the event included a laser light show, a black-tie gala, a "people's reception" that fed and entertained thousands and a swearing-in before 13,000 supporters in a sports arena. But now it appears that the state's voters will never get a full accounting of who paid the bills. 
 Mr. Pataki's aides created a private corporation to raise the money. It was headed by Charles Gargano, the campaign finance chairman who is now Commissioner of Economic Development. As an extra-governmental organization, N.Y. Inaugural '95 was not legally obliged to disclose the names of contributors or abide by campaign finance limits of $5,000 per donor. But the Governor's aides vowed that the inaugural committee would do both.
It did neither. An investigation by The Times's James Dao revealed that Mr. Gargano's committee raised about $500,000, with donations as high as $25,000. Most of them came from people who need something from state government -- firms with large state contracts, corporations under heavy state regulation. Their names have never been made public. Late last month, the Governor's representatives dissolved the corporation, just weeks before they would have had to file a report giving information about its operations.
None of the administration's explanations seem plausible. The Governor's spokeswoman claimed the contributors' names were being kept confidential for "ethical reasons," so that state workers would not be tempted to show favoritism toward the donors. But some of the names were listed right on the inaugural program. The inaugural committee had always intended to accept up to $25,000 per corporation, she said. The only mistake occurred when the Governor's staff misunderstood and promised to stick to the limits required under state election laws.
For the voters, the real sadness here arises from the missed opportunity. This Governor came to Albany with a new broom, and he could have chosen to sweep it clean. Instead, Mr. Pataki has endorsed this inaugural dodge, and he continues to condone Mr. Gargano's seedy fund-raising procedures. Mr. Pataki's commissioners are permitted to raise donations, as long as they do not solicit them from businesses that deal directly with their agencies. Of course, the possibilities for ultrafine distinctions and contributor tradeoffs are endless.
With his alarming affinity for business-worse-than-usual, Mr. Pataki is missing a chance to make the Republicans into a party of reform in Albany.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Chinese Schizophrenia

BYLINE: By PHILIP TAUBMAN 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
Ding Fa Zhang, the editor of The Xinmen Evening News, a lively Shanghai tabloid that eschews political coverage, says business is so brisk he hardly knows how to spend the profits. With the paper's ad space booked three months in advance, Mr. Ding has become a construction tycoon, plowing the paper's surplus income into new office buildings.
Leo Yang, a Dale Carnegie instructor and general manager of a Shanghai dairy products company, is developing new ice cream treats for next summer that he hopes can match the popularity of the Crunch Bar, a mixture of ice cream and crushed Oreo cookies that was this year's surprise seller. His manufacturing plant is located in Pudong, a sprawling East Shanghai corporate and industrial zone that just a few years ago was undeveloped farmland. 
 Liu Bo, the executive vice president of the Shanghai Stock Exchange, recently returned from a visit to New York, where he consulted with Wall Street executives on how to increase the trading volume in Shanghai and develop a market for mutual funds. The Shanghai exchange is still recovering from a disastrous collapse in the bond futures market earlier this year.
Shanghai shows all the signs of China's breakneck economic expansion, one of the many boom-or-bust cities driven by Beijing's turn toward market economics. But just under the bustle there is an unsettling reality. Many of the basic building blocks of a modern market economy are still missing. The currency is not yet convertible. The banking system is antiquated and unsound. Financial regulation is largely absent, commercial law is arbitrarily enforced and corruption is rampant.
Most important, China's economic center of gravity is not the stock market or the banks or the hundreds of new companies. It is the Communist Government in Beijing, which is still churning out laborious five-year plans and subsidizing a huge network of unprofitable state enterprises. The system essentially is a command market economy, a schizophrenic formula designed to fuse Communism and capitalism.
The Government's role remains ubiquitous, as Beijing meddles in every area of economic activity. Before Motorola could open a plant to make cellular phones and beepers in Tianjin, the American company needed approval of Government officials in Beijing. If municipal officials in Shanghai want to revise the tax incentives that have attracted business development in Pudong, they need a policy change in Beijing. Even Mr. Ding of The Evening News said he would not ask reporters to investigate police corruption in Shanghai because that would violate journalism standards set in Beijing.
While still heavy, the hand of Government is not always steady. Beijing recently canceled $6 billion in tax rebates promised to export businesses under a value-added tax imposed in 1994. Many companies had counted on the payments to turn a profit this year. The Government has slowed economic reform by abruptly demanding a greater share of provincial tax revenues and more control over the establishment of joint ventures.
China's novel modernization formula has worked so far, producing explosive expansion over the last 15 years. In cities where sleek new buildings crowd the skyline and the ping of beepers and cell phones competes with conversation in elegant restaurants and hotel lobbies, it is easy to forget that China remains a Communist state. But during a visit to Beijing, Tianjin and Shanghai, I could not help wondering whether the advanced case of political sclerosis in China would eventually undermine the country's economic vitality, particularly if an improved standard of living leads to renewed agitation for more freedom and democracy.
The Chinese leadership, for all its economic innovation, remains a fervent keeper of the Communist political faith. Li Zhaoxing, a Vice Foreign Minister, captured the unyielding spirit of several meetings with senior Chinese officials when he explained that China's Constitution protects freedom of speech but not the rights of dissidents. "A citizen is a citizen, a criminal is a criminal," he said with a cold smile. PHILIP TAUBMAN

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL;
Holding That Line, Wailing That Sax

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 18

 BODY:
With both teams relying on the run, it had been a bruising first half, particularly for the linemen, in Friday night's championship game between Wilton and Brien McMahon of Norwalk.
As the gun sounded to end the half before a crowd of about 7,000 at Boyle Stadium at Stamford High School, players from both teams headed for the locker rooms. All, that is, except for Peter Yarusavage, a 250-pound lineman who had played the entire half, which ended with Wilton leading the defending state-championship McMahon team, 7-6. 
 Instead, the 17-year-old Yarusavage ran to his team's bench and deposited his helmet and shoulder pads. Then he ran to the north end zone, where his father, George, met him with a bear hug, and his mother, Colleen, began what has become young Peter's halftime ritual -- a quick change into his band uniform, which includes a jacket, cape, plumed hat, gloves and his sax, but not the striped pants or shoes; his football pants and cleats stay on. Then, Yarusavage hustled over to hook up with the 111-member McMahon marching band for its halftime show.
In an era of the one-way football player, meet a three-way player, Peter Yarusavage, who stars at offensive right guard, defensive left tackle and on the baritone saxophone in the outstanding Brien McMahon High School band. Yarusavage is also a star in the classroom, where, while tackling such subjects as physics, economics, calculus, Spanish and English, he currently has a 3.56 grade-point average.
Playing with the McMahon band at halftime is hardly a respite from playing every down during a football game and, indeed, even playing on every special team, except McMahon kickoffs. And with a team that went 12-0 last year and may qualify for the state tournament again if it beats its intracity rival Norwalk High on Thanksgiving Day, the Senators (the team is named for a late United States Senator, Brien McMahon of Norwalk) do not kick off that often. On Friday night, for example, the band played a spirited eight-minute jazz medley, starting with "Don't Get Around Much Anymore."
When the band's performance ended, the 6-foot Yarusavage again hurried to his mother's side, handed her his sax, doffed his band garb and ran on the field to join his teammates, who were already loosening up for the second half. Neither the lack of rest nor Coach Rob Trifone's halftime talk seemed to have any bearing on Yarusavage, who made a number of tackles in the second half and helped open big holes in the line as McMahon (8-2) came back to win, 19-7, handing Wilton its first loss in 10 games this season.
"I ask the other offensive guard, Sean McGrath, what the coaches said at halftime, so I know what we're supposed to do," said Yarusavage, one of McMahon's four captains. "Is it tiring? I don't think so. It's worked out fine."
Trifone is quite happy to share Yarusavage with the band's director, Tom Miner. They worked out the arrangement along with Yarusavage and his mother.
On Tuesdays and Thursdays, Yarusavage, after two and a half hours of football practice, hurries to the band room at Brien McMahon, where his mother is waiting with dinner at 5 P.M. After eating, he hustles to the parking lot to practice with the band.
On Saturdays, the routine is even more rigorous, particularly when the Senators are playing on the road. Then, Yarusavage practices with the band from 9 to 11:30 A.M. and drives to the game site with his father, since the band does not go on trips, except for special games, such as the Fairfield County championship, which McMahon has won two years in a row.
"And on several Saturdays last year and this year," Miner said, "Peter has driven back to Norwalk from a road game to meet our bus in the parking lot and go off to a competition with us on Saturday nights."
That routine, he said, earned Yarusavage the band's ABCD Award, which stands for Above and Beyond the Call of Duty.
How and why does he do it? "Because I love to play the saxophone, and I love football," he said. "But I guess I have more friends in the band, since I played in the band with a lot of them in middle school, but hadn't played organized football."
How good is Yarusavage?
"Peter is my best lineman, both on offense and defense," Trifone said. "I told him at the beginning that this routine was going to be very trying and that there would be a lot of constraints. But he's very committed and he's handled it very well."

HEADLINE: When Patients Try to Protect Medical Records

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Nov. 15 front-page article on the medical records confidentiality bill reports that some consumer advocates have been advising patients to avoid filing insurance claims even though the services they used were fully covered by their policies. This strategy, the advocates say, will protect sensitive personal information about the patient's health, keeping it out of insurer databases and reducing the risk of its disclosure. 
 Although this advice is well intentioned, it is misguided. I call this strategy the "don't claim-don't tell" strategy. It hurts only the patient; it helps only the insurer. Here's why.
First, by refraining from making a legitimate claim, the patient alone bears the cost of the medical service, instead of the insurer. Although some patients may be able to afford initial treatments for some illnesses or injuries, the need for future treatment and the costs may not be predictable. At some time in the future, these patients may need to rely on their insurance, and all the alleged benefits of concealment will be lost.
More important, the "don't claim-don't tell" strategy is unlikely to protect patient confidentiality. Any secrecy will be short-lived. Even if a claim is not filed, the medical information still exists in the health practitioner's records.
Sooner or later it may be shared with another practitioner, particularly if the trends toward computerization of medical records and integrated health delivery continue.
Most Americans change jobs several times during their work careers -- another trend that is likely to continue in our changing economy. As long as the United States persists in building its health care "system" on private, employer-subsidized insurance, cost-conscious employers will increasingly demand access to employee medical histories.
The information revolution enables employers to gather ever more data on all of us from health care providers and from medical information services to manage the costs of paying for employees' illnesses and those of their families.
When applying for a new job, with a detailed personal health questionnaire to complete, the patient who once engaged in "don't claim-don't tell" faces a painful dilemma.
Should the patient pretend that the illness never existed? Should the patient expect the treating physician to join in this deception? Should the patient simply hope that the prospective employer does not have access to some database, somewhere, that contains this information?
The "don't claim-don't tell" strategy must inevitably backfire sooner or later. And it is the patient (and anyone else on that policy) who suffers when the insurance coverage is refused or sharply limited when any perjury is discovered.
"Don't claim-don't tell" is a desperate, doomed strategy that papers over the underlying problems with our health care "system." What we need is a system in which being ill is a misfortune rather than a dangerous, shameful fact we must conceal lest we lose not only our health but also our benefits and even livelihoods.
 
PAMELA S. GREEN
Lincoln, Mass., Nov. 16, 1995
The writer is a visiting lecturer on law and public health at Harvard.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter
