HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Madison From 50th to 57th Street;
From Hodgepodge to Shopping Corridor

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
TRY this geographic free-association test on New York shoppers: Say Madison Avenue above 57th Street. Then Madison south of 50th Street. Now Madison between 50th and 57th Streets.
The first will probably pull some reference to high-fashion women's clothes selling for astronomical prices. The second usually conjures up visions of well-cut men's suits. And the third phrase generally brings to mind . . . nothing in particular. 
 For some time now, Madison Avenue in the 50's has been a characterless hodgepodge of unrelated stores, filler linking the Rodeo Drive cousin to the north and the Bond Street cousin to the south. The Gap and Gap Kids have been on the stretch for a few years, but unlike in other parts of town -- Third Avenue north of Bloomingdale's being the most notable recent example -- few national chains have rushed to follow.
Talbot's, the New England women's apparel chain, has its flagship New York City store near 54th Street, and Tourneau has had a watch store on 52d Street for decades, but both are upscale anomalies in a patternless area that national retailers have, for the most part, ignored.
Now that is starting to change. Within the last few years, Bostonian Shoes opened on 53d Street, a Coach leather store opened on 57th Street, and The Limited opened an Express store on 51st Street. It was that Express, selling high-fashion to young shoppers in a spot where a variety store stood for years, "that signaled to other retailers that this stretch was now O.K. for fashion uses," said Faith H. Consolo, a senior managing director at the Garrick-Aug brokerage.
New retailers are pouring in. The Nine West Group opened an Enzo Angiolini, its upscale shoe chain, on 55th Street in September, and will open an Easy Spirit -- the shoe-store chain that it recently acquired from U.S. Shoe -- a few doors north next month. Folli Follie, an international jewelry chain, is to open near 56th Street around Thanksgiving. Brokers say that The Limited wants to open other stores on the strip, and that Borders Books is scouring the area.
"The area is turning into a great middle-class, middle-of-the-road retail place, an almost classic Main Street," said Richard Seligman, a senior managing director at the Edward S. Gordon Company brokerage.
Retailers see it that way, too. "Madison has always had high-quality retailing, but the area is becoming positively gentrified," said Robin Bartosh, chief executive of Cosmetics Plus, which has had a store near 53d Street for 15 years.
RENTS are soaring. Spaces that a few years ago went for annual rents of $110 a square foot now command $175 and more (although, as always, solid-credit chains in large spaces pay less). Nor has the steep rise dampened ardor for the area.
"I'm getting a lot of clamor from delis and other food stores who really believe that there is not enough food available to service the waves of traffic that go through here now," said Rob Nager, director of retail leasing at Colliers ABR.
A lot of unrelated reasons are converging to revitalize Madison Avenue's midtown stretch. First, there's the law of supply and demand. Spaces on upper Madison are both expensive and scarce, and rarely large enough to accommodate typical mall retailers. By contrast, bank and airline defections and a few store closings have opened a lot of good, big space below 57th Street.
Dime Savings Bank wants to sublet 5,500 square feet on 54th Street. Sterling National Bank is ready to vacate its branch on 55th Street, if it finds a tenant for the 6,000 square feet of street level space and 8,000 square feet of basement space it occupies. There are about 6,000 square feet of street-level space, and 4,000 square feet of mezzanine space sitting empty on 53d Street, where a furniture store once operated.
Smaller stores, too, are getting easier to find. There are about 1,100 square feet available right next to Tourneau, although several brokers say the watch store may expand into the space. Timothy's New World Coffee, put off by the many coffee bars on surrounding streets, changed its mind about opening a coffee bar in 1,350 square feet it recently leased near 51st Street, and is looking for a subtenant. There is a 350- square-foot slot available near 53d Street.
The big spaces are particularly tempting to national chains, many of which are publicly traded and feel a need to show constant expansion to shareholders. Most of them have already saturated the available shopping malls that have been their metier, and have been forced to turn to urban locations. In New York, there are fewer and fewer of those locations around.
"Retail space is getting tight all over the city, so of course tenants go where stores are available," said Edward A. Friedman, president of Newmark Retail Services.
And the pedestrian traffic on the avenue keeps increasing. The area's office buildings, many of which had huge vacancy rates during the last recession, are filling up again, spewing forth more lunchtime and after-work shoppers. And the recent vibrancy in the hotel business has caused the area to fill up on weekends and evenings, too.
The pricey Four Seasons hotel, which opened on 57th Street in 1993, and the revved up Palace Hotel, the 50th Street hotel that the Sultan of Brunei bought from the Helmsley family that same year, have brought many international tourists and business people to the area. The Omni Berkshire hotel at 52d Street, which reopened a few months ago after a one-year overhaul, and the soon-to-be-renovated Roosevelt Hotel at 45th Street, promise to bring even more.
"Our weekend sales have been flat since the Omni closed, but we really expect its reopening to give us back our Saturday and Sunday tourist business," said Mr. Bartosh of Cosmetics Plus.
The area's retail newcomers come with simiarly high expectations. "Maybe three years ago this wouldn't have been the perfect location for us, but today it sure is," said Myrvet Ben-Abdallah, chief financial officer of Madison Jewels, Folli Follie's American distributor. "Now we can capitalize on the brand recognition we have with the Europeans and the Japanese."
New Yorkers, too, have more reason to visit the stretch on weekends. There is Sony Plaza, the glitzy group of shops and attractions in the street-level part of the Sony building at 55th Street, which Sony is in the process of fine-tuning. And next year the Freedom Forum's Center for Media Studies will be opening a museum of news, as well as holding numerous meetings and seminars, in the retail space in the I.B.M. building a block north of Sony.
The activity has caused several retailers to move Madison Avenue higher on their priority lists. "The changes we've been seeing made us move here quicker than we might have," said Brenda Wurtz, 9 West's senior vice president of real estate and store planning. "We always go after spaces where we see potential, and we see a lot happening on Madison both now and in the future."
IN a sense, Madison Avenue retailing is finally turning into what developers had originally envisioned it to be. Back in the 80's, when the Sony building (then the AT&T building), the I.B.M. building, and several other nearby Madison Avenue towers first went up, many of the building owners were hyping their locations as the new alternative to Fifth Avenue, and asking for annual rents of well over $200 a square foot.
"They kept telling investors and brokers that their spaces were perfect for chic, upscale stores because they were but a block away from Fifth," recalled Michael N. Hirschfeld, who heads his own brokerage company. "No one realized that, in retailing, a block away can be Death Valley."
The realization quickly hit home. Mr. Hirschfeld remembers numerous stores, including a French sportswear store and a Korean handbag shop, that came in, paying annual rents of as much as $275 a square foot. They quickly closed, unable to survive at those rents. Slowly at first -- then precipitately when the recession hit in the late '80s -- the rents came down, and food shops, card stores, drugstores and others aimed at servicing the local office workers moved in.
There are still plenty of stationery stores, eyeglass stores and the like dotting the area and catering almost entirely to the office crowd. But, brokers and retailers say, the "feel" of the area is changing rapidly.
"It used to just feel like a place with a mix of stores," Ms. Consolo said. "Now it's getting the feel of a real shopping corridor."
 The article should have verified the account with New World, or attributed the information to the brokers who provided it. A lawyer for New World says that the company had terminated the lease and was not seeking subtenants, and that concern about competition was not a factor. The matter is now in litigation.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 17, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Commercial Property column in the Real Estate Section on Nov. 19 discussed changes in retailing on Madison Avenue. It included a brief reference to space that had been leased for a coffee bar on 51st Street. The article misidentified the concern that had leased the space. It was New World Coffee, not Timothy's New World Coffee. The article said that New World had decided against opening at the 51st Street location and was seeking subtenants for the space because of the number of other coffee bars nearby.

HEADLINE: State Invites Public's Ideas on I-287 Bottleneck

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
LIKE the irate tempers of commuters, the rhetoric is heating up over proposals to ease traffic congestion along Interstate 287. Increasingly, as a public hearing on the matter nears, the battle lines are being drawn between environmental groups opposing further expansion of the busy east-west corridor and the business community, which wants better ways to bring more workers, travelers and shoppers to White Plains and its environs.
The Cross Westchester Expressway, as I-287 is also known, cuts a broad swath through the county just north of White Plains, forming one of the most heavily traveled corridors in southern New York State. 
 Built more than 30 years ago, shortly after completion of the Tappan Zee Bridge, the six-lane highway connects the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway (Interstate 87) with the New England Thruway (Interstate 95) -- and carries 100,000 vehicles a day. With the recent completion of I-287 in northern New Jersey, the road has picked up additional truck traffic and become part of a major suburban beltway.
As the populations of nearby Dutchess, Putnam, Rockland and Orange Counties have grown and more major businesses have located along the expressway, the problems have increased. On better days during rush hour, vehicles inch along at 30 miles an hour. Often, they are at a standstill. Also, the accident rate has steadily risen and now exceeds statewide averages for similar roads.
At the Dec. 6 hearing, the State Department of Transportation will officially unveil plans to the public to spend up to $365 million to improve conditions on 14 miles of the interstate from Route 303 west of the Tappan Zee Bridge to I-95. Although transportation officials support plans for a high-occupancy-vehicle lane to move traffic more quickly, they say they are eager to please and remain open to suggestions.
"There's nothing Machiavellian about our motives," said Richard A. Peters, regional planning and program manager for the Department of Transportation. "We could take the do-nothing approach, rehabilitate the six lanes that are there, add another lane each way or add a reversible H.O.V. lane. Our goal is to provide safe, economical and efficient transportation for the people of New York. We're all heading for the same place. We're just disagreeing sometimes on how to get there."
As for the environmentalists, they favor the do-nothing approach, asserting that bigger roads bring more traffic, generate more air pollution and invade what little open space is left. They support increased reliance on mass-transit alternatives.
"If you build, people and businesses will come, and that's how we got to this gridlock situation to begin with," said Maureen M. Morgan, president of Federated Conservationists of Westchester, a 30-year-old network of 70 environmental organizations.
Meanwhile, those representing business interests said they would like to expand the road. They see an office-vacancy rate as high as 30 percent in downtown White Plains and in industrial parks along the interstate.
"It's absurd to say you want to fill up that office space and at the same time limit road development," said Frank Ronnenberg, executive director of the Westchester Transportation Management Organization, a state and county partnership formed three years ago to study transportation issues.
Those opposing expansion of the road, like James T. B. Tripp, general counsel for the Environmental Defense Fund, a national advocacy group, say that additional capacity will not solve congestion problems or benefit business.
"Typically, what happens is that billions are spent to expand a highway, only to induce businesses and people to develop along it," Mr. Tripp said. "Some see road development as a way to promote economic revitalization, but it also may have the opposite effect in the long run, because it can encourage sprawl. It can enable businesses to move farther away."
The environmentalists, like Mr. Tripp and Ms. Morgan, support the development of more mass transit in Westchester and Rockland Counties and the use of discounts for travelers who cross the Tappan Zee Bridge at off-peak hours, a policy known as congestion pricing.
The high-occupancy lanes are not practical, Ms. Morgan recently said, claiming that few people would chose to car pool to work.
"There are too many disadvantages," she said. "People talk too much, or they talk too little, or they rattle their newspapers. For most commuters, a car pool is too much of a close situation.
"The ads say, 'I spend half of my life in the car.' But, my God, who in their right mind would want to? What we need is more and better mass transit."
Mr. Ronnenberg, representing business interests, agreed that mass transit could prove to be the best alternative for many commuters. His organization, which is financed in part by the Federal Highway Administration, has encouraged more bus service on the county-operated Bee-Line System's routes. It has also supported three shuttles that pick up train travelers in White Plains and transport them to office parks on Route 287.
In compliance with the Federal Clean Air Act, the organization has completed transportation surveys with employees at 315 work sites in the county and conducts workshops to inform commuters of mass transit options.
Although the Westchester Transportation Management Organization is opposed to high-occupancy lanes -- "They serve too small a group for too short a distance," Mr. Ronnenberg said -- the group backs expansion of I-287 to eight lanes.
"There is the reality of lots of empty office space along the corridor, and so we need to look at the situation from all points of view," he said.
The American Automobile Association will also be represented at the hearing, and it is also supporting expansion of the expressway.
"Retaining only six lanes will basically suffocate Westchester over time," said Mark Kulewicz, a traffic engineer for the motorists' advocacy organization.
Also, he said that Westchester's severe ozone problem, determined by Federal air-quality standards, was being exacerbated by stop-and-start traffic on I-287.
The automobile association also opposes congestion pricing on the Tappan Zee Bridge. Mr. Kulewicz said such a policy had met strong opposition from commuters using the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge in California. "Quite simply," he said, "the public did not want to be charged more to get to work."
He added: "Let's face it. The automobile is the most convenient way to travel. And if you make it too difficult for people to go to one place, they will go to another that is more convenient. White Plains and Harrison will lose out."
But Paul J. Feiner, Town Supervisor of Greenburgh, said he didn't buy Mr. Kulewicz's arguments.
"I-287 doesn't do a thing for Westchester," said the Supervisor, who argued that truck drivers and travelers rarely stop on their way to other destinations. "The state should be fixing problems on the road, not causing more problems."
Mayor Sy J. Schulman of White Plains, however, said he favored widening the road and even including a high-occupancy lane in the plans to benefit business development. "We don't want to choke off the future," he said.
The State Department of Transportation is projecting that the number of vehicles will continue to increase along I-287 -- from 100,000 now to 170,000 a day by the year 2021. According to projections, if no roadway improvements are made, in 30 years, traffic will practically be brought to a halt for three hours or more during peak periods.
Under the department's "no-build alternative," the state would make only spot improvements to correct structural deficiencies in the road and overpasses but would not address congestion and safety.
Under another proposal to be aired at the hearing, the state would correct safety and operational problems. A concrete median barrier would be placed in the center of the expressway, and several acceleration and deceleration lanes would be lengthened. Also, most of the bridges would be rehabilitated or replaced.
The eight-lane plan calls for four 12-foot-wide lanes in each direction.
The purpose of the high-occupancy-vehicle plan, the state said, is to encourage more use of car pools, buses and vans and "move more people in fewer vehicles."
The Dec. 6 public hearing will begin at 4:30 P.M. at the County Center in White Plains.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 14; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1155 words

HEADLINE: Giving Small Businesses Keys to Success

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
THERE are those who work from 9 to 5 and there are those who work from 5 to 9 and the difference between them, Lloyd Shefsky said, is that those in the 5 to 9 category are working for themselves.
"Only they get to decide if 5 to 9 means 4 hours of work or 16 or anything in between," Mr. Shefsky said. "I know entrepreneurs who have succeeded by working four hours a day and made a fortune. But when they worked, they were so passionate about what they were doing that no matter what it took them to do, they'd do it." 
 Mr. Shefsky heads a Chicago law firm that specializes in advising entrepreneurs. He also is the author of the book "Entrepreneurs Are Made Not Born" (McGraw Hill). He appeared here recently as one of the speakers at an entrepreneur conference and workshop co-sponsored by the Entrepreneurial Center in Purchase, Citibank and the Westchester/Fairfield County Business Journal, which was held in Reid Castle at Manhattanville College.
As for the other conference speakers, Tim and Nina Zagat, publishers of the Zagat Surveys, Ruth Henderson, owner of the Silo, a cooking school in New Milford, and Spencer Putnam, chief operating officer of the Vermont Teddy Bear Company, they all agreed that one trait successful entrepreneurs have in common is passion for their venture.
"Passion is absolutely essential, it is important to choose something you love to do," Mr. Zagat said. "If you don't, you won't do all the extra things people do to make their dreams work and chances are the venture won't succeed."
The 147 conference participants who paid $149 to attend were mainly those who had already started businesses, said Marge Lovero, president of the Entrepreneurial Center.
"This was our ninth entrepreneurial conference, and I was struck with the way things have changed over the years," she said. "People came from New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania to the conference and we had fewer start-ups. The participants were older and more men than women were in attendance. Many of them were former executives embarked on second or third careers. Others were established small-business owners who were looking for ways to grow their businesses."
The first conferences were held at Manhattanville College, Ms. Lovero said, when Manhattanville was an all-women school and the conference participants were all women.
"That was the time when opportunities for corporate careers were unlimited," she said. "It was not the era of the entrepreneur and information on entrepreneurship was scarce. We were one of the first to recognize that people who wanted to know how to become entrepreneurs needed a place to learn how to take the initial step."
In 1992, the entrepreneurial center expanded so well that it left the college to set up as a nonprofit organization with headquarters at 100 Manhattanville Road in Purchase, the former Nestle Building.
"We took our own advice and grew our business so successfully that we now have 50 teachers who give on-site training in entrepreneurship to employees of Fortune 500 companies," Ms. Lovero said. "We teach employees of large corporations how to take ownership responsibility. When they do that they change their mindset and become more effective employees." The fear of failure, Ms. Lovero pointed out, is the No. 1 barrier stopping would-be entrepreneurs in their tracks.
"That was true nine years ago at our first conference, and it is true today," she said. "So when Spencer Putnam told the participants at the conference how they turn their failures into a learning experience, the audience really took heart."
The focus of the most recent conference was on marketing. Participants have the chance to attend various workshops dealing with subjects like targeting your market, financing your marketing efforts and the legal aspects of marketing.
Small businesses, Ms. Lovero said, are called the engines of the economy because today about 20 million of them are in existence.
"Entrepreneurs create opportunities for others," said John Geils, who, with his son William, owns Wina Products in Fairfield, manufacturers of products for the pet market. The Geilses were at the conference, said John Geils, in order to seek ways to make their year-old business grow.
"We know we have unique products, one we call Dander-Seal controls pet allergies and seals and controls pet dander," William Geils said. "And it's nontoxic and keeps the house allergy free . But we need advice in marketing, and we are getting it here."
Debra C. Weissman, another conference participant, said this is the best time to be an entrepreneur. "Especially in the health-care field, which is changing as we speak," said Ms. Weissman, who was on her way to a workshop on breakthrough marketing strategies. "I have a medical and dental practice management-consulting business in White Plains, and I started in business by showing doctors and dentists how to run their practices on a business-like basis," she said. "I used to work at a very good job at a major hospital in Manhattan, but I realized that there was a job ceiling that I kept bumping into. As an entrepreneur, I feel the sky's the limit."
Barbara F. Hibbert is a former corporate executive who spent 23 years training employees at I.B.M. Ms. Hibbert is now using the skills she honed at International Business Machines to build her own company. As an entrepreneur, she is not only training employees for clients, but has become a meeting planner as well. "I work hard, I travel a lot and do you know what?" she said, "I love being my own boss."
Cynthia Ehrenkrantz is no novice business owner. She has run her fine-food and confectionary brokerage in White Plains for 11 years. But Ms. Ehrenkrantz said she came to the conference "because I am looking for advice on how to take my business to the next level." "I know I am ready to expand," she continued, "and the workshops that deal with marketing, especially financing marketing efforts and marketing with a competitive edge I think will be extremely useful to me."
Marilyn R. Zuckerman, the manager of A.T.&T. corporate quality office, presided over a workshop called "Marketing Quality or Else." She was there, Ms. Zuckerman explained, because big business also needs expertise in developing entrepreneurship.
"The same things that drive entrepreneurs are necessary in big business today," she said. "That is the willingness to put in long hours, the ability to listen to customers and supply them with what they want. These are essential today if companies are going to thrive. Look at start-up companies, that's where the cutting-edge ideas come from."
As for Mr. Shefsky's definition of an entrepreneur -- "someone who enters a business before the nerve system or core is established and who conceives an idea and gathers the sources to create and develop it into a successful venture" -- the conference attendees agreed it was apt.
